headline: No More Statutes of Limitations for Rape
abstract: Bill Cosby came close to escaping sexual assault charges. How many others do?
lead_paragraph: THIS week, Bill Cosby was charged with three counts of aggravated indecent assault. The felony charges stemmed from an incident more than a decade ago, in which Andrea Constand says Mr. Cosby drugged and assaulted her in his home. Mr. Cosby says he intends to fight the charges, and no court has found him liable for sexual misconduct.

headline: Freddie Gray Complained of ‘Bad Back’ Before Arrest, Filing Says
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A court document made public on Thursday suggests that defense lawyers will argue that Mr. Gray was already injured when he was loaded into a Baltimore police van.
lead_paragraph: Freddie Gray, the 25-year-old black man who died of a broken neck after he was taken into police custody in Baltimore, complained of back trouble less than two weeks before that encounter, according to a document filed in court by defense lawyers for a police officer charged with murder in his death.

headline: Justice in Taxes, Most Likely Short-Lived

headline: No. 1 Clemson Advances to National Championship Game
abstract: Led by quarterback Deshaun Watson, the Tigers defeated fourth-seeded Oklahoma in the first College Football Playoff semifinal.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — No. 1 Clemson rose to prominence this season largely behind its offense and quarterback Deshaun Watson, who finished third in the Heisman Trophy voting. The Orange Bowl between the Tigers and No. 4 Oklahoma featured the best two quarterbacks in college football — Watson and Baker Mayfield — but the Tigers’ defense essentially ended the comparison.

headline: Ackman Sheds Some Valeant Shares
abstract: William Ackman’s hedge fund said in a regulatory filing that its stake was now 8.5 percent, down from 9.9 percent, of the drug company that has been drawing fire on several fronts.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund of William A. Ackman said on Thursday that it had sold some of its shares in Valeant Pharmaceuticals, the embattled drug company that Mr. Ackman earlier this year went to considerable lengths to defend.

headline: Howard Davis Jr., Who Beat Grief to Win Boxing Gold, Dies at 59
abstract: Davis, who was mourning his mother when he earned a gold medal at the 1976 Montreal Olympics, had more than 100 victories as an amateur but never won a world title.
lead_paragraph: Howard Davis Jr., a boxer from Long Island who in 1976 won an Olympic gold medal and also received the Val Barker Trophy, awarded to the most outstanding Olympic fighter, over his teammates and fellow gold medalists Michael and Leon Spinks and Sugar Ray Leonard, died on Wednesday at his home in Plantation, Fla. He was 59.

headline: Flooding in Missouri Raises Vexing Questions
abstract: Can greater defenses be erected? Should homes be vaulted on stilts? Or is it time for some communities to pack up and leave?
lead_paragraph: ARNOLD, Mo. — Linda Thorne peered out the back of her trailer near here on Monday night to find water sloshing up the wooden steps.

headline: As Brooklyn Park Stalls, Fingers Point at Religious Group
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Depending on whom you ask, the fault for the state of Bridge Park 2 lies with flawed zoning, communication breakdowns or the Jehovah’s Witnesses, who promised to fix it but never did.
lead_paragraph: There is little to indicate that the misshapen expanse of concrete, bounded by a chain-link fence and at times dusted with crumbling pieces of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway that runs alongside it is, in fact, a city park. A few thousand feet west is one of New York’s glossiest green esplanades, the sprawling Brooklyn Bridge Park, alongside the East River in the same Dumbo neighborhood. But here, the only clue that the lot is not a car park or a stalled construction site is the green parks department sign proclaiming Bridge Park 2.

headline: Why Fans Stand by Perennial Losers
abstract: If a sports team rarely wins, why do some fans doggedly support it? Academics try to unravel the psychological quagmire.
lead_paragraph: Although they advanced to the World Series in October, the Mets last won a championship in 1986. For some fans, the vigor surrounding that team still has not worn off.

headline: Chris Mullin Sees Mixed Signs in St. John’s Loss
abstract: The Red Storm dropped their Big East Conference opener on Thursday. Still Mullin, the St. John’s basketball legend turned first-year coach, sees signs of improvement.
lead_paragraph: With six seconds left in yet another loss, Chris Mullin, the St. John’s basketball legend turned first-year coach, sprang out of his seat and grimly trudged down the sideline to where Creighton Coach Greg McDermott stood. The two shook hands as the final buzzer sounded.

headline: Experts Foresee Obstacles for Both Sides in Bill Cosby Case
abstract: Legal experts said the road to conviction was filled with significant hurdles, including a lack of forensic evidence related to the decade-old allegation by the woman at the center of the case.
lead_paragraph: For years, as Bill Cosby and his lawyers aggressively rebutted accusations that he was a sexual predator, his defenders could point to one incontrovertible fact: He had never been charged with a crime.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Hugo Galindo had planned to watch the ball drop in Times Square. But early Thursday morning, he was beaten and stabbed just blocks from his home.
lead_paragraph: Hugo Galindo had been scheduled to work at a private party at a restaurant on New Year’s Eve, but he was looking forward to it nonetheless. He and a cousin, both food runners at a Times Square restaurant, planned to climb to the roof just before the stroke of midnight, the cousin said, and watch the storied ball drop.

headline: Privilege, Pathology and Power
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Editorials', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The superrich live in their own reality. That’s a problem when the monstrously self-centered influence elections and policy.
lead_paragraph: Wealth can be bad for your soul. That’s not just a hoary piece of folk wisdom; it’s a conclusion from serious social science, confirmed by statistical analysis and experiment. The affluent are, on average, less likely to exhibit empathy, less likely to respect norms and even laws, more likely to cheat, than those occupying lower rungs on the economic ladder.

headline: A Lingering Taste
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Grandparents', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Recalling the wait for a favorite dish and a life away from the war.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, while my parents traveled to the United States to assess a possible life there, they rented a chalet in the Lebanese coastal town Jounieh and left us in the care of my maternal grandmother. It was a thrilling summer for me. More than any of my siblings, I was tired of the war in Lebanon, which had been going strong for almost a decade. I was particularly fed up with living in constant fear — from the shellings, the sniper attacks, the bombings, the checkpoints, the kidnappings and the threats directed at my Palestinian-born parents, who met and married in Beirut. I spent much of my time daydreaming about a new, perfect and utterly ‘‘normal’’ life in America.

headline: How to Listen to a Police Scanner
abstract: Ignore mundane calls. Notice the circadian rhythms of crime where you live.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Don’t buy special equipment,’’ says Tom Coleman, who has been listening to Chicago police- and fire-radio communications 24 hours a day for eight years. (He says he has mastered the skill of ‘‘half listening’’ in his sleep.) Find the department feed you want at broadcastify.com or on a smartphone app like 5-0 Radio Police Scanner. Though Coleman himself owns a $600 scanner, he mostly tunes in online.

headline: Pope Francis Urges Overcoming ‘Indifference’ to Attain Peace
abstract: In his first message of 2016, he said that apathy “creates barriers, suspicions, fears and closure,” and he called on people to open their hearts to the needs of others.
lead_paragraph: In his first message of 2016, Pope Francis summoned humanity to show compassion and to transcend the apathy that impedes peace in a world that has been filled of late with conflict and suffering.

headline: The Year the Studios Get It Right
abstract: Blockbusters like “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” and “Mad Max: Fury Road” delivered much of the year’s best cinema and ought to be up for Oscars. Wait, what?
lead_paragraph: In February, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will consecrate a best picture, most likely choosing from among a roster of respectable, serious dramas. A few early favorites have already faded — does anyone remember “The Walk” or “Everest”? “Sicario” or “Black Mass”? — but the field of Oscar movies is crowded with aspirants. Meanwhile, movie audiences have had other ideas, driving box-office totals to record heights with their enthusiasm for reanimated dinosaurs, romantic trainwrecks and galactic battles. Popularity is not the same as quality, of course, but 2015 was a year when a lot of the best cinematic art could be found at the multiplex, amid the sequels and blockbusters.

headline: Atlanta Begins Charging for a Streetcar Named Undesirable by Some
abstract: In the streetcar system’s first year, residents often described it as somewhere between disastrous and vaguely satisfactory. And that was when it was free.

headline: 1916: Hundreds Sink With the Persia
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A steamship for Bombay is torpedoed in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Admiralty announces that the P. and O. line steamship Persia, 7,974 tons, which left London for Bombay, was torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine on Thursday [Dec. 30]. The vessel carried 300 crew and 235 passengers, including 86 women and 30 children, and as only four boatloads escaped, it is feared that this culmination of the wholesale slaughter of innocents in 1915 by enemy submarines is only eclipsed in horror by the sinking of the Lusitania on May 7, when the sea-murderers sent 1,198 innocent persons, including hundreds of Americans, to a watery grave.

His father, a leader of the local Red Guards, emerged with his spirit broken by what he saw and did.

headline: Gunman Kills 2 in Tel Aviv in Attack on a Busy Street

The assault created mayhem along a busy street and led to an intense manhunt by the authorities. The suspect was still at large late Friday.

headline: 1941: Air Line Keeps Rome-Rio Link
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An Italian-owned airline keeps flying to South America in 1941.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — L.A.T.I., the Italian owned and operated air line which is the only trans-Atlantic link between the Rome-Berlin Axis and the Western Hemisphere, completed its first year of operations today [Dec. 23]. In spite of the war in Europe, it is still making weekly flights with land planes between Rome and Rio de Janeiro. It is an important line, for by it the Axis reaches South American countries and the United States without running the risk of confiscation or censorship at a British control station.

headline: Robert Irwin’s Big Visions, Barely Seen

headline: Obama to Consider Executive Actions on Gun Violence
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: President Obama will meet with Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch on Monday to discuss what he can do to curb gun violence, sidestepping an entrenched Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will meet with Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch on Monday to discuss what he can do to curb gun violence, sidestepping an entrenched Congress.

headline: Happy New Year!
abstract: Peas and mustard greens, pizza dough, Alfred Lord Tennyson and more recipes for the New Year.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Think Seriously About Spending for Play
abstract: Deliberate planning for leisure, concentrating on activities that refresh and reinvigorate, may actually mean more fun for less money.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you keep a budget. If you do, perhaps you have entries for travel or even specific entries for your hobbies.

headline: How Jeb Bush Hopes to Save His Candidacy
abstract: Rival campaigns seem to be counting him out, but Mr. Bush’s allies have a long-shot plan they hope will win him the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: HIALEAH, Fla. — Jeb Bush and his supporters still have a pile of money to spend, remnants of $100 million raised when he seemed early last year to be a sure bet. They have an expansive ground operation in New Hampshire. And allies have just begun a new ad campaign in Iowa.

headline: Dayo Okeniyi, Getting Comfortable Wearing a Badge
abstract: In the new NBC drama “Shades of Blue,” Mr. Okeniyi plays a rookie New York City detective who makes a deadly mistake on a drug bust.
lead_paragraph: In the new NBC drama “Shades of Blue,” Dayo Okeniyi plays Michael Loman, a rookie New York City detective who makes a deadly mistake on a drug bust with Harlee Santos, a detective played by Jennifer Lopez. The show, which has its premiere on Thursday, Jan. 7, centers on a tight-knit unit, led by Matt Wozniak (Ray Liotta), whose members sometimes step outside the law to protect their own. But loyalties are tested when Santos is ensnared in an F.B.I. investigation and reluctantly becomes an informant.

headline: Gina DePalma, Acclaimed Pastry Chef at Babbo, Dies at 49
abstract: Ms. DePalma, a chef who prized flavor above eye appeal, helped make Babbo one of Manhattan’s most beloved and admired restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Gina DePalma, a pastry chef whose artfully simple Italian desserts helped make Babbo in Greenwich Village one of Manhattan’s most beloved and admired restaurants, died on Tuesday at a hospice in the Bronx. She was 49.

headline: Taliban Attack Kabul Restaurant, Setting Off Shootout
abstract: The first attack of the new year began with a bomb blast at the restaurant, in a neighborhood where many foreigners live. A 12-year-old boy was killed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban launched their first attack of the new year by setting off a bomb on Friday at a French restaurant in Kabul once popular with foreigners, and gunmen then engaged in a protracted shootout with the police.

headline: At the Gym, Abs and Stats
abstract: On the heels of Soul Cycle comes Orangetheory, with no mysticism but with monitors that broadcast your performance to the whole class.
lead_paragraph: In New York, gyms, commitments to which swell every January before being forgotten by Presidents’ Day, can trace their history to a man named Friedrich Ludwig Jahn, who began teaching outdoor athletics classes in Berlin early in the 19th century. Jahn taught gymnastics on devices of his own invention: balance beams, parallel bars and so on.

headline: Turkey Says Hitler Comment by President Erdogan Was ‘Distorted’
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who seeks to imbue his largely ceremonial office with sweeping powers, had cited Hitler when asked whether a strong presidency was possible in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey issued a statement on Friday saying that comments by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan — in which he cited Hitler in response to a question about whether a strong presidency was possible in Turkey — had been misinterpreted.

headline: New York Discovers Keyless Entry Systems
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Locks and Keys', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Smart locks and their associated apps allow owners, tenants and landlords to remotely allow access to homes and to track who comes and goes.
lead_paragraph: In the next few months, residents at a handful of buildings in the city will be able to walk up to their apartment doors and go inside without fumbling for keys. And if the dog walker or cleaning service comes by while they are out, residents can use an app to let them in remotely. Ditto for deliveries.

headline: What I Love | Tim Blake Nelson
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Home for the actor is the Upper West Side. Lately, he’s been walking to work: His film, “Anesthesia” was shot in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Home for the actor is the Upper West Side. Lately, he’s been walking to work: His film, “Anesthesia” was shot in the neighborhood.

headline: Tim Blake Nelson on the Upper West Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The actor and writer-director of “Anesthesia,” a new film, lives with his wife, Lisa Benavides-Nelson, and sons.
lead_paragraph: Tim Blake Nelson is happiest when his household runs like clockwork.

abstract: This weeks properties are in Greenwich Village, Chelsea and Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This weeks properties are in Greenwich Village, Chelsea and Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: This week’s homes include a seven-bedroom Victorian in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Fairfield, Conn.

abstract: This week’s homes include a seven-bedroom Victorian in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Fairfield, Conn.

headline: For $30.5 Million, Fifth Avenue and Facing the Park
abstract: A grand park-facing apartment at the exclusive co-op building at 834 Fifth Avenue is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, J. Tomilson Hill, and his wife, Janine Hill, paid $30,500,000 for a grand park-facing apartment at 834 Fifth Avenue, the majestic 16-story limestone building designed by Rosario Candela, where just last spring a sale set a record for city co-ops. It was the most expensive completed sale of the week, according to public records.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 17: Rankings and Matchups
abstract: The fantasy football season is over for many, but for those still playing, here are a few players we like in Week 17.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 17. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 17 player rankings.

headline: Natalie Cole, ‘Unforgettable’ Voice and Million-Selling Hitmaker, Dies at 65
abstract: Ms. Cole was a Grammy winner whose biggest hit was “Unforgettable,” a virtual duet with her father, Nat King Cole, that topped the 1991 charts.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Cole, a buoyantly jazzy singer who became a million-selling, Grammy Award-winning pop hitmaker with her 1975 debut album and went on to even greater popularity when she followed the example of her father, Nat King Cole, in interpreting pre-rock pop standards, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 65.

headline: Dallas Stars Visit New York, and They’re Bringing a Defense
abstract: The high-scoring Stars, who will play the three metropolitan area N.H.L. teams in the next four days, have dropped their goals-allowed average to 2.46 a game from 3.13 last season.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — With an explosive offense and aspirations for the N.H.L. playoffs, the Dallas Stars convened for training camp understanding that the dirty work of defense needed to be addressed.

headline: Hillary Clinton Raised $37 Million in Last 3 Months
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign raised $37 million in the three-month period that ended Dec. 31, bringing her total war chest for use in the Democratic presidential contest to more than $112 million.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign raised $37 million in the three-month period that ended Dec. 31, filling the war chest of a campaign that has pulled in more than $112 million overall for the Democratic contest, her campaign said Friday.

headline: S.M.U., With No Titles to Shoot For, Remains Undefeated
abstract: Coach Larry Brown’s Southern Methodist University men’s basketball team is 12-0 but ineligible for postseason play this season.
lead_paragraph: Only three undefeated teams remain in Division I men’s college basketball. One is Oklahoma, the No. 3 team in the country and a candidate for this year’s national title. No. 24 South Carolina is also unbeaten, and is bidding for its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance since 2004.

headline: Before Ball Dropped, So Did Viewership of College Football Playoff Semifinals
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Television', 'College Football Playoff National Championship', 'Orange Bowl (Football Game)', 'Sugar Bowl']
abstract: ESPN paid a price for the semifinals’ move to New Year’s Eve this season, with ratings for each game down by more than a third from last season.
lead_paragraph: Viewership for Thursday’s two College Football Playoff semifinal games was down drastically when compared with last season, a clear indication that ESPN paid a price for the games’ move to New Year’s Eve.

headline: App Makers Reach Out to the Teenager on Mobile
keywords: ['Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: One app’s effort to understand its teenage audience illuminates the habits of a generation that is constantly connected and often anxious.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, advertisers have spent untold millions trying to turn Talia Kocar and her peers in the millennial generation into loyal customers. But on a recent afternoon in Santa Monica, Calif., in a kind of consumer torch-passing, Ms. Kocar, 25, watched a focus group of teenagers drink free Snapple and suck Doritos powder off their thumbs while answering questions about their smartphones.

headline: Taking Flight
abstract: If the Jets win at Buffalo on Sunday, they will clinch an A.F.C. wild-card berth. Ben Shpigel breaks down the key moments that have led the Jets to the brink of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: If the Jets win at Buffalo on Sunday, they will clinch an A.F.C. wild-card berth. Ben Shpigel breaks down the key moments that have led the Jets to the brink of the playoffs.

headline: Eagles Snapper Used Magic to Fix Shattered Childhood
abstract: After Jon Dorenbos’s father murdered his mother when he was 12, he got his life back on track through football and the help of an aunt, but mostly through magic.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Soon after Jon Dorenbos’s mother was murdered by his father, he moved in with his aunt and returned to his hometown for a Little League all-star game where he witnessed his first magic show. Today, Dorenbos, the Philadelphia Eagles’ long snapper, says that 30-minute experience helped turn around his life.

headline: Rules for Instagram
abstract: Leila Khan and Lucy Nemerov, two eighth graders from Palo Alto, Calif., and their friends explain why they delete their Instagram photos.
lead_paragraph: Leila Khan and Lucy Nemerov, two eighth graders from Palo Alto, Calif., and their friends explain why they delete their Instagram photos.

headline: Want to Keep New Year’s Resolutions? Consider the Consequences of Failing
abstract: The best chance of succeeding at your goal is when you have an incentive — like a financial, social or health cost — not to fail, experts say.
lead_paragraph: THE New Year’s resolutions are still new. And a cynic — or realist, given past performance — might say many of them will fail by spring, if not sooner.

headline: With Win After Win, Tigers Leave ‘Clemsoning’ in Their Past
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Orange Bowl (Football Game)', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: The term, which once haunted Clemson’s football program, may no longer apply to the unbeaten Tigers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — As Clemson pulled away from Oklahoma in the second half of the Orange Bowl on Thursday night, the former Tigers quarterback Tajh Boyd made his way down to watch the end of the game from the sideline. For the last few years, Boyd, the Tigers’ starter from 2011 to 2013, had been hanging around the program, both to mentor players and to watch it grow in prominence.

headline: At C.D.C., a Debate Behind Recommendations on Cellphone Risk
abstract: While consensus holds that there is little to no evidence linking cellphone use to an increased risk of health problems, scientists and health agencies disagree about what guidance to give the public.
lead_paragraph: When the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published new guidelines 18 months ago regarding the radiation risk from cellphones, it used unusually bold language on the topic for the American health agency: “We recommend caution in cellphone use.”

headline: Older Students Learn for the Sake of Learning
abstract: Many retirees, not trying to earn degrees, participate in programs like the Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes, which are affiliated mostly with colleges and universities.
lead_paragraph: JOSH AND SUSAN FRIED attend classes three days a week but they never receive any grades or cram for midterms or finals. They are not trying to earn an additional degree or retrain for a new career.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Carolyn Ryan, Jennifer Steinhauer and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Looking Beyond the Internet of Things
abstract: Adam Bosworth, a tech pioneer, sees the future in servers that manage and learn from data gathered by sensors implanted in practically everything.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you have sent email on Google or used Microsoft’s browser or databases, you have touched the technology handiwork of Adam Bosworth.

headline: New York Wants Fantasy Customers Repaid
abstract: The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, wants FanDuel and DraftKings to give back the millions of dollars they have made in the state and pay a penalty.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general wants the two largest daily fantasy sports companies, FanDuel and DraftKings, to give back the hundreds of millions they have made in the state and pay a stiff penalty for running what he argues are illegal gambling operations.

headline: In ‘Star Wars,’ Was the Death Star Too Big to Fail?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Movies', 'Gross National Product (GNP)']
abstract: “Star Wars” offers a way to model systemic risk.
lead_paragraph: AT the end of “Star Wars: Episode VI — Return of the Jedi,” the heroic Rebel Alliance defeats the evil Galactic Empire, destroying the second Death Star, the empire’s central space station (and superweapon). Audiences typically respond to the destruction of the Death Star with triumphant cheers.

headline: Jihadists Deepen Collaboration in North Africa
abstract: The active coordination is turning one of the most inhospitable territories on earth into a complex security challenge for African and global forces.
lead_paragraph: SAHARA DESERT, Niger — A group of light armored vehicles skated over the moonscape of the Sahara, part of one of the largest detachments the French military has deployed here since colonial times. Its mission is growing ever more urgent: to cut smuggling routes used by jihadists who have turned this inhospitable terrain into a sprawling security challenge for African and international forces alike.

headline: For Bratton and Kelly, Linked Legacies and Locked Horns
abstract: William Bratton and Raymond Kelly have both held New York City’s top police job twice, and Mr. Kelly’s comments on crime numbers have forced a simmering tension into the open.
lead_paragraph: For a quarter-century, they have circled each other as hard-bitten rivals for one of the plum jobs in law enforcement, the claim to the Tiffany badge of the commissioner of the New York Police Department, the country’s biggest police force. They are the only men to have held the rank twice in something akin to an extraordinary game of musical chairs.

headline: A Tip of the Hat to ‘Beach Blanket Babylon’
abstract: The revue, which has been running in San Francisco since 1974, still feels fresh and goofy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is often the locals who blithely ignore the most storied attractions in their midst. Not until, say, an energetic Aunt Nora storms into town and insists on visiting the Statue of Liberty does a longtime New Yorker make a point of paying personal tribute to that grande dame — with or without an indulgent roll of the eyes.

headline: Harvard’s Find of a Colonial Map of New Jersey Is a Reminder of Border Wars
abstract: The map, created in 1769 by the celebrated British surveyor Bernard Ratzer, has been restored and digitized for the university’s online manuscript collection.
lead_paragraph: The border wars between New York and New Jersey have seen fierce fighting over the years, from actual shots fired in the 18th century to trash-talking and legal wrangling over the ownership of Ellis Island almost into the 21st.

headline: Jewish Deportee on Persecution, Past and Present
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Terrorism', 'Concentration Camps', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Marceline Loridan-Ivens, whose memoir takes the form of a letter to her murdered father, says the France where her family sought protection is increasingly at risk.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Deported to Birkenau at 15, she last saw her father in the camps when he slipped her an unimaginable onion and a tomato, before he was murdered at Auschwitz.

headline: Review: ‘Bordertown’ and ‘Cooper Barrett’ Debut
abstract: One show plays to the immigration debate and the other centers on life for 20-somethings.
lead_paragraph: If you thought the political debate over immigration has devolved into a cartoon, just wait until “Bordertown” arrives Sunday night to finish the job. This animated sitcom on Fox is as subtle and amusing as a brick border wall.

headline: Clarion Choir Delves Into the Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, a Rachmaninoff Rarity
abstract: Branching out from its usual repertory, the group gave a soaring performance of this expressive liturgical work.
lead_paragraph: To kick off 2015 a year ago, Trinity Wall Street presented a performance of Rachmaninoff’s Vespers by the Clarion Choir at St. Paul’s Chapel as part of its Twelfth Night Festival. Reviewing elsewhere that night, I couldn’t hear it, but to judge from all reports, the performance must have been stunning.

headline: Armed Texans Celebrate State’s New Open-Carry Status
abstract: About 100 people rallied on the steps of the Capitol, displaying their firearms and exulting that it’s now legal to do so.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For decades, the south steps of the State Capitol have served as a staging area for rallies on issues ranging from abortion to immigration rights, but Friday was the first time that demonstrators walked around here with handguns on their hips.

headline: Backstage at ‘The Nutcracker’
abstract: An illustrated look at the world in the wings of George Balanchine’s classic ballet at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: An illustrated look at the world in the wings of George Balanchine’s classic ballet at Lincoln Center.

headline: Review: A Precious Harvest in ‘The Pearl Fishers’ at the Met
abstract: A new production of Bizet’s “Les Pêcheurs de Perles” brought Penny Woolcock, the British director and filmmaker, to the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: When word gets around, the sleeper hit of the Metropolitan Opera season could be the new production of Bizet’s “Les Pêcheurs de Perles” (“The Pearl Fishers”) that opened on Thursday night, a New Year’s Eve gala event. When a major house presents a new staging of a repertory staple, like Verdi’s “Otello” or, for that matter, Bizet’s “Carmen,” the creative team is under pressure to come up with something fresh, to make a statement that stands out. With a lesser-known work like “The Pearl Fishers,” generally deemed an appealing but flawed opera (patches of soaring music, a justly famous duet, colorful choral writing, but an uneven score with a stilted libretto), the challenge is different and more liberating: The production must make a case for the overlooked opera, must bring out its riches without refashioning its essence.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Wife, Camille, Must Testify in His Accusers’ Civil Case
abstract: A federal judge in Massachusetts ruled that the entertainer’s wife of almost 52 years can be deposed in a defamation case brought by seven women.
lead_paragraph: On the heels of Bill Cosby’s arrest on sexual assault charges, a federal judge in Massachusetts has delivered further bad news for the entertainer, ruling that his wife of almost 52 years, Camille, can be deposed in a civil case filed against him by seven women who say he defamed them.

headline: A Word With Cherry Jones: ‘I’m Having the Kind of Year Actors Live For’
abstract: Ms. Jones, the Broadway star, is playing a lesbian poetry professor with strong feelings about transgender issues on Amazon’s “Transparent.”
lead_paragraph: Cherry Jones may have played the president on the Fox series “24,” but she admits to being a “theater snob” who always thought she would do her best work on the stage. Then she saw the first season of “Transparent,” the critically lauded series on Amazon, chronicling the life of Maura Pfefferman (Jeffrey Tambor), who comes out to her adult children as a transgender woman.

headline: Authorizing War Against ISIS
keywords: ['War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'War Powers Act (1973)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Readers discuss inaction by Congress on a resolution giving the president authority to use military force.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Readers discuss how New York City and Albuquerque are trying to address the problem and offer their own suggestions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: The president of AARP New York State discusses Social Security and retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Raccoons Invade Brooklyn
abstract: City law requires any of the animals that are captured to be euthanized in a humane fashion, but many exterminators and homeowners aren’t doing it.
lead_paragraph: A truck pulled up at a small house with a brick porch and a garden on a recent afternoon, and a man wearing a hooded sweatshirt climbed out. A woman led him to the backyard. When they emerged a few minutes later, he was carrying a wire-mesh cage.

headline: Conjuring the Magic in New York’s Past
keywords: ['Magic and Magicians', 'Psychics and Fortune Tellers', 'Occult Sciences']
abstract: A magician named Belinda Sinclair offers visitors performances that weave in lessons on the women who held séances in the area a century ago.
lead_paragraph: On the third floor of a tenement in Hell’s Kitchen, the sorceress awaits.

headline: Wishes for the New Year
abstract: From Times Square to the web, we asked people to tell us their wishes for 2016.
lead_paragraph: From Times Square to the web, we asked people to tell us their wishes for 2016.

headline: A Smarter Plan to Make Retirement Savings Last
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Retirement', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: The current system is leaving millions of Americans in poverty or near-poverty. Here’s a proposal to save future generations.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, President Obama inaugurated yet another way to encourage Americans to save for retirement. In the new myRA accounts, workers can save up to $15,000 in a low-fee investment plan that, like a government savings bond, guarantees the principal. The accounts are a small step toward helping households save, but they are not an effective solution to the coming retirement crisis.

headline: Over 50, Female and Jobless Even as Others Return to Work
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Age, Chronological', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Discrimination', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Although the economy has improved since the financial crisis, waves from the recession continue to upend job seekers and now a new study shows long-term unemployment has risen among women.
lead_paragraph: The latest signs of an improving economy were good enough to help persuade the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. But the better job market is not good enough to land Chettie McAfee a job.

headline: 5 Years and $7 Later, U.S. Returns a Seized Hip-Hop Site
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Music', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The blog OnSmash was among music sites shut down in 2010, accused of copyright infringement and selling counterfeit goods.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Thanksgiving Day in 2010, all the music at OnSmash.com, a popular hip-hop blog, disappeared. In place of its usual feed of videos, song links and industry gossip, the site displayed a seizure notice from the federal government, a result of a raid of dozens of websites suspected of trafficking in counterfeit goods and pirated content.

headline: Chuck Schumer Seems to Relish Role as Chief Villain of G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The New York senator’s long political career has taken a new turn as Republicans make him their villain of choice — a role he hasn’t exactly rejected.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have put his face in their campaign commercials and spat his name as an insult on the debate stage. Presidential candidates and talk-radio hosts have invoked him as a kind of comic-book villain, thwarting Republicans at every turn.

headline: Let’s Rethink Our Homeless Shelters
abstract: Holistic services are critical to equipping families in need with skills and treatment.
lead_paragraph: MORE than 57,000 New Yorkers will sleep in a shelter tonight. In this city of glistening wealth, they lack a permanent place to call home. Thousands more suffer outside the shelter system; they are on the streets, bracing for the bitter cold ahead.

headline: Man Crushed by Elevator at Building That Had a History of Complaints
abstract: Stephen Hewett-Brown, 25, helped a resident escape a broken elevator on the Lower East Side shortly before he was crushed, witnesses said.
lead_paragraph: Just minutes before midnight on Thursday, Erude Sanchez and her 10-year-old nephew stepped into an elevator on the third floor of her apartment building with a bag of trash, squeezing in alongside New Year’s Eve revelers and other residents.

headline: Knicks Spoil Their Own Comeback With an Implosion in the 4th Quarter
abstract: After the Bulls built a big lead, the Knicks managed to nose ahead in the second half, only to go 2 of 19 from the field in the final period.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Coach Derek Fisher allowed 2 minutes 3 seconds to elapse before he motioned to an official for relief. Fisher’s first timeout on Friday evening was a needed reprieve for the Knicks, who gathered near the bench and enjoyed a brief stretch during which the Bulls were prohibited from driving for layups, sinking 3-pointers and causing general mayhem.

headline: In America, a Man Discovers His Jewish Heritage
abstract: Aleksey Bikov came to New York from Tashkent, Uzbekistan, to escape the poverty and anti-Semitism he faced there.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, Aleksey Bikov came to New York City from Tashkent, Uzbekistan. Simple things, such as well-maintained sidewalks and wheelchair lifts on buses, left him awe-struck.

headline: Our Favorite Styles Photos of 2015
abstract: A look at some of the year’s most striking Styles section images.
lead_paragraph: The world around fashion and style had a fierce digital appetite in 2015. With it came a hunger for images of all kinds: striking fashion, still portraiture and drama captured behind the scenes at shows and in daily lives. Here are some of the year’s photos that made us pause for a moment and really take a look.

headline: Canadiens’ Mike Condon, Inspired by a Boston-Area Hero, Stifles Bruins
abstract: Canadiens goalie Mike Condon, who grew up in nearby Holliston, Mass., was rarely threatened in the first 30 minutes as the Canadiens controlled play in both ends.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — They still are not whole. But key people are filtering back into the Montreal Canadiens’ lineup, with the expectation that the beginning of the new year will be a lot better than the end of the old year.

headline: Despite a Warmer Winter, Annual Polar Bear Club Swim Still Chills
abstract: It looked like Coney Island on a particularly festive summer day, except that it was Jan. 1, when thousands of people flock to the seaside to start their year off the right way — with an unseasonal ocean swim.
lead_paragraph: The boardwalk crawled with Santas, mermaids and polar bears. Music was blasting from the speakers. People were dancing, spreading out blankets on the sand or sipping from flasks as they greeted old friends.

headline: Pennsylvania: Cosby Thanks Fans in Message on Twitter
abstract: Bill Cosby made his first public statement since being charged with aggravated indecent assault, posting a message to Twitter saying, “Friends and fans, Thank You.”
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby made his first public statement since being charged with aggravated indecent assault in Pennsylvania on Wednesday, posting a message on Twitter on Thursday night that said, “Friends and fans, Thank You.” The charges facing the 78-year-old entertainer stem from an accusation made by Andrea Constand that Mr. Cosby drugged and sexually abused her in 2004 in his home in Cheltenham Township, a suburb north of Philadelphia, prosecutors said. Aggravated indecent assault carries a punishment of five to 10 years in prison and a $25,000 fine. Mr. Cosby was charged after being dogged for years by sexual assault allegations made by dozens of women. In recent months, he has filed defamation lawsuits against eight of his accusers, including the former model Beverly Johnson.

headline: Christian McCaffrey Dazzles as Stanford Runs Away With Rose Bowl
abstract: McCaffrey, the Heisman runner-up, amassed 368 yards by every conceivable means — rushes, receptions and punt and kick returns.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — On Friday, Christian McCaffrey presented an argument to extend the Heisman Trophy voting beyond the regular season, and Stanford made the case that defeats suffered way back on Labor Day weekend should be discounted when ultimately evaluating teams for bowl games and in year-end polls.

headline: India and Pakistan Try Again
abstract: Will the warm handclasp of Narendra Modi and Nawaz Sharif lead to progress on delicate issues that have long divided their two countries?
lead_paragraph: As they clasped hands while walking down the red carpet at the Lahore airport recently, Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan and Narendra Modi of India looked more like close friends than the leaders of two countries whose tense relations have long been a threat to regional stability.

headline: St. Louis Area Surveys Toll as Flood Risk Shifts South
abstract: Some towns began to let residents in to inspect their flood-ravaged homes even as residents flanking the Mississippi River farther south in Missouri and Illinois evacuated.
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC, Mo. — The floodwaters that swept away cars and swamped living rooms decorated for Christmas slowly drained from homes and businesses outside St. Louis on Friday, leaving behind months of cleanup as the threat of record-breaking floods headed south toward towns and farm communities flanking the Mississippi River.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Challenges: The Short List
keywords: ['Editorials', 'State of the State Message (NYS)', 'Paid Time Off', 'Minimum Wage', 'Campaign Finance', 'State Legislatures', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: A few big things that would make New York a better place.
lead_paragraph: For Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, 2016 could and should be a year of great achievement. He is not facing re-election and is not seeking a spot on the national Democratic ticket. That means his considerable drive and political talents can be trained on making the state more livable for its 20 million inhabitants, and its government more ethical.

headline: Alabama and Its Leader Rise Together
abstract: Jake Coker had his best game when it mattered most: in the semifinals of the College Football Playoff.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Alabama quarterback Jake Coker and his teammates basked in a shower of confetti amid a boisterous celebration after their 38-0 victory over Michigan State late Thursday night. The final score indicated dominance on both sides of the line of scrimmage, a signature performance for a Crimson Tide team that had been criticized for not having more of them.

headline: Cutting the Cord and Feeling Good About It
abstract: Canceling cable has meant becoming more intentional and picking out things that are really enjoyable.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years ago, when I first thought about living without cable TV, it seemed impractical. But given the proliferation of entertainment choices online, life without cable no longer seems impossible.

headline: Our New Year Quiz
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Test how well you blocked out parts of the last political year.
lead_paragraph: Test how well you blocked out parts of the last political year.

headline: Friday Night Music: More Wild Reeds
abstract: Harmony to soothe the soul.
lead_paragraph: A followup on last week. This is really lovely:

headline: Mass Master
abstract: David Phillips provides our first Saturday challenge of 2016.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Some puzzle constructors are attracted to a marquee phrase as their seed entry and some constructors can’t resist the Scrabbly allure of the rarer letters of the alphabet when selecting a place to start filling their themeless grids. Today, David Phillips shows us what it’s like to fall for the allure of the letter X.

headline: Qaeda Affiliate Uses Video of Donald Trump for Recruiting
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Muslim Americans']
abstract: A video by the Shabab, Al Qaeda’s Somalia branch, criticizes racism in America and features footage of Mr. Trump announcing a plan to bar Muslims from entering the country.
lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda’s branch in Somalia released a recruitment video on Friday that criticized racism and anti-Muslim sentiment in the United States and contained footage of the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump announcing his proposal to bar Muslims from entering the country.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Viewers may want to catch up on a year gone by by taking in the space drama “The Martian” or the scabrous comedy “Chi-Raq.” There’s also comfortable postholiday fodder like “Meet the Parents.”
lead_paragraph: Today you might want to catch up on 2015 by watching two critically lauded films  from the directors Ridley Scott and Spike Lee. Or you can put a week of holiday stress into perspective by revisiting the trials endured by Greg Focker (Ben Stiller) in “Meet the Parents” and “Meet the Fockers.”

headline: Corrections: January 2, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “My family has begged for food since the Ming dynasty. I’m the 19th generation.”

headline: Confessions of a Columnist
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: How I underestimated Donald Trump’s potential in the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: EVERY New Year’s, in a spirit of self-examination, I try to catalog my worst blunders from the preceding year. But this year, like almost every pundit in America, I have one mistake that overshadows all the others, one confession that makes my other faults seem venial by comparison.

headline: Iranian Protesters Ransack Saudi Embassy After Execution of Shiite Cleric
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Capital Punishment', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, an outspoken campaigner for Shiite rights, is likely to exacerbate sectarian tensions across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Iranian protesters ransacked and set fire to the Saudi Embassy in Tehran on Saturday after Saudi Arabia executed an outspoken Shiite cleric who had criticized the kingdom’s treatment of its Shiite minority.

headline: Spanx for the Holidays
abstract: The love-hate relationship many women have with their “sculpting” undergarments is particularly fraught this time of year.
lead_paragraph: Many of us think of the holidays as the giving season. I think of it as the stalking season. That’s because I have been relentlessly followed online by advertisements for shapewear. The emails have poured in, and every sales site I frequent — Zulily, MyHabit, Ideel — has touted their wonders.

headline: Bill Gates: The Billionaire Book Critic
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A blog by the Microsoft co-founder has become an influential force in the publishing world.
lead_paragraph: Evan Thomas, the best-selling biographer of Robert F. Kennedy and Dwight D. Eisenhower and the author of a half-dozen other books, has seen those books reviewed over the years by The New Yorker, The Washington Post and The Atlantic. But with the recent publication of his latest work, “Being Nixon: A Man Divided,” he experienced for the first time a new phenomenon: the Bill Gates bump.

headline: F.D.A. Regulator, Widowed by Cancer, Helps Speed Drug Approval
abstract: Dr. Richard Pazdur, the Food and Drug Administration’s oncology chief, says his wife’s ordeal was influential in a change that many had advocated but that critics say erodes safeguards.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — Mary Pazdur had exhausted the usual drugs for ovarian cancer, and with her tumors growing and her condition deteriorating, her last hope seemed to be an experimental compound that had yet to be approved by federal regulators.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted on @nytimes during the last week of 2015 took followers from an island in Antarctica to Times Square, before the ball dropped.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted on @nytimes during the last week of 2015 took followers from an island in Antarctica to Times Square, before the ball dropped.

headline: Gunmen Killed in Pathankot, India, Air Base Attack
abstract: At least four attackers were killed as Indian authorities defended the base in Punjab State. Several Indian security force members were also reported dead.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least four gunmen were killed in an attack at an Indian air force base that began early Saturday near the border with Pakistan in Pathankot, in Punjab State, the police said.

headline: When a Doorman Is Underage
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Doormen', 'Child Labor', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Cooperatives', 'Building Service Employees']
abstract: This week’s questions are about child labor laws, tending vines and an unresponsive building management company.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Making And Using Models
abstract: It’s about self-discipline.
lead_paragraph: Larry Summers, Brad DeLong, and yours truly are having a bit of a three-cornered dialogue about the role of models in policy, set off by Larry’s initial post about why he believes the Fed is making a mistake in raising rates. We’re now in round two – and before I get to the specifics, let me ask: Don’t you wish real life were like this? (Let me pull Marshall McLuhan John Maynard Keynes out from behind this sign.)

headline: For Donald Trump, Lessons From a Brother’s Suffering
abstract: Mr. Trump, whose appeal is predicated on an aura of toughness and perpetual success, seldom speaks of his brother Freddy, who died as an alcoholic in 1981 at age 43.
lead_paragraph: One evening in the 1960s, Donald J. Trump, still in college but eager to make it big, met his older brother, Freddy, for dinner in a Queens apartment complex built by their father.

headline: Tips for Uber, From a Backseat Driver
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Customer Relations', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: The system for the popular app-based, ride-hailing business needs work, starting with its cancellation policy and its accuracy of pickup estimates.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler views Uber with a mix of delight and skepticism, roughly the same way he feels about KFC’s Double Down sandwich, that improbable confection of bacon and cheese between two slabs of fried chicken. Part of him is tempted. The other part wonders, “Is that even real?”

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: We welcome back Marching bands by Brendan Emmett Quigley.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Marching Bands puzzles are so much fun and it is beyond me why more people don’t do them.

headline: Bringing Solar Power to India’s Poor
abstract: A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.
lead_paragraph: A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.

headline: Electrifying India, With the Sun and Small Loans
abstract: A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the hundred or so residents of Paradeshappanamatha, a secluded hamlet in the southern Indian state of Karnataka, gathered along the central pathway between their 22 densely clustered homes, and watched as government workers hoisted a solar-powered streetlamp. As the first display of electricity in the town, it was an object of mild interest, but, being outside, the light didn’t help anyone cook or study, and only attracted moths.

headline: FASB Proposes to Curb What Companies Must Disclose
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Corporations']
abstract: A regulatory change that would allow companies more discretion in deciding what is “material” information arouses concern among investors and auditors.
lead_paragraph: Accounting rule makers are not generally known as flame-throwers. But with a new proposal, the Financial Accounting Standards Board has lobbed a miniature Molotov cocktail into the usually staid world of audit standards, upsetting investor groups and experts in the field.

headline: Bernie Sanders Took In $33 Million in Last Quarter
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders’s presidential campaign took in more than $33 million in the final three months of the 2015, as his wide base of small donors enabled him to raise just $4 million less than his rival Hillary Clinton in their fight for the Democratic nomination.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders’s presidential campaign raised more than $33 million in the final three months of 2015, as his wide base of small-amount donors enabled him to come within $4 million of the amount raised by Hillary Clinton, his rival for the Democratic nomination, his campaign said Saturday.

headline: Ex-N.F.L. Player’s New Team Takes On Challenges of A.L.S.
abstract: Steve Gleason learned he had A.L.S. after retiring from football; he has since formed a group that uses technology to help those with the disease.
lead_paragraph: Since 2011, Steve Gleason has traveled to Machu Picchu, road-tripped from New Orleans to Alaska and started a nonprofit. He also became a consultant for Microsoft and collaborated on a movie that was accepted by the Sundance Film Festival — even though he gradually lost the ability to talk and became paralyzed except for his eyes.

headline: Telecommuting Can Make the Office a Lonely Place, a Study Says
abstract: New research finds that off-site work can disrupt teamwork, alienate people who remain in the office and perpetuate increased telecommuting.
lead_paragraph: Ever since telecommuting became a viable option for a broad spectrum of workers, some companies have offered it as a tempting perk. Why not make workers happier by allowing them to spend more time with their families, avoid long commutes and exert more control over their schedules? Plus, off-site work enables businesses to save money on real estate and hire talented people who live in far-flung locations.

headline: A Job That Nourishes the Soul, if Not the Wallet
abstract: Trading a higher paying but mind-numbing position for one in which the greatest rewards were not financial.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer was in his mid-20s. He narrowed his eyes, peered at me from behind his cluttered desk and said, “So, why are you quitting?”

headline: Review: A Mexican ‘Taco Dive Bar’ That’s Anything But
abstract: This restaurant in Peekskill puts a primacy on its tequila-rich drinks menu. But the full-service restaurant is hardly a dive, and much more than a bar.
lead_paragraph: The name of Taco Dive Bar, a Peekskill newcomer, suggests an emphasis on drinks, and they are good. The house margaritas are strong and tasty, made with 100 percent agave tequila, a touch of agave syrup and fresh lime, and the tequila-rich bar offers a full menu of reposados and añejos, both varieties of aged tequila, as well as the usual fare.

headline: Slow and Steady May Win the Race for the Knicks, Someday
abstract: The Knicks have always been one of the league’s slowest teams, and that is not changing despite the run-and-gun style of the Golden State Warriors and other teams.
lead_paragraph: Every few years, the Knicks seem to have a new guiding principle, a new mastermind, a new star or a new direction. But if there is a near constant in the never-ending remaking of one of the N.B.A.’s original franchises, it is that the team goes at its own pace, and that pace is fairly slow.

headline: On Perilous Migrant Trail, Women Often Become Prey to Sexual Abuse
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: Along with all the perils refugees face, women have added accounts of being assaulted, traumas that do not end with their arrival in Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — One Syrian woman who joined the stream of migrants to Germany was forced to pay down her husband’s debt to smugglers by making herself available for sex along the way. Another was beaten unconscious by a Hungarian prison guard after refusing his advances.

headline: Review: Casa Margarita, a Cantina Where the Margarita Is Master
abstract: The Mexican restaurant, located in Southington, Conn., offers a baker’s dozen of margaritas concocted from more than 80 tequilas and mezcals.
lead_paragraph: If margaritas are what you most hanker for when sitting down to a Mexican meal, Casa Margarita, in Southington, Conn., provides plenty of incentive to return again and again. From an impressive selection of more than 80 tequilas and mezcals, the restaurant concocts a baker’s dozen of margaritas, including one seasoned with smoked salt, several spiked with rum, bourbon or gin and others muddled with cucumber or watermelon.

headline: It’s Not Cricket, but It’s a Ballgame in Australia
abstract: Officials from the Australian Baseball League said that they hope local interest in the sport will grow with the support of Major League Baseball, which has a 75 percent ownership stake.
lead_paragraph: PERTH, Australia — More than 10,000 miles from his home in chilly New England, Pawtucket Red Sox Manager Kevin Boles tucked a stopwatch into his sweatshirt pocket and clocked the first pitch of the game between his Perth Heat and the Canberra Cavalry. It was 80 degrees, a typical December day.

headline: Sheldon Adelson’s Purchase of Las Vegas Paper Seen as a Power Play
abstract: The billionaire casino magnate's recent purchase of The Las Vegas Review-Journal has prompted concerns that he could use the newspaper to influence a lawsuit against his business empire.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Two days after Sheldon Adelson’s lawyers lost in their attempts to have a judge removed from a contentious lawsuit that threatens his gambling empire, a call went out to the publisher of this city’s most prominent newspaper.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: The League of YES
abstract: Able children help children with disabilities join in the game.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’re sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. The League of YES, formerly known as the Miracle League of Long Island, inspired Edward and Kelli Kanaley to write.

headline: Review: Bank on the Seafood at Fish Urban Dining in Ridgewood
abstract: Situated in a former Bank of America branch on East Ridgewood Avenue, the seafood restaurant has 30-foot ceilings, huge chandeliers and extends into what was the vault.
lead_paragraph: It would not be an exaggeration to say that the setting of Fish Urban Dining is striking. Situated in a former Bank of America branch on East Ridgewood Avenue, the restaurant has 30-foot-high ceilings with six huge chandeliers, and its sleek dining room extends into what was the bank’s vault, complete with a five-ton steel door.

headline: Review: Beijing House Is Strictly Chinese, and Proud of It
abstract: Beijing House in Syosset, N.Y., a popular newcomer, is part of a resurgence of exclusively Chinese, non-fusion restaurants on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Beijing House in Syosset is the latest example of the resurgence of Chinese restaurants on Long Island. Just a few years ago, nearly every Asian newcomer seemed to be fusion or Japanese. Diners who wanted strictly Chinese fare had to settle on the few, older and more traditional restaurants that had survived all the trends.

headline: Panthers’ Receivers Deliver, Mystifying Critics and Defenses
abstract: Carolina entered the season without a proven No. 1 wide receiver, but Ted Ginn Jr., Jerricho Cotchery and others have helped Cam Newton reach a career high in touchdown passes.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Among the more persistent slights of the Carolina Panthers, despite their 14-0 start this season, was the notion that they were the worst undefeated team in N.F.L. history. Perfect teams in the past, critics said, were more impressive, more talented and more worthy of that perfection.

headline: Liza Lou’s Handmade Sea of Sparkling Glass
abstract: Ms. Lou, known for her intricate installations of colored glass beads, has blanketed the floor of the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase with her latest work.
lead_paragraph: For those who wear glasses, the artist Liza Lou suggests taking them off when viewing her newest work, “Color Field.” The site-specific installation, a monumental, iridescent grid of colors, is part of the exhibition “Liza Lou: Color Field and Solid Grey” at the Neuberger Museum of Art. “Color Field” blankets most of the floor of the Theater Gallery, requiring museumgoers to walk around its periphery. As they do, the piece seems to shimmer and transform: now airy, now dense; patterns emerging and disappearing; tonal relationships continually shifting.

headline: Beginning Greek, Again and Again
keywords: ['Greek Civilization', 'Language and Languages', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Greek Language', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Few of my students will really understand the language. So why do I go on?
lead_paragraph: WHEN I moved my Beginning Greek course, last year, from the spring to fall semester, I did not reckon with the impact on my psyche of diminishing daylight. As the days grew shorter, my thoughts about the course grew darker. When the semester concluded, just before the winter solstice, those thoughts had also reached a nadir, giving way to the fear that I had failed, once again, in my 30-year quest to turn bright and eager undergraduates into readers, and lovers, of ancient Greek.

headline: How to Cultivate the Art of Serendipity
abstract: Innovation isn’t all hard work or dumb luck: It’s about paying attention.
lead_paragraph: DO some people have a special talent for serendipity? And if so, why?

headline: Social Security in an Election Year
abstract: With more retirees relying on the program, candidates should be suggesting sensible fixes, not broad cutbacks.
lead_paragraph: This election season offers an opportunity to reframe the debate over Social Security. It is necessary, of course, to ensure the program’s long-term health beyond 2034, when the system is projected to come up short. But this can’t be done by broadly cutting benefits. In fact, there’s mounting evidence that Social Security, which has become ever more important in retirement, needs to be expanded.

headline: Nora Volkow
abstract: A psychiatrist and brain researcher on enjoying Latin American novels, the marvels of Bach and the oddity of not following anything
lead_paragraph: The psychiatrist and brain researcher Nora Volkow is the director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

headline: The Smell of Loss
abstract: I miss my mother-in-law. But can her perfume really be haunting me?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — THE first time it happens is a dark winter’s afternoon, not quite a year after her death. I’m at my desk working, and there it suddenly is: sharp, glassy-green, with that faint, musky undertone that catches at the back of your throat.

headline: The Stately Gift Shops of England
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Television', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The essential message of “Downton Abbey” is that the rich will always be with us, however bankrupt or indebted or criminally incompetent they may be.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a child, my parents would take me to visit stately homes. I grew up in a part of England that seemed to be filled with them — Tudor mansions, pseudo-Palladian villas, Gothic piles — and whole Sundays would be spent walking along their corridors or exploring knot gardens with a host of people I didn’t know.

headline: Is the Drive for Success Making Our Children Sick?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Across the country, children are experiencing depression, anxiety and even physical strain because of the pressures of school.
lead_paragraph: STUART SLAVIN, a pediatrician and professor at the Saint Louis University School of Medicine, knows something about the impact of stress. After uncovering alarming rates of anxiety and depression among his medical students, Dr. Slavin and his colleagues remade the program: implementing pass/fail grading in introductory classes, instituting a half-day off every other week, and creating small learning groups to strengthen connections among students. Over the course of six years, the students’ rates of depression and anxiety dropped considerably.

headline: The Value of a High School Diploma
abstract: High school graduation rates are rising, but how prepared are the students for college and careers?
lead_paragraph: High school graduation rates are rising, but are the students ready for college and careers?

headline: Marco Rubio Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: Is it wise to wager on a hyper-controlled candidate who’s all puzzles and paradoxes?
lead_paragraph: MATH was never my strongest subject, so maybe I’m just not crunching the numbers right.

headline: Whatever Happened to Latino Political Power?
abstract: Growing numbers haven’t led to real clout.
lead_paragraph: DEMOGRAPHY is destiny, or so the saying goes, but Latinos are learning this political season that destiny can take detours.

headline: The Pentagon’s Insubordination on Guantánamo
abstract: The Defense Department cannot be allowed to continue dragging its feet on prisoner releases.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Congress and the Pentagon have stood in the way of President Obama’s goal of shutting down the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The legislative hurdles have been predictable in a Republican-led Congress that so often opposes Mr. Obama’s initiatives reflexively. The stalling at the Defense Department, where officials have used every bureaucratic trick in the book to slow down the release of inmates, is startling, though, and basically amounts to insubordination.

headline: Memories of Whistling Past Nuclear Armageddon
abstract: A different kind of terrorism reigned during the tense years of the Cold War. The proposed solution? Bomb shelters.
lead_paragraph: No one called it terrorism back then, but the angst of day-to-day existence during the Cold War was chillingly recalled with the release last month of the government’s top-secret nuclear target list for 1959. “Population” was the obscenely brief title of target category No. 275 — population, as in the citizens of major cities who war planners estimated would necessarily die by the millions.

headline: The Dirty Truth About ‘Clean Diesel’
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: It turns out that this supposedly green fuel has been quietly killing us.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — AS scandals go, it was a juicy one. Volkswagen, one of the world’s highest grossing automakers, persuaded consumers it had created a new generation of so-called clean diesel cars — until investigators discovered that defeat devices, which activated emissions controls only when the cars were tested, were concealing the fact that its vehicles emitted up to 40 times the permitted levels of pollutants during regular use.

headline: A Reign of Glory Ebbs Away for Tom Coughlin and the Giants
abstract: After 12 seasons, Coughlin may coach his final game Sunday for the Giants, but his substantial legacy is assured.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The focus of the New York pro football world on Sunday will be on Buffalo, where the jaunty Jets, in a surprise, chase a playoff berth that might lead the franchise to its first Super Bowl in 46 years.

headline: Rock Out for a Good Cause at Light of Day Winterfest
abstract: More than 150 bands are expected to perform at the annual music festival that starts on Jan. 10. The highly celebrated charity event has raised more than $3 million for research on Parkinson’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The rock ’n’ roll troubadour Willie Nile tours so frequently that remembering what city he was in a week ago sometimes poses a challenge. But he always knows where he’ll be in January.

headline: A Beat Unmistakably His Own
abstract: At 59, Sal Cataldi has released a funk-tinged album, “Sketches of Spam,” that ranges in influence from Frank Zappa to Miles Davis.
lead_paragraph: Sal Cataldi often performs his original music, which ranges in influence from Frank Zappa to Miles Davis to Nick Drake, behind a pair of belly dancers. After he finishes a gig, he heads home to his double-decker barge at Toms Point Marina, in Port Washington. His day job, in Manhattan, has included orchestrating a 50-zombie march across the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Dale Bumpers, Liberal Stalwart of Arkansas Politics, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Bumpers, a four-term United States senator, was part of a generation of moderate Southern Democrats to emerge in the late 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Dale L. Bumpers, a liberal governor and four-term Democratic senator from Arkansas who came out of retirement in 1999 to make a passionate closing argument defending President Bill Clinton against removal from office in a Senate trial, died on Friday at his home in Little Rock, Ark. He was 90.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Eagles at Giants
abstract: Here’s what you need to know when the Eagles play the Giants.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Jets at Bills
abstract: Here’s what you need to know when the Jets play the Bills.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., CBS

headline: Coach’s Fire Returns With a Fresh Attitude
abstract: Ron Wilson is the first former N.H.L. head coach to lead Team USA at the International Ice Hockey Federation’s world junior championship.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — After his 18-season N.H.L. coaching career ended tumultuously, Ron Wilson needed time to decompress and fall back in love with hockey before he would even consider coaching again. Now, almost four years after the Toronto Maple Leafs fired him, Wilson is back behind the bench, and this time he’s having fun.

headline: A Mother Marks Her Son’s Progress by His Confidence and Clear Speech
abstract: Charlene Wise’s autistic son was too terrified to go trick-or-treating in 2014. But Delquon, 6, who has also been diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity and obsessive compulsive disorders, took to the streets with glee this past Halloween, another sign of his newfound grasp of the world.
lead_paragraph: On Halloween 2014, Delquon Matthews refused to go trick-or-treating, terrified he would fall victim to ghouls and goblins. This past Halloween, dressed as Raphael, one of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, he took to the streets with glee.

headline: A Different Note on Race at Yale
abstract: A music professor has sought to address a history of segregation in shape-note singing, as social justice protests have roiled universities.
lead_paragraph: When Ian Quinn, a professor of music at Yale, attended his first sacred harp hymn-singing session in a stone chapel in Berkeley, Calif., in 2008, he was so impressed with the session’s openness to all comers, and the egalitarian message it sent to music-makers generally, that he decided to push for a similar session when he returned to New Haven.

headline: At Insa in Brooklyn, a Mix of Karaoke and Korean Barbecue
abstract: A group of entrepreneurs shared a meal, talked a little business and then mapped out a set of songs to sing.
lead_paragraph: Though Brooklyn has its share of hybrid operations, like a barbershop where you can get a cocktail, it has suffered from a lack of fine-dining karaoke joints, which have traditionally clustered in Koreatown, in Manhattan in the 30s. But just two weeks ago, the restaurant Insa opened in Gowanus, offering a wide array of Korean barbecue dishes and after-dinner entertainment in one of five karaoke rooms with wacky themes. Owned by Sohui Kim and Ben Schneider, the married couple behind the Good Fork in Red Hook, Insa, which occupies a sprawling former warehouse at 328 Douglass Street, may be the only place in Brooklyn where you can cook cuttlefish and octopus on your table grill and then repair to the Jungle Room for a performance of “Hound Dog.” Last week, a group of Brooklynites was planning to do precisely that — albeit with a bit more food and without the Elvis.

headline: Ancient Rome and Little Italy, in the Bronx
abstract: A museum at Fordham University offers antiquities to peruse for free, best followed with a meal on Arthur Avenue, the Bronx’s Little Italy.
lead_paragraph: Alumni like Denzel Washington, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Alan Alda and Lana Del Rey know it, but for those who never attended Fordham University, its regal beauty might be a surprise. With its landscaped lawns, well-groomed hedges and Gothic architecture, it was a go-to location for collegiate dramas, including “Love Story,” “Quiz Show” and “A Beautiful Mind.” The reason for plebeians to intrude is the Fordham Museum of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Art, housed in the contemporary William D. Walsh Family Library on the campus in the Bronx. The intimate museum is a bit like Nick Carraway living next door to Jay Gatsby, its more illustrious neighbors being the New York Botanical Garden and the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Winter White
abstract: The photographer Jan Staller’s images capture those brief moments when the snow still lies unsullied on New York city streets and park meadows.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Jan Staller’s images capture those brief moments when the snow still lies unsullied on New York city streets and park meadows.

headline: Jan Staller’s Images Show New York’s Untrammeled Snows of Yesteryear
abstract: For decades, the photographer has captured those brief moments before passing taxis or dogs sully the purifying transformation brought by the snow.
lead_paragraph: Winters in the city are beautiful only for a moment. A pristine lace of snow falls, but then, within minutes, a taxi — or a dog — comes by to dirty it up.

headline: How Aerin Lauder, Cosmetics Scion, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The granddaughter of Estée Lauder is often awake early with her family’s pets and likes to check in on people buying her cosmetics line at the beauty counter.
lead_paragraph: Aerin Lauder is a granddaughter of Estée Lauder, who started her cosmetics company in 1946 with a mere four products. Ms. Lauder, 45, spent 25 years working for the family business before introducing Aerin, her own beauty, home and luxury lifestyle label, in 2012. “Beauty is my heritage, but my passion is home, so I love spending time there,” Ms. Lauder said of her Sundays. She lives on Manhattan’s Upper East Side with her husband of 20 years, Eric Zinterhofer, 44, an investment banker, and their sons, Jack, 16, who attends boarding school, and Will, 15.

headline: Untangling an Accounting Tool and an Ancient Incan Mystery
