headline: Please, Read My Book (Unless You’re a Friend of My Sons)
abstract: I’m trying to promote the dirty book I just wrote. Please don’t tell anyone.
lead_paragraph: I’m incredibly proud of the book I wrote. I hope it has some of the things I love when I read other people’s work. I want readers to find the story funny and sad; honest and relatable. My characters fall in and out of love, they try things they never thought they would and things they will never admit to. And some of these things are dirty. This did not have to be a dirty book. At several points, I could have faded to black, like a 1950s Hollywood movie. No, this didn’t need to be a dirty book. It just gets to be.

headline: How Do Sunni and Shia Islam Differ?
abstract: Here is a primer on the differences between the two branches of Islam.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s execution of the Shiite cleric Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr could escalate tensions in the Muslim world even further. In the Shiite theocracy Iran, the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei,  said on Sunday that Saudi Arabia, which is ruled by a Sunni monarchy, would face “divine vengeance” for the killing of the outspoken cleric, which was part of a mass execution of 47 men. Sheikh Nimr had advocated for greater political rights for Shiites in Saudi Arabia and surrounding countries. Saudi Arabia had accused him of inciting violence against the state.

It was billed as a peaceful demonstration, but after “Amazing Grace” was sung and hugs were exchanged, a small, armed contingent declared outside a supermarket that it was taking a stand and asked who wanted to join.

headline: ‘The Breaks,’ a TV Movie on VH1, Examines the Year Hip-Hop Found Its Flow
abstract: The movie, the basis of a possible series, dramatizes the year 1990, when rap music was suspended between its gritty urban roots and mainstream acceptance.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, hip-hop was a subculture striving to breach the mainstream without losing its soul. The music had matured at breakneck speed in the 1980s. Rappers pushed past boasts and chants with storytelling, complex wordplay and sociopolitical consciousness, as producers vastly extended the sound-collage possibilities of sampling. “Yo! MTV Raps,” which started in 1988, was expanding the hip-hop audience beyond its urban core, and MC Hammer had a worldwide hit with “U Can’t Touch This.” But at the same time the crack epidemic was closing down the New York City clubs that had been hip-hop laboratories, while radio stations still resisted hip-hop’s genuine innovators and major labels considered hip-hop a novelty that would run its course. Everyone involved was inventing the music and the business on the spot.

headline: Alex Brightman Rides a ‘School of Rock’ Wave
abstract: At 28, the busy Mr. Brightman has found his signature role as loutish, lovable teacher in this play based on the 2003 hit movie.
lead_paragraph: What kinds of backstage pleasures does a newly minted heavy-metal star enjoy these days? At the Winter Garden Theater, Alex Brightman, the lead actor of Broadway’s “School of Rock,” has furnished his diminutive dressing room with such not-so-hedonistic gratifications as a steam-inhaler mask, tasteful throw pillows and a collection of year-end award-season movies on DVD.

headline: In ‘Fiddler on the Roof,’ a Title Role Shared Onstage and Off
abstract: Jesse Kovarsky strikes Chagall-worthy poses onstage, while the violinist Kelly Hall-Tompkins makes the music come alive in the orchestra pit.
lead_paragraph: Pop quiz: Who plays the title role in the new Broadway revival of “Fiddler on the Roof”?

headline: A Healthy Diet’s Main Ingredients? Best Guesses
abstract: As the federal government is again rethinking the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, there’s fresh debate over just what makes a healthy diet.
lead_paragraph: First doctor: “This morning for breakfast he requested something called ‘wheat germ, organic honey and tiger’s milk.’”

headline: Review: ‘Superstore’ and ‘Telenovela’ Play It Safe on NBC
abstract: Hispanics receive increased network exposure on these two new comedies, but the shows don’t take many chances.
lead_paragraph: Two new shows on NBC that address the shortage of Hispanic characters on television play the demographic game about as safely as it can be played, putting well-known Latina stars in nonthreatening, nonchallenging comedies. But progress is progress, and one of the shows, “Superstore,” is pretty good. The other, “Telenovela,” is just dumb.

headline: Acts of Bravery
abstract: A fairly easy Monday puzzle by Herre Schouwerwou.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Well, if you are going to break into solving crossword puzzles as a New Year’s resolution, this is a pretty decent one with which to do it. This puzzle by Herre Schouwerwou is mostly easy to solve and the plethora of theme material is clued easily, so it won’t slow you down. Not only that, but you just know that any puzzle that debuts PINK FLOYD, POPPIN’ FRESH and PILLOW FIGHTS is going to be fun.

headline: Laurie Anderson Puts on a Concert for Dogs in Times Square
abstract: Ms. Anderson will also present part of her film “Heart of a Dog” at the Midnight Moment series on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Laurie Anderson recalled in an interview, she was backstage with the cellist Yo-Yo Ma at a Rhode Island School of Design graduation ceremony when she turned to him and said, “I have this fantasy where I look out, and the whole audience is dogs.” He replied: “Are you kidding? I have the same fantasy.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Cabaret of Plants,’ Richard Mabey Demonstrates Their Richness
abstract: In his new book, the British naturalist writes about how plants are aware of their environment in a way we have yet to comprehend.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a picture of a jungle. There are the familiar palms and vines, and down in a corner a monkey sitting on a branch. Ask a number of people, “What is this a picture of?” and it’s a good bet that most will say it shows a monkey.

headline: Arron Afflalo, With 38 Points, Carries Knicks Past Hawks
abstract: Afflalo took the game’s first shot, a jumper, and hit it, going on to finish 7 of 8 from 3-point range and 14 of 17 from the field on an afternoon when Carmelo Anthony struggled.
lead_paragraph: To start 2016, Arron Afflalo switched to a new pair of black Air Jordans as his on-court sneaker of choice.

headline: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Arabs', 'Women and Girls', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Restaurants', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Youth']
abstract: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.
lead_paragraph: HAIFA, Israel — At Elika, a bar in the Hadar neighborhood of this hilly port city, a 30-something psychodramatist rolled a cigarette and sipped coffee with her father, a well-known actor in Israel. The bartender poured tall beers for two women who wandered in for an afternoon pint. Nearby, a 22-year-old woman with a partly shaved head and colorful tattoos sat alone, working on her laptop.

headline: Who’d Steal Lincoln’s Hand? Art Theft Baffles Illinois Museum
abstract: The police said they had little information in the disappearance of a plaster sculpture that has been missing from the Kankakee County Museum since at least Dec. 11.
lead_paragraph: KANKAKEE, Ill. — Someone stole Abraham Lincoln’s hand.

headline: Auto Sales, the Fed’s December Meeting and Employment Numbers
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Automobiles', 'Interest Rates', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: This week, automakers are expected to post big gains, the Federal Reserve will publish an official account of its December meeting and the Labor Department will report on hiring and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: The first Monday of the new year will mark the first day of extended trading hours for China’s currency, the renminbi. The move, announced last Wednesday by China’s central bank, is the most recent in a number of steps taken over the last few years by Beijing to make the renminbi more international.

headline: Closing the Farm-to-Table Gap in Alaska
abstract: The quest for a crisp head of lettuce has opened the door to two start-ups with starkly different visions for growing fresh produce in a frozen state.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Across much of Alaska at this time of the year, as winter tightens its grip with darkness and cold, finding a nice crisp head of lettuce at an affordable price can be like prospecting for gold. Where the farm-to-table distance is measured in thousands of miles, the odds get long.

headline: New Elections Likely in Catalonia After Separatist Leader Is Rebuffed
abstract: In a vote by a far-left party’s political committee, the leader of the region, Artur Mas, failed to gain the necessary support to remain in office.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Catalonia is likely to convene new regional elections after a far-left party there voted Sunday against allowing Artur Mas to continue as leader of the region and its secessionist movement.

headline: Under New Leader, Discovery Channel’s Brand Reboot Shows Promise
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Reality Television']
abstract: By moving away from ratings stunts and tired content, Rich Ross has managed to help lift the TV network’s viewership and nab a sought-after demographic.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood loves a comeback story. And right now, there is perhaps none better than Rich Ross and Discovery.

headline: Girl Scout Cookie Sales Go Digital, With Help From Visa and Dell
abstract: The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. permitted web sales of cookies for the first time in 2015, and Visa and Dell are investing an estimated $3 million this year to help improve the platform.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Girl Scouts have taken their cookies digital, companies are following them online.

headline: Raine Group Finds Deals for Clients, and Itself
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Quiet, huge transactions include selling a $400 million stake in Manchester City soccer team’s parent to China Media.
lead_paragraph: The Raine Group may not be as instantly recognizable as Wall Street fixtures like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Newspapers']
abstract: President Obama is the first president to publish visitor logs of the journalists who attend off-the-record discussions meant to promote context and candor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after President Obama announced in a 2014 speech that he was escalating his campaign against Islamic extremists, a number of prominent columnists suggested they knew exactly what he was thinking.

headline: Accordion Store’s Departure Signals End of Manhattan’s Music Row
abstract: Squeezed out by high rents and e-commerce, the last holdout on this segment of West 48th Street closed its doors in December.
lead_paragraph: For decades, musicians from around the world flocked to a segment of West 48th Street in Manhattan that was known as Music Row. Both sides of the block, just off Times Square, were lined with shops that sold and repaired guitars, drums, keyboards and other instruments.

headline: Peyton Manning Returns and Leads Broncos to No. 1 Seed in A.F.C.
abstract: Manning replaced a struggling Brock Osweiler and helped Denver defeat the Chargers.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — For a little over a half, Peyton Manning stood stoutly on the Broncos’ sideline, not once appearing to favor his left foot, with a torn plantar fascia that had caused him to miss six games. Manning looked fine, which caused a woolen blanket of disbelief to settle over Sports Authority Field at Mile High during the Broncos’ regular-season finale against the San Diego Chargers.

headline: A Homey Hangout for Broadway Stars Closes After 14 Years
abstract: Angus’ Cafe Bistro, a restaurant on West 44th Street, attracted stars and producers of ‘The Producers’ as investors and patrons.
lead_paragraph: Trent Rhoton was drinking a pint and a shot at the bar of Angus’ Cafe Bistro on Sunday afternoon when a friend wandered over to greet him. “It’s the end of an era,” said the friend, John McMahon, as they clinked glasses.

headline: Economists Take Aim at Wealth Inequality
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income', 'Taxation']
abstract: At the American Economic Association’s annual meeting, what was once mainly an issue among players on the margins of the profession is taking center stage.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When pundits and presidential candidates talk about inequality and the tiny sliver of the population whose fortunes have soared, they often drop names like Warren Buffett, Bill Gates, Sheldon Adelson and Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: For Tom Coughlin, a Tribute; for Pat Shurmur, an Audition
abstract: Both teams’ previous elimination from playoff contention made for an unusual game where Philadelphia wanted to show it could run its offense and the Giants aimed to win another game for Coach Tom Coughlin.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants had one big edge over the Philadelphia Eagles entering Sunday’s season finale. Their head coach, Tom Coughlin, had been in the job for 12 years. Pat Shurmur, Philadelphia’s interim coach, had been in his job for all of five days.

headline: Hocine Aït-Ahmed, a Pro-Democracy Algerian Leader, Dies at 89
abstract: After freedom from France, Mr. Aït-Ahmed remained an influential figure in Algerian politics, pushing for democracy and opposing successive governments.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Hocine Aït-Ahmed, a leader of the Algerian war of independence against France that began in 1954 and a major opponent of the Algerian governments dominated by the military since then, died on Dec. 23 in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 89.

headline: John Holm, 72, Dies; Opened Linguistics to Creole and Pidgin Tongues
abstract: Mr. Holm studied creole and pidgin languages spoken by millions of people around the world, especially the English-derived creoles of the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: John Holm, a linguist who helped bring the study of creole and pidgin languages into the scholarly mainstream, died on Dec. 28 in Azeitão, Portugal. He was 72.

headline: Jets’ High Hopes End in Same Place: Out of the Playoffs
abstract: The Jets’ season-ending loss raised as many questions as the last part of the season had seemed to answer.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — I’m not sure what I expected from the Jets on Sunday.

headline: Depression Leaves a Man Adrift, but a Stranger Helps Him Find Purpose
abstract: A Brooklyn man was managing schizophrenia despite a diagnosis at 13. But he continued to struggle with depression, giving up on his education until a chance encounter.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Torres was told he would not amount to much even before he learned at age 13 that he had schizophrenia. His brother called him slow, classmates called him retarded, and he was teased relentlessly.

headline: Cowboys’ Star on the Rise in a Dallas Suburb
abstract: Ford Center at the Star in Frisco, Tex., will house the team’s headquarters, training center, offices and a 12,000-seat indoor stadium that will be shared with area high schools.
lead_paragraph: FRISCO, Tex. — Jerry Jones does not do small. He took the money-losing Dallas Cowboys and turned them into the most valuable team in America. He built AT&T Stadium, the biggest venue in the N.F.L. With the help of lucrative licensing and sponsorship deals, the Cowboys generated $620 million last year, the highest revenue in the league, according to Forbes.

abstract: Dear Abbots, welcome back! Are you ready for a season of bloodless murders and chaste marriage proposals? And the dagger-mouth of Maggie Smith?

lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old woman was killed on New Year’s Day, discovered face down in her bedroom in Queens, the police said; her death is the first homicide in New York City in 2016.

headline: A Soccer Team, Its Foreign Owner and Local Discontent
abstract: Eighteen months after Wang Hui, a Chinese businessman, bought the Dutch soccer club ADO Den Haag, the team is far from being the powerhouse Wang promised to make it.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — A new Chinese owner arrived at the Dutch soccer club ADO Den Haag in early 2014, promising multimillion-dollar investments and better days ahead. Fans of the club liked the sound of that.

lead_paragraph: Here is what is known about the armed group occupying an Oregon wildlife refuge, and their beliefs and demands.

lead_paragraph: James Tutein was always around for his neighbors. He was the one who would hold the door open when they were carrying packages or make room under his umbrella if it was raining outside.

headline: In N.F.L., Black Monday Was Sort of Gray

lead_paragraph: By the standard of the past two N.F.L. seasons, when bullying and domestic violence scandals swamped the league, this season has been tame. But that does not mean the league has operated smoothly.

lead_paragraph: Gene Luen Yang often mines his life for his graphic novels. He has explored being a second-generation American, and harnessed his love of computer programming. Starting this week, he will have a whole new experience to draw on.

headline: The Best of Week 17 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in the league this week.
lead_paragraph: Texans defensive end J. J. Watt was back to his old self, leading a dominant defense that helped the Texans rout the Jaguars and win their first A.F.C. South title since 2012. Watt, playing without a cast for the first time since breaking his left hand on Dec. 9, had three sacks, forced a fumble and recovered another. Watt leads the N.F.L. with 17 ½ sacks. He joined Reggie White as the only players in N.F.L. history to have three 15-sack seasons in their first five years in the league.

headline: What to Watch Monday
abstract: In a new season of “The Bachelor,” a software salesman from Indiana holds the roses. For love without the limo, there’s “Pride and Prejudice,” starring Keira Knightley.
lead_paragraph: The roses have been plucked and the limo lined up for a night of first impressions on the 20th-season premiere of “The Bachelor.” Second glances let love bloom in “Pride and Prejudice.” (The one starring Keira Knightley. Sorry, Colin Firth fans.)

headline: The Growth of Contemporary African Photography at LagosPhoto
abstract: A new book, “Africa Under the Prism,” captures the kaleidoscope of random energy, disorder and color on the continent, from work shown during the arts festival’s first five years.
lead_paragraph: A new book, “Africa Under the Prism,” captures the kaleidoscope of random energy, disorder and color on the continent, from work shown during the arts festival’s first five years.

headline: The Growth of Contemporary African Photography at LagosPhoto
abstract: A new book, “Africa Under the Prism,” captures the kaleidoscope of random energy, disorder and color on the continent, from work shown during the arts festival’s first five years.
lead_paragraph: Lagos is an African megacity humming with chaotic energy. Potholed roads and even the city’s superhighways are crowded with traffic, overloaded vendors, earsplitting noise, choking pollution, piercing colors and powerful smells. Extreme wealth is set against a backdrop of grinding poverty, hope battles despair, daily acts of kindness and generosity are offset by cruelty, greed and corruption, and creativity is inspired by necessity because of the city’s broken infrastructure and the looming threat of ruin. Between these extremes, and usually to the background drone of a generator, exist the rich and textured lives of some 20 million people.

headline: What’s Going On in Our Prisons?
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: New York State needs effective and independent oversight of its troubled prison system.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Strickland’s  barbaric and unnecessary death at the hands of prison guards at the Clinton Correctional Facility in upstate New York highlights the need for independent oversight of the state’s prisons. His beating in 2010, the details of which have only recently come to light, is the latest in a long list of instances of brutality toward inmates in New York’s prison system.

abstract: The difference that 2012 made shows us the stakes involved in 2016.
lead_paragraph: You have to be seriously geeky to get excited when the Internal Revenue Service releases a new batch of statistics. Well, I’m a big geek; like quite a few other people who work on policy issues, I was eagerly awaiting the I.R.S.’s tax tables for 2013, which were released last week.

headline: We Need a New Green Revolution
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Food', 'Research', 'Avian Influenza', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Pesticides', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The United States needs to increase research in agriculture to feed a growing world population in a warming world.
lead_paragraph: DESPITE the four-year drought that has parched California and led to mandatory restrictions on water use, farmers there have kept feeding the country. California produces more of 66 different food crops than any other state, $54 billion of food annually.

headline: Connecticut’s Second-Chance Society
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The state has become a remarkably productive laboratory of criminal justice reform.
lead_paragraph: One day last month, Dannel Malloy, the governor of Connecticut, was sitting with a small group of inmates at a New Haven jail, where he had gone to announce a new job-training program for prisoners nearing their release date.

headline: Trump Did Not Break Politics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: Other politicians remade the rules right in front of our eyes.
lead_paragraph: Politics, we’re often told, is governed by rules — basic principles that explain not just what’s going to happen, but what rational candidates and parties can be expected to do. Donald J. Trump seems to casually defy all these rules — insulting Senator John McCain, a veteran; disparaging women; and building a rhetorical wall to keep out the single demographic group that his party seems to need for its survival, Latinos.

headline: Mexico Stubbornly Resists Accountability
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government', 'Prison Escapes']
abstract: The Mexican government has moved swiftly to whitewash corruption and play down scandals.
lead_paragraph: When he campaigned for the presidency of Mexico, Enrique Peña Nieto used the title of his book, “Mexico, the Great Hope,” to explain the record he hoped to achieve and the nation he hoped to build. More than three years into his presidency, it seems more likely that he will be remembered not as the transformational leader Mexicans thought they had elected, but as a politician who skirted accountability at every turn.

headline: France’s Diminished Liberties
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Constitutions', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'Search and Seizure', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Antiterrorism efforts are threatening a cornerstone of democracy — the equality of all citizens before the law.
lead_paragraph: Since President François Hollande of France declared a state of emergency after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Nov. 13, more than 2,700 police raids have been carried out. They have yielded very little that can be linked to terrorism, but have traumatized citizens and left havoc in their wake.

headline: Accepting the Past, Facing the Future
abstract: What would we be willing to sacrifice to prevent the catastrophes humanity now faces? And why are so many of us not doing so?
lead_paragraph: How do we relate to our past, and what might this tell us about how to relate to our future? One of the most provocative approaches to this question comes from Friedrich Nietzsche, whose doctrine of the eternal return asks this: “What if some day or night a demon were to steal after you into your loneliest loneliness and say to you: ‘This life as you now live it and have lived it, you will have to live once more and innumerable times more’”? To ask myself the question of the eternal return is to wonder about the worth of what I have done, to inquire whether it would stand the test of being done innumerable times again.

headline: Wall St. Slides After Chinese Stocks Plunge
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Company Reports', 'New Year']

headline: ‘The Defender,’ by Ethan Michaeli
abstract: Franklin Roosevelt’s White House feared, threatened and shunned The Chicago Defender for calling out its racism.
lead_paragraph: Franklin Roosevelt held an average of 84 presidential news conferences a year — 14 times the number given by Ronald Reagan and three to four times the output of Bill Clinton, George W. Bush or Barack Obama. Roosevelt charmed the White House press corps to within an inch of its life, leaked big stories to favored reporters and still made time for writers from obscure trade journals and others who were technically ineligible for press credentials. He nevertheless shunned the Negro press, shutting it out of the White House press corps until the last of his 12 years in office. By avoiding fire-breathing newspapers like The Chicago Defender, The Baltimore Afro-American and The Pittsburgh Courier, Roosevelt insulated himself from questions about what ­African-Americans saw as the burning issue of the 1940s: the government’s decision to embrace segregation in the military. Separating military men and women — and even the plasma in the wartime blood bank — by race, the government ratified racial apartheid in the South and introduced Jim Crow segregation into parts of the country where it had been unknown.

headline: Elizabeth Strout’s ‘My Name Is Lucy Barton’
abstract: Strout’s new novel is about a girl’s unquestioning, almost animal love for her mother, and her mother’s love in return.
lead_paragraph: One of this nation’s most abiding myths is that social origins don’t matter. Each of us is Gatsby, or can be, with the potential to be reinvented and obliterate the past. This is nowhere more true than in New York City, where, surrounded by millions, each person supposedly stands upon his or her own merits. If we reach a sophisticated urban consensus on how to speak, how to dress, how to live, then who will know what lies beneath the surface? Who will know what any one of us might really mean by words like “home,” “childhood” or “love”?

headline: 1941: Panama Insists on Sovereignty
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Panama asks the United States to observe the country’s sovereign rights, in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Panama has no objection to cooperating with the United States in the establishment of defenses for the Canal Zone, but asks in return strict regard for the country’s sovereign rights, Dr. Carlos N. Brin, newly appointed Panamanian Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday upon his arrival. Dr. Brin, a graduate of George Washington University, said in reply to another question that he had no special mission other than to ‘‘try and impress the fact that Panama undoubtedly considers the government and people of the United States as her best friend.’’ ‘‘And I hope that the United States will consider us a good friend and treat us as such,’’ he added. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1941

headline: 1966: African-American Becomes Mayor in Ohio
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The first African-American is elected as a city mayor in 1966.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio — A 44-year-old undertaker and campaigner for civic integration took office as Springfield’s first Negro mayor today [Jan. 4] and said: ‘‘This is going to be a big job.’’ Mayor Robert C. Henry was the unanimous choice of the city council last night. He is the first Negro to serve as mayor of a major U.S. city. Four-fifths of the city’s population are white. There are areas where Negroes have settled predominantly, but there is no black ghetto, as in some Northern U.S. cities. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1966

headline: Police Seek Assailant in Fatal Stabbing of Bronx McDonald’s Manager
abstract: The restaurant’s night manager, Adam Garcia, 28, was killed before dawn on Monday while finishing his shift at a store on Broadway in Kingsbridge, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The night manager of a McDonald’s in the Bronx was stabbed to death outside the restaurant before dawn on Monday and the suspect in the killing fled, leading to a hunt for a man the police described as homeless and mentally unbalanced.

headline: Pakistani Censorship ‘Runs Counter’ to Times Values
abstract: A top International Times editor describes how and why a Times story was censored in Pakistani print editions last weekend.
lead_paragraph: The printer’s email came as The International New York Times was going to press in Pakistan, and it was to the point: “We are compelled to remove the article appearing on front page and page 2 of the INYT’s Saturday Jan. 2-3 2016 as it contains comments on the Quran and Prophet Muhammad that can cause serious offence to our readers.”

headline: John Angelo, Investor and Co-Founder of Angelo Gordon, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Angelo started Angelo Gordon with Michael Gordon in 1988, and helped build it into an investment firm with $26 billion in assets.
lead_paragraph: John M. Angelo, who co-founded Angelo Gordon & Company and helped build it into an investment firm that manages $26 billion in assets, died on Friday. He was 74.

headline: Protect Your Child’s ‘PDF': Playtime, Downtime and Family Time
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Homework', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: It’s not just what our children do, but what they don’t do, that counts.
lead_paragraph: Re-entry is not easy.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Barbaric Executions
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: The killings take the region on a foolhardy course and deserve powerful American condemnation.
lead_paragraph: The execution of the popular Shiite cleric Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr and 46 other prisoners on Saturday was about the worst way Saudi Arabia could have started what promises to be a grim and tumultuous year in the kingdom and across the Middle East. It is hard to imagine that the Sunni rulers of the kingdom were not aware of the sectarian passions the killings would unleash around the region. They may even have counted on the fierce reaction in Iran and elsewhere as a distraction from economic problems at home and to silence dissenters. America’s longstanding alliance with the House of Saud is no reason for the Obama administration to do anything less than clearly condemn this foolhardy and dangerous course with a more robust response than its call Monday for both sides to exercise restraint.

headline: Volkswagen Civil Suit
abstract: The Justice Department challenged Volkswagen in federal court, saying that the German automaker installed illegal devices to impair emissions controls, increasing air pollution.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department challenged Volkswagen in federal court, saying that the German automaker installed illegal devices to impair emissions controls, increasing air pollution.

headline: Adele Ends Her 2015 Takeover With a Sixth Week at No. 1
abstract: The singer added 307,000 copies of “25” to her sales tally in the final week of the year; the album has now sold a total of 7.44 million.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to music sales, the last week of 2015 — just like the entire year — belonged to Adele.

headline: Photos Show El Faro’s Resting Place, but Sinking Remains Mystery
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Sonar', 'Recording Equipment']
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board released photographs and video footage of the sunken cargo ship that show a breach in its hull.
lead_paragraph: A weekslong search for the cargo ship El Faro, lost in a hurricane on Oct. 1 with 33 mariners aboard while on a route to San Juan, P.R., from Jacksonville, Fla., ended about a month later with the discovery of its wreckage nearly three miles under the sea. On Sunday, investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board released photographs and video footage captured by remote-controlled underwater vehicles of the sunken ship that show a breach in its hull.

headline: Girl, 15, Is Arrested in Deaths of Mother and Her Boyfriend
abstract: Destiny Garcia was charged with murder in the killings of the Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, couple, whose bodies were found Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The 15-year-old daughter of a woman who was killed along with her boyfriend in Brooklyn was arrested on Monday and charged with two counts of murder, the police said.

headline: Donald Trump, in First Ad, Plays to Fears on Immigration and ISIS
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslim Americans', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Shrouded in darkness, the ad trumpets Mr. Trump’s call to bar Muslims from entering the United States and promises a wall on the Mexican border.
lead_paragraph: After running his campaign on a shoestring for months, thanks to the news media’s obsessive attention, Donald J. Trump has released his first campaign commercial, promising to stop illegal immigration and defeat the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

headline: Giants Close Door on Tom Coughlin Era, Ushering In Uncertainty
abstract: Although Coughlin was one of the Giants’ most successful coaches, especially in the modern era, his last four teams did not qualify for the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tom Coughlin’s smile in the aftermath of Sunday’s loss to the Philadelphia Eagles might have been the biggest tip-off of what was to come.

headline: Migrant Who Walked Channel Tunnel Is Granted Asylum in Britain
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Abdul Rahman Haroun, the Sudanese man who walked from France to England, might still face charges for obstructing a railway engine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Sudanese man who walked the 31 miles through the Channel Tunnel in August only to be arrested in Britain has been granted asylum and can stay in the country, his lawyers said on Monday.

headline: Real Madrid Replaces Rafael Benítez With Zinedine Zidane as Coach
abstract: Real Madrid is switching from one of Europe’s most experienced coaches to a largely untested one.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Real Madrid replaced one of Europe’s most experienced coaches with a largely untested one on Monday, firing the unpopular Rafael Benítez, who had spent only seven months on the job, and appointing Zinedine Zidane.

headline: Facts & Figures: When Will Women Get Equality on Corporate Boards?
abstract: Not for a long time, a new report suggests.
lead_paragraph: Women held about 16 percent of the board seats at S&P 1500 companies in 2014, according to a new report from the Government Accountability Office (GAO).

headline: Leveling Criticism at China’s Elite, Some Borrow Words From the Past
abstract: The term “Zhao family,” from a novella by Lu Xun, has resurfaced as a disparaging stand-in for China’s rich and politically connected.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Once again, the early-20th-century writer Lu Xun, whose scathing critiques of the pre-revolutionary Chinese social order won him a place in the Chinese Communist pantheon, even though he himself was not a Marxist, has provided a popular phrase for much that is amiss in China today.

headline: As Saudi-Iranian Tensions Build
abstract: Readers discuss the fallout from Saudi Arabia’s execution of a Shiite cleric.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Making a Favorite Joke in Boone
abstract: Stop No.1 on Ted Cruz’s 28-town swing of Iowa features a favorite joke.

headline: In a First, Element Will Be Named by Researchers in Japan
abstract: Element 113 is credited to scientists from the Riken institute in Japan, who will bestow an official name more than 12 years after they began their efforts.
lead_paragraph: Since the 19th century, European and American discoveries have monopolized the naming of elements on the periodic table. It is evident in entries like francium, germanium, scandium, polonium, europium, californium, berkelium and americium.

headline: N.F.L. Completes Greatest Passing Season in League History
abstract: The league set records in 2015 for passing attempts, completions and yards per game, as well as for completing percentage and passer rating.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the N.F.L. becomes more passer friendly, in quantity and quality. That trend held true in 2015, which will go down as the greatest passing season in league history.

headline: Review: ‘The Shannara Chronicles,’ an Elfin Adventure, Debuts on MTV
abstract: This series, based on the second book of the fantasy trilogy by Terry Brooks, features characters desperately trying to save a magical tree that protects the world from demons.
lead_paragraph: Terry Brooks’s original “Shannara” trilogy predates much of the name-brand fantasy fiction that has been turned into box-office gold lately. You need to keep reminding yourself of that as you’re watching “The Shannara Chronicles,” MTV’s television adaptation, which begins on Tuesday night. Amberle and Eretria, the saga’s two strongest female characters, might look like Katniss Everdeen knockoffs, but chronologically, Katniss could be either’s daughter.

headline: A Reprieve for Fungus-Battered Frogs
abstract: Researchers on the Spanish island of Majorca have succeeded in eradicating a disease that is devastating amphibians around the world.
lead_paragraph: After a six-year effort, researchers on the Spanish island of Majorca have rid several groups of Majorcan midwife toads of the pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis — better known as chytrid fungus, or B.d. It’s the first time the disease, which is devastating amphibians worldwide, has been eradicated in a wild population.

headline: As Justices Weigh Affirmative Action, Michigan Offers an Alternative
abstract: With the Supreme Court considering a challenge to the affirmative action policy of the University of Texas, campuses like Michigan are finding new ways to attract minorities.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Kedra Ishop got results.

headline: Study Shows Larger Effect of Clouds on El Niño
abstract: The research indicates that cirrus clouds trap the heat coming off the Pacific Ocean, further warming the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Clouds help amplify El Niño’s effect on the atmosphere to a greater degree than once thought, a new study reports.

headline: An Artist Pays Tribute to Her Dog — in Times Square
abstract: A three-minute adaptation of Laurie Anderson’s film, “Heart of a Dog,” can be seen at the end of each day as part of the Midnight Moment program.
lead_paragraph: Since its inception in 2012, the Midnight Moment program has presented the work of prominent artists including Tracey Emin, Jesper Just and Andy Warhol in the unlikeliest of places: on several giant screens right in the middle of Times Square. Each month, Times Square Arts and the Times Square Advertising Coalition choose one artist whose work will be showcased daily over the course of a month in a three-minute video, beginning at 11:57 p.m. and finishing at midnight — an appropriately digestible format.

headline: Amateur Sleuths on the Dinosaur Trail
abstract: With only two field paleontologists, the Forest Service has turned for help to a small group of amateur fossil-hunters, many in their 70s and 80s.
lead_paragraph: COMANCHE NATIONAL GRASSLAND, Colo. — On a dry, chilly morning in the Southern Colorado grasslands, Bruce Schumacher led a group of AmeriCorps volunteers across the narrow, shallow Purgatoire River to an out-of-place bump in the landscape.

headline: An Examination of the Nude Figure in Turkish Art at the Pera Museum
keywords: ['Art', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Women and Girls', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Museums']
abstract: At the Pera Museum in Istanbul a show examines how Turkish artists fought cultural restrictions a century ago in order to paint the nude figure.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — As an increasingly conservative Turkey grapples with questions of free expression, it might seem to be a risky time for an exhibition examining how Turkish artists fought cultural restrictions a century ago in order to paint the nude figure.

headline: European Sympathies Lean Toward Iran in Conflict With Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Capital Punishment', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Iran has long been a pariah, but Saudi Arabia’s embrace of the death penalty and its support of extremist Sunni ideology has hardened some Western attitudes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the days since Saudi Arabia inflamed tensions with Iran by executing 47 people, including a Shiite cleric, European observers have been quick to condemn the action, reflecting broader concern across the Continent about Saudi policy and its role in the tumult rolling through the Middle East.

headline: Healthful School Lunches Mean Healthier Students
abstract: The Healthy Hunger-Free Kids Act, which mandated increased availability of whole grains, vegetables and fruits at schools, means children are eating healthier, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in 2012, a federal law went into effect to improve the nutritional quality of school lunches. The law appears to be working, according to a new report.

headline: Chick-fil-A in Manhattan Closes to Address Health Violations
abstract: The company voluntarily closed the restaurant on Wednesday after city inspectors cited six violations. No date was given for reopening.
lead_paragraph: Chick-fil-A’s Midtown Manhattan restaurant remained closed on Monday for a fifth business day after an inspection by city health officials found several violations, including the presence of fruit flies and food stored at the wrong temperature.

headline: An Effort to Save J.M.W. Turner’s Country House
abstract: With contributions from private donors, an art auction and the government-run Heritage Lottery Fund, the British landscape painter’s Sandycombe Lodge will undergo a renovation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — J. M. W. Turner may not have been as naked in his appetites as his character was in Mike Leigh’s 2014 movie, “Mr. Turner,” but the British landscape painter certainly enjoyed life. Besides a London mansion, Turner kept a modest country house 10 miles southwest of the city in Twickenham that he designed, where he and his father relaxed, fished and entertained.

headline: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?
lead_paragraph: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

headline: Obama to Expand Gun Background Checks and Tighten Enforcement
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Obama’s executive actions on guns will stop short of the kind of large-scale changes that he unsuccessfully sought from Congress three years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will announce executive actions on Tuesday intended to expand background checks for some firearm purchases and step up federal enforcement of the nation’s gun laws, White House officials said Monday, once again trying to sidestep a gridlocked Congress on a politically divisive issue.

headline: Bombings Near Kabul Airport Add to String of Attacks Around Afghan Capital
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: In the more powerful of the Monday attacks, a truck of explosives was rammed into the wall of a compound for foreign and Afghan civilian contractors, killing one and injuring more than 20.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two bombings struck near Kabul’s international airport on Monday, killing one and injuring more than 20, Afghan officials said.

headline: Hillary Clinton Tells Democrats in Iowa: ‘I Need You’
abstract: At the start of a two-day tour of the state, Hillary Clinton said she would seek to improve the Affordable Care Act and backed the president’s proposed executive action on gun control.
lead_paragraph: As her husband tried to stay on message in New Hampshire, Hillary Clinton embarked on a “River to River” tour of Iowa on Monday, with six events across the state over two days.

headline: A Warm and Rejuvenating Winter Tea Recipe
abstract: From one of the co-owner chefs of the Chinatown restaurant Dimes, this goji berry and ginger elixir boosts immunity — and energy levels.
lead_paragraph: “One of coziest things about winter is curling up with a hot drink,” says Alissa Wagner, the co-owner and chef, along with Sabrina De Sousa, behind the chic, health-conscious Chinatown restaurant Dimes. In her mug for the new year: rejuvenating goji berry and ginger tea, which will be added to the menu this month. “It’s packed with ingredients to boost the immune system and even has maca powder for a blast of energy — a crucial bonus to help get through those long winter days,” Wagner notes. She suggests doubling the simple recipe and keeping a jar in the fridge so the tea can be warmed up at a moment’s notice.

headline: Review: ‘Killing Fields,’ on Discovery, Examines a Cold Case
abstract: This series mixes elements of reality television and documentary in looking at a 1997 killing in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: To the bubbling mini-genre of long-form true crime — “Serial,” “The Jinx,” “Making a Murderer” — add “Killing Fields,” a new series starting on Tuesday on Discovery. At six episodes, or just over four hours minus commercials, it’s at the shorter end of the spectrum when it comes to season-long examinations of a single criminal case.

headline: Fliers Go Their Own Way With Airline Meals
abstract: The alternatives for those who travel frequently on business can include taking food from home or shopping just before a flight.
lead_paragraph: Business travelers have plenty to think about when they fly. Once wheels come up, laptops land on the tray table. But diving into spreadsheets, business plans and email requires sustenance.

headline: Death Sentences Surge, Even as More Countries Drop Capital Punishment
abstract: Amnesty International found a 28 percent increase in the number of people sentenced to death in 2014, as some countries resumed capital punishment after suspending it for years.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The death penalty is steadily receding toward the dustbin of history worldwide, with fewer than two dozen countries relying on it at all as a form of punishment.

headline: G.M.’s Investment in Lyft Hedges Against a Future With Fewer Car Owners
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: With the rise of self-driving cars, shared ownership and ride-hailing, people may buy fewer cars in the future. General Motors’ large stake in Lyft could help it navigate these trends.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is hedging against incursions from Silicon Valley. The Detroit carmaker’s $500 million stake in Lyft is a way into the growing ride-hailing industry and brings another partner in the development of autonomous vehicles. The deal taps into potential changes in car ownership and usage — and even employment.

headline: Hezbollah Attacks Israeli Military Vehicles
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The militant group said the assault in a disputed border area was a response to Israel’s killing of Samir Kuntar, a Hezbollah operative, last month.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hezbollah attacked Israeli military vehicles on Monday in a disputed border territory, an assault the militant group said was in response to Israel’s killing last month of Samir Kuntar, a key Hezbollah operative in Syria.

headline: Review: In Julian Barnes’s ‘Keeping an Eye Open,’ Paintings Worth a Thousand Words
abstract: The novelist focuses his critical eye on the works of familiar artists like Degas, Braque and Magritte, as well as the work of lesser-known masters.
lead_paragraph: Gustave Flaubert — the subject of Julian Barnes’s magical novel-biography-meditation, “Flaubert’s Parrot” — argued that great paintings required no words of explanation. But as Mr. Barnes writes in “Keeping an Eye Open,” an illuminating new collection of essays on art, “we remain incorrigibly verbal creatures who love to explain things” — “put us in front of a picture and we chatter, each in our different way.”

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Billybob’s Beef Brisket and the N.S.A.
abstract: Ted Cruz’s microphone went out during his second stop on his Iowa bus tour, and President Obama and the National Security Agency took the blame.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Activision Buys Major League Gaming to Broaden Role in E-Sports
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The video game company hopes to build a mainstream audience for competitive video gaming through a cable channel.
lead_paragraph: Activision Blizzard, the publisher of Call of Duty and other hit video game franchises, has acquired the assets of Major League Gaming, an early organizer of professional video game competitions.

abstract: Afghanistan and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 4, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Egypt, Iran and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Egypt, Iran and India.

headline: Checking Out Pusha T’s Closet
abstract: The Virginia-based rapper favors John Elliott, By Walid and Rolex, not to mention his own Adidas line.
lead_paragraph: Pusha T, 38, who is based in Norfolk, Va., has been involved in nearly every major facet of the hip-hop world, beginning with his early days as half of the duo Clipse. He recently signed on as president of Kanye West’s record label G.O.O.D. Music, and his latest album, “King Push: Darkest Before Dawn — the Prelude,” was released on Dec. 18. Here, five favorites from his diverse closet.

headline: Behind a Shopping Center in New Jersey, Signs of a Mass Extinction
abstract: For decades, a quarry provided sand used for water filtration. Now it’s lush with fossil discoveries and opened annually to the public.
lead_paragraph: MANTUA TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Behind a Lowe’s home improvement store here, scientists are methodically scraping and sifting through a quarry pit that may contain unique insights to the mass extinction that eliminated the dinosaurs.

headline: Verbatim: Hillary Clinton Won’t Respond to Donald Trump’s ‘Alternate Reality’
abstract: Hillary Clinton says she won’t respond to Donald J. Trump’s “alternate reality.”
lead_paragraph: — Hillary Clinton, to a voter in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on Monday when asked about Donald J. Trump’s attacks

headline: Review: Exploring the Work of Delia Derbyshire, an Unsung (but Often Heard) Pioneer
abstract: The ensemble Counter)induction and the clarinetist Benjamin Fingland presented this program at Spectrum, which also included other contemporary composers.
lead_paragraph: The theme from the BBC science fiction series “Dr. Who” is instantly recognizable. Less well known are the contributions of Delia Derbyshire, the pioneering British composer who arranged Ron Grainer’s score for that show into its more famous electronic incarnation.

headline: Reviews: Classical Music Albums
abstract: Cellos and pianos compete, American symphonies have Teutonic titles, and a Steinway system creates new kinds of duets.
lead_paragraph: Alisa Weilerstein, cello; Inon Barnatan, piano

headline: Gianandrea Noseda to Lead National Symphony Orchestra
abstract: The Italian conductor, who will become music director of this Washington-based ensemble, is now leading the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in “The Pearl Fishers.”
lead_paragraph: Gianandrea Noseda, an Italian conductor whose international career has recently taken off, has accepted his first major post with an American orchestra. He will be the next music director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, the orchestra announced on Monday.

headline: Broadway Has a Record-Breaking Week
abstract: Broadway had its best attended and highest grossing week ever.
lead_paragraph: If Broadway needs a New Year’s resolution for 2016, it might try ending the year the way it did in 2015.

headline: Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, Won’t Seek Re-election to the House
abstract: Mr. McDermott, one of the most liberal members of the House and a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee, announced he would retire at the end of his 14th term this year.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington and one of the most liberal members of the House, announced Monday that he would retire at the end of the year, ending a tumultuous 14-term congressional career.

headline: On David Bowie’s ‘Blackstar,’ Turning to Jazz for Inspiration
abstract: David Bowie, whose music has been as changeable as his image, enlisted the Donny McCaslin Quartet, a rugged jazz-rock combo, for his new album.
lead_paragraph: A lot of questions arose when David Bowie unveiled “Blackstar,” the 10-minute title track of his new album, as a music video in November. What was the meaning of the clip’s sci-fi surrealism? What had inspired its ominous lyrics? And, perhaps more practically, who were these musicians helping to shape its gnarly but limber style?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

abstract: The most popular stories of the year from the Real Estate section.

headline: The Migrant Effort to Cross the English Channel
abstract: From Calais, France, migrants fleeing Syria’s conflict hop onto trucks or moving trains in a desperate — and often futile — effort to reach England.
lead_paragraph: From Calais, France, migrants fleeing Syria’s conflict hop onto trucks or moving trains in a desperate — and often futile — effort to reach England.

headline: Birth Control Without Seeing a Doctor: Oregon Now, More States Later
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: As of Jan. 1, women in Oregon can get contraceptives directly from a pharmacy, without having to go to a doctor first. Here are answers to a few questions about the new law.
lead_paragraph: As of Jan. 1, women in Oregon can get contraceptives directly from a pharmacy, without having to go to a doctor first. Here are answers to a few questions about the new law.

headline: Thom Browne Brings a Designer’s Eye to Cooper Hewitt Show
abstract: The designer will pack an installation with mirrors, shiny wallpaper and other reflective objects.
lead_paragraph: Silver-plated shoes in pairs on the floor. Spectral figures, dressed in white, lying on gurneys in an operating theater. Row after row of identically clad schoolboys, standing at attention behind identical desks. For years, the fashion designer Thom Browne has treated industry insiders to presentations that look more like art installations than like a typical runway show. This March, when the exhibition “Thom Browne Selects” opens at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum on Fifth Avenue, ordinary civilians will finally get to experience Mr. Browne’s theatrical sensibility firsthand.

headline: Report Finds Juvenile Program Failed to Reduce Robberies, but Police Are Expanding It
abstract: Despite the lack of success shown in a 2014 report, police officials say the Juvenile Robbery Intervention Program is valuable because of the good will it creates.
lead_paragraph: For years, the New York Police Department has tried to stop robberies before they might happen by intervening in the lives of some young offenders. The approach was heralded by the author Malcolm Gladwell in a best-selling 2013 book as an innovative way to shake up the criminal justice process. Elected leaders gave $2 million over the last two years in support.

headline: Yahoo Shuts Down Its Video Portal
abstract: The end of Yahoo Screen is a sign of the Internet company’s shrinking video ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, spent much of the last two years telling Wall Street that video was a cornerstone of her turnaround strategy.

headline: Iran, Emerging From Sanctions, Faces Crisis After Saudi Arabia Embassy Attack
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Capital Punishment', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Shiite Muslims', 'International Relations']
abstract: Some Iranians are wondering whether Saudi Arabia has again gained the upper hand in a new diplomatic crisis.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — When a Saudi state executioner beheaded the prominent Shiite dissident Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr on Saturday, the Shiite theocracy in Iran took it as a deliberate provocation by its regional rival and dusted off its favored playbook, unleashing hard-liner anger on the streets.

headline: Donald Trump Finally Buys TV Ads, and Lots of Them
abstract: Donald J. Trump had promised to spend at least $2 million a week on advertising, and he has already reserved nearly that much through Jan. 12.
lead_paragraph: After months of waiting, Donald J. Trump has followed through on his promise to advertise, and advertise big, in early voting states in January.

headline: Bipartisan Criminal Justice Overhaul Is Haunted by Willie Horton
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The 1988 presidential campaign that saw the furlough of a Massachusetts inmate has helped stall legislation that has support from both parties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Conservatives and liberals embrace it. Some of the most influential members of the House and Senate on both the Republican and Democratic sides are pushing it. Advocacy groups across the ideological spectrum are promoting it as well.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: A Daughter’s Tantrum, and a Lesson
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz recalled a tantrum from his then-three-year-old daughter Caroline, and used it as an allegory for America.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Dangerous Sectarian Game
abstract: The Saudi royals think that stoking hatred of Shiites will keep them in power.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Saudi Arabia executed the Shiite cleric and political dissident Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr on Saturday, the country’s leaders were aware that doing so would upset their longtime rivals in Iran. In fact, the royal court in Riyadh was probably counting on it. It got what it wanted. The deterioration of relations has been precipitous: Protesters in Tehran sacked Saudi Arabia’s embassy; in retaliation, Saudi Arabia severed diplomatic ties. More severe fallout could follow — possibly even war.

headline: G.M. Chief Mary Barra Is Named Chairwoman, Affirming Her Leadership
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Mary Barra is credited with stabilizing G.M. after the company admitted to selling millions of cars with defective ignition switches that were later tied to at least 124 deaths.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In a move that consolidates power at the top of the nation’s largest automaker, General Motors said on Monday that its chief executive, Mary Barra, had also been named chairwoman of its board.

headline: Streets, if Not the Air, Clear Out as Delhi Tests Car Restrictions
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Automobiles', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The experiment has riled many of the Indian capital’s elite even as its ability to reduce pollution remains unclear, with air quality still at “hazardous” levels Monday.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Traffic was flowing smoothly Monday morning on Outer Ring Road in South Delhi, usually jammed at that hour by subway construction and cars. An upscale market was dotted with free parking spaces. Monkeys ambled down one street in the colonial heart of the capital, easily dodging the few cars.

headline: Libya: Islamic State Attacks Oil Port
abstract: Islamic State militants attempted to capture an oil port along Libya’s coast, in fighting that left at least seven people dead and set fire to a storage tank of crude oil.
lead_paragraph: Islamic State militants attempted to capture an oil port along Libya’s coast early Monday, in fighting that left at least seven people dead and set fire to a storage tank of crude oil, according to witnesses. The militants began their assault on the Sidra oil port with suicide bomb attacks on a checkpoint, but by Monday afternoon, the offensive had been beaten back by guards. The Islamic State in Libya is regarded as one of the most dangerous affiliates of the extremist group outside of Iraq and Syria, and has gained strength in Libya by capitalizing on infighting among various armed factions. The attack on Monday was at least the second by the Islamic State on the Sidra port, and showed the determination of the group to expand its territory beyond its stronghold in the western Libyan town of Surt.

headline: Illinois: City Lawyer Quits After Judge Finds Misconduct
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: A federal judge found that he and a colleague had committed misconduct by waiting to turn over key evidence in a civil case about a police shooting.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for the City of Chicago resigned Monday as a federal judge found that he and a colleague had committed misconduct by waiting to turn over key evidence in a civil case about a police shooting. The lawyer, Jordan Marsh, resigned on the same day Judge Edmond E. Chang of United States District Court threw out a jury’s verdict that cleared the officers of wrongdoing and ordered Chicago to pay the plaintiffs’ legal bills. Thomas Aumann, the other lawyer, resigned in August. The ruling involves a 2011 traffic stop that ended in the fatal shooting of Darius Pinex by officers who said radio traffic had led them to pull over his vehicle. The radio recordings were not turned over to lawyers for Mr. Pinex’s estate until the trial had started, and Judge Chang said Mr. Marsh “intentionally concealed” them. Also Monday, the acting chief of Chicago’s much-criticized Independent Police Review Authority announced staffing changes that she said were designed to build trust in the agency, which has rarely faulted officers for shootings.

headline: Confidence Games
abstract: Insight, or not thinking it through?
lead_paragraph: OK, one more round in this models versus instincts go-round. As Robert Waldmann points out over at Brad’s place, there’s a bit of bait-and-switch going on at this point; my Mundell-Fleming claim — that countries in a liquidity trap borrowing in their own currencies shouldn’t fear Greek-style confidence crises — is being transmuted into the claim that confidence never matters, and the Blanchard result that is being cited has little bearing on that assertion.

It could not bring itself, at least in public, to condemn the execution of a dissident cleric who challenged the royal family, for fear of undermining the fragile Saudi leadership that it desperately needs in fighting the Islamic State and ending the conflict in Syria.

lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — When Charles Gwathmey died in the summer of 2009, New York City lost one of its most prolific and influential architects. Adherents of the strict rationalism of Modernist design, Mr. Gwathmey and his partner, Robert Siegel, had still managed to infuse their clean lines and grand geometries with warmth and humanity in more than 400 projects spanning four decades, including the expansion of the Guggenheim Museum and a new building for the United States Mission to the United Nations.

headline: The Cultural Contours of Saving a Life
abstract: I could keep pounding on the patient’s chest, but the tiny Liberian hospital lacked the resources to keep her alive.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, while I was still a fledgling doctor in training, I worked in a tiny rural hospital in a village in West Africa. By our American standards, the word “hospital” would have been a fictional exaggeration of this barest-bones facility, but here, on the Liberia-Sierra Leone border, it was the only place that offered people access to Western medicine, should they seek it. The next hospital over — bigger but not much shinier — was at least a six-hour drive away in a four-wheel-drive all-terrain vehicle on a good day, without any rains melting the treacherous dirt roads. About two weeks after I arrived there, I was caring for a young woman who was seriously ill. At that point, I was bold enough to take charge medically, but still barely able to see the outline of the big picture — the cultural contours within which I should have been operating.

headline: The Empty Threat of ‘Boots on the Ground’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'English Language', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Politicians twist themselves into knots to say we should or should not send troops to the Middle East — trying to wage war without actually sacrificing bodies.
lead_paragraph: Since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, the United States has fought two very long, very costly and, in the end, not very successful wars. Barack Obama was elected president in no small part because he promised to bind up the nation’s wounds and withdraw its troops. Yet the enemy, in the forms of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State, remains and must be confronted, in part, the Obama administration believes, by the American military. The president has struggled to find a language that distinguishes between force, which most Americans want, and war, which they don’t. He and his team have therefore promised, vowed, pledged that, come what may, they will not use ‘‘boots on the ground.’’

headline: To Catch a Rapist
abstract: A special-victims unit fights the hidden epidemic of sexual assault that is disturbingly difficult to investigate.
lead_paragraph: A dull, frigid winter morning. Overhead, the sky was locked in gray, only occasionally releasing an ashen, icy flake or two, more like iron shavings than snow. On the third floor of the New Haven police station, Detective Kris Cuddy had just finished interviewing the mother of a young rape victim. After escorting the woman downstairs, she was returning to her office in the Special Victims Unit. Her square-heeled boots made a quick, hard sound as she left the elevators, a tock-tock-tock that could be heard above the ringing phones and cubicle chatter. The detective had an Irish face — blue-eyed, pale-skinned, puckish, her coppery brown hair shorn close at the sides into a fauxhawk. She was one of only four investigators in the S.V.U., and she had 32 cases open at the moment. But during interviews with victims or their family members, she never displayed any sign of the pressure she was under. Her manner was steady and reassuring. So we’re here to discuss an incident that happened recently, she would begin, making only a vague allusion to the matter at hand before stepping back to allow people to tell the story in their own way. She would offer water, offer a tissue. Let them talk, circling back later to gather more details. At the end of interviews with victims, she almost always told them they were brave.

headline: 1891: Battles With Indians
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Battles between United States troops and the Sioux are fought in 1891.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — There was a severe engagement last night [Jan. 4] between the United States forces under the command of General Miles and the Sioux, near Gordon, Nebraska. The fighting was desperate, and the Hotchkiss guns were freely used by the military. The details of the engagement are not to hand. There is a rumor that General Miles was killed in the battle, but this is not credited at army headquarters. According to a telegram received late to-day at Chicago, a battle between the troops and the Indians was fought to-day near the Pine Ridge Agency. Hundreds of Indians were killed, and the troops also suffered heavily. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1891

headline: 1941: Mexico Reports New Nazi Plot
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A plot by Nazis against the United States is discovered by Mexico in 1941.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Nazi agents were reported on high authority today [Jan. 5] to be making progress in a newly conceived plan to disrupt preparedness activities in their hemisphere by urging Mexico and other American republics to try to collect huge cash demands from the Roosevelt administration before committing themselves further on continental defense unity. These German agents, with headquarters in Mexico City and Madrid, were said already to have split the Cabinet of President Avila Camacho into two camps. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1941

headline: How Moby Begins Every Single Morning
abstract: The musician is banning bad habits in the year ahead and sticking to healthier routines — including his daily breakfast smoothies. Here’s his recipe.
lead_paragraph: “My biggest hope for the new year is that we, collectively, stop doing things that we all know don’t work,” says Moby. “We all know which things are bad and not working, but we keep doing them anyway, which is, simply, stupid.” One thing that does work for the musician: his daily breakfast smoothie, which he’s adapted over eight years from a simple banana, kale and berry recipe. It has evolved to include specialty supplements like omega-rich DHA oil and protein-packed chia seeds; now, he says, “It’s like drinking a giant antioxidant battery every morning.” A version is available on the menu at Little Pine, the new all-day dining vegan restaurant Moby recently opened in Silver Lake, Los Angeles — though, he admits, “The rest of the Little Pine menu is a little less virtuous.”

abstract: A physical therapist describes the powerful bonds she formed with the wounded veterans and her fellow physical and occupational therapists at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
lead_paragraph: Last week I was at the wedding of an old co-worker. There was a big cast there, all past employees (physical and occupational therapists) from the amputee section of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Included in the mix was a former patient I recognized immediately, though I did not remember his injuries. That I remembered his face, but not the fact that he was missing both arms and a leg at the groin, caught me totally off guard.

headline: Thanks to El Niño, Thirsty California Is Suddenly All Wet

lead_paragraph: A procession of storms pushing across the Pacific is bringing at least five days of rain and snow to California, a bit of relief for a state sapped by four years of drought.

headline: Finding a Common Thread in the Al Jazeera Doping Report

lead_paragraph: When last seen, Charles Sly starred in a do-it-yourself YouTube confession in which he insisted that everything he had said to an undercover Al Jazeera reporter about banned substances and professional athletes, including Peyton Manning and Ryan Howard, had been a fabulous lie.

headline: In ‘American Crime’ Season 2, a Rape Accusation Raises Troubling Questions
abstract: This ABC series takes a searing look at race, class and homophobia through the prism of a sexual assault charge.
lead_paragraph: The title “American Crime” is both generic (you might mistake it for FX’s coming “American Crime Story,” about the O. J. Simpson case) and grandiose. It offers not just to tell a story but to deliver a diagnosis: to identify a sin that is distinctive to, and an indictment of, an entire nation.

headline: Gerard and Kelly to Perform at Schindler House  and Glass House
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Art', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Finances', 'Glass', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Museums', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In a collaboration with Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project, Gerard and Kelly explore themes of queer intimacy “within the legacies of modernist architecture.”
lead_paragraph: Architecture and performance art have gone together at least since Yves Klein’s “Leap Into the Void,” his 1960 photomontage that makes it look as if he is swan-diving from the ledge of an elegant mansard roof. Beginning this weekend, the dancers and visual artists Brennan Gerard and Ryan Kelly will use two of the country’s most beloved 20th-century houses – the Schindler House, designed by Rudolph M. Schindler in West Hollywood, Calif., and the Glass House, Philip Johnson’s masterpiece in New Canaan, Conn. – as walk-in texts for a performance work focusing on what they describe as “themes of queer intimacy and domestic space within the legacies of modernist architecture.”

headline: A Beer With Russell Tovey, a Star of ‘A View From the Bridge’
abstract: No postshow histrionics for this 34-year-old actor after another performance of “A View From the Bridge.” Just a quick bite with his bulldog Rocky, and the subway home.
lead_paragraph: Five nights and three afternoons a week, Rocky, a little French bulldog, naps under the vanity table of Russell Tovey’s tiny and bright Broadway dressing room. The many things on top of it include a tidy pile of fan letters, a jar of Lubriderm, a jar of extra-crunchy Skippy and a check for $20 from an admirer — for beers.

headline: Blizzard Buried Some Dairy Cows in the Snow; 35,000 Die
abstract: More than 35,000 dairy cows died after a two-day storm hit West Texas and New Mexico on Dec. 26, leaving farmers unable to reach them amid gusts of 80 miles per hour and 14-foot snow drifts.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Tex. — After a mild and dry Christmas Day, a fierce blizzard whipped across the rolling plains of West Texas and eastern New Mexico. The wind blew mercilessly for 48 hours, leaving snow drifts as high as 14 feet.

headline: Thai Street Food, Now at the Lucky Bee on the Lower East Side
abstract: Also, Biang moves to the East Village, Chinese dry-pot cooking at MaLa Project, and meatballs to take home at Maroni Hot Pots.
lead_paragraph: The Lucky Bee Rupert Noffs and his business partner, the chef Matty Bennett, are taking a farm-to-table approach to Thai street food. It’s easy for Mr. Bennett, who was at the Fat Radish, a locavore spot. The setting, dominated by a big bar, is splashed with vibrant pink. “The pink was my idea,” said Mr. Noffs, “and I think it works.” In the front, snacks like salt-and-pepper chicken wings and oysters with nahm jim chile sauce are dispensed. The menu has crisp pork belly with palm sugar caramel and chile vinegar; grilled squid with sunchokes, coconut and shaved bottarga; and a green curry of vegetables with pickled mustard greens. The cocktail list features drinks made with honey: A dollar of each drink sold goes to the New York City Beekeepers Association. The partners hope to raise bees on the roof: 252 Broome Street (Ludlow Street), 917-262-0329, luckybeenyc.com.

abstract: Tom Coughlin’s last act as Giants coach, like his first 12 years ago, was an emotional, high-energy oration, leaving many in his audience, including Eli Manning, fighting back tears.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The day he was hired as Giants coach 12 years ago, Tom Coughlin stepped to a lectern and launched into a speech that had all the fire-and-brimstone rhetoric of a pastor lecturing a congregation. His message was one of restoration, a how-to on building a winner from the ashes of a team that had lost 12 of 16 games the previous season.

keywords: ['ANGLICAN CHURCHES', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: A response to a Catholic academic’s argument about how the church might change.
lead_paragraph: I’ve taken a little time off from obsessive coverage of things Catholic since the invitation to argument (that sounds better than “declaration of war,” right?) I issued to certain Catholic academics and my First Things lecture on conservative Catholicism’s Francis-era crisis. But now that we’re in the New Year I want to respond to one of the most in-depth rejoinders to my forays, which was supplied by John W. Martens of the University of Saint Thomas, writing for America Magazine.

Salad dumped out of a bag, or some out-of-season steamed asparagus or roasted brussels sprouts — these basics let us check the “green” box. But they are hardly inspiring.
