headline: Deadly Snits
abstract: Why do small things inspire white rage?
lead_paragraph: Josh Marshall has a great term for what is happening in Oregon: white privilege performance art. We have people engaging in armed insurrection over the vast oppression of being asked to pay a small fee when grazing their animals on public land; surely an important part of the story is the fact that the perpetrators know that they won’t face the consequences that would follow if, you know, some nonwhite group pulled a similar stunt — and they’re be Fox News heroes forever after.

headline: Review: Jennifer Lopez as a Conflicted Cop in ‘Shades of Blue’
abstract: Ms. Lopez plays a corrupt Brooklyn detective and Ray Liotta her boss in Adi Hasak’s police series that begins Thursday on NBC.
lead_paragraph: On “Law & Order,” the show that anchored NBC for years, things were generally pretty straightforward: crime, investigation, arrest, prosecution. Nothing is straightforward on “Shades of Blue,” the network’s newest police show, which begins on Thursday. Jennifer Lopez plays a dirty Brooklyn detective on a crew full of them, and the choices that confront her and others aren’t between right and wrong, but between damage-control options.

headline: Review: ‘Living on Paper,’ Seven Decades of Letters From Iris Murdoch
abstract: Though she was prolific as an author, Murdoch found time to commit hours to her correspondence. Fans, friends and lovers were the beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: Every letter, in its way, is a love letter, at least every personal one. The letters of the British novelist and philosopher Iris Murdoch contained more yearning than most. She was, to borrow the title of one of her novels, a kind of sacred and profane love machine.

headline: American Dance Institute to Move to Catskill, N.Y.

Now American Dance Institute is moving north: It announced on Tuesday that it would build a new headquarters at a former lumberyard in Catskill, N.Y.

headline: Help Sought to Close 18-Minute Gap in San Bernardino Inquiry
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Amid signs that the investigation is slowing down, they issued a public appeal for help from anyone who might have information on an 18-minute window before the couple were killed in a shootout with the police.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — Federal investigators announced Tuesday that they had accounted for almost all the four hours between the time that a husband-and-wife terrorist team killed 14 people at a holiday party here last month and the time that they died in a bloody police shootout — all except for an 18-minute window.

headline: A Cold Remedy You Can Make at Home
abstract: This recipe for a Kombucha-based elixir, from the new Naturopathica Chelsea outpost, includes ginger, lemongrass — and horseradish and cayenne.
lead_paragraph: “In retrospect, I think I was a little ahead of my time,” says Barbara Close, the founder and CEO of the healing-arts brand Naturopathica. When she opened her East Hampton store in 1995, people would stop in and “take these herbal tinctures and say, ‘Ooh, these taste bitter’ — they didn’t really understand how to use them,” she recalls. Back then, she says, the path to health was: “You get sick, you hope to get an appointment with your doctor, you get a prescription and it treats your symptoms. Now, wellness has become mainstream.” And the biggest change, according to Close, may be how we approach it: “It’s the periods in between doctor appointments that are important. What are the rituals of self-care that you can do preventatively to keep your health and vitality at its best?” She offers answers aplenty at Naturopathica Chelsea, her second brick-and-mortar location.

headline: ‘13 Hours’ Gives Benghazi Attack Cinematic Treatment

headline: With Film Supply Dwindling, a Photographer Known for Huge Polaroid Images Is Retiring
abstract: Elsa Dorfman turned one of the world’s most unwieldy cameras, a 20-inch-by-24-inch Polaroid, into an instrument of warmth and intimacy.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — To make a good portrait, the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson once counseled, “you have to try and put your camera between the skin of a person and his shirt.” It would be tricky for any portraitist, but especially daunting for Elsa Dorfman. Her camera is taller than she is, weighs as much as an N.F.L. linebacker and looks, from certain vantage points, like a 1970s liquor cabinet.

headline: Adele Album Resists the Streaming Trend in Music Sales
abstract: While CD and download sales continued to plunge in 2015, and streaming shot up, Adele’s “25” — an album not available for streaming — was the exception.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, the prevailing theme in the recorded music business has been that CD and download sales were plunging while streaming has shot up quickly, as listening habits shift online.

headline: The Hear-Nothing Gun Crowd
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The current fight over gun control is a howling storm of misrepresentation, sadly almost entirely from one side.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes in American politics it seems as if we are all talking past each other, that whatever one side says about an issue like, say, taxes zooms right past the other side. The current fight over gun control is not one of those moments. It is a howling storm of misrepresentation, sadly almost entirely from one side. This week’s developments fit the pattern.

headline: Michigan: Emergency Declared Over Flint’s Water
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan declared a state of emergency for the Flint area as concerns grew about the health effects of lead-tainted water there.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan declared a state of emergency for the Flint area on Tuesday as concerns grew about the health effects of lead-tainted water there. His order, which followed emergency declarations by the city and county governments, came on the day federal officials announced an investigation of the contamination. Mr. Snyder’s administration has been criticized as slow to respond to residents’ concerns about their water. Last week, he apologized and announced staffing changes at the state agency that oversees environmental quality. Flint, which had long received water from Lake Huron provided by Detroit’s water utility, began drawing its water from the Flint River in 2014 in an effort to save money while a new pipeline was built. Residents soon complained about rashes and strange odors from the river water, but city and state officials mostly insisted that it was safe to drink. Last year, elevated levels of lead were found in children’s blood, and in October, Flint switched back to Detroit’s water system. Mr. Snyder, a Republican, said Tuesday that the emergency declaration would allow for more state resources to be used in addressing the effects of the tainted water.

headline: Judge Rules for Cosby’s Wife
abstract: Camille Cosby will not have to sit for a deposition Wednesday in a lawsuit filed against her husband, Bill Cosby, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled.
lead_paragraph: Camille Cosby will not have to sit for a deposition Wednesday in a lawsuit filed against her husband, the entertainer Bill Cosby, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled Tuesday, as he granted Mrs. Cosby’s request to postpone any deposition until her lawyers have a chance to appeal.

headline: Pickups and S.U.V.s Lead Way to a Record Year for Automakers

lead_paragraph: Six years after plunging sales during the recession forced automakers into bankruptcies and painful restructuring, the industry has roared back to achieve new heights.

headline: Why the Government Owns So Much Land in the West
abstract: Understanding the dispute in Oregon requires a look at American history, and how geography, climate and politics shaped “the frontier.”
lead_paragraph: The United States government owns 47 percent of all land in the West. In some states, including Oregon, Utah and Nevada, the majority of land is owned by the federal government. Of course, it used to own nearly all of it.

headline: Las Vegas News Staff Advised on Covering Adelson
abstract: Reporters and editors at The Las Vegas Review-Journal were given guidelines for how the paper should cover its new owner, the billionaire Republican donor Sheldon Adelson.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the billionaire casino mogul Sheldon Adelson acquired The Las Vegas Review-Journal last month, the newspaper’s reporters and editors have agonized over whether their coverage of Mr. Adelson and his business interests would be compromised.

headline: This Land Is Your Land. Or Is It?
abstract: The armed protesters in Oregon are acting on an idea of property that is intellectually bankrupt.
lead_paragraph: Since last weekend, armed men have been in control of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon. Incensed by the sentencing of local ranchers to jail time for burning public lands, the protesters want the federal government out of the land business. Their stated goal is to return the refuge to the locals so that “people can reclaim their resources.” But this raises an important question: Why does justice demand that the land and resources belong to the locals instead of the commons? What makes property private?

headline: Bank Rule Distorting Performance Is Repealed

lead_paragraph: An “Alice in Wonderland” accounting rule that allowed stressed banks to book huge gains simply because they were stressed has been overturned.

headline: Venezuela Opposition Takes Reins of Assembly as Tensions Rise
abstract: The opposition achieved a landslide victory in elections in early December, winning two-thirds of the 167 seats in the Assembly and breaking with a long period of domination by the socialist movement.

headline: To San Bernardino, Obama’s Gun Plan Goes Too Far or Falls Short
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Opinions on President Obama’s plan to expand background checks run the gamut in the city, but many residents seem to agree that it will do little to stop mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — The fear comes up in discussions in line at the movies, where a group of mothers say there are too many guns on the streets for them to feel safe. For others, the mass shooting that killed 14 people here last month has prompted a rush to buy a gun for the first time, suddenly convincing them that only a firearm can protect them.

headline: 40 Alumni Assert Sexual Abuse at a Rhode Island Prep School
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']

lead_paragraph: It was never happening. Not the way it unfolded, anyway. But that did not stop the Mets from pushing aggressively to bring baseball’s most electrifying player to a team on the rise. Imagine Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza, who might make up this year’s Cooperstown class, sharing the middle of the lineup in Flushing. The Mets sure did.

Settlers caught rainwater in tanks and grazed their livestock across public land that had yet to be brought under government control.

headline: ‘See Also’ Notations
abstract: Jules P. Markey makes us look both ways.

It’s mostly because when you’re in the solving zone — that elusive feeling where you start solving and your writing implement hand doesn’t stop moving or your hands don’t stop typing until the entire grid is filled — it’s frustrating to have to stop and look for another clue somewhere else in the grid. It interrupts one’s solving CHI, as it were.

headline: Up With Extremism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Gun Control']
abstract: Here’s the radical campaign platform we need. We’re just not ready for it.
lead_paragraph: From its very inception, Donald Trump’s campaign for president has been life imitating Twitter. His candidacy is built on Twitter bursts and insults that touch hot buttons, momentarily salve anxieties and put a fist through the face of political correctness, but without any credible programs for implementation.

headline: Putin’s Year in Scandals
abstract: Russia is a mafia state, not only because it is run like the mafia but also because it is run by organized crime.
lead_paragraph: GOING into 2016, Vladimir V. Putin is a very different politician from the one he was a year ago. His most significant changes have little to do with what he has done in the last 12 months. Instead they were wrought by the justice systems of two foreign countries — Britain and Spain — and a slew of Russian and Western journalists and activists. Thanks to all these disparate efforts, there has emerged a vivid, comprehensive and, most important, public picture of allegations of corruption and connections to organized crime that in the past had been the province of rumors or maverick investigations publishers wouldn’t dare to print.

headline: ­In Oregon, Myth Mixes With Anger
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal Lands', 'Ranches', 'Environment', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: The West won’t be won by ideologues brandishing guns and seizing government property.
lead_paragraph: TO outsiders, one of the puzzling aspects of the anti-government militia’s takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge is its location. Twenty-five million birds a year visit the refuge in the high desert of southeastern Oregon, but few people have heard of it. Yet Malheur is a place of bitterly contested human histories that remain potent today.

headline: Purity, Disgust and Donald Trump
abstract: What wellspring of feeling is the leading Republican candidate tapping into that his opponents aren’t?
lead_paragraph: What has Donald Trump tapped into that other Republican candidates are missing? I posed this question to some of my best sources.

abstract: Some will wear a headscarf in solidarity with Muslim women. Others say that only perpetuates the sexist dogma of conservative clerics.

headline: On Display at CES, Tech Ideas in Their Awkward Adolescence
keywords: ['International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Electronics', 'Wearable Computing', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: Plenty of groundbreaking technologies are in the works, but in the meantime, expect to be bombarded with early, clumsy versions of tomorrow’s tech.
lead_paragraph: It’s a cliché for journalists to whine about International CES, the annual consumer electronics show that brings gadget-hounds and billionaires like a nerdy plague upon Las Vegas this week. As many have complained — yours truly included — CES long ago devolved into a noisy parade of puffed-up announcements that usually amount to nothing.

headline: Fan’s Statue Will Honor Martin Brodeur, Foundation of Devils’ Glory Years
abstract: A California artist who grew up attending Devils games with his father is producing a sculpture of the team’s longtime goaltender that is to be installed at Prudential Center in February.

headline: Amid Conflict, Life and Art in Goma
abstract: Looking for a different narrative in a conflict-torn region, Natalie Keyssar looked at the lives of young people in Goma in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: Last July, Natalie Keyssar traveled to Goma in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo set on telling a story about the region that was different from the many narratives about its refugee population or the scars from recent wars. Instead, she spent the month among the area’s youth, letting them dictate the subject matter.

headline: Jaden Smith for Louis Vuitton: The New Man in a Skirt
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Transvestism', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Men and Boys', 'Gender']
abstract: The 17-year-old’s appearance in a new ad campaign is writing yet another chapter in gender fluidity.

headline: Retiring a U.N. Building Not Quite Fit for the World Stage

For the last year, Ms. Gaignard, who takes self-portraits costumed as various alter egos she imagines, then builds fictional domestic spaces for them, has lived in this nondescript, book-filled and thoroughly carpeted apartment with a professional couple in their late 20s, their chatty lime-green parrot and three cats.

lead_paragraph: For Senator Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, gun violence was not an issue he ran on: It chose him. The massacre at Newtown Elementary School in Sandy Hook happened a month after he won his seat.

headline: My Marriage Didn’t End When I Became a Widow
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Marriages', 'Widows and Widowers']
abstract: He’s gone, but I’m still keeping my promises to him.
lead_paragraph: When my husband died from cancer last March at age 37, I was so grief-stricken I could barely sleep. One afternoon, I visited his grave — in a field high in the Santa Cruz Mountains, overlooking the Pacific Ocean — and lay on top of it. I slept more soundly than I had in weeks. It wasn’t the vista that calmed my restless body; it was Paul, just there, under the earth. His body was so easy to conjure — limbs that had linked with mine at night, soft hands that I had grasped during the birth of our daughter, eyes that had remained piercing even as cancer thinned his face — and yet, impossible to hold. I lay on the grass instead, my cheek against the ground.

headline: Avoiding the Dreaded ‘Second-Term Curse’
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Two years ago, as President Obama wrestled with an array of political challenges, pundits and partisans reached for a familiar explanation: the “second-term curse.”

headline: Why Do We Feed Wild Animals?
abstract: Millions of people all over the world set out food for wild animals. Is it for them or for us?
lead_paragraph: White-­haired, with a faintly aristocratic glamour, Mrs. Leslie-­Smith lived alone in a wooden bungalow full of books and glossy houseplants a few doors from my childhood home. One warm autumn evening more than 30 years ago, she invited my mother and me to watch her nightly ritual. She scattered broken cookies outside her garden doors, where they glittered dustily under the light of an outside lamp. We sat in the darkened room and waited. A striped black-­and-­white face appeared at the edge of the illuminated lawn. Then, out of the night, two badgers trundled across the grass to crunch up the cookies, so close to us that we could see their ivory teeth and the patterned skin on their noses. They weren’t tame — if we had turned on the light, they would have bolted — but I wanted to press my hands to the glass to get closer to them, to somehow make them understand I was there. The space between us in the house and these wild creatures in the garden was filled with unexpected magic.

headline: Debbie Wasserman Schultz Thinks Young Women Are Complacent
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Marijuana', 'Medical Marijuana', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee talks about sexist criticism, marijuana and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: After the Bernie Sanders campaign improperly accessed voter data, the Democratic National Committee was swift with its punishment, suspending his campaign from having access to the database. How did you come up with that sanction? Quite honestly, we are putting this behind us. The American people deserve an intelligent debate, and this isn’t one.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What Makes a Caesar
abstract: Some salads call for breaking the rules. This is not one of them.
lead_paragraph: Jillian from Quebec writes: My husband and I have had a decade-long dispute about my putting cauliflower in Caesar salads. My husband thinks it’s a mistake. I wrote to Dan Pashman of WNYC’s ‘‘The Sporkful,’’ and he sided with me.

headline: The Mystic, the Monk and the Play Brought to You by Powerball
abstract: A lottery winner is producing “The Glory of the World,” a new play that explores the life of the 20th-century American Catholic thinker Thomas Merton.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like the setup for some kind of droll joke: A lottery winner and a rhinoceros arrive at the birthday party for a dead mystic. Art, and a blowout brawl, ensues.

headline: Do We Have to Send Our Kid to a Bad Public School?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Families and Family Life', 'Elderly', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The Ethicist on a fair share of local engagement, extravagant parents and guilt over a friend’s theft.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I are an interracial couple living in Oakland, Calif. We are both first-generation college graduates for whom solid public-school educations made all the difference. We are struggling with choosing a public school for our son, who will enter kindergarten this year. State test scores came out recently, and our neighborhood public school, which is filled with some of the city’s poorest kids, scored very low. I have to believe there is something seriously wrong with how the school is educating kids. (Otherwise, the school, which we know fairly well through volunteering, seems perfectly fine.) My wife and I both work full-time and also care for her mother and disabled sibling, so we know that we can’t put in the kind of time that would be required to turn the school around. We also fear that we cannot teach our son enough outside school hours to make up for a significant deficit in his education.

headline: The Lawyer Who Became DuPont’s Worst Nightmare
keywords: ['Water', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Rob Bilott was a corporate defense attorney for eight years. Then he took on an environmental suit that would upend his entire career — and expose a brazen, decades-long history of chemical pollution.
lead_paragraph: Just months before Rob Bilott made partner at Taft Stettinius & Hollister, he received a call on his direct line from a cattle farmer. The farmer, Wilbur Tennant of Parkersburg, W.Va., said that his cows were dying left and right. He believed that the DuPont chemical company, which until recently operated a site in Parkersburg that is more than 35 times the size of the Pentagon, was responsible. Tennant had tried to seek help locally, he said, but DuPont just about owned the entire town. He had been spurned not only by Parkersburg’s lawyers but also by its politicians, journalists, doctors and veterinarians. The farmer was angry and spoke in a heavy Appalachian accent. Bilott struggled to make sense of everything he was saying. He might have hung up had Tennant not blurted out the name of Bilott’s grandmother, Alma Holland White.

headline: Charlotte Rampling and Those Dolly Birds
abstract: The star of “45 Years” says the role of “the sweet girlfriend who is happily following the man” never appealed to her.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Rampling, the elusive, slow-burning British actress, astounded audiences this season with her performance opposite Tom Courtenay in “45 Years,” about a long-married couple struggling with a revelation about the husband’s girlfriend from long ago. While overlooked by the Golden Globes, Ms. Rampling, 69, collected a slew of awards and nominations for her portrayal, and is predicted to garner her first Oscar nod when the nominations are announced on Jan. 14. Last month, in the lounge of the Soho Grand Hotel, Ms. Rampling spoke with the Bagger about avoiding “dolly bird” roles, wandering men and her endless admiration for Cate Blanchett. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: How the Daily Fantasy Sports Industry Turns Fans Into Suckers
abstract: While FanDuel and DraftKings look the other way, a small set of sophisticated high rollers is preying upon millions of innocent newbies — like me — every day.
lead_paragraph: Full disclosure: I am a 36-year-old dude who bores easily, drinks I.P.A.s and wears sports-themed T-shirts, especially ones with faded, nostalgic logos that suggest better times. In my early 20s, I developed a gambling problem that I’ve since learned to spread out over a variety of low-stakes games — Scrabble, pitch-and-putt golf, my stock profile on ETrade. I watch somewhere between six and 20 hours of basketball per week. I try to keep up with the usual cultural things — documentaries about conflict in South Sudan, Netflix binge shows, memes — but whenever I find myself awake in the early morning and there is no email to answer and no news to track, I watch SportsCenter, or I scan the previous night’s N.B.A. box scores to check up on Porzingis, or I read some dissertation on Johnny Cueto’s unusual ability to hold runners on first base. It’s not the most glamorous way to spend my time, but what can I do? My mind, at its most aimless, obsessively seeks out sports information. I am, in other words, the target demographic for the daily fantasy sports industry.

headline: Pierre Boulez, Composer and Conductor Who Pushed Modernism’s Boundaries, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Boulez belonged to an extraordinary generation of European composers who, while in their 20s, came to the forefront during the decade or so after World War II.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Boulez, the French composer and conductor who helped blaze a radical new path for classical music in the 20th century, becoming one of its dominant figures in the decades after World War II, died on Tuesday at his home in Baden-Baden, Germany. He was 90.

headline: Bird-Watching, Patriotism and the Oregon Standoff
keywords: ['Birdwatching', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Birds', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: What the armed activists don’t understand about freedom and the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, at the height of his substance abuse, Johnny Cash was called in to make a deposition, but not about possessing drugs. Instead, the singer was in trouble for leaving a burning truck at the side of a road in Los Padres National Forest in California. The flames had started a forest fire that jeopardized not only the refuge itself, but the lives of nearly 50 critically endangered California condors, which at that time made up a sizable portion of the global population. Facing the prospect of a lawsuit, and filled with “amphetamines and arrogance,” as his autobiography put it, Cash defiantly told his government questioners, “I don’t give a damn about your yellow buzzards.”

headline: 1941: Roosevelt Urges Arms Loans
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Roosevelt asks Congress to approve loans to Allied nations in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt, delivering in person his annual message to Congress on the state of the Union, recommended today [Jan. 6] that Congress appropriate ‘‘billions of dollars’’ for the manufacture of warplanes, tanks, guns and ships to be lent to nations resisting aggression, such as Great Britain, China and Greece. The President specified that ‘‘our most useful and immediate role’’ in the second world war is not to send man power overseas, but to serve as an arsenal for the nations which are defending themselves and looking to us for material assistance. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 7, 1941

lead_paragraph: After a flood in 1993 destroyed much of Valmeyer, Ill., its residents decided to leave it behind and move the town elsewhere.

headline: A Town Drowned and Resurrected on a Bluff Misses Its Old Home
abstract: After a catastrophic flood in 1993, the residents of Valmeyer, Ill., picked up their town and moved to a bluff a mile and a half away. But they miss the old town on the Mississippi River.
lead_paragraph: VALMEYER, Ill. — This little town on the Mississippi River nearly drowned in the Great Flood of 1993. Houses filled with 16 feet of muddy water. Streets disintegrated and washed away. After Valmeyer’s 900 residents surveyed the wreckage, they vowed, tired and grieving, that they would not let it happen again.

headline: Father Charged With Murder in Death of Pregnant Daughter
abstract: William Caruth, 61, was arrested on Wednesday hours after the body of his 39-year-old daughter, Andrea Caruth, 39, was found in a hole beneath the basement of her home in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: At five months pregnant, Andrea Caruth was counting down the days until she learned the gender of her baby. She had arranged to meet her best friend for a shopping trip after a doctor’s visit on Wednesday, another step toward motherhood for a woman who had looked forward to it for years as she took care of young children at a day care center in her home in the Bronx.

headline: Donald Trump Is Also an Outlier in Political Science
abstract: The key role of party elites has evolved but has not fundamentally changed, an author of “The Party Decides” says.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has confounded politicians, pundits and political scientists as he runs a most unconventional — and so far successful — campaign to win the Republican presidential nomination. Here’s the way we think these things are supposed to play out: Party leaders shape and guide the nomination process. We call it the invisible primary, and it was described in an influential 2008 book, “The Party Decides.” I asked David Karol, a University of Maryland associate professor of political science and one of the book’s four authors, whether Mr. Trump’s rise reveals a fundamental shift in party control. He thinks not. Here’s our conversation, slightly edited.

headline: Taxpayer Advocate Warns of ‘Pay to Play’ I.R.S. System
abstract: The agency plans to expand the role of tax preparers and reduce telephone interaction with taxpayers, she said.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from Congress to do more with less, the Internal Revenue Service is planning to increase its reliance on technology and tax preparers. But this push threatens to create a “pay to play” system where the only taxpayers who will receive personalized service are those who can afford to pay for it, the agency’s taxpayer advocate warned.

headline: 1966: India and Pakistan Near Truce
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: India and Pakistan are close to a truce in 1966.
lead_paragraph: TASHKENT, U.S.S.R. — India and Pakistan have virtually agreed on an agenda for their conference here and have made progress toward a nonaggression pact that may be signed in the next few days, authoritative diplomatic sources said today [Jan. 6]. The agreement was reportedly hammered out today during separate talks that Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin held with Pakistani President Mohammed Ayub Khan and Indian Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri. The two Asian leaders are also considering an agreement to withdraw occupation troops from both countries. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 7, 1966

headline: Georgia Town Teaches ‘Fight Back’ as Option in Mass Shootings
abstract: In Douglasville, Ga., and other cities, seminars instructing residents to stay alert, and to attack the attacker if necessary, have become increasingly common.
lead_paragraph: DOUGLASVILLE, Ga. — When the police held town hall meetings here in the past, they were lucky to see a half-dozen people. But the topic of the most recent one was “Active Shooter: A Citizen’s Guide to Planning for Survival.” And the place was packed.

headline: France Forfeits Its Own Values
abstract: Will President Hollande’s plan to strip citizenship from terrorists with dual nationality destroy his country’s founding principles?
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — IN French, the word “déchéance” has several meanings, all of them bleak. It can refer to the fall of a civilization, or the degradation of the social fabric. More formally, it means the forfeiture of a right or a possession — one’s citizenship, for example. All three meanings, carrying echoes of the country’s experience under Vichy, resonate in a political drama unfolding in France.

headline: Chipotle Is Subpoenaed in Criminal Inquiry Over Norovirus Outbreak
abstract: The action in California is the latest setback for the restaurant chain, which said it expected a drop of 14.6 percent in same-store sales for its fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: Chipotle Mexican Grill said on Wednesday that it had been served a federal grand jury subpoena as part of a criminal investigation seeking information about a norovirus outbreak at a California restaurant.

headline: Lauren Gunderson on ‘I and You,’ a Play With an Explosive Twist
abstract: The playwright talks about her incentive for injecting a cathartic surprise into the play, which centers on two teenagers bonding over poetry homework.
lead_paragraph: A playwright who makes a living writing plays is an anomaly in any city, but it’s especially rare to build a viable career almost entirely outside New York. It has worked for Lauren Gunderson, whose plays have been steadily produced by theaters around the country, including in her current home base, San Francisco, since she received a masters in dramatic writing from New York University in 2009.

headline: Great Recipes for the Middle of the Week
abstract: The only recipe for whole-roasted cauliflower you’ll ever need, and more recipes for the week.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Chiefs Enter Playoffs as N.F.L.’s Hottest Team
abstract: With a 10-0 run, Kansas City became the first team to start 1-5 but make the playoffs since the 1970 Bengals, but the Chiefs have not won a playoff game since 1993.
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, the Kansas City Chiefs’ season appeared to have gone badly awry. With a loss to the Vikings on Oct. 18, the Chiefs fell to 1-5. Their star running back, Jamaal Charles, was out for the year with a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Coach Andy Reid was under fire, notably for a puzzling decision to hand off to Charles at the end of regulation in Week 2 against Denver, which led to a fumble and a loss.

headline: Samantha Bee Prepares to Debut ‘Full Frontal’
abstract: The former “Daily Show” correspondent will break up late-night TV’s boys club, beginning Monday night on TBS.
lead_paragraph: It was crunchtime for Samantha Bee.

headline: The Power of Documentaries on the Oscar Trail
abstract: A win in this category, or even a nomination, can turn the spotlight on an injustice or a problem and inspire action.
lead_paragraph: It’s way too easy to feel jaded about Oscar season. The forced pomp, the moneyed campaigns, the boggling repetition of dozens of awards fetes could jaundice any eye. But it’s tougher to be cynical about the documentary category, where an Oscar nomination, let alone a win, can have mighty ripple effects.

headline: North Korea Blast Revives Question: How Do You Contain Pyongyang?
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The detonation that rocked Northeast Asia is a reminder that North Korea was on an atomic spending spree while U.S. negotiators focused on Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early in his first term, President Obama conducted some quick triage on how his administration would face a gamut of nuclear challenges: Focus on stopping Iran’s nuclear program before it succeeded in building a weapon, but do not waste a lot of energy trying to roll back a North Korean program that had already built a small arsenal that the desperately poor country had little incentive to give up.

headline: Two Workers Charged in Hay Theft
abstract: Angel H. Parra Penafiel and Hugo Ramirez-Morales have been charged with felony grand larceny in the theft of about $30,000 worth of hay over nearly three years in Westchester County.
lead_paragraph: Angel H. Parra Penafiel and Hugo Ramirez-Morales have been charged with felony grand larceny in the theft of about $30,000 worth of hay over nearly three years in Westchester County.

headline: Chris Christie Taking High Road in Ad Responding to Marco Rubio
abstract: Much as he has done in the debates, Mr. Christie tries in his new ad to draw a contrast not with his Republican presidential rivals, but with Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Finding himself the target of numerous attack ads in New Hampshire, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is responding with an ad titled “We Need to Keep Our Eye on the Ball,” running only in the Granite State.

headline: Michael Weatherly Leaving ‘NCIS’
abstract: The actor, who plays the agent Tony DiNozzo, has been with the CBS show since it debuted in 2003.
lead_paragraph: Michael Weatherly, who plays the roguish agent Tony DiNozzo on “NCIS,” confirmed Tuesday night that he was leaving CBS’s popular crime procedural after 13 seasons. He will leave the show at the end of the current season, which concludes in April.

headline: In Lois Colley Murder Investigation, 2 Are Accused of Stealing Hay From Farm
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Two workers have been arrested, but the police would not say if they were suspects in the murder of Mrs. Colley, 83, who was found bludgeoned to death in her home in Westchester County.
lead_paragraph: Investigators trying to solve the murder of a Westchester County socialite on her family’s 300-acre horse farm have yet to unravel a killing that has captivated and mystified residents in one of the New York City region’s most affluent and tranquil communities.

headline: Pinterest Hires Its First Head of Diversity
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: In addition to hiring Candice Morgan to lead its diversity efforts, Pinterest said it will launch two initiatives to introduce more engineers from underrepresented backgrounds into the field of technology.
lead_paragraph: Like much of corporate America, Silicon Valley has long had a workplace diversity problem. That is leading to the emergence of a new job title: chief diversity officer.

headline: Edit Tweets? Users Debate a Missing Twitter Feature
abstract: Amid the uproar over a plan for 10,000-character tweets, users press for the ability to fix their typos.
lead_paragraph: Never mind longer tweets, many Twitter users are saying. What about an editing function?

headline: Iraq Offers to Mediate Dispute Between Saudi Arabia and Iran
abstract: The offer appeared to reflect fears in Iraq that the conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran could aggravate sectarian tensions and hurt the campaign against ISIS.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Iraq’s foreign minister on Wednesday offered to mediate the fight raging between Saudi Arabia and Iran over the Saudi government’s execution of a dissident Shiite cleric, saying that “we need to stop the escalations.”

headline: Home Entertainment Sales Remain Stagnant
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)']
abstract: Disc sales dropped 12 percent last year, the Digital Entertainment Group reported, but streaming was up almost 25 percent.
lead_paragraph: More of the same is what the Digital Entertainment Group reported in its year-end summary of home entertainment sales in the United States. Total sales of films and television shows in home entertainment formats are still treading water, having risen less than 1 percent for the year, to about $18.1 billion in 2015 from about $17.9 billion in 2014, according to the organization’s preliminary numbers released on Wednesday.

headline: Emma Rice Bringing a New Take on ‘Cymbeline’ to Shakespeare’s Globe
abstract: Shakespeare’s “Cymbeline” will be reworked as “Imogen” at the Globe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Emma Rice will kick off her first season as artistic director of Shakespeare’s Globe this spring with one of Shakespeare’s best-loved classics and one that has never been seen.

headline: L’Oréal Takes the Wearables War to the Beauty Counter
abstract: The makeup giant’s latest product is not a lipstick or an eyeshadow, but a stretchable electronic you apply to your skin to measure UV exposure.
lead_paragraph: L’Oréal is not a name usually associated with International CES, the annual consumer electronics show, but Guive Balooch, global vice president of L’Oréal’s Technology Incubator, was in Las Vegas on Wednesday to unveil the beauty giant’s new foray into wearable tech — and it’s not a bracelet (thank the heavens).

headline: Oculus Rift Will Cost $599
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: Facebook’s Oculus has set a price and other details for its Oculus Rift virtual reality system.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s Oculus is finally offering clarity on how much of a premium a virtual reality experience will cost.

headline: Political GIFs Are the New Sound Bites This Campaign Season
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media', 'Science and Technology', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Whether it is Donald J. Trump’s amused looks or Hillary Clinton’s shoulder brush, animated GIFs are offering a new way for candidates to connect with voters.
lead_paragraph: Every few decades, a piece of technology comes along that alters political campaigning.

headline: Why People With Mental Illness Are Able to Obtain Guns
abstract: A major background check loophole, variation in state laws and incomplete record-sharing leave openings for people with mental illness to purchase guns.
lead_paragraph: A major background check loophole, variation in state laws and incomplete record-sharing leave openings for people with mental illness to purchase guns.

headline: Samuel L. Jackson Defends Use of Epithet in ‘Hateful Eight’
abstract: In his view, critiques of Quentin Tarantino’s script are unfair: “It’s coming out of characters’ mouths from an honest place.”
lead_paragraph: One of the parlor games this winter movie season has been counting the number of times a certain racial epithet is uttered in Quentin Tarantino’s new film, “The Hateful Eight.” The answer, according to Gawker, is about 65 times, which is less than in his last film, “Django Unchained,” where he recorded his all-time high, of sorts, for the word’s usage onscreen.

headline: Where Home Brewers Tell Their Tales
abstract: Bitter & Esters, in Prospect Heights, sells equipment for the growing home-brew industry, holds classes and has educational tastings.
lead_paragraph: Bitter & Esters, in Prospect Heights, sells equipment for the growing home-brew industry, holds classes and has educational tastings.

headline: A Bright Idea Among Wall Street’s European Pay Disclosures
abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s policy of canceling bonuses if a group’s long-term returns aren’t met could make pay more defensible.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s disclosure of European pay practices combines the useful and the useless.

headline: ‘MDLSX,’ From the Troupe Motus, Comes to La MaMa Downstairs
abstract: Silvia Calderoni, a longtime member of this boundary-defying international theater company, examines gender in an autobiographical show.
lead_paragraph: “MDLSX”: At first glance, the title of the latest offering from Motus — a boundary-defying international theater troupe that honestly and ardently aspires to the revolutionary — brings to mind an optometrist’s eye chart. But look again, a directive that is implicit in all Motus productions; imagine these letters connected by vowels. Now, perhaps, you start to see “Middlesex,” with its suggestions of indeterminate gender (and the title of a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel on just that subject by Jeffrey Eugenides), or “muddle” or “medium, large, small.”

headline: Review: In ‘When Breath Becomes Air,’ Dr. Paul Kalanithi Confronts an Early Death
abstract: This memoir tells how he adjusted his attitude and life before dying of cancer at 37.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Paul Kalanithi sent his best friend an email in May 2013 revealing that he had terminal cancer, he wrote: “The good news is that I’ve already outlived two Brontës, Keats and Stephen Crane. The bad news is that I haven’t written anything.” It was a jokey way of dealing with the unthinkable but also an indication of Dr. Kalanithi’s tremendous ambition. He had led a fascinating life and was not about to leave it unchronicled.

headline: Cologne Mayor’s ‘Arm’s Length’ Advice on Sexual Attacks Stirs Outcry
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Responding to reports of attacks by groups of men on New Year’s Eve, the mayor said women could protect themselves by keeping “an arm’s length” away.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The mayor of Cologne has inflamed a debate in Germany about migrants and sexual harassment by suggesting that women can protect themselves from men on the streets by keeping them more than an arm’s length away.

headline: Gilbert E. Kaplan, Publisher and Improbable Conductor, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Kaplan, the founder of Institutional Investor magazine, turned his obsession with Mahler’s Second Symphony into a vocation, leading international orchestras in its performance.
lead_paragraph: Gilbert E. Kaplan, a financial publisher who had an accidental second career as an international symphony conductor — despite the fact that he could scarcely read music and possessed a concert repertoire of exactly one piece — died on New Year’s Day in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: The ‘Crazy Nutcase’ With the Nuclear Bomb
abstract: Ted Cruz, reacting to North Korea’s claim that it tested a hydrogen bomb, offered his appraisal of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, calling him a “crazy nutcase.”
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper campaign bus tour.

headline: Cuomo Proposes $22 Billion to Improve New York’s Roads and Bridges
abstract: The funding would pay for upgrades in upstate New York as part of an effort to invest in the region, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: As part of a broader push to modernize New York’s infrastructure, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday proposed spending $22 billion to improve state roads and bridges.

headline: ‘Younger’ Ages Into a Second Season on TV Land
abstract: This drama about passing for a younger woman opens with its heroine’s workplace secret more or less intact.
lead_paragraph: For women stung by ageism in the workplace, “Younger,” the Darren Star series on TV Land, might at first have seemed like a lame joke. Not the part where Liza, a divorced 40-year-old with an Ivy League degree played by Sutton Foster, struggles to re-enter the publishing world after a long absence taken to raise her daughter — that rang all too true. Rather, the part where she hooks up with a 26-year-old tattoo artist who eyes her fresh face and killer body and assumes she’s in his demographic. Which sparks the notion that, with a bit of cosmetic tweaking and online purging, she can shave off enough years to begin anew. Right. If only job security were as simple as calling your hair stylist.

headline: Enrique Marquez Pleads Not Guilty in San Bernardino Massacre Case
abstract: Trial is set for Feb. 23 for Mr. Marquez, who is accused of supplying weapons to the couple, Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik, who killed 14 people in San Bernardino.
lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — Enrique Marquez pleaded not guilty Wednesday on charges of supplying two assault weapons that Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik used to massacre 14 people at the Inland Regional Center in San Bernardino last month. Mr. Marquez, dressed in a white jumpsuit, his legs and hand shackled, spoke in a clear voice as he entered his plea on that charge, as well as on counts that he and Mr. Farook had conspired on an earlier terrorist plot that was not carried out. Answering a series of questions from the United States Magistrate, Sheri Pym, Mr. Marquez said he had been informed of his constitutional rights and read the indictment. The hearing for Mr. Marquez, who is 24 and was a longtime friend of Mr. Farook’s, lasted just over four minutes. Ms. Pym set the trial for Feb. 23.

headline: Hindu Heroes, Savored Through Fantastical Masks at the Met
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum recently acquired five wooden masks from the 18th century and has surrounded them with art that fleshes out a rapturous religious tale.
lead_paragraph: It’s a short step from religious ritual to theater, and barely any distance at all in the case of certain popular Hindu dramas of southern India. Performed during seasonal festivals, they are epic in length — they go on for hours, often through the night — and fantastic in character, telling the stories of gods who have the adventure-filled lives of superheroes. You get a vivid sense of this proto-“Star Wars” mood in “Encountering Vishnu: The Lion Avatar in Indian Temple Drama” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Met recently acquired five large 18th-century wooden masks created for a play about the god Vishnu who, in the guise of the lion-man called Narasimha, visited earth to defeat an evil king and restore order to the universe. The masks are stupendous, and paintings and prints that the Met has placed around them flesh out a tale that, even today, can inspire devotional rapture under the stars. (metmuseum.org)

headline: ‘Bone Tomahawk’ Gets Another Look
abstract: As part of its series “The Contenders,” MoMA is screening this film starring Patrick Wilson and Kurt Russell.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Wilson had a memorable 2015 in Season 2 of “Fargo,” the much-admired, marvelously off-kilter FX television series, but he was also part of another unorthodox project last year, the horror western “Bone Tomahawk.” The movie received a limited theatrical run in October but deserves much more, and the Museum of Modern Art is doing its part by giving it a showing at 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Jan. 12, in a series it calls “The Contenders,” which spotlights films of significance from last year that went relatively unnoticed.

headline: Big Opera or Cozy Concert? Take Your Pick
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera features Franco Zeffirelli’s production of Puccini’s “Turandot,” and the Juilliard School holds its ChamberFest.
lead_paragraph: Grand and intimate square off across 65th Street this week. At the Metropolitan Opera, Franco Zeffirelli’s gargantuan production of Puccini’s “Turandot” returns with the formidable soprano Nina Stemme in the title role. (She portrays Strauss’s Elektra in April.) The experienced Paolo Carignani conducts, Marco Berti is Calaf, and Anita Hartig is Liù. But the real star is the Zeffirelli spectacle, alternately cheesy and enchanting. (7:30 p.m., Monday, Jan. 11, and 8 p.m., Friday, Jan. 15; metopera.org.)

headline: Fed Minutes Show Some Concern on Economic Outlook
abstract: As they moved to raise interest rates in December, some Federal Reserve officials were cautious in their assumptions about the months ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, marshaled a strong consensus among Fed officials for the momentous decision to raise the central bank’s benchmark interest rate last month, but concerns among policy makers about the strength of economic growth could slow the march toward higher rates.

headline: Fixing Social Security
abstract: “Raising the ceiling on wages subject to Social Security deductions is long overdue,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Futurist Cocktails in Milan
abstract: The city’s Surfer’s Den is at the forefront of a crop of bars reimagining recipes from the freewheeling, century-old art movement.
lead_paragraph: The city’s Surfer’s Den is at the forefront of a crop of bars reimagining recipes from the freewheeling, century-old art movement.

headline: In Milan, a New Spin on a Century-Old Cocktail
abstract: Several bartenders in Milan have taken to creating drinks, like the Surfer’s Den’s Ape Vigorosa, inspired by the freewheeling Futurist movement.
lead_paragraph: More than a century ago, the Italian artists of the Futurist movement issued the first of their provocative manifestos — a call for art that would shock the country’s bucolic peasant society into the industrialized age. The artists broadcast their message in paintings of speed and flight, in antagonistic theater pieces that frequently ended in fistfights and eventually — as would happen perhaps only in Italy — in a cookbook. “We will now establish the way of eating best-suited to an ever more high-speed, airborne life,” declared their leader, Filippo Tomasso Marinetti. The “Futurist Cookbook,” published in 1932, detailed multisensory scenarios and the anarchic dishes and drinks that composed the artists’ dinners — events for curious guests and journalists, witnesses to the Futurist demands to refashion Italy from art to plate.

headline: Why Experts Doubt That North Korea Tested a Hydrogen Bomb
abstract: North Korea claimed on Wednesday that it had tested a hydrogen bomb, the most powerful kind of nuclear weapon.
lead_paragraph: North Korea claimed on Wednesday that it had tested a hydrogen bomb, the most powerful kind of nuclear weapon.

headline: “Nearly Eternal,” a Subversive Take on Food
abstract: The photographer Norbert Schoerner and the art director Steve Nakamura explore the boundaries between the real and artificial.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Norbert Schoerner and the art director Steve Nakamura explore the boundaries between the real and artificial.

headline: Demanding Action on Guns
abstract: A reader praises President Obama’s plan as “heartful, humble and heroic,” but also worries that it might be hopeless.

headline: A Subversive, Uncanny Look at Food
abstract: The photographer Norbert Schoerner and art director Steve Nakamura launch “Nearly Eternal,” a book of artificial food samples doing strange things.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s a raw egg yolk gripped by levitating chopsticks or sugar magically sprinkling over a juicy grapefruit, the images in the new book “Nearly Eternal” are a surreal — and slightly sinister — take on food.

headline: Robert De Niro’s Caribbean Resort Plan Draws Criticism
abstract: The plan to open a luxury property called Paradise Found in Barbuda has stalled, though the government vows construction will begin this year.
lead_paragraph: In the year since the government of Antigua and Barbuda and investors led by the actor Robert De Niro announced plans to open a luxury resort on the smaller of the dual-island nation, protests have surfaced and the project has stalled, though the government vows construction will begin this year.

headline: In ‘Fiddler,’ a Balancing Act to Rival Tevye’s
abstract: Hofesh Shechter had never choreographed for a Broadway show, but his childhood experience led him to embrace the challenge of adjusting the work of Jerome Robbins.
lead_paragraph: “Fiddler on the Roof” is about balance. The idea is there in the title image and at the start of the show, when the dairyman protagonist, Tevye, explains that the people of his shtetl maintain their balance by relying on tradition. Much of the plot challenges him to keep his footing while adapting to new ways.

headline: Latinos and Politics
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A professor says Latinos are focused on many issues, not just immigration, and use their political power in many ways, not just at the ballot box.

headline: Compassion for Syrian Refugees
abstract: A reader urges Americans to open our borders, and our hearts, to “help to heal our fractured relations with the Muslim world.”

headline: Marco Rubio’s ‘Cute Boots’ and Other Campaign Issues
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Shoes and Boots', 'News and News Media', 'Photography', 'Social Media']
abstract: The political reporter Michael Barbaro writes about the dust-up the presidential candidate Marco Rubio kicked up with his new boots.
lead_paragraph: It was a quick Tweet, dashed off in a few seconds, observing an (unimportant) moment of fashion on the presidential campaign trail. Then it went viral, triggering endless speculation, campaign attacks and a series of news stories illustrating how mysterious, powerful and, yes, trivial, social media can be.

headline: At CES, Netflix Adds Over 130 Countries to Streaming Service
abstract: Netflix has gone live in nearly every country in the world, rapidly accelerating its plan to be fully global by the end of this year. China is a major exception.
lead_paragraph: Netflix went live with its streaming television service in nearly every country across the world on Wednesday, an unexpected acceleration of the company’s aggressive quest for global ubiquity by the end of 2016.

headline: Robert H.B. Baldwin, Transformer of Morgan Stanley, Dies at 95
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As president and chairman, Mr. Baldwin expanded the investment bank into a full-service financial brokerage and changed its long-entrenched culture.
lead_paragraph: Robert H. B. Baldwin, a Wall Street maverick who presided over the transformation of Morgan Stanley from a prestigious but staid old investment bank into a modern, competitive financial services corporation in the 1970s and early ’80s, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Skillman, N.J., near Princeton. He was 95.

headline: Prison Guards’ Contract
abstract: The New York State correctional officers union takes issue with an editorial’s portrayal of its workforce.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Private Capital Fund-Raising Goal Rises to a Record $946 Billion
abstract: Another year of growth is expected in investments in private equity, debt, real estate, infrastructure and natural resources funds.
lead_paragraph: The number of private capital funds raising money from investors is on the rise, and the amount they are seeking to raise is a record $946 billion at the beginning of the year. That surpasses the previous high-water mark in terms of fund-raising goals set at the beginning of 2009, according to new data from Preqin.

headline: Grindr, the Gay Dating App, Hooks Up With Fashion
abstract: The popular social-networking app will live-stream J.W. Anderson’s men’s wear collection in London.
lead_paragraph: When the monthlong marathon of men’s fashion shows kicks off this week, so will the scrimmage to cover it: the race by newspapers, magazines, television networks, social media platforms and blogs to get a piece of the action for themselves and their viewers.

headline: Alex Gordon, Leader of Royals’ Title Run, Signs 4-Year Deal
abstract: Gordon unexpectedly re-signed with Kansas City for $68 million, with a $23 million mutual option for a fifth year or a $4 million buyout.
lead_paragraph: When the Mets and the Kansas City Royals meet on opening night in a rematch of the 2015 World Series, many of the faces across the field from the Mets will look familiar, and the group will include Alex Gordon, the face of the franchise. On Wednesday, Gordon unexpectedly re-signed with the team for four years and $68 million, with a $23 million mutual option for a fifth year or a $4 million buyout.

headline: Former ‘Walking Dead’ Producer Blasts AMC
abstract: Frank Darabont, the original show runner of the hit AMC series “The Walking Dead,” has painted an unflattering depiction of that network’s executives.
lead_paragraph: The original show runner for the hit AMC series “The Walking Dead” has painted an unflattering depiction of that network’s executives, accusing them of slashing the budgets for the horror drama just as the show was finding success and of failing to adequately appreciate the often grueling work of its cast and crew.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Coffee, Cookies and a Song
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: In Sibley, Iowa, Ted Cruz lampooned the anodyne “issues” pages populating most candidates’ websites.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: A Beloved L.A. Chef’s Restorative Turmeric Tonic
abstract: At Sqirl, Jessica Koslow’s restaurant with a cult following, a warm and healing drink riffs on the classic hot toddy.
lead_paragraph: “Ask your body what it needs and know when it’s satisfied,” says Jessica Koslow, the chef-owner of the wildly popular Sqirl restaurant in Los Angeles. “That’s the mantra.” When she broke her ankle a few years ago, Koslow says she went looking for “anything to help this lady who stands in the kitchen all day.” She found turmeric, a native rhizome of India known for its anti-inflammatory properties, and incorporated it into a healing elixir. “I enjoyed it so much that I played around with a recipe for it that I could serve daily at the restaurant.” For the new year, she created a new tonic — a take on the traditional hot toddy, and what she calls a “healthy, digestive sleep aid.” Others might just call it delicious.

headline: China Weighs Ban on Manta Ray Gills, Sold in Traditional Market as Modern Panacea
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Stingrays', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Medicine and Health', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Demand for the gills, which researchers say were never used in traditional medicine and may actually do harm, has led to overfishing and spurred a conservation campaign.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — Depending on one’s point of view, the huge Qingping market here offers either one of China’s largest selections of natural healing ingredients for traditional Chinese medicine or a vast array of desiccated and dismembered animal carcasses hawked by little better than snake oil salesmen, some of whom actually sell snake-based remedies.

headline: Six Steps to Teaching Children About the Stock Market
abstract: The goal of letting kids invest is to teach them that buying individual stocks is essentially gambling before there’s much money involved.
lead_paragraph: In the first three trading days of the new year, the stock market has fallen far enough and fast enough that it has prompted news alerts on phones and shouting heads on television. So why would you want to expose your children to any of that?

headline: Wheaton Professor May Be Fired for Pro-Islam Stance
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The private evangelical college has said her statements are inconsistent with its religious doctrines.
lead_paragraph: A college professor in Illinois who is at risk of being fired for her remarks on Islam and Christianity spoke out on Wednesday, saying she was grateful for her supporters.

headline: Obama to Nominate Joseph Votel as Head of U.S. Central Command
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: The move reflects the Obama administration’s pivot to fighting abroad with American Special Operations troops.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Gen. Joseph L. Votel, the head of Special Operations Command, to replace Gen. Lloyd J. Austin as the next leader of United States Central Command, Defense Department officials said Wednesday.
