headline: Commuter Transit Benefit Becomes More Generous
keywords: ['Commuting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Federal legislation signed last month raised the amount mass transit riders can set aside pretax; it now equals the amount allowed for parking costs.
lead_paragraph: The new year is bringing some good news for workers who participate in their employer’s commuter benefits program to help pay for the cost of going to work by mass transit.

headline: Top Alabama Judge Orders Halt to Same-Sex Marriage Licenses
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Chief Justice Roy S. Moore cited a pending State Supreme Court case in issuing an edict that goes against the United States Supreme Court’s decision.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, Roy S. Moore, on Wednesday effectively ordered probate judges in the state not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, a move that could cloud the carrying out of the United States Supreme Court decision that legalized same-sex unions.

headline: From ‘Lulu’ to ‘Madama Butterfly,’ Tragedy Transcended by a Visceral Truth
abstract: Anthony Tommasini explores how some wrenching operas convey such emotional depth that the listener is transported instead of sad.
lead_paragraph: Is there a bleaker opera than Berg’s “Lulu,” with its wrenching 12-tone score and sordidly depressing story? It tells of a calculating femme fatale who can also be seen as a victimized young woman getting ahead as best she can in a male-dominated society. The opera would seem guaranteed to leave you shattered, almost sickened.

headline: J.P. Morgan Securities Fined $4 Million for False Statements to Clients
abstract: The bank falsely stated on one of its websites that its private bank advisers were paid based on their performance for clients, regulators said.
lead_paragraph: Regulators have fined J.P. Morgan Securities $4 million for making false statements on the client website of its private bank and in its marketing materials about how its private bank advisers are paid.

headline: Talking Hops at Bitter & Esters in Prospect Heights
abstract: Bitter & Esters, a shop in Prospect Heights, sells all the tools of the trade and gives beer aficionados a community of like-minded artisans.
lead_paragraph: Except for maybe that final celebratory phase, home brewing seems to be a solitary endeavor. But at Bitter & Esters, a home-brew shop in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, hopeful brewers discuss all parts of the process with like-minded beer aficionados, from the minutiae (and there is quite a lot of detail) to the merrymaking when an especially good batch is turned out.

headline: Kamoinge’s Half-Century of African-American Photography
abstract: A new book takes a look at the collective’s groundbreaking work in “speaking of our lives as only we can.”
lead_paragraph: A new book takes a look at the collective’s groundbreaking work in “speaking of our lives as only we can.”

headline: More Than 180,000 Drone Users Registered in F.A.A. Database
abstract: Michael Huerta, the agency’s administrator, indicated that many users had not registered their drones and said he recognized the difficulty in informing the public about the requirement.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday said that about 181,000 drone users had registered in the two and half weeks since the agency began requiring registration of the popular machines.

headline: Report of Orgy at Brussels Police Station Is Unfounded, Officials Say
abstract: The rumors of debauchery were started by disgruntled female officers who had not been invited to a party with soldiers at the station, officials said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Reports of an orgy involving two female Brussels police officers and a group of Belgian soldiers on a night when Brussels was on high alert for a terrorist attack are unfounded, a Brussels police spokeswoman said Wednesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
abstract: Serbia and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Serbia and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 6, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Serbia, Yemen, Syria and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Serbia, Yemen, Syria and the United States.

headline: An Art Performance That Takes Stock — Literally
abstract: For her residency at 303 Gallery, Sarah Meyohas will trade on the New York Stock Exchange and create paintings based on the experience in real time.
lead_paragraph: A Wharton graduate with an M.F.A. from Yale, Sarah Meyohas has impressive credentials — but it’s her extracurricular activities that put the 24-year-old artist ahead of her class. This Friday night, Meyohas kicks off a 10-day residency at 303 Gallery with a performance on financial markets, which she describes as a pseudo-lecture on the current state of affairs. (A related project is her cheekily named art-world cryptocurrency, one unit of which equates to 25 square inches of photographic print.)

headline: Rumors of Immigration Raids Stoke Fear in New York
abstract: Though none of the rumors appeared to be true, immigrants who are undocumented and even those who have legal status have stayed home from work and school.
lead_paragraph: The rumors had been flying in the New York area since Saturday: Officials from Immigration and Customs Enforcement had swooped into churches and public schools, dragged away an undocumented family at the Staten Island Mall, pulled over drivers on the Southern State Parkway and set up blockades in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, and at the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: You Asked, John Kasich Answered
abstract: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

headline: Ebola Treatment Using Plasma From Survivors Is Not Effective, Study Says
abstract: The treatment was at one point the top experimental therapy recommended by the World Health Organization for testing during the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: A treatment once considered among the most promising for Ebola patients was not found to be effective in a study performed in Guinea, researchers reported Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: ‘Girls’ Will Say Goodbye After Sixth Season
abstract: Hannah Horvath and her friends won’t be around for much longer. The HBO show ends its run in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Four years after Hannah Horvath’s parents cut her off in the first episode of HBO’s “Girls,” the network has announced that Lena Dunham and the show’s other creators will be doing the same thing to their audience. The show’s sixth season, scheduled to be broadcast in 2017, will be its last, the network said.

headline: A Fresh Start at Dover Street Market, and an End-of-Season Sale at Totokaelo
abstract: A capsule collection by the Hill-Side at CB2, big discounts on fall collections, and more.
lead_paragraph: Out with the old, in with the new. This week, Dover Street Market has a special installation featuring 10 unique sculptural forms encrusted with tactile materials like terrazzo, clustered rocks and semiprecious stones with healing properties from the New York design practice Amoia Studio ($5,000 for a 15-by-18-inch column) and Anndra Neen cage clutches ($675). At 160 Lexington Avenue.

headline: At Morgan Stanley, a Promotion and a Departure in the Top Executive Ranks
abstract: Colm Kelleher has been named president and will run the wealth management business that Mr. Fleming led.
lead_paragraph: A shuffle at the top of Morgan Stanley has led to the departure of Gregory J. Fleming, an executive who was once seen as a leading candidate to run the Wall Street firm.

headline: Review: ‘Blackstar,’ David Bowie’s Emotive and Cryptic New Album
abstract: The album, which features a quartet led by the saxophonist Donny McCaslin, was released on Mr. Bowie’s 69th birthday.
lead_paragraph: “Blackstar”

headline: Paiute Indians Assert Legacy on Occupied Wildlife Refuge Land
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Native Americans', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Members of the Burns Paiute Tribe said that if anyone should get the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge property back, it should be them.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — Hundreds of residents crammed into a building at the Harney County Fairgrounds here on Wednesday night, far surpassing the capacity of the rows of brown metal folding chairs set up on a concrete floor, to talk in often deeply emotional terms about their community — and just who should be in charge of its destiny.

headline: Review: Rachel Platten Experiments With ‘Wildfire’
abstract: Ms. Platten’s debut major label album reveals that hiding under all that earnest intention, there’s a savvy pop star itching to be heard.
lead_paragraph: “Wildfire”

headline: Texas Trooper Who Arrested Sandra Bland Is Charged With Perjury
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Perjury', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: A Texas grand jury indicted Trooper Brian Encinia, who arrested Sandra Bland, the Chicago-area woman who days later was found dead in her jail cell.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, Tex. — The state trooper who arrested Sandra Bland, the Chicago-area woman who three days later was found hanged in her cell at the Waller County jail, has been indicted on a perjury charge, a special prosecutor here said Wednesday.

headline: N.F.L. Owners Find Fault, Take Action and Steer Clear of Blame
abstract: Every year, amid the carnival of firings on the Monday after the N.F.L.’s regular-season finale, the team owners often escape responsibility for failure.
lead_paragraph: In September, after watching the Giants beat Washington to earn their first win in what was to be Tom Coughlin’s final season, I cautioned disgruntled fans.

headline: Shinola Takes Its ‘Detroit Cool’ Message on the Road
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The manufacturer of handcrafted American-made watches, bicycles and leather goods has begun an aggressive expansion beyond its home base.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — “When I first saw this neighborhood, I thought: ‘You want to put a store here? You kidding me?’” said Tom Kartsotis, the Shinola founder, recalling his initial tour of Detroit’s Cass Corridor, where he opened his company’s flagship two and a half years ago, with a couple of colleagues. While there were signs of resurgence, he said, “This was a rough part of town.”

headline: Global Brands, Taking Cue From Tinkerers, Explore Crowdfunding
abstract: As companies like General Electric and Hasbro experiment with seeking ideas and funding from the masses, Indiegogo has started offering them consulting services.
lead_paragraph: The Opal Nugget Ice Maker machine had all the usual hallmarks of a crowdfunded hit, aside from one tiny bit of fine print.

headline: Review: Jane Lynch as the ‘Angel From Hell’ (With a Drink in Hand)
abstract: Ms. Lynch and Maggie Lawson as Amy and Allison are an id-and-superego pairing whose roots stretch back as far as Rhoda and Mary on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”
lead_paragraph: Jane Lynch’s lanky frame and wolfish grin are so ubiquitous on screen that it’s easy to forget that she hasn’t had her own television show. That deficit is corrected on Thursday night when CBS presents “Angel From Hell,” a sitcom in which she plays Amy, a guardian angel who’s essentially a well-meaning, pathologically needy stalker with a drinking problem and a tendency to overshare.

headline: ‘Allegiance’ Announces Broadway Closing Date
abstract: The musical, about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, will have played 113 regular performances when it finishes.
lead_paragraph: “Allegiance,” the new Broadway musical about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, will close Feb. 14, after 37 previews and 113 regular performances.

headline: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
abstract: In a filing in federal bankrupcty court, the New York State Attorney General’s office raises several questions about a proposed reorganization of the defunct opera company.
lead_paragraph: Is the plan to revive the late, lamented New York City Opera feasible?

headline: Review: Pérotin and Lang, 800 Years Apart, at Trinity Church
abstract: Works by one medieval composer and one Pulitzer Prize-winning Post-Minimalist met as part of Trinity Wall Street’s Twelfth Night Festival.
lead_paragraph: “Time’s Arrow” is the theme of this season’s ambitious Twelfth Night Festival, during which Trinity Wall Street presents an array of old and contemporary music. It was a particularly fitting title for Tuesday’s concert at Trinity Church: The program paired vocal music written by Pérotin, a master of the Notre Dame school of medieval composers in Paris, with works by David Lang, the Pulitzer Prize-winning master of Downtown New York Post-Minimalism.

headline: NBC’s Seeso Looks to Be Must-See TV
abstract: The streaming service, which goes live on Thursday, features both older shows, including “Saturday Night Live,” and new, original comedy series.
lead_paragraph: “Must-see TV” was once the slogan NBC used to promote its prime-time series, the idea being that viewers simply had to watch its shows if they wanted to be part of the television conversation. Today that phrase might be a good measuring stick for the assortment of streaming services asking for our attention and money: Is anything on them “must-see TV”?

headline: Recalling Pierre Boulez, a Conductor-Composer With an Ear to the Alternative
abstract: Mr. Boulez — Leonard Bernstein’s successor at the Philharmonic, who died on Tuesday at 90 — championed contemporary music.
lead_paragraph: In June 1969, the stunning news broke that the New York Philharmonic had appointed Pierre Boulez to succeed Leonard Bernstein as its music director. The decision understandably rattled the classical music establishment: Mr. Boulez was not just an uncompromising Modernist composer, but he had also first come to attention as a polemicist dismissive of those writing music beholden to tonal harmony.

headline: The Face of North Korean Television
abstract: Ri Chun-hee, a host for North Korean state television for over 40 years, returned after a four-year absence to announce, despite international doubts, the country’s test of a hydrogen bomb.
lead_paragraph: Ri Chun-hee, a host for North Korean state television for over 40 years, returned after a four-year absence to announce, despite international doubts, the country’s test of a hydrogen bomb.

headline: Governor Declares Emergency Over Los Angeles Gas Leak
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown, who is ordering California agencies to move quickly to resolve the long-running issue, has drawn criticism for not responding faster.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Natural gas has been spewing into the air in the Porter Ranch neighborhood here since late October, sickening residents, prompting thousands to evacuate their homes and pouring greenhouse gas into the atmosphere.

headline: You Asked, John Kasich Answered
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Voting and Voters', 'Youth']
abstract: Governor Kasich responded to a reader’s question during his visit to the editorial board.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, we asked you to submit questions for John Kasich. During his visit to the editorial board, he picked one of your questions from a hat to answer on camera. Watch his response below:

headline: Review: ‘Intensio’ Suggests a Self-Portrait, With Help From Friends
abstract: Daniil Simkin, a principal for American Ballet Theater, recruits some company colleagues and others for works by the likes of Jorma Elo and Annabelle Lopez Ochoa.
lead_paragraph: The boy in the home movie, practicing at a ballet barre, has serious eyes flecked with fear. When the adult he became — the American Ballet Theater principal dancer Daniil Simkin — tells us that what he really wanted to be was a dentist, it’s both funny and sad. Mr. Simkin is the son of Russian ballet dancers; his mother home-schooled him in their art. The dream of dentistry never had a chance.

headline: Coca-Cola Retreats From Social Media War Over Crimea
abstract: Coca-Cola deleted a map of Russia from the web after managing to anger both Russians and Ukrainians by first excluding and then including Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola withdrew a cartoon map of Russia from the web on Wednesday, after managing to anger both Russians and Ukrainians by first excluding and then including Crimea in Russia’s territory.

headline: Review: ‘Growing Up Hip Hop’ Shares the Perks and Perils of Progeny
abstract: This new reality series follows several music-world figures and their children.
lead_paragraph: In the premiere episode of “Growing Up Hip Hop,” a new reality series about the scions of several prominent hip-hop figures, Angela Simmons — a daughter of Rev Run of Run-DMC — is fretting about a coming fashion show she’s orchestrating. Then she gets interrupted.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Chipotle, Marco Rubio, Donald Trump
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: House Votes to Send Bill to Repeal Health Law to Obama’s Desk
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Vetoes (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The House voted for the 62nd time to repeal the Affordable Care Act, in effect forcing a rare veto from the president to protect his signature domestic achievement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As its opening move in the newly convened Congress, the House voted Wednesday to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the 62nd such vote but the first time that a bill will make it to President Obama’s desk, forcing a rare veto to protect his signature domestic achievement.

headline: Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza Trot Into Baseball Hall of Fame
abstract: Griffey, who received a record 99.3 percent of the vote, would be the first player with a Mariners cap on his plaque. Piazza, who got in on his fourth try, is likely to represent the Mets.
lead_paragraph: Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza, two of the most prolific sluggers of the high-scoring 1990s, were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on Wednesday. Griffey, who slammed 630 home runs, was elected on the first ballot with a record 99.3 percent of votes cast by members of the Baseball Writers’ Association of America. Piazza, whose 396 homers as a catcher are the most for anyone at the position, got in on his fourth try, with 83 percent.

headline: Fear Factor Rising for Federal Workers as Refuge Occupation Goes Unchallenged
abstract: A defender of federal employees’ rights and safety decries the slow government response to the occupation of a national wildlife refuge.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Ruch, who directs Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility, sent a fresh note about an under-appreciated risk that’s building as long as federal authorities don’t directly challenge the anti-government zealots who’ve taken over Oregon’s Malheur National Wildlife Refuge. The lack of response, while wise in many ways (as I wrote yesterday), could send a signal to other extremists that they can challenge the government with impunity. This puts federal employees at risk, particularly those in agencies that are a popular target in the West, particularly the Bureau of Land Management.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Loaded Pizza, and Loaded Guns
abstract: Mr. Cruz visited a Godfather’s Pizza in Spirit Lake and, when asked about gun rights, recounted a tale of a woman who had been pulled over while carrying a derringer in her boot.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Complaint on Yik Yak
abstract: A complaint to the Department of Education against the University of Mary Washington over a Yik Yak-related episode contains graphic language.
lead_paragraph: A complaint to the Department of Education against the University of Mary Washington over a Yik Yak-related episode contains graphic language.

headline: Putting the Heat on Yik Yak After a Killing on Campus
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A Washington lawyer’s civil rights complaint against the free messaging app that’s all the rage on campuses nationwide could spell trouble.
lead_paragraph: Despite pressure to reform what has been variously described as its misogynist, racist and bullying nature — Yik Yak, the anonymous, localized free messaging app, remains the rage on college campuses across the country.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: TransCanada Seeks $15 Billion From U.S. Over Keystone XL Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The action will be taken through a provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the company said.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — TransCanada said on Wednesday that it would seek $15 billion in damages over the Obama administration’s decision to cancel the company’s Keystone XL pipeline project.

headline: ‘The Pill’ Not Tied to Birth Defects
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Birth Defects', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: A large new study has found that taking oral contraceptives around the time of pregnancy did not increase the risk of birth defects.
lead_paragraph: Some small studies have suggested that oral contraceptive use may be associated with an increased risk of birth defects, possibly by altering vitamin levels in the blood. But a large new study has found that taking oral contraceptives around the time of pregnancy did not increase the risk.

headline: Mexican Soda Tax Followed by Drop in Sugary Drink Sales
abstract: A tax on sugary drinks in Mexico appears to have had a significant impact: After one year, a new study found, sales of sugary beverages in Mexico fell while bottled water purchases rose.
lead_paragraph: A tax on sugary drinks implemented in 2014 in Mexico appears to have had a significant impact: After one year, sales of sugary beverages in the country fell as much as 12 percent while bottled water purchases rose 4 percent, a new study found.

headline: Video Feature: Apps Give Journal Writers Inspiration, and Maybe a Nudge
abstract: Mobile diary-writers can get reminders and other tools to create entries and enhance them with information; some apps allow sharing over social media.
lead_paragraph: KEEPING a journal is something many of us try to take up at the start of a new year, but it can be a hard habit to stick with. To make it a bit easier, you can keep a digital journal or diary with you wherever you go, and many are set up to encourage people to keep typing away day after day.

headline: App Smart | Digital Diaries
abstract: A look at apps that help you document your daily life, through words, pictures and social media.
lead_paragraph: A look at apps that help you document your daily life, through words, pictures and social media.

headline: I.M.F. Breakthrough Is Seen to Bolster U.S. on World Stage
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Resolution of a five-year impasse over the International Monetary Fund and other moves in 2015 eased concerns about America’s global economic role.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A string of agreements between the White House and Congress, capped by last month’s surprise accord that ended a five-year impasse over the International Monetary Fund, has eased, though not dispelled, concern that America is retreating from global economic leadership.

headline: United Airlines Chief, Oscar Munoz, Has Heart Transplant
abstract: Mr. Munoz has been on medical leave since Oct. 19. The company expects him to return in several months.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Wednesday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, had heart transplant surgery earlier in the day and was in recovery.

headline: U.S. Sends Two Guantánamo Detainees to Ghana
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The transfer of the two Yemenis represented the first time that lower-level detainees had been resettled in sub-Saharan Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Wednesday transferred to Ghana two Yemeni men who had been imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for nearly 14 years, the Pentagon said. The transfer marked the start of what is expected to be a flurry of 17 departures in early 2016.

headline: Cuomo Lays Out Renovation Plan for Penn Station and Farley Post Office
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said the plan would be part of a series of projects including new air and rail terminals that he called “the biggest construction program in our state’s history.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo continued laying out his vision for a modernized, statewide transportation network on Wednesday afternoon with one more ambitious project: the renovation of Pennsylvania Station, one of the busiest transit halls in the Western Hemisphere, and the creation of an adjunct train and retail hub within the walls of the blocklong general post office across Eighth Avenue.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s New No. 2
abstract: Colm Kelleher has spent much of his career at the firm moving up the ranks through its trading and capital markets operations.
lead_paragraph: Colm Kelleher, named Wednesday as president of Morgan Stanley and the heir apparent to its current chief executive, James P. Gorman, has spent much of his career at the firm moving up the ranks through its trading and capital markets operations.

headline: After Mass Shootings, Some on Wall St. See Gold in Gun Makers
abstract: The stock prices of Smith & Wesson and Sturm, Ruger have each risen more than shares of Apple since 2009, driven by surging sales linked to fears of regulation.
lead_paragraph: In the days after the Paris terrorist attacks last November, world leaders denounced the shooting massacres. On Wall Street, the money manager Louis Navellier saw a buying opportunity.

headline: Macy’s to Cut 4,500 Jobs, After Holiday Sales Slump
abstract: The retailer said it would eliminate about 3 percent of its work force in a major restructuring drive.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s said on Wednesday that it would eliminate about 4,500 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, in a major restructuring drive. It said slumping holiday season sales had hurt its bottom line.

headline: Todd Bowles Makes Changes to Jets’ Coaching Staff
abstract: The Jets fired the special teams coach Bobby April as well as the lone holdovers from Rex Ryan’s staff, the special teams assistant Steve Hagen and the assistant offensive line coach Ron Heller.
lead_paragraph: Todd Bowles expressed his dissatisfaction with the Jets’ poor special teams this season by firing the unit’s two coaches. Gone are Bobby April, who spent one season in charge, and his assistant, Steve Hagen, who had previously worked with the team’s tight ends.

headline: Bill Cosby Inquiries in California to Be Dropped
abstract: Los Angeles County prosecutors cited the statute of limitations and insufficient evidence in saying no charges would be filed in two cases.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County District Attorney’s Office announced Wednesday that it would not pursue sexual assault charges against Bill Cosby, saying investigators had decided that any criminal charges based on the complaints of two women there were blocked by the statute of limitations or lacked sufficient evidence.

headline: A Publisher Puzzles Staff With His Role in Las Vegas
abstract: The publisher of two small newspapers in Connecticut suddenly appeared in the newsroom of The Las Vegas Review-Journal, much to his newsrooms’ mystification.
lead_paragraph: When a relatively obscure newspaper publisher showed up in photographs last month addressing the staff of The Las Vegas Review-Journal, his appearance baffled journalists — in Connecticut.

headline: Under Gun Rules, F.B.I. Will Receive Health Data
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Disability Insurance']
abstract: State agencies and Social Security will disclose to the F.B.I. “protected health information” including those who are dangers to themselves or who cannot manage their own affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Responding to Republicans who have repeatedly tied gun violence to mental health issues, President Obama’s new gun control plan will allow state agencies and the Social Security Administration to provide certain “protected health information” to the F.B.I. to help crack down on weapons sales to people who pose a danger to themselves or others or are unable to manage their own affairs.

headline: Guns, Anger and Nonsense in Oregon
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Land Use Policies', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Federal Lands', 'Ranches']
abstract: The armed takeover of federal buildings by a self-styled militia is illegal and dangerous, and it displays a misreading of history.
lead_paragraph: It is a familiar claim by many Second Amendment defenders — and, during the Obama administration, an increasingly popular one — that unfettered gun rights are necessary to protect American citizens against the threat of a tyrannical government.

headline: Venezuela: New Lawmakers Defy Supreme Court
abstract: The lawmakers swore in three three legislators who were blocked from taking their seats by the court last month.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on Wednesday swore in three legislators who were blocked from taking their seats by the Supreme Court last month, setting up a showdown with the president’s Socialist party. The opposition won a supermajority in the National Assembly on Dec. 6, ending the United Socialist Party’s 16-year-long grip on power. But before the new legislature could take charge, the Socialists approved 13 new Supreme Court justices, and days later, the court blocked four opposition lawmakers from taking their seats. That decision has created uncertainty about the supermajority, which the president’s rivals need to gain added powers, including the ability to remove Supreme Court justices and change the Constitution. On Wednesday, three of the four politicians were sworn in over objections of the Socialists. “What’s happening today is a flagrant violation of the Venezuelan Constitution,” said Diosdado Cabello, a Socialist lawmaker and the former leader of the Assembly. He said that the Socialists would ask the Supreme Court to find the Assembly leadership in contempt of the court order that blocked the politicians from taking their seats.

headline: With Giants Job Open, Sean Payton Reaffirms Vow to Saints
abstract: Payton, a former Giants assistant who had seemed a potential candidate to replace Tom Coughlin as their coach, said he would stay with the Saints “as long as they’ll have me.”
lead_paragraph: New Orleans Coach Sean Payton, who as a former Giants assistant seemed a potential candidate to replace Tom Coughlin as Giants coach, reaffirmed his desire to stay with the Saints on Wednesday.

headline: Sampling the Work of Pierre Boulez
abstract: The critics of The New York Times offer a guide to Mr. Boulez’s artistry as a composer and conductor.
lead_paragraph: The critics of The New York Times offer a selective, subjective guide to the career of Pierre Boulez, who died on Tuesday at 90, suggesting just a few samples of his work as both a composer and conductor.

headline: Baltimore Officer Must Testify in Colleagues’ Trials in Freddie Gray Case
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Witnesses']
abstract: Legal experts said they were unaware of any Maryland case in which a criminal co-defendant had been forced to testify before his own trial, and the judge who issued the order seemed to agree.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Officer William G. Porter, whose trial in the death of Freddie Gray ended last month in a deadlocked jury, must testify in the trials of two fellow officers, a judge here ruled Wednesday, in a novel twist to an increasingly complicated prosecution.

headline: Pentagon Will Extend Military Honors to Drone Operators Far From Battles
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The Defense Department is scheduled to announce awards to honor drone operators and those who launch cyberattacks similar to those given to pilots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, the military’s drone pilots have toiled in obscurity from windowless rooms at bases in suburban America, viewed by some in the armed forces more as video game players than as warriors.

headline: Founders Fund Leads a Financing Round for Nubank, a Brazilian Start-Up
abstract: The venture capital firm, co-founded by the Silicon Valley financier Peter Thiel, joined several other investors in raising $52 million for the financial technology company.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The billionaire and prominent Silicon Valley financier Peter Thiel has returned to investing in Brazil, even as the country remains mired in recession and faces almost weekly political upheavals.

headline: Carmakers Forge Ahead With Electric Vehicles
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: General Motors and several other car companies are focusing on electric vehicles at the International CES consumer trade show in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Although sales of electric and hybrid vehicles have struggled, automakers are charging ahead to bring new battery-powered vehicles to market.

headline: Florida Professor Who Cast Doubt on Mass Shootings Is Fired
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: James F. Tracy suggested that the 2012 massacre of children at Sandy Hook Elementary and other mass shootings were a hoax designed by the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A Florida Atlantic University professor who suggested in blog postings and radio interviews that the 2012 massacre of children at Sandy Hook Elementary and other mass shootings were a hoax designed by the Obama administration to boost support for gun control was fired Tuesday.

headline: A Flawless Swing, but 3 Votes Shy of a Perfect Ballot

Todd Hundley, the Mets’ biggest star, was out with an injury, and three little-known catchers — Todd Pratt, Vance Wilson and Tim Spehr — were competing to replace him.

headline: How Donald Trump Loses
abstract: He doesn’t actually have to collapse; he just has to fail to expand his current support.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump isn’t going to be the Republican nominee.

headline: Cornering the Anger Market
abstract: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders both have campaigns about outrage, but Sanders’s has much better villains.
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk for a minute about Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump.

headline: The Supreme Court and a Life Barely Lived
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Child Custody and Support', 'States (US)']
abstract: A 1989 Supreme Court decision continues to immunize government from the kind of accountability that common sense and justice would seem to require.
lead_paragraph: IT wasn’t surprising that a man named Joshua Braam, who died in November in Muskego, Wis., at the age of 36, didn’t make the engaging “lives they lived” lists that appeared at year’s end. The life he lived was constricted in the extreme. A series of savage beatings by his father, who had obtained custody after a divorce and whose history of abuse had been reported to the local child welfare authorities to no avail, left Joshua comatose and permanently brain damaged at the age of 4. At 12, he was adopted by Richard and Ginger Braam, who cared for him for the rest of his life.

headline: Guns, Tears and Republicans
abstract: The critics in the G.O.P. who scolded the president for weeping while talking about shooting deaths have it wrong. We should all be crying.
lead_paragraph: President Obama shed tears on Tuesday as he called for new gun safety measures, and some critics perceived weakness or wimpishness. Really? On the contrary, we should all be in tears that 225,000 Americans have already died of gun violence in his seven years in office.

headline: Beggars Banquet in Congress
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The need to spend hours in “call rooms” seeking political donations takes away from time actually spent serving constituents.
lead_paragraph: Talk to members of Congress as they retire after years in the Capitol and a disturbing thread runs through their adieus that has nothing to do with serving the people — yes, the people. Far from it: It’s more about how happy they are at having no further obligation to romance the donors — yes, the campaign donors. Departing lawmakers can hardly contain their joy at leaving behind the job’s awful necessity of darting from the Capitol day in and day out to cubbyholed precincts down the block known as “call rooms,” where they beg shamelessly for campaign money to keep their political careers going.

headline: Why Doctors Shouldn’t Be Punished for Giving Prostate Tests
abstract: Medicare should encourage patients to weigh the costs and risks of prostate tests, not punish doctors for ordering them.
lead_paragraph: BOTH of us have raised serious questions about prostate cancer screening. Nevertheless, we hope Medicare chooses not to pursue a strategy of penalizing doctors for ordering prostate-specific antigen, or PSA, tests.

headline: North Korea Flexes Its Nuclear Muscle
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: The United States and its allies can no longer ignore the real and growing nuclear threat from North Korea, and China must use its influence.
lead_paragraph: There was a predictable ritual to the world’s reaction to North Korea’s latest nuclear test, its fourth. Vigorous condemnation, followed by promises never to accept the North as a nuclear weapons state, followed by chest-thumping demands for more sanctions. The problem is that while the North Korean threat is real and growing, the United States and its partners have failed miserably at finding an effective solution.

headline: Kamoinge’s Half-Century of African-American Photography

lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, when African-American photographers were keenly aware of their isolation in a field dominated by white men, two collectives held a joint meeting. The result of that encounter was a decision to merge and form a more robust group they called Kamoinge, which in Kenya’s Kikuyu language means a group of people acting together.

lead_paragraph: KJ Dell’Antonia, editor of the Motherlode blog, has a tradition of writing about her New Year’s parenting resolutions at the start of each January. Yes, parenting isn’t something anybody is perfect at. It takes work, patience and practice.

headline: Rethinking Weight Loss and the Reasons We’re ‘Always Hungry’
abstract: In his new book, “Always Hungry?,” David Ludwig argues that the primary driver of obesity today is not an excess of calories per se, but an excess of high glycemic foods like sugar, refined grains and other processed carbohydrates.
lead_paragraph: David Ludwig often uses an analogy when he talks about weight loss: Human beings are not toaster ovens. If we were, then the types of calories we consumed would not matter, and calorie counting would be the most effective way to lose weight.

abstract: Should the government still own so much land in the West or should its control over that land be reduced?

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘Sicario’
abstract: The 12-time Oscar-nominated cinematographer Roger Deakins discusses his work on the drug cartel thriller directed by Denis Villeneuve
lead_paragraph: He’s been nominated for 12 Oscars and helped bring many a director’s vision to life behind the camera. Now the cinematographer Roger Deakins is back in the Oscar conversation for his work on the thriller “Sicario,” directed by Denis Villeneuve. (The two also teamed up on the 2013 drama “Prisoners.”)

headline: Mexican Pork Chops, by Way of Brooklyn
abstract: Making pipian — a thick sauce of seeds and chiles — with help from place and memory.
lead_paragraph: Pipian is a classic Mexican sauce, thick with seeds and nuts, spicy with chiles, that takes its name from the pepitas, or pumpkin seeds, that are used in its creation. The version I make makes no claims to authenticity, though. The recipe does not derive from the fieldwork of great Mexican cooking masters like Diana Kennedy or Patricia Quintana (who might rail against it), nor from personal experience cooking in central Mexico with the women and men who have been making such sauces since the region’s pre-Hispanic era. (They might shrug.) It is not red or green, as many pipian sauces are, but a delightful, almost pumpkiny orange and brown, with a texture that approximates the look of washed velvet.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘A Field Guide to American Houses’
abstract: Virginia McAlester’s book scrutinizes the nation’s homes, brick by brick.
lead_paragraph: A dovecote is a small, decorative shelter for pigeons often built on top of a house. It looks like a receptacle for secret messages from a fairy-tale world, and this whimsy makes up for the fact that no one actually wants pigeons roosting on their house. Dovecotes are especially common in certain parts of the Los Angeles suburbs, on ‘‘storybook ranch’’ homes — houses recast on the exterior to resemble a cottage that one of the Seven Dwarves might live in.

headline: New Dietary Guidelines Urge Less Sugar for All and Less Protein for Boys and Men
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Eggs', 'Food', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Meat', 'Men and Boys', 'Sugar']
abstract: New federal dietary guidelines announced on Thursday urge Americans to drastically cut back on sugar, and for the first time have singled out teenage boys and men for eating too much meat.
lead_paragraph: New federal dietary guidelines announced on Thursday urge Americans to drastically cut back on sugar, and for the first time have singled out teenage boys and men for eating too much meat, chicken and eggs.

headline: My Accidental Career as a Russian Screenwriter
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Television Sets and Media Devices']
abstract: Stifled by the Kremlin’s impositions on free speech, I quit my job as editor of the Russian GQ and found freedom in cinema — sort of.
lead_paragraph: Прочитать на русском.

headline: Obama to Hold Event on Gun Efforts, Hoping to Reach Outside the Choir
abstract: Some lucky gun rights advocates will get the chance to tell the president directly what they think about his efforts to restrict gun sales during a televised town-hall-style forum on Thursday night, according to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Some lucky gun rights advocates will get the chance to tell the president directly what they think about his efforts to restrict gun sales during a televised town-hall-style forum on Thursday night, according to the White House.

headline: Truck Bomb Kills at Least 65 at Libya Training Camp
abstract: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing in the western coastal town of Zlitan, one of the deadliest in the country in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — A suicide bomber attacked a training camp for Coast Guard cadets early on Thursday, killing at least 65 people in one of the deadliest bombings in Libya in recent memory, according to security officials.

headline: Many in Hong Kong Fear Beijing’s Reach After Editor and Colleagues Disappear
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Political Prisoners', 'Missing Persons', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Censorship']
abstract: The case of five employees of a publishing house calls into question the legal guarantee that people in Hong Kong would be shielded from China’s reach until midcentury.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong-based editor, who specializes in gossipy books about Chinese leaders, vanishes. His wife files a missing persons report with the police. She abruptly withdraws it after a faxed letter surfaces, apparently in her husband’s calligraphy, stating that he is in mainland China of his own volition, helping with an investigation. Hong Kong border officials have no record of his ever leaving.

headline: Q. and A.: Chen Tao, Who Runs ‘Star Wars’ Site, on Film’s Impact in China
abstract: Mr. Chen, who manages China’s biggest website for fans of “Star Wars,” discussed the movie’s fan base and how he became addicted to the Force.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, 21 years after “Star Wars” was released in the United States, a teenage Chen Tao found a “Star Wars” video game on his first computer and, in the process, discovered a whole new galaxy.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday — Best Seats in the House
abstract: President Franklin D. Roosevelt with his daughter, Anna, watched a baseball game between the White House press corps and a team fielded by the broadcast journalist Lowell Thomas near Pawling, N.Y., on Sept. 21, 1935.

headline: Man With Fake Explosives Killed in Paris on Charlie Hebdo Anniversary
abstract: The attack, around noon, prompted the closing of schools, shops and streets, and the man’s body lay on the street outside the station on the Rue de la Goutte d’Or.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French police officers fatally shot a man who was wielding a cleaver and yelling “Allahu akbar” as he tried to attack a police station in northern Paris on Thursday, setting off alarms as France marked the one-year anniversary of the terrorist attack on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

headline: Walid Raad’s Unreality Show Spins Middle Eastern History as Art
abstract: In his MoMA retrospective, Mr. Raad devises a set of fantastic tales from a few hard facts and a backdrop of war.
lead_paragraph: Official political history is as self-assured sounding and logically suspect as presidential primary promises. This is the kind of history — a modest amount of matter plumped on clouds of hot air — that the Conceptual artist Walid Raad devises in his Museum of Modern Art retrospective: a set of fantastic tales spun from a few hard facts, with the live equivalent of an operatic mad scene at the center.

headline: Roger Rosenblatt: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of the novel “Thomas Murphy” would like to meet Mary Shelley: “I’d ask her who the monster is meant to be. . . . Then I’d ask her how a 19-year-old comes up with this stuff.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of the novel “Thomas Murphy” would like to meet Mary Shelley: “I’d ask her who the monster is meant to be. . . . Then I’d ask her how a 19-year-old comes up with this stuff.”

headline: Honoring Mom (and Molière) With ‘Imagining the Imaginary Invalid’
abstract: Clove Galilee revives a show she developed with her mother, Ruth Maleczech, a founder of the experimental theater company Mabou Mines, who died in 2013.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, the actress Ruth Maleczech, who was soon to receive a diagnosis of metastatic breast cancer, underwent an operation on her leg that left her temporarily bedridden.

headline: 17 Workers in Lansing, N.Y., Rescued From Cargill Salt Mine
abstract: Rescuers pulled the miners to the surface after they had spent the night trapped in an elevator 900 feet below ground.
lead_paragraph: Rescue crews pulled 17 miners to the surface on Thursday morning after they spent the night trapped in an elevator 900 feet below ground at a road salt mine in central New York.

headline: A Cultural Revolution in Malaysia
abstract: Leveraging ancient trading links, China is fostering closer ties through pop music.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR — Shila Amzah is a Malaysian pop star famed as much for her fashion sense as for her powerful voice. Her vast collection of striking, multicolored hijabs has made her a style icon and a role model for young Muslim women across the country. These days, though, she sings primarily in Mandarin, and — as her 2.5 million followers on the Chinese microblogging site Weibo suggest — a majority of her fans are from mainland China.

headline: Absolutely Final Delivery
abstract: A returnee to New York City after 30 years in Europe was amazed at how many things one can get delivered to one’s doorstep.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Saks Owner Clinches Deal for Gilt Groupe
abstract: The online fashion retailer, once seen as revolutionary, is sold for $250 million in cash.
lead_paragraph: Once emblematic of New York technology and innovation, Gilt Groupe has agreed to be acquired by Hudson’s Bay Company for a quarter of its private valuation.

headline: 1941: U.S. Steps Up Arms Production
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Roosevelt creates a board to oversee arms production in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt acted promptly today [Jan. 7] in furtherance of his pledge to Congress yesterday to defend democracy by sending ‘‘ever-increasing’’ numbers of warplanes, guns, tanks and ships to Great Britain, China and Greece. The action took the form of creating the Office of Production Management, whose duties, in brief, will be to speed up production of warplanes and all other essential war supplies in the interest not only of the United States but of Great Britain and all other countries which are resisting aggression by the Berlin-Rome-Tokio axis. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1941

lead_paragraph: Use the hashtag #52places on Instagram to show us the one place you think people should travel in 2016.

headline: 52 Places to Go in 2016
abstract: It’s a big world out there, so we’ve narrowed it down for you. From the temples of Malta to the crystalline waters of the Yucatán, explore our top destinations to visit this year.

headline: Venture Investing Declined Sharply at the End of 2015
abstract: Venture capitalists pulled back from start-up investing in the fourth quarter of 2015, in a somber end to the year.
lead_paragraph: Venture capitalists pulled back from making new bets at the end of last year. The number of deals fell to a nearly two-year low because of worries that there was too much froth in start-up investing.

headline: Reader Idea | Students Talk to Students About Drug and Alcohol Use
abstract: In our first Reader Idea from a student, a high school senior from Chicago explains how she and her fellow peer educators used a Times article to spur student discussion on a sensitive topic.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2010, when we invented our Great Ideas From Readers column, we introduced it by saying:

abstract: Jonathan Lippman is focusing his work on New York law and appellate matters as well as trying to expand access to legal services for the needy.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s former chief judge has joined the litigation and trial practice of the law firm Latham & Watkins.

headline: What You Need to Know About Guns in America
abstract: This collection of past Times interactive graphics and explanatory articles focuses on the American gun control debate.
lead_paragraph: This collection of past Times interactive graphics and explanatory articles focuses on the American gun control debate.

headline: Statue Honoring ‘Comfort Women’ Faces Uncertain Fate
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Women and Girls', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The statue is a reminder of the sordid history Japan prefers to forget, and Japan wants it removed.
lead_paragraph: Since 2011, a haunting bronze sculpture of a young woman in traditional Korean dress has been positioned on a sidewalk near the Japanese embassy in Seoul. Barefoot, her hands clenched in her lap, she sits in a chair and stares impassively, a symbol of thousands of Korean women who were used as sex slaves by Japan’s army from the early 1930s until 1945.

headline: In the Birthplace of Pizza, Pollution Rules for Ovens Spur Outrage
abstract: The mayor of San Vitaliano, Italy, is taking heat from local pizzeria owners over a new law requiring filters on wood-fired stoves to curb emissions.
lead_paragraph: SAN VITALIANO, Italy — If there is one label that Antonio Falcone, a doctor turned civic leader, does not want to be known by, it is “the anti-pizza mayor.”

headline: How to Add Currency Symbols to Text in Android
abstract: Press-and-hold shortcuts will reveal numerous characters on both the ABC and ?123 keyboards, including the symbols for the euro, the peso and the yen.
lead_paragraph: Q. Do you need a special keyboard to make a euro symbol on Android 6.0?

keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Let’s recap a busy day at the International CES, where many of the most interesting announcements had nothing to do with smartphones or their apps.

headline: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Bronx McDonald’s Manager
abstract: Rafael Gonzalez, a homeless man who had been a regular at the restaurant, turned himself in and was charged with second-degree murder and manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: The police have arrested a homeless man and charged him with fatally stabbing a McDonald’s manager in the Bronx, after the worker ejected him from the restaurant, where he had been camped out for hours, officials said on Thursday.

abstract: Can you solve a real-life medical mystery involving a 59-year-old man tormented by a thunderous pounding in his head?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you solve a real-life medical mystery involving a 59-year-old man tormented by a thunderous pounding in his head?

abstract: Administrators warned her that Twitter discussions involving a fellow student may have broken an anti-bullying law, she says.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey high school student found herself in a social media storm on Wednesday after she live-tweeted and apparently secretly recorded a trip to her principal’s office.

headline: 52 Places: New Ways to Get There
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'High-Speed Rail Projects', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Transportation']
abstract: From the Orient Express to a 500-mile driving route in Scotland, new options to get to the places you want to see.
lead_paragraph: So many places to go, right? But also so many ways to get to them. Here are a few to look out for this year.

headline: How We Picked the 52 Places to Go in 2016
abstract: Answers to frequently asked questions about how the Travel editors choose the destinations.
lead_paragraph: Each January, the editors of the Travel section publish our Places to Go issue. And each year after we do, readers wonder why their favorite destination was overlooked or why their least favorite made the top 10. To add some clarity to the process, we’ve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our 52 Places to Go in 2016.

headline: Lesson for Stalemated Sides in Oregon: A Texas Standoff Without End
abstract: In a wooded 47-acre compound southeast of Dallas, a standoff that started in 2000 came to an end years later, in 2014. Officially, anyway.
lead_paragraph: TRINIDAD, Tex. — How long can the Oregon standoff last? If the one that dragged on here in this rural East Texas town is any example, the answer is at least a decade, and perhaps much longer.

headline: 1966: Rebellion After Officers Exiled
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Dominican armed forces rebel against an order to exile top officers in 1966.
lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO — The Dominican armed forces today [Jan. 7] rebelled against a provisional government order for 34 top officers to leave the country in the interests of political peace. The defiance of the order — which applied to both rightist and former rebel leaders — started the worst crisis in the Dominican Republic since last summer’s four-month civil war. Provisional President Hector Garcia Godoy ordered 12 top officers, including former rebel leader Col. Francisco Caamano Deno and Armed Forces Minister Francisco Rivera Caminero, to diplomatic posts abroad. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1966

headline: Law Firm Mergers Rose Again Last Year
abstract: Leading the way was the multinational law firm Dentons, which will have 3,000 more lawyers than the next largest firm.
lead_paragraph: Last year saw a record number of law firm mergers and acquisitions – 91 — and the largest-ever law firm merger, according to a newly released tally from the legal consulting company Altman Weil’s online tracking service.

headline: You Asked, Rand Paul Answered
abstract: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 11: Hotel California
abstract: In which we finally figure out what this season is actually about: stagnation.
lead_paragraph: It was somewhere during this penultimate episode of the fifth season of “American Horror Story” that I finally realized what the season is actually about: stagnation. For all the creepiness that a hotel’s transience lends to a story, what about the people who never leave? The Liz Taylors, the Irises, stuck watching as their lives pass them by, or Sally and March, stuck as the living pass them by.

headline: Roberta Vinci, Still Aglow From Landmark Upset, Embraces New Normal
abstract: Vinci, 32, who ended Serena Williams’s bid for a Grand Slam in 2015, spoke of retirement and said her goal for this year is to crack the top 10 for the first time.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — After putting an end to Serena Williams’s Grand Slam bid in the United States Open semifinals on an extraordinary September afternoon, Roberta Vinci has had to redefine what passes for normal in her life.

headline: Muslim Brotherhood Supporters Clash With Security Forces Outside Cairo Hotel
abstract: The Egyptian government attributed the violence to political unrest and said that tourists had not been directly targeted.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Security forces and supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood exchanged fire outside a hotel in Cairo on Thursday, in a sign of political tensions in advance of the fifth anniversary of the 2011 revolution this month.

headline: How the Government Has Responded to Armed Standoffs
abstract: Law enforcement officials’ response to armed antigovernment confrontations has changed over time. Here are examples.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials’ response to armed antigovernment confrontations has changed over time. Here are examples.

headline: Chris Christie Says Hillary Clinton Would Cut Marco Rubio’s ‘Heart Out’
abstract: In what could be a preview of next week’s Republican presidential debate, Gov. Chris Christie laced into Senator Marco Rubio in an interview with the conservative radio host Laura Ingraham this week, saying that Hillary Clinton will “cut his heart out.”
lead_paragraph: When the “super PAC” backing Senator Marco Rubio assailed Gov. Chris Christie’s record in New Jersey in tough new television ads this week, it was as if Mr. Christie had been presented with a gift.

headline: Fewer 1,000-Yard Rushers as Grand Milestone Fades
abstract: A trend toward more passing and other factors have led to fewer running backs reaching 1,000 yards. Seven did it this season, the lowest number since 1991.
lead_paragraph: The 1,000-yard rushing season has long been the benchmark of greatness in the N.F.L. Emmitt Smith did it a record 11 times, and Hall of Famers like Walter Payton, Barry Sanders, Tony Dorsett and Franco Harris all racked up many 1,000-yard seasons.

headline: Cynthia Harvey Named Artistic Director of American Ballet Theater School
abstract: Her appointment comes with the retirement in April of the current artistic director, Franco De Vita.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Harvey, the ballerina and teacher, has a busy year ahead. In addition to consulting work, she is to serve as a coach at the Prix de Lausanne, the global competition for young dancers, and continues to run her ballet nonprofit group, En Avant Foundation. But in the spring she will take on one of her biggest projects yet: She has been named the next artistic director of American Ballet Theater’s Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, effective in May.

headline: Bronx Man Charged With Slashing a Woman in Chelsea
abstract: The attack, which occurred just before 6 a.m. on Wednesday, left the woman with a gash around her lip that required seven stitches.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx man has been arrested and charged with slashing a woman across the face in Chelsea this week, leaving her with gashes near her lip that required seven stitches, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Favors Big Tariffs on Chinese Exports
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Donald J. Trump said he would favor a 45 percent tariff on Chinese exports to the United States, proposing the idea during a wide-ranging meeting with members of the editorial board of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said he would favor a 45 percent tariff on Chinese exports to the United States, proposing the idea during a wide-ranging meeting with members of the editorial board of The New York Times.

headline: Zhu, Chris Young and Wiki Release New Albums
abstract: Among this week’s look at new music, two memoirs are also added to the mix: One from Mac Mall, the other from Darlene Ortiz.
lead_paragraph: Genesis Series

headline: How an Unlikely Duo Became the Hottest Songwriters in Pop Music
abstract: Julia Michaels and Justin Tranter scored four Billboard hits together last year, including songs for Selena Gomez and Justin Bieber.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ten minutes into a recent recording session with a Grammy-winning producer they had never previously met, Julia Michaels and Justin Tranter, the in-demand pop songwriters of the moment, had a bouncy new hook.

headline: Video Review: Mercedes GLC300 Is a Midsize Crossover With Few Faults
abstract: The new GLC300 is drawn with softer lines than the GLK and is also roomier and 175 pounds lighter.
lead_paragraph: MERCEDES-BENZ isn’t new to the midsize crossover market. Its angular GLK arrived in America in 2009. Its replacement does far more than swap the letter K for a C. The new GLC300 is drawn with softer lines, reminiscent of the long-nose C-Class sedan. And why not? They share architectures.

headline: A Baker’s Antidote for Overindulgence
abstract: Melissa Weller of Sadelle’s in SoHo sips a daily turmeric tonic first thing in the morning to compensate for her work diet.
lead_paragraph: A life of everything bagel sandwiches and warm sticky buns can take its toll. “I do a lot of baking and tasting of baked goods while I work, and I compensate by eating lots of vegetables and legumes, and drinking a lot of water,” says Melissa Weller, the celebrated baker at the popular SoHo restaurant Sadelle’s, a New York Times Critics’ Pick, reviewed by Pete Wells this week. With balance as her goal, there are times when the baker completely eliminates dairy and sugar (and alcohol) from her diet. “I will still taste what I am baking at work, but only small tastes,” she says. Her other line of defense? A daily turmeric tonic. “I go to this first thing in the morning when I wake up,” says Weller, who started making the drink about a year ago at home. (Sqirl’s Jessica Koslow also touts turmeric for its restorative properties.) But babka lovers, have no fear: There are no plans of adding this drink to the menu anytime soon.

headline: Georgia Prosecutors Seek Indictment of Officer Who Shot Unarmed Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: “Our position is that the facts and the circumstances surrounding the shooting death of Anthony Hill warrant a charge for felony murder,” the prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — A prosecutor here said Thursday that he would seek a felony murder indictment against a white police officer who last year shot and killed Anthony Hill, a black man who was naked and unarmed at the time of the fatal encounter.

headline: In Britain, Shadows of Past Military Tactics Loom Large
abstract: An ISIS video warns that Britain will lose in Syria “as you lost in Iraq and Afghanistan,” and reports of abuse by British troops in Iraq are growing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a time known to its detractors as a decade of hubris, when Western powers deployed the muscular military tactics of the 19th and early 20th centuries in the opening years of the 21st to project their power in flawed attempts to forge distant national destinies in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Obama Pleads for Stricter Gun Laws and Faces Tough Questioning
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: In an intense but civil town-hall-style event broadcast live on television, activists pressed President Obama to justify his gun-control efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an intense but civil town-hall-style event broadcast live on television, gun rights activists repeatedly pressed President Obama on Thursday night to justify his gun control efforts, putting him on the defensive over an issue that has divided the nation’s capital and the presidential campaign trail.

headline: For Stock Markets, January Is a Cloudy Crystal Ball
abstract: The Stock Trader’s Almanac first posited that January markets can foretell the direction of the trading year, but statistics experts say causation is impossible to prove — or disprove.
lead_paragraph: As January goes, so goes the entire market year.

headline: Jeb Bush Names Most-Loved Family Member. (Hint: It’s Mom.)
abstract: In New Hampshire, Jeb Bush revealed that he loves his mother more than his father, and the former Florida governor went on to add that he is “better looking” than Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — The men of the Bush family hate being “put on the couch,” their preferred term for dismissing the news media’s attempts to psychoanalyze their political dynasty.

headline: ‘The Finest Hours’ Relives a Perilous, Forgotten Rescue
abstract: The film explores a maritime incident from 1952 that naval historians refer to as the greatest small-boat rescue in history.
lead_paragraph: QUINCY, MASS. — “The Finest Hours,” which opens Jan. 29, is very closely based on a real-life rescue that took place at sea in February 1952, when, during a nor’easter at least as fierce as the one immortalized in “The Perfect Storm,” not one but two oil tankers broke apart off the coast of Cape Cod. They were T2’s, ships hastily built of inferior metal during World War II and sometimes known as “serial sinkers” for their tendency to snap in half during cold weather.

headline: Stephen Petronio and Anish Kapoor Team Up to Sell Art for Dance’s Sake
abstract: The choreographer Stephen Petronio, who is beginning a $3 million campaign to establish a choreographic residency program in Pawling, N.Y., announced Thursday that he had received a gift from the artist Anish Kapoor.
lead_paragraph: Once again the world of visual art, which creates durable works that can command astronomical prices, is coming to the aid of the world of performing arts, in which it is increasingly difficult to find the money to create and present works that last just until the curtain falls.

headline: Review: In ‘The Treasure,’ Digging for Something of Value in Romania
abstract: Corneliu Porumboiu, this film’s director, waits for dramatic events to arise instead of forcing the action.
lead_paragraph: Costi, the Romanian Everyman at the center of “The Treasure,” leads a reasonably comfortable if not terribly exciting life. Played by Cuzin Toma, an actor with a melancholy, sensitive face and a gentle manner, Costi has an office job and a tidy, somewhat sterile apartment, where he lives with his wife, Raluca, and their young son, Alin (played by Mr. Toma’s real-life wife and son, Cristina and Nicodim). The boy likes to hear fairy tales at bedtime, and his father soon finds himself on an adventure that has all the markings of a modern fable.

headline: New York to Appoint Civilian to Monitor Police’s Counterterrorism Activity
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Muslim Americans', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: An agreement, coming as the city moves to settle lawsuits over surveillance targeting Muslims, would restore some of the outside oversight that was eliminated after the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: The mayor will appoint an independent civilian to monitor the New York Police Department’s counterterrorism activities, lawyers said in court documents on Thursday as they moved to settle a pair of lawsuits over surveillance targeting Muslims in the decade after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Poland’s President Approves Controls on State Media, Alarming E.U. Leaders
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The legislation will allow Poland’s new conservative government to appoint and dismiss the executives in charge of public television and radio broadcasters.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s president, Andrzej Duda, signed a law on Thursday that gives the government greater control over state broadcasters, despite the objections of European Union officials who fear that the measure will weaken freedom of the press.

headline: Parents Monitoring Teenagers Online, and Mostly, Getting It Right
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Social Media', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Parents are relying more on talk than tools to monitor teenagers online.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, researchers from Pew have been looking at parents, teenagers and the Internet. They’ve looked at how teenagers live their lives online, and how they feel about that new (to adults) arena. Now, in a newly released report, the researchers are exploring what parents and teenagers say about how parents monitor teenagers online and, perhaps more interestingly, how they don’t.

headline: Oregon Pinot Noir Delivers an Element of Surprise
abstract: Early rains in 2013 forced small yields, with lean and earthy flavors that are full of tension.
lead_paragraph: Recent vintages of Oregon pinot noir have been fascinating. But they may have also been confusing for consumers who would like a one-word association with the notion of Oregon pinot noir.

headline: Reader Response: A Natural Hair Salon in Santo Domingo
abstract: A beauty salon specializing in natural, curly hair in the Dominican Republic, where straightened hair reigns, got a huge response from readers.
lead_paragraph: Our recent article about people who travel to a salon in the Dominican Republic that styles hair in natural coils rather than straightening it drew more than 100 comments from readers. Many not only touched on the standard of straightening hair but also expanded on the view of race within the Dominican Republic. Here are a few edited excerpts.

headline: Mama Mea Culpa: A Tattered Family Relationship Needs Mending
abstract: Plus: an unhappy colleague who doesn’t hesitate to share, a party for a departing friend and prolonging a debate.
lead_paragraph: My mother-in-law plays favorites, openly doting on my husband’s brother and his family. I ignored it for years; it didn’t seem to bother my husband. I also ignored that I was treated worse. But things changed when I had children. After a visit when my mother-in-law spent little time with my children, praising her other grandchildren instead, I sent a letter telling her what I had noticed. It was badly received. We have settled into an icy standoff. My children have not noticed their nana’s absence, but I hate to think of them not knowing her. What should I do?

headline: Marco Rubio Aims New TV Ad at Iowa’s Evangelical Voters
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a Roman Catholic, addresses his faith in the ad as he tries to slow the momentum of Senator Ted Cruz in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: As the Rubio campaign tries to halt the momentum of Senator Ted Cruz in Iowa, it has released a new ad aimed directly at evangelical voters, called “Faith,” in which Senator Marco Rubio discusses Christianity.

headline: Judith Kaye, a Pioneer in New York’s Courts [Updated]
abstract: Ms. Kaye, who died this week, was the first woman to serve as chief judge of New York State.
lead_paragraph: Judith Kaye, the former chief judge of New York State — and the first woman to hold that very influential job — has died after an illness, The New York Daily News reported on Thursday. She was 77.

headline: Marvin Newman Beyond the Single Image
abstract: “Sequentially Sought,” an exhibition at the Howard Greenberg Gallery, showcases Marvin Newman’s sometimes tongue-in-cheek series from 1950s New York and Chicago.
lead_paragraph: “Sequentially Sought,” an exhibition at the Howard Greenberg Gallery, showcases Marvin Newman’s sometimes tongue-in-cheek series from 1950s New York and Chicago.

headline: Confronting the Oregon Standoff, What Would Teddy Have Done?
