abstract: What would Teddy Roosevelt, who created the Malheur refuge, have done about an armed occupation?
lead_paragraph: [On Jan. 26, one occupier was killed and seven arrested as law enforcement officials tightened a cordon around Malheur.]

headline: As Rebel-Held Town of Madaya Starves, Syria Agrees to Food Aid, U.N. Says
abstract: With no firm date for deliveries to begin to Madaya, however, tens of thousands of people remain at risk, United Nations officials warned.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Amid mounting international dismay over reports of starvation deaths and images of skeletally thin children in the besieged, rebel-held Syrian town of Madaya, the Syrian government agreed Thursday to allow the delivery of humanitarian aid, according to the United Nations.

headline: Judith S. Kaye, First Woman to Serve as New York’s Chief Judge, Dies at 77
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Women and Girls', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Judge Kaye was the first woman named to New York’s highest court and held the job of chief judge longer than any of her 21 male predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Judith S. Kaye, the first woman named to the highest court in New York and the first to serve as the state’s chief judge — a job she held longer than any of her 21 male predecessors — died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Company Names Andrew Essex Chief Executive
abstract: Tribeca Enterprises, the company behind the Tribeca Film Festival, has hired a new chief executive from Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Tribeca Enterprises, the company behind the Tribeca Film Festival, has hired a new chief executive from Madison Avenue as it seeks further growth, in particular by turning its constellation of businesses into a more cohesive whole.

headline: Why Polls Have Been Wrong Recently
abstract: Polls often err, but it can be hard to identify a cause. A new analysis by Pew offers some interesting guidance.
lead_paragraph: The polling industry has been hit hard by high-profile misfires in recent years. Pollsters got last November’s Kentucky governor’s race wrong, as they did the 2014 midterm elections. They have missed predictions in elections in Israel and Britain.

headline: When Narcissism Mixes With Money in Politics
abstract: Readers call for change in a presidential year.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 6 Tips for Investors When the Stock Market Tumbles
abstract: The impulse when the stock market falls hard for a few days in a row is to do something but it probably doesn’t make much sense to overhaul an investment strategy based on a blip of market activity.
lead_paragraph: The impulse when the stock market falls hard for a few days in a row is to do something but it probably doesn’t make much sense to overhaul an investment strategy based on a blip of market activity.

headline: Kim Jong-un’s Generational Ambitions
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The hydrogen-bomb test the young leader claims to have conducted isn’t just saber-rattling — it suggests his vision for the future of his isolated country.
lead_paragraph: It was party time in Pyongyang. Workers scrambled to hang congratulatory banners in the lobby of the Koryo Hotel, my home away from home in the North Korean capital, where I was posted as an Associated Press correspondent. A gaggle of cooks, still in aprons and chef’s hats, dashed out from the kitchen to watch the festivities, and mothers tightened the pink bows in their daughters’ hair as the girls fidgeted in anticipation.

headline: Brother Vellies’s Aurora James Travels To Ethiopia
abstract: The designer finds inspiration in the people of the Omo Valley — and meets with craftsmen she employs through her work with the Ethical Fashion Initiative.
lead_paragraph: The designer finds inspiration in the people of the Omo Valley — and meets with craftsmen she employs through her work with the Ethical Fashion Initiative.

headline: The Oregon Protest and the Battle Over Western Lands
abstract: An armed protest at a remote federal wildlife refuge was the latest flare-up in a decades-long struggle over control of federal land.
lead_paragraph: An armed protest at a remote federal wildlife refuge was the latest flare-up in a decades-long struggle over control of federal land.

headline: Factory Jobs and Robots
abstract: The Alliance for American Manufacturing writes that robots are less responsible for lost jobs than recessions and offshoring.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kevin Spacey Named Chairman of Relativity Studios
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Relativity Media announced the appointments of Mr. Spacey, the actor, and his business partner Dana Brunetti to executive roles as it acquired a production company operated by the pair.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Relativity Media, emerging from bankruptcy, is adding some star power to its executive ranks. On Thursday, the company said the actor Kevin Spacey would become chairman of its Relativity Studios unit and Mr. Spacey’s business partner, Dana Brunetti, would become president.

headline: People’s Choice Awards Red Carpet
abstract: The fans do the voting for these awards, naming winners that include “Homeland” and the actress Priyanka Chopra.
lead_paragraph: The fans do the voting for these awards, naming winners that include “Homeland” and the actress Priyanka Chopra.

headline: Kitty Kallen, Big Band Singer of ‘Bésame Mucho,’ Dies at 94
abstract: Her voice, sweet and clear, welcomed the troops home from World War II, singing, “Kiss me one, kiss me twice, kiss me once again.”
lead_paragraph: Kitty Kallen, her voice sweet and clear, welcomed the troops home from World War II, singing: “Kiss me once, then kiss me twice, then kiss me once again. It’s been a long, long time.” She turned out hits like “Bésame Mucho,” “I’m Beginning to See the Light,” “In the Chapel in the Moonlight” and “Little Things Mean a Lot” — many reaching the Top 10.

headline: Football Injuries
abstract: A reader writes that a shorter play clock would do little to make the game safer.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: You Asked, Rand Paul Answered
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'National Debt (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senator Paul answered a reader’s question during his visit to the editorial board.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, we asked you to submit questions for Rand Paul. During his visit to the editorial board, he picked one of your questions from a hat to answer on camera. Watch his response below:

headline: A Designer Finds Inspiration — and Creates Jobs — in Ethiopia
abstract: Aurora James, creative director of the brand Brother Vellies, traveled around the country — where she is producing pieces with local craftspeople.
lead_paragraph: As the founder and creative director of the three-year-old shoe company Brother Vellies, Aurora James often travels to different countries in Africa — such as South Africa, Kenya and Morocco — where she sources fabrics and manufactures all of her products.

headline: Review: ‘Germinal’ Sheds a Light on Creativity and All Creation
abstract: This show from France, part of the Under the Radar Festival, reinvents a creation myth, tracing the evolution of human consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Let there be light, for starters. That’s the classic way to begin things, right?

headline: This Is Her Face. This Is Her Face in Bread. Any Questions?
abstract: A gluten-free age gets the Instagram trend it deserves, bread-facing.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of a woman who became famous on Instagram for smooshing her face into bread products.

headline: Rape Statute of Limitations
abstract: A criminal defense lawyer defends the law.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ted Cruz’s Tax Proposal

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Regulate Drones
abstract: A retired law professor offers a solution to the problem of who gets to regulate these recreational flying vehicles.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trying to Understand China’s Market Upheaval
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The falling renminbi may be a sign that China sees currency devaluation as a solution to its economic woes. Or maybe planners are losing their grip.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than six months, market turmoil in China is rattling the rest of the world. As in August last year, the trigger is a sudden slide in the value of the renminbi, which in turn has dragged down domestic stocks. Though the cause of the sell-off is uncertain, the implications for the rest of the world are ominous.

headline: Peeking Into the Gilded Age at the Met
abstract: A new period room at the Metropolitan Museum of Art showcases 19th-century design, alongside an exhibition focused on furniture from the era.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art recently unveiled a new period room, and it’s a beauty. Called the Worsham-Rockefeller Dressing Room, it’s a consummate expression of Aestheticism, a trans-Atlantic, 19th-century design movement that combined European Renaissance, Modern, Islamic and Japanese styles into luxurious objects and sumptuous environments for well-to-do hedonists. Having recently undergone conservation by the Met, the dressing room joins 19 other period rooms in the museum’s American Wing.

headline: Sharing a Cab, and My Toes
abstract: During a taxi ride home a co-worker makes a surprising request.
lead_paragraph: As I rode in a cab across the Brooklyn Bridge, a man I barely knew was sucking my toes. The lights of the bridge streaked overhead, and Manhattan was a jeweled kingdom shrinking behind us in the darkness of the rearview mirror.

headline: Marco Rubio Reacts to Those Boots That Were Made for Talking
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida seemed both disgusted and amused by the worldwide attention that have bee given to his sleek high-heel boots.
lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. — “This is craziness!” Marco Rubio said on Thursday, finally addressing the buzz over his boots.

headline: Ross Partridge on ‘Lamb’ and Uncomfortable Viewers
abstract: The actor and director says that the film’s central relationship, between a 47-year-old man and an 11-year-old girl, isn’t easily defined.
lead_paragraph: The friendship between a middle-aged man and a young girl is at the heart of “Lamb,” a drama from the director Ross Partridge, who also stars as the lead character David Lamb, and adapted the screenplay from the novel by Bonnie Nadzam. The character, adrift and searching for meaning, meets an 11-year-old girl, Tommie (Oona Laurence), in a parking lot when she asks him for a cigarette. This begins an unlikely friendship, one that may raise eyebrows and cause discomfort for many viewers. The film, and book from which it is adapted, looks at the not-easily-definable contours of the relationship in compelling ways, but the subject matter is tricky to say the least.

headline: Ötzi the Iceman’s Stomach Bacteria Offers Clues on Human Migration
abstract: An insight into the peopling of Europe has emerged from an unlikely source — the stomach contents of a 5,300-year-old body pulled from a thawing glacier.
lead_paragraph: An insight into the peopling of Europe has emerged from an unlikely source — the stomach contents of a 5,300-year-old body pulled from a thawing glacier in the eastern Italian Alps.

headline: Can U.S. Remain an Island of Stability in the Global Economy?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The economic mismatch between the United States and much of the rest of the world is not good for either party.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese stock market is plummeting so fast that authorities there keep shutting it down. North Korea set off a bomb in a nuclear test. Two of the Middle East’s great powers, Saudi Arabia and Iran, are eyeing each other menacingly. In the European Union, political extremists are on the rise, migrants are pouring in and Britain may drop out (three phenomena that are not unrelated).

headline: Genetic Flip Helped Organisms Go From One Cell to Many
abstract: Some simple changes in ancient organisms might have given rise to a world of multicellular animals.
lead_paragraph: Narwhals and newts, eagles and eagle rays — the diversity of animal forms never ceases to amaze. At the root of this spectacular diversity is the fact that all animals are made up of many cells — in our case, about 37 trillion of them. As an animal develops from a fertilized egg, its cells may diversify into a seemingly limitless range of types and tissues, from tusks to feathers to brains.

headline: Based on Hall Vote, Bonds and Clemens Shouldn’t Be Excited
abstract: As it turned out, nothing about the Baseball Hall of Fame voting this year indicated that the electorate was warming to the idea of electing Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, it’s time to ratchet things down a little bit.

headline: After Outcry Over Lack of Female Grand Prize Nominees, Angoulême Comics Festival Opens Prize to a Vote
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The Angoulême International Comics Festival prompted protests when it nominated only men for its Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: How do you say “no girls allowed” in French? That was the sentiment this week when the Angoulême International Comics Festival in France released its list of 30 nominees for its Grand Prix award and none was female.

headline: Media General Agrees to Be Acquired by Nexstar, but Meredith Objects
abstract: Media General is still bound by a previous deal to acquire the Meredith Corporation, which is reluctant to call off the engagement.
lead_paragraph: Media General should be familiar with soap operas. The company operates 71 television stations across the United States. But it is having a difficult time climbing out of a particularly tricky mergers and acquisitions love triangle.

headline: A Surge of Interest in East-Bloc Mementos
abstract: From auctions to exhibitions to new books, the art, industrial design and political detritus of Communist-era rule are very much of the moment.
lead_paragraph: When Communist regimes in Europe were unraveling in 1989, collaborators and dissidents alike began destroying vital historical material, from statues of dictators to family snapshots of government informers to manuals that exaggerated the quality of East German car engines. Now relics of ordinary life and heinous acts in the Soviet bloc are resurfacing in museums, publications and auctions.

headline: Julie Ault at Galerie Buchholz, the Curator as Artist
abstract: Ms. Ault expands on her method of expressive, highly individualized curating by combining art owned and borrowed.
lead_paragraph: Julie Ault’s art mediums are collaboration and accumulation. She was a co-founder in 1980 of Group Material, a collective that treated archival-style installations as walk-through art objects. She created a memorable 2013 solo show at Artists Space, “Macho Man: Tell It to My Heart,” entirely from her personal collection of work by other artists gathered over many years. In the 2014 Whitney Biennial, she further expanded on this method of expressive, highly individualized curating by combining art owned and borrowed.

headline: Planned Parenthood, in Its First Primary Endorsement, Backs Hillary Clinton
abstract: Planned Parenthood said that it would endorse Hillary Clinton — its first endorsement in a presidential primary in the nonprofit’s 100-year existence.
lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood, which has become an ideological minefield in the 2016 presidential election, said Thursday that it would endorse Hillary Clinton — its first endorsement in a presidential primary in the nonprofit’s 100-year existence.

headline: Paris Museums and Nightclubs Show Signs of Recovery After Attacks
abstract: Public campaigns and promotions have helped lift attendance at museums, theaters and nightclubs after the slump caused by the Nov. 13 attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The first nights after the Nov. 13 attacks in and around Paris, dancers at the Crazy Horse cabaret donned their sequins and gamely performed “La Marseillaise” before empty tables and uncorked Champagne bottles.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: A Momentary Scare
abstract: At a Pizza Ranch in Pocahontas, Iowa, Ted Cruz expressed gratitude about the size of his family, and checked on a woman who briefly fainted, reportedly at the sound of a Democrat’s name.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: The Choreographer-Director David Gordon’s Archive to Go to Public Library
abstract: A series of experimental workshop performances re-examining Mr. Gordon’s past is also coming.
lead_paragraph: What do you get when a seminal postmodern choreographer donates his archives? A “reconsideration of conventional archival methodology,” naturally, along with a series of new, experimental workshop performances re-examining the artist’s past.

headline: Signature Theater Names Paige Evans as Artistic Director
abstract: Ms. Evans, the artistic director of LCT3, Lincoln Center Theater’s program for the production of shows by new playwrights, directors and designers, will succeed James Houghton.
lead_paragraph: Signature Theater Company, one of the leading Off Broadway nonprofit organizations, has chosen a top official of Lincoln Center Theater to be its next artistic director.

headline: Crowd Gathers to Greet Donald Trump in Bernie Sanders Territory
abstract: A crowd of Trump supporters, hecklers and curious observers braved freezing temperatures to get a glimpse of the Republican presidential candidate who dared to set foot upon the traditionally liberal turf of Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Hours before Donald J. Trump was set to hold a rally in the Flynn Center here, a crowd of supporters, hecklers and curious observers braved freezing temperatures to get a glimpse of the Republican presidential candidate who dared to set foot on the traditionally liberal turf of Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: To Feel More at Home, Islanders Skip Morning Trips to Brooklyn
abstract: The team is reverting to a game-day routine based on Long Island for now, so players have more time at home before heading to Barclays Center for games.
lead_paragraph: SYOSSET, N.Y. — Halfway through their first season in Brooklyn, the Islanders are, for now, stopping their game-day routine of morning commutes to Barclays Center and afternoon hotel stays near the arena.

headline: Monika Baer Makes Emblems of Liquor Bottles
abstract: Ms. Baer’s “on hold,” at Greene Naftali, plays with illusionism and abstraction.

headline: Michel Platini Ends Bid for FIFA Presidency
abstract: Mr. Platini, who was a favorite to win the election before receiving an eight-year ban from world soccer, dropped out of a race that technically did not include him.
lead_paragraph: Michel Platini said Thursday that he was ending his bid to become FIFA president, dropping out of a race that technically did not include him and one that he is officially barred from winning.

headline: Bill Viola’s New Video Project Is a Rebirth of Sorts
abstract: In “Inverted Birth,” slow-motion and reverse techniques are used to dramatic effect with a flood of water.
lead_paragraph: Bill Viola goes for big, cosmic themes, which he funnels into technically impressive video works of compelling, quasi-religious sincerity. The main event of this exhibition is an awesome video called “Inverted Birth.” The 15-foot-tall projection shows in slow motion and in reverse a man standing on a bare stage as he is subjected to a tremendous deluge of liquid. This is accompanied by the electronically amplified roar of pouring water.

headline: Robin Winters Evokes Counterculture Flair in ‘Free Standing Sentence’
abstract: The small paintings, sculptures and other works in this exhibit are on shelves that wrap around the walls at eye level.
lead_paragraph: Robin Winters moved to New York from California in the early 1970s and later participated in Colab, a downtown artists’ group that mounted radical exhibitions like “The Real Estate Show” (1979-80) and “The Times Square Show” (1980). But he has always retained elements of San Francisco’s ’60s counterculture, in which he came of age, roaming among performance, painting, poetry and blown glass. His current exhibition is perfectly installed in Present Company, a cozy young gallery in Bushwick that describes itself on its website as an “exhibition and social space.”

headline: ‘The Creeping Expansion of Gun Control Laws’: Readers on Obama’s Executive Actions
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Gun Control', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In response to a recent editorial, readers debated whether the government wants to confiscate guns from responsible owners.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the debate about President Obama’s planned executive actions on firearms was one question: Will the government ultimately want to confiscate weapons from responsible gun owners?

headline: Saudi Aramco I.P.O. Is Weighed by Kingdom
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A listing of shares could make Saudi Aramco, whose reserves are 10 times that of Exxon Mobil, the most valuable public company in the world.
lead_paragraph: There are big initial public offerings — the $25 billion stock sale by the Alibaba Group, the biggest on record; the $16 billion market debut of Facebook — and then there are really big ones.

headline: Moonchild Sanelly’s Johannesburg
abstract: The musician and designer takes T to some of her favorite spots in her hometown, South Africa’s biggest city.
lead_paragraph: The musician and designer takes T to some of her favorite spots in her hometown, South Africa’s biggest city.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Arms Test
abstract: Readers call for enactment of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty and a return of the 1954 Geneva Conference on Korea.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Trip Through Johannesburg With Its Coolest Resident
abstract: The musician and fashion designer shows T her favorite spots in South Africa’s biggest city.
lead_paragraph: Describing Moonchild Sanelly’s look with precision is an impossible feat — it’s as if Sailor Moon took an acid trip through the continent of Africa. But it’s distinctly South African: wildly inventive, undeniably original and solidly homegrown. When we meet to take a shopping trip in her hometown Johannesburg, she is wearing a jet-black velvet jumpsuit of her own creation, set off by the electric-blue wool she’s plaited into her natural hair to create a brightly-colored bob. (She calls it her “moon mop.”) In Johannesburg, Sanelly is something of a local celebrity, known for her performances and the pool parties she throws to celebrate a new song or fashion collection. Walking through the hip neighborhoods of Maboneng and Braamfontein, the energetic 28-year-old stops to say hello to nearly everyone, from the stylish women having afternoon drinks at an outdoor bar to the guys in the Adidas shop and the men selling grilled meat on the street.

headline: Tony Yazbeck Will be the New J.M. Barrie in ‘Finding Neverland’
abstract: Tony Yazbeck will replace Matthew Morrison in “Finding Neverland.”
lead_paragraph: Neverland has found its next J.M. Barrie.

headline: “Mad About the Boy” Opens in London
abstract: A new exhibition at the London College of Fashion explores men’s wear and youth culture.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition at the London College of Fashion explores men’s wear and youth culture.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Jan. 9 Through 17
abstract: Members of the Dance Theater of Harlem will perform at the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center this month.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: In London, an Exploration of Men’s Wear and Youth Culture
abstract: “Mad About the Boy,” a new exhibition at the London College of Fashion, opens on the eve of the men’s shows.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow, men’s shows will officially begin in London — and just in time comes an exhibition, “Mad About the Boy,” that puts it all in context. Held in the gallery of the London College of Fashion, the show examines the link between garments on the catwalk and the youth tropes they drew inspiration from, and vice versa. Silhouettes from designers including Raf Simons, J.W. Anderson and Christopher Shannon are shown alongside fashion, street and documentary images.

headline: A View of Mexico City
abstract: Above and beyond the Angel of Independence monument in the city's Paseo de la Reforma.
lead_paragraph: Above and beyond the Angel of Independence monument in the city's Paseo de la Reforma.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Jan. 9 Through 17
abstract: The comedian Arsenio Hall, who had a hit syndicated late-night show in the early 1990s, will perform on Jan. 16 at Foxwoods Resort Casino.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: New Pee-wee Herman Film to Be Shown at SXSW
abstract: The South by Southwest Film Festival announced a handful of films to premiere at the festival, including a new Pee-Wee Herman movie.
lead_paragraph: Pee-wee Herman’s on his way to Austin.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
abstract: Serbia and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Serbia and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 7, 2016 — Pictures of the day
abstract: Photos from Serbia, France, the West Bank and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Serbia, France, the West Bank and Germany.

headline: Review: ‘Dynasty,’ Tom Holland’s Chronicle of the First Five Emperors Who Ruled Ancient Rome
abstract: This British historian tells the story of ancient Rome with great authority and relish.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing could be fainter than those torches which allow us, not to pierce the darkness, but to glimpse it,” wrote the philosopher Seneca, shortly before his former student Nero forced him to commit suicide. And ancient history — where the record is fragmented and riddled with unknown unknowns — is a pictorial parade lit more by flickering torches than by a steady, burning light. Still, with his new book, “Dynasty,” the British historian Tom Holland has crafted a history of early Rome that has all the gripping detail and narrative momentum of a novel.

headline: Review: The Cellist Okkyung Lee Tests Extended Technique’s Boundaries
abstract: Ms. Lee joined the drummers Chris Corsano and Ches Smith for an evening of improvisation, part of her three-night residency at Jack in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: What Okkyung Lee does on the cello is often called “extended technique,” which means producing sounds by unusual means. But she more or less obliterates the need for the term. When she keeps her fingers choked up on the neck, pointing downward near the bridge, or rubs her bow against the strings to make sluicing sounds and hard, guttural rips, this is her standard; this is her usual. It’s part of her language.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Using ‘Star Wars’ to Knock the Democrats
abstract: Ted Cruz said that the new “Star Wars” movie was “much more realistic and down-to-earth than whatever the Democrats were talking about” at their last debate.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: How News From Seoul Found Its Way Into the Paper in 75 Minutes
abstract: News of seismic activity in North Korea surfaced Tuesday night. How did The Times get a full story on the paper’s front page the next morning?
lead_paragraph: David E. Sanger, The Times’s chief Washington correspondent who has covered North Korea’s nuclear program since its infancy, was watching television with his wife and children at around 9:15 on Tuesday evening when he saw reports of seismic activity in North Korea.

headline: Portraits by Ethan James Green
abstract: The photographer’s photos, many of which highlight the fluidity of gender, are intimate, sympathetic and haunting.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s photos, many of which highlight the fluidity of gender, are intimate, sympathetic and haunting.

headline: Intimate, Haunting Portraits of New York City Youth
abstract: The photographer (and model) Ethan James Green finds many of the subjects in his ongoing series of creatives on social media.
lead_paragraph: While his images are stylistically timeless, the photographer Ethan James Green’s process is entirely contemporary: He actively uses social media as a tool to discover subjects for his ongoing series of New York City creatives. “I think the rules are quickly changing!” Green says. “With social media, DIY has become much easier. Most of the people I photograph knew each other first online and now many are working with each other professionally. I think it has allowed the city to become a bit like the Wild West again.”

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Jan. 9 Through 17
abstract: The Nassau County Museum of Art offers “Family Sundays at the Museum” with hands-on art activities and opportunities to converse and collaborate.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Anesthesia’ Ponders the Meaningfulness of Life
abstract: This film considers the cruel paradox of living amid life-enhancing technological miracles that don’t fulfill a yearning for a more purposeful existence.
lead_paragraph: “Anesthesia,” Tim Blake Nelson’s exquisitely compressed cri de coeur about the meaning of life in a hyper-connected world, begins as a knife-wielding stranger viciously attacks Walter (Sam Waterston), a wise, kindhearted Columbia University philosophy professor at the door of his apartment building. The circular story immediately backtracks to observe Walter, who is on the verge of retirement after 34 years, addressing a class and posing the same unanswerable questions he has been pondering out loud for more than three decades.

headline: Venomous Sea Snakes Showing Up in Distress at Beaches
abstract: New reports of the snakes on Australian beaches came after the rare appearance of two in California.
lead_paragraph: A species of highly venomous sea snake that made rare appearances on two California beaches in recent months has also been washing up thousands of miles away in Australia.

headline: Review: ‘Big Dance: Short Form’ Delivers Traditional Repertory With a Party Midway
abstract: Big Dance Theater turned intermission into an onstage celebration of that group’s 25th-anniversary season, bringing a rush of vitality to the program at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: A Ping-Pong table, a game of Twister, cocktail franks heated in a microwave and cans of Budweiser? No, it wasn’t your typical intermission.

headline: Ad Wars of 2016 Campaign Erupt in a Changing TV Arena
abstract: Candidates and the outside groups supporting them are betting that television ads will remain a crucial political battlefield when signs increasingly suggest otherwise.
lead_paragraph: On WMUR, the dominant television station in Manchester, N.H., about 25 percent of commercial time is being eaten up by presidential campaign ads. Already this week, the candidates and their allies have fired off a dozen new commercials, a third of them negative, in Iowa and New Hampshire markets.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Jan. 9 Through 17
abstract: Spike Lee’s film “Chi-Raq,” inspired by Aristophanes’ “Lysistrata,” will be shown on Jan. 12 and 13 at the Rosendale Theater.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Anesthesia’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Anesthesia.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Anesthesia.”

headline: Review: In ‘Angel’s Bone,’ Terrified Seraphim at the Mercy of Mortals
abstract: Du Yun’s audacious opera at the 3LD Art & Technology Center portrays two angels who land in a couple’s backyard and are then viciously exploited.
lead_paragraph: Smaller, louder and unmistakably of the moment: That seems to be the punchy vision of opera that drives the Prototype Festival, which opened its fourth season on Wednesday with Du Yun’s audacious and searing “Angel’s Bone.” It’s an appallingly good work when you consider that it takes on the subject of child trafficking and mixes in elements of magic realism and a musical cocktail of Renaissance polyphony, electronica, Modernism, punk rock and cabaret.

headline: Maurice Hines Opens His Heart in ‘Tappin’ Thru Life’
abstract: Mr. Hines, who has been performing for most of his life, uses his autobiographical show to teach the next generation and to keep memories alive.
lead_paragraph: The main difference between how Maurice Hines talks to a reporter visiting his dressing room and how he talks to an audience from the stage is that offstage the polished anecdotes don’t smoothly segue into song and dance. Mr. Hines is an entertainer, one who has been performing professionally for most of his 72 years. He aims to please, and he knows how to do it.

headline: In Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis, an Absence of Enforcers
abstract: With high unemployment and rising departures by residents, Puerto Rico’s decision to skip $37 million of interest and principal payments is probably only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: The municipal bond market in the United States is desperately lacking enforcers. Puerto Rico’s debt crisis is the latest example to expose the shortcoming. Foolish financial crowds had better wise up to other danger zones.

headline: Martin Shkreli Used $45 Million E-Trade Account to Secure Bond
abstract: The account at the online securities firm, disclosed by federal prosecutors, is the first public accounting of how much money the businessman has made.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, the New York businessman charged by federal prosecutors with defrauding his former hedge fund investors, is worth at least $45 million.

headline: Donald Trump Brings Gridlock to Vermont
abstract: Donald J. Trump brought gridlock to Burlington, Vt., as the police braced for an overflow of thousands of political activists who were certain to be shut out from the candidate’s rally.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Donald J. Trump brought gridlock here on Thursday afternoon, as the police shut down two blocks of the city’s main corridor and braced for an overflow of thousands of political activists who would not fit inside the intimate Flynn Theater for his rally.

headline: Review: John Luther Adams’s ‘The Light Within’ Highlights Ensemble Program at National Sawdust
abstract: Among the multimedia pieces presented by Le Train Bleu, Mr. Adams’s work, despite lacking a visual component, offered the most alluring sensory experience.
lead_paragraph: During a performance of John Luther Adams’s “The Light Within,” at National Sawdust on Tuesday evening, I had the luxurious sensation of being enveloped in almost tactile layers of sound. Indeed, on this program of multimedia pieces presented by the ensemble Le Train Bleu, Mr. Adams’s work, despite being the only one without a visual component, offered the most alluring sensory experience.

headline: Municipal Identification Card Program Offers Free Cultural Benefits
abstract: Enrollment in the program includes free annual memberships to 40 institutions. Here’s a borough-by-borough list of highlights.
lead_paragraph: It’s early in the new year, but miserly culture hounds can already reap dividends. New York City has just extended through 2016 the free enrollment deadline for its municipal identification card program. Benefits include free annual memberships to 40 institutions.

headline: Review: Visiting a Lolita-Land of Sorts With ‘Lamb’
abstract: “Lamb,” with Ross Partridge as its director, star and screenwriter, based his film on a novel by Bonnie Nadzam.
lead_paragraph: “Lamb,” a slow-burning creep-out about a kidnapping, would like you to see it as a requiem for the lost and the loveless. Set in a present that looks like real life but doesn’t feel like it, the story pivots on its title sad sack, David Lamb, a habitual dissembler and possible sociopath mired in personal and professional crisis. Death, marital and work woes, a young mistress — Lamb has it all when one day he sweeps away an 11-year-old girl, taking her for, well, what exactly is the question that reverberates queasily through this movie, its hotel rooms and weepy moments.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Lamb’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Lamb.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Lamb.”

headline: Bequest Adds Expressionist Layers to Dallas Museum of Art
abstract: Dorace Fichtenbaum’s will enriches the Dallas museum, while the Morgan Library & Museum highlights Warhol’s work with books, and Art21 names a new executive director.
lead_paragraph: Dorace Fichtenbaum had been generous toward the Dallas Museum of Art, donating funds as well as artworks. But the museum never expected this.

abstract: The actress wore a beaded Armani Privé top and skirt on stage at the People’s Choice Awards last night.

abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “The Treasure.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “The Treasure.”

headline: Bill Clinton, Back in Iowa, Refuses to Respond to Donald Trump
abstract: Bill Clinton returned to the campaign trail in Iowa, where he shied away from questions about Donald J. Trump but embraced topics like renewable energy and confronting allergies.
lead_paragraph: “Are there a lot of apiaries here?”

headline: Recordings Add Detail in Death of Woman Forced From Florida Hospital
abstract: Three state agencies are investigating the death in Blountstown of Barbara Dawson, whom the police tried to remove from a parking lot.
lead_paragraph: State officials in Florida are investigating the death of a 57-year-old woman who was removed from a hospital by a police officer last month and then spent about 20 minutes on the ground in the parking lot before later being pronounced dead.

headline: At the Studio Museum in Harlem, 4 Shows Engage a Cultural Conversation
abstract: Shows culled mostly from the museum’s permanent collection join the conversation on black culture.
lead_paragraph: For nearly five decades, the Studio Museum in Harlem has served as a cultural repository, reflecting the ruptures, shifts and spectrum of experiences for artists of African descent. Its current grouping of shows, culled mostly from the museum’s permanent collection, echoes this landscape, looking backward and forward. The main exhibition, “A Constellation,” includes the work of 26 artists and focuses on themes of abstraction, the figure and the history of the African diaspora. “Black: Color, Material, Concept” continues the conversation around blackness initiated by Thelma Golden, director and chief curator of the museum, who introduced the term “post-black” into the cultural conversation almost 15 years ago with the exhibition “Freestyle.” In the basement, a sculptural installation by Marc Andre Robinson weaves together formalism with black cultural history, while another, “Lorraine O’Grady: Art Is … ” offers a fantastic exhibition of photographs documenting Ms. Grady’s performance piece during the 1983 African-American Day Parade, in which she skillfully weaves together art, activism and participation.

headline: Starring Me! A Surreal Dive Into Immersive Theater
abstract: A reporter’s unnerving plunge into 10 events across New York City involving all kinds of audience participation.
lead_paragraph: All of us have anti-bucket lists of things we do not want to do before we die, and mine includes any activity requiring potentially embarrassing public participation. Wearing a costume, declaiming before a crowd, playing spin the bottle, clapping along to a jaunty show tune, marching, chanting, speaking spontaneously into a microphone, ceding free will to a larger force, doing the hokeypokey and turning myself about — I have made it my business to avoid these things.

headline: Review: ‘The Forest’ Centers on the Search for a Twin at a Suicide Site in Japan
abstract: Natalie Dormer plays twins, one of whom has gone missing, in this horror film by Jason Zada, set in an area near Mount Fuji where many have taken their own lives.
lead_paragraph: It needs to be said at the start that there is something unsavory about using suicide as the underpinning for a horror movie. Anyone who has experienced the suicide of a loved one should stay away from “The Forest,” set in the so-called Suicide Forest at the base of Mount Fuji in Japan, where an inordinate number of people go to kill themselves.

headline: U.S. Prods China on North Korea, Saying Soft Approach Has Failed
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Propaganda', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry told China that its soft approach to reining in North Korea has failed, and that Beijing must agree to stronger sanctions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a striking public rebuke of China, Secretary of State John Kerry warned Beijing on Thursday that its effort to rein in North Korea had been a failure and that something had to change in its handling of the isolated country it has supported for the past six decades.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: China, Hillary Clinton, Oregon
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Columbia’s WKCR Goes Silent Online
keywords: ['Radio', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Royalties']
abstract: The radio station said it’s working to restore service, but questions remain about why it was cut off.
lead_paragraph: Streaming audio is more essential to the music industry than ever before, but last week WKCR-FM (89.9), the radio station of Columbia University, abruptly shut its online simulcast, cutting off the eclectic station from listeners outside the reach of its broadcast signal.

headline: An Ice Cream Mogul and His Fellow Burlingtonians React to a Trump Rally
abstract: In a liberal enclave fiercely loyal to Bernie Sanders, Burlington’s former mayor, residents were amazed and perplexed by Donald J. Trump’s planned rally on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — As a line of hundreds snaked around the block and down the street from where Donald J. Trump was set to hold a rally on Thursday night, more than 100 protesters gathered across the street, hoisting signs reading “Bern, Trump, Bern” and chanting that Mr. Trump should stay away. More demonstrators clustered nearly, holding candles in silent vigil.

lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: In ‘Sweaty Betty,’ Two Single Dads and Their Pals Getting Through the Day
abstract: Joseph Frank and Zachary Reed’s first feature follows two young men, a 1,000-pound pig and a lively pit bull as they weave in and out of their neighborhood outside Washington.
lead_paragraph: Hovering somewhere between fiction and documentary, “Sweaty Betty” makes unlikely heroes of two young single fathers and a 1,000-pound pig named Ms. Charlotte. Guess which of the three receives a dedicated segment on the local news?

headline: Amy Schumer Is Actually Kind of a Fashion Plate
abstract: With the help of the stylist Leesa Evans, the raunchy actress has chosen sleek and sexy designer gowns for recent premieres and award ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: With the help of the stylist Leesa Evans, the raunchy actress has chosen sleek and sexy designer gowns for recent premieres and award ceremonies.

headline: Giants Interview Steve Spagnuolo and Teryl Austin for Coaching Position
abstract: On Friday, the Giants are also expected to meet with Adam Gase, the Bears’ offensive coordinator.
lead_paragraph: The Giants continued to work through their list of potential candidates for a new coach Thursday when they interviewed Steve Spagnuolo, their defensive coordinator last season, and Teryl Austin, the defensive coordinator for the Detroit Lions the past two seasons.

headline: Review: ‘Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art,’ a Documentary
abstract: James Crump’s film looks at artists who, in the early 1960s, headed into the open spaces of North America to mold the land.
lead_paragraph: “Earthworks are an older tradition than oil painting, going back 3,000 years,” the artist Carl Andre observes late in “Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art,” a cogent, brisk, sometimes thrilling documentary written and directed by James Crump. More than a couple of shots of Stonehenge turn up as supporting evidence for that claim. Mr. Crump’s film, though, is mostly concerned with a group of American artists who, in the early 1960s, began not just working with natural materials for their pieces but also went out into the open, sometimes arid, spaces in North America to mold or scar, or both, the land itself.

headline: 20 Years Ago: ‘Pride and Prejudice’ Was Reborn on TV
abstract: In January 1996, the Jane Austen industry was recharged with the American broadcast of a new “Pride and Prejudice,” starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.
lead_paragraph: The biggest surprise in the opening episode of the final season of “Downton Abbey” wasn’t about “Downton” at all; it was — ohmygod, there’s Wickham! Wickham, you old scoundrel, is that really you? And has it really been 20 years?

abstract: The memorial concert at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village, “Au Revoir, Pierre: A Tribute to the Life and Works of Pierre Boulez,” will start at 6 p.m.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Boulez, who died on Tuesday, will be honored by musical luminaries on Saturday, Jan. 9, at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village.

headline: Review: In ‘Unlucky Plaza,’ a Comic Hostage Crisis via Tabloid Storytelling
abstract: Ken Kwek’s debut feature, set in Singapore, centers on a hapless diner owner, loan shark, motivational speaker and other motley characters.
lead_paragraph: Set in Singapore and just as densely packed, Ken Kwek’s debut feature “Unlucky Plaza” bundles loan-shark drama, culture-clash comedy, hostage negotiations and a talk-show framing device. The multicultural milieu lends an initial boost as Mr. Kwek’s jokes and plot entanglements take potshots at life in Singapore, but all the air seeps out of this attempt at zippy, tabloid-nutty storytelling.

headline: A New Economic Era for China Goes Off the Rails
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: After its markets plunged last summer, and weeks after President Xi Jinping announced plans to avoid further disruptions, China again finds itself at the center of economic turmoil.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When President Xi Jinping of China convened a group of top officials to discuss the economy last month, the highly publicized meeting was seen as a moment of triumph.

headline: Review: In ‘Henry Gamble’s Birthday Party,’ Sexual Repression (and Clothes) Start to Fall Away
abstract: As Christian families lounge and swim at a pool party, the teenage protagonist slowly moves toward accepting his sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: In “Henry Gamble’s Birthday Party,” from the prolific independent writer and director Stephen Cone, teenagers and their parents struggle to reconcile their sheltered Christian lifestyles with the complexities of adulthood, sex and the secular world. Similar internal conflicts were the subject of Mr. Cone’s “The Wise Kids” (2012), an earnest, autobiographically inspired feature.

headline: Barack Obama: Guns Are Our Shared Responsibility
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Firearms']
abstract: I will not campaign for, vote for or support any candidate, even in my own party, who does not support common-sense gun reform.
lead_paragraph: THE epidemic of gun violence in our country is a crisis. Gun deaths and injuries constitute one of the greatest threats to public health and to the safety of the American people. Every year, more than 30,000 Americans have their lives cut short by guns. Suicides. Domestic violence. Gang shootouts. Accidents. Hundreds of thousands of Americans have lost brothers and sisters, or buried their own children. We’re the only advanced nation on earth that sees this kind of mass violence with this frequency.

headline: Loyalty Test for Those Wanting In to Trump Rally in Vermont
abstract: Having handed out too many tickets for a theater that holds just 1,400 people, the Trump campaign was turning away ticket-holders who said they did not support the candidate.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Want to see Donald J. Trump speak in Vermont? Then you better pledge allegiance to Mr. Trump.

headline: Stephen Cone Narrates a Scene From ‘Henry Gamble’s Birthday Party’
abstract: The writer and director discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Issues of spirituality, sexual identity and morality come together by the swimming pool in the drama “Henry Gamble’s Birthday Party.”

headline: Venture Funding Slackened in the Last Quarter of 2015
abstract: Venture capitalists pulled back from making new bets at the end of last year.
lead_paragraph: Venture capitalists pulled back from making new bets at the end of last year. In the fourth quarter of 2015, the amount of money funding private companies fell 30 percent from the previous quarter, to $27.3 billion, according to a report from the research firm CB Insights. Deal-making dropped 13 percent over the same time period to 1,743 transactions, a level not seen since the first quarter of 2013. In 2015, venture funding peaked in the third quarter at $38.7 billion, according to CB Insights. In total, funding for all of 2015 hit $128.7 billion, nearly as much money as was deployed in 2013 and 2014 combined, the data showed.

lead_paragraph: AS autonomous driving technology advances, perhaps the most notable benefit is the promise of a striking reduction in accidents.

headline: China’s Economic Turmoil Sends Ripples to Global Markets
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Some analysts and economists say they are becoming less optimistic that the United States will remain unscathed by China’s struggles.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, the collapsing United States economy laid a dead hand on the rest of the world, a dubious role that was then assumed by Europe, whose sovereign debt crisis often pumped fear around the globe.

headline: Gov. Paul LePage of Maine, a Christie Supporter, Makes Racially Charged Remarks
abstract: Mr. LePage, the first major elected official to endorse Gov. Chris Christie for president, talked of drug dealers with names like “D-Money” who came into the state and impregnated “white girls.”
lead_paragraph: The first major elected official to endorse Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey for president made racially charged remarks this week about drug dealers entering his state and impregnating “white girls.”

headline: Review: Sacred and Secular, Bach Closes a Festival
abstract: Trinity Wall Street’s Twelfth Night Festival ended on Wednesday with a concert at St. Paul’s Chapel in Lower Manhattan that focused on Bach cantatas.
lead_paragraph: Trinity Wall Street’s wildly varied Twelfth Night Festival, 13 days densely packed with new and ancient music, ended on Wednesday with a Bach concert in St. Paul’s Chapel on lower Broadway. This was the third in a flurry of Bach at One events that began on Monday and comprised the festival’s homestretch.

headline: Louis Langrée, Mr. Mostly Mozart, Brings His Cincinnati, and Tchaikovsky, to New York
abstract: This maestro turned to traditional, challenging Tchaikovsky for a Lincoln Center program with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The French conductor Louis Langrée, who has been thriving as music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra since 2013, may be a little frustrated that New York audiences know him better as the music director of the Mostly Mozart Festival. He can be proud of his accomplished tenure with the festival, which was stagnating when he arrived in 2003.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: The One About the Locusts and the Regulators
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas visited Webster City, where he quoted Stephen Sondheim and told an old standby joke.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Earthquakes in Oklahoma Raise Fears of a Big One
abstract: The state recorded two of its largest earthquakes in years, fueling concern that burying oil and gas wastes in seismically active areas is courting danger.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma was rocked Wednesday night by two of the state’s largest earthquakes in recent years, further fueling scientists’ concern that the continued burial of oil and gas wastes in seismically active areas was courting a much more powerful earthquake.

headline: Cuomo Announces $1 Billion Expansion for Javits Center
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan would create more than one million square feet of event space and New York City’s largest ballroom at the convention center.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the day that the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986, exhibitors and hotel operators complained that the black glass complex along 11th Avenue in Manhattan was too small, too hard to navigate and perpetually damp from a leaky roof.

headline: St. George’s School Agrees to Inquiry Into Sexual Abuse
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: The Rhode Island school said it would commission a third party to investigate reports spanning several decades of abuse of students.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — St. George’s School, an elite Rhode Island prep school embroiled in a widening sexual abuse scandal spanning decades, said Thursday that it would commission a new, independent investigation into allegations of misconduct against former staff and former students.

headline: Obama’s Gun Initiative Seen as Having Limited Effect on Unlicensed Dealers
abstract: “No one’s going to stop us” trading firearms through gun clubs and other markets, says one enthusiast who has long operated without a license, record-keeping or background checks.
lead_paragraph: Jack Strahan has been a small-time trader of guns and gun parts for years, and he is not stopping now.

headline: No Short-Term Fix for California Methane Leak
abstract: After early efforts to plug a leaky well failed, officials see a relief well as the solution. But drilling such a well takes time.
lead_paragraph: To the dismay of thousands of residents of Porter Ranch, Calif., whose lives have been upended by a huge natural-gas leak from a nearby well, the local utility says it will take at least another month and a half to shut it down.

headline: Blunt Political Assessments in Bill Clinton Transcripts
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Newly released documents offer a fresh look at Bill Clinton’s later years in the White House, including transcribed phone calls and meetings with Tony Blair, the British prime minister.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He thought George W. Bush was perpetrating “a fraud” on America as a presidential candidate, Vladimir V. Putin had “enormous potential,” and the people of Wyoming would be “shooting at me” if he visited.

headline: Samsung’s Operating Profit Rises 15%, a Sharp Slowdown
abstract: The conglomerate’s operating performance in the fourth quarter was a steep deceleration from a rise of almost 80 percent in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Last year, with smartphone sales sagging, Samsung Electronics said it would orchestrate a turnaround using the components that power electronics — things like chips, screens and circuits.

headline: Sandy Alderson, Recovering From Cancer, Defends Mets’ Moves
abstract: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, who is being treated for cancer, made his first public appearance since collapsing during a news media briefing in November.
lead_paragraph: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, who has been undergoing cancer treatments, joined a contingent of club executives at the New York Athletic Club on Thursday for Mike Piazza’s Hall of Fame news conference.

headline: Obama Administration Optimistic About Health Plan Goal
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medicare']
abstract: The administration said 11.3 million people had signed up for health insurance so far in the third open enrollment period, citing “unprecedented demand for marketplace coverage.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Thursday that 11.3 million people had signed up for health insurance so far during the Affordable Care Act’s third open enrollment period, with indications of a strong desire for coverage among young adults and others who were not enrolled last year.

headline: Pat Harrington, the Super on ‘One Day at a Time,’ Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Harrington was best known for his award-winning role as Schneider on the CBS sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Pat Harrington Jr., an Emmy-winning character actor best known as Schneider, the building superintendent and would-be Lothario on the popular sitcom “One Day at a Time,” died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Response on Hillary Clinton Email ‘Incomplete,’ Report Finds
abstract: An independent investigator said the State Department provided an “inaccurate or incomplete” response when a watchdog group asked whether Mrs. Clinton used alternate email accounts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department provided an “inaccurate or incomplete” response when a watchdog group asked in 2012 whether Hillary Clinton had used any alternate email accounts, saying it had no relevant records, even though dozens of top officials knew that she relied on a private email address for official communications, an independent investigator reported Thursday.

headline: Guatemalan Judge in FIFA Corruption Case Is Released on $4 Million Bond
abstract: Héctor Trujillo, a former top Guatemalan soccer official caught up in the United States’ investigation of FIFA, was held for the past week in solitary confinement at a Brooklyn detention center.
lead_paragraph: Héctor Trujillo, a Guatemalan judge and soccer official charged by the United States in December with accepting and laundering hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes, was held in solitary confinement at a detention center in Brooklyn for the past week until he was released Thursday on a $4 million bond.

headline: Donald Trump Supporters Turned Away From His Rally
abstract: It was about half an hour into Donald Trump’s speech that the police here made it official: No one else in line, which still snaked around the block, was getting in.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — It was about half an hour into Donald Trump’s speech that the police here made it official: No one else in line, which still snaked around the block, was getting in.

headline: Removal of Chávez Images From Venezuela Capitol Raises Tension
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Triumphal portraits of former President Hugo Chávez were carted away this week as his party’s political rivals moved into the chamber.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — With triple-digit inflation showing no signs of retreating and the new National Assembly vowing to remove the president, Venezuela over the last few days careered toward crises both economic and political.

headline: Index-Card Financial Advice
abstract: A selection of trimmed-down financial advice from financial experts and personal-finance writers at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A selection of trimmed-down financial advice from financial experts and personal-finance writers at The New York Times.

headline: An Idea by Moynihan Rises Like a Phoenix: Relocating Pennsylvania Station
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s announcement that he would begin construction of a new Pennsylvania Station this year includes Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan’s long-ago suggestion: Use the Farley building.
lead_paragraph: A ride on the Times Square shuttle nearly 30 years ago.

headline: Campbell Labels Will Disclose G.M.O. Ingredients
abstract: Campbell Soup breaks from its rival food companies to disclose the presence of genetically engineered ingredients in its products.
lead_paragraph: Breaking from its industry rivals, Campbell Soup will become the first major food company to begin disclosing the presence of genetically engineered ingredients like corn, soy and sugar beets in its products.

headline: Her College Dreams Delayed, She Slept at Airports
abstract: Karen Carter was pursuing a goal of working in interior design but couldn’t make ends meet. Then a friend suggested that she seek shelter among stranded travelers.
lead_paragraph: With no bed of her own to sleep in, Karen Carter took a friend’s advice to seek shelter at the airport. Every night for nearly three weeks, she went to a different terminal so that she would not be recognized for regularly returning.

headline: Transcripts of Phone Calls Between Bill Clinton and Tony Blair
abstract: President Bill Clinton’s library released transcripts of phone conversations with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, offering a revealing look at Mr. Clinton. Here is selection of documents pulled from the full 532 page release.
lead_paragraph: President Bill Clinton’s library released transcripts of phone conversations with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, offering a revealing look at Mr. Clinton. Here is selection of documents pulled from the full 532 page release.

headline: With Two Homers, Emotions Go Deep for Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza
abstract: Neither Ken Griffey Jr. nor Mike Piazza ever won a World Series, but each slugger smashed a home run that is destined to remain a part of baseball lore.
lead_paragraph: Ken Griffey Sr., proud veteran of the Big Red Machine, likes to say that his son got the records, but he got the rings. Fair point: Ken Griffey Jr. was elected to the Hall of Fame this week but never did play in the World Series. Mike Piazza, who will share the stage in Cooperstown this summer, made it there once and lost.

headline: West Bank: Israelis Kill 4 Attackers
abstract: Israeli forces fatally shot four Palestinians in the West Bank on Thursday as the assailants tried to stab soldiers, the military said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces fatally shot four Palestinians in the West Bank on Thursday as the assailants tried to stab soldiers, the military said. Three Palestinian cousins from the village of Sair, near Hebron, were spotted approaching the heavily guarded Gush Etzion junction, Palestinian news reports said. The military said that all three were shot after they tried to stab soldiers who approached them. A short time later, a 16-year-old Palestinian from the same village was killed at the Beit Einoun junction near Hebron, the Palestinian news agency Wafa reported.

headline: Short Passes Fly, More Picks Are Set, and Penalties Follow
abstract: Offenses are increasingly relying on the short-pass game and ‘pick plays’ to combat a rise in man-to-man coverage by larger cornerbacks. But that often creates more offensive pass interference penalties.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The crowd roar at Gillette Stadium soared last month with each tackle Patriots running back James White broke — sprinting past a linebacker, spinning away from a safety, stiff-arming a cornerback — before weakening in disappointment when he was brought down inside the 10-yard line.

lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia is reviewing whether to sell public shares in its state-owned oil company, Aramco, with a decision coming in the next few months, the country’s defense minister and deputy crown prince told The Economist in an interview published Thursday.

headline: F.B.I. and Police Task Force Arrests 3 for Armored-Car Robberies
abstract: The suspects, one of whom is a state prison guard, were taken into custody after a string of crimes in the Bronx over the past several months.
lead_paragraph: Three men, including a state prison guard, were arrested on Thursday for participating in three brazen daytime robberies of armored cars in the Bronx over the past several months, the authorities said.

headline: Mike Richards Happy to Be Back After Signing With Capitals
abstract: Richards, arrested after a controlled substance had been intercepted by the border authorities in Canada, signed a one-year contract with the Washington Capitals.
lead_paragraph: A contrite Mike Richards met the news media on Thursday for the first time since signing a one-year contract with the Washington Capitals.

headline: Central African Republic: Runoff Is Set for Presidential Candidates
abstract: The top two candidates are likely to meet in a runoff election later this month, officials announced Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The top two presidential candidates are likely to meet in a runoff election later this month, officials announced Thursday. Both candidates are former prime ministers. Anicet-Georges Dologuélé, an economist, received about 24 percent of the votes, according to provisional results. He will face Faustin-Archange Touadéra, a former mathematics professor, who received 19 percent. The two men emerged from a field of 30 in an election that, while peaceful, involved logistical problems and prompted allegations of fraud. Candidates can appeal to the Constitutional Court, which has 15 days to review any appeals and validate the final results. The runoff is scheduled for Jan. 31. Sectarian violence between Christians and Muslims in the past several years has caused nearly a million people to flee their homes.

lead_paragraph: The days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in New York City in 2016.

lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Donald J. Trump touched down in one of America’s most progressive cities Thursday night, bringing the bombastic message that has captivated Republican voters into the backyard of a Democratic opponent, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

abstract: The Capitals, who eliminated the Islanders from the playoffs last season, notched their 30th win with a 4-1 rout.
lead_paragraph: As Alex Ovechkin’s wrist shot slithered past Jaroslav Halak to give the Washington Capitals a 2-0 lead late in the first period, Halak, the Islanders’ goaltender, shook his head in frustration as he hunched in front of his net.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Two refugees from Iraq were arrested on terrorism-related charges on Thursday in California and Texas, where the governor called for an end to the resettlement of refugees from countries overrun by terrorist groups.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 8-14
abstract: One Step Beyond (Friday) The American Museum of Natural History’s two biggest after-hours programs for the 21-and-over crowd are, in a way, antithetical. First are the occasional adult sleepovers, in which people pay hundreds of dollars to live out childhood fantasies of roaming empty museum halls and curling up in sleeping bags under the famous life-size blue whale. Then there is the much less expensive ($25 in advance) One Step Beyond, where partying trumps nostalgia, and the Rose Center for Earth and Space becomes a dance club that brings in big names in techno, electronica and hip-hop. (Above, a previous party inside the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Hall of the Universe.)
lead_paragraph: One Step Beyond (Friday) The American Museum of Natural History’s two biggest after-hours programs for the 21-and-over crowd are, in a way, antithetical. First are the occasional adult sleepovers, in which people pay hundreds of dollars to live out childhood fantasies of roaming empty museum halls and curling up in sleeping bags under the famous life-size blue whale. Then there is the much less expensive ($25 in advance) One Step Beyond, where partying trumps nostalgia, and the Rose Center for Earth and Space becomes a dance club that brings in big names in techno, electronica and hip-hop. (Above, a previous party inside the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Hall of the Universe.)

headline: Ashraf Pahlavi, Twin Sister of Iran’s Last Shah, Dies at 96

lead_paragraph: Ashraf Pahlavi, the twin sister of the last shah of Iran, known equally for her work with the United Nations on behalf of women’s causes and her opulent lifestyle, died on Thursday at her home. She was 96.

lead_paragraph: “Downton Abbey” fans bemoaning the absence of Lady Rose this season can get their fix when the actress who played her, Lily James, steps out of the ashes and into the glass slipper in “Cinderella.” A White House concert commemorates the act behind the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities. And the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami drives around Tehran in “Ten.”

headline: The Self-Reliant Generation
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Youth', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Millennials lean to the left, but because of several other characteristics, they may not help the Democratic ticket in November.
lead_paragraph: Last month Fox News released a poll showing Hillary Clinton leading Bernie Sanders in Iowa by 14 points. But the amazing part of the poll was the generation gap. Among likely caucusgoers under 45, Sanders was crushing Clinton 56 to 34 percent. Among the older voters, Clinton was leading 59 to 24.

headline: Donald Trump Drags Bill Clinton’s Baggage Out
abstract: Hillary Clinton is accountable to voters for her own words and actions, not Mr. Clinton’s sexual history.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump seems to view his role as the person who dredges up what nobody else wants to talk about. And so he has dragged out Bill Clinton’s marital infidelity.

headline: When China Stumbles
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: Beijing’s financial troubles shouldn’t add up to global devastation. But more than math is involved in economics.
lead_paragraph: So, will China’s problems cause a global crisis? The good news is that the numbers, as I read them, don’t seem big enough. The bad news is that I could be wrong, because global contagion often seems to end up being worse than hard numbers say it should. And the worse news is that if China does deliver a bad shock to the rest of the world, we are remarkably unready to deal with the consequences.

headline: Crackpots in Cowboy Hats, and in Congress
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Federal Lands', 'Ranches']
abstract: The locked-and-loaded crazies in the Oregon desert are using the same language as Republican legislators who want to take away an American birthright.
lead_paragraph: Most of the ranchers I know are decent folks, men and women of a few well-chosen words, slow to rouse, distrustful of a show horse on four legs or two. And then there’s the armed gang who seized an Oregon bird sanctuary — Y’all Qaeda, as the twittersphere has dubbed them.

headline: Stopping North Korea’s Nuclear Threat
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Obama administration has to make clear to its leaders that nukes won’t make it safe.
lead_paragraph: DURING nuclear negotiations in 2005, a North Korean diplomat let slip an unexpectedly candid comment, offering valuable insight into his government’s nuclear policy: “The reason you attacked Afghanistan is because they don’t have nukes. And look at what happened to Libya. That is why we will never give up ours.”

headline: What Donald Trump Owes George Wallace
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The real estate mogul won’t be the president, just as the former Alabama governor wasn’t. But losers as well as winners shape the future.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, reality television star and real estate mogul, is different in many ways from major political figures in our past. But there are striking similarities between Mr. Trump and George C. Wallace, the Deep South politician who ran for president each opportunity he got from 1964 through 1976. The connections between the two — their rhetoric and their ability to fire up crowds — give us a better sense of what Trumpism will mean once he is gone from the campaign stage. After all, political losers as well as winners can shape the future.

headline: A Shameful Round-Up of Refugees
abstract: Many who pose no threat to American security are being sent back to some of the most dangerous countries in our hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: President Obama once said this about his administration’s deportation priorities: “We’ll keep focusing enforcement resources on actual threats to our security. That means felons, not families. That means criminals, not children. It means gang members, not moms who are trying to put food on the table for their kids.”

headline: The Depths of Injustice in Chicago
abstract: It will take more than political showmanship from Mayor Rahm Emanuel to calm the discontent that has roiled the city.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago built his career on the claim that he is at his best in times of crisis. But it will take more than political showmanship to calm the discontent that has roiled the city since November, when a Police Department video showed a white officer executing a black teenager named Laquan McDonald and exposed a cover-up by officers who had been at the scene. Chicagoans were still protesting the McDonald case on Christmas weekend when police officers responding to a domestic dispute killed two more African-Americans, one of whom was a bystander and a mother of five.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — A trip to the South of France has long been reckoned a perfect antidote to the gloom of the British midwinter, but the rugby players of Bath are unlikely to get much rest or tranquility from their visit this weekend.

lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans seem to be very unhappy with President Obama’s new executive actions on guns, though they are probably quite happy that the actions provided them such a juicy issue with which to stir up voters in an election year.

headline: Fingerprint of Fugitive in Paris Attacks Is Found in Brussels Apartment
abstract: A search in the Schaerbeek section of the city also uncovered traces of an explosive and material that might have been used to build suicide belts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Belgian investigators searching a Brussels apartment have found the fingerprint of a fugitive wanted in connection with the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris, as well as material that might have been used to assemble suicide belts and traces of an explosive used in the assaults, officials announced on Friday.

abstract: Readers react.
lead_paragraph: RE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED

headline: Sex and the Saudi
abstract: Two young people get together, break the law and fall in love.
lead_paragraph: One winter day a few years ago, I met a girl I really liked. I saw her at a park in Qatif. We were looking at each other, so I went up to her and said, ‘‘Hi, you look beautiful.’’ She thanked me, and I handed her a piece of paper with my number on it. ‘‘We should talk more,’’ I told her. ‘‘I’m interested in you.’’ Then I left immediately.

headline: How to Hold a Heart
abstract: Don’t let it slip. Two hands are better than one.
lead_paragraph: There is an adage that says a good surgeon needs a lion’s heart, an eagle’s eyes and a lady’s hands. Kathy Magliato, the director of women’s cardiac services at Providence Saint John’s Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif., can palm a basketball — but, she says, anyone can hold a heart: ‘‘Don’t worry about the size of your hands.’’ Instead, concentrate on not dropping it; a heart covered with blood is very slippery.

headline: Ian McKellen Will Take That Seat, if You’re Offering It

lead_paragraph: Ian McKellen, the venerated film and stage actor who received an Oscar nomination for playing a wizard (in “The Lord of the Rings”) a decade after being knighted by the queen, returned to the awards conversation this year, though perhaps too quietly. In “Mr. Holmes,” Mr. McKellen plays the famed sleuth Sherlock Holmes, his depiction toggling between a fit middle-ager and a doddering 93-year-old.

headline: Obama and Trump Events Highlight a Central Divide on Guns

Trump, promised a crowd of more than 1,400 people in Burlington, Vt., that he would eliminate gun-free zones in schools on his first day in office.

keywords: ['Censorship', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']

abstract: This edition of Teenagers in the Times features young people who made the news for a variety of reasons in December.
lead_paragraph: Our latest round-up of articles about young people that have appeared in The Times includes several high-profile stories, including the disappearance of Ethan Couch, 18, who used an “affluenza” defense in a fatal drunken-driving case and was found in December in Mexico with his mother.

abstract: A Chinese official did not mention the United States by name but said all countries had a responsibility to persuade the North’s government to abandon its nuclear program.
