headline: Turkey, Which Sought Middle Ground, Enters Saudi-Iranian Dispute
abstract: Reports in Iran’s news media that linked a visit by the Turkish president to Saudi Arabia with the kingdom’s execution of a Shiite cleric stirred anger in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — As the Middle East has descended into bitter sectarian conflict in recent years, Turkey has tried to remain above the fray, posing as an honest broker and peacemaker. Increasingly, though, it is being drawn into the conflict, and its preferred status as disinterested mediator is slowly becoming untenable.

headline: A Self-Appointed Herald of Hip-Hop in China
keywords: ['Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Movies']
abstract: Tsalta Baptiste, who lives in Shaoxing, combined his love of acting and hip-hop to create a trailer for an unmade Tupac Shakur biopic, which drew many viewers online.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment he moved from California to Shaoxing in China’s Zhejiang Province in October 2014, Tsalta Baptiste enjoyed a sense of notoriety. That happens when you’re an African-American man suddenly living in a nation with a population of more than 1.3 billion. Mr. Baptiste’s passing resemblance to Kobe Bryant also helped in a country that reveres the Los Angeles Lakers star.

headline: Steve Israel: Confessions of a Congressman
abstract: I’ll miss the House of Representatives, but I won’t miss begging for money.
lead_paragraph: Washington — IT’S now safe to pick up your phones and read your emails. That’s right, I won’t be calling to ask you to donate to my congressional campaign. As I announced on Tuesday, I’ll be leaving Congress at the end of this term — sentimental about many things, but liberated from a fund-raising regime that’s never been more dangerous to our democracy.

headline: Golden Mao Statue in China, Nearly Finished, Is Brought Down by Criticism
abstract: The 120-foot-tall structure, said to have cost $465,000, had been under construction for months when it began to attract attention online.
lead_paragraph: ZHUSHIGANG, China — Just two days after images of a giant gold-colored statue of Mao in the bare fields of Henan Province spread across the Internet, the statue was gone — torn down apparently on the orders of embarrassed local officials.

headline: It’s Payback Time for Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Income', 'Parenting', 'United States Economy', 'Children and Childhood', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Society is getting a free ride on our unrewarded contributions to the perpetuation of the human race.
lead_paragraph: A COUNTRY that gives every citizen enough cash to live on whether she needs it or not: It’s got to be either a fool’s paradise or a profligate Northern European nation. And lo, in November, the Finnish government proposed paying every adult 800 euros or about $870 a month. Fits of this seemingly irrational generosity, called a universal basic income or U.B.I., are becoming surprisingly common. The Swiss will vote in a referendum on basic income this year. The Dutch city of Utrecht will soon  start a basic-income pilot program. Canada’s ruling Liberal Party recently adopted a resolution calling for a similar experiment.

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
abstract: An Annie Leibovitz exhibition opens in London; a minimalist artist has a solo show in Osaka, Japan; and a buskers’ festival runs in Christchurch, New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: Suresnes, France

headline: Crimea to Face Power Shortages for Months, Officials Say
abstract: After lines were sabotaged, electricity will not be fully restored until an “energy bridge” from Russia is completed in May, according to the Kremlin-appointed government.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Crimea will experience power shortages until at least May, the Kremlin-appointed government of the region announced after a meeting in Simferopol, the capital, on Thursday.

headline: Where History Buffs Should Go in 2016
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Theater', 'Burning Man Festival', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: Beatrix Potter turns 150, the National Park Service, 100, and Shakespeare is honored 400 years after his death.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Britain takes the cake celebrating the births of several famous writers, and the death of one illustrious playwright; in the American West, an icon of contemporary bohemia approaches middle age; victory and defeat are commemorated on French battlefields; and the struggle for independence is cause for celebration in Central America.

headline: Where Foodies Should Go in 2016
abstract: Truffles, beer, cherries and crustaceans are singled out for celebrations.
lead_paragraph: The renowned chef René Redzepi of the two-Michelin-starred Noma in Copenhagen wasn’t exaggerating when he said, “People will travel anywhere for good food — it’s crazy.” Indeed, food lovers are now trooping around the world to both accessible and remote destinations. Perhaps Mr. Redzepi should have added that overindulging is almost certainly the case with — and maybe the point of — any culinary-inspired trip.

headline: Where Music Lovers Should Go in 2016
abstract: From the drums of Burkina Faso to a Battle of the Bands in Montreal, highlights in a year of music.
lead_paragraph: What does the rhythm of life sound like in 2016? Drums are keeping traditions alive in Basque Country and Burkina Faso; California is calling on the voices of strong women to inspire new music; and in Montreal, jazz lovers are preparing for what is sure to be the classiest Battle of the Bands in history.

headline: Where Sports Fans Should Go in 2016
abstract: Whether your game is golf, soccer, snow biking or Ping-Pong, 2016 is shaping up to be a flag-waving year among fans.
lead_paragraph: Whether your game is golf, soccer, snow biking or Ping-Pong, 2016 is shaping up to be a flag-waving year among fans.

headline: How Should You Manage Your Money? And Keep It Short
abstract: A comparison of lists giving financial advice shows that experts agree on the basic steps. So why do so few people follow the recipe?
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Treasure,” “Anesthesia” and “Lamb.”

headline: ISIS Militant Kills Mother on Group’s Orders, Activists Say
abstract: The fighter shot his mother in front of a crowd of hundreds because she had tried to persuade him to leave the extremist organization, according to two monitoring groups.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An Islamic State militant killed his own mother in front of a post office in the northern Syrian city of Raqqa this week, Syrian activists said on Friday, with one monitoring organization adding that the episode began when she tried to persuade him to leave the extremist group.

headline: Maggie Smith Shifts From Dowager to Down and Out for ‘The Lady in the Van’
abstract: In a new film, Ms. Smith plays an ornery homeless woman. “It was a change from all those hats and clothes in ‘Downton,’” she said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Old friends, Maggie Smith and the playwright Alan Bennett sat on a sofa at a chic hotel, lobbing lines at each other as they recalled how they first met. “Then she vaulted right over the pig,” Mr. Bennett said. Ms. Smith threw herself back on the sofa and laughed uproariously. “It was terrifying,” she said, wiping her eyes. Mr. Bennett looked at her, straight-faced. “For the pig, too, I imagine,” he said.

headline: 1916: Tsar’s Troops Push Forward
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russian troops force their way through another fortified line in 1916.
lead_paragraph: Czernowitz has not yet fallen, but from the continued successful development of the Russian operations in this region and from the further slow though important progress made, it would appear that the event cannot now be long delayed. The tsar’s troops have forced their way through yet another fortified line, and, according to latest reports, four miles or less separate them from their goal.

headline: 18 Asylum Seekers Are Tied to Attacks on Women in Germany
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sex Crimes', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Police', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The police chief in Cologne was forced out amid a growing uproar over an assault on women that unfolded on New Year’s Eve and has stoked fears of newcomers.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German authorities on Friday tied asylum seekers for the first time to the wave of violent assaults on women in Cologne on New Year’s Eve as debate intensified over whether the country had made a mistake in opening its doors last year to more than a million migrants.

headline: ‘Runaways’ to Be Revived This Summer
abstract: New York City Center announced Thursday, two days after the death of Elizabeth Swados, that it would stage a revival of her musical “Runaways” this summer.
lead_paragraph: The death of Elizabeth Swados on Tuesday prompted much reminiscing in the theater community about the composer/author’s breakthrough show, “Runaways,” which was staged at the Public Theater and then on Broadway in 1978.

lead_paragraph: Every marriage has its deal. Here, to give just one handy example, were the terms of the deal struck by the personal finance expert Jane Bryant Quinn and her second husband, David: Ms. Quinn would put up with the suburbs and Mr. Quinn would put up with her.

headline: ‘Mein Kampf,’ Hitler’s Manifesto, Returns to German Shelves
abstract: Scholars and historians spent three years preparing a nearly 2,000-page edition with about 3,500 annotations in anticipation of the work entering the public domain.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — At a time when nationalist and far-right politics are again ascendant in Europe, a team of German historians presented a new, annotated edition of a symbolic text of that movement on Friday: “Mein Kampf,” by Adolf Hitler.

headline: New Year, Old-Fashioned Investment Strategy
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Plenty of so-called experts are lining up to offer advice on how to invest in 2016. But how should you weigh their opinions?
lead_paragraph: THE beginning of the year is the time when many people sit down with their financial advisers or otherwise seek out advice about their finances. And with stock markets’ rocky start to the year, that impulse may be greater this time around — that is, if people don’t run and hide.

headline: ‘Mein Kampf’: From Best-Seller to Blacklist
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune: Adolf Hitler’s manifesto went from being a best-seller in Paris in 1938 to being banned in Berlin in 1945.
lead_paragraph: The manifesto of Adolf Hitler, “Mein Kampf” was first published in 1925. A second volume followed in 1926. This year, the book will be reprinted and sold in Germany for the first time since World War II. Below, a few excerpts from the European editions of The New York Herald and the New York Herald Tribune, which followed the manifesto from best-seller status to blacklisted label.

headline: When Collecting Wasn’t All About the Money
abstract: The excesses of today's art market are much different from the time when Peggy Guggenheim was selling Jackson Pollocks for $200 to $600.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A documentary released last year revealed fresh insights about the life of the 20th century’s most celebrated female art collector.

headline: More Context Needed in Article on Haifa Culture
abstract: The feature piece drew complaints from all sides on issues involving Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: The recent article about a burgeoning social scene in Haifa was intended as a “slice of life,” a window into a place that Times readers don’t often see.

headline: VW Refuses to Give American States Documents in Emissions Inquiries
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Privacy', 'Automobiles']
abstract: VW has refused to provide emails or other communications to attorneys general in the United States, citing German privacy laws, state officials say.
lead_paragraph: Citing German privacy laws, Volkswagen has refused to provide emails or other communications among its executives to attorneys general in the United States, impeding American investigations into the company’s emissions-cheating scandal, according to officials in several states.

headline: Topman Design: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 show from Topman Design.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 show from Topman Design.

headline: Winter Jazzfest Returns With a Marathon
abstract: A bonanza that has kept expanding since the mid-2000s, it’s a place to catch up on important new conversation-starters at multiple stages.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve heard somewhere that jazz roared back to life in 2015. It’s a boldfaced claim rooted in a shaky premise, but if you seek supporting evidence, look no further than Winter Jazzfest. An early-January bonanza that has kept expanding since the mid-2000s, it’s a place to catch up on important new conversation-starters.

headline: Independent Spirit in Many Flavors at the Out of Israel Showcase at 92Y
abstract: Dana Katz, a Tel Aviv-born New York choreographer, gathers some of Israel’s most vigorous voices for this showcase’s sixth edition.
lead_paragraph: In dance as in politics, Israel’s visibility and influence are remarkably disproportionate to its size. For years, dance aficionados have celebrated the adventurous physicality coming from that small country, making it one of its most popular and exciting cultural exports. The familiar ambassadors have been big companies like Vertigo, Kibbutz Contemporary Dance and, of course, the Batsheva Dance Company, whose signature gooey movement style, known as Gaga, has swept the dance world.

headline: A Fighter’s Hour of Need
abstract: Interviews reveal the events in the 60 minutes after a 2013 bout at Madison Square Garden that left Magomed Abdusalamov with severe brain damage.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 2, 2013, Mike Perez defeated Magomed Abdusalamov in a heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden. This is a reconstruction of the hour after the fight, based in part on the transcripts of two dozen interviews given under oath and conducted by the New York State Office of the Inspector General as part of its continuing investigation into the fight and the operations of the State Athletic Commission.

headline: Daily Report: Samsung Continues Looking for the Big Bump
abstract: Samsung has been looking for ways to prod growth for many quarters now. It is still looking.
lead_paragraph: Samsung has been looking for ways to prod growth for many quarters now. It is still looking.

headline: 2015 Was a Great Year for Jobs. 2016 Will Have a Hard Time Matching It.
abstract: A big question is whether the pace of job growth of the last two years can continue now that we are close to what economists consider full employment.
lead_paragraph: The newest numbers on the state of the American job market are good news on almost every front and show that 2015 was a blockbuster year for jobs. That raises some important questions — and doubts — about what will happen in 2016.

headline: Relocating Old iPhoto Events in Photos for OS X
abstract: How Mac users can find and organize their digital photos after upgrading to Photos for OS X.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I migrated from iPhoto to Photos for OS X on my Mac, all of my iPhoto Events were converted into albums and buried in a parent folder called iPhoto Events. This makes reaching them very time-consuming. Is there a way to move all these old events into the main Albums tab?

headline: Unexpected, but Not Unusual, Expenses Thwart Efforts to Save
keywords: ['Savings', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Personal Finances', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: For many Americans, unplanned expenses crop up almost every month. Here are some tips for saving money to cover those events.
lead_paragraph: MORE than 70 percent of Americans say they find it hard to save because of expenses they didn’t plan for, according to research published on Thursday by the Pew Charitable Trusts.

headline: The Importance of Being Prepared for a Natural Disaster
abstract: Disasters are especially hard for older adults, especially those with chronic illnesses, but thorough emergency preparation can save lives.
lead_paragraph: AS hot, wind-fed wildfires swirled around her town in early September, Darlene Simmons, 76, was busy cooking spaghetti in her kitchen. As a resident of Middletown, a small town in Northern California, she had been through wildfires before. But her home, where she had lived for 45 years, had never been harmed.

headline: 1941: Anti-Aircraft Drills Scare Ducks
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Ducks cause changes in anti-aircraft training in 1941.
lead_paragraph: CAMP UPTON, L.I. — Ducks, for the second time in less than a month, have been the cause of changes in anti-aircraft training here. The first time it was wild ducks, which interfered with firing of anti-aircraft batteries. Now, because of the nerves of market ducks on the south shore duck farms, anti-aircraft searchlights of the 198th Coast Artillery Regiment will be directed only north and west of the camp.

headline: Government Declassifies Passages in Three Surveillance Reports
abstract: In response to an ongoing Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the federal government has declassified and revealed additional passages of three inspector general reports related to surveillance. The government previously released versions of these reports, but decided to reprocess them and remove further redaction markings. The newly visible portions are marked.
lead_paragraph: In response to an ongoing Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the federal government has declassified and revealed additional passages of three inspector general reports related to surveillance. headline: British Man Admits Past in Terror Cell in Yemen
abstract: Minh Quang Pham pleaded guilty in federal court in Manhattan to three terrorism-related counts.
lead_paragraph: A man who prosecutors say received military training in Yemen from Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born radical Muslim cleric who was later killed by the United States in a drone strike, pleaded guilty on Friday in Manhattan to three terrorism-related counts.

headline: Rahm and His Party
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Rahm Emanuel’s legacy in an age of gridlock.
lead_paragraph: The fall of Rahm Emanuel, seemingly a political dead man walking because of his alleged role in covering up the video showing Chicago cops shooting a black teenager, has united right and left in schadenfreude. The right is delighted because Emanuel is a prominent overclass Democrat, an enforcer for the last two Democratic presidents, the man who led the midterm “thumping” that undid George W. Bush’s congressional majorities in 2006, and the mayor of a city that’s a case study in one-party misgovernment. The left, meanwhile, is happy to see him fall because Emanuel is a prominent centrist Democrat, whose role in both the Clinton and Obama White Houses involved prodding his bosses to temper their liberalism and tack somewhat to the right.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Following the Flows of Migration
abstract: Our selection of weekly web gems includes charts on social media echo chambers and China’s stock market woes.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

abstract: Andy Dalton could return from a thumb injury to play in the postseason, but the Bengals will start his backup, A. J. McCarron, on Saturday against the Steelers.
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati Bengals have had a season to remember, winning their first eight games and finishing 12-4, their best record since 1988. But in a wild-card playoff game on Saturday night, they will be underdogs at home to the Pittsburgh Steelers, whom they beat for the A.F.C. North crown. The reason is the absence of their starting quarterback, Andy Dalton, one of the league’s top passers this season.

The laser system supposedly works OK for moderate exercise, but it stands to reason that it would have trouble dealing with the sweat and jiggling of hard cardio.

abstract: “My brain didn’t catch up to my mouth,” Mr. LePage said two days after he told an audience that “guys with the name D-Money, Smoothie, Shifty” come from out of state to sell heroin and, before leaving, “impregnate a young white girl.”
lead_paragraph: A combative Gov. Paul R. LePage of Maine, who has a history of making blunt, sometimes racially tinged remarks, found himself in a familiar position on Friday as he sought to walk back a comment that had drawn widespread condemnation for its racial overtones.

headline: Beaver Hides, Bear Grease and ‘The Revenant’
abstract: Costuming the film’s trappers required extensive research. Frontiersmen’s journals and the Canadian park service were among the many sources used.
lead_paragraph: Designing the costumes for “The Revenant” was both a physical and metaphysical challenge for Jacqueline West. This story of early-19th-century trappers stranded in the American wilderness was filmed largely outdoors in the Canadian Rockies during fall and winter, when temperatures sometimes reached 40 degrees below zero, so keeping the actors warm — “and alive,” she added — was a serious concern.

lead_paragraph: MIYAZAKI, Japan — FOR some of Japan’s most adored celebrities, the journey to fame starts in a converted Internet cafe above a bowling alley in this sunny southwestern city.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE NAZIS NEXT DOOR: How America Became a Safe Haven for Hitler’s Men, by Eric Lichtblau. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) Drawing on interviews and a trove of released documents, Lichtblau, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The New York Times, recounts how America accepted approximately 10,000 Nazis in the wake of World War II. Many of these were recruited to work as scientists or as spies for the United States government, while others immigrated as “refugees.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BLIZZARD, by Vladimir Sorokin. Translated by Jamey Gambrell. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A doctor struggles through a snowstorm to aid the victims of a zombie plague in this combination satire and dystopian tale set in the near future.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Rosanna Pansino, whose “The Nerdy Nummies Cookbook” is No. 5 on the food and fitness list, is a YouTube star with more than three million subscribers to her online baking show.
lead_paragraph: Sugar and Spice: Every year around this time, when people are still recovering from the holidays and the main hardcover lists have settled into deep-freeze mode — a single new entry in the past four weeks! — it has become traditional for Inside the List to wander a little afield. Sometimes we reprint a list from years past. Sometimes we ask best-selling authors for their book-related wish lists or resolutions. This year, we bring you cookies: specifically, Rosanna Pansino’s atom cookies, from “The Nerdy Nummies Cookbook,” at No. 5 in its second month on the food and fitness list (available online). Pansino belongs to the growing club of YouTube stars who have crossed over into publishing; her online baking show, also called “Nerdy Nummies,” has more than three million subscribers who watch her take goofy delight in treats like doughnut waffles. (These are, literally, store-bought glazed doughnuts, heated and pressed in a home waffle iron. I’m not sure that qualifies as baking, but it sounds amazing.) If you suspect that Pansino’s appeal has as much to do with charm and presentation as with the actual recipes, her book probably won’t change your mind. But she is charming, in her way. Here’s how she introduces those atom cookies, which are just six-pointed sugar cookies iced and decorated to resemble a science class’s atom model, with an M&M nucleus and candy pearl electrons: “Atoms are the building blocks of every type of matter in the universe — even you! My grandfather was a nuclear physicist, my uncle followed in his footsteps, and my dad’s old high school even had an atom on its emblem. I guess you could say we have an atomic bond. I decorated my atoms green, blue and purple, but you can make your atom cookies any color you want. Just remember: Never trust an atom . . . they make up everything!”

headline: In the Presence of History
abstract: Brent Staples began his journalism career in Chicago, where he worked with several notable alumni of The Defender, a pioneering black newspaper.
lead_paragraph: This week, Brent Staples, an editorial writer at The Times, reviews “The Defender,” a history of that pioneering black newspaper in Chicago, which was founded in 1905.

headline: Moonlight Drives Zooplankton’s Winter Migrations
abstract: During Arctic winters, zooplankton migrate from the surface when they moon is full, a study found.
lead_paragraph: During the dark winter months in the Arctic Ocean, zooplankton migrate by the light of the moon, a new study reports.

headline: Suspect in Tel Aviv Rampage Is Killed in a Shootout With Police
abstract: The man suspected of killing three Israelis a week ago in a shooting rampage died on Friday in a shootout with the police in northern Israel, officials said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The man suspected of killing three Israelis last week in a shooting rampage in Tel Aviv was killed on Friday in a shootout with the police near his home in northern Israel, according to police officials.

headline: Angry Birders: Standoff at Oregon Refuge Has Riled a Passionate Group
keywords: ['Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Birds', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: With no resolution to the standoff in sight, birders are concerned that one of the nation’s premier observation spots for birds will be off limits for the foreseeable future.
lead_paragraph: Noah Strycker was in a hotel room in Ethiopia when he saw news that Oregon’s Malheur National Wildlife Refuge had been occupied by an armed group protesting the federal government’s imprisonment of two local ranchers. He had just completed a record-breaking “Big Year” of birding, in which he often spent 18 hours a day, without taking a day off, observing some 6,042 species of birds in 41 countries on seven continents. Mr. Strycker’s obsessive pursuit had taken him to the ends of the earth, but news of the occupation brought Malheur to mind as the place where he first fell in love with birding.

headline: Economists and Inequality
abstract: A harder subject than you think.
lead_paragraph: I’m a few days late on this characteristically lucid Justin Fox column on why it took so long for economists to focus on income inequality. But as one of the economists who did write about inequality — especially the rise of the one percent — pretty early, I think Fox has missed one important aspect: it’s a hard issue to model.

abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Ocean Grove, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Ocean Grove, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.

headline: A Costume Maker’s Unlikely Star Factory
abstract: Hiromi Kano’s factory turns out some of Japan’s most popular mascots — the smiling, dancing animals, mutated foodstuffs and saucer-eyed humanoids that promote every conceivable thing in the country.
lead_paragraph: Hiromi Kano’s factory turns out some of Japan’s most popular mascots — the smiling, dancing animals, mutated foodstuffs and saucer-eyed humanoids that promote every conceivable thing in the country.

headline: ‘The Sleep of the Righteous,’ by Wolfgang Hilbig
abstract: Stories sketch the life of an émigré dogged by his past.
lead_paragraph: The brutality, betrayals and deadening conformity of East Germany have provided fodder for a long list of celebrated writers. Christa Wolf won acclaim for her nuanced critiques of the now defunct Communist dictatorship, though her reputation took a beating with her admission that she had served as a ­Stasi informant. Heiner Müller’s scathing dramas challenged the authoritarian regime and earned him scorn as a “historical pessimist.” Then there was Wolfgang Hilbig, born in Saxony in 1941, who shoveled coal in a factory boiler room before discovering his true calling. Permitted to resettle in West Germany in 1985, he began attracting attention for his evocations of the East’s apocalyptic postwar landscape and the dislocations of a Cold War-era émigré who felt like an outsider in both societies.

headline: ‘Paradise City,’ by Elizabeth Day
abstract: A novel sets the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case in London.
lead_paragraph: Novels in which separate story lines collide often give the impression that even the most disparate people are somehow connected. And when that collision occurs through an act of violence, it’s sometimes assumed that other differences can be ignored — because, after all, what life has been lived without some pain and suffering? At best, such stories come across as saccharine odes to our shared humanity. But in a novel like Elizabeth Day’s tale of contemporary London, “Paradise City,” they can seem to exploit the circumstances of the less fortunate and the marginalized.

headline: ‘Defenders of the Unborn,’ by Daniel K. Williams
abstract: Views on abortion were different before Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Among those of us who wish to protect access to abortion, it’s easy to feel that “right to life” language is a cover for an attack on feminism. It’s a feeling supported by a common story about ­history: The anti-abortion movement began after Roe v. Wade, because conservative evangelicals were threatened by women’s newfound power over their bodies. What else could explain the movement’s swift rise in the decade following the Supreme Court’s decision, if not a widespread reaction against equal rights?

headline: Dave Hickey’s ‘25 Women: Essays on Their Art’
abstract: The controversial critic Dave Hickey claims the label of feminist.
lead_paragraph: “Most of my favorite people are women,” Dave Hickey proclaims in the introduction to “25 Women.” This statement, and indeed the whole book, can be read as a response to the accusations of sexism that have followed Hickey since the culture wars of the ’90s, when he published “The Invisible Dragon,” a series of cantankerous essays attacking the academic art establishment. According to Hickey, beauty, once the handmaiden of art, had been sacrificed on the altar of political correctness by a censorious ring of tenured apparatchiks. Hickey’s antagonists fought back. For the feminist critic Amelia Jones, his “revival of an abstract notion of ‘beauty’ ” served to validate “a particular group of critics (almost all white men) as having access to the truth.” For its critics, beauty was hardly innocent or self-evident, but hampered with cultural baggage: the objectification of women, the exclusion of minorities and the meretricious seductions of the marketplace.

headline: New Health Advice for Britons: No More Than Six Pints a Week
abstract: Updated guidelines recommend keeping alcohol intake to less than the equivalent of about six pints of beer, seven glasses of wine, or half a bottle of whiskey a week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used,” the villain Iago says in Shakespeare’s “Othello.”

headline: Words Unwired
abstract: A new generation of writers gives us the intimacy, the assurance of their solitude.
lead_paragraph: What’s the point of a literary magazine today? That’s a question I heard a lot five years ago, when my colleagues and I decided to relaunch The Paris Review.

headline: ‘Fake Missed Connections,’ by Brett Fletcher Lauer
abstract: After a failed marriage, a poet looks for love online.
lead_paragraph: For people still willing to get romantically involved with a Brooklyn writer, the poet Brett Fletcher Lauer’s memoir, “Fake Missed Connections,” may send them back to the shuffleboard bars of Gowanus for less troublesome freight. Lauer, the deputy director of the Poetry Society of America and author of the poetry collection “A Hotel in Belgium,” begins his memoir with a ringing phone; the call (or, as he later refers to it, “The Phone Call”) is from a woman he doesn’t know, informing Lauer that his wife is having an affair with her husband. “Who was that?” Lauer’s wife asks from the couch, and the memoir’s first story line — an archaeological dig in the ground of marital infidelity and its aftermath — is underway.

headline: New York City
abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
lead_paragraph: CITY ON A GRIDHow New York Became New YorkBy Gerard Koeppel296 pp. Da Capo, $29.99.

headline: Christopher Hitchens’s ‘And Yet . . .’ and Roger Scruton’s ‘Fools, Frauds and Firebrands’
abstract: Hitchens and Scruton assess thinkers, writers and political figures.
lead_paragraph: In “The New York Intellectuals,” his seminal 1968 essay looking back on the coterie of writers who burst on the scene in the late 1930s and exercised an outsize influence on the American mind until the rise of the New Left in the early ’60s, Irving Howe nicely captured what is distinctive about intellectuals in all times and places.

headline: Golden Globe Awards Parties Off to a Cold, Rainy Start
abstract: Cate Blanchett and Kristen Wiig make the W Magazine soiree, but it’s “Mr. Robot’s” Rami Malek who’s most sought after.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s been rainy and cold here, with nighttime temperatures in the 40s, and the Beverly Hilton, where the Golden Globes will be held on Sunday, isn’t looking glamorous at all, thanks to a new 12-story hotel going up in front of it. (It’s to be a Waldorf Astoria.) Things feel topsy-turvy, but, then again, it’s been a topsy-turvy awards season.

headline: ‘Alex Haley: And the Books That Changed a Nation,’ by Robert J. Norrell
abstract: Alex Haley brought attention to black America.
lead_paragraph: In 1977 Alex Haley, the author of the best-selling “Autobiography of Malcolm X,” achieved world renown after ABC broadcast an eight-part version of his book “Roots,” published the previous year to great acclaim. “Roots,” which chronicled Haley’s search for his African ancestors (and in doing so created a template for the genealogical boom reflected in popular series like “Finding Your Roots,” with Henry Louis Gates Jr.), became an international phenomenon that turned the financially insecure Haley into an icon. Yet Haley’s newfound celebrity and wealth proved to be a double-edged sword. Allegations of plagiarism and historical inaccuracies scarred him, diminishing his literary reputation, and, argues the historian Robert J. Norrell in his briskly paced “Alex Haley: And the Books That Changed a Nation,” unfairly tarnished the author of “the two most influential books on African-American history in the second half of the 20th century.”

headline: ‘One Child,’ by Mei Fong
abstract: How the repercussions of China’s recently repealed one-child policy have reshaped its society.
lead_paragraph: Readers would be forgiven for thinking that the announcement, on Oct. 29, 2015, that China was changing its one-child policy would have turned this book from an account of the daily lives of Chinese people into a work of history. Not so. The event itself came rather late for Mei Fong’s “One Child.” But she makes disconcertingly clear that the repercussions of population control will continue to reverberate throughout China. The policy itself remains a monument to official callousness, and Fong’s book pays moving testimony to the suffering and forbearance of its victims.

headline: ‘The Idealist: Aaron Swartz and the Rise of Free Culture on the Internet,’ by Justin Peters
abstract: The short life of Aaron Swartz, a passionate advocate of free information.
lead_paragraph: On a late autumn day in 2010, Aaron Swartz, an open-information advocate and early partner at the website Reddit, sneaked into a basement closet at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and surreptitiously connected his laptop to the school’s high-speed Internet network. Using the school’s credentials, he gained access to JSTOR, a database of academic journals, and began to illegally download thousands of files. Once a promising entrepreneur, Swartz had eschewed the traditional Silicon Valley career path for an unorthodox campaign of radical public-interest activism. He believed that the five million documents behind the JSTOR paywall were a common good and that they needed to be liberated by guerrilla action.

headline: ‘Shame and Wonder,’ by David Searcy
abstract: An author changes genre to take in the world around him.
lead_paragraph: “When people talk about style they are always a little astonished at the newness of it,” F. Scott Fitzgerald once wrote, “because they think that it is only style that they are talking about.” But uncommon literary style is always integrative, both the mother and the daughter of invention, wrought from a writer’s desperation “to express a new idea with such force that it will have the originality of the thought.”

headline: ‘The Geography of Genius,’ by Eric Weiner
abstract: A tour of some of the world’s exceptional places.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, the Soviet Union tried to make a version of Silicon Valley from scratch. A city called Zelenograd came to life on the outskirts of Moscow and was populated with all manner of brainy Soviet engineers. The hope — naturally — was that a concentration of clever minds coupled with ample funding would result in a wellspring of innovation and help Russia keep pace with California’s electronics boom. The experiment worked as well as one might expect. Few people will read this on a Mayakovsky-branded tablet or ­smartphone.

headline: ‘Dictator,’ by Robert Harris
abstract: The final volume of Harris’s Ancient Rome trilogy follows Cicero’s last years.
lead_paragraph: Cicero, the Roman statesman whose talent for oratory was such that he remains to this day a byword for eloquence, has always divided opinion. A key player in the death agony of Rome’s traditional republican system of government, he was lauded by his admirers as a defender of constitutional propriety and dismissed by his foes as a vacillating opportunist. Posterity has proved similarly conflicted. While America’s founding fathers revered him as a model of civic duty, he was excoriated by the most formidable German classicist of the 19th century, Theodor Mommsen, as a precursor of that lowest class of writer, a “newspaper columnist.” A person’s attitude to Cicero can often be most revealing.

headline: Martin O’Malley Could Get Excluded From the Next Democratic Debate
abstract: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland, who has argued most strenuously for more Democratic debates, is at risk of not qualifying for the next one under criteria laid out by NBC, the network hosting the Jan. 17 debate in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland, who has argued most strenuously for more Democratic debates, is at risk of not qualifying for the next one under criteria laid out by NBC, the network hosting the Jan. 17 debate in South Carolina.

headline: French Tax Authorities Investigate Karl Lagerfeld Over Tax Evasion Claims
abstract: Reports say the designer may have hidden as much as $21.7 million outside the country.
lead_paragraph: The new year may have begun, but one old trend seems to be refusing to go out of fashion: luxury industry big-hitters who run afoul of the law for alleged tax evasion.

headline: ‘Affluenza’ Case Mother, Tonya Couch, Appears in Texas Court
abstract: Ms. Couch, who is accused of helping her son escape to Mexico to avoid jail, was ordered held in custody for now.
lead_paragraph: The mother of the Texas teenager known for using an “affluenza” defense in a fatal drunken-driving case appeared in a Fort Worth court on Friday to face a felony charge related to helping her son flee to Mexico.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Twist on Paid Leave: She Plans to Tax Wealthiest
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Family Leaves', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Her proposal on paid family leave is distinct in the way that she wants to pay for it, but she hasn’t spelled out the details.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton explained her proposal for paid family leave for the first time on Thursday, and it shared a lot with other politicians’ plans: 12 weeks of paid time off to care for a new child or a sick family member or to recover from an illness or injury.

headline: A Welcome Move on Police Surveillance
keywords: ['Police', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: A new settlement should help curb unjustified surveillance of people targeted for personal, political, religious or racial reasons.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years have passed since the federal courts reacted to the New York City Police Department’s disregard for the Constitution by limiting how far the department could go in conducting surveillance on constitutionally protected activity. The court-ordered guidelines were loosened after 9/11 to give the police more flexibility. But over time, the tendencies that had forced the courts to act in the first place began to reassert themselves. In 2013, for example, the Associated Press showed that the department was using the “terrorism” designation to spy on law-abiding Muslims — and to ignore court-ordered limitations on investigations of constitutionally protected activity.

headline: New Clinton Emails Show Mixed Concerns on Security of Information
abstract: The latest documents show both a cavalier attitude toward handling communications at the State Department and concern for security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a Friday morning in June 2011, after Secretary of State Hillary Clinton had waited more than 12 hours for a set of talking points to be sent to her, a top aide told her the delay was because staff members were having problems sending faxes that would be secure from probing eyes.

headline: With Nuclear Test, North Korea’s Leader Asserts Role of Instigator
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Kim Jong-un is often dismissed as erratic, but this week he increased tensions between the United States and China and put more pressure on South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The young leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, has often been dismissed as inexperienced, erratic and even clueless. But with the North’s test of a nuclear bomb this week, he appears to have mastered a strategy that has served his reclusive country well: playing one big power against another.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Seattle Seahawks’ Defense Stands Out, Even Across Eras
abstract: Seattle’s Z-Score, a measure of how many standard deviations an element is from the mean, shows just how good its defense has been over the last four years.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks have allowed the fewest points in the N.F.L. in each of the last four seasons. No team during the Super Bowl era has matched that feat. In fact, the only other team to lead the N.F.L. in points allowed for such a stretch was the Cleveland Browns, who did it in five consecutive seasons from 1953 to 1957.

headline: New Jersey’s Private-Sector Retirement Plan Moves Forward
abstract: Lawmakers passed a bill, which was sent to Gov. Chris Christie, that would create a low-cost savings program for employees of small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Employees who work for private businesses in New Jersey are one step closer to receiving a relatively low-cost retirement savings plan, which would be run by the state but offered through employers.

headline: Governors Ball 2016 Books Kanye West, the Strokes and the Killers
abstract: Beck, Robyn, Haim and M83 are also on the lineup for the festival, scheduled for June 3-5 on Randalls Island.
lead_paragraph: In its quest to compete with Coachella, Bonnaroo and Lollapalooza, New York’s own big summer festival, Governors Ball, is going with Kanye West. The rapper has received top billing for the 2016 event along with the Strokes and the Killers. Beck, Robyn, Haim and M83 are also on the lineup for the festival, scheduled for June 3-5 on Randalls Island.

headline: Charles Koch Knocks Positions of Donald Trump and Ted Cruz
abstract: In an interview with The Financial Times, the billionaire Republican donor Charles Koch bemoaned the state of the field of Republican candidates seeking the nomination and suggested that big money was losing its influence in politics these days.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire Koch brothers have long been power brokers within the Republican Party, using their wealth to steer candidates and their policies. But this election season is turning out to be a different story, with a billionaire celebrity and a firebrand senator from Texas taking the political debate in directions that Charles G. Koch finds worrisome.

headline: The London Men’s Collections Start the Fall Fashion Season
abstract: The British capital’s men’s wear shows will cover four days, with 170 designers showing their work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fashion buyers and news media from around the world are arriving this weekend for London Collections Men, a four-day event that has become not just a curtain raiser for the traditional men’s wear catwalk season but also a source of financial firepower that goes far beyond its runways.

lead_paragraph: In July, the Twitter account of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont sent a single tweet that convinced Michael Render that this was the most exciting candidate he had ever seen.

headline: Obama Shifts Online Strategy on ISIS
abstract: The administration will overhaul its response to online propaganda from the Islamic State after acknowledging it had largely failed to counter extremists on social media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday announced an overhaul of its efforts to respond to online propaganda from the Islamic State after months of acknowledgments that it had largely failed in its attempts to counter extremist recruitment and exhortations to violence on social media.

abstract: On their own or served over rice, polenta or salads, or added to soups and stews, home-cooked beans are the foundation for a simple, healthy and satisfying meal.

lead_paragraph: With days to go before the 32 N.F.L. owners are expected to vote on whether to allow one or two teams to relocate to the Los Angeles area, officials in St. Louis angrily disputed the arguments that the Rams owner E. Stanley Kroenke made to justify being allowed to move his team to Southern California.

headline: When Can Women Stop Trying to Look Perfect?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Age, Chronological', 'Movies', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Beauty (Concept)']
abstract: Carrie Fisher got older. So does everyone. Just relax about it.
lead_paragraph: AS a lifelong devotee of fashion and tabloid magazines, I’ve read dozens of “Beautiful/Sexy at Any Age” features. You’ve probably seen these spreads, showcasing a bevy of lovely women whose faces, fashions, exercise routines and skin-care regimens are laid out to encourage imitation. For years, readers could stare at starlets and actresses and singers in their 20s, their 30s, their 40s and even edging bravely into their early 60s.

headline: U.S. Sends Kuwaiti Detainee Home From Guantánamo
abstract: The departure of the Kuwaiti man, who had been in American military custody for 14 years, reduced the detainee population at the prison to 104.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Friday repatriated the last Kuwaiti man it had held at its wartime prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, bringing an end to his 14 years in American military custody without trial.

headline: No ‘Making a Murderer’ Pardon From Obama, White House Says
abstract: Despite online petitions signed by hundreds of thousands of people, the president simply doesn’t have the power to pardon state prisoners.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will not be pardoning Steven Avery and Brendan Dassey, the subjects of the Netflix documentary series “Making a Murderer.”

headline: Up for Auction: Real Art, Owned by a Seller of Forgeries
abstract: An auction house raised nearly $5 million by selling works owned by Glafira Rosales, who has pleaded guilty to dealing in forgeries.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Gaston & Sheehan auction house, family-owned and located in Pflugerville, a small city in central Texas, has been a trusted place used by federal marshals to sell the many things seized in criminal cases.

headline: A State of Mind
abstract: Photographs by Janet Delaney show New York in the mid-1980s, a time defined by yuppies, hip-hop and the emerging AIDS crisis.
lead_paragraph: Photographs by Janet Delaney show New York in the mid-1980s, a time defined by yuppies, hip-hop and the emerging AIDS crisis.

headline: Janet Delaney Photographs New York in the 1980s
abstract: Ms. Delaney took pictures in New York from 1984 to 1987 and left them alone for decades. When she revisited her work, she found a city of street characters and urban dramas.
lead_paragraph: New York in the mid-1980s was a city braced for powerful forces: the swaggering yuppiedom of “Bonfire of the Vanities” and Oliver Stone’s “Wall Street” (both 1987); the AIDS epidemic and the crack wars; the graffiti boom and the golden age of New York hip-hop. For the photographer Janet Delaney, who visited regularly from the West Coast, between trips to Nicaragua, New York in the mid-1980s was a street theater where people wore their anxieties on their faces, a city that looked you in the eye. It was also a tough place to break into as an outsider, she said.

headline: Mandatory Union Fees Getting Hard Look by Supreme Court
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Government Employees', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The justices have already voiced skepticism about making people give money to public unions. They may now be ready to rule that it’s unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Harlan Elrich is a high school teacher in California, and that means he must pay about $970 a year to a labor union. He teaches math, and he said the system did not add up.

headline: It’s Raining Campaign Ads: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Nick Corasaniti explains how he listens to the flood of Presidential campaign ads now blasting through Iowa and New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: An endless stream of ads dropping into an email inbox is a waking nightmare for most regular people. For me, it’s one of the joys of the political-ad beat.

headline: Gunman Said He Shot Philadelphia Officer for ISIS, Police Say

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A man who wounded a Philadelphia police officer in a patrol car, emptying his gun and even reaching through the car window to shoot the officer, told investigators that he did it in the name of Islam and the Islamic State, police officials said Friday.

headline: Puerto Rico Pleads for Congressional Help as Lawsuits Are Filed
abstract: Two bond insurers sued Puerto Rico on Thursday over missed payments, and Governor Alejandro García Padilla again asked Congress for bankruptcy access.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico’s governor on Friday renewed his plea for Congress to provide bankruptcy protection for the debt-ridden island, after two bond insurers filed lawsuits over his decision to default on millions of dollars in bond payments last week.

lead_paragraph: A duplex penthouse at the Greenwich Lane condominium complex, which is rising at the site of the former St. Vincent’s Hospital campus in Greenwich Village, sold for $26,030,475.81 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Irene Neuwirth’s Perfect Mornings (and Smoothie Recipe)
abstract: The jewelry designer shares what she’s drinking right now to stay energized — and full.
lead_paragraph: “In a perfect world I wake up early — which I always do — take my dog Teddy for a long walk, get coffee, work out and make my smoothie,” says the jewelry designer Irene Neuwirth. Though she has a weakness for cheeseburgers, Neuwirth starts each day with a protein-packed shake that has evolved over the years. “It’s been a bit of trial and error. Ingredients come and go, but this is what I’m really enjoying right now,” she says of its current incarnation. “The chia seeds give me energy, and the protein powder actually fills me up. And I always love fresh fruit. It’s a solid balance of delicious and good for you.”

abstract: Ted Cruz asked the crowd at a church to spend one minute a day in prayer until caucus day. “One minute, lifting our country up in prayer,” he said, his eyes narrowing as the cheers swelled.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire investor, is walking away largely unscathed from nearly a decade of investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators into accusations of insider trading at his former hedge fund.

headline: Old Mariner, With Rhymes and Love for East Village
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: Phillip Giambri, 74, says life kept trying to make him a writer, and he kept trying to be a drunk. He runs open-mike sessions in his beloved East Village.
lead_paragraph: It was after noon on Monday, so Phillip Giambri, 74, put on his pork-pie hat and walked from his apartment on St. Marks Place to Grassroots Tavern, a joint with low ceilings, cheap drinks and a pervasive tang of stale beer that smelled like tough, old New York.

headline: European Starling, the Bard’s Bird
abstract: The bird, mentioned in one of Shakespeare’s plays, was introduced in the United States around 1890 and has become a significant pest species.
lead_paragraph: There are few birds as universally reviled as the European starling, and consequently, few with as interesting a story to tell. The bird is not the oily, crop-eating winged rat of legend. In fact, it is closer to an avian Horatio Alger: In human-altered environs, it gets my vote for the bird most likely to succeed.

headline: How Would Mao Stack Up in New York?
abstract: A 120-foot-tall statue of Mao that was torn down Thursday certainly looked enormous in the fields of Henan Province in China. But it would have been pretty impressive in New York, too.
lead_paragraph: A 120-foot-tall statue of Mao that was torn down Thursday certainly looked enormous in the fields of Henan Province in China. But it would have been pretty impressive in New York, too.

headline: Stories of Brooklyn, From Gowanus to the Heights
abstract: Covering the history of the Gowanus Canal; the discovery of photographs intended for an essay by Truman Capote; and the story of century-old homes in Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: The Gowanus Canal may never evoke Venice, but within a few decades, developers are betting, people will be paying a high premium to inhabit its banks. Until then, readers can get a historical view through Joseph Alexiou’s edifying “Gowanus: Brooklyn’s Curious Canal” (New York University Press, $29.95).

headline: Young Moviemakers Meet Old Masters at the Frick
abstract: The Ghetto Film School collaborates with the Frick Collection in a program that exposes students to artwork at the museum and lets them shoot there.
lead_paragraph: In the Gilded Age mansion of the Frick Collection, in a room devoted to Jean-Honoré Fragonard’s bucolic wall panels called “The Progress of Love,” two young men meet and begin a flirtatious debate about the four stages of love illustrated in the 18th-century canvases, from a painted couple’s first pastoral encounter to their joyful reminiscing over old love letters. The more worldly of the two men suggests that actual love can be far more treacherous. Indeed, the arc of their relationship eventually bears this out: Far from Fragonard’s happily-ever-after scenario, it ends with a breakup devastating to one of the men. Years later, he advises his teenage niece that pain is a privilege of being human. “Life’s little pleasures are worth rotting for,” he says.

headline: Saudi Aramco I.P.O. Prospect Reflects Kingdom Looking Beyond Oil
abstract: In a move that would have political and demographic motives, the kingdom is considering its strategy while the price of oil remains low.

abstract: A $30 billion fund underscores China’s ambitions to expand its tech capabilities and signals how those ambitions are being threatened by recent market turmoil.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese technology regulator said on Friday that it would cooperate with a bank to set up a $30 billion fund to support the country’s huge electronics supply chain.

lead_paragraph: In a now familiar ritual, the release on Thursday of hundreds of pages of transcribed phone calls and meetings between former President Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, then the British prime minister, from early 1997, to late 2000, was followed by journalists and political junkies sharing striking, funny or odd excerpts from the chats on social networks.

headline: Big City Book Club to Discuss ‘We Are Not Ourselves’
abstract: After reviewing suggestions from readers, the Big City Book Club has selected the 2014 novel by Matthew Thomas about a multigenerational Irish-American family in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Big City Book Club asked readers to suggest the best New York-centric books they read in 2015. A few titles cropped up frequently, but the one repeated with the most enthusiasm was “We Are Not Ourselves,” by Matthew Thomas, a 2014 novel about a multigenerational Irish-American family in New York. With the author, we held  a live online discussion on Thursday, Feb. 11, at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: How Al Roker and His Wife, Deborah Roberts, Spend Their Sundays
abstract: The television weatherman and his wife, who is a correspondent for ABC, have written a book that highlights the differences in their personalities.
lead_paragraph: With the dramatic temperature changes this winter, Al Roker might need to prepare to break his own Guinness World Record, set in 2014, when he gave an uninterrupted 34-hour weather report. But the 61-year-old host and weatherman of NBC’s “Today” is also busy promoting a book he wrote with his wife, Deborah Roberts, a correspondent for ABC, called “Been There, Done That: Family Wisdom for Modern Times.” “It kind of highlights our differences,” Ms. Roberts, who is in her 50s, said. “I’m a Southern belle, a little more formal, and Al is a little more of a loosey-goosey guy who grew up in Brooklyn and Queens.” The couple live in a brownstone on the Upper East Side with their children, Leila, 17, and Nick, 13, and their dog, Pepper. Mr. Roker also has a daughter, Courtney, 28.

headline: Former Cardinals Executive Pleads Guilty to Hacking Astros
abstract: Christopher Correa pleaded guilty on Friday in an unusual case of high-tech cheating involving two Major League Baseball clubs.
lead_paragraph: Chris Correa, a former scouting director for the St. Louis Cardinals who was fired for his role in hacking the database of the Houston Astros, pleaded guilty on Friday in United States District Court in Houston to five counts of unauthorized access to a protected computer.

headline: You Don’t Need More Free Time
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'Research', 'Working Hours', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Happiness', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Well, you might. But that’s not the real key to finding work-life balance.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS work some of the longest hours in the Western world, and many struggle to achieve a healthy balance between work and life. As a result, there is an understandable tendency to assume that the problem we face is one of quantity: We simply do not have enough free time. “If I could just get a few more hours off work each week,” you might think, “I would be happier.”

headline: A Group Show, Curated by an Artist Who Hates Group Shows
abstract: Mark Flood’s “The Future Is Ow” brings together the painter’s own work with that of four of his Houston contemporaries.
lead_paragraph: The artist Mark Flood plays curator this winter with “The Future Is Ow” at Marlborough Chelsea. The prophetically titled exhibition gathers together the most futuristic work of the Houstonian’s artist circle, which includes Chris Bexar, Paul Kremer, El Franco Lee II and Susie Rosmarin. Billed as a group show governed by a common interest in digital printing, it celebrates years of fruitful friendship both in and out of the studio — and the informal layout, which includes a mattress floor and plywood fortresses, is more reminiscent of a clubhouse than an exhibition. “I get the idea and the title for a show at the same time,” explains Flood, who has been collecting his peers’ work for decades. “I don’t think the future is going to look like a James Bond movie; I think it will be some shelter where everyone sits on the floor surrounded by art.” Here, a look at Flood’s brave new world.

headline: Seeing Miró’s Majorca Studio, Just the Way He Kept It
abstract: A re-creation of Joan Miró’s Mediterranean workplace is on exhibition, 60 years after he began working there.
lead_paragraph: PALMA, Majorca — In 1938, the Spanish artist Joan Miró, then 45, was living a precarious existence in Paris, moving from one insufficient studio to the next. His situation was scarcely better than it had been in Spain, where he had painted “in tiny cubicles where I could hardly turn around,” he wrote that year in “I Dream of a Large Studio,” an essay for a French art review.

headline: For a Local Sinatra, Construction, Crooning and Despair
abstract: Gary Russo, an ironworker known for performing pop standards in a rich baritone, wrestled with private demons as his local celebrity dimmed.
lead_paragraph: Just after 1 a.m. on July 28, Leonora Russo woke to a commotion at her home in Howard Beach, Queens. First came the yelps of her daughter’s Chihuahua, then the crash of her front door slamming shut. By the time she reached her window, Ms. Russo saw only a black Dodge Dakota receding into the night.

headline: Review: American Realness, a Festival of Audacious Movements and Slitherings
abstract: The seventh edition of this annual celebration of contemporary performance featured a piece that made you think of dance as undomesticated wildlife.
lead_paragraph: Though it may feel out of the way — far, far east on the Lower East Side — there’s no missing American Realness once you get there. In its seventh edition, this annual festival of contemporary performance announces itself boldly, its name projected in big block letters on the facade of Abrons Arts Center, home to most of the festival’s 18 boundary-blurring productions.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Thunder in the Head Solved
abstract: Readers try to solve the case of a middle aged man who developed chest pain that radiated to his neck, followed by a persistent and loud whooshing in his ear.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers with a difficult real-life case of a middle aged man who developed chest pain that radiated to his neck, followed by a persistent and loud whooshing in his ear. You were asked to figure out what was causing this patient’s pulsatile tinnitus and why he developed it. While several of you got half of the answer, as of this writing, no one put together both halves of the puzzle.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump trails Senator Ted Cruz in Iowa but has a commanding double-digit lead in New Hampshire with less than a month to go before voting begins in the first contests in the Republican presidential nominating fight, according to new Fox News surveys.

headline: Behind the Oregon Standoff, You’ll Find Big Questions About Democracy
abstract: America’s long history of land disputes is where deep questions — like what our nation is ultimately for — turn suddenly concrete.
lead_paragraph: Arguments about federal land have been a feature of American political life since the birth of the nation. The details of the controversies may vary, but the theme is always the same: How should we use federal lands for the collective and individual benefit of the nation? The issue sounds abstract and philosophical. But given that the federal Bureau of Land Management administers roughly one-eighth of the nation’s landmass, its decisions confront the question in a very concrete way: What, fundamentally, is our land for?

lead_paragraph: President Obama’s pledge not to back any Democrat who does not support new gun-control measures set off a new skirmish late Friday between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders, with Mr. Sanders facing fresh questions over his record on the issue.

lead_paragraph: Steven H. Davis, the former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, will not face another criminal trial over allegations of accounting fraud at the once mighty New York law firm, but he will remain in legal limbo for the next five years.

headline: Ted Stanley, Whose Son’s Illness Inspired Philanthropy, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Stanley, who made his fortune selling collectibles, gave hundreds of millions of dollars to biomedical research on psychiatric disorders.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, something went terribly wrong with Jonathan Stanley’s brain. A college junior, he was visiting a friend in New York when he suddenly suspected that secret agents were pursuing him. For three days, he raced through the city’s streets and subways without food or water until the police found him penniless in a deli perched naked on a plastic milk crate.

headline: Greater Risk of Crash Prompts Hyundai Elantra Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Hyundai is recalling 155,000 2011-12 Elantra models because the electronic stability control may malfunction, suddenly reducing engine power while trying to alter the direction of the vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Hyundai is recalling 155,000 2011-12 Elantra models because the electronic stability control may malfunction, suddenly reducing engine power while trying to alter the direction of the vehicle, according to a report posted in December on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Hyundai blamed a malfunctioning sensor on the electronic stability control system, which is supposed to detect if the vehicle is sliding in a direction at odds with how the steering wheel is turned. The recall is necessary because the sensor may activate the electronic stability control when it is not needed, “increasing the risk of a crash,” the automaker told regulators. Hyundai said it was not aware of any accidents or injuries related to the defect. Some owners began complaining to regulators as early as 2013. “It feels as if the auto is driving on flat wheels or on ice,” a New Jersey owner wrote in 2013.

lead_paragraph: Plus: An Art Deco party on New Year’s Day.

headline: U.S. Gives States 2 More Years to Meet Driver’s License Standards
keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'State Legislatures', 'Airport Security', 'Law and Legislation', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: States not complying with federal requirements for extra safety features in driving licenses gain a two-year extension before residents must use a passport or other government ID to board a flight.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security has given states an extra two years to comply with federal requirements to issue driving licenses with extra safety features, meaning that residents of noncompliant states will have until January 2018 before having to use a passport or other official identification to board a domestic flight.

headline: Brazil: Protest Over Higher Bus Fares Erupt in 3 Cities
abstract: Demonstrations in São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Belo Horizonte reflected resentment over efforts to cover budget shortfalls.
lead_paragraph: Protests flared in the cities of São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Belo Horizonte on Friday night over increases in bus fares, reflecting resentment over efforts by the municipal authorities to cover budget shortfalls during Brazil’s most severe economic crisis in decades. Anti-riot police units clashed with protesters in downtown São Paulo. The unrest drew comparisons to the much larger demonstrations that shook cities across Brazil in 2013, which also crystallized over increases in bus fares. Some of the demonstrators in São Paulo destroyed buses, ransacked banking offices and threw rocks and bottles at the police, who used tear gas. Clashes also erupted between the police and protesters in downtown Rio de Janeiro.
