headline: Cause of Crises? For Rio Governor, Life Incriminates Art
abstract: As problems grow in Rio de Janeiro State seven months before it hosts the Olympics, its governor, Luiz Fernando de Souza, partly blames a painting that was in his office.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Just seven months before the start of the Olympic Games here, Rio de Janeiro State has declared a public health emergency, plunging oil royalties have officials scrambling to pay pensions, and assailants enjoy such free rein that muggings in downtown Rio are a regular feature on television news programs.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Winter Flair
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Hats and Caps', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Head wraps were inventively stylish, and fur bonnets were a favorite. Men wore shearling coats, and one woman swirled in a pleated Chanel coat.
lead_paragraph: The doggies on Fifth Avenue were snuggled into winter coats, and the fountain in Bryant Park was a cascade of icicles. Head wraps were inventively stylish, and fur bonnets were a favorite. Men wore shearling coats, and one woman swirled in a pleated Chanel coat. Cat-eye bags provided a touch of whimsy.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Benghazi, and the Benefits of Spanking
abstract: Talking about Hillary Clinton and Benghazi, Ted Cruz notes that his 5-year-old daughter gets a spanking when she lies.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Florida: Ex-Leader of Salvadoran Military Deported
abstract: General José Guillermo García, who was minister of defense in El Salvador in the 1980s, was deported after an immigration judge found he assisted in torture.
lead_paragraph: The authorities have deported General José Guillermo García, who was minister of defense in El Salvador in the 1980s, after an immigration judge found that he had a role in human rights violations in that period, including in the 1980 slaying of Archbishop Óscar Arnulfo Romero while the prelate was saying Mass in San Salvador. In a decision in February 2014, the judge found that General García, a close ally of the United States during the Salvadoran civil war, should be deported for assisting “numerous acts of torture and extrajudicial killing while he was command,” a Department of Homeland Security news release said. An appeal by General García, 82, of the lower court ruling was denied on Dec. 8. He was arrested on Dec. 17 at his home in Florida, where he had been living for many years, and was flown to San Salvador on Friday.

headline: California: Gas Leaking in Neighborhood to Be Burned
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Air Pollution', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Air-quality regulators have reached an agreement with the Southern California Gas Company to capture and burn off some of the natural gas escaping from a blown-out well.
lead_paragraph: Air-quality regulators have reached an agreement with the Southern California Gas Company to capture and burn off some of the natural gas escaping from a blown-out well, which continues to pump tons of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, into the air and has sickened residents in the nearby Los Angeles neighborhood of Porter Ranch. The gas company will take measures within 10 days to use carbon absorbers and thermal oxidizers to capture and burn off some of the gas, according to the regulators. Though regulators still do not know exactly how much gas is escaping, they acknowledged it would not be possible to capture all of it. The agreement requires the gas company to conduct extensive air-quality monitoring, and to pay for a study of the leak’s effect on residents’ health.

headline: Firehouse Loses a Spotted Symbol of Healing
abstract: Twenty, a Dalmatian given to a firehouse that suffered heavy losses on Sept. 11, 2001, died on Tuesday after years of living among the firefighters.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, 2001, seven members of Ladder Company 20 on Lafayette Street in the NoLIta neighborhood of Manhattan were killed in the collapse of the World Trade Center, about a mile and a half away, along with seven members of Squad 18, which shared the firehouse at the time with the ladder company.

headline: Lawfulness of Strip Search by Police Officer Is Under Scrutiny
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure', 'Subways']
abstract: Shortly after swiping onto the wrong subway platform, Tynneal Grant found herself in police custody and being ordered to remove her clothes for a search.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in 2014, Tynneal Grant faced the kind of subterranean dilemma that often confronts New Yorkers: an absent-minded swipe of a MetroCard onto the wrong subway platform, followed by vague instructions from a ticket booth clerk about how to cross to the right one without spending another $2.50 on fare.

headline: Pulled Once More Toward the Healing Power of Art
abstract: Sent into a downward spiral by the death of her mother, Tanya Nickolan found a refuge in art therapy, as well as something to strive toward in the future.
lead_paragraph: The death of her mother in 2011 left Tanya Nickolan inconsolable.

headline: Stephen W. Bosworth, U.S. Diplomat Who Helped Oust Ferdinand Marcos, Dies at 76
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Mr. Bosworth persuaded the Philippine dictator to allow free elections, then delivered Washington’s pink slip to him when he refused to accept defeat.
lead_paragraph: Stephen W. Bosworth, a former American ambassador who pulled off a diplomatic coup in 1986 by persuading the Philippine dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos to allow free elections, and then personally delivered Washington’s pink slip to him when he refused to accept defeat, died on Jan. 4 at his home in Boston. He was 76.

headline: A Republican Muslim Out to Expand the Ranks
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Saba Ahmed, a relative newcomer to the Washington lobbying scene, has taken on the improbable and perhaps ill-fated mission of attracting Muslim voters to the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wearing a black hijab and a Pakistani ankle-length gown, Saba Ahmed lined up one morning inside the Rayburn House Office Building here, waiting to lobby members of the Armed Services Committee.

headline: Over 200 Members of German Choir Were Abused, Investigator Says
abstract: The investigator said he assumed that the older brother of Pope Benedict XVI knew of the abuse when he ran the Bavarian boys’ choir for 30 of the nearly 40 years covered by the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — At least 231 children who sang in a boys’ choir led for 30 years by the brother of former Pope Benedict XVI were abused over a period of almost four decades, a lawyer investigating reports of wrongdoing said Friday.

headline: A New Old Plan for Penn Station
abstract: Governor Cuomo’s proposal to revitalize Penn Station made New Yorkers perk up. But how much will it cost and how long will it take?
lead_paragraph: You could have gotten dizzy following the bouncing governor, Andrew Cuomo, around New York in the last few days, ahead of his State of the State address next week. To generate excitement about his plans for transportation and infrastructure, he has been leading a road show, spreading proposals one by one, far and wide. Between Proposal 5 (lower Thruway tolls!) and 7 (a bigger Javits Convention Center!), was one to make a New Yorker perk up: Proposal 6, transforming Penn Station.

headline: André Courrèges, Fashion Designer Who Redefined Couture, Dies at 92
abstract: His ‘Space Age’ collection upended the little black dress.
lead_paragraph: André Courrèges, the French designer who brought the space age to the catwalk and into the closets of women like Catherine Deneuve and Jacqueline Kennedy, died on Thursday at his home in Neuilly-sur-Seine outside Paris. He was 92.

headline: Homeland Security Looked Past Antigovernment Movement, Ex-Analyst Says
abstract: When gunmen took over federal land in rural Oregon last week, Daryl Johnson, a former Department of Homeland Security official, was not surprised.
lead_paragraph: Daryl Johnson once worked in the branch of the Department of Homeland Security that studied the threats posed by antigovernment groups. His former office was shut down more than five years ago.

headline: China’s Obsolete Economic Strategy
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The country’s leaders have turned what should have been a benign, natural slowdown into a chaotic descent.
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable that China’s economy would slow from its once turbocharged growth rates. But its leaders have made so many mistakes in recent months that they have turned what should have been a benign, natural slowdown into a chaotic descent.

headline: Trump and Other Republicans Do the Gun Lobby’s Bidding
abstract: They distort President Obama’s reasonable gun control proposals while peddling simplistic evasions and dangerous misinformation.
lead_paragraph: Just when President Obama was attempting a reasoned debate on gun control this week, Donald Trump was engaged in his latest pandering to the gun rights crowd — vowing as president to strike down laws that bar firearms from schools. ”My first day, it gets signed, O.K.?” Mr. Trump told a campaign rally in Vermont on Thursday. “My first day. There’s no more gun-free zones.”

headline: Egypt’s Parliament Prepares for Session With Some Familiar Names
abstract: Although some of the most reviled Mubarak-era figures were barred from the election, several other officials or close relatives have seen their political fortunes restored.
lead_paragraph: ISMAILIA, Egypt — As his jeep careened along a narrow country road, swerving to avoid slower traffic, Talaat el-Sewedy, a newly elected parliamentarian, juggled two cellphones as he fielded a barrage of demands from supporters.

headline: Coach Takes a Big Step Back From Manziel and Favre
abstract: Mike Sherman, a college and pro football coach for 33 years, is bringing his skills to a high school in Eastham, Mass., whose football team went 1-10 in 2015.
lead_paragraph: WEST DENNIS, Mass. — In many of Mike Sherman’s 33 years as a college and pro football coach, the winter was a time of bustle and activity.

headline: Germany’s Post-Cologne Hysteria
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sex Crimes', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Assaults', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: After the attacks, is rational discussion about Germany’s refugees possible?
lead_paragraph: Berlin — ON New Year’s Eve, hundreds of men gathered in the plaza at the main train station in Cologne, Germany, groping and robbing scores of women as they passed by. By the end of this week the police had received 170 complaints, including 120 related to sexual assault.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: You Going to Eat Those Fries?
abstract: As he closed out his Iowa bus tour, Ted Cruz got distracted during his stump speech.

headline: Dirty School Buses, Sick Kids
keywords: ['Buses', 'Diesel Power', 'Education (K-12)', 'Air Pollution', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Volkswagen should be forced to replace old, diesel-belching school buses as penance for its emissions cover-up.
lead_paragraph: AS former state public health officials in Maryland, we were quite embarrassed and angry to learn that we had been driving around in little pollution factories, otherwise known as Volkswagen diesels. At the same time, we understand that the car owners are not the only victims of the company’s deceptions. To make right by the environment and those harmed by air pollution, Volkswagen should stop sending us apologies — and should start replacing thousands of old school buses across the country.

headline: Denna Laing, Who Fell During Outdoor Women’s Classic, Has No Feeling in Her Legs
abstract: The news was the first public update on the condition of Denna Laing, a forward for the Boston Pride, since she was carried off the ice in a game on Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: Boston Pride forward Denna Laing sustained a severe spinal cord injury after falling near the boards during the Outdoor Women’s Classic on Dec. 31 at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass.

headline: Yemen Reverses Decision to Expel U.N. Rights Envoy
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: The United Nations has criticized Yemen, and its most powerful backer, Saudi Arabia, for their reported use of cluster bombs in heavily populated areas.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The government of Yemen on Friday reversed its decision to expel a United Nations representative from the country, and its envoy to the United Nations said that he hoped for “better relations” with the world body.

headline: Wanted: Straight Shooters
abstract: The nation could find a rare moment of gun consensus by supporting safety training.
lead_paragraph: We have come a long way in the debate on gun safety. Well, actually we haven’t come anywhere at all. But we’ve certainly talked a lot.

headline: George Elsey, One of the Last Survivors of World War II White House, Dies at 97
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Elsey worked in the White House Map Room under Presidents Roosevelt and Truman, and later became an assistant to Truman, writing policy papers and speeches.
lead_paragraph: He went to the White House living quarters to hand President Franklin D. Roosevelt top-secret messages. When the first atomic bomb was dropped on Japan, he decoded the news and took it to President Harry S. Truman.

headline: Center of a Defense
abstract: A challenging Saturday offering from Jason Flinn.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you can get yourself into habits that completely, entirely lead to your undoing. Don’t worry; it’s the end of the week and I’m just being melodramatic. I’m really talking about puzzle solving.

headline: Effort to Vacate Man’s Murder Verdict Focuses on Work by Detective in Case
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: John D. Bunn is seeking to clear his name after he was convicted in the fatal shooting of an off-duty correction officer.
lead_paragraph: During his 1992 murder trial in the killing of an off-duty correction officer, John D. Bunn, then an illiterate 15-year-old, took his lawyer’s advice and did not testify. Things were different on Friday, as Mr. Bunn, now 39, took the witness stand in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn and testified tearfully about the case in an effort to have his conviction vacated.

headline: New York to Add 300 Shelter Beds for Homeless Young People
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan, which calls for 100 new beds a year for the next three years, targets an age group that can often feels unwelcome in traditional shelters.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in his latest attempt to address New York City’s homelessness crisis, unveiled a plan on Friday to add 300 shelter beds for older teenagers, an age group that advocates say is underserved and especially vulnerable to suicide and sex trafficking.

headline: Bronx Man, Arrested in Slashing, Is Charged in Other Attacks
abstract: The police say a man who was arrested on Wednesday has now been charged in an attack that occurred in November.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx man arrested in the slashing of a woman’s face this week in Manhattan has been charged in a separate case with attacking a woman two months ago on a Midtown sidewalk, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Knicks Battle to End but Can’t Faze Spurs, Who Win 31st Straight at Home
abstract: Kristaps Porzingis scored 28 points for the Knicks, who fell short at the buzzer and failed to stop San Antonio’s regular-season home winning streak.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Like straight-A students in high school, the San Antonio Spurs have a way of making other teams seem inadequate. It has been this way for about a decade and a half.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Abortion Comes Up, Briefly
abstract: Ted Cruz was asked if he could support abortions in cases of rape, setting off a few murmurs in the crowded room.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

abstract: “Mad Max: Fury Road” comes to cable. Judge Jeanine Pirro takes on the case of Steven Avery. And Jason Sudeikis and Alison Brie try to avoid commitment.
lead_paragraph: “Mad Max: Fury Road,” a critics’ favorite last year, makes its way to cable. Judge Jeanine Pirro takes on the case of Steven Avery, the subject of the Netflix hit “Making a Murderer.” And Jason Sudeikis and Alison Brie try to avoid commitment — and each other — in “Sleeping With Other People.”

headline: Doctors Unionize to Resist the Medical Machine
abstract: An Oregon medical center’s plan to increase efficiency by outsourcing doctors drove a group of its hospitalists to fight back by banding together.
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning on Aug. 12, 2015, a 68-year-old man named Barry turned up at PeaceHealth Sacred Heart Medical Center in Springfield, Ore., confused and feverish.

headline: The Lark-Owl Scale: When Couples’ Sleep Patterns Diverge
abstract: Do you collapse with the kids, or stay up past midnight? This is what happens when bedmates have mismatched sleep habits: They hardly see each other.
lead_paragraph: I learned about my friends’ sleep problems by accident. We were having a cookout with three families not long ago, and the children were off playing by themselves. The couples sat down for an adult conversation that might otherwise have turned to Hollywood, parenting or Donald Trump, when suddenly one of the women announced she had a confession: She never got to see her husband.

headline: Parasitic Infections Common in Roman Times
abstract: Despite advances in sanitation, Romans were often infested with lice, tapeworms and more.
lead_paragraph: Two thousand years ago, the ancient Romans introduced public multiseat toilets, hand-washing stations, sewage systems, aqueducts for drinking water, and heated public baths.

headline: A Day at the Races
abstract: Wealthy landowners and businessmen in Punjab keep up some erstwhile royal traditions, including greyhound races.
lead_paragraph: Wealthy landowners and businessmen in Punjab keep up some erstwhile royal traditions, including greyhound races.

headline: Chasing the Lure of a Royal Past With Greyhound Racing in Punjab
abstract: By racing dogs in an unmarked field, wealthy Sikh landowners — some of them gas station moguls in the United States — are trying to keep alive the ways of the maharajahs.
lead_paragraph: FARIDKOT, India — A column of 4-by-4s turned off a dusty road in rural Punjab last week, past ox carts and farmworkers holding sickles, and came to a stop in an unmarked field. Servants circled around to the backs of the vehicles and unloaded, ever so carefully, the animals everyone had come to see.

headline: Campus Sex … With a Syllabus
abstract: How do you teach college students about sexual consent? The answer: very, very carefully.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — “Where did I learn about sexual consent?”

headline: Guns to Gloves
abstract: After his friend was shot on Christmas Eve in 2013, Chris Wilmore — known as Scarface — began recruiting for his backyard fight club, as a way to encourage people to settle disputes with gloves, not guns.
lead_paragraph: After his friend was shot on Christmas Eve in 2013, Chris Wilmore — known as Scarface — began recruiting for his backyard fight club, as a way to encourage people to settle disputes with gloves, not guns.

lead_paragraph: HARRISONBURG, Va. — Chris Wilmore was devastated after his close friend was shot to death on Christmas Eve in 2013, in a dispute over a woman.

headline: A Tour of Animatronic Tails and a Potemkin Village at International CES
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Las Vegas has a fake Statue of Liberty and a fake Eiffel Tower. So why not add a fake Twitter town for business meetings?
lead_paragraph: As usual, lot of strange stuff graced the floor of International CES, the consumer electronics trade show that took place in Las Vegas this week. There was a Roomba-like robot that cleans your grill — perfect for that post-labor future in which we’re all too lazy to spend 30 seconds running a brush across the barbecue. In another booth was a robot that roams around a tennis court picking up balls: Ballboys, you’ve just been disrupted.

keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Assaults', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The officer was shot in the ankle and five people were stabbed early Saturday when a large brawl involving as many as 100 people erupted at what officials described as an illegal “jump-up” party.
lead_paragraph: It was around 2 a.m. on Saturday when police officers from the 40th Precinct’s anticrime unit arrived at the scene of a large brawl in the South Bronx that officials said involved dozens of people, some armed with bats, knives and guns.

headline: Astrid Andersen: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall 2016 looks from Astrid Andersen.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 looks from Astrid Andersen.

headline: ‘Broken System’ Allows ISIS to Profit From Looted Antiquities
abstract: A police raid in Bulgaria was heralded as a rare success against the trafficking of antiquities, but it also highlighted the barriers officials face.
lead_paragraph: SHUMEN, Bulgaria — Acting on a tip, the police raided four homes in eastern Bulgaria, looking for contraband that regularly traverses this country on the way to markets in Western Europe and America. In one rusting shed behind an apartment block here, they found a cache of looted antiquities: 19 classical statues and fragments of marble or limestone.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Cars With, and Without, Drivers
keywords: ['International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: Auto manufacturers, ride-hailing companies and lawmakers are turning their attention to self-driving cars.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: How ‘Crazy’ Are the North Koreans?
abstract: It’s time to stop treating the government in Pyongyang like cartoon villains.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AS someone who has spent most of the past 25 years of his professional life in the United States government, think tanks and academia trying to stop the North Korean nuclear weapons program, I found last week’s nuclear test and the events that followed depressingly familiar. They reminded me of Captain Renault’s famous line from “Casablanca” just before he shuts down Rick’s Café: “I’m shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on in here!” The reactions to North Korea’s 2006, 2009 and 2013 nuclear tests were the same — shock. Yet a decade has gone by and the North Korean nuclear threat has only grown.

headline: SoHo. TriBeCa. And ReBeCha?

abstract: This week’s questions are about naming New York neighborhoods; conflicts of interest on co-op boards; and clogged drains co-op buildings.

lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 show from Coach.

lead_paragraph: With trick catches, textbook throwing form and more than a few smiles, Marco Rubio is showing a lighter side — both self-assured and self-deprecating — to football fans in a new ad to be released this weekend, titled “Football.”

abstract: Lou Dalton’s take on fall 2016.
lead_paragraph: Lou Dalton’s take on fall 2016.

headline: Christopher Cabrera of Xactly: Learning to Stay Above the Drama
abstract: Mr. Cabrera, founder and C.E.O. of the employee-incentive software company Xactly, says being the fourth of five children meant learning to fight for everything, including dinner.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Christopher Cabrera, founder and C.E.O. of Xactly, which provides employee-incentive software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: One Market Prediction Is Sure: Wall Street Will Be Wrong
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy']
abstract: No one can accurately predict the short-term path of the stock market. But even if no single reliable indicator exists, there are some signs to watch.
lead_paragraph: The stock market ended 2015 with a whimper and began the new year with a shudder. Even before Wall Street showed up for business on Monday morning, stocks fell 7 percent in China, and the turmoil that started in Asian markets cascaded around the world.

headline: Drawing on Experience to Teach Independent Living Skills
abstract: An assistant program coordinator at the Helen Keller National Center teaches people who are deaf and blind to take care of their needs.
lead_paragraph: Maricar Marquez, 44, is an assistant program coordinator for independent living at the Helen Keller National Center in Sands Point, N.Y.

headline: Variety: A Wild Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon take us outdoors in the first acrostic of 2016.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Welcome to our first acrostic puzzle of 2016! I hope you’ve bundled up, because we are headed outdoors with Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon to explore nature and the circle of life.

headline: Challenging Uber, Lyft Bets on a Road Wide Enough for Two
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Effective monopolies are the rule in technology companies. But with a recent billion-dollar investment, Lyft may show that ride-hailing is an exception.
lead_paragraph: The word “monopoly” has a distinctly nefarious ring to it, conjuring up images of thuggish industrialists in smoky rooms, scheming to undermine their rivals.

headline: Tom Coughlin Is Expected to Talk With Eagles About Coaching Job
abstract: The former Giants coach is said to have a meeting scheduled with his longtime division rival Philadelphia for an informal discussion about its vacancy.
lead_paragraph: When he stepped down as Giants coach in a news conference on Tuesday, Tom Coughlin said he had not necessarily given up on being a football coach again. The Giants had offered Coughlin a front-office job.

headline: For Republicans, Mounting Fears of Lasting Split
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: In an election campaign with a different, angry feel, the party’s establishment is facing a people’s coup.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party is facing a historic split over its fundamental principles and identity, as its once powerful establishment grapples with an eruption of class tensions, ethnic resentments and mistrust among working-class conservatives who are demanding a presidential nominee who represents their interests.

headline: Mexico Moves to Extradite Drug Kingpin Called El Chapo to the U.S.
abstract: Mexican officials said the process to extradite Joaquín Guzmán Loera could take months, and his lawyers are expected to fight it.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — After long resisting requests from Washington, the Mexican government is moving toward extraditing Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, to the United States to face drug and murder charges there, Mexican officials said on Saturday.

headline: There Are Debates That Even a Playoff Will Never Settle
abstract: From the culmination of World War II until the advent of the Bowl Championship Series, there were only five consensus title winners, so there is plenty of fuel for the fire.
lead_paragraph: Who was the national champion of the 1978 college football season? The world may never know.

headline: A Start-Up That Aims to Bring Back the Farm-to-Vase Bouquet
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Florists', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The locavore movement urges buying food produced in one’s immediate region. Farmgirl Flowers is trying to do the same for flowers.
lead_paragraph: Where Christina Stembel lives in California, she is surrounded by flower farmers, yet 80 percent of the flowers sold in the United States are imported. She is trying to help change that percentage with her San Francisco-based company, Farmgirl Flowers.

headline: Dorthaan Kirk Is Newark’s First Lady of Jazz
abstract: Ms. Kirk, the widow of Rahsaan Roland Kirk, the blind multi-instrumentalist, brings her name, and her connections, to events around the city.
lead_paragraph: Dorthaan Kirk answers to a lot of names.

headline: At Men’s Shows, Vibrant Prints and Inventive Rain Gear
abstract: For fall/winter 2016, Craig Green creatively adorned anoraks, Topman focused on burnt golds and florals — and Alex Mullins was inspired by waiting in the rain.
lead_paragraph: For fall/winter 2016, Craig Green creatively adorned anoraks, Topman focused on burnt golds and florals — and Alex Mullins was inspired by waiting in the rain.

headline: At Westchester Broadway Theater, ‘Show Boat’ With or Without Dinner
abstract: The Westchester Broadway Theater is now offering show-only tickets for selected performances, allowing patrons to skip the included meals at a substantial savings.

headline: In Hartford Schools, Granting Artistic License to Learn
abstract: The Hartford school system has adopted a program that helps students retain reading, writing and arithmetic skills through exposure to mediums like painting, music and dance.
lead_paragraph: Students from Patricia Wakefield’s fifth-grade class at Rawson Elementary School in Hartford positioned their bodies collectively, to form a turtle. One boy sat on the floor to be the turtle’s head, another sat behind him to be the tail, and three children stood on each side and bent at the waist, arms outstretched, to form a bridge-like shell.

headline: When She Gets Into the Kitchen, a Young Woman Gets ‘in the Zone’
abstract: Jaslie Pulinario, who struggles with anxiety and depression, has found an outlet: a pastry class where “There’s nothing bothering me.”
lead_paragraph: Four mental illnesses, three suicide attempts and two absentee parents have left a collective mark on Jaslie Pulinario.

headline: One Town at a Time in Iowa, With Ted Cruz
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz recently set off on a six-day, 28-town bus tour, which ends Saturday, and we sent one of our reporters, Matt Flegenheimer, along with him. Here are some interesting, selected moments from the tour.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz recently set off on a six-day, 28-town bus tour, which ends Saturday, and we sent one of our reporters, Matt Flegenheimer, along with him. Here are some interesting, selected moments from the tour.

headline: As Fatherhood Nears, Love Is the High Score
abstract: When the arrival of a child falls during a big tournament, the world’s best players gladly drop their rackets in order to witness the miracle of birth.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — When Ben Mitchell won his semifinal match at the Australian Open wild-card playoffs in December, his girlfriend’s reaction was underwhelming, and he knew why.

headline: Hillary Clinton Ad Blasts Republicans, Saying Only She ‘Can Stop Them’
abstract: The ad offers Mrs. Clinton as the sole alternative to the Republican candidates, portraying her as a battle-hardened candidate who can take them on.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has released an aggressive new attack ad, fanning fears about the main Republican presidential candidates to make the point that she, and no other Democrat, “can stop them.”

headline: Museum Explores Trials and Triumphs of Female Artists
abstract: Often barred from art schools and life classes, female artists have faced formidable obstacles, as shown in ‘You Go, Girl!,’ an exhibition at the Heckscher Museum.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, “You Go, Girl! Celebrating Women Artists,” the exuberantly titled exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art, looks like many other surveys of American art, especially on Long Island, filled with lots of landscapes and abstracts. But step a little closer — close enough to notice details and read the texts on the walls — and you’ll learn about the difficulties that female artists have faced and how they’ve adapted or triumphed over them.

headline: Myanmar’s Peace Prize Winner and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Aung San Suu Kyi is taking power with silence on the government’s abuse of the Rohingya minority.
lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — SOON the world will witness a remarkable sight: a beloved Nobel Peace Prize winner presiding over 21st-century concentration camps.

headline: A Year of Challenges in the News Business­
abstract: The Times is heading into a news-heavy year. All the while, it will need to keep grappling with the changing media landscape.
lead_paragraph: What is the biggest domestic story of the year ahead for The New York Times? Pretty clearly, it’s the presidential election.

headline: Germany on the Brink
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sex Crimes', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Men and Boys', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: How today’s migration could unsettle Europe for generations.
lead_paragraph: ON New Year’s Eve, in the shadow of Cologne’s cathedral, crowds of North African and Middle Eastern men accosted women out for the night’s festivities. They surrounded them, groped them, robbed them. Two women were reportedly raped.

headline: To Be Happier, Start Thinking More About Your Death
abstract: People who apply the “last-year test” tend to spend more time on the things that give them the most satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: WANT a better 2016? Try thinking more about your impending demise.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Toys', 'Gender', 'Family Leaves', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Scientists, Give Up Your Emails
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Research', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: Publicly funded science should be transparent, despite what some scientists describe as harassment by interest groups seeking access to their records.
lead_paragraph: IN recent months, the Obama administration has been locked in a battle with Representative Lamar Smith of Texas, the Republican chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, who disputes the scientific consensus on climate change.

headline: Obnoxiousness Is the New Charisma
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Smug, mean and in the lead, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz are rewriting the rules of likability.
lead_paragraph: IN a typical presidential campaign, the most successful candidates lay claim to leadership with their high-mindedness. They reach for poetry. They focus on lifting people up, not tearing them down. They beseech voters to be their biggest, best selves.

headline: St. Teresa and the Single Ladies
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Families and Family Life', 'Single Persons', 'Philosophy']
abstract: We still have few models for how to construct a life outside of coupledom.
lead_paragraph: Ávila, Spain — I made the mistake of falling for a man who wants a wife. I should clarify that I do not mean he wants me to be his wife. Men don’t look at me and think I’d make good wife material. Maybe because of how much I swear. But I go to Berlin to see him, he tells me his future plans for marriage and family, and I understand that I am not compatible with those plans. Then I flee, to huddle in the backs of cathedrals, an impulse that I do not fully understand.

headline: Drone Regulations Should Focus on Safety and Privacy
abstract: Recreational and commercial unmanned aircraft can be fun and useful, but clear rules that balance competing rights are needed.
lead_paragraph: Though it would have been inconceivable just a few years ago, among the most popular gifts this past holiday season was the drone. Increasingly coveted by hobbyists and businesses, these devices flew (as it were) off the shelves and into living rooms by the hundreds of thousands.

headline: The Ideological Roots of the Oregon Standoff
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Federal Lands', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The conservative path to today’s land-use fervor.
lead_paragraph: IT is tempting to dismiss the antigovernment gunmen who took control of an animal refuge in Oregon on Jan. 2 as fanatics working at the fringes of American politics. But if the methods used by the rancher Ammon Bundy to seize the federal property were radical, the ideological roots of the operation were somewhat more mainstream.

headline: The Joy of Psyching Myself Out­
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Writing and Writers', 'Research', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: When I left the lab behind for life as a writer, it made the world look weird.
lead_paragraph: IS it possible to think scientifically and creatively at once? Can you be both a psychologist and a writer?

headline: Is the Hoverboard Cool?
abstract: No skateboard of mine ever caught fire.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY visited a big-box electronics store, and decided to test-ride a hoverboard.

headline: As College Football’s Popularity Expands, So Does Its Champions’ Jewelry
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: Compared with the championship rings of days gone by, modern jewelry presented to members of title-winning teams has grown in size to almost comical proportions.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — After Alabama’s athletic director suggested last month that if college athletes were paid, many would spend the money on “tattoos and rims,” he clarified the statement as a “frivolous” reference to a recent scandal at another university. “We hope to educate our student-athletes,” he said, “that those are not wise investments.”

headline: Casely-Hayford: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest designs from Casely-Hayford.
lead_paragraph: The latest designs from Casely-Hayford.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Maybe We’ll Stick With Miniature Golf
abstract: Ted Cruz did not quite promise he would never golf as president, but he suggested he would not golf well.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Leo, Hillary and Their Bears
abstract: On long, grueling odysseys, politics can be a bear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IT’S hard to say which of the three monomaniacal, monumentally grueling quests is the most riveting.

headline: Egypt’s President Turns to Religion to Bolster His Authority
abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who came to power after ousting a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, has increasingly used religion to justify a crackdown on his rivals.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi opened a much-heralded extension to the Suez Canal in August, the official Friday Prayer sermon that week hailed it as a “gift from God.”

headline: Review: Eastern Comforts at Roots Asian Kitchen
abstract: Roots Asian Kitchen has a wide range of offerings, Chinese, Thai, Korean and Japanese, from sushi to crepes.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekday evening, Roots Asian Kitchen, pleasantly dim but for strings of white lights, looked doubly inviting tucked in between the glare of its strip mall neighbors.

headline: At the Supreme Court, a Big Threat to Unions
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Government Employees', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Justice Samuel Alito actively dislikes a longstanding precedent protecting public-union funding. Now he has another chance to kill it.
lead_paragraph: A case the Supreme Court will hear on Monday morning threatens to undermine a four-decade-old ruling that upheld a key source of funding for public-sector unions, the last major bastion of unionized workers in America.

headline: Review: Butcher’s Bar & Grill, a Newcomer in Williston Park
abstract: More commonly known as the BBG, this Long Island steakhouse opened in November and is operated by two former employees of the Old Homestead Steakhouse in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: You might get confused if you’re looking for the Butcher’s Bar & Grill, a steakhouse in Williston Park that opened in November. The restaurant is more commonly known as the BBG, which is the name on the sign you’ll see over the door as you enter.

headline: America and Its Fellow Executioners
abstract: Despite a global trend against capital punishment, the U.S. remains among the top five countries that resort to using the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: Aside from the barbarism and injustice of Saudi Arabia’s execution of 47 men on Jan. 2, the state-sponsored killings — some by beheading — bucked a strong trend against capital punishment in most of the world. According to the annual report of Amnesty International, executions were carried out in 22 countries in 2014, the year covered; there were 25 in 2004. The total number of people known to have been executed also fell. To its disgrace, the United States was still among the five countries that most often used capital punishment — alongside China, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Iraq — but the number of executions in America continued to decline.

headline: How to Fix the Country’s Failing Schools. And How Not To.
abstract: Newark, N.J., had Cory Booker and Chris Christie. Union City had teachers and parents.
lead_paragraph: A QUARTER-CENTURY ago, Newark and nearby Union City epitomized the failure of American urban school systems. Students, mostly poor minority and immigrant children, were performing abysmally. Graduation rates were low. Plagued by corruption and cronyism, both districts had a revolving door of superintendents. New Jersey officials threatened to take over Union City’s schools in 1989 but gave them a one-year reprieve instead. Six years later, state education officials, decrying the gross mismanagement of the Newark schools, seized control there.

headline: Back in Postseason, the Redskins Move On From a Loss That Lingered
abstract: Washington won its division this season behind Kirk Cousins, after a wild-card loss in 2013 in which their star quarterback was injured sent the franchise into disarray.
lead_paragraph: ASHBURN, Va. — For a long time, the Washington Redskins have been trying to exorcise the demons of their last playoff appearance. On Jan. 6, 2013, they were riding a seven-game winning streak, and Robert Griffin III, a rookie sensation and franchise quarterback in the making, was the N.F.L.’s hottest story. The Redskins even grabbed a 14-0 lead in their wild-card game against the Seattle Seahawks before a hobbled Griffin tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee, and his team lost, 24-14.

headline: Review: Cielo, an Italian Restaurant in Wilton, Brims with Variety
abstract: At Cielo, which means sky in Italian, the food commands attention, beginning with the eggplant that comes in a tomato-basil sauce with soft, crusty bread before the meal begins.
lead_paragraph: Emily and Hakan Basaran enjoyed some success with Carpe Diem, their Italian restaurant in New Canaan, but the building that housed it was going to be taken over by a post office, so they looked for a new location.

headline: Two Sides of Gratitude
abstract: Writers react to an essay by Barbara Ehrenreich, “The Selfish Side of Gratitude.”
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to an essay about “gratitude’s rise to self-help celebrity status.”

headline: A Placebo Treatment for Pain
abstract: Our own brains might offer an alternative to addictive opioids.
lead_paragraph: THE crisis of painkiller addiction is becoming increasingly personal: Sixteen percent of Americans know someone who has died from a prescription painkiller overdose, according to a recent Kaiser Family Foundation survey; 9 percent have seen a family member or close friend die.

headline: Tom McCarthy
abstract: The “Spotlight” director on George Saunders, the National and UConn women’s basketball.
lead_paragraph: Tom McCarthy is the director and co-writer of “Spotlight,” a film about the journalists who exposed widespread sexual abuse of children by Roman Catholic priests in Boston and the wider institutional cover-up.

headline: Florence King, Writer Who Wielded an Acerbic Wit, Dies at 80
abstract: Ms. King, who wrote “Misanthrope’s Corner” for National Review, could sting her targets even as she made them laugh.
lead_paragraph: Florence King, a columnist, author and professional misanthrope who was a constitutional crosspatch about all manner of things — in particular those things that smacked in the slightest of what she decried as touchy-feely late-20th-century liberalism — died on Wednesday at her home in Fredericksburg, Va. She was 80.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Look Out Below
abstract: As his two young girls played quietly at his feet, Ted Cruz noted, “Every parent knows, it’s much more dangerous when they’re quiet.”
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Review: At Savannah’s Southern House, Thinking Outside the Skillet
abstract: At Savannah’s in Cortlandt Manor, many entrees are available in half portions, a mercy that the prudent might consider if desserts figure into the plan.
lead_paragraph: At Savannah’s Southern House, the vibe is jolly and hospitable; the setting clean and airy; the cuisine unique in Westchester County. Prices are moderate and portions are huge. The restaurant supplies big cloth napkins for fingers glossy from sauce and deep-fried chicken. Not least, many entrees are available in half portions, a mercy that the prudent might consider, especially if one of the lovely desserts figures into the dinner plan.

headline: Rick Cluchey Dies at 82; Prison Theater Was His Redemption
abstract: After his release from prison, Mr. Cluchey spent time in Europe with Samuel Beckett.
lead_paragraph: Rick Cluchey had never been in a theater — “not even to rob one,” as he was fond of saying — before he was convicted of armed robbery when he was 21 and sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Vikings Coach’s Trouble With Winning: Enjoying It
abstract: A defensive savant with a fiery personality and a salty vocabulary, Mike Zimmer, 59, spent more than three decades as a college and N.F.L. assistant before becoming a first-time head coach.
lead_paragraph: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — Few N.F.L. coaches savor winning less than Mike Zimmer, the second-year head coach of the Minnesota Vikings.

headline: Sibling: Fall 2016
abstract: Sibling’s fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Sibling’s fall 2016 show.

headline: After Assaults in Cologne, Merkel Proposes Tougher Asylum Laws
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s proposal came as the city bristled with violent tension following New Year’s Eve assaults on scores of women.
lead_paragraph: COLOGNE, Germany — As Chancellor Angela Merkel proposed tougher laws regulating asylum seekers in the wake of the New Year’s Eve assaults on scores of women in Cologne, the city again bristled with violent tension on Saturday.

headline: With No Winners in Powerball Drawing, Jackpot Is Expected to Surpass $1 Billion
abstract: The prize was the largest ever for a lottery in United States history, attracting even those who rarely play to plunk down some money.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most affluent neighborhoods of New York City, a pocket on the Upper East Side with stately buildings and ice cream shops where scoops can be as expensive as entrees, a street sweeper waited in line on Saturday to make a modest wager to join the economic ranks of those who live on the blocks where he works.

headline: Rangers Take Unlikely Lead but Are Still Seeking a Turnaround
abstract: The Rangers scored three goals in the third period to erase a 2-0 deficit, but the Capitals tied the game in the final seconds of regulation and sent the Rangers to another loss.
lead_paragraph: After Derek Stepan came agonizingly close to sending the Rangers to their most thrilling win of the season, Alex Ovechkin went to work.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Shares the Load by Shooting Less and Trusting More
abstract: Anthony remains the focal point of the Knicks’ offense, but he may no longer consider shooting the basketball to be his birthright.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The words tumbled from Carmelo Anthony’s mouth, louder and faster than usual.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: The Tattooed Hunk Had a Familiar Face
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas took the opportunity to remind people of a poster that depicted him as a smoking, tattooed hunk, noting, “I don’t smoke cigarettes.”
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Flint Wants Safe Water, and Someone to Answer for Its Crisis
abstract: Officials in Flint, declared to be in a state of emergency, are working to address lead contamination in the water of the city, where 40 percent of residents live below the poverty line.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — A caravan of Genesee County sheriff’s office cruisers snaked its way through the streets here on Thursday, doling out water filters and jugs of water to frustrated and terrified residents who have been trying to cope for more than a year with the public health crisis that has been flowing out of their taps.

headline: China’s Hunger for Commodities Wanes, and Pain Spreads Among Producers
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Commodities', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Mines and Mining', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: For years, China gobbled up metals, crops and fuels for its rapidly expanding economy, and producers aggressively broadened operations to satisfy China’s appetite. Now, all has changed.
lead_paragraph: Chile is expanding its largest open-pit copper mine below the northern desert to dig up 1.7 billion additional tons of minerals, even as metal prices plummet around the globe.

headline: Political Promises
abstract: This puzzle by Patrick Merrell is really funny. Please don’t get me fired by arguing in the comments.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We here in the United States are coming up on an election year, on the off chance that you have recently been residing in an underground bunker with no access to media or the Internet. So it’s not surprising that we have been given a chance to practice listening with a straight face to all of the promises we can expect to hear as the presidential campaign comes to its ultimate, teeth-rattling conclusion.

headline: Christopher Shannon: Fall 2016
abstract: Christopher Shannon presents looks for next fall.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Shannon presents looks for next fall.

headline: All-Bedouin Tech Company Hints at Shift in Israel
abstract: Companies like Sadel Tech and government initiatives are aiming to bring more young Arabs into the technology work force.
lead_paragraph: ABU QREINAT, Israel — A resident of a ramshackle sprawl of shacks and houses in the Negev Desert, Rabaa Al-Hawashleh is an unlikely worker in Israel’s high-tech industry.

headline: Separatists in Catalonia Select Leader to Avoid Vote
abstract: The agreement ends more than three months of feuding among separatist parties over who should lead the next regional government.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Catalan separatist parties on Saturday reached an 11th-hour agreement to replace the leader of the region, Artur Mas, and avoid new elections that risked derailing Catalonia’s push to secede from the rest of Spain.

headline: A Tumultuous Housing Program in Algeria
abstract: A government housing program in Algeria is one of the most ambitious in the region, but critics say it is creating as many problems as it solves.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — The air was festive on a recent morning as families moved into their new apartments, courtesy of the Algerian government. Women’s shrieks of joy sounded from the balconies as children tried out the swings beneath a large banner that declared, “Our aim, Algiers, a capital without slums.”

headline: Cubans’ Difficult Journey Through Central America
abstract: A circuitous route from the island to the United States has been blocked as Nicaragua, an ally of Cuba, refused to let a large wave of migrants pass from Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: A circuitous route from the island to the United States has been blocked as Nicaragua, an ally of Cuba, refused to let a large wave of migrants pass from Costa Rica.

headline: Cubans, Fearing Loss of Favored Status in U.S., Rush to Make an Arduous Journey
abstract: Worried that an advantage in immigration law may end as the United States restores relations with their country, many Cubans have rushed off the island, only to be stalled in Central America.
lead_paragraph: LA CRUZ, Costa Rica — In Gretchen López’s slumber, during whatever winks of sleep she could get in a crowded open air shelter, she dreamed she was sending money to her mother in Cuba to renovate her crumbling house and buy delicious food.

headline: Republican Candidates, Minus Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, Play Nice at Poverty Forum
abstract: Six Republican candidates — without the two front-runners, who were campaigning in Iowa — offered a substantive and surprisingly cordial discussion on poverty.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — After a week filled with attack ads and months of caustic debates, six of the Republicans running for president gathered in the same place on Saturday and showed they can, after all, get along.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
abstract: My head talks again.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Hubbard and I will be on This Week tomorrow. I believe that we’re talking about The Force Awakens. Also Marco Rubio’s boots. Possibly some economics.

headline: Insurers Say Costs Are Climbing as More Enroll Past Health Act Deadline
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Many people wait until they become ill or need medical services to sign up under the Affordable Care Act, driving up costs broadly, insurers have told federal health officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eager to maximize coverage under the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration has allowed large numbers of people to sign up for insurance after the deadlines in the last two years, destabilizing insurance markets and driving up premiums, health insurance companies say.

headline: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
abstract: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The urban attacks are suddenly coming at a dizzying pace — five in the first week of January alone. Three were relatively simple even if massive bombings, but in the others, Taliban gunmen entered important cities, seized buildings and hostages when they could, then set off their explosives vests when capture seemed imminent, sometimes after hours of fighting.

headline: Chiefs End 22-Year Run of Playoff Futility by Thrashing the Texans
abstract: Kansas City followed its script to late season success: Its defense picked off four Brian Hoyer passes and recovered one of his two fumbles, while its offense capitalized on the miscues.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The last time the Kansas City Chiefs won a playoff game, Joe Montana was their quarterback, Michael Jordan wanted a tryout with the Chicago White Sox, and Sonic the Hedgehog was all the rage. The team’s owner, Clark Hunt, was 28 years old.

headline: ‘Girls’ Creator Lena Dunham Visits Iowa on Tour to Support Hillary Clinton
abstract: In Iowa City and Des Moines, Ms. Dunham made a feminist pitch to packed audiences of mostly young women about why they should vote for Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — When Hannah Horvath, the lead character of the hit HBO series “Girls,” arrived in Iowa during the show’s fourth season, the Brooklyn transplant was struck by the quietude, the cheap real estate and the fresh produce that is pervasive in America’s heartland. The infatuation faded, however, and she soon quit and returned home.

headline: Sean Penn Met With ‘El Chapo’ for Interview in His Hide-Out
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Fugitives', 'Prison Escapes', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Before he was captured, Joaquín Guzmán Loera met with the actor in his jungle hide-out for seven hours in October and spoke about his empire, Donald Trump and the movie business for Rolling Stone.
lead_paragraph: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, started out in business not long after turning 6, selling oranges and soft drinks. By 15, he said in an interview conducted in a jungle clearing by the actor and director Sean Penn for Rolling Stone magazine, he had begun to grow marijuana and poppies because there was no other way for his impoverished family to survive.

headline: Remembering Hadiya Pendleton
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Oak Creek, Wis, Shooting (2012)', 'Tucson Shooting (2011)', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: During a State of the Union address in 2013, the president introduced Nate and Cleo Pendleton, parents of Hadiya, who was killed in Chicago by gun violence at age 15.
lead_paragraph: During a State of the Union address in 2013, the president introduced Nate and Cleo Pendleton, parents of Hadiya, who was killed in Chicago by gun violence at age 15.

headline: Long Dormant, the First Super Bowl Is Resurrected
abstract: The stitched-together version, which NFL Films has pieced together from footage in its archive, will air as a three-hour extravaganza on Friday.
lead_paragraph: NFL Network will show Super Bowl I on Friday night, which should please and surprise anyone who thought copies of the game had been lost, erased or turned to video dust.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: T-Shirts and Votes Must Be Earned
abstract: One of Ted Cruz’s new favorite jokes ties Hillary Clinton to Chicago’s reputation for voting high jinks.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Historian Group Rejects a Resolution Condemning Israel
abstract: Members of the American Historical Association, the nation’s largest organization for professional historians, rejected a resolution condemning what was characterized as Israel’s interference with the right to education for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The movement among some scholars to condemn Israel suffered a setback on Saturday, when members of the American Historical Association, the nation’s largest organization for professional historians, rejected a resolution condemning what was characterized as Israel’s interference with the right to education for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.

headline: Donald Trump Ramps Up Attacks on Ted Cruz’s Eligibility
abstract: At two rallies in Iowa, Donald J. Trump again questioned whether Ted Cruz was a “natural-born citizen,” while Mr. Cruz suggested the attack was being made out of desperation.
lead_paragraph: OTTUMWA, Iowa — Donald J. Trump sharply escalated his rhetoric about Senator Ted Cruz’s eligibility to be president on Saturday, suggesting that because he was born in Canada there were unanswered questions about whether he met the constitutional requirement to be a “natural-born citizen.’’

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: The Trip Ends
abstract: Ted Cruz asked attendees to do three things: vote for him, volunteer and pray daily until the Feb. 1 caucuses.

headline: Woman Raped by 5 Men in Brooklyn Playground, Police Say
abstract: The woman, 18, was walking with her father on Thursday night in Brooklyn when they were attacked by a group of men with a gun, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A young woman was walking with her father in a Brooklyn playground on Thursday night when five men approached them, pulled out a gun, ordered her father to leave and then took turns raping her, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Spencer Stone, Airman Who Halted Attack on Train, Will Attend State of the Union
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Sergeant Stone was one of those who subdued a gunman on a train in France, and he had a second near-death experience in Sacramento, where he was stabbed outside a bar.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Staff Sgt. Spencer Stone of the Air Force was driving to work on a stormy morning a few days ago when a White House aide phoned with an invitation to join the first lady on Tuesday for President Obama’s last State of the Union address to Congress.

headline: Sharon Lu, Bryte Moa-Anderson
abstract: The couple work in Los Angeles, where she is a doctor and he is a bank vice president. They met in the lounge of a New York hotel.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sharon Marie Lu and Bryte Jason Moa-Anderson were married Jan. 9 at the Scripps Seaside Forum, an event space in San Diego. The ceremony was officiated by Leif Moa-Anderson, the groom’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

headline: Brigid Harrison, Paul Meilak Jr.
abstract: The bride is a professor and author; the groom is a retired police detective.
lead_paragraph: Brigid Callahan Harrison and Paul Meilak Jr. were married Jan. 9 at the National Arts Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Jay Pinkerton, a Catholic priest with CITI Ministries, officiated.

headline: Carolyn Grossman and Adam Meagher: On One Knee, in an Unfinished Subway
abstract: The groom kneeled down in the construction site, wearing a hard at and orange vest, to propose to his bride, who was dressed exactly the same way.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Jill Grossman and Adam Patrick Meagher were married Jan. 9 at the Charles Ringling Mansion at New College of Florida in Sarasota, from which the bride graduated. Hope C. Michelson, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Carrol Chang and David Osei: A Life Begins in a Cardboard House
abstract: The groom built a cardboard house for his beloved, and attached a proposal to it.
lead_paragraph: Carrol Jung Chang and David Kodjo Owusu-Agyeman Osei were married Jan. 6 in Meridian Hill Park in Washington, under a feature of the District of Columbia’s marital code that now allows couples to join themselves.

headline: Alison Gordon, Kyle Gugerty
abstract: The couple met in 2010 while working at the Jewish Community Center of Greater Washington.
lead_paragraph: Alison Brooke Gordon, the daughter of Glenda R. Gordon and Kenneth A. Gordon of Boca Raton, Fla., was married there Jan. 9 to Kyle Eugene Gugerty, the son of Francine A. Farber of Bethesda, Md., and Michael J. Gugerty of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Bennett Miller officiated at the Addison, an event space.

headline: Jill Bloomfield, Benjamin Margolis
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at a break-the-fast meal after Yom Kippur.
lead_paragraph: Jill Bloomfield and Benjamin David Margolis were married Jan. 9 by Rabbi Alan Litwak at the Eden Roc Resort in Miami Beach.

headline: Sharon Csontos, Donald Myers Jr.
abstract: The couple met at a birthday party for the groom, held on Valentine’s Day in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Esther Csontos and Donald Nicholas Myers Jr. were married Jan. 9 at the Ashford Estate, an event space in Allentown, N.J. Erika Barrett, a cousin of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Nara Lee, Byron Lichtenstein
abstract: The bride, a lawyer, and the groom, who works for a venture capital firm, met at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Nara Lee and Byron Thornton Lichtenstein were married Jan. 6 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina M. Townes, a staff member at the New York City clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Danielle Mazandi, Robert Cooper
abstract: The bride works for New York Public Radio, and the groom is an investment bank executive.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Alexandra Mazandi and Robert Lawrence Cooper were married Jan. 9 at St. Aloysius Church in Washington. The Rev. Kenneth Meehan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Victorious Steelers Twist Knife Handed to Them by Bengals
abstract: Bengals fans suffered through the league’s longest playoff drought before witnessing their team’s stirring comeback and subsequent collapse Saturday, which resulted in the Steelers’ 18-16 victory.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — This city awoke Saturday by peeking out from under its covers, one wary eye at a time. Was it safe to come out? Did it even want to?

headline: Review: In a New Book, Pope Francis Calls Mercy Essential
abstract: “The Name of God Is Mercy” renews the pope’s call for a Roman Catholic Church that responds to a wounded humanity.
lead_paragraph: During his training as a Jesuit priest in the 1960s, Jorge Mario Bergoglio — who, decades later, would become Pope Francis — spent three years teaching literature and psychology in his native Argentina. He taught the classics, like “El Cid,” but when his students expressed an interest in authors like Antonio Machado and Fernando de Rojas, he taught them, too, as a way of nurturing a love of literature in his pupils. He also encouraged his students to write, and had his friend Jorge Luis Borges read their stories.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Pics or it didn’t happen,” said the pop star and actor Nick Jonas, who, backstage after the Topman Design show at London Collections Men, had found a Wi-Fi connection and hopped onto his Instagram account to share a video with 5.6 million of his nearest and dearest.

headline: New Management Settles in at Huntsman, the Pride of London’s Savile Row
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: The hedge fund manager Pierre Lagrange took over the company amid a swirl of press, not all of it kind. But now he focused on expanding business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A stone’s throw from the flagships of various global luxury behemoths on New Bond Street, the gentlemen’s tailors of Savile Row remain steadfast in their devotion to tradition and understatement. Bells tinkle in mahogany doorways to sound a customer’s arrival; swaths of checks, wool and herringbone from the finest mills in Britain are piled high; and cutters sit hunched in basements and poky back rooms to fulfill orders for wealthy clients around the world.

headline: In Madrid, Hope Has a New Name: Zidane
abstract: The briskest trade at Madrid’s Santiago Bernabéu Stadium was for merchandise with Zinedine Zidane’s name printed on the back. The old player, new coach and messiah — Zidane — is back.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — These are surreal times in Spain. Barcelona and Real Madrid ran in nine goals between them against opponents they are expected to beat nine times out of 10.

headline: El Chapo Faces Array of Drug Charges in United States
abstract: Joaquín Guzmán Loera has never appeared in an American court, though after his capture, Mexico indicated it might cooperate after years of requests by the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1995, a federal grand jury in San Diego charged a little-known Mexican drug trafficker named Joaquín Guzmán Loera and 22 underlings with creating a cocaine ring that stretched from Southern California to New Jersey.

headline: A Less Prominent Career, a More Primary Parent, and Satisfied
abstract: Taking the lead role in parenting, and supporting a spouse’s career, isn’t necessarily a compromise.
lead_paragraph: These days, when she judges the moment right, my wife has taken to praising me as “a great dad” in the mixed company of family and friends. I’ve practiced an aw-shucks shrug for the occasion. I suspect many modern dads are paid similar compliments for doing things moms have done for eons.

headline: 1941: Roosevelt Proposes Defense Bill
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Roosevelt introduces a defense bill in Congress in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt’s much-discussed bill for converting the United States into an ‘‘arsenal for democracy’’ by giving him unlimited peace-time power to ‘‘sell, transfer, exchange, lease, lend or otherwise dispose of’’ the promised ‘‘billions of dollars’’’ worth of warplanes, ships, guns and tanks to Great Britain, China, Greece and the Latin-American republics to fight off Axis aggression, was introduced simultaneously in both houses of Congress today [Jan. 10].

lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 men’s collection from Margaret Howell.

headline: Cuomo Proposes Higher-Education Initiative in New York Prisons
abstract: Mr. Cuomo announced a plan to offer college courses to inmates across the state in an effort to reduce recidivism.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It was nearly two years ago that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo floated a plan for the state to pay for college courses for inmates. But it sank in the face of withering opposition from critics who mocked Mr. Cuomo’s initiative as “Attica University” and Republican members of the state’s congressional delegation who argued that New York should put “kids before cons.”

headline: James Long: Fall 2016
abstract: Designs from James Long’s fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Designs from James Long’s fall 2016 show.

headline: 1966: Shastri Dies After Signing Kashmir Pact
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The prime minister of India dies after signing the Tashkent Declaration in 1966.
lead_paragraph: TASHKENT, U.S.S.R. — Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India died here early today of a heart attack, hours after he and President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan had signed an agreement aimed at bringing peace to Kashmir. The tiny, 61-year-old Indian leader collapsed after he and Marshal Ayub had attended a farewell banquet given by Soviet Premier Alexei Kosygin to celebrate their agreement.

headline: 1920: Versailles Treaty Comes Into Force
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Treaty of Versailles enters into full force after an exchange of ratifications in 1920.
lead_paragraph: The Treaty of Versailles was signed on June 28, 1919, ending, in principle, the state of war between the Allies and Germany. The treaty came into full effect after six months of negotiations in Paris. Below, an excerpt from an analysis on the agreement by the European edition of The New York Herald:

abstract: The Sibling and Coach collections, which showed in London, were inspired by everyone from Grace Jones to Bruce Springsteen.
lead_paragraph: The Sibling and Coach collections, which showed in London, were inspired by everyone from Grace Jones to Bruce Springsteen.

headline: Bernie Sanders Makes Strong Showing in New Polls
abstract: Hillary Clinton holds a three-point lead over Senator Bernie Sanders in Iowa and Mr. Sanders is up by almost the same margin in New Hampshire according to a new set of surveys from NBC/The Wall Street Journal/Marist.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton holds a three-point edge over Senator Bernie Sanders in Iowa, a tightening of the race with roughly three weeks until voting begins, according to a new set of surveys of likely voters from NBC/The Wall Street Journal/Marist.

headline: The Larger, but Quieter Than Bundy, Push to Take Over Federal Land
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Federal Lands', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A growing Republican-led movement is pushing the federal government to hand the states millions of acres of Western public lands — as well as their rich stores of coal, timber and grazing grass.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Ken Ivory, a Republican state representative from Utah, has been roaming the West with an alluring pitch to cattle ranchers, farmers and conservatives upset with how Washington controls the wide-open public spaces out here: This land is your land, he says, and not the federal government’s.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Mexican pork chops, whole roasted cauliflower and more ways to win dinner in the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Diligent Courting of Evangelicals Pays Off in Iowa
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Endorsements', 'Home Schooling', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Mr. Cruz’s success in consolidating evangelical Christian voters in Iowa reflects how he has methodically pursued the state’s Christian right.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — On Sunday, Pastor Bradley Cranston stood at his pulpit in Burlington, Iowa, and, citing Exodus 18:21 (“select out of all the people able men who fear God ... as leaders”), endorsed Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, urging his parishioners to also consider voting for him.

headline: Princess Cristina’s Tax Fraud Trial Set to Begin in Spain
abstract: The sister of King Felipe VI was indicted last year after an investigation into whether her husband and others had embezzled public money.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Princess Cristina of Spain is scheduled to appear in court on Monday, accused of tax fraud as part of a corruption case centered on money embezzled from public contracts that is bringing a member of the country’s royal family to trial for the first time.

abstract: The awards season begins with the Golden Globes. CBS’s empowered women return in new episodes. And “Je Suis Charlie” looks back at the 2015 terrorist attack on Charlie Hebdo.

lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 designs from Pringle of Scotland.

headline: London’s Men’s Wear Shows Revel in the Club Scene
abstract: E. Tautz had roller-disco nostalgia; Sibling, Grace Jones-style boxing; and, at the MAN showcase, Charles Jeffrey’s Dalston parties.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Under intermittent rain and the occasional occlusion of cement-colored skies, London Collections Men began the international fall fashion season for men’s wear on Friday, so hot on the heels of the new year, joked Dylan Jones, the editor of British GQ and the L.C.M. chairman, that “we like to think of it as a continuation of New Year’s Eve.”

headline: Nets Dismiss Hollins and Reassign King; Owner Vows to Instill ‘Winning Culture’
abstract: The team made the moves in the midst of its worst season since it moved to Brooklyn from New Jersey. The assistant Tony Brown will be the interim coach.
lead_paragraph: The Nets, in a midseason shake-up after years of reckless spending and trades, announced Sunday that the team had fired Coach Lionel Hollins and reassigned General Manager Billy King.

headline: Hospital Aided by Doctors Without Borders Is Bombed in Yemen
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: At least four people were killed and the Shiara Hospital, in northern Yemen, near the border with Saudi Arabia, suffered severe damage.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A hospital in northern Yemen supported by the medical charity Doctors Without Borders was struck by ordnance early Sunday, killing at least four people and causing several buildings to collapse, the organization said in a statement.

headline: Strong Showing for ‘The Revenant’ at Box Office
abstract: The Leonardo DiCaprio period film had an impressive opening, but was second for the weekend behind “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.”
lead_paragraph: A savvy 20th Century Fox marketing campaign combined with the raw star power of Leonardo DiCaprio helped drive “The Revenant” to a grizzly-size $38 million in weekend ticket sales, adding sizzle to a soft box office season for prestige films.

headline: Sold on a View, New Year’s Revelers Fall to a Forgery Scheme
abstract: After buying counterfeit tickets to a Times Square comedy club, some who thought their ball-drop vantage point was secure were left out in the cold.
lead_paragraph: Getting into the LOL Times Square Comedy Club should not be difficult: Go to Times Square, and when a person with an LOL sign or identification badge approaches you and asks, “Hey, do you like comedy?” say yes. You’re in. Make your way to the club on Seventh Avenue and head upstairs to the windowless bar and black-box theater crowded with tables for two. Enjoy the show.

headline: An Uncertain New Chapter in Sinaloa, Home State of ‘El Chapo’
abstract: To many residents in Sinaloa, where Joaquín Guzmán Loera was captured, he was and remains El Señor (the Lord), a mythical figure who inspires as much respect as fear.
lead_paragraph: LOS MOCHIS, Mexico — The capture of the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera stunned the world and earned President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico a much-needed round of applause. Yet here in the narcotics kingpin’s home state, Sinaloa, the news landed with a thud.

headline: Young, Mexican and Ready to Raise Their Political Voices
abstract: Even before Donald J. Trump began his presidential campaign by demonizing Mexican immigrants, young people with ties to the country were becoming politically active and urging others to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Bundled up against the cold, Janet Perez walked down Willis Avenue in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx this month, politely approaching parents waiting for their children after school.
