headline: A Primer on the N.F.L. Relocating a Team to Los Angeles
abstract: The league’s owners will meet this week and are expected to vote on proposals for relocation. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has talked about returning to the Los Angeles area almost from the moment the Raiders and the Rams left after the 1995 season. All the talk may end when the 32 owners meet Tuesday and Wednesday in Houston, where they are expected to vote on proposals that would allow one or two teams to return to the nation’s second-largest market. Here is a primer:

abstract: Dispatches from the red carpet and backstage — and thoughts from our reporters, editors and critics watching the show.

headline: In Final State of the Union Address, Obama Aims to Set Tone for ’16 Campaign
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Mr. Obama hopes to use his last address as president to frame the debate about who should replace him and where the country should go from here.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the final time, President Obama will mount the rostrum in the House chamber on Tuesday to deliver a State of the Union address. But this time, aides said, he will not bring with him a long list of proposals that will languish in Congress — after all these years, a victory of experience over hope.

abstract: If the Iran nuclear deal, his health care law and the financial recovery are deemed successes, Barack Obama could be seen as a near-great president.
lead_paragraph: Republicans say that President Obama is too passive on foreign policy. A few Democrats see him that way when it comes to politics. The president, however, is planning an aggressive finale.

headline: Ellen Stovall, Three-Time Cancer Survivor and Advocate, Dies at 69
abstract: Ms. Stovall led a grass-roots campaign to make cancer treatment and prevention, and the search for a cure, the top health care and research priorities in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Stovall, a three-time cancer survivor and, as the president of the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship, a prominent advocate for patients dealing with a host of problems during and after their cancer treatment, died on Tuesday in Rockville, Md. She was 69.

headline: Hillary Clinton Attacks Bernie Sanders Over Gun Control
abstract: Mrs. Clinton also brushed aside criticisms by Donald J. Trump and other Republicans about her husband’s past scandals as several presidential candidates hit the talk show circuit Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton pressed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on his gun control record during her appearance on “Face the Nation” on CBS on Sunday, and brushed off “dead end” attacks from Donald J. Trump and other Republicans about Bill Clinton’s past scandals.

headline: Obama’s Guests at State of the Union Include Syrian Refugee and Mexican Immigrant
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Also invited is Jim Obergefell, the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case legalizing gay marriage, and others who illustrate America as “inclusive and compassionate.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Syrian refugee, a former illegal immigrant who went on to serve in the United States Army and the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case last year legalizing same-sex marriage will be among the official guests on Tuesday as President Obama delivers his final State of the Union address.

headline: With Ball’s Lace Facing Wrong Way, Seahawks Win by a Thread
abstract: On a potential game-winning kick against the Seahawks, Vikings kicker Blair Walsh was presented with a problem: The laces were facing him. He missed the 27-yarder, and Seattle escaped with a victory.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — There is only one lace, threaded through 16 holes, on an official N.F.L. game ball. When a holder sets the ball for a kicker, the rule of thumb is “laces out” — meaning the holder should rotate the ball to put the lace on the side facing the goal posts. Something about the way that white strip meets the kicker’s foot can make the ball fly in unpredictable directions.

headline: Mohammad Javad Zarif: Saudi Arabia’s Reckless Extremism
abstract: Until now, writes Iran’s foreign minister, Tehran has acted with restraint toward Riyadh’s provocations.
lead_paragraph: THE world will soon celebrate the implementation of the landmark agreement that resolves the unnecessary, albeit dangerous, crisis over Iran’s nuclear program. All parties hoped, and continue to believe, that the resolution of the nuclear issue would enable us to focus on the serious challenge of extremism that is ravaging our region — and the world.

headline: Suspect Shot by Paris Police Tied to German Migrant House
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The German police said the man, who approached a Paris police station with fake explosives last week, had lived in a house for migrants in Germany.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The man shot to death by the police in Paris last week as he approached a police station with a meat cleaver and fake explosives was a petty criminal who used multiple identities and who lived in a house for asylum seekers in Germany’s most populous state, the German police said on Sunday.

headline: Illumina Creating Company to Develop Early-Stage Cancer Detection Test
abstract: Illumina, a maker of DNA sequencing machines, said it was forming the company to develop a blood test that would work for any type of cancer, but some experts see risks.
lead_paragraph: Some people see it as the holy grail in oncology — a simple blood test that can detect any kind of cancer at an early stage, when it is easiest to treat and possibly cure.

headline: Catalonia’s New Leader Vows to Continue Secessionist Drive
abstract: Carles Puigdemont told the regional Parliament, “This isn’t a time for cowards, nor for rashness, nor for renunciations.”
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The new leader of the regional government of Catalonia told lawmakers on Sunday that he would carry out a plan to separate the region from the rest of Spain.

headline: Yahoo’s Brain Drain Shows a Loss of Faith Inside the Company
abstract: Faced with the failure of her efforts to reignite growth at Yahoo, Marissa Mayer is now turning to the opposite strategy: cutting jobs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, the glamorous, geeky Google executive hired to turn around Yahoo in 2012, used to inspire hope in Yahoo’s work force just by visiting the cafeteria for ice cream and mingling.

headline: Review: In Donna Uchizono’s ‘Sticky Majesty,’ Two Queens and Their Handmaidens
abstract: Evoking a rigid court hierarchy, the work requires its five dancers to sustain muscular tension for long periods.
lead_paragraph: As its title suggests, the choreographer Donna Uchizono’s “Sticky Majesty” features a pronounced hierarchy. There are only five dancers, all women, divided into groups, one of two and one of three. All have solo opportunities, but it’s the two (Molly Lieber and Heather Olson) who dominate and ordain, and the three (Hadar Ahuvia, Sarah Iguchi, Meg Weeks) who are courtiers or attendants.

headline: Review: ‘Au Revoir, Pierre,’ a Celebration of Boulez
abstract: This benefit concert, organized at short notice after Mr. Boulez’s death, featured some of New York’s most dedicated interpreters of the conductor-composer.
lead_paragraph: Organized at short notice after the death of Pierre Boulez on Tuesday, “Au Revoir, Pierre,” a tribute concert on Saturday at Le Poisson Rouge, showed off the qualities long associated with Mr. Boulez and his music: seriousness, precision, experimentation.

headline: Review: American Realness Illuminates Racial Identities With 3 Dance Works
abstract: Jaamil Olawale Kosoko, Ligia Lewis and keyon gaskin performed mostly solo pieces at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: “Where may I kiss you?” You don’t expect to hear that question while waiting around a theater lobby for a performance to begin, especially not from a veiled stranger. But Keyon Gaskin established a certain intimacy early on in his 40-minute solo, “its not a thing,” at Abrons Arts Center on Friday. Cloaked in black with a scarf draped over his face, Mr. Gaskin approached individual guests, inquired about their fears (“When were you afraid today?”) and offered a kiss, planted in black lipstick.

headline: Kate del Castillo, Actress Tied to ‘El Chapo,’ Set Up Sean Penn Meeting
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Social Media']
abstract: Ms. del Castillo, a Mexican television star, is believed to have brokered the meeting between the drug lord, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, and Mr. Penn last year.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Last fall was a busy time for the Mexican television star Kate del Castillo. She became an American citizen, advertised her new tequila and appeared tirelessly to promote her new film “The 33,” a retelling of the story of the trapped Chilean miners in 2010, in which she stars alongside Antonio Banderas as his valiant wife.

headline: Review: In ‘Dog Days,’ a Family Clawing for Survival
abstract: David T. Little and Royce Vavrek’s opera at the Skirball Center depicts a desperate household in a post-apocalyptic landscape.
lead_paragraph: It’s not surprising that “Dog Days,” the utterly bleak and musically original if heavy-handed opera by the composer-librettist team of David T. Little and Royce Vavrek, has won widespread attention since its acclaimed 2012 premiere. With its boldly eclectic score and powerful libretto, “Dog Days” tells an apocalyptic story unstintingly. The director Robert Woodruff’s gritty staging opened on Saturday at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, presented by the center and Beth Morrison Projects as part of the Prototype Festival. At the end, the courageous cast and creative team received lusty bravos from many in the hall.

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Hotel,’ a Pair Weighs Whether Someone Checks Out for Good
abstract: What at first seems a love triangle turns quickly into something darker in Donnacha Dennehy and Enda Walsh’s work, at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: What was it that the Eagles sang about the ominous Hotel California? “You can check out any time you like, but you can never leave”?

headline: Review: Dez Mona’s ‘Sága,’ Acoustic Time Travel in a Song Cycle About Roots
abstract: The Belgian band teamed with Baroque Orchestration X for a sensual performance at National Sawdust.
lead_paragraph: For decades pop music has looked to global influences to enrich its sound. But a few years ago the Belgian band Dez Mona, which had previously been known for its theatrical jazz-tinged glam rock, sought inspiration from a largely uncharted continent: the distant past. On Saturday evening the group presented the fruits of that expedition, “Sága,” at National Sawdust in Williamsburg as part of this winter’s Prototype Festival. For this theatrical song cycle about roots and longing, Dez Mona teamed up with the Belgian ensemble Baroque Orchestration X, a group dedicated to performing new music on period instruments like the harpsichord, theorbo and viola da gamba. The result was an evening of unfailingly gorgeous music that felt exotic and familiar at once.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Gun Control in America
abstract: President Barack Obama made a push for tighter laws to curb gun deaths in America last week, announcing plans for executive actions that would increase background checks for gun buyers.
lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama made a push for tighter laws to curb gun deaths in America last week, announcing plans for executive actions that would increase background checks for gun buyers. He also wrote an Op-Ed in The Times addressing the politics surrounding the issue.

headline: Wave After Wave of Defenders Help Alabama Roll On
abstract: The Crimson Tide, allowing just 13.4 points per game, have turned their surplus of talent into intensely specialized platoons, allowing them to counter any particular offensive look.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Dillon Lee was perhaps the most valuable defensive player of the Cotton Bowl on Dec. 31, amassing six tackles, one for a loss, and an interception in Alabama’s 38-0 demolition of Michigan State.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 11
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘A Funny Thing Happened,’ Insights into What Made the Musicals Sing
abstract: “Songs From the Road to Broadway” opened the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics and Lyricist’s series, with Kathleen Marshall hosting and directing.
lead_paragraph: Only aficionados of Broadway musical history are aware that “Getting to Know You,” the classic teacher-student introductory song from “The King and I” that seems set in stone, had two earlier incarnations. Originally written for Nellie Forbush to sing in “South Pacific,” it was titled “Suddenly Lovely,” then renamed “Suddenly Lucky,” before it was dropped and later equipped with new lyrics for “The King and I.”

headline: Super Bowl 50 Commercials Are Expected to Have a Lighter Tone
keywords: ['Super Bowl', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Football', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: TV ads often reflect the mood of the times, but many criticized those that aired during last year’s game as gloomy. This year, despite turmoil in the news, the spots are likely to be more fun.
lead_paragraph: For this year’s Super Bowl, marketers want to have fun again.

headline: Review: ‘The Offending Gesture’ Takes On Foreign Policy’s Barking Madness
abstract: Mr. Wellman’s play at the Connelly Theater uses Hitler’s dog, among other tools, to criticize international relations today.
lead_paragraph: Mac Wellman’s experimental plays tend to go by in a mystifying blur, and “The Offending Gesture” at the Connelly Theater is no exception. But this blur is particularly enjoyable, a concoction involving Hitler’s dog, a Finnish guy’s dog, Iraq and the absurdities of international relations. Oh, and musical cats.

headline: Eaten Away
abstract: The return of Howard Barkin.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Howard Barkin — one of the nicest people in the world, who just happens to be able to solve crossword puzzles freakishly fast — he had made his constructing debut in The New York Times by showing us all the ways you can insert a CHECK after the words in familiar phrases.

headline: Ultra Embraces Streaming Singles to Keep a Dance Genre Booming
abstract: “Nothing is more cumbersome than a piece of plastic when all you want is the music,” said Patrick Moxey, founder of the electronic dance music label Ultra Music.
lead_paragraph: The disco ball was spinning like a glitter moon and a pair of go-go dancers grooved in neon wigs at a Brooklyn nightclub during the recent 20th-anniversary party of Ultra Music, one of the record labels behind the explosive growth of dance music in the United States.

headline: Clemson’s Inspired Run Starts With Dabo Swinney
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']

abstract: Afghanistan is the world’s biggest opium producer, and there is evidence that the country’s drug problem is worse than government officials acknowledge.
lead_paragraph: CAMP PHOENIX, Afghanistan — The bridges that span the Kabul River in the heart of this capital city have long harbored their own special hell. For several years, hundreds of heroin addicts lived beneath the bridges, on river banks carpeted with used needles that crunched underfoot — as hollow as the countless grant proposals that never produced solutions.

headline: Billie Allen, Actress Who Bridged a Racial Gap, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Allen appeared on and off Broadway when New York theater was not especially welcoming to black performers, and she helped integrate network television.
lead_paragraph: Billie Allen, an actress who appeared on and off Broadway when New York theater was not especially welcoming to black performers, and who helped integrate network television, making frequent appearances on “The Phil Silvers Show” in the 1950s and in commercials in the 1960s, died on Dec. 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: With Freddie Gray Murder Trial Set to Begin, Hints of a ‘Rough Ride’
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: It is a high-stakes, high-profile prosecution that would have been unimaginable here a year ago, before Mr. Gray’s death in police custody.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When Freddie Gray emerged from a police transport van with the spinal cord injury that killed him, the talk on the streets was that he had been given a “rough ride” intended to hurt him. Now the veteran police officer who drove that van is about to stand trial on a murder charge, and that street talk may finally be put to a courtroom test.

headline: With Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a Distant Owner, the Nets Have Lost Their Way

headline: G.M. Trial, Bank Earnings and December Retail Numbers
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Production']
abstract: General Motors will face a trial over defective ignition switches; bank earnings season begins; and the Commerce Department will release retail sales data.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Monday will face a trial in the first of six so-called “bellwether” cases in 2016 over deadly defective ignition switches in its vehicles. The bellwethers, frequently used in product liability litigation when many people may have similar claims, could help G.M. and lawyers for the plaintiffs work out trial strategies or help determine whether to settle. The first case going to trial involves Robert Scheuer, who was injured when his 2003 Saturn Ion crashed into a tree in May 2014. Of the six bellwethers, three were picked by lawyers for the plaintiffs and three by the defense. —Danielle Ivory

lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The Golden Globes worked hard on Sunday to live up to its reputation as the most unserious of Hollywood’s major awards stops, as stars spewed profanity from the stage, the host swigged beer, many presenters appeared discombobulated and A-list dinner guests disengaged early on.

headline: Taking Control After a Tumultuous Childhood
abstract: The only one of four sisters to graduate from high school, Jasmin Gonzalez is mindful of being a positive role model to her siblings and to her young son.
lead_paragraph: Before she even knew what the word “advocate” meant, Jasmin Gonzalez was doing it for herself and her three sisters. All four were taken away from their drug-addicted parents and placed into foster care when Ms. Gonzalez was 3 years old. Memories of abuse by her first foster parents remain vivid.

headline: Review: Shedding Skins in Motus’s Genre-Blurring ‘MDLSX’ at La MaMa
abstract: In this play, at La MaMa Downstairs, Silvia Calderoni takes on many guises and expounds on the inadequacy of our vocabulary.
lead_paragraph: Silvia Calderoni must be made of mercury, or some improbably liquid element that has yet to be discovered. Surely no body of mortal flesh could undergo the quicksilver transformations achieved by this remarkable performer in “MDLSX,” a perceptions-scrambling work from the Italian revolutionary theater troupe Motus.

headline: Amid Flashy Australian Compatriots, Samantha Stosur Quietly Stays the Course
abstract: Though eclipsed by headline-grabbing young stars, Samantha Stosur is the only Australian to have been ranked in the top 10 in singles within the last nine years, peaking at No. 4 in 2011.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — The tempestuous Nick Kyrgios, with his whip of a forehand and meticulously razored etchings in his eyebrows and hair, will command some attention next week as a local in the Australian Open. As will another Aussie, Bernard Tomic, a slowly reforming wild child whose arrest in Miami in July barely derailed a season in which he broke into the top 20 for the first time. And as long as he lasts in the tournament, the elder statesman Lleyton Hewitt will be a crowd favorite in what he has said will be his final tournament.

headline: Golden Globes Red Carpet: Couture Without the Cliché
abstract: Women rejected old-fashioned mermaid gowns, princess frocks and sex bomblet slithers in favor of an entirely more no-nonsense aerodynamic ease.
lead_paragraph: All the talk about women’s equality in Hollywood over the last year, all Jennifer Lawrence’s openness about paycheck politics and Carrie Fisher’s attack on ageism and #askhermore, all the expressed desire for female power to be recognized and the old order of things to change, seems to have had an effect in at least one, perhaps unexpected, area of the industry: the red carpet.

headline: Steady and Unselfish, Knicks Are Winning the Games They Used to Lose
abstract: The Knicks added more evidence of their progress to the pile with a 100-88 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: Signs of the Knicks’ gradual progress have come in different forms. Coach Derek Fisher has shortened his rotation. Kristaps Porzingis has spent more time plying his trade at the center position. And Carmelo Anthony has shown a willingness to cede more of the spotlight, going so far as to — gasp — pass up a look at a potentially winning shot last week.

headline: El Chapo’s Arrest Prompts Mixed Feelings Among Mexicans in New York
abstract: The news of the arrest of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, drew a sigh in New York City’s Mexican enclaves, but for a number of different reasons.
lead_paragraph: “People come in saying, ‘How sad! They got him!,’” said Gloria Calixto on Sunday, from behind the counter of Guadalupita II, a corner store in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, that was bursting with piñatas and sugar-dusted pastries, chilies and Virgin Mary figurines.

For a few hours, politics was forgotten as we cheered on the Alabama Crimson Tide to its 38-0 triumph over the Michigan State Spartans.

keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Editorials']

headline: The Obama Boom
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Dire warnings from Republicans about the effect of President Obama’s policies on employment have simply not come true.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember the “Bush boom”? Probably not. Anyway, the administration of George W. Bush began its tenure with a recession, followed by an extended “jobless recovery.” By the summer of 2003, however, the economy began adding jobs again. The pace of job creation wasn’t anything special by historical standards, but conservatives insisted that the job gains after that trough represented a huge triumph, a vindication of the Bush tax cuts.

headline: Rwanda’s Entrenched President
abstract: President Paul Kagame backers abroad should pay more attention to the country’s worsening human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: During a New Year’s Day speech, President Paul Kagame of Rwanda pretended to be humbled by the outcome of a constitutional referendum that paved the way for him to seek a third term and, conceivably, rule until 2034.

headline: Governors Get Smarter on Medicaid
abstract: Some leaders from both parties have seen the wisdom of not rejecting generous federal matching funds.
lead_paragraph: Republican and Democratic governors in several states that have refused to expand their Medicaid programs are now seeking to do so, but will need approval from Republican-dominated legislatures. Even if they are not moved by humanitarian concerns to improve health care for their poorest citizens, recalcitrant legislators should at least see the folly of rejecting extremely generous matching funds. The federal government will pay 100 percent of the cost for newly eligible enrollees in 2016 and 95 percent in 2017, phasing down to 90 percent in 2020 and subsequent years.

headline: Focus on Illegal Guns
abstract: Regulations such as safety features and registration are needed to make a dent in gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Late Thursday night a madman approached a police cruiser in Philadelphia and fired at least 11 times at the officer in the vehicle, striking him three times in the left arm.

headline: When Philosophy Lost Its Way
abstract: Once upon a time, acquiring wisdom and being a good person were intimately linked. The modern university changed all that.
lead_paragraph: The history of Western philosophy can be presented in a number of ways. It can be told in terms of periods — ancient, medieval and modern. We can divide it into rival traditions (empiricism versus rationalism, analytic versus Continental), or into various core areas (metaphysics, epistemology, ethics). It can also, of course, be viewed through the critical lens of gender or racial exclusion, as a discipline almost entirely fashioned for and by white European men.

headline: For One Night, China’s Great Hall of the People Reverberates With Music
abstract: On a cold night in Beijing, China’s colossal legislative building held a concert by a group of the country’s leading classical and popular musicians.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On a bone-chilling night in the Chinese capital, a giant Communist red star chandelier glistened amid the galaxy of ceiling lights as thousands of people filed into the main auditorium of the Great Hall of the People. But this was not your typical gathering in the colossal building on the western edge of Tiananmen Square. There were no solemn-faced bureaucrats in dark suits, no reports on economic growth targets to be delivered.

headline: In First Round of N.F.L. Playoffs, Home Is Where the Heartbreak Is
abstract: The Redskins’ lopsided loss to the Packers capped a winless weekend for the four home teams — something that had never happened in the wild-card round under a system that began in the 1990 season.
lead_paragraph: LANDOVER, Md. — Kudos to the Washington fans who made the trip on Sunday to FedEx Field, ready to cheer their beloved, oft-beleaguered Redskins.

headline: Does That Mutt Have a MetroCard? Subway Riders Are Divided on Dogs

headline: Studying Sharks’ Social Lives to Expose Their Friendly Side
abstract: Researchers in Australia are studying the social behavior of sharks to help battle the misconception that sharks are largely solitary killing machines.

headline: Israel Faces New Brand of Terrorism, This Time From Young Settlers
abstract: Israel’s domestic security agency sees a group of young extremists from settlement outposts as being behind a wave of violence against Palestinians.

They want “to live simply, to build their own things and to commune with God,” said the father, Gedalia Meyer.

headline: ‘The Expatriates,’ by Janice Y. K. Lee
abstract: Living abroad, a novel’s American women face new expectations.
lead_paragraph: A female, funny Henry James in Asia, Janice Y. K. Lee is vividly good on the subject of Americans abroad. “The Expatriates,” her second novel, is set like her first, “The Piano Teacher,” in Hong Kong, and the two books taken together are a rich education in an almost century of cruelty, exploitation, deep pockets and good parties in the city — a setting that becomes a complicated character in its own right. In her new book, Lee observes an affluent community of contemporary Westerners, but more specifically, those who “crossed over into that other country of motherhood,” another foreign land requiring expatriation.

headline: ‘The Cosmopolites: The Coming of the Global Citizen,’ by Atossa Araxia Abrahamian
abstract: The global trade in citizenship serves many functions.
lead_paragraph: In 2008 the United Arab Emirates came up with a novel solution to their bidoon “problem” — the presence of thousands of stateless persons within their territories. Most bidoon descend from families who resided there long before the creation of the U.A.E.; many were from nomadic tribes and simply failed to register as nationals at the time. Yet they have been denied citizenship. That status would give them access to the myriad benefits accorded full members of this wealthy oil state — from free health care and education, to a guaranteed income, subsidized utilities, a marriage bonus, land and an interest-free house loan. Instead, they are categorized as illegal immigrants.

headline: Signs of the ‘Human Age’
abstract: A team of scientists argue Earth has now entered a distinct age from the Holocene epoch, due to the colossal changes humans have made since the mid-20th century.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Arguments Over Requiring Union Members to Pay Dues
abstract: In a case that Justice Elena Kagan has said could “radically restructure the way workplaces across” the United States “are run,” the court will hear from both sides of a case brought by 10 California teachers who say they have a First Amendment right not to pay fees to a union.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court will hear a single argument on Monday, instead of the usual two. It will last 80 minutes, instead of the usual 60. And it will feature four lawyers: one for 10 California teachers who say they have a First Amendment right not to pay fees to a union; one for the union, which says it must be able to insist that nonmembers pay for their fair share of the costs of collective bargaining; and ones for California and federal government, which say the union is right.

headline: Silence Is the Enemy for Doctors Who Have Depression
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Doctors', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Too many physicians are suffering, and medicine is a profession in which admitting a problem carries a stigma.
lead_paragraph: In my first year of training as a doctor, I knew something was wrong with me. I had trouble sleeping. I had difficulty feeling joy. I was prone to crying at inopportune times. Even worse, I had trouble connecting with patients. I felt as if I couldn’t please anyone, and I felt susceptible to feelings of despair and panic.

Anderson — would live-stream his fall men’s show exclusively on Grindr, the gay social-networking app, has been the whispered, and then not-so-whispered, talk of the first days of men’s fashion week here. “Now there’s a show that would’ve looked good on Grindr,” one showgoer cracked to another about a collection that featured men in cutout trousers and one very visible pair of thong underwear.

headline: Popular Approval For Stronger Gun Safety, But Scant Optimism

abstract: A majority of Americans support the president’s actions on guns. Will that be enough to make gun safety an issue in the coming election?
lead_paragraph: In his final year in office President Obama is choosing to buck the politics of the gun in America. Though the gun lobby’s supposed power at the ballot box has never been clearly established, Democrats feared it enough to avoid the gun issue for decades, especially once they lost control of the House in 1994 after roiling opponents by enacting the stronger gun controls of the Brady law.

headline: Manchu, Former Empire’s Language, Hangs On at China’s Edge
abstract: Descendants of the settlers, who embarked in 1764 on a trek that took them from the northeast to the west, struggle to keep a nearly vanished tongue alive.
lead_paragraph: QAPQAL XIBE AUTONOMOUS COUNTY, China — Loyal to the core and prized for their horsemanship, several thousand Manchu soldiers heeded the emperor’s call and, with families and livestock in tow, embarked in 1764 on a trek that took them from northeastern China to the most distant fringes of the Qing dynasty empire, the Central Asian lands now known as Xinjiang.

headline: 1916: Draft Is Likely In Great Britain
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Draft is likely to be voted in Great Britain in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The debate on the second reading of the Military Service Bill opened in the House of Commons today [Jan. 11] with every indication that Mr. Asquith’s proposals for limited compulsory service will be adopted by a very large majority. After a meeting of the Irish Nationalists today, Mr. Redmond has announced in Parliament the withdrawal of Irish opposition to the Bill, and the Government’s only serious opponents are now a section of the Labor Party and a few Radicals. Even in regard to the attitude of organized labor, a settlement of differences seems probable.— The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 12, 1916

headline: The Other Side of Billionaires
abstract: Not all of the super-rich are smug and selfish.
lead_paragraph: Re “Privilege, pathology and power” (Jan. 2-3): Paul Krugman implicates all billionaires as smug, selfish, pathological and Republican. Hence they are without empathy, out of touch, and use their money and power to influence elections. What about George Soros, Eli Broad, David Geffen and Tom Steyer? Are they without gobs of money, ego or the desire to inject their own “statist” principles into elections? Have they not sworn to spend countless millions in an effort to “re-shape” America? Mr. Krugman would do better to write about both sides of the billionaires’ battle.

headline: Lessons, and Parallels, in Jeb Bush’s Failed Run for Governor

He was my soundtrack for strutting up and down 8th Street, in [Greenwich] Village.”

headline: 1941: Germany and Italy Join Forces
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The first joint action by German and Italian airmen is carried out in 1941.
lead_paragraph: The first joint action by German and Italian airmen in the Mediterranean was announced here today [Jan. 11] by the high commands. The combined forces, the military communiqué said, attacked units of the British fleet in the Sicilian Channel, which, between Sicily and North Africa, has been a major factor in the success of the British operations from Sidi Barrani to Tobruk, in Libya. Direct hits were scored on several warships, it was said. The attack on the British warships, the communiqué said, was made at about noon yesterday by torpedo and dive-bombing planes.  — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 12, 1941

This has its advantages, because soft broccoli can be mashed with the back of a spoon, and the broken-down vegetable is very nice as a sauce with pasta.

headline: From One New Brand, Unisex Shirts and Pottery

lead_paragraph: In the airy reception room of a townhouse in London’s Chelsea, Arthur Yates has arranged a rack of vibrant unisex shirts next to a display of hand-painted milk urns. The two elements are unlikely halves of the same project: Bruta, his fashion and homeware brand that launched quietly last year. “There wasn’t some master plan,” he recalls. “I was just doing them in my bedroom with help from my girlfriend. And now it’s growing into something a little bit more serious, and people are taking interest.”

headline: Michael B. Jordan Shrugs, and Jennifer Lopez Shimmies

lead_paragraph: Man, are the Golden Globes after-parties ever a gloriously sprawling corporate free-for-all. They fill the Beverly Hilton’s parking lots and stretches of open space: giant tents with indoor-outdoor carpeting, D.J.s, twinkly lights, cater waiters, security guards, updos and swag. It’s like being aboard a very strange, very expensive cruise ship.

lead_paragraph: Hours before the Golden Globes began Sunday, the ceremony’s accountants waltzed across the red carpet carrying briefcases handcuffed to their wrists. The cases held the award winners’ names, and one of the accountants said to a few reporters, “I think people will be surprised.”

headline: U.S. Repatriates Saudi Held at Guantánamo Since 2002
abstract: The Saudi, Mohammad al Rahman al Shumrani, was captured in late 2001 and arrived at the wartime prison on Jan. 16, 2002, five days after it opened.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the 14th anniversary of the arrival of the first Afghanistan war detainees at the American naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the military announced Monday that it had repatriated a Saudi who had been held there without trial since the prison’s earliest weeks.

headline: Donald Trump Has Commanding Lead in Latest New Hampshire Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Donald J. Trump is handily leading the field in New Hampshire in the Republican presidential race, according to a new Monmouth University poll, running far ahead of his closest competitors, Senator Ted Cruz and Gov. John Kasich.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is handily leading the field in New Hampshire in the Republican presidential race, according to a new Monmouth University poll, running far ahead of his closest competitors, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.

headline: Whitney Museum Acquires Major Work by Archibald Motley
abstract: The piece, “Gettin’ Religion,” a museum curator said, “will come to be regarded as one of the icons of the Whitney’s collection.”
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced that it had acquired its first work by Archibald Motley, an under-recognized 20th-century painter whose stark portraits and tumultuous dance-club scenes helped define the Chicago and Harlem Renaissances.

headline: Cuomo Won’t Face Federal Charges Over Moreland Ethics Panel
abstract: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, had been investigating the shutdown of the commission, which was created with promises of cleaning up corruption.
lead_paragraph: An inquiry by the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s interference with an anticorruption panel that he created and abruptly shut down has concluded there was not enough evidence to bring a criminal case to court against him.

headline: Progress in Jimmy Carter’s Quest to End Guinea Worm Disease
abstract: Only 22 cases of the disease were reported in 2015, a significant drop from the 126 cases reported in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Only 22 cases of Guinea worm disease were reported in 2015, the Carter Center announced last week, a significant drop from the 126 cases reported in 2014.

headline: Restaurants Counter Outside Cakes With Cakeage Fees
abstract: Owners and chefs debate whether to add the fee for cakes brought in by customers.
lead_paragraph: Cakes are meaningful, so it is no surprise that people sometimes bring them along to a restaurant as a celebratory coda to a special meal. And it’s no surprise that restaurants don’t always like it.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Stars Hit the Parties
abstract: Cate Blanchett, Katy Perry, Ricky Gervais, Madonna and Sean Penn hit the Golden Globes parties.
lead_paragraph: Cate Blanchett, Katy Perry, Ricky Gervais, Madonna and Sean Penn hit the Golden Globes parties.

headline: Iowa Poll Finds Ted Cruz and Donald Trump in Tight Race
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas remain locked in a tight race for the lead in Iowa less than three weeks before the state’s caucuses, according to a new survey from Quinnipiac University.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas remain locked in a tight race for the lead in Iowa less than three weeks before the state’s caucuses, according to a new poll.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Stars Hit the Parties
abstract: Cate Blanchett, Katy Perry, Ricky Gervais, Madonna and Sean Penn hit the Golden Globes parties.
lead_paragraph: After the Globes Globes, celebrities kept the night going at numerous after-parties. Cate Blanchett arrived at one hosted by the Weinstein Company and Netflix. See the photos.

headline: Shire Pays High Price for Baxalta
abstract: The deal brings Shire scale in rare diseases, but offers few cost synergies, plenty of risk and relies on revenue growth that may be optimistic.
lead_paragraph: Shire’s merger with Baxalta looks a little expensive.

headline: For French Ski Resorts, a Scramble to Offset Snow Deficit
abstract: Given the importance of winter tourism, resorts are trying to keep visitors entertained in a world where they can always just hop a flight to a beach.
lead_paragraph: CHAMONIX, France — Bright sunshine and mostly brown slopes welcomed skiers to the Chamonix-Mont-Blanc Valley just before New Year’s Eve, a sight that hardly came as a shock.

headline: Story Approval by Drug Lord? Times Editors Discuss Rolling Stone Case
abstract: Sean Penn’s interview with the drug kingpin El Chapo was a “great get” of a story, but Times editors would have walked away from the interview, they say.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:25 p.m.

headline: Pouring a Foundation on Mars
abstract: Researchers devise a building material that could be made from materials on the planet.
lead_paragraph: If humans were to attempt to colonize Mars, transporting construction materials would be difficult and expensive. Researchers at Northwestern University have proposed an alternative, a kind of concrete that can be made with materials from Mars itself: sulfur and Martian soil. The sulfur concrete is almost as strong as conventional concrete, durable in acid and salt environments, and recyclable, the researchers say. Sulfur has been used as a bonding agent since ancient times. In the 17th century, sulfur was often used to anchor metal to stone.

headline: Nets’ Owner Takes ‘Full Responsibility’ for State of the Team
abstract: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the team’s owner, said he had underestimated the pressures of competing in New York, calling it “maybe my most important lesson.”
lead_paragraph: Many of the elements of a typical Mikhail D. Prokhorov news conference were on display on Monday: the deadpan humor, the rhetorical showboating, the stubborn optimism and the incongruous talk of N.B.A. championships.

headline: When Financial Talk Turns Personal
abstract: One comment from a friend or even a stranger about a major purchase can consume you, but you shouldn’t let it.
lead_paragraph: Recently, my family needed a new vehicle. I’ve always wanted a truck, and I knew we would get tons of use out of it. Could I have found a cheaper vehicle? Sure. But I knew we could afford the truck, so after lots of careful thought, we decided to buy it.

headline: Children’s Book Awards Honor Diversity
abstract: The awards, given by the American Library Association, were announced on Monday at the group’s midwinter conference in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Matt de la Peña’s illustrated children’s book, “Last Stop on Market Street,” about a boy’s reflections during a bus ride to a soup kitchen with his grandmother, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature, a rare honor for a picture book.

headline: In Retreats, Start-Ups Find a Way to Recharge Workers’ Batteries
keywords: ['Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Business Travel', 'Workplace Environment', 'Motivation and Incentive Programs']
abstract: As human resource departments look to reward employees without paying more, the idea of team-building through offsite gatherings is growing in popularity.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Reeves, the co-founder and chief executive at the payroll and benefits management start-up Gusto, rented a house for a week in 2013 with his roughly 10 colleagues for what he called a “workation.”

headline: Human Traffickers Found to Exploit U.S. Visas and Data-Sharing Failures
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Human Trafficking', 'Visas', 'Foreign Workers', 'Prostitution', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Forced Labor']
abstract: Two federal agencies were faulted for failing to stop the use of fiancé and work visas to bring people to the United States for forced labor or prostitution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Human traffickers used fiancé and work visas to bring dozens of victims to the United States, exploiting a lack of data sharing between immigration offices within the Department of Homeland Security, according to the agency’s internal watchdog.

headline: How David Bowie Changed Wall Street
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Intellectual Property', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Music', 'Royalties']
abstract: “Bowie bonds” inspired a wave of esoteric asset-backed securities deals based on intellectual property.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie was known for his ability to reinvent himself. But he also helped inspire a pocket of Wall Street that tries to create money out of weird things like billboard rental income, cellphone tower lease payments and literary or film libraries.

headline: Supercrown Pairs Coffee With Everything in Bushwick
abstract: Also, horseradish from Long Island; discussing and eating Jewish deli food; mint from the Pacific Northwest; a gin manual; and sausage from California.
lead_paragraph: Darleen Scherer, who founded Gorilla Coffee in Park Slope, Brooklyn, sold her interest last year and has gone on to open Supercrown Coffee Roasters, a combination cafe, retail shop and coffee roaster with a behemoth of a German roasting machine positioned in full view. The coffees include some from Indonesia, like Sulawesi, with rewarding depth and balance. And she has staked out some unusual territory in coffee drinks. There’s a decadent coffee milkshake made with Ample Hills ice cream, and once the weather warms, a Scandinavian-style blend of coffee and lemonade that may be an acquired taste. To eat, there are pastries from Brooklyn purveyors like Bien Cuit and bialys, onion and prosciutto, made by Roberta’s and topped with poached eggs: Supercrown Coffee Roasters, 8 Wilson Avenue (Flushing Avenue), Bushwick, Brooklyn, 347-295-3161; supercrown.coffee.

headline: ISIS Attack on Baghdad Mall Kills 17
abstract: A gun battle raged for nearly two hours in the Iraqi capital, but most of the casualties were caused by a car bomb and two suicide bombers.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Islamic State militants attacked a shopping mall in eastern Baghdad on Monday evening, killing at least 17 people and turning the neighborhood into an urban war zone at rush hour, with helicopters hovering overhead and snipers taking positions on nearby rooftops.

headline: Sarah Howe Wins T.S. Eliot Poetry Prize
abstract: Sarah Howe’s “Loop of Jade” is the first debut collection of poetry to win the T.S. Eliot Prize.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sarah Howe, a British poet born in Hong Kong, was awarded the 2015 T.S. Eliot Prize for her debut collection “Loop of Jade” on Monday evening.

headline: Ratings Drop for Golden Globes
abstract: About 18.5 million people tuned in to NBC’s broadcast, down about 5 percent from last year’s total.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Sunday night’s off-color Golden Globes, filled with bleeps and controversial jokes, did not result in better viewership.

headline: Top Suspect in Paris Attacks Had Traveled to Britain, Officials Say
abstract: Abdelhamid Abaaoud had visited Britain despite being named in an international arrest warrant for a foiled plot, and appeared to have taken pictures of London landmarks, officials said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The man believed to be the coordinator of the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris had previously traveled undetected to Britain despite being named in an international arrest warrant for his role in a foiled plot in Belgium in early 2015, European law enforcement officials said Monday.

headline: Teenager Attacks Jewish Teacher in Marseille With a Machete
abstract: The teenager told the French police that he had carried out the attack in the name of God and the Islamic State, according to the Marseille prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A teenager attacked a Jewish teacher with a machete in the southern French city of Marseille on Monday, and afterward told the police that he had carried out the attack in the name of God and the Islamic State, according to the Marseille prosecutor.

headline: 1955-65 | The Last Decade of New York’s Old Penn Station
abstract: A look at Pennsylvania Station’s past uncovers treasures in The Times’s photo archive.
lead_paragraph: Any chance to explore the history of old Pennsylvania Station in mid-Manhattan underscores the wealth of The Times’s photo and clipping archive. We’ve come to call it the “lively morgue” for a very good reason: Its holdings, numbering in the millions (though stored under precarious conditions in the basement of an abutting office building), don’t just illuminate the past but breathe life into it. They warrant a regular feature on Tumblr.

headline: ‘Sickout’ by Detroit Teachers Closes Most Public Schools
abstract: The district ordered 64 of its about 100 schools closed on Monday after teachers called in sick in an effort to bring attention to dilapidated buildings.
lead_paragraph: Most of Detroit’s public schools closed Monday in the face of a “sickout” by teachers who protested what they called unsafe, crumbling, vermin-infested and inadequately staffed buildings, and the failure of state lawmakers to agree on a plan to rescue a system teetering on the edge of insolvency.

headline: Adele Cedes Billboard’s Singles Chart to Justin Bieber After 10 Weeks
abstract: Adele’s “25” is still the top-selling album of the week, adding an additional 164,000 copies sold to its tally for a seventh week at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Adele may still be ruling album sales, but this week she yields her reign over Billboard’s singles chart to Justin Bieber.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men in Fur
abstract: In London, Coach 1941, Burberry and Katie Eary all showed collections featuring oversized shearlings and minks.
lead_paragraph: Blame it on Chewbacca’s return to the big screen — or the continuing nostalgia for all things ‘70s — but fur is quite literally huge this season. Oversized, overfluffed shearlings and minks were standout pieces at the men’s shows in London this weekend, especially in collections from Katie Eary, Burberry and Coach 1941. Though intimidating on their own, paired with urban staples such as track jackets, sweatshirts and sneakers, they seemed tough rather than flashy. Here’s hoping winter 2016’s climate actually merits wearing one.

headline: Manu Ginobili Made Spurs Assistant a Believer Back in Italy
abstract: Ettore Messina signed Ginobili at age 21 to play for him in Italy. Messina is now an assistant for the Spurs as Ginobili, at 38, winds down his N.B.A. career.
lead_paragraph: Trending on the Internet recently was a video of Manu Ginobili assisting on a fast-break basket, while lying down on the job.

headline: State Retirement Plans
abstract: A reader says workers who don’t have traditional pension plans through their employer could benefit from a state-sponsored plan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Five Fashion Hairstylists on How to Create Casual Buns
abstract: The classic style is back for spring 2016, but why wait until then to try it? Experts share how to get their runway looks at home.
lead_paragraph: “Pull your hair off your face.” In the annals of maternal admonishments, the refrain is all too common.

headline: Nailing the National Anthem: Who’s Done It Best?
abstract: Many people still laud Whitney Houston’s performance of “The Star-Spangled Banner” before the Super Bowl in 1991. Do you have a favorite rendition?
lead_paragraph: No matter what surprises are in store in the national college football championship game on Monday night (referred to from here on out as “the Natty”), one thing is for certain: Like just about all other sporting events in this country, it will begin with a rendition of the national anthem. On Monday night, the anthem will be sung by Ciara, who is known for hits like “Goodies” and “Oh.”

headline: Index-Card Financial Advice From Readers
abstract: Our collection of money advice written on index cards yielded an outpouring of submissions from both New York Times readers and financial experts.
lead_paragraph: Our collection of money advice written on index cards yielded an outpouring of submissions from both New York Times readers and financial experts.

headline: When a Big Baby Isn’t So Big
abstract: Research showed that mothers who believed they were having large babies were nearly five times more likely to ask for a scheduled C-section.
lead_paragraph: Katy Clemens wanted to have a natural, drug-free childbirth. Then an ultrasound suggested her baby would weigh 11.5 pounds, and her doctors insisted she schedule a cesarean section.

headline: Facts & Figures: The Rise of Independents
abstract: Last year was the fifth in a row in which 40 percent or more Americans identified themselves as independents rather than Democrats or Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Last year was the fifth in a row in which 40 percent or more Americans described themselves as political independents, according to a Gallup poll. In 2015, 42 percent of those polled said they were independents; 29 percent identified as Democrats and 26 percent as Republicans.

headline: David Bowie’s Style, Through the Years
abstract: The iconic singer, producer, actor and artist died Sunday at age 69. Here, some of his most idiosyncratic and indelible looks.
lead_paragraph: The iconic singer, producer, actor and artist died Sunday at age 69. Here, some of his most idiosyncratic and indelible looks.

headline: Lawsuit Over Keystone Pipeline
abstract: A League of Conservation Voters official calls TransCanada’s suit against the United States “beyond the pale.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Diplomats Meet in Pakistan in Effort to Restart Peace Talks With Taliban
abstract: In Islamabad, representatives of the United States, China, Pakistan and Afghanistan met to try to lay the groundwork for talks with the insurgents.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Senior diplomats from Pakistan, Afghanistan, China and the United States met in Islamabad on Monday to try to lay the groundwork for a new round of peace talks with the Taliban.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
abstract: London and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: London and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 11, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from London, Ukraine, France and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from London, Ukraine, France and South Africa.

headline: Unhappy New Year at Broadway Box Office
abstract: After a record-breaking week, grosses were down considerably.
lead_paragraph: The winter doldrums have begun on Broadway.

headline: A Personalized Diet, Better Suited to You
abstract: With the rise of personalized approaches to nutrition, often based on genetic testing, broad standards seem less and less relevant.
lead_paragraph: In what has come to feel like a twice-a-decade mea culpa, the federal government last week released another revision of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, this time urging many of us to consume less sugar and less protein. The new recommendations may well influence nutrition labeling, school lunches and government assistance programs.

headline: Beyond Monty Hall
abstract: The Monty Hall Problem is an absolute classic probability challenge. Can you solve these twists by Laura Feiveson?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle is twist on a stunning, counter-intuitive classic — the Monty Hall Problem, made famous by Marilyn vos Savant in her “Ask Marilyn” column in Parade Magazine. Here was the problem in its original form as sent in by a reader to Ms. vos Savant:

headline: Hillary Clinton Confronts Bernie Sanders as Polls Show Her Lead in Iowa Narrowing
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Taxation']
abstract: Facing new pressure from Bernie Sanders in Iowa, Hillary Clinton warn Iowans that, if elected president, he would put their health insurance in the hands of Republican governors and raise taxes on the middle class.
lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Iowa — Facing new pressure from Senator Bernie Sanders in Iowa, Hillary Clinton confronted him in direct terms on Monday, warning Iowans that if elected president, he would put their health insurance in the hands of Republican governors and raise taxes on the middle class.

headline: National Championship 2016 Highlights and Analysis
abstract: Alabama beat Clemson, 45-40, to win the 2016 College Football Playoff national championship game.

headline: Revolt in Governing Party Shakes Tunisian Politics
abstract: The Islamist party Ennahda is the dominant faction again after the president’s secular party lost members who protested his son’s post as party chief.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s main Islamist party, Ennahda, re-emerged as the dominant faction in Parliament on Monday as mass resignations from President Béji Caïd Essebsi’s secular party continued, largely to protest his son’s position as party chief.

headline: This Land Is Our Land
abstract: A New York reader registers an objection.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Arrival of Electric Light
abstract: A Times article on April 15, 1858, out of Havana mentioned the technology, but it would be two decades before Thomas Edison’s name appeared.
lead_paragraph: Since the early 19th century, inventors had been tinkering with various methods of using electricity to produce light. The New York Times first wrote of the technology on April 15, 1858. That day, “Our Own Correspondent” in Havana described celebrations of Holy Week that included “an electric light” cast across the harbor “revealing the name of Queen Isabel.”

headline: Chris Christie Makes Steady Rightward Shift on Guns
abstract: Governor Christie, who first won office saying he would toughen laws regulating firearms, has used his recent record in New Jersey to recast himself as a champion of the Second Amendment.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic attack ad from 2009 showed Chris Christie’s face beside a row of bullets, branding him as an ally of the National Rifle Association. A narrator warned that unlike Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat who was then New Jersey’s governor, Mr. Christie “stands with the N.R.A. and opposes banning armor-piercing rifles.”

headline: White House Increases Outreach for State of the Union
abstract: The White House is leaving no platform uncovered for the president’s last State of the Union address, unveiling a new Snapchat account and live encounters this week on NBC and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will make one of his final prime-time addresses to the country on Tuesday, and the White House is leaving no platform uncovered in its effort to magnify its message.

headline: Ringling Circus Elephants
abstract: File footage of elephants performing in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey circus.
lead_paragraph: File footage of elephants performing in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey circus.

headline: Review: In ‘City of Thorns,’ Ben Rawlence Tells a Refugee Camp’s Story
abstract: In this book, Mr. Rawlence spotlights nine people to describe life in a Kenyan refugee camp he calls the biggest in the world.
lead_paragraph: In English, Dadaab means “the rocky hard place,” a translation of such freakish metaphorical precision that Ben Rawlence, the author of “City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World’s Largest Refugee Camp,” has the sense to use it with great restraint. Stamped on a dusty desert plain in Kenya, Dadaab — the camp of the book’s title — is home to a half million inhabitants. Most are Somalis who have fled famine or terror in their home country (sometimes both), but others come from Sudan, Rwanda, Uganda, Ethiopia. What unites them all is that they live in a state of suspension seemingly interminable and intolerable.

headline: At the Golden Globes, Earrings From Another Era
abstract: Kirsten Dunst, Cate Blanchett and Kate Winslet all chose dangling accessories that were (or just looked) over a century old.
lead_paragraph: Several actresses chose to wear dangling earrings to last night’s Golden Globes, but the standout trend were the vintage (and vintage-inspired) pieces that brought Old Hollywood — in some cases, really old Hollywood — back to the red carpet. Kirsten Dunst chose Fred Leighton diamond pendant earrings that date from the 19th century, while Cate Blanchett matched her Givenchy fringe gown with a pair of Tiffany & Co. platinum diamond and pearl earrings from 1915. And Kate Winslet’s Neil Lane diamond earrings are a contemporary design heavily influenced by the Art Deco period.

headline: When Good Medicine Mixes With Bad
abstract: Two sides of health care swirl together, almost impossible separate. And missteps lead occasionally to beneficial results.
lead_paragraph: We like to think that bad and good medicine are easy to distinguish. A huge construct of education, licensure and regulation depends on that single, simple premise. And yet, perhaps more often than not, the good and the bad swirl together like cream poured into coffee, almost impossible to separate.

headline: Mexico’s Recapture of El Chapo
abstract: Readers discuss whether to extradite the drug lord and Sean Penn’s interview in Rolling Stone.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Shadowhunters,’ a Teenage Fantasyland Roamed by Demon Killers
abstract: This series on Freeform, until now the ABC Family channel, centers on a bored student who discovers a spooky new identity.
lead_paragraph: To be a teenager is to be bored. Boredom is a natural part of development: to grow restless with the cosseted world you were raised in and thus prepare to separate from it.

headline: Peach App for the iPhone Stakes a Social Media Claim
abstract: The app has quickly become an object of fascination, as people share animated GIFs, line drawings, songs and cake. Yes, cake. But will it last?
lead_paragraph: The world may have plenty of social media platforms already, but a new one called Peach captured the fancy of early adopters and technology bloggers over the weekend.

headline: David Bowie’s Effect on Music Videos
abstract: David Bowie had an indelible effect on music videos as a storytelling method. From “John, I’m Only Dancing” in 1972 to “Lazarus” just last week, Bowie’s experimentation helped make music videos what they are.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie had an indelible effect on music videos as a storytelling method. From “John, I’m Only Dancing” in 1972 to “Lazarus” just last week, Bowie’s experimentation helped make music videos what they are.

headline: Two Teams in Search of Sports-Obsessed Brooklyn
abstract: Does Brooklyn have the passion, population and demographics to fall for a professional franchise? We may not know until the Nets and the Isles start winning.
lead_paragraph: We’ve watched Jackie Robinson steal home a hundred times on those old reels, and breathed all the loving poetry about the Bums of Brooklyn. It is an idyllic vision, the rainbow merger of community and sports team, an interracial Eden.

headline: Catalan Independence Bid Looms Over Spain’s Coalition Efforts
abstract: Catalonia’s status will be impossible for the leaders of the country’s main parties to avoid in determining what kind of government will emerge.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — If it appeared for a moment that Catalonia’s drive to secede from Spain would implode along with the political fortunes of its leader, it has not turned out that way.

headline: Head of Poland’s Governing Party Leads a Shift Rightward
abstract: Jaroslaw Kaczynski holds no elective office, but as leader of the governing Law and Justice Party he is the primary force in a rightist consolidation of authority.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s new right-wing government has moved rapidly in its first months in power to pack more sympathetic judges on to the nation’s highest court and blunt its ability to overturn new laws. It has announced plans to put the choice of the country’s top prosecutor directly in the hands of party leaders. It has granted a presidential pardon to a former security chief who has been appealing a three-year sentence for abuse of office stemming from the governing party’s last time running the country.

headline: Princess Cristina of Spain Stands Trial in Tax Fraud Case
abstract: Cristina, the sister of King Felipe VI, is the first member of Spain’s royal family to stand trial, in a case that has become a major embarrassment for the Spanish monarchy.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Princess Cristina became the first member of Spain’s royal family to stand trial on Monday, in a tax fraud case that has become a major embarrassment for the country’s monarchy.

headline: Panel Reasserts Mammogram Advice That Triggered Breast Cancer Debate
abstract: A medical panel issued an update to its guidelines Monday, but still says women with average risk of breast cancer can safely begin screening at 50.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, an influential panel of medical experts ignited a nationwide uproar by suggesting that women needed fewer mammograms than had long been recommended. Instead of starting at age 40 and being screened every year, women with average risk of breast cancer could safely begin at 50 and be tested every other year, the group said, citing extensive data to support its advice. It also said that after 74, there was not enough evidence to determine whether routine mammography was worthwhile.

headline: Review: The Pianist Jenny Q Chai, Evoking Chopin Without His Work
abstract: Ms. Chai has gained attention for unconventional programs that combine piano pieces, live electronics and video imagery, as in her Piano Steampunk series.
lead_paragraph: The dynamic Chinese-American pianist Jenny Q Chai has gained attention for unconventional programs that combine piano pieces, live electronics and video imagery, like the one she presented on Sunday afternoon at Le Poisson Rouge, intriguingly titled “Where Is Chopin?”

headline: David Bowie, Master of the Music Video
abstract: He helped transform the idea of the music video from a mere promotion to an art form in its own right.
lead_paragraph: Among many other things, David Bowie was a pioneer and maestro of the music video: From the start of his career, he understood the possibilities of a fledgling format, the ways in which music and image could conspire to tell a richer, more complicated story. Whether in a narrative or purely expressionist mode, he brought acute visual poetry to the screen, helping to transform the music video from an afterthought — a flat promotional tool — into its own challenging (and ever-changing) artistic medium.

headline: Review: ‘The Changeling,’ Where Murder Is the Natural Solution
abstract: In Thomas Middleton and William Rowley’s 1622 Jacobean tragedy, at the Lucille Lortel, a young noblewoman needs a hit man.
lead_paragraph: Sensation slides into silliness in “The Changeling,” a 1622 tragedy — with generous dollops of comedy — by Thomas Middleton and William Rowley. The convoluted story grows more lurid and strained as the play hurtles toward its predictably bloody conclusion, but with a fine cast bringing sufficient heat to the panting plotlines, the Red Bull Theater and its artistic director, Jesse Berger, once again win admiration for presenting a rarely seen drama from the Jacobean era with highly caffeinated verve. (Their previous productions include Middleton’s “Women Beware Women” and “The Revenger’s Tragedy.”)

headline: Marco Rubio Takes Darker Tone, Saying American Dream ‘Is Dying’
abstract: Summoning a bit of Donald J. Trump’s gloom, Senator Marco Rubio on Monday told an audience here that half of young Americans believe the American Dream is dead, a warning sign he said should rouse voters to seek a new direction in 2016.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. – Summoning a bit of Donald J. Trump’s gloom, Senator Marco Rubio on Monday told an audience here that half of young Americans believe that the American Dream is dead, a warning sign he said should rouse voters to seek a new direction in 2016.

headline: Review: Lars Jan’s ‘The Institute of Memory (TIMe)’ Is a Search for Identity
abstract: Mr. Jan’s play is a multimedia quest to uncover details about his father’s past.
lead_paragraph: The “searching for my father” (or, less often, “mother”) play or film is a genre at this point, but not many of the works in it are as adventurous as “The Institute of Memory (TIMe),” Lars Jan’s multimedia personal journey, part of the Under the Radar festival. Not many delve as deeply, either. Mr. Jan goes right into the brain of his father in search of a man who always seemed a cipher.

headline: Father of Koch Brothers Helped Build Nazi Oil Refinery, Book Says
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The book, “Dark Money,” by Jane Mayer, traces the rise of the modern conservative movement through the activism and money of a handful of rich donors.
lead_paragraph: The father of the billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch helped construct a major oil refinery in Nazi Germany that was personally approved by Adolf Hitler, according to a new history of the Kochs and other wealthy families.

headline: Is America Headed in the Right Direction? Readers Respond
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: As President Obama prepares to address the nation, tell us whether you think America is headed in the right or wrong direction.

headline: Review: In ‘The Holler Sessions,’ a D.J. as True Believer
abstract: Frank Boyd plays a hard-core music obsessive in this piece, staged as if it were a live radio show at the Coil Festival.
lead_paragraph: An unkempt Kansas City disc jockey named Ray has appointed himself an altar boy at the exalted shrine of jazz, and his faith burns like a five-alarm fire. Embodied with respect and ferocity by Frank Boyd in “The Holler Sessions,” which runs through Friday at the Paradise Factory, Ray radiates a hard-core obsessiveness that’s both scary and contagious. You get the feeling that he wears sunglasses inside not to be cool, but because the light he’s seen is so bright.

headline: Review: ‘The Art of Luv (Part 1),’ a Quest for the Perfect Erotic Recipe
abstract: Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble’s show at the Public combines elements of a yoga class with a multimedia exploration of the dynamics of attraction.
lead_paragraph: “Chair or floor?” This startling question greets you as you enter “The Art of Luv (Part 1): Elliot” at the Under the Radar Festival. Audience members have the option of sitting in seats or plopping down on the floor near the performers — pillow provided, thank goodness. You are also offered a hot hand towel, as in a Japanese restaurant. The production, from the Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble, combines the atmospherics of a yoga or meditation class — we are given breathing instructions — with a quirky, mostly entertaining multimedia exploration of the dynamics of erotic attraction in contemporary culture.

headline: In London, Men’s Designers Explore Change — and Tradition
abstract: Jonathan Anderson explored the idea of speed in his fall/winter 2016 collection — while Dunhill quietly refreshed old classics.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Anderson explored the idea of speed in his fall/winter 2016 collection — while Dunhill quietly refreshed old classics.

headline: Julian Castro Warns Latinos Would Suffer if G.O.P. Abandons Health Law
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Julián Castro, the federal housing secretary, said that if Republicans “recklessly” abandoned the Affordable Care Act without replacing it with “something thoughtful,” Latinos would “suffer tremendously.”
lead_paragraph: Julián Castro, the federal housing secretary, whom Hillary Clinton has mentioned as a potential running mate, said Monday that if Republicans “recklessly” abandoned the Affordable Care Act without replacing it with “something thoughtful,” Latinos would “suffer tremendously.”

headline: Three’s a Trend: Hoods on the Men’s Runways
abstract: At London Collections: Men, designers including Craig Green and Agi & Sam experimented with the look.
lead_paragraph: There’s a theme emerging across the runways at London Collections: Men — and it may indicate what’s on British designers’ minds. Once banned from shopping malls across the country, hoods — or at least models wearing hoods — popped up all over the runways, evoking everything from hypochondria to surveillance paranoia.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: David Bowie, Golden Globes, Sean Penn
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New England’s Top Sports Teams Support Transgender Bill
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Freedom Massachusetts, a coalition backing protections for transgender people, said it had the backing of teams like the New England Patriots.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — New England’s top professional sports teams have thrown their support behind legislation that would guarantee protections for transgender individuals in public spaces in Massachusetts, advocates for that measure announced on Monday. The supporters hope the teams’ muscle could help persuade legislators that the bill has broad appeal.
