lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: David Bowie in the Movies
abstract: From "The Man Who Fell to Earth" to "Labyrinth," a look back at David Bowie film roles.
lead_paragraph: From "The Man Who Fell to Earth" to "Labyrinth," a look back at David Bowie film roles.

headline: Cartoon: Mourning David Bowie
abstract: The musician leaves behind many legacies.
lead_paragraph: The musician leaves behind many legacies.

headline: Celebrating David Bowie, a Star Who Burned Bright to the Last
abstract: Testimonials for Mr. Bowie poured in form the worlds of music, art, fashion and performance, where he had an outsized presence.
lead_paragraph: As fans mourned David Bowie on the streets of London, Berlin and New York on Monday, a flurry of events served as a reminder of just what an outsize — and active — presence he had remained in the worlds of music, art, fashion and performance right up to the very end of his life.

headline: Oil Prices Slide Again, and the Bottom Is Not Yet in Sight
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Commodities', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Oil futures have dropped every day of the year so far because of slumping demand, and analysts say the trend is likely to continue.
lead_paragraph: The continuing collapse in commodity prices pushed oil futures still lower Monday, and analysts predicted that the slide was far from over.

headline: Police Officer Shot During Bronx Street Fight Was Hit by Colleague
abstract: The bullet removed from Officer Sherrod Stuart’s leg was from a 9-millimeter semiautomatic handgun, the police said, not from a gun wielded by a man who opened fire during the fight.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer shot in the leg while responding to a melee outside a party in the South Bronx over the weekend was wounded by a fellow officer, officials said on Monday.

headline: Listening to David Bowie: A Critic’s Tour of His Musical Changes
abstract: From the 1969 breakout “Space Oddity” to his 2016 farewell “Blackstar,” 16 songs that explore the singer and songwriter’s narrative and musical gifts.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie made pop of impassioned critical distance. He told a good musical story by standing outside of it and knew how to make you think about the artist’s relation to his work and the listener’s relation to the artist; he took the question of image and identity seriously. (The first song he recorded under his stage name, released in 1966, was called “Can’t Help Thinking About Me.”) In a certain way, all his songs were metafictions, even when they seemed personal, even when they were hits. Here is a handful of the best and most widely loved.

headline: Rand Paul and Carly Fiorina Are Dropped From Mainstage Republican Debate
abstract: There will be noticeably fewer candidates on the main debate stage when Republican presidential hopefuls gather in Charleston, S.C., on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: The Republican debate stage will be noticeably smaller when the candidates gather in Charleston, S.C., on Thursday night for their first debate of the year.

headline: Interest in Tom Coughlin Spreads to the 49ers, and the Giants Keep Seeking His Successor
abstract: Coughlin met with the Eagles and may soon meet with San Francisco. The Giants interviewed the ex-Falcons coach Mike Smith and were expected to talk to the Bengals’ offensive coordinator, Hue Jackson.
lead_paragraph: The Giants and Tom Coughlin continued to be in the middle of a churning and ever-changing coaching interview merry-go-round on Monday.

headline: New Pressures, and Commitments, After Fire Takes Family’s Home
abstract: Tajiauna Spence and her children became homeless last year when a fire broke out in an apartment below hers. Now they live in a homeless shelter in Brownsville, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Tajiauna Spence and three of her daughters ate dinner at a McDonald’s in Chelsea late last month. Her grandson, Styles, was the center of the group’s affections as he played with his gloves and made random demands.

headline: Where the Sidewalk Ends, Abruptly: Delivery Ramp Vexes Condo’s Residents in Lower Manhattan
abstract: Residents at 20 Pine Street, a condominium conversion in the financial district, are troubled by a sidewalk ramp for FedEx’s new Lower Manhattan distribution center.
lead_paragraph: In a library just off the lobby of 20 Pine Street, a condominium conversion a block from the New York Stock Exchange, a couple of neighbors met last week to address a problem that had been vexing them for more than a year: a ramp for FedEx’s new Lower Manhattan distribution center.

headline: A New Focus on Liquidity After a Fund’s Collapse
abstract: It has been a searing few months for Third Avenue Management, which shut down its junk bond fund when investors demanded payouts that far exceeded available funds.
lead_paragraph: The college seminar was drawing to a close in October and Martin J. Whitman was pondering the hits and misses in his long career at the top of Third Avenue Management, one of Wall Street’s better-known value investment firms.

headline: Nothing Remains: David Bowie’s Vision of Love
abstract: At the core of Bowie’s music and his apparent negativity is a profound yearning for connection and, most of all, for love.
lead_paragraph: On the title track of “Blackstar,” the David Bowie record released just a couple of days before his death on Jan. 10, Bowie sings, “I’m not a pop star.” True, he was an attractive celebrity with hit records, great hair and a vaguely gender-bending past. But for me, and for his millions of fans, he was someone who simply made life less ordinary. Indeed, Bowie’s music made me feel alive for the first time. And if that sounds like overstatement, then perhaps you don’t get what music is about and what it can do.

headline: Golden Globes Reflect a New Trajectory for TV
abstract: The Golden Globe awards rewarded shows outside the norms of television-success formulas, giving the nod to offbeat, even dark productions.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Over the last decade, NBC Universal’s cable chief, Bonnie Hammer, has occasionally visited the Golden Globes under less-than-glamorous conditions: sitting in a production truck for the E! network, dressed in jeans and sneakers, with her hair pulled back. By time the network wrapped up its red carpet show and the show actually began, a limo would be summoned, a pizza ordered and Ms. Hammer’s night would be all but over.

headline: Kentucky: Notice Served on Closing of Health Site
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Gov. Matt Bevin has formally notified the Obama administration that he plans to “wind down and cease operation” of the state’s health insurance exchange.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Matt Bevin has formally notified the Obama administration that he plans to “wind down and cease operation” of the state’s health insurance exchange. Mr. Bevin, a newly elected Republican who opposes the Affordable Care Act, said in a letter to Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of health and human services, that he wanted Kentucky residents to start using the federal insurance exchange serving 38 other states “as soon as is practicable.” Kentucky residents will continue using the state’s exchange, called Kynect, during the open enrollment period that ends Jan. 31. Mr. Bevin’s predecessor, Steven L. Beshear, a Democrat, has said it would cost the state at least $23 million to dismantle Kynect.

headline: Grindr Sells Stake to Chinese Company
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Online Dating', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: For Beijing Kunlun, Grindr offers a chance to expand beyond its gaming assets, as well as markets outside China.
lead_paragraph: Grindr, the popular dating and social networking app for gay men, has found itself a match.

headline: Deal Paves Way for Vote on Casino Referendum in New Jersey
abstract: The agreement between the State Senate president and the speaker of the Assembly sets up a vote to approve putting expansion of casino gambling on the ballot in November.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie returned to the State House on Monday and announced a compromise between two Democratic legislators over their proposals for a referendum on casino gambling in North Jersey.

headline: Alliance of 2 de Blasio Critics Fosters Speculation About Mayoral Challenge
abstract: Comptroller Scott M. Stringer and Representative Hakeem Jeffries of Brooklyn, both Democrats, have publicly disavowed plans to run against the mayor, but could pose different threats in a primary.
lead_paragraph: They stood side by side, two Democratic leaders deploring the plague of gun violence. But the event, a news conference on the steps of City Hall, was notable for more than its subject matter.

headline: Air Force General Says Russia Missile Defense ‘Very Serious’
abstract: Gen. Frank Gorenc, commander of Air Force operations in Europe and Africa, said the Russian strategy, known as anti-access/area denial, or A2/AD, was among the most worrisome trends he had seen.
lead_paragraph: The commander of United States Air Force operations in Europe and Africa expressed “very serious” concern Monday over what he described as big buildups of complex Russian missile defenses that increasingly threaten NATO military access to air space in parts of Europe, including one-third of the skies in Poland.

headline: The North American International Auto Show
abstract: Press previews for the Detroit auto show, which was first held in 1907, are Monday and Tuesday. Over 750 vehicles are expected to be on the floor of the Cobo Center.
lead_paragraph: Press previews for the Detroit auto show, which was first held in 1907, are Monday and Tuesday. Over 750 vehicles are expected to be on the floor of the Cobo Center.

headline: Automakers Go Electric, Even if Gas Is Cheap
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Low gas prices have meant healthy sales of trucks and S.U.V.s, but automakers are looking ahead to stricter fuel economy rules by showcasing electric and hybrid models.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — While American consumers were taking advantage of low gas prices to buy trucks and sport utility vehicles in large numbers, some automakers delayed investing in slower-selling electrified vehicles.

headline: New York City’s High School Graduation Rate Tops 70%
abstract: The announcement, which also noted that just over 78 percent of state students earned a diploma, came as state officials met to consider changes in graduation requirements.
lead_paragraph: As New York State officials met on Monday to consider changes to high school graduation requirements, the state announced that the graduation rate inched up last year, with New York City’s edging above 70 percent for the first time.

headline: Extradite El Chapo Guzmán
abstract: The Mexican government should move swiftly to send the world’s top drug kingpin to the United States for trial.
lead_paragraph: The last time the world’s top drug kingpin, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, was nabbed, Mexico’s top prosecutor said the government would consider extraditing him to the United States in 300 years or so, once all his criminal cases at home had been settled. Embarrassed by his escape in July — his second — Mexican officials appear to have changed their minds. Soon after he was taken into custody on Friday, the Mexican government indicated it had started extradition proceedings to send Mr. Guzmán to the United States. That is the right call.

headline: When Restless Billionaires Trip on Their Toys
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Philanthropy', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The Facebook co-founder trying to unload The New Republic is hardly the only billionaire to reach beyond his grasp.
lead_paragraph: “If you really care about an institution and want to make it strong for the ages, you don’t walk out. You roll up your sleeves, you redouble your commitment to those ideals in a changing world, and you fight.”

headline: Venezuela: Court Held Lawmakers in Contempt
abstract: The opposition to President Nicolás Maduro and his party won a large majority in the Assembly, but some Socialist candidates filed lawsuits challenging the results.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday held the leaders of the National Assembly in contempt and said the Assembly’s actions could be void, setting up a conflict between the two branches of government. The dispute stems from the swearing in last week of three lawmakers by the Assembly in defiance of a ruling by the court. The opposition to President Nicolás Maduro and his United Socialist Party won a large majority in the Assembly in elections last month. But some Socialist candidates filed lawsuits challenging the results and in one of those the court responded by halting the swearing in three lawmakers. The new Assembly leaders condemned that ruling as an attempt to undermine the new majority and swore the three opposition candidates in anyway. The summary of the Monday decision posted on the court’s website said all decisions made while the three members were “incorporated” into the Assembly would be void. The Assembly has said it will push legislation this week to free a number of prisoners who lawmakers who they say are being held for political reasons and will pursue laws to reduce the influence of Mr. Maduro’s administration.

headline: El Chapo Case Draws Mexico Closer to U.S.
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prison Escapes', 'United States International Relations', 'Smuggling', 'Extradition']
abstract: Joaquín Guzmán Loera’s escape from prison helped shrink the distance between Mexico and the United States, creating a sense of shared urgency that had not existed in years.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico has started letting American agents carry guns on its soil. A special Mexican unit trained by Americans has been revived after stalling because of mistrust and a sense of national pride. American agents are working with Mexican soldiers to seize guns, and the two nations just agreed on a plan to tackle the heroin epidemic.

headline: Late Reshuffling Clouds Vote on N.F.L. Moves
abstract: Last-minute maneuvering before the owners’ meeting to decide which teams were headed to Los Angeles clouded the issue further.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the N.F.L. hours away from convening a special two-day meeting among owners to decide on moving one or possibly two teams to Los Angeles, it seemed likely that the city would get a team, but which one and where they would play grew murkier Monday during a round of last-minute jockeying.

headline: David Bowie Allowed His Art to Deliver a Final Message
abstract: Mr. Bowie, who in his 50-year career reimagined the worlds of pop music, art and fashion, told very few people about the cancer that preceded his death on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: In the video for David Bowie’s “Lazarus,” released last week, the mythic singer and rock ’n’ roll shape-shifter, ever thin but bordering on gaunt, is blindfolded and writhing in a hospital bed. “Look up here, I’m in heaven,” he sings. “I’ve got scars that can’t be seen.” In the end, a shaking Mr. Bowie retreats backward into a darkened armoire.

headline: Balancing Terror and Reality in State of the Union Address
abstract: When President Obama speaks to Congress on Tuesday night, he will offer reassurance on the country’s efforts against terrorism, but he is said to believe that the sense of danger has been inflated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama speaks to the nation in his final State of the Union address on Tuesday night, he will offer a familiar reassurance that the country is expending enormous effort to protect Americans against international terrorism.

headline: President Obama to Focus on American Potential in 2016
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Instead of listing initiatives that are likely to fail, the president will use his last State of the Union address to focus on American potential and the need to take on long-term challenges, aides said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first State of the Union address, President Obama delivered a somber portrayal of a nation mired in a crippling economic crisis and bitter partisanship. As he prepares to deliver his seventh and final such speech on Tuesday, the financial calamity has passed but the partisanship has gotten worse.

headline: Nick Saban Builds a Legacy Under a Long Shadow
abstract: Alabama’s current coach, who was seeking a fourth national title with the Crimson Tide on Monday, has accomplished a great deal in his career but is unlikely to eclipse Bear Bryant.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Midway through his final session with reporters before Monday night’s College Football Playoff championship game, Alabama Coach Nick Saban was peppered with the customary questions about strategy, the Crimson Tide’s one-loss season and how it felt to be playing in yet another title game.

headline: Conflicts Keep 24 Million Children Out of School, Unicef Report Finds
abstract: The highest proportion was in South Sudan, where more than half the school-age children are not in school.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 24 million children living in 22 countries affected by conflict are not in school, the United Nations said Monday. A report released by Unicef, the United Nations Children’s Fund, said that of roughly 109 million children of primary and secondary school age in these countries, almost one in four are not getting an education. The highest proportion was in South Sudan, where more than half the school-age children are not in school, followed by Niger, at 47 percent; Sudan, 41 percent; and Afghanistan, 40 percent. The impact of war and upheaval on childhood education is regarded as a long-term crisis by Unicef, which has frequently warned of the effects of trauma and illiteracy as children reach adulthood.

headline: As U.S. Modernizes Nuclear Weapons, ‘Smaller’ Leaves Some Uneasy
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The Energy Department and the Pentagon have been readying a weapon with a build-it-smaller approach, setting off a philosophical clash in the world of nuclear arms.
lead_paragraph: As North Korea dug tunnels at its nuclear test site last fall, watched by American spy satellites, the Obama administration was preparing a test of its own in the Nevada desert.

headline: Hog the Mirror
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel on the runway.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today, we strut the runway with Zhouqin Burnikel. Eyes up, chin down, slouch mysteriously and pout seductively. Make the audience want you. Make those high-fashion duds look great.

headline: Court Allows FanDuel and DraftKings to Operate in New York Amid Appeal
abstract: The two largest daily fantasy websites were granted a stay by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court while they try to fend off a challenge from the state’s attorney general.
lead_paragraph: The two largest daily fantasy websites, FanDuel and DraftKings, were granted a stay on Monday by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court and can continue to operate in the state while they try to fend off a challenge from New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: Protesters Rip Out Fence at Refuge in Oregon
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Land Use Policies', 'Federal Lands']
abstract: The armed occupiers of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge escalated their defiance of the federal government, saying their action would allow a rancher’s cattle to graze on the land.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — The armed men who have occupied a federal wildlife refuge here escalated their defiance of the federal government on Monday, using bare hands and a Wildcat excavator stolen from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to rip apart a barbed-wire fence erected by the government at a far end of the vast refuge.

headline: Scott Harshbarger to Investigate Abuse Cases at St. George’s School
abstract: The former attorney general of Massachusetts will lead an inquiry into accusations of sexual abuse spanning decades at the school in Middletown, R.I.
lead_paragraph: Scott Harshbarger, a former attorney general of Massachusetts and former president of Common Cause, was named on Monday as the independent investigator into sexual abuse accusations spanning decades at St. George’s School, an elite prep school in Middletown, R.I.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Sexual Assault Charges
abstract: The lawyers claim that the district attorney’s office in Montgomery County, Pa., promised in 2005 that Mr. Cosby would not be prosecuted if he testified in a civil case.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Bill Cosby said Monday that they were asking for the dismissal of sexual assault charges filed against him in Pennsylvania, arguing that the local district attorney’s office had promised in 2005 that Mr. Cosby would not be prosecuted.

headline: Iran Reports Removing Core From Reactor
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Iran reported on Monday that it had removed the core of its plutonium-producing nuclear reactor at Arak as part of its efforts to complete its obligations under a new international agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran reported Monday that it had removed the core of its plutonium-producing nuclear reactor at Arak as part of its efforts to complete its obligations under a new international agreement, even as President Obama moved to guard the deal against action in Congress.

headline: Four Teenagers Are Charged in Brooklyn Rape Case
abstract: A fifth suspect is being sought in the sexual assault of an 18-year-old woman at a playground in the Brownsville neighborhood, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Four days after the sexual assault of an 18-year-old woman at a Brooklyn playground, prosecutors late Monday charged four teenagers with first-degree rape, officials said.

headline: Italy: American Woman Found Dead
abstract: Local news reports said the body of the woman, Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, was found in her bedroom on Saturday by her landlady and her boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Florence are investigating the death of a young American woman who was found in her apartment in the center of the city over the weekend, the police said on Monday. Local news reports said the body of the woman, Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, was found in her bedroom on Saturday by her landlady and her boyfriend, Federico Fiorentini, a well-known local artist. There were reports that marks were found on Ms. Olsen’s neck, suggesting she may have been strangled. Pathologists were performing an autopsy on Monday to determine the time and cause of death.

headline: Stable Spurs Meet Turbulent Nets, and the Outcome Is Predictable
abstract: San Antonio, the N.B.A.’s epitome of consistency, met the Nets, a struggling team that had just fired its coach and reassigned its general manager. Not surprisingly, the Spurs ran away with the game.
lead_paragraph: At his first pregame news conference since being named the Nets’ interim coach, Tony Brown found an unopened bottle of water awaiting him at the dais. He cheerily proclaimed, “It’s a great day.”

headline: Joe Girardi Opts for Aroldis Chapman Over Andrew Miller as the Yankees’ Closer
abstract: Girardi, the Yankees’ manager, in an interview on the team’s YES Network, said Chapman would assume the role ahead of Miller, who performed superbly last year in his first season as a closer.
lead_paragraph: Aroldis Chapman, the Yankees’ recently acquired All-Star reliever, will go into spring training as the team’s closer, Manager Joe Girardi said Monday.

headline: Ad Buys Position Marco Rubio to Dominate Iowa Airwaves
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Television', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The Rubio campaign’s buying strategy has scheduled 7,000 ads to be aired in Iowa this month, while his rivals rely on the deep pockets of “super PACs.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio and his allies will deploy a barrage of ads across Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina before the first caucus and primary contests next month, spending less money than some of his opponents yet still managing to reach more television viewers.

headline: Consumer Loan Delinquencies Edged Up in Third Quarter
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The American Bankers Association attributed the weaker credit to slower job growth and lower consumer confidence.
lead_paragraph: A measure of consumer credit worsened in the third quarter, a potentially troubling sign for banks that have enjoyed a long spell of low defaults.

headline: De Blasio to Announce New System Dedicated to Addressing Gun Crime in New York City
abstract: Starting this month, people charged with the possession of a firearm in the city will be sent to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which will preside over gun arrest cases.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to quell stubbornly persistent gun-related violence in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday will unveil a new system for handling such cases, creating a dedicated gun court in Brooklyn and a 200-officer police division focused on gun crime.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | lectern
abstract: This word has appeared in 185 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: lectern • \ˈlek-tərn\ • noun

headline: Rupert Murdoch, News Corp. Chief, and Jerry Hall Announce Engagement
abstract: Mr. Murdoch, the media titan, and Ms. Hall, a former model, made the announcement in the classifieds of The Times of London, a newspaper Mr. Murdoch’s company owns.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the executive chairman of News Corporation, and the former model Jerry Hall got engaged over the weekend and announced their pending nuptials Tuesday in the classifieds of a newspaper he owns.

headline: Alabama Wins Fourth National Championship in Seven Years
abstract: The Heisman Trophy winner Derrick Henry ran for 158 yards and three touchdowns, leading No. 2 Alabama past No. 1 Clemson for the College Football Playoff championship.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Nick Saban won his fourth national title in seven seasons on Monday night, and his fifth over all, with an Alabama team headlined by Derrick Henry, the second Tide player, after Mark Ingram Jr., to win the Heisman Trophy. The Heismans bookending Saban’s first and fourth titles since 2009 buttress the belief outside Tuscaloosa, Ala., that Saban is the beneficiary of bountiful talent.

headline: Hillary Clinton Promises Not to Be ‘Deporter in Chief’
abstract: At the Iowa Black and Brown Forum, a nationally televised event focused on minority issues, Mrs. Clinton broke with the Obama administration in arguing that raids are not an appropriate method of enforcing immigration laws.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure to consolidate her support among Latinos as Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont gains ground on her in Iowa, Hillary Clinton broke with the Obama administration on a key immigration provision on Monday night and promised not to be the “deporter in chief” if elected president.

headline: Richard Libertini, Actor, Dies at 82; Had Memorable Turn in ‘The In-Laws’
abstract: Mr. Libertini, a ubiquitous presence on stage, screen and television, was best known for his antic turn as the deranged General Garcia in the 1979 film comedy.
lead_paragraph: Richard Libertini, a character actor best known for his antic turn as a deranged Latin American general in the 1979 film comedy “The In-Laws,” died on Thursday at his home in Venice, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Joe Biden Says Obama Offered Financial Help During Son’s Illness
abstract: The vice president told CNN that the president had wanted to spare the Bidens from the prospect of selling their house to help Beau Biden’s family after a cancer diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: President Obama offered to personally give Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. money to help out when the vice president’s son became sick, Mr. Biden recalled in an interview that aired on Monday.

headline: Dalian Wanda of China Buys Legendary Entertainment for Up to $3.5 Billion
abstract: Wanda, which already owns the AMC cinema chain, said the purchase would help the producer of movies like “Jurassic World” gain access to China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Dalian Wanda Group, a politically powerful property and entertainment company in China, said on Tuesday that it was buying Legendary Entertainment, one of Hollywood’s biggest movie production companies, for as much as $3.5 billion.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
abstract: You can stream some of David Bowie’s impressive film roles, including Andy Warhol in “Basquiat.” President Obama delivers his final State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: We’ll remember David Bowie for his music, but his film roles were no less indelible. You can stream him as Andy Warhol in “Basquiat,” Pontius Pilate in “The Last Temptation of Christ” and as a space visitor in his calling card, “The Man Who Fell to Earth.” Meanwhile, President Obama delivers a State of the Union address for the last time.

headline: Statins May Help, Not Hinder, Heart Bypass Recovery
abstract: A review of 21 studies found that continuing to take statins both before and after coronary artery bypass surgery reduced complications.
lead_paragraph: People who are taking statin medications and need heart bypass surgery are often told to discontinue the drugs before and after surgery because of concerns about adverse effects. But that may not be a wise idea, a new review of studies has found.

headline: Corrections: January 12, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, January 12, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 12, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “What seemed not too long ago intriguingly complicated, ambiguous and opaque now seems pretty clear: a man who was yearning for immortality.”

headline: The 40,000-Mile Volcano
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Volcanoes', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: A major project in the Pacific Ocean off the West Coast is monitoring a steaming ridge full of living and mineral wonders on the ocean floor circling Earth.
lead_paragraph: Picture a volcano. Now imagine that its main vent extends in a line. Now imagine that this line is so long that it runs for more than 40,000 miles through the dark recesses of all the world’s oceans, girding the globe like the seams of a baseball.

headline: Digging Deeper Into Vivian Maier’s Past
abstract: When she started delving into Vivian Maier’s family history, an amateur researcher had no idea that her search would become an obsession.
lead_paragraph: This is the first report on a two-part story revealing new research reported on Vivian Maier. The second report is now published,

headline: Despite Clear Dangers, DuPont Kept Using a Toxic Chemical
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Chemicals', 'Water Pollution', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Congress should urgently complete its efforts to reform the Toxic Substances Control Act.
lead_paragraph: An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday has laid bare the unconscionable decades-long efforts of the DuPont company to hide the dangers of an obscure chemical and bamboozle regulators into allowing toxic pollution to continue long after the dangers were known to the company. The article by Nathaniel Rich described how a corporate lawyer, Rob Bilott, built a devastating case against DuPont, based on the company’s own studies and internal documents. The case illustrates the urgent need for Congress to complete its efforts to reform the Toxic Substances Control Act, which has allowed tens of thousands of untested chemicals to remain on the market with little more than the manufacturer’s say-so that they are safe.

headline: Willie Horton’s Heirs
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: New ads from Donald Trump and Ted Cruz are part of a tradition that began with a race-baiting 1988 spot.
lead_paragraph: In Donald J. Trump’s first television ad of the 2016 campaign, released last week, a photo of Hillary Clinton and President Obama flashes across the screen, followed by stark black-and-white images of the San Bernardino, Calif., attackers, Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik.

headline: The Brutalism of Ted Cruz
abstract: The Texas Republican lacks the Christian virtues many evangelical voters may expect.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Michael Wayne Haley was arrested after stealing a calculator from Walmart. This was a crime that merited a maximum two-year prison term. But prosecutors incorrectly applied a habitual offender law. Neither the judge nor the defense lawyer caught the error and Haley was sentenced to 16 years.

headline: How to Help the Syrians Who Want to Return Home
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The argument over admitting Syrian refugees obscures the bigger issue: How do we support those who want to return to Syria?
lead_paragraph: IN the aftermath of terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., American support for accepting more Syrian refugees has withered. The Republican presidential hopeful Donald J. Trump has called for blocking all Muslims from entering the United States, saying we are at war with radical Islam. Other politicians, including some governors and members of Congress, now specifically label Syrian refugees a threat.

headline: ‘Making a Murderer’ Is About Justice, Not Truth
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The point of true-crime serials is that we never really know what happened.
lead_paragraph: Durham, N.C. — THE release last month of “Making a Murderer,” a 10-part documentary from Netflix, capped a year in which popular culture’s portrayal of the criminal justice system seems to have shifted. Out with the old tropes about truth-seeking investigators and tidy resolutions; in with the disquieting, dysfunctional reality of many courtrooms and police stations.

headline: Strong Unions, Strong Democracy
abstract: Weakening labor increases inequality and instability. The Supreme Court should do neither.
lead_paragraph: IF the questions that came up during oral argument in Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association on Monday are any guide, the ruling bloc of conservative justices appears ready to render a decision later this year that would significantly weaken public sector labor unions.

headline: Agony and Starvation in the Syrian War
abstract: Aid convoys and their supplies offer only a respite. What is needed is an immediate end to the civil war.
lead_paragraph: After haunting pictures and stories of starving civilians showed up on international news sites and social media, food and other desperately needed aid were finally allowed into the Syrian town of Madaya on Monday. Yet this should not be a cause for celebration or complacency. The aid convoys and their supplies offer only a respite in the slow-motion agony that is destroying Syria and its people.

headline: In India, Dispensers of Balm Travel to Death’s Door
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Hospice Care', 'Morphine', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: The palliative care system in Kerala, India, has been singled out as a beacon of hope in offering the possibility of a dignified death to everyone.
lead_paragraph: A white van coursed through narrow roads along the monsoon-soaked coastline of Kerala, a state in southwestern India. Inside, Radha Upasarna, a volunteer, and two nurses looked over the roster of patients they would visit, most of whom had cancer or heart disease or were paraplegic.

headline: John Maynard Keynes: Great Economist, Terrible Currency Trader
abstract: It’s really hard to make money in currency trading, as a look at the trading records of one of the 20th century’s greatest economists makes clear.
lead_paragraph: If you watch a lot of business news on cable, you will inevitably see advertisements for software platforms that enable do-it-yourself currency trading.

headline: A Therapist’s Fib
abstract: Is it ever justified to help a client believe a fiction?
lead_paragraph: An old New Yorker cartoon features a man suspended upside down from the ceiling, like a stalactite. A psychiatrist explains to the wife that the first objective is to convince the man that he is a stalagmite.

headline: Reflecting on Obama's Presidency
abstract: What have been the defining aspects of Obama's legacy as president?

headline: News Q’s | Ötzi the Iceman’s Stomach Bacteria Offers Clues on Human Migration
abstract: What were scientists recently able to recover from Ötzi the Iceman’s stomach?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Ötzi the Iceman’s Stomach Bacteria Offers Clues on Human Migration.”

headline: Philippine Supreme Court Approves Return of U.S. Troops
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Under the decision, the United States will be allowed to station troops and weapons at crucial bases, decades after Manila lawmakers expelled American troops.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The United States won a significant victory on Tuesday in its efforts to counter China’s rising influence in the South China Sea, as the highest court in the Philippines cleared the way for American troops to return to the country.

headline: Istanbul Explosion Kills 10 Tourists, and ISIS Is Blamed
abstract: The Turkish government said that the Islamic State was behind the attack in the district of Sultanahmet, and that the dead were all foreign citizens.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — On any given day, the heart of this city’s historic district, where the monuments of three empires — Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman — collide with a mix of majesty and tranquillity, is a bustling center of tourism, one of the world’s most visited places.

headline: Block by Block | Ditmas Park
abstract: Leafy streets and idiosyncratic houses distinguish the Brooklyn neighborhood of Ditmas Park.
lead_paragraph: Leafy streets and idiosyncratic houses distinguish the Brooklyn neighborhood of Ditmas Park.

headline: Block by Block: Ditmas Park
abstract: Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, “Block by Block.”
lead_paragraph: Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, “Block by Block.” Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

headline: If Shonda Rhimes Can Say Yes, So Can I
abstract: In honor of the TV executive’s new book, “Year of Yes,” the writer embarked on his own experiment, vowing to try it all for one month.
lead_paragraph: It is the hallmark of most adults, as we lurch zombielike into middle age, increasingly to become distilled versions of ourselves. What once burgeoned or flourished now crystallizes or self-embalms. In the last year, I started doing needlepoint while drinking a gin and tonic; currently nothing holds my interest like “The Great British Baking Show” and its explications of self-saucing puddings. My friends call me Danger.

headline: David Bowie’s Fashion Legacy
abstract: The rock star gave the fashion industry a lot more than a look (or 12) — he gave it a philosophy.
lead_paragraph: When the news of David Bowie’s death broke this week, and emails circulated that mourned and celebrated the artist, a colleague asked what designers Mr. Bowie had most influenced. “What designer didn’t he influence?” another wrote. It’s a good question.

headline: Hillary Clinton Races to Close Enthusiasm Gap With Bernie Sanders in Iowa
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: With voters mobbing Mr. Sanders at events in the state, exposing a disparity in passion for the two Democrats, Mrs. Clinton has gone on the attack and tried to energize supporters.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Iowa Democrats are displaying far less passion for Hillary Clinton than for Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont three weeks before the presidential caucuses, creating anxiety inside the Clinton campaign as she scrambles to energize supporters and to court wavering voters.

headline: What Musicians or Bands Mean the Most to You?
abstract: What is it about their music or personality that you admire?
lead_paragraph: Has a musician ever meant more to you than as just a person who makes music? He, she or they may have become an inspiration or role model, and perhaps even become a part of your identity and how you see yourself.

headline: Sitting With Michelle Obama to Stand for State of the Union Themes
abstract: Americans, ordinary and well known alike, have over the years been invited to President Obama’s annual addresses to represent his policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each year the first lady attends the State of the Union address with about two dozen guests who capture the news of the day and exemplify the president’s message. This year’s guests, for instance, include a Syrian refugee, the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case last year legalizing same-sex marriage and an Air Force sergeant who helped take down a gunman on a train in France.

headline: ‘Excellent Daughters,’ by Katherine Zoepf
abstract: An American reporter spends years trying to understand women in the Arab world.
lead_paragraph: “Why are foreigners so interested in the hijab?” a devout young Syrian woman demanded after reading a newspaper article by Katherine Zoepf in which she appeared. “We spent so many months talking to you about what we think, what we believe, what is on our minds.”

headline: ‘Their Promised Land: My Grandparents in Love and War,’ by Ian Buruma
abstract: An author’s Jewish grandparents were also very, very English.
lead_paragraph: Bernard and Win wrote to each ­other as teenagers in love in the long-lost years when Europe committed suicide in World War I. They continued their correspondence whenever they were apart, through another world war. They wrote about how much they missed each other, about classical music and gardening and, of course, about their children.

headline: Invisible Designs
abstract: A recent translation of Cold War-era stories by the Czech writer Bohumil Hrabal reminds us that we ignore his sly and idiosyncratic work to our detriment.
lead_paragraph: Bohumil Hrabal died only once — in Prague, on Feb. 3, 1997 — but there are at least two versions of the story.

headline: Face in the Crowd: Mark Ronson at Burberry
abstract: Styles caught up with Mr. Ronson, the D.J. and producer, in the tent in Kensington Gardens before the British brand’s event.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When it comes to the London men’s wear shows, Burberry is widely considered the jewel in the crown and one of the few events able to lure an A-list front row. The British behemoth starts proceedings promptly, unlike a vast majority of shows, so, about 15 minutes before the lights go down, there’s often a celebrity or four standing around. Styles caught up with Mark Ronson, the D.J. and producer, in the tent in Kensington Gardens.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

abstract: Tuesday: Remembering an icon, changeable weather, and the arrival of starlings.
lead_paragraph: Updated 8:56 a.m.

headline: Of Ted Cruz’s Birth Status, Senator Claire McCaskill Says, ‘I Think It’s a Question’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When Senator John McCain of Arizona faced questions about meeting constitutional qualifications for the presidency because of his birth in the Panama Canal Zone, Ms. McCaskill of Missouri came to his defense. But she is not exactly extending a helping hand for Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, who faces similar questions about his birth in Canada.
lead_paragraph: When Senator John McCain of Arizona, the 2008 Republican nominee for president, faced questions about meeting the constitutional qualifications because of his birth in the Panama Canal Zone, one Democratic colleague rushed to end any doubt.

headline: Morning Agenda: No Bottom in Sight for Oil Prices
abstract: When Billionaires Trip on Their Toys | A New Focus on Liquidity | How David Bowie Inspired Changes on Wall Street
lead_paragraph: NO BOTTOM IN SIGHT FOR OIL PRICES | The collapse in commodity prices pushed oil futures even lower on Monday and analysts predicted that the slide was far from over,Jad Mouawad reports in The New York Times.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Junior Doctors’ Strike in England Disrupts Care for Thousands
abstract: The first strike by medical doctors in the country in four decades heightened tensions over the stewardship of a widely revered health system that has come under growing strain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Hospital doctors in England staged their first strike in four decades on Tuesday, disrupting treatment for thousands of patients in the National Health Service and escalating political tensions over a publicly funded health care system so revered that it was once likened to a national religion.

headline: China Is Said to Arrest 4 Human Rights Advocates
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession', 'Political Prisoners', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The move against the four, already detained for six months, continues a nationwide sweep of more than 200 lawyers and associates who worked on civil rights cases.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese police have formally arrested four human rights advocates in the last week on charges of subverting state power after detaining them for the last six months, according to one of their colleagues and rights groups.

headline: Chelsea Clinton to Campaign in New Hampshire Amid Threat From Sanders
abstract: Chelsea Clinton will make her first campaign swing of 2016 with three events in the state, where the Hillary Clinton campaign has been trying to quell a rising challenge from Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton campaign has been dispatching a rotation of high-power surrogates to New Hampshire, most recently Lena Dunham and Abby Wambach.

headline: Helen Mirren Doesn’t Feel Worthy of Your Admiration
abstract: But the star of “Woman in Gold” and “Trumbo” says “it’s incredibly flattering” to be considered a role model.
lead_paragraph: Helen Mirren, people. Helen. Freaking. Mirren. The Bagger has only been at this gig for a year or so, but interviewing Ms. Mirren — at length, in a TimesTalk — has far and away been one of the brightest highlights yet.

headline: Hotels Offer Perks for Four-Legged Guests
abstract: Adventure parks, free toys, robes, mats and more are tempting owners to travel with their canine companions.
lead_paragraph: A dog bed and a free rawhide bone may have represented the hospitality vanguard for pet friendliness a decade ago, but now the bar has been raised, not just by hotels supplying monogrammed doggy robes and play parks, but even tour operators that welcome canine companions.

headline: For Some Atlanta Hawks, a Revved-Up Game of Uno Is Diversion No. 1
abstract: The favored in-flight pastime of a group of players including Al Horford, Kent Bazemore and Dennis Schroder is a schoolchildren’s card game with some added twists.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Lamar Patterson was new to the Atlanta Hawks when he discovered several teammates playing a popular card game at training camp. Patterson asked if he could join them. He thought he knew the rules.

headline: More ‘Progressive’ Than Thou
keywords: ['English Language', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: This year’s Democratic primary season has become a contest to claim this label — but in American politics, it has always had a slippery definition.
lead_paragraph: In these last gasping weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Hillary Clinton has settled upon a political identity, declaring herself ‘‘a progressive who likes to get things done.’’ The label reassures left-wing Democrats that she shares their values while also signaling to the party’s centrists that she is above all pragmatic. Clinton introduced the phrase in October, at the first Democratic presidential debate, where it produced whoops of joy from the live audience: Here was Clinton striking back at the supposedly pie-in-the-sky Bernie Sanders. The Clinton campaign was so enthused by the response that it printed up bumper stickers with the phrase, and in early December, Clinton repeated it in an email to Howard Dean’s grass-roots group, Democracy for America, pleading for an endorsement.

headline: Poll Watch: Obama’s Gun Policies Are Popular, but Verdict Is Mixed on Other Issues
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: President Obama’s plan to expand gun background checks has wide support among Americans, but he faces deep skepticism about his performance on other issues, a New York Times/CBS News poll says.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s plan to expand background checks to cover more gun sales generated wide support among Americans, but it did little to improve his overall standing with the public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Trials of Alice Goffman
abstract: Her first book, ‘On the Run' — about the lives of young black men in West Philadelphia — has fueled a fight within sociology over who gets to speak for whom.
lead_paragraph: Before the morning last September when I joined her at Newark Airport, I had met Alice Goffman only twice. But in the previous months, amid a widening controversy both inside and outside the academy over her research, she and I had developed a regular email correspondence, and she greeted me at the gate as if I were an old friend. A 34-year-old untenured professor of sociology at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, Goffman had just begun a year of leave at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, which she hoped she might use to escape her critics and get back to work. Now, though, she was returning to Madison for a four-day visit, to deliver a lecture and catch up with her graduate students.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’: Going Beyond the Verdict
abstract: This 10-episode FX mini-series stars Cuba Gooding Jr., John Travolta and David Schwimmer. It has its debut on Feb. 2.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after some 107 million people watched a Los Angeles jury announce that it had found O. J. Simpson not guilty of the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman, are television viewers ready to see it all again?

headline: Digging Deeper Into Vivian Maier’s Past
abstract: When she started delving into Vivian Maier’s family history, an amateur researcher had no idea that her search would become an obsession.
lead_paragraph: When she started delving into Vivian Maier’s family history, an amateur researcher had no idea that her search would become an obsession.

headline: In Final State of the Union Address, Obama May Set Aside Convention
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Top aides have made it very clear that the speech would not be the usual litany of legislative priorities but would instead be a grander call to arms on the major challenges facing the nation.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will reach one of the first major milestones of his last year in office on Tuesday night when he delivers his seventh and final State of the Union address.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 5-11, 2016
abstract: Have you been following this week’s news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following this week’s news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: 1935: Amelia Earhart Spans Stretch of Pacific
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune: Amelia Earhart completed a solo flight across the Pacific in 1935.
lead_paragraph: On January 12, 1935, Amelia Earhart completed a solo flight across 2,300 miles of the Pacific Ocean, from Honolulu to California. Three years earlier, Earhart became the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Below, an excerpt from the European edition of The New York Herald on her journey in 1935:

headline: A Progressive Way to End Corporate Taxes
abstract: Instead of paying a slice of their profits, companies could turn over nonvoting stock to the government.
lead_paragraph: Washington — JUST about every American chief executive has the same dream: to get out from under the corporate income tax. For many, that means lobbying Congress to change the tax code. But for a growing number, it also involves increasingly creative — and successful — tricks to avoid their liability.

headline: A Lineup of Missteps
abstract: Here’s a sobering start to the new year: an extra long rundown of gaffes and missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and our ever-vigilant readers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sobering start to the new year: an extra long rundown of gaffes and missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and our ever-vigilant readers.

headline: Trump Says N.F.L. Is Boring; It Has Actually Never Been More Exciting
abstract: The rise in passing and scoring lines up with the rise in N.F.L. ratings, popularity and revenue.
lead_paragraph: Six of the eight teams left standing in this N.F.L. season are pass-wacky — only Carolina and Seattle rush more than they throw. The whole league is pass-wacky; Chase Stuart of Football Perspective, writing for The Times, noted that the N.F.L. just set records for pass attempts, passing yards and passing touchdowns per game.

headline: An Enduring Coach Pulls a Timely Trick
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: The kick was a classic underdog maneuver, a gamble from a program that is seemingly always favored and from a coach, Nick Saban, who used never to make such moves.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The biggest play of the national championship game was a surprise in the moment because it was a surprise in the much greater sweep of Alabama’s history and Coach Nick Saban’s career.

headline: The Airbnb From Hell
abstract: It wasn’t the quality of the apartment that got under the renter’s skin; it was the overbearing host and her endless complaints.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Bully for Neurotoxins
abstract: Guess who likes heavy metals?
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal has a remarkable editorial titled The Carnage in Coal Country, accusing President Obama of destroying jobs through his terrible, horrible, no good regulations on coal: “According to the National Mining Association, 40,000 coal jobs have been lost in the U.S. since 2008.”

headline: Brazil’s Digital Backlash
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Instant Messaging', 'Social Media', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A government that once championed Internet freedom now seems more interested in surveillance and censorship.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A São Paulo judge sent shock waves across Brazil last month with a ruling that required Brazilian telecommunications operators to block the use of the instant messaging platform WhatsApp for 48 hours. Less than 13 hours later, another São Paulo judge reversed the decision, restoring service. But in the meantime, as many as 100 million Brazilians had been seriously inconvenienced, and civil libertarians around the world looked on with dismay.

headline: Iranian Official Denies That Nuclear Reactor Was Sealed
abstract: The country’s deputy nuclear chief said a report that technicians had removed the core of the country’s heavy-water reactor and poured concrete into the cavity was baseless.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian nuclear official on Tuesday denied a report that technicians had removed the core of the country’s only heavy-water reactor and poured concrete into the cavity, a final step toward the completion of the historic nuclear agreement in July and the lifting of sanctions on Iran.

headline: Daily Report: One Grand Experiment Ends for a Facebook Co-Founder
abstract: The decision by Chris Hughes, a Facebook co-founder, to put The New Republic up for sale is a reminder of the unusual places Facebook money has ended up, with unusual outcomes.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley wealth can end up in unexpected places, with unusual results.

headline: You Will Not Win the Powerball Jackpot
abstract: Probably. Sorry.
lead_paragraph: Despite the dreams that felt so real, you are still not filthy rich.

headline: Why Putin Loves Trump
abstract: People think the Russian president is a hard-nosed realist. But the danger is that he’s nothing of the kind.
lead_paragraph: Sofia, Bulgaria — “VLADIMIR VLADIMIROVICH, is war coming?”

headline: Inside the Set of ‘Sesame Street’
abstract: After 45 years on the public broadcaster PBS, Big Bird, Elmo and the rest of the “Sesame Street” crew are settling into a new set as well as a new television home on the premium cable network HBO.
lead_paragraph: After 45 years on the public broadcaster PBS, Big Bird, Elmo and the rest of the “Sesame Street” crew are settling into a new set as well as a new television home on the premium cable network HBO.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Gets New Upscale Look for HBO Premiere
abstract: Oscar the Grouch has a recycling bin and Big Bird has moved to a tree as the children’s classic debuts on HBO, aiming at a generation that doesn’t distinguish between TV and mobile screens.
lead_paragraph: Big Bird’s nest has moved to a tree. Elmo has moved from an apartment into a brownstone. His best friend, Abby Cadabby, loves her new community garden. And while Oscar the Grouch still makes a trash can his home, he now pops up through an underground tunnel of connecting recycling and compost bins.

headline: Bryson Tiller and Other Singers Are Bringing Hip-Hop Into R&B
abstract: Rhythm and blues is no longer taking hip-hop’s assault lying down. Singers like Mr. Tiller are finding new ways to invigorate the genre.
lead_paragraph: So much of hip-hop’s history has been about absorption and conquering. No other genre in pop has made so much mulch of its enemies and its obstacles. When it came to R&B, the dominant sound of prerap black pop, hip-hop was stealthy.

headline: Picking a Windows 10 Security Package
abstract: Paid security protection software has its advantages, but some services guard your system free.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m just starting to use a Windows computer again after many years on a Mac. I want to protect myself but the number of options is overwhelming, including antivirus, anti-spyware, anti-spam, anti-malware, personal firewalls, anti-phishing, anti-Trojan and so on. Do I need all this and should I be paying for all this protection or will some of the free programs suffice?

headline: Picasso Bust at Center of Custody Battle Between Gagosian and Qatar Royal Family
abstract: The art dealer Larry Gagosian and the Qatar royal family are disputing the ownership of a Picasso sculpture of his mistress, Marie-Thérèse, on view at MoMA.
lead_paragraph: The high-powered art dealer Larry Gagosian says he bought it. The royal family of Qatar says it bought the sculpture, too. And now they are facing off in court over who owns Picasso’s important plaster bust of his muse (and mistress) Marie-Thérèse Walter, a star of the Museum of Modern Art’s popular “Picasso Sculpture” show.

headline: A New Director for Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival
abstract: Pamela Tatge, the director of the Center for the Arts at Wesleyan University, is to take over beginning April 18.
lead_paragraph: Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, nestled in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts, has a new leader: Pamela Tatge, who is to take over as executive director beginning April 18. Previously, the position of executive and artistic director was held by Ella Baff. Ms. Tatge is the director of the Center for the Arts at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., where, for the past 16 years, she has organized programming in dance, music, theater and the visual arts.

headline: Alabamians Cross State Lines, Seeking a Golden Ticket
abstract: With more than a billion dollars up for grabs in the Powerball jackpot this week, people flocked to Georgia, a state that actually participates in the lottery.
lead_paragraph: TALLAPOOSA, Ga. — There was not much in the world that was more important to many Alabamians in recent days than the national football championship game between the University of Alabama and Clemson.

headline: Creative Capital Awards Nearly $4.4 Million in Arts Grants
abstract: The winners, 46 in all, each receive $50,000 in funding, as well as $45,000 worth of career development services.
lead_paragraph: Artistic projects that aim to reflect broad cultural conversations about gender, gun violence and race are among those chosen for nearly $4.4 million worth of grants awarded by Creative Capital, the organization announced on Tuesday.

headline: 1916: Key Citadel May Have Fallen
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Central Powers gain access to an Adriatic port in 1916.
lead_paragraph: If it is true that Mount Lovcen has gone, then a position of great importance has been lost to the Allies. This strip of Austrian territory, says the ‘‘Times,’’ contains Cattaro, with its deep inlet from the sea, the Bocche di Cattaro — a natural harbor of great value.

headline: MoveOn Site Puts Its Backing Behind Bernie Sanders
abstract: “MoveOn members are feeling the Bern,” the liberal website’s political action executive director said, in endorsing Bernie Sanders. The group spent months in search of an alternative to Hillary Clinton and invested $1 million in ads to draft Elizabeth Warren.
lead_paragraph: The liberal political group MoveOn.org threw its endorsement to Senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic presidential contest, backing him after its officials spent months in search of an alternative to Hillary Clinton and invested $1 million in ads to draft Senator Elizabeth Warren for the race.

headline: Decoding Airline Fare Classes to Make the Most of Your Miles
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: When you are fare hunting, you want to parse the various fare class letters and find out the miles you’ll receive if you fly in those classes.
lead_paragraph: Do you know what a Q fare is? How about an X or a Z? When you browse for flights on an airline’s website, assorted letters appear in your search results. Travelers often miss them. Or see them but don’t factor them into their decision about which flight to choose. But these letters matter. Because of them, the person to your left may receive more award miles than you, reach elite status faster than you, or change her itinerary at no cost while you pay a $200 fee — yet you’re both in the same cabin. What gives?

headline: Pakistani Soldiers Search Times Reporter’s Home
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The soldiers searched the Islamabad home without a warrant and left without seizing any property. Civilian government officials later apologized.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Pakistani paramilitary soldiers searched the private home in Islamabad of a New York Times reporter on Tuesday morning without a warrant, leaving without seizing any property or making an arrest.

headline: Bernie Sanders Has Edge in Iowa and Widens New Hampshire Lead, Polls Find
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders is breaking away from Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire and has erased her lead in Iowa, according to new polls that show him solidifying the support of Democrats ahead the first two 2016 presidential voting contests.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders is breaking away from Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire and is edging ahead of her in Iowa, according to new polls that show him solidifying the support of Democrats ahead the first two 2016 presidential primary election contests.

headline: Revitalizing the Waterfront in Redondo Beach, Calif.
abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private partnership to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.
lead_paragraph: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private partnership to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

headline: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.
lead_paragraph: REDONDO BEACH, Calif. — The Redondo Beach pier juts into Santa Monica Bay, at the southern end of a string of beach cities loosely connected by a bike path and teeming with visitors.

headline: 1941: R.A.F. Bombs Turin
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British planes drop bombs and pamphlets on Turin in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Swooping across the Alps, British bombers dropped loads of bombs and pamphlets on Turin, in northern Italy, last night [Jan. 11] while other R.A.F. raiders attacked objectives in western Germany, including the Nazi naval base and shipyards at Wilhelmshaven and targets on or near the Dutch and Belgian coasts.

headline: 3 Philadelphia Publications Are Donated to a Nonprofit Journalism Institute
abstract: Ownership of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philly.com and The Philadelphia Daily News, has been transferred to The Institute for Journalism in New Media.
lead_paragraph: H.F. Lenfest, the owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com, announced on Tuesday that he had donated the publications to a newly formed nonprofit journalism institute.

headline: ‘Silence of the Lambs’ House Can’t Find a Buyer
keywords: ['Movies', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Serial Murders', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Other homes with Hollywood cachet do well, but the setting for a serial killer’s dungeon seems to be a tough sell.
lead_paragraph: Since it was listed for sale last summer, a century-old house made famous as the home of a serial killer in the 1991 movie “The Silence of the Lambs” has attracted plenty of curiosity, but it has mostly languished on the real estate market.

headline: Per Se
abstract: Fine dining from the chef Thomas Keller in Columbus Circle.
lead_paragraph: Fine dining from the chef Thomas Keller in Columbus Circle.

headline: At Thomas Keller’s Per Se, Slips and Stumbles
abstract: A new look at one of the nation’s landmark restaurants.
lead_paragraph: The lady had dropped her napkin.

headline: U.S. to Block Fungal Peril to Salamanders With Ban on Pet Imports
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fungi', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Salamanders']
abstract: After months of urging by conservation biologists and environmental groups, the Obama administration moves to stave off a devastating threat to American salamanders.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of President Obama’s final State of the Union address, his administration gave North American salamanders a chance, and conservationists a reason to cheer.

headline: Stung by Low Oil Prices, BP Will Cut 4,000 Jobs
abstract: More cuts are considered likely in an industry that had already lost an estimated 250,000 jobs since the price of crude began to drop in 2014.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The persistent plunge in oil prices has translated into a new round of industry job cuts.

headline: Glass Beads Made in Czech Village Adorn Bodies of the World’s Tribes
abstract: Glittering glass beads produced at the Preciosa factory in Desna can be found across the world, a favorite of the Masai and Samburu tribes in Kenya and Tanzania, and the Kayapos of the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: DESNA, Czech Republic — When the January issue of National Geographic landed in his mailbox last year, Petr Pus nearly fell to the floor. There on the cover and throughout the issue were members of the Kayapo tribe, living far up the Amazon in conditions more Stone Age than information age, all of them adorned with face paint and a glittering assortment of beads.

headline: Marin Montagut’s Atelier in Normandy
abstract: The artist takes T around his bucolic home-away-from-home in in Saint-Luc, where he creates his Bonjour City Map-Guides series.
lead_paragraph: The artist takes T around his bucolic home-away-from-home in in Saint-Luc, where he creates his Bonjour City Map-Guides series.

headline: A French Watercolorist’s Countryside Escape
abstract: Marin Montagut, the illustrator of Bonjour City Map-Guides, takes T in and around his bucolic atelier in Normandy.
lead_paragraph: Rarely without his navy and white marinière — or his robin’s-egg blue Vespa — the French illustrator-filmmaker-multimedia artist Marin Montagut has emerged as a darling of sorts in the Parisian cultural scene. Known first for his documentaries for the fashion paragon Inès de la Fressange, he’s earning attention today for weaving watercolors of his favorite fashionable addresses in Paris, London and New York into Bonjour City Map-Guides, a series of pocket-sized folding maps. And yet, the globetrotter produces much of his work about an hour from the City of Light in his creative home-away-from-home in Saint-Luc, Normandy — prepossessing as much for its design as for its bucolic environs.

headline: The Artist Behind Our 52 Places to Go in 2016 Cover
abstract: When we needed a cover illustration for our annual 52 Places to Go issue, we turned to Rafael Lopez, a celebrated illustrator.
lead_paragraph: When we needed a cover illustration for our annual 52 Places to Go issue, we turned to Rafael Lopez, a celebrated illustrator. After all, our No. 1 pick this year is Mexico City, where Mr. Lopez is from and lives part-time. He’s also an extraordinary artist who’s created dynamic and colorful posters, murals and postage stamps. We were delighted with the results. To learn more, we asked Mr. Lopez a few questions about his inspiration, his life and his work. He sent his answers, which are below, edited for length and clarity, by email from San Miguel de Allende.

headline: New York Times Names New Media Columnist
abstract: Jim Rutenberg, chief political correspondent for the Sunday magazine, will fill the role last held by David Carr, who died in February.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times said on Tuesday that Jim Rutenberg, chief political correspondent for the Sunday magazine, would become its media columnist, filling a role that has been vacant since the death of David Carr about a year ago.

headline: American Ballet Theater Names Kara Medoff Barnett Executive Director
abstract: Ms. Barnett, who succeeds Rachel S. Moore, is a ballet aficionado with a long career in the arts, including her most recent position as managing director of Lincoln Center International.
lead_paragraph: She started ballet lessons at 3 in North Carolina, but gave up dancing for college, then Harvard Business School and a career in the arts that eventually led her to become an executive at Lincoln Center. Now Kara Medoff Barnett is returning to her first love: She will be the next executive director of American Ballet Theater, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Dear Powerball Winner: Take Our Advice and Take the Annuity
abstract: Comparing payout options is fun to imagine, but also a useful way to think about taxes, investment opportunities and human nature.
lead_paragraph: So let us suppose, reader, that you have won a $1.5 billion Powerball jackpot. Congratulations! You have some important decisions to make, such as what ailing magazine to acquire and what congressional seat your spouse should run for. But first, you must choose whether to take the prize as an annuity paid over 30 years, or a lump-sum payment right now.

headline: At Burberry Men’s Show, a Simple Tribute to David Bowie
abstract: Christopher Bailey honored the late musician in his men’s fall/winter 2016 show, while newcomer Liam Hodges explored British car culture.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bailey honored the late musician in his men’s fall/winter 2016 show, while newcomer Liam Hodges explored British car culture.

headline: Coachella Promoters Announce Panorama, a New Music Festival in New York
keywords: ['Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Governors Ball Music Festival', 'Music']
abstract: No details about the performers were confirmed for the festival, which will take place a month after Governors Ball in the same location on Randalls Island.
lead_paragraph: The promoters behind Coachella are bringing a new pop festival to New York in July, after months of behind-the-scenes lobbying and a press-release war with a homegrown competitor, Governors Ball.

headline: New Generation of Diesel Technology
abstract: The Diesel Technology Forum rebuts an Op-Ed essay raising doubts about “clean diesel.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Persian (or Arabian) Gulf Is Caught in the Middle of Regional Rivalries
abstract: As tensions escalate between Iran and Saudi Arabia, a dispute over the name of the body of water between them illustrates the disagreements at the heart of their dispute.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a name?

headline: Get Paid to Organize Your Children’s Closets (and Yours)
abstract: Three bags of unwanted clothing turned into $175 in gift cards and $86.09 in Paypal cash.
lead_paragraph: Anyone can clean out a closet. We pull out all the clothes and apply some standard (for children, that’s little more than “does it fit?”; for adults, it ranges from “have I worn it recently?” to the organizational guru Marie Kondo’s now-famous question, “Does it bring joy?”) If an item passes, back it goes, while failures are headed for donation boxes. Typically, especially for ourselves, we hang too many things back up. When clothes are “as good as new,” or were expensive, sometimes it’s hard to persuade ourselves to give them away, even if on some level we know we don’t really want them any more.

headline: Sasha Petraske’s Legacy Lives On With Seaborne in Red Hook
abstract: The bar owner had a few enterprises in the works when he died last August, one of which will be realized: a new bar in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The bar owner Sasha Petraske, a pioneer of the current cocktail revival, had a few projects in the works when he died last August at age 42, including a book and a hoped-for third iteration of his trailblazing speakeasy Milk & Honey.

headline: China Is Said to Detain Swedish Human Rights Worker
abstract: Activists described the detention of Peter Jesper Dahlin as another step in the Chinese government’s drive to silence human rights campaigners.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Swedish man who worked in support of human rights groups and grass-roots legal advocates in China has been detained in Beijing on accusations of endangering state security, supporters of the man said Tuesday. They described the detention of the Swede, Peter Jesper Dahlin, as another step in the Chinese government’s drive to silence human rights defense campaigners.

headline: A Saudi Aramco I.P.O. Could Herald a Wider Sale of Assets
abstract: The Saudi government owns stakes in local companies worth $170 billion. By spinning these off to compensate for lower oil revenue, it could fund years of budget deficits.
lead_paragraph: The sale of a bit of Saudi Aramco, a government-owned oil producer, could be the first in a series of spinoffs and privatizations by Riyadh.

headline: Per Se Review
abstract: Fine dining from the chef Thomas Keller.
lead_paragraph: Fine dining from the chef Thomas Keller.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Classic White Shirts
abstract: Alexander McQueen, Wales Bonner and Rory Parnell-Mooney showed the simple style in their fall/ winter 2016 collections.
lead_paragraph: London is a city where, at least with respect to fashion shows, anything goes — from pants with butt cleavage to bucket headpieces. All the more reason for a classic white shirt to feel special. They’ve popped up all over the London Collections: Men fall/winter 2016 runways, in such wildly disparate shows as Wales Bonner and Rory Parnell-Mooney (where references ranged from the jazz composer Sun Ra to catholic schools, respectively). At Alexander McQueen, a simple white shirt was the perfect foil to bold prints and ornate gilets.

headline: Change the Ways of Congress?
abstract: A former candidate writes that it’s “a fool’s errand.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Museum-Style Sampling of Italian Futurism
abstract: The works of Italian modernists are the focus of this show, the kind of historical exhibition that can take decades to pull together.
lead_paragraph: A connoisseur’s love of Italian modernist painting, abstract in style and modest in scale, lies behind this compendious, museum-style exhibition, organized by the dealer Gian Enzo Sperone. It’s the sort of historical show that can take decades to pull together. And that this can be done on such a scale by a commercial gallery is surely only possible because the art in question still has a fairly limited set of of devotees and remains obtainable.

headline: Los rostros de los que resisten la crisis económica de Puerto Rico
abstract: Con la crisis económica de Puerto Rico muchos profesionales jóvenes se han visto obligados a buscar oportunidades en el continente americano. Joseph Rodríguez retrató a los que se han quedado en el país”.
