headline: Number of Female Directors of Top Films Ticks Up, Study Says
abstract: Women made up 9 percent of the filmmakers behind the top-grossing movies in 2015, up from 7 percent the year before.
lead_paragraph: The latest study on gender equality in Hollywood found that last year, women accounted for 9 percent of the directors of the 250 top-grossing domestic films. This might not sound great, but it’s an improvement over 2014, when women made up just 7 percent of directors for those films. The 2015 result put women on par with the level achieved in 1998.

headline: Taking Action in Syria
abstract: “How much more suffering must we witness before world leaders take real action to end the war in Syria?” a writer asks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Art Made by Tempting Animals
abstract: Dana Sherwood’s latest work involves leaving precisely chosen feasts out for Brazilian ocelots and Danish deer — and filming the results.
lead_paragraph: At the artist Dana Sherwood’s apartment on the Upper West Side, her dog, Hera, answers the door, tail wagging. A lifelong equestrian who now competes in dressage, Sherwood is used to collaborating with animals — and connects with them on a fundamental level. “Dressage is all about understanding a horse through the feel of your body; it’s like inventing another language,” says Sherwood. “What I’m interested in lately is the difference between what we assume animals think and how they actually behave.” In her new solo show, “Crossing the Wild Line,” at Denny Gallery on the Lower East Side, Sherwood takes nature’s pulse by way of an unlikely combination of media: pastry, video and drawing.

headline: Obama Confronts Americans’ Fears in State of the Union Speech
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: In his final State of the Union message, the president urged Americans to confront the challenges of the future by rejecting fear and embracing change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday set forth an ambitious vision for America’s future but conceded his own failure to heal the political divisions holding back progress, calling it a lasting disappointment of his tenure.

headline: English Doctors Share Frustrations
abstract: Junior doctors in London staged a strike against government plans to reform pay and work hours. They joined their colleagues across the country for the first protest in 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Junior doctors in London staged a strike against government plans to reform pay and work hours. They joined their colleagues across the country for the first protest in 40 years.

headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Part of Florida Death Penalty
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Jury System', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Sixth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: A court majority ruled that juries were not given sufficient say over which inmates should be put to death.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court struck down an aspect of Florida’s capital punishment system on Tuesday, saying it did not give jurors a sufficient role in deciding whether defendants should be put to death.

headline: Turkish Ambassador’s View
abstract: Serdar Kilic discusses the Turkish president’s reference to “Hitler’s Germany” and the country’s treatment of Kurds.

headline: Ad Backing Jeb Bush Calls Marco Rubio Untrustworthy on Immigration
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, has released its third negative ad criticizing Senator Marco Rubio, this time attacking him over his record on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, has released its third advertisement criticizing Senator Marco Rubio, this time attacking him over immigration. The ad is called “Vane” — no doubt a deliberate homophone.

headline: Directors Guild Nominates ‘Revenant,’ ‘Spotlight’ and ‘Big Short’
abstract: “Mad Max” and “Martian” also make the Directors Guild list, but “Carol” is shut out.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro G. Iñárritu (“The Revenant”), Tom McCarthy (“Spotlight”), and Adam McKay (“The Big Short”) were among the feature film nominees chosen as the year’s best by the 15,000-member Directors Guild of America, whose final winners — to be announced at a ceremony on Feb. 6 — often hew closely to pictures that win an Academy Award. Since 2000, all but three Directors Guild winners (“Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” “Brokeback Mountain” and “Gravity”) went on to claim the best picture Oscar.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Backing of Food Services Union
abstract: The United Food and Commercial Workers Union will endorse Hillary Clinton, giving the Democratic candidate a welcome boost as polls in Iowa and New Hampshire show Senator Bernie Sanders gaining ground.
lead_paragraph: The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union will endorse Hillary Clinton on Tuesday, giving the Democratic candidate a welcome boost as polls in Iowa and New Hampshire show Senator Bernie Sanders gaining ground.

headline: Witness Recalls the Moment of Blast
abstract: A man who saw the explosion in Istanbul’s central district of Sultanahmet on Tuesday recounts what he saw.
lead_paragraph: A man who saw the explosion in Istanbul’s central district of Sultanahmet on Tuesday recounts what he saw.

headline: David Chang Opens Momofuku Nishi in Chelsea
abstract: Also, pick your pasta and sauce at Aunt Jake’s; high-end food stalls near Pennsylvania Station; and movies and meatballs in Bushwick.
lead_paragraph: Momofuku Nishi Word got out last Friday that David Chang would open his latest venture that evening at 6. A long line had formed outside the Chelsea restaurant by 5 p.m. By 6:15, plates of food were streaming to the bare wood communal tables. Mr. Chang was there, baseball cap pulled low, describing how he had originally envisioned a fast-food model but changed his mind in favor of a restaurant with a decidedly eclectic menu. It hints of Italy, but in the hands of Joshua Pinsky, the chef, the bagna cauda winks at Caesar salad, and cacio e pepe swaps out the cheese for fermented chickpeas to become ceci e pepe. There’s no shortage of noodles, and the menu is deciphered with playful footnotes. Reservations will be taken in a few weeks: 232 Eighth Avenue (West 22nd Street), 646-518-1919, nishi.momofuku.com.

headline: Shona McCarthy New Head of Edinburgh Fringe
abstract: Shona McCarthy succeeds Kath Mainland as chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society.
lead_paragraph: Shona McCarthy, an arts leader and consultant, has been appointed chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society, the organization that oversees the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest multi-arts festival in the world. Ms. McCarthy, who will take over in early March, assumes a post currently occupied by Kath Mainland, who has run the Society for seven years. Ms. Mainland announced in November that she was stepping down to become executive director of the Melbourne Festival.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Ducks Try to Reclaim Edge on Kings
abstract: Anaheim, which took over regional supremacy last season but has struggled to score, will meet first-place Los Angeles for the first time this season on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players. (All times Eastern.)

headline: Video Is Said to Show the Moments Before a Suspected Gang Rape in Brooklyn
abstract: A smartphone video that defense lawyers said showed a verbal encounter before a suspected rape at a Brooklyn playground emerged on Tuesday, after a fifth suspect was arrested.
lead_paragraph: A smartphone video that its owner and defense lawyers said showed a brief verbal encounter before a suspected gang rape at a Brooklyn playground emerged on Tuesday, another development in an increasingly complex inquiry that has roiled the city.

headline: Mark Morris to Choreograph a New Full-Length Work
abstract: The work, “Layla and Majnun,” is to have its premiere in Berkeley, Calif., in September.
lead_paragraph: The Mark Morris Dance Group has announced that Mr. Morris is to choreograph a full-length dance narrative, “Layla and Majnun,” based on a love story that has its origins in seventh-century Persia. It is to have its premiere in Berkeley, Calif., in September. The music, live as always with Mr. Morris, will involve Azerbaijani mugham, a complex combination of music and poetry, to be performed on both traditional and Western instruments by the Silk Road Ensemble with the father and daughter Azerbaijani vocalists Alim Qasimov and Fargana Qasimova.

headline: F.D.A. Nominee Clears One Hurdle, but Others Remain
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'Salmon', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Dr. Robert M. Califf’s candidacy as the head of the Food and Drug Administration is likely to be blocked over the agency’s approval of genetically engineered salmon.
lead_paragraph: A crucial Senate committee on Tuesday voted unanimously to approve Dr. Robert M. Califf, a cardiologist and clinical trial expert from Duke University, as the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. Approval by the full Senate, however, is unlikely to happen soon, because Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska has pledged to block his candidacy over the agency’s approval of genetically engineered salmon.

headline: Readers Respond to the Lonesome Single Men of New York
abstract: Nearly 900 comments have greeted our article on the middle-aged New York bachelors who lamented where they have ended up.
lead_paragraph: A storm of readers’ comments — over 650 on The New York Times’s site and over 200 on The Times’s main Facebook page — followed the posting of “Meet the Bachelors Who Yearn for Something More,” an article by Sridhar Pappu on aging single men in New York.

headline: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.
lead_paragraph: Hopping from one interview to the next, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York hit the news media circuit to convey the urgency of the surprise executive order he issued last week requiring local governments to move homeless people off the streets when the temperature goes below freezing.

headline: Putin Doesn’t Rule Out Asylum in Moscow for Syria’s Assad
abstract: The Russian president told a German newspaper it was premature to discuss Mr. Assad’s future but not impossible the dictator would relocate to Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There has long been speculation about whether President Bashar al-Assad of Syria might one day join the list of cashiered dictators who call Moscow — or at least its plush, gated suburbs like Rublovka — home.

headline: Hillary Clinton Accuses Bernie Sanders of Not Standing Up to Gun Lobby
abstract: Hillary Clinton, appearing with the president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, attacked Bernie Sanders on his 2005 vote to shield gunmakers from lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa – With Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont taking the lead in a new Iowa caucus poll, Hillary Clinton sharply challenged his core political message on Tuesday, saying his denunciations of big-money special interests were undercut by his 2005 congressional vote for a bill granting legal immunity for gun manufacturers – a bill backed by the National Rifle Association.

headline: Reducing the Stress on Students
abstract: Readers’ suggestions include bringing back the “joy in learning,” avoiding the “Harvard-or-bust mentality” and reducing overscheduling.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The David Bowie Song That Fans Are Listening to Most: ‘Heroes’

lead_paragraph: A chart of the songs Spotify users listened to most after David Bowie’s death.

headline: Bill Foster, Coach Who Set Duke on Winning Track, Dies at 86
abstract: Mike Krzyzewski has become associated with Duke’s rise as a basketball power, but it was his predecessor, Foster, who re-energized the program after it had languished in mediocrity.
lead_paragraph: Bill Foster, a basketball coach who specialized in reviving underperforming college teams and achieved success at a handful of programs, most notably Duke, which he guided to the national final in 1978, died on Jan. 7 in Chicago. He was 86.

headline: Republican Candidates Grapple With a Touchy Topic: Poverty
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Poverty', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: With the primaries bearing down, six presidential hopefuls ponder how to cut government without further harming the poor and helpless.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — On Saturday, only three weeks before voters in Iowa first get to weigh in on the presidential candidates, six Republican hopefuls gathered at a convention center here to talk about poverty. Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, the top two, weren’t there. But still, poverty?

headline: Chris Christie, in State of the State Speech, Pledges He Won’t Fade Away
keywords: ['State of the State Message (NJ)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The governor said on Tuesday that he had pulled the state “back from the economic brink” and that he had no intention of abandoning his policy approaches on the state level.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, facing emboldened Democratic opponents at home and the first sustained attacks from his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, used his State of the State address here on Tuesday to promise lawmakers, or perhaps to warn them, that he would not fade away in the final years of his second term.

headline: How to Transform Penn Station: Move the Garden
abstract: It is encouraging that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has championed Penn Station’s cause, but he’s passed on the really big idea: moving Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo entreated New Yorkers last week to “think big” again, invoking Robert Moses, New York’s take-no-prisoners planning czar of the 20th century.

headline: A.I.G. Investors Unhappy With Insurer’s Strategy, Advisory Firm Says
abstract: An online questionnaire from Sanford C. Bernstein & Company found that A.I.G. investors wanted the insurer to sell or spin off businesses to better focus its operation.
lead_paragraph: If the American International Group’s chief executive, Peter D. Hancock, was planning to essentially maintain the status quo at the insurer, he should probably expect resistance from investors.

headline: 3-Year-Old Finds Gun in Dad’s Store, and Old Story Plays Out
abstract: The gun was at the Lumberton, N.C., convenience store for protection. The boy got his hands on it, and joined the roster of children killed in shootings.
lead_paragraph: The 3-year-old was sitting on a stool behind the counter near the cash register while his father, the owner of a small convenience store in North Carolina, chatted with a customer on Sunday.

headline: ‘Bellwether’ G.M. Trial Opens Over Defect Claim
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a federal courtroom in Manhattan, General Motors raised questions about the story of a man who was injured in a 2014 accident in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: While acknowledging its role in failing to report a deadly defect for more than a decade, General Motors on Tuesday forcefully questioned the story of a man who was injured in a May 2014 crash and is suing the company.

headline: Volvo Makes a Comeback, With a Detour Through China
abstract: Even the smallest auto companies are flourishing in the booming American market, none more so than this tiny Chinese-owned, Swedish-run luxury brand.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Record sales in the American auto industry have left the biggest carmakers flush with cash, which they are pouring into new models on display this week at the annual North American International Auto Show here.

headline: 45 Whales Die on Indian Shore
abstract: Scores of whales washed ashore near the Tiruchendur beach in the state of Tamil Nadu. Though many were towed back to sea, 45 died.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Scores of large, short-finned pilot whales washed ashore in southern India, an official said Tuesday, and 45 have died on a beach. But many others have been guided back to sea.

headline: Op-Photo: Visiting the Oregon Protesters, in Revolutionary Costume
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: A man dressed as one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence recently visited the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, currently occupied by armed protesters.
lead_paragraph: A man dressed as one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence visited the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon on January 10. The refuge is currently occupied by armed protesters led by Ammon Bundy.

headline: Man Cuddles 1,500-Pound Bear (and Lives to Share the Video)
abstract: The story behind a popular Facebook video posted by a rehabilitation center for animals in New York State.
lead_paragraph: After a video was posted to Facebook that showed a man attempting to cuddle with a Kodiak bear, over 11 million people had a logical response: Click.

headline: Video Review: With the S60, Volvo Adds a Sedan to Its Cross Country Line
abstract: The car is 2.6 inches higher than the standard S60 and gets decent fuel economy, but trunk space is a serious shortcoming.
lead_paragraph: VOLVO’S Cross Country line has been a hit that automakers dream of. Raising the height, adding all-wheel drive and dressing it in Fjallraven-like cladding gave their wagons the likability of s’mores.

headline: Puerto Rico Utility’s Debt Plan Still Fragile, Lawmakers Are Told
abstract: A House subcommittee heard testimony that a restructuring plan for the electric monopoly still needs approval by the island’s legislature.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Puerto Rico’s troubled electric monopoly, mired in about $9 billion of debt, stands to run out of money by midsummer if its hard-won plans to restructure fall through — something that could happen this month, a top official of the utility told a congressional panel on Tuesday.

headline: Residents in Whitesboro, N.Y., Vote to Keep a Much-Criticized Village Emblem
abstract: For the past four decades, people have debated the appropriateness of a village seal showing a white man wrestling a Native American man to the ground.
lead_paragraph: The official emblems of towns and villages generally attract little attention. Often pastoral, they are generally gentle and unassuming. Not so the seal of the Village of Whitesboro, in central New York.

headline: Street Style in London
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'London Fashion Week', 'Fashion Shows']
abstract: The looks on the streets during London Men’s Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The looks on the streets during London Men’s Fashion Week.

headline: David Bowie (1947-2016)
abstract: The British legend wrote songs above all about being an outsider: an alien, a misfit, a sexual adventurer, a faraway astronaut.
lead_paragraph: The British legend wrote songs above all about being an outsider: an alien, a misfit, a sexual adventurer, a faraway astronaut.

headline: How The Times Prepares for Convention Coverage, and ‘Who Is Larry Doby?’
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Republican National Convention', 'Baseball', 'Walking', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs']
abstract: Walter Baranger, who participated in a convention site walk-through in Cleveland, writes about campaign coverage and surprise swag.

headline: Monte Irvin, Star Outfielder Who Lost His Prime to Racism, Dies at 96
abstract: Irvin, among the most talented players in the Negro leagues, was already 30 when he joined the New York Giants in 1949. “I was way past my peak then,” he later said.
lead_paragraph: Monte Irvin, the New York Giants outfielder who was one of the first outstanding black players in the major leagues and a Hall of Famer for his brilliance in the Negro leagues, where he spent most of his prime years before baseball’s color barrier was shattered, died on Monday night at his home in Houston. He was 96.

headline: Facts & Figures: Cruz’s Canadian Birth Could Matter in Iowa
abstract: Forty-seven percent of likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa think someone born outside the country shouldn’t be able to be president.
lead_paragraph: Forty-seven percent of likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa do not think someone born outside the United States should be able to become president, according to a new survey by Public Policy Polling. That could pose some difficulty for Ted Cruz, who was born in Canada.

headline: Review: In Fox’s ‘Second Chance,’ a Life Resurrected
abstract: A corrupt onetime sheriff is brought back to life by a Frankenstein-style duo after he dies in this new series, raising the question of whether he will make amends.
lead_paragraph: The Frankenstein genre and the buddy cop genre may seem a long way from each other, but “Second Chance,” which begins on Wednesday night on Fox, is born of both. And it’s aptly titled. The premiere has so much going on and is so absurd that you may be tempted not to return, but give it another try. Rewards await.

headline: Review: At American Realness Festival, Mirrored Movements and a Nearly Naked Yvonne Meier
abstract: Sizing up the world premiere of Jillian Peña’s “Panopticon” and works by Keith Hennessy, Jassem Hindi and Ms. Meier, at Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: In Greek mythology, Panoptes was a giant with a hundred eyes. In architecture, the panopticon, a circular building designed so that everything can be seen from its center, was sometimes used for prisons. Then there’s the choreographer Jillian Peña, who, like a modern-day Panoptes, is obsessed by the notion of multiples. On Saturday afternoon, as part of the American Realness festival, Ms. Peña offered the premiere of “Panopticon,” in which one dancer serves as a mirror to the other. Unfortunately, it wasn’t the best reflection of her experiments in twinning.

headline: The Biggest Powerball Jackpot Ever: The Odds and Where the Money Goes
abstract: Where does all that lottery money go? Answers to key questions on a record Powerball drawing.
lead_paragraph: News flash: Your chances of winning the Powerball jackpot are not great — just one in 292.2 million. Still, with the next drawing scheduled for Wednesday at 10:59 p.m. Eastern time, ticket sales are going through the roof around the country.

headline: Review: ‘Museum of Memories’ Explores What’s Left of a Life Lost
abstract: Suicide is at the heart of “Museum of Memories,” a production of the European company New International Encounter.
lead_paragraph: The young man is dead, and we know this because he tells us so himself. “When I died it was my heart that stopped beating,” Markus says gently, no grievance in his tone. Death is what he wanted, at least at the time.

headline: Review: In ‘Intimacy,’ What They Did for Love
abstract: The piece by the Australian company Ranters Theater is said to be based on a series of conversations with strangers.
lead_paragraph: “What’s the most extreme thing you’ve done out of love for someone else?”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Iran Seizes U.S. Sailors Amid Claims of Spying
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American officials said that the military had lost contact with the boats in the Persian Gulf and that Iran had promised to return the sailors soon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran seized two United States Navy patrol boats and 10 crew members who were described as “trespassing” on Tuesday in Iranian waters near a major naval base.

headline: Jan. 12, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, South Africa and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, South Africa and India.

headline: Review: A Woman Grows Up in ‘Employee of the Year’
abstract: The life story of a woman is told in this show from the company 600 Highwaymen, but the actors are 9 or 10 years old.
lead_paragraph: “Employee of the Year” was performed in October 2014 as part of the Crossing the Line festival. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwood’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 17, 2014; the full text is online here. The play continues through Sunday as part of the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, Manhattan; 212-967-7555, undertheradarfestival.com.

headline: California Rejects VW’s Diesel Recall Plan
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The company’s proposal for repairing vehicles equipped with a device to cheat on emissions tests is “substantially deficient,” state regulators said.
lead_paragraph: Regulators in California on Tuesday formally rejected Volkswagen’s plan to fix its polluting diesel engines, underscoring their frustration with the German automaker’s ability to repair its defective vehicles.

headline: Weary of Chaos, Factions in Libya Consider Peace
abstract: Four years after Libya’s revolution, warring factions in Misurata have taken steps toward peace that could help lift the country out of war.
lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — Four years after Libya’s revolution, the scars of war are still visible in this city — buildings pockmarked with bullet and rocket holes, graffiti on the walls remembering fallen fighters, and a war museum where rusty ammunition spills across the sidewalk in front.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Rod Nordland, Donald G. McNeil Jr. and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: PAC Backing Jeb Bush Counters Campaign Message With Ad Critical of Marco Rubio
abstract: While Jeb Bush is portraying himself as a serious candidate for serious times, the “super PAC” supporting him is running attack ads against Marco Rubio.
lead_paragraph: GRINNELL, Iowa — The messages coming out of the political world of Jeb Bush could not be more different.

headline: A ‘Barbie From Outer Space’ Touches Down on a New Stage
abstract: Erin Markey, whose new play is about to open at the Abrons Arts Center, has developed a cult following through performances that mix humor, songs and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: After belting out the moody opening song of her new musical, “A Ride on the Irish Cream,” Erin Markey, her long hair swaying across a microphone stand in the rehearsal room, paused to give her band notes.

headline: Mats Ek, the Swedish Choreographer, Says His Goodbye Isn’t Quite a Farewell
abstract: Mr. Ek, 70, a major figure in the European dance world, is calling a two-year halt to performances of his works.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Last dance for the choreographer Mats Ek,” France Musique declared. “Mats Ek, the great Swedish choreographer, leaves the stage after 50 years of creation,” Les Echos said. “The choreographer removes his works from the stage,” Le Figaro reported in an article headlined “Mats Ek: The Shock of Farewell.”

headline: ‘Bowie Again!’ Fashion Critic’s Notebook
abstract: The fashion critic Vanessa Friedman started working on a piece about Mr. Bowie’s legacy the morning after learning of his death.
lead_paragraph: Emails about how best to report on the formative relationship David Bowie had with the fashion industry started to swirl through the Style section (and between the Style and Culture sections) as soon as we heard news of Mr. Bowie’s death.

headline: Review: Jane Mayer’s ‘Dark Money,’ About the Koch Brothers’ Fortune and Influence
abstract: In “Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right,” Ms. Mayer reports on David and Charles Koch’s empire and political influence.
lead_paragraph: When Jane Mayer published her 10,000-word article about Charles and David Koch in The New Yorker in August 2010, David Koch denounced her piece in print and, as she reports in her new book, “Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right,” a “private investigative firm with powerful political and law enforcement connections was retained.” While there was no hard evidence on who had hired the firm, “clues leading back to the Kochs were everywhere.”

headline: Teenagers, Fire and a Video Camera. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: The Pennsylvania State Police said two 13-year-olds had been charged with disorderly conduct after one boy lit the other on fire — with his approval.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate the resolve — or lack of judgment — of teenage boys seeking Internet fame.

headline: Report Is Expected to Detail Corruption in World Track and Field
abstract: The report, to be released Thursday as the second installment from a commission investigating doping allegations, is expected to focus on officials accused of blackmailing athletes.
lead_paragraph: A report to be released Thursday is expected to describe bribery and corruption at the highest levels of international track and field, two months after the sport was shaken by revelations of a state-sponsored doping system in Russia that implicated athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors, laboratories and the country’s antidoping authorities.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Say Binding Promise in 2005 Should Prevent Prosecution
abstract: Lawyers say the former Montgomery County district attorney, Bruce Castor, made a binding promise not to prosecute Mr. Cosby in the Andrea Constand case.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s lawyers have made it clear in court papers that they plan to use a former district attorney who once declined to prosecute the entertainer as a critical weapon in their effort to battle sexual assault charges filed against him last month in Pennsylvania.

headline: New York City Opera Will Return, and Soon, Under Reorganization Plan
abstract: The venerable opera company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in 2013, will be taken over by the NYCO Renaissance, which hopes to use the City Opera name by next week.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera is coming back under new management.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Google Picks Former Obama Adviser to Lead Global Public Policy
abstract: Caroline Atkinson, who left her position as a White House deputy national security adviser last month, will join Google in March and be based in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Google, facing increased scrutiny from European regulators, has hired a former senior adviser to President Obama to lead its global public policy team.

headline: Review: ‘Teachers,’ Expanded From Web to Television
abstract: This show on TV Land is about six inappropriate elementary schoolteachers played by the comedy ensemble the Katydids.
lead_paragraph: “Teachers,” born as a web series and now expanded by TV Land into a half-hour comedy, is convincing evidence that more can be less. The series, which begins on Wednesday night, is about six inappropriate and inept elementary school teachers, characters who were subtly sharp in webisodes of a few minutes’ duration. In 30-minute increments, they grow a bit wearying.

headline: Rebuilding of Nepali Homes Hit by Quakes Is Still Delayed, Official Says
abstract: The reconstruction of houses destroyed in earthquakes will not begin until April, a year after the first tremors hit, a Nepali official has said.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The reconstruction of houses destroyed in Nepal’s devastating earthquakes last year will not begin until April, a year after the first tremors hit, the newly appointed head of Nepal’s Reconstruction Authority has said.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: David Bowie, Istanbul, Bernie Sanders
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.S. Restricts Movement of Salamanders, for Their Own Good
abstract: Scientists hope that a rule making it illegal to import salamanders or move them across state lines, will help stop a deadly fungus.
lead_paragraph: The Fish and Wildlife Service is barring the door against 201 species of salamanders, making it illegal to import them or move them across state lines, the agency announced on Tuesday. Scientists hope the ban will help prevent a devastating outbreak from driving native salamander species extinct.

headline: Saudi Arabia Arrests Samar Badawi, Human Rights Advocate
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The arrest of Ms. Badawi, who has pushed for more rights for women, is the kingdom’s latest effort to clamp down on dissent, advocacy groups said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia arrested a prominent human rights activist on Tuesday in what advocacy groups called the kingdom’s latest effort to clamp down on dissent.

headline: From Chicago to Broadway
abstract: “Aida,” “Light in the Piazza” and other musicals that played in Chicago before Broadway.
lead_paragraph: “Aida,” “Light in the Piazza” and other musicals that played in Chicago before Broadway.

headline: Before Broadway, Musicals Make a Detour to Test the Waters in Chicago
abstract: A city with a large population and a sizable base of experienced showgoers helps gauge what theatergoers might make of a new production.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the director Jerry Mitchell was looking for a place to try out a new musical about a struggling shoe company saved by a drag queen, he picked Chicago because the city was familiar (Mr. Mitchell grew up in the Midwest) and the audiences friendly (compared with New York).

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the State of the Presidential Race
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News national poll finds a significant narrowing of the race for the Democratic nomination while Donald Trump maintains his sizable lead among Republican primary voters.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News national poll finds a significant narrowing of the race for the Democratic nomination while Donald Trump maintains his sizable lead among Republican primary voters.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A New York Times/CBS News poll finds a sharp generational divide within the Democratic Party, with voters under 45 favoring Mr. Sanders.
lead_paragraph: As the first nominating contest approaches, Hillary Clinton’s commanding lead nationally in the Democratic primary has largely melted away, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: At the London Men’s Shows, Sprinters and Marathoners Alike
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: The breakneck pace of modern life finds varied expression in collections from Christopher Kane, J.W. Anderson, Grace Wales Bonner and others.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The new year has barely begun before the men’s fashion season does.

headline: State of the Union: Reasons for Optimism
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Unemployment', 'Birth Rates', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Some of the positive statistics President Obama could cite: fewer gun homicide deaths, more babies, lower unemployment and cheaper fuel.
lead_paragraph: President Obama told the nation Tuesday night what he thought is the state of the union. Republicans got to respond. Our take? Things are pretty good. We offer a few indicators that give us reason to be optimistic, though, as with most things, there are always caveats.

headline: Chelsea Clinton, Again Her Mother’s Surrogate, Takes Up the Fight Against Bernie Sanders
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In returning to the presidential campaign trail for the first time since 2008, Chelsea Clinton focused on motherhood and attacked Senator Bernie Sanders over his health care and education proposals.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Again playing the part of candidate surrogate — though with a message now tailored to young parents like herself — Chelsea Clinton spoke of motherhood Tuesday on the New Hampshire trail while also amplifying her mother’s increasing attacks on Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: Uber Invites Developers to Build Apps for Customized Passenger Distractions
abstract: The idea, the company says, is to give riders access to information and entertainment that interest them during their time in Uber cars.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the huge ride-hailing service, delivers millions of rides to passengers. Now the company wants to give people something to do while they’re in the car.

headline: Louisiana’s New Governor Signs an Order to Expand Medicaid
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Governors (US)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: John Bel Edwards acted to fulfill a campaign pledge tied to the Affordable Care Act and aimed at aiding hundreds of thousands of state residents.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — On Tuesday, his second day in office, Gov. John Bel Edwards signed an executive order expanding Medicaid coverage under the Affordable Care Act, fulfilling a campaign promise that will expand health coverage to hundreds of thousands of people in one of the nation’s poorest states.

abstract: The plea from the United Nations humanitarian coordinator for Syria cited sick and malnourished residents in Madaya, some resembling “skeletons that are now barely moving.”
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The head of the United Nations’ relief efforts for Syria pleaded with all warring parties on Tuesday to lift their sieges on key towns and let aid agencies deliver food and medical care to people stuck behind front lines.

keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The hedge fund Lion Point Capital has proposed two candidates for the board of Ally Financial and urged the company to explore strategic alternatives.
lead_paragraph: When the financier Saul P. Steinberg tried to take over Chemical Bank in 1969, he drew the ire of the governor of New York.

headline: Ted Cruz Suggests Donald Trump Is Taking Cues From Democrats
abstract: Ted Cruz, facing persistent elbows from Donald J. Trump over his Canadian birth, delivered his most forceful response yet on Tuesday, suggesting that Mr. Trump was catering to Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz, facing persistent elbows from Donald J. Trump over his Canadian birth, delivered his most forceful response yet on Tuesday, knocking Mr. Trump’s “New York values,” questioning his knowledge of foreign affairs and suggesting that the billionaire developer was taking his cues from Democrats.

headline: Hillary Clinton, a Surging Rival and the Return of the ‘Magic Wand’
abstract: As the polls tighten in Hillary Clinton’s primary fight against Senator Bernie Sanders, her language is starting to carry echoes from a similar point in 2008, when Senator Barack Obama started surging.
lead_paragraph: As the polls tighten in Hillary Clinton’s primary fight against Senator Bernie Sanders, her language is starting to carry echoes from a similar point in 2008, when Senator Barack Obama started surging.

headline: With Lincoln Continental Reborn, Ford Renews Push Into China
abstract: At the Detroit auto show, Ford executives said they were undaunted by the economic troubles in China and were pressing ahead with their global plans for the car.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Last April, Ford Motor announced with fanfare that it would reintroduce its storied Lincoln Continental luxury sedan, with an eye on sales in the expanding Chinese market.

headline: With N.F.L. Relocation Fates in Owners’ Hands, the Games Begin
abstract: With 32 wealthy owners and billions of dollars at stake in an effort to put a team or teams back in Los Angeles, nothing is clear or simple.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — On paper, the choices have been clear for months when it comes to the N.F.L.’s big, probably imminent return to Los Angeles.

headline: Millions Leave Native Lands, With Broad Repercussions
abstract: According to the latest United Nations estimates, 244 million people, or 3.3 percent of the world’s population, live in a country other than the one where they were born.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Humanity is on the move, but we are traipsing across the globe a bit less than you might think.

headline: Koch Executive Disputes Book’s Account of Founder’s Role in Nazi Refinery
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A senior executive of Koch Industries on Tuesday sent a letter to the company’s employees disputing a new book about the Kochs and other conservative families, saying it significantly exaggerated the role of the company’s founder, Fred C. Koch, in constructing an important refinery for the Nazi regime in Germany.
lead_paragraph: A senior executive of Koch Industries sent a letter on Tuesday to the company’s employees disputing a new book about the Kochs and other conservative families, saying it significantly exaggerated the role of the company’s founder, Fred C. Koch, in constructing an important refinery for the Nazi regime in Germany.

headline: A Conversation With Moshe Shuster
abstract: Mr. Shuster, 71, is the founder of VRE Development. Its condominium developments in Manhattan include the Charles and the Lumiere.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Shuster, 71, is the founder and president of VRE Development, which does business as the Victor Group. The company, with headquarters in Wall, N.J., and an office in Manhattan, was previously known as Victor Homes. Its condominium developments in Manhattan include the Charles and the Lumiere, and its current projects include 281 Fifth Avenue and the Getty, at 239 10th Avenue.

headline: New Attack Ads Call Marco Rubio a Flip-Flopper on Immigration
abstract: Ads from “super PACs” backing Ted Cruz and Jeb Bush also paint Mr. Rubio as being overly close to President Obama and Senator Chuck Schumer.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio is getting savaged on the topic of immigration reform, with ads from groups backing two of his rivals painting him as a flip-flopper and as overly close to President Obama and Senator Chuck Schumer.

headline: ‘Serial’ Podcast, Needing More Reporting Time, Goes Biweekly
abstract: A producer said a 14-day window between episodes of a podcast about Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was needed to accommodate “narrative developments.”
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of every episode of “Serial,” the host, Sarah Koenig, opens with these words: “From This American Life and WBEZ Chicago, it’s ‘Serial,’ one story told week by week.”

headline: Maryland: Trial in Freddie Gray Death Complicated by Appeals Schedule
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The trial of Officer Caesar R. Goodson Jr. has another scheduling obstacle, an appeals court set March 4 for oral arguments for another officer who is trying to avoid testifying.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Officer Caesar R. Goodson Jr. of the Baltimore police, charged with murder in the death of Freddie Gray, encountered another scheduling obstacle Tuesday when an appeals court set March 4 for oral arguments in the appeal of another officer who is trying to avoid testifying. On Monday, the Court of Special Appeals said the Goodson trial may not go forward until it hears the appeal of the other officer, William G. Porter, whose own trial on manslaughter charges ended in a deadlocked jury last month. The state considers Officer Porter its star witness in the Goodson case, but he is trying to assert his Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate himself. The legal wrangling could alter the schedules of four other officers facing charges in the death of Mr. Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody in April. The death set off riots in Baltimore.

headline: David Margulies, ‘Ghostbusters’ Mayor and Tony Soprano’s Lawyer, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Margulies, a versatile character actor, performed in scores of supporting stage, film and television roles.
lead_paragraph: David Margulies, a versatile character actor who performed in scores of supporting stage, film and television roles but was most conspicuous as the common-sense mayor in “Ghostbusters” and as Tony Soprano’s sleazy lawyer, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Florida’s Death Machine Loses Again
abstract: The Supreme Court finally strikes down an unconstitutional law requiring a judge, not a jury, to sentence someone to death.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three Supreme Court terms, the justices have struck down a Florida law that treated the Constitution as little more than a speed bump on the road to quicker and easier death sentences.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case Involving Judgments Against Iran
abstract: The Supreme Court will consider whether Congress acted constitutionally in passing a 2012 law that helps families of victims of terrorist attacks collect judgments against Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Iranian government has come under sharp criticism for not giving imprisoned Americans a fair and public court hearing. But on Wednesday at the Supreme Court, Iran will get just that.

headline: College Football Championship Game TV Viewership Drops 23 Percent
abstract: Alabama’s 45-40 victory over Clemson on Monday night drew an average of 25.7 million viewers on ESPN, a substantial drop from the 33.4 million who watched last year’s game.
lead_paragraph: Alabama’s 45-40 victory over Clemson in the College Football Playoff championship game Monday night on ESPN drew an average of 25.7 million viewers, a 23 percent drop from the 33.4 million who watched last year, when Ohio State beat Oregon.

headline: Board for Ferguson Schools Is Accused of Racial Bias
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A lawsuit against the Ferguson-Florissant School District board argues that at-large voting discriminates against minorities.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — In a suburban school district that includes most of Ferguson and 10 other towns in northern St. Louis County, three of four students are black. Yet there have never been more than two black members on the seven-person school board at the same time. Does that mean the system of electing the board is racially biased?

headline: A Guardian Is Accused of Holding 2 Teenagers Captive in Queens for Years
abstract: Sook Yeong Park was charged with labor trafficking, third-degree assault and endangering the welfare of a child for her treatment of two teenagers from South Korea.
lead_paragraph: She was regularly missing from her classes at Francis Lewis High School in Queens, and when she was there, teachers would catch the girl, a 16-year-old from South Korea, nodding off during lessons.

headline: Rookie’s English Needs Work, but His Game Is Thriving
abstract: For Blackhawks left wing Artemi Panarin, a Russian, the language of hockey takes over at the rink, and he has responded by becoming one of the top first-year players in the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Artemi Panarin stood before his locker in the corner of the dressing room, virtually hidden from sight. Engulfed by an ever-growing semicircle of visitors, he began to fidget, searching for any possible escape route from what had become another uncomfortable interrogation.

headline: MetLife Weighs Split of Retail Business
keywords: ['Life Insurance', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The insurer is weighing several options, including an I.P.O., to create a company better able to compete with smaller life insurance and annuity providers.
lead_paragraph: The giant insurer MetLife said on Tuesday that it was exploring spinning off its retail life and annuity business in the United States because of financial pressures it is facing under regulations put in place in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: U.N. to Help U.S. Screen Central American Migrants
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The program is aimed at people fleeing El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras and would involve setting up processing centers in several other Latin American countries.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is turning to the United Nations to help screen migrants fleeing violence in Central America, senior administration officials said Tuesday, and to help set up processing centers in several Latin American countries in the hopes of stemming a flood of families crossing the southern border illegally.

headline: Jersey Shore Town Deems a Seaside Pavilion a Monumental Mistake
abstract: Meant as a tribute to the resiliency of Highlands, N.J., after Hurricane Sandy, a concrete structure donated by a nonprofit construction trade group has instead become a point of contention.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLANDS, N.J. — The story of how an angular, concrete pavilion that weighs more than a fully loaded Boeing 767 jet wound up on a patch of beach here is complex enough. Getting rid of it may be even more complicated.

headline: Rams Moving to Los Angeles Area, and Chargers Could Join Them
abstract: With their move approved by the team owners, the Rams will give the Los Angeles area its first N.F.L. team since the Rams and the Raiders left in 1995. The Chargers have the option to join them as soon as next season.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After more than two decades, the N.F.L. has found its way back to Los Angeles.

headline: Standing in the Way of a Community Court in Brooklyn
abstract: For six years, officials have tried to open a court in the Brownsville area to curb incarceration, based on a model in Red Hook. But a City Council member has effectively vetoed it.
lead_paragraph: Brownsville, Brooklyn, is the capital of the flaring atrocity, the moment of horror that vanishes in the blink of an eye from the view of the city beyond.

headline: Fervor in Oregon Compound and Fear Outside It
abstract: While life in the compound taken over by armed protesters at Malheur National Wildlife Refuge exhibits a mix of the mundane and the insurrectionary, many nearby residents want them to leave.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — Deep inside the federal wildlife compound where armed citizens have been garrisoned for more than a week, 9-year-old Zoey Justus was preparing a snack platter for the occupiers — fruit, cheese, Ritz crackers — and her parents were explaining why they had brought her to an armed insurrection.

headline: Implant for Opioid Addicts Urged for Federal Approval
abstract: A panel of medical experts recommended to the F.D.A. that the implant, Probuphine, be approved to deliver doses of buprenorphine — one of the most common medical treatments for addicts.
lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — A panel of medical experts recommended Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new way of treating opioid addicts, using a slender rod implanted into the arm that delivers medicine for months at a time. Some doctors say it could help ease the national epidemic of drug overdoses.

headline: Mexico: Actors Who Met El Chapo Are Not Targets of Inquiry

The government had been unclear about the nature of the investigation in recent days, with some outlets reporting that the pair were under investigation for their secret meeting with Mr. Guzmán in early October.

headline: The Age of Protest
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'News and News Media']
abstract: It’s no wonder people are morally aroused by the behavior they are exposed to. But beware when moral arousal manifests as moral outrage.
lead_paragraph: If you go to The Guardian’s website these days you can find a section that is just labeled “Protest.” So now, with your morning coffee, you can get your news, weather, sports — and protests. I found stories there headlined, “Five Fresh Ideas for the Street Art Agitator in 2016,” “Muslim Woman Ejected From Donald Trump Rally After Silent Protest” and, appropriately, “We Are Living in an Age of Protest.”

headline: Where Police Violence Encounters Mental Illness
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police']
abstract: There is a crisis in police violence, but there is also a crisis in mental health services that we leave to the police to solve.
lead_paragraph: NEARLY 20 years ago, I was a social worker in a county jail where I first began to understand just how frequently the police deal with people with mental illnesses. Run-ins with the police were a regular occurrence for many of my clients, with officers often knowing them by name. They were overwhelmingly poor, and poor people with mental illnesses are also likely to experience homelessness and substance abuse — issues that place them at increased risk of police contact and incarceration.

headline: Teach Your Teachers Well
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Principals (School)']
abstract: We can’t regulate our way to higher teacher quality. To help our children, we need to nurture their teachers.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, at the urging of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s Board of Regents suspended the use of state tests to evaluate teachers. This is a wise first step, but it won’t improve our schools unless we go further and build a professionalized system of support that views teachers as learners and challenges them to improve their classroom practices.

headline: Poland Deviates From Democracy
abstract: Poland’s retreat from the fundamental values of liberal democracy is reprehensible and foolish.
lead_paragraph: It has been distressing these past weeks to watch Poland, long the poster child of Eastern European states that shed the Kremlin’s suffocating embrace, adopting dictatorial measures of its own, not least a right-wing, nationalistic assault on the country’s media and judiciary. The European Commission is scheduled to examine possible sanctions on Wednesday, but it is unlikely to take any, in part because Hungary and other governments sympathetic to Poland would veto them and also because they would serve only to deepen Warsaw’s hostility to the European Union.

headline: The West 80s: An Aesthetic of Its Own
abstract: The West 80s is largely a quiet neighborhood of stately older apartment buildings and townhouses, bustling bookstores and cultural institutions.
lead_paragraph: Kim Johnson was introduced to the West 80s of Manhattan about a dozen years ago when she attended a party there, on one of the blocks between Riverside Drive and West End Avenue. She was then renting an apartment in the West 70s, with her husband, Scott, but she found something different, “something really magical,” in the 80s. To her, the area felt quiet, green, community-minded and “cozy,” she said. “We thought we were in a whole different city.”

abstract: The poet talks about running for president, voting as a sexual act and gender vacationing.
lead_paragraph: Many people would be surprised to hear that according to you, poetry is alive and well in America. Our national political conversation has recently seen some rather unpoetic lurches to the right. How do you make sense of that? Poetry always, always, always is a key piece of democracy. It’s like the un-Trump: The poet is the charismatic loser. You’re the fool in Shakespeare; you’re the loose cannon. As things get worse, poetry gets better, because it becomes more necessary.

headline: Below the Line: Record Producer, Movie Composer
abstract: The scores of “Mad Max,” “Creed” and other contenders were created by artists perhaps better known for their work with pop stars and other big names.
lead_paragraph: The scores from new movies are often less likely to have the kind of wider cultural impact that make the themes from “Star Wars” or “Raiders of the Lost Ark” instantly hummable. But many of the artists working in film composition today have recorded or produced hits before. For instance, Trent Reznor, who with Nine Inch Nails made multiplatinum records, gained prestige of a different kind when he and Atticus Ross won Oscars for their score for “The Social Network” in 2011.

headline: In Exile
abstract: Deportations and violence have driven tens of thousands of people of Haitian descent from their homes in the Dominican Republic — while the world is silent.
lead_paragraph: At the far southeastern tip of Haiti, just outside the border town of Anse-à-Pitres, there was a farm. When the farmer’s grandfather bought the land years ago, he arrived with a cow that birthed twin calves. It was a sign of good fortune — a gift from God — so he named the land the “gift ranch,” or Parc Cadeau.

headline: ‘ABC Dream’ and ‘Awake Beautiful Child’
abstract: Two stylish new alphabet books deliver enchantment along with the ABCs.
lead_paragraph: It’s true that alphabet books exist primarily to familiarize new readers with the 26 letters. But with letters the center of attention, ABC books can also be perfect vehicles for writers to play with words and for illustrators to show off their design chops — and lately, many have been gorgeous, stylish creations, more Alfa Romeo than family S.U.V. Paging through some of these thoughtfully conceived and designed books can have a calming, almost meditative, effect. Their restrained, visually pleasing qualities are like manna from heaven in an era in which many schools seem to have decided, sadly, that learning to read should be a quick-and-dirty business, done with cheap, garish books and throwaway worksheets.

headline: Yes He Did
abstract: Obama’s macro record: not too bad.
lead_paragraph: These days many Americans live in an alternative political reality, in which the simplest factual assertions are met with anger and derision. When I, like many others, noted that job growth since Obamacare went into full effect has been the fastest since the 1990s — which is simply what the BLS data say — I got a barrage of mail from people claiming that I’m crazy, a liar, etc.. Similarly, but on of course a much bigger scale, a lot of what I’m seeing in reactions to the State of the Union amounts to the assertion that only an imbecile or a hack could believe Obama’s talk about the strength of the U.S. economy relative to other advanced countries — when that’s a simple fact.

headline: 1941: Changes to the Italian Army
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Changes are made to Italy’s forces in Albania in 1941.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Two months after taking command of the Italian forces in Albania, Gen. Ubaldo Soddu has been relieved of active duty at his own request, it was announced here today [Jan. 13]. Ill health, necessitating a long rest and care, was given as the reason for his retirement. All that the military command vouchsafed today concerning the fighting in Albania was that there had been normal activity of patrols and artillery and that Italian planes had machine-gunned and shelled enemy troops and columns of trucks on the march. No word has as yet reached the Italian people officially to confirm the claims of further Greek successes, which foreign broadcasts have reported. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 14, 1941

headline: ‘Hunters in the Dark,’ by Lawrence Osborne
abstract: A teacher is lured by thoughts of never returning from a trek through Southeast Asia.
lead_paragraph: I read this book in what is called an advance reader’s edition, a trade convenience generally made up of the first-pass pages from the forthcoming hardcover edition, bound in paper, with a version of the jacket art on the front and a version of the flap copy on the back. In this case, the flap copy was appropriately enticing (but when is it ever not?), and it opened by categorizing the work as “literary suspense.” Immediately the pedant in me reared its caviling head: Aren’t all novels literary, in that they’re assembled from letters and words? (From the Latin litteratura, writing composed of letters of the alphabet.) And aren’t all novels to some extent suspenseful — or else why would we ever finish one? Surely there must always be a managed momentum toward finding out what happens in the end, however slight that may be?

headline: ‘The Lovers: Afghanistan’s Romeo and Juliet,’ by Rod Nordland
abstract: A journalist becomes part of the story of an outlawed marriage.
lead_paragraph: The sentimental title of “The Lovers” suggests a hopeful tale of youthful romance, of passion and perseverance against the backdrop of a war-ravaged Afghanistan. Zakia and Ali, the journalist Rod Nordland’s Afghan Romeo and Juliet, are Tajik and Hazara, Sunni and Shia, disparate ethnicities and rived sects. They live in Bamiyan, where the Taliban destroyed two famed sandstone Buddhas in 2001. They fall in love as teenagers, exchanging flirty glances in the fields of their village, skirting elders and convention. Soon their parents find out; marriage is deemed impossible, and Zakia runs away to a shelter. The two elope but remain sentenced to a life on the run, with Ali facing criminal charges after Zakia’s family lodges a kidnapping case against him.

headline: Bringing a Grandmother’s Upstate Home to the Lower East Side
abstract: The Rising States’ Meagan Delaney takes T inside her grandmother Denise Hare’s Dutchess County home — which inspires Delaney’s Ludlow Street boutique.
lead_paragraph: “What if I said, ‘I’m an old soul, it all started in 1983?’” asks Meagan Delaney, the owner of the Lower East Side boutique the Rising States, erupting into a throaty laugh. Her story does begin in the mid-’80s on Kodiak Island, Alaska; her mother, a Russian Aleut and the youngest of 13 children, hadn’t left Kodiak before meeting Delaney’s dad, a Manhattanite who moved north to deal in fishing boats. “Two of my best friends still have the postcards that I sent to them while on a trip to the city when I was 8 years old,” Delaney says. “The funniest card reads, ‘New York is so cool. They have this store called the GAP’ — Gap in capital letters. I bought a ‘Blossom’ hat (a denim hat with a massive fake flower on the front), a sweater and some leggings, and I thought I was the coolest kid alive when I went back to Kodiak.”

Another is a “9/11 truther” with a website claiming that the Sept. 11 attacks were a government conspiracy. A third caucus precinct captain, who like the others attended a training session in West Des Moines last month, said the campaign’s goal of having them each enlist 25 supporters was unrealistic.

headline: Ricky Jay and the Met Conjure Big Magic in Miniature
abstract: A new exhibition is devoted to work by an 18th-century calligrapher who specialized in micrography — handwriting so small it’s barely legible to the naked eye.
lead_paragraph: The magician Ricky Jay, considered by many the greatest sleight-of-hand artist alive, is also a scholar, a historian, a collector of curiosities. Master of a prose style that qualifies him as perhaps the last of the great 19th-century authors, he has written about oddities like cannonball catchers, poker-playing pigs, performing fleas and people who tame bees. But probably his most enduring interest is a fellow polymath, an 18th-century German named Matthias Buchinger.

headline: All the Young Bands: The Artists David Bowie Championed
abstract: Musicians recall the nudges of support that Mr. Bowie gave them early in their careers. “We felt he had all the time in the world for us,” a guitarist recounts.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie’s dense catalog is a rich portrait of the ways in which he subverted rock and pop norms, exalted his fellow misfits and delighted in reinvention. It’s also a testament to the power of collaboration: Throughout his career, Mr. Bowie teamed closely with writers and producers, including Tony Visconti, who has frequently worked by his side since “Space Oddity” in 1969.

headline: The Former Kiehl’s Heiress’s Luxury Line of Skin Care
abstract: Jami Morse Heidegger brings decades of experience — and some of the highest-quality ingredients in the industry — to Retrouvé.
lead_paragraph: When third-generation Kiehl’s heir Jami Morse Heidegger sold the family business to L’Oreal in 2000, she thought she was walking away from beauty for good. But the luxury of having time away ironically sucked her back in. “I had been traveling so much for work and had three young children at home at the time,” she recalls. “I wanted to take care of myself, but there wasn’t anything on the market that addressed all of my concerns. I wanted something that was anti-aging but with top-quality oils to address the dryness I felt living in California desert.” So, she enlisted her longtime chemist from Kiehl’s to help formulate several products to rejuvenate her own skin. The requirement: Create mixtures with the highest possible concentration of effective ingredients.

headline: Venerating Mao, Even Where Famine Remains a Memory
abstract: A statue of Mao, torn down last week, had been erected in a province devastated by the famine caused by his Great Leap Forward.
lead_paragraph: ZHUSHIGANG, China — Only the orange of thousands of freshly dug carrots, washed in icy water and packed for delivery by village women, brightened this fog-draped village last Friday, one day after the authorities razed a golden statue of Mao Zedong erected by local admirers that had towered over the dun fields.

headline: Justices Hear Case Over Puerto Rico’s Sovereignty
abstract: The Supreme Court is deciding whether the island is an independent sovereign or a territory, a huge matter of pride and politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faced with the prospect of definitively resolving the status of Puerto Rico, the Supreme Court on Wednesday explored ways in which to render a narrow decision. But a lawyer for the Obama administration was adamant that the court’s decision should be based on the fundamental ground that the commonwealth is a territory of the United States without independent sovereignty.

Oluo finds himself in “Now I’m Fine,” the engaging musical memoir that opened on Tuesday night at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar festival.

headline: Review: In ‘Colony,’ on USA, Los Angeles Is Occupied

lead_paragraph: “Colony,” USA’s new sort of sci-fi, sort of geopolitical conspiracy series, gives up its secrets slowly. In truth, it hardly gives them up at all. As the hours roll by, the facts of life in the show’s near-future Los Angeles remain vague. We know that much of the city has been surrounded by a shiny metal wall hundreds of feet tall. But who put it there? What do they look like? Are they extraterrestrial? Sorry — maybe next week.

headline: Research Doesn’t Back a Link Between Migrants and Crime in U.S.
