keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Sneakers', 'Headphones and Headsets', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Everyday items, from headphones to ballerina flats, that can be customized to fit you perfectly — all from your smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the startup boom, a host of companies have recently sprung up that aim to make everything from headphones to ballerina flats perfectly personal, with intuitive sites and apps that allow you to explore your own preferences in great detail. Here, seven of our favorite ways to customize your life this year — without leaving the house.

headline: Review: Lisette Oropesa Scales Down Her Voice but Not Her Presence
abstract: Ms. Oropesa, a lyric soprano, performed a song recital with the pianist John Churchwell in the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes singers who are at home on the opera stage have trouble adjusting to the intimate requirements of a song recital. Not the lovely lyric soprano Lisette Oropesa, who on Tuesday night gave a rewarding performance with the stylish pianist John Churchwell in the Park Avenue Armory’s Board of Officers Room.

headline: Review: Ches Smith’s ‘The Bell’ Plays With Listeners’ Expectations
abstract: The drummer Mr. Smith is joined by the violist Mat Maneri and the pianist Craig Taborn on this new album, which offers a variety of musical styles.
lead_paragraph: The Bell

headline: Jan. 13, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from The Netherlands, Afghanistan, Israel and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The Netherlands, Afghanistan, Israel and India.

headline: Review: At American Dance Platform, Charm and Structure Without Flight
abstract: Opening night featured the Martha Graham Dance Company and Reggie Wilson/Fist and Heel Performance Group.
lead_paragraph: American Dance Platform is a new project at the Joyce Theater. From the audience’s point of view, though, it looks much like what has been happening at the Joyce each year in the second week of January. This is APAP week (for the Association of Performing Arts Presenters), when curators and producers come shopping in New York and when a number of the city’s performance spaces showcase multiple dance companies. With American Dance Platform, as in previous years, the Joyce gives a week to eight highly varied companies, appearing in four double bills.

headline: Stella McCartney Unveils Her Pre-Fall Collection in Hollywood
abstract: Katy Perry, Johnny Depp and Elizabeth Olsen join fashion stars at the landmark Amoeba Music store.
lead_paragraph: Katy Perry, Johnny Depp and Elizabeth Olsen join fashion stars at the landmark Amoeba Music store.

headline: Inside the Golden Globes Parties: Stars Find Their Cliques
abstract: Cate Blanchett, Leonardo DiCaprio, Jennifer Lawrence, Sean Penn and Madonna hit the Golden Globes party circuit.
lead_paragraph: If Hollywood is high school, the parties surrounding Golden Globes weekend were essentially an opportunity to show who belonged to which clique.

headline: Finding the Keys for the Right Ballet Steps
abstract: Few outside ballet circles realize the importance of those who play the piano to set the tone for dancers.
lead_paragraph: “There are only two tempos, too fast or too slow,” Cameron Grant, the principal pianist with New York City Ballet, said with a melancholy laugh after rehearsal a few weeks ago. It was the middle of “Nutcracker” season, and that evening he was scheduled to play the celesta, the bell-like keyboard instrument that accompanies Sugarplum’s solo, in the orchestra pit. With his neat appearance and calm demeanor, Mr. Grant is a constant, quiet presence in the theater, someone relied on by dancers, ballet masters and the orchestra. And yet few outside the circle of his colleagues realize how central he and the other company pianists are to the life of the theater.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: David Bowie, N.F.L., Iran
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Danes Debate How to Handle Migrants
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Politicians in Denmark reacted to a bill that would require refugees to help finance their stay. The proposal is the latest of several recent migrant-deterring measures taken by the country.
lead_paragraph: Politicians in Denmark reacted to a bill that would require refugees to help finance their stay. The proposal is the latest of several recent migrant-deterring measures taken by the country.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Clive James, Writing Toward the Twilight
abstract: Since learning he was terminally ill, Mr. James has been working at full speed, producing books of poetry and essays a well as a translation of Dante’s “Divine Comedy.”
lead_paragraph: Since 2010, when the brilliant Australian critic, poet and memoirist Clive James learned he had terminal leukemia, he’s had his afterburners flipped on. He has been on a vivifying late-career tear.

headline: Goldman Says It Supports IEX, but Raises Market Structure Issues
abstract: Goldman Sachs pointed out to the S.E.C. that one exchange should not have an unfair advantage over another in its control of market data.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs told the Securities and Exchange Commission in a letter dated Tuesday that it supported a proposed new stock exchange, but also pointed out that one exchange should not have an unfair advantage over another in its control of market data.

headline: Studio Two-Step Sometimes Defies Oscar Labels
abstract: The sleight of hand, of sorts, that goes into awards-show maneuvering can be very obvious.
lead_paragraph: Far and away the biggest head-scratcher at the Golden Globes on Sunday was how on earth “The Martian” — that rip-roaring laugh riot about a marooned astronaut’s ingenious and desperate efforts to stay alive — walked away with the top award for best comedy or musical.

headline: How Nikki Haley Was Redeemed by Donald Trump
abstract: The governor’s identity may feel tailored to reassure white Americans — but in her response to the State of the Union address, she appealed to a nation united by something deeper than appearances.
lead_paragraph: It is a truth universally acknowledged that an Indian-American in possession of gubernatorial dreams must be in want of a name like Nikki or Bobby. If I had a name like that, I would not be in Brooklyn writing some online-only essay, wearing a Uniqlo hoodie. I would probably be in Jackson, Montgomery or Raleigh, wearing a red velvet robe, tweaking my State of the State address. And if my name were Nikki or Bobby, the state of the state would be pukka — sorry, strong.

headline: Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review
abstract: Applications are open for the Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review, where editors, curators, gallerists and book publishers will conduct two days of private photo critiques.
lead_paragraph: Applications are open for the Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review, where editors, curators, gallerists and book publishers will conduct two days of private photo critiques.

headline: Brian Bedford, Stage Actor Who Brought the Classics to Life, Dies at 80
abstract: The versatile Mr. Bedford gained renown at Stratford in Canada and on Broadway portraying dozens of characters, most notably in works by Shakespeare, Molière and Chekhov.
lead_paragraph: Brian Bedford, the British-born actor, reared in working-class misery, who became a stellar portrayer of the princes, kings, fops and faded aristocrats of Shakespeare, Molière and Chekhov, died on Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Ted Cruz Didn’t Report Goldman Sachs Loan in a Senate Race
abstract: As Mr. Cruz tells it, loyalty and sacrifice helped finance his 2012 Senate bid in Texas. Turns out, a Goldman Sachs loan did as well.
lead_paragraph: As Ted Cruz tells it, the story of how he financed his upstart campaign for the United States Senate four years ago is an endearing example of loyalty and shared sacrifice between a married couple.

headline: Republicans Lead Congress With Two Distinct Agendas
abstract: Secure in his leadership, Speaker Paul D. Ryan has embraced an ambitious agenda, while his counterpart in the Senate, Mitch McConnell, keeps an eye on his tenuous majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan has been pressing House Republicans to develop an aggressive, conservative policy blueprint that sets the contours of the presidential campaign.

headline: Chocolate Armenteros, Trumpeter in Afro-Cuban Tradition, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Armenteros could often be found at the center of the genre’s changes, playing with innovators and popularizers including Arsenio Rodríguez, Cachao Lopez, Benny Moré and Eddie Palmieri.
lead_paragraph: Chocolate Armenteros, a Cuban trumpeter who was a standard-bearer of the Afro-Cuban musical tradition for almost seven decades, died on Jan. 6 in a nursing home in Mohegan Lake, N.Y. He was 87.

headline: Bill Clinton Cites Personal Losses in Pushing Fight Against Drug Abuse
abstract: Campaigning for his wife in New Hampshire, Bill Clinton opened up about three people close to the family who had lost their lives to drug abuse or an overdose.
lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H. — Hillary Clinton has made battling the drug epidemic a central part of her presidential campaign. But she has only briefly mentioned of her personal connection to it.

headline: Museum of Natural History’s New Dinosaur Sticks Its Head Out
abstract: Curators hope a casting of a 122-foot long fossil can top a dinosaur exhibit that draws big crowds.
lead_paragraph: Curators hope a casting of a 122-foot long fossil can top a dinosaur exhibit that draws big crowds.

headline: A New Dinosaur Takes Shape
abstract: The American Museum of Natural History unveils a new dinosaur exhibit this month. The process required careful planning and delicate handiwork.
lead_paragraph: The American Museum of Natural History unveils a new dinosaur exhibit this month. The process required careful planning and delicate handiwork.

headline: C.D.C. May Warn Pregnant Women Against Travel to Countries With Zika Virus
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Defects', 'Mosquitoes', 'Viruses', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The mosquito-borne virus has been linked to brain damage in newborn babies in Brazil and other Latin American and Caribbean nations.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials are debating whether to warn pregnant women against travel to Brazil and other Latin American and Caribbean countries where mosquitoes are spreading the Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in newborn babies.

headline: Former FIFA Vice President Arrives in Brooklyn to Face Charges
abstract: Alfredo Hawit of Honduras, who was president of Concacaf and a vice president of FIFA, pleaded not guilty to charges including wire fraud, money laundering and racketeering conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: The 21st of 41 defendants in the United States’ sprawling corruption case focusing on world soccer was brought to Brooklyn on Wednesday to face charges.

headline: New Dinosaur Poses Question: Does This Museum Make Me Look Fat?
abstract: On Friday, the American Museum of Natural History will unveil the cast of a 122-foot-long dinosaur that is one of the largest ever found. It is too big, in fact, to fit completely inside its new home.
lead_paragraph: The juvenile Barosaurus had just been laid out on the floor in the American Museum of Natural History when a staff member noticed a piece of candy corn wedged in the creature’s mouth. “So that’s what killed the dinosaurs,” said Alec Madoff, a senior preparator at the museum who had wielded the saw that felled the dinosaur.

headline: Rams’ Departure Is Another Blow to St. Louis Area, and a Chance to Shift Priorities
keywords: ['Football', 'Relocation of Business', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Population']
abstract: As city officials, civic leaders and residents confront the latest defeat, they find themselves calculating what the loss means and how to move forward.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Five years ago, it was grim census data showing that the city’s population had decreased by 8 percent at a time when officials were expecting it to grow.

headline: Ailing Valeant Chief’s Return Date Is Uncertain
abstract: The drug maker’s acting C.E.O., Howard B. Schiller, said it was uncertain when J. Michael Pearson, who Valeant said had been hospitalized with severe pneumonia, would be back.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is still uncertain when J. Michael Pearson, the chief executive of the troubled drug maker Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, will return to the company, his temporary replacement told investors on Wednesday.

headline: SurveyMonkey Names New Chief, Its Second in Six Months
abstract: The survey company appointed Zander Lurie as its new chief executive, replacing Bill Veghte after just six months in the job. Mr. Veghte took over after the longtime chief David Goldberg died last May on a vacation to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: SurveyMonkey, an online polling firm shaken by the sudden death of its chief executive last year, has replaced the man who took over in the aftermath.

headline: Chilling Messages in Journal of Louisiana Theater Shooter
abstract: John R. Houser, who had a history of mental illness, denigrated women, blacks and gay people in the journal he kept before killing two people and himself in July.
lead_paragraph: Before he opened fire at a Louisiana movie theater in July, a man with a history of mental illness filled dozens of pages with chilling references to violence and to a white man accused of killing nine black worshipers at a South Carolina church, as well as grievances against women, blacks, gay people and the news media.

headline: Bronx Science Bans Cellphones From Wi-Fi as Students Devour It
abstract: Since New York City lifted its long-held prohibition on cellphones in schools, teenagers have been eating up their schools' bandwidth.
lead_paragraph: When the New York City Education Department lifted a long-held ban on cellphones in school buildings last year, it acquiesced to the omnipresent reality of technology in daily life.

headline: Amnesty International Reports Torture of Detainees in Tunisia
abstract: New evidence of the torture and deaths of detainees in police custody in Tunisia has emerged, indicating a rise in repression as the government seeks to crack down on terrorism.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — New evidence of the torture and deaths of detainees in police custody has emerged in Tunisia, indicating a rise in repression as the government has sought to crack down on terrorism, Amnesty International warned Wednesday.

headline: For Help on Camera and Off, M.L.B. Orders Interpreters for Latino Players
abstract: According to a new initiative pushed by the Yankees’ Carlos Beltran, each of the league’s 30 teams will provide a full-time interpreter for Spanish-speaking players.
lead_paragraph: In April 2014, Michael Pineda, the Yankees pitcher, had been ejected from a game for having pine tar on his neck. Later the same night, he answered questions from more than a dozen reporters in English about the embarrassing incident.

headline: Gov. Cuomo on the State of New York
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Homeless Persons', 'Minimum Wage', 'State Legislatures', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'State of the State Message (NYS)']
abstract: The governor lays out ambitious plans for 2016, including a big boost in the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo laid out an ambitious policy agenda for the coming year in a State of the State address on Wednesday that blended the personal and political. He harked back to a “tough” 2015, when he lost his father, Mario, pivoting deftly to a call for 12 weeks of paid family leave. He made a powerful economic and moral case for a $15 minimum wage, and pledged multibillion-dollar investments in transportation, infrastructure and housing, and an aggressive plan to attack homelessness.

headline: Defense Secretary, in Speech to Deploying Troops, Lauds Push Against ISIS
abstract: Ashton B. Carter’s speech came as the Obama administration was trying to convince an apprehensive public that its strategy to destroy the Islamic State would be effective.
lead_paragraph: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter provided an upbeat assessment on Wednesday of the Obama administration’s efforts to defeat the Islamic State and said that missions now underway by a new deployment of Special Operations forces are “generating a virtuous cycle of action” against the extremist group.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Sets $46 Billion Bond Sale
abstract: A merger boom last year has set the stage for a string of big bond transactions in 2016 as companies finance those purchases.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev has completed a $46 billion, seven-part bond deal to help finance its acquisition of a fellow brewing company, SABMiller, in the second-largest corporate debt offering ever in the United States, according to Thomson Reuters.

headline: Iraq and the Kurds Are Going Broke
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Kurds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Low oil prices could seriously damage the effort to defeat the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi and American officials leading the military campaign against the Islamic State now have to wrestle with a challenge that has the potential to change battlefield fortunes: the slumping price of oil.

headline: El Chapo Enticed by Star Power of Mexican Actress, Not Sean Penn
abstract: Conversations between the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera and the actress Kate del Castillo offer a window into the psyche of one of the world’s most wanted criminals.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the infamous drug lord known as El Chapo, had never heard of Sean Penn.

headline: Giants Said to Promote Ben McAdoo to Head Coach
abstract: McAdoo, who has been the team’s offensive coordinator for the past two seasons, will replace the longtime coach Tom Coughlin.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when the Giants named the little-known Ben McAdoo as their new offensive coordinator, the team co-owner John Mara, who approved the hiring, conceded that he did not know Ben McAdoo from Bob McAdoo, the 1970s-era Knicks forward.

headline: Hello, They Must Be Going
abstract: The N.F.L. owners’ decision to let the owner of the St. Louis Rams move his team to just outside Los Angeles is consistent with their tear-’em-up, toss-’em-out ethos.
lead_paragraph: Bye-bye.

headline: Sylvan Barnet, Scholar, Is Dead at 89; Edited Signet Shakespeare Paperbacks
abstract: A Tufts University professor introduced generations of college students to the bard through the Signet Classic Shakespeare series.
lead_paragraph: Sylvan Barnet, a literary scholar who introduced generations of college students to Shakespeare through the Signet Classic Shakespeare series, for which he was the general editor, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.

headline: President May Have Exaggerated Role of Stimulus in Clean Energy, Experts Say
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Economic Stimulus Act (2008)', 'Solar Energy', 'United States Economy', 'Wind Power']
abstract: Changes in energy prices and dependence on foreign oil had little to do with the stimulus law, experts say, crediting them to government policies, market forces and private sector activities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in his final State of the Union address on Tuesday night, boldly proclaimed the successes of what he called “the single biggest investment in clean energy in our history,” the 2009 economic stimulus that pumped $80 billion into clean and renewable energy projects.

headline: Myra Carter, Dying Mother in Albee’s ‘Three Tall Women,’ Dies at 86
abstract: The actress was closely associated with the Albee canon, starting with her performance of this unpleasant character in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Myra Carter, an award-winning stage actress who originated the grueling role of Edward Albee’s dying nonagenarian mother in his autobiographical play “Three Tall Women,” died on Jan. 9 in Manhattan. She was 86.

headline: Los Angeles Greets Return of Rams With a Cool Eye
abstract: A metropolitan area with the slogan “Entertainment Capital of the World” is not easily swept off its feet. Still, those who were looking could find bursts of enthusiasm over the return of the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — And on the day after, the City of Angels ... went about its business.

headline: Lawrence Phillips, Volatile Football Star, Dies at 40
abstract: A gifted running back for Nebraska and the St. Louis Rams, Phillips derailed his career with a series of violent criminal acts off the field.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Phillips, a gifted running back who derailed his own career — and his life — with a series of violent criminal acts off the field, died on Wednesday in a hospital near Delano, Calif., where he was in prison. He was 40.

headline: Do You Want to Be Chicago’s New Police Superintendent?
abstract: The application to be Chicago's new police superintendent includes eight essay questions. Among the topics: accountability, use of technology and experience with matters related to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The application to be Chicago's new police superintendent includes eight essay questions. Among the topics: accountability, use of technology and experience with matters related to terrorism.

headline: In Chicago, a Fraught Opening Atop the Police Force
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The next leader of the 12,000- sworn officer force will inherit a department facing a federal investigation into its practices, an impassioned protest movement and the political turmoil surrounding Mayor Rahm Emanuel.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The job requires extensive management experience, the ability to deal with “significant distrust” and skill at addressing “highly publicized issues involving use of force.” It includes an unhappy work force, an angry public and a boss who is immersed in his own battles for survival. Federal investigators have begun sniffing around.

headline: Internet Yields Uneven Dividends and May Widen Inequality, Report Says
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Income Inequality', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The vast changes wrought by technology have not expanded economic opportunities or improved access to basic public services in ways that many had expected.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Can the Internet save the world?

headline: Fire-Suppressing Compound
abstract: Jeffrey Wechsler gets tripped up.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — How much fun is this? Yesterday, I left you with a song by THE BEATLES, based on a clue about SIDE TWO of “Magical Mystery Tour,” and today the entire theme is about THE BEATLES.

headline: ‘Moonshot’ to Cure Cancer, to Be Led by Biden, Relies on Outmoded View of Disease
abstract: The idea that a concerted government push can lead to a “cure” for cancer is nearly a half century old, stretching back to President Nixon’s failed “War on Cancer.”
lead_paragraph: Last Friday a group of 15 cancer researchers cut short a meeting at the Food and Drug Administration. The reason: They had been invited to Vice President Joseph R. Biden’s office to discuss his “moonshot” to cure cancer.

headline: How Rams’ Move May Affect Broadcasts and Ratings
abstract: One or two teams in the Los Angeles market will limit networks’ freedom to show doubleheaders each week. And ratings might not be a positive story even if Los Angeles is the second-largest market in the country.
lead_paragraph: For a generation, Los Angeles football fans have grown accustomed to watching other cities’ teams on television. The Raiders fled back to Oakland. The Rams migrated to St. Louis.

headline: Medical Device Maker Failed to Report Infections, Senate Report Says
keywords: ['Medical Devices', 'Infections', 'ANTIBIOTICS', 'Digestive Tract', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Serious infections linked to scopes used to examine the small intestine have been more widespread than the F.D.A. knew, though manufacturers are required to report them, a panel says.
lead_paragraph: Serious infections linked to poorly cleaned medical devices called duodenoscopes, used to examine the small intestine, have been more widespread than previously known, according to a Senate report released Wednesday.

headline: Ethiopia Halts Regional Plan After Protests
abstract: The government had hoped to integrate the capital, Addis Ababa, with the surrounding area, but the idea touched off a violent response.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — The Ethiopian government has canceled a widely promoted plan to integrate the capital, Addis Ababa, with the surrounding region after it touched off protests and violence that has killed scores of people since late last year.

headline: Defense Lawyers in Etan Patz Retrial Seek to Bar Prosecutor
abstract: The lawyers say statements made about the case by the prosecutor, Joan Illuzzi, during her campaign to be the Staten Island district attorney made it hard to find an impartial jury.
lead_paragraph: Defense lawyers asked a judge in Manhattan on Wednesday to bar a veteran prosecutor from taking part in the coming Etan Patz murder retrial because of statements she made about the case during her unsuccessful campaign to be the district attorney for Staten Island.

headline: Newer N.F.L. Owners Show Muscle in Tug of War
abstract: The N.F.L.’s decision to allow the St. Louis Rams to move to Los Angeles symbolizes a changing of the guard that may have a lasting impact on how the league operates.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The N.F.L. hailed its decision on Tuesday to allow the St. Louis Rams move to Los Angeles and build a nearly $3 billion stadium and entertainment district in suburban Inglewood as a triumphant return to the nation’s second-largest market.

headline: Tunnel Repairs Could Disrupt L Train in Coming Years
abstract: Work is not expected to begin until next year on the tunnel that carries the subway line between Manhattan and Brooklyn, but when it does, it will cause major headaches for many.
lead_paragraph: The chatter stunned riders of the L train on Wednesday: The tunnel that carries the subway line between Manhattan and Brooklyn could be shut down for more than a year.

headline: A Family Emerges Even Closer From Times of Darkness
abstract: After Jesus Negron lost his job and his family faced eviction, they helped one another endure 10 months without electricity in their Bronx apartment.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of 10 months in the Negron household, starting in spring 2014, darkness became routine.

headline: A Skateboard Stunt Turns Fatal for a Former Chef
abstract: Richard Oates, who left a restaurant career to run a skateboard shop in Brooklyn, was killed by a truck on which he was hitching an illegal ride with his skateboard.
lead_paragraph: Richard Oates was a skilled chef with a deft touch that put him at the top of his class at culinary school — and sped him through the kitchen ranks to central positions at the New York City restaurants where he worked. But he was, perhaps, an even better father, according to friends and former colleagues, and skateboards were the vehicles by which they said he was committing his life to his two young sons.

headline: N.C.A.A. to Let Underclassmen Return to College After Trying Out for N.B.A.
abstract: The rule change is a shift from the past where players had to declare for the draft before the N.B.A. combine and in doing so renounce future college eligibility.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — College men’s basketball players who are not seniors will now be able to try out for N.B.A. teams, receive a draft grade and then decide on returning to college — a stark shift from the past, when players had to declare for the draft before the N.B.A. combine and in doing so renounce future college eligibility.

headline: Powerball Has 3 Big Winners, in California, Florida and Tennessee
abstract: Officials said winning tickets for the record $1.5 billion jackpot were sold in California, Florida and Tennessee. Results from other states were still out.
lead_paragraph: The world’s biggest lottery jackpot of $1.5 billion will be a three-way split of $528 million each.

headline: Nets Rally Past Knicks Before Hostile Home Crowd
abstract: Many of the fans at Barclays Center were cheering for the visiting Knicks, but the Nets ground their way to their first victory under the interim coach Tony Brown.
lead_paragraph: When the Barclays Center doors opened Wednesday night, an army of orange and blue infiltrated the lower and upper bowls of the arena.

headline: As Islanders Evolve, Coach Jack Capuano Keeps a Steady Course
abstract: Five years into the job, Capuano faces new ownership, a seasoned lineup and higher expectations as he pushes for a third playoff berth in four years.
lead_paragraph: SYOSSET, N.Y. — Five years into the job, Islanders Coach Jack Capuano still straps a whistle to his left glove and uses it liberally at practice. He covers the rink like a Zamboni, rushing from one end to the other, smacking his stick on the ice to make a point.

headline: Explosions in Jakarta, Indonesia
abstract: Blasts and gunfire were reported in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta on Thursday.

headline: Global Markets Move Lower After Sell-Off
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Nasdaq Composite Index']
abstract: As American stocks headed toward a correction, Asian investors remained wary about the risks from China’s slowdown and European shares fell.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Global markets continued their jitters on Thursday — with China a lone bright spot — as investors continued to show concern about the strength of the world’s largest economies.

headline: Jakarta Attack Raises Fears of ISIS’ Spread in Southeast Asia
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Muslims and Islam', 'International Relations', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: The two civilians killed in the explosions and gunfire were a Canadian and an Indonesian, senior officials reported. Five assailants were also killed.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Islamic State claimed responsibility for a terrorist attack in the Indonesian capital on Thursday, raising the specter of an expanded presence by the group in Southeast Asia.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | paradox
abstract: This word has appeared in 372 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: paradox • \ˈper-ə-ˌdäks, ˈpa-rə-\ • noun

headline: Bomb Blasts and Gunfire Rip Through Jakarta
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A traffic police post was heavily damaged by the blasts, and at least one officer was killed by gunfire, according to witnesses speaking to a local television station.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The center of the Indonesian capital was rocked by a series of explosions and gunfire on Thursday. The police seemed to have been the chief targets.

headline: Italy: Arrest in Killing of American
abstract: A manwas arrested in the death of an American woman whose body was found in her apartment in Florence last weekend.
lead_paragraph: The police in Italy have arrested a man in the death of an American woman whose body was found in her apartment in Florence last weekend, according to Italian news reports on Thursday. The man, who was not identified, was facing a charge of aggravated murder in connection with the death of the woman, Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, according to the news agency ANSA. The suspect, who was described as a 25-year-old African immigrant, was ordered detained by the prosecutor in Florence.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: Josh Holloway and Carlton Cuse of “Lost” fame team up again on “Colony.” Kevin Hart and Olivia Munn face off on “Lip Sync Battle.” And Jillian Bell and Charlotte Newhouse bring “Idiotsitter” to TV.
lead_paragraph: Dynamic duos: Josh Holloway and Carlton Cuse of “Lost” team up on “Colony.” Kevin Hart and Olivia Munn of “Ride Along 2” make like Usher and Nelly on “Lip Sync Battle.” And Jillian Bell and Charlotte Newhouse bring their web series, “Idiotsitter,” to TV.

headline: Corrections: January 14, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, January 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “This has been the elephant in the room that no one is prepared to acknowledge: that the great fear is the fear of Islam.”

headline: Applications for the 2016 New York Portfolio Review
abstract: Applications are now open for the Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review, where editors, curators, gallerists and book publishers will conduct two days of private photo critiques.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to succeed as a photographer? It takes time, passion and obsession to make great work. But you also need the opportunity to get your work seen and celebrated.

headline: Gov. Christie Leaves Gun Controls Behind in New Jersey
abstract: The governor’s view has shifted as he tries to woo the pro-gun vote.
lead_paragraph: It’s unfortunate that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey started running away from his own record on sensible gun controls as soon as he began his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. Shameless pandering to voters in gun-friendly states has ensued. Mr. Christie abandoned his onetime fierce support of an assault weapons ban and reversed his opposition to armor-piercing .50-caliber rifles that have no place in civilized society.

Many of you gave your own examples of lies told and why you believed they were or were not justified. It was heartening to find so many people prepared to reason thoughtfully about important moral issues.

A local medic has been surviving on the rehydration salts he gives patients, while a business school graduate makes soup from grass for his 70-year-old father, consulting shepherds about which kinds their long-since-slaughtered flocks liked best.

abstract: Staying in bed is a chance to take stock of your life.
lead_paragraph: Now with computers on our laps, it’s hard to be perfectly, indulgently sick in bed. With our phones right there, we are tied to the life we were living yesterday, when we weren’t yet sick in bed. It’s time to be truly sick in bed this winter — sick like in the old days, when there was ginger ale from the store and fresh magazines on the night stand. Put it on the autoresponder: I’ll reply to you next week when I’m no longer sick in bed.

headline: My Return to Nepal, in Memoriam

We had come to the foothills of the Himalayas by way of various story lines of my life, including President Kennedy’s 1961 inaugural address and my father’s death in 2014. These events led us to Nepal, and to a walk through the clouds.

headline: Against Neutrality
abstract: The apparent impartiality of photographs can conceal as much as it reveals — especially when the subject is violence or prejudice.
lead_paragraph: The photograph and the words arrive simultaneously. They guarantee each other. You believe the words more because the photograph verifies them, and trust the photograph because you trust the words. Additionally, each puts further pressure on the interpretation: A war photograph can, for example, make a grim situation palatable, just as a story about a scandal can make the politician depicted look pathetic. But images, unlike words, are often presumed to be unbiased. The facticity of a photograph can conceal the craftiness of its content and selection.

headline: The Happiness Code
abstract: A new approach to self-improvement is taking off in Silicon Valley: cold, hard rationality.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, three dozen people, mostly programmers in their 20s, gathered in a rented house in San Leandro, Calif., a sleepy suburb of San Francisco, for a lesson in ‘‘comfort-zone expansion.’’ An instructor, Michael Smith, opened the session with a brief lecture on identity, which, he observed, can seem immutable. ‘‘We think we behave in certain ways because of who we are,’’ he began. ‘‘But the opposite is also true. Experience can edit identity.’’

headline: 1941: Japan Opens Propaganda Office
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Japan begins to oil propaganda guns in Mexico in 1941.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Japan began to oil propaganda guns in Mexico today [Jan. 14] for immediate use in a twofold fight against United States economic penetration and against the newly announced plan of the Roosevelt administration to block Axis purchases of Mexico’s war minerals and oil. High authorities disclosed that representatives of Domei, the official Japanese news agency, have established offices in this capital for distribution of news free of charge to Mexican and other Latin-American newspapers. The United States has no propaganda agency to combat this obvious effort by Japan to influence the Americas. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 15, 1941
