There’s 400 thread-count Egyptian cotton! Complimentary champagne! Japanese toilets!

headline: The Secret Behind Italy’s Favorite New Film
abstract: The new film “Quo Vado?” is bigger than “Star Wars,” because it speaks to the country’s nostalgia for safe, secure careers.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A BALDING government clerk in his late 30s has one true love: “il posto fisso,” a job for life. He doesn’t want to compete in the labor market; he has no urge to move on. He doesn’t even want to earn more. Give him a desk, a chair and a 9-to-5 job in the “pubblica amministrazione,” and he’s happy. Clocking in late, chatting with colleagues, accepting small bribes from taxpayers (most favored: quail), a regular salary — that’s life!

headline: Ron Lieber: Your Money Matters
abstract: At a Times Insider event, the Times columnist, Ron Lieber talked money — spending, earning and socking it away.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, new years bring resolutions … perhaps to exercise more, or eat better, or maybe be a little wiser with money.

headline: Guantánamo Population Drops to 93 after 10 Prisoners Go to Oman
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The transfer of 10 lower-level Yemeni detainees, which took place on Wednesday, was the largest single resettlement of prisoners in the yearslong effort to close the prison.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Thursday announced that it had transferred 10 lower-level Yemeni detainees from the Guantánamo Bay prison to Oman. The departure of the unusually large group of prisoners — each of whom spent about 14 years in custody — reduced the prison population to 93, the first time it has been in double digits since the Bush administration began bringing Afghanistan war prisoners to the naval base in January 2002.

headline: As Aid Reaches Syrians, U.N. Chief Says Withholding Food Is a War Crime
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Malnutrition']
abstract: As aid convoys reached three besieged towns in Syria, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon called on all sides to lift sieges and protect civilians.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The head of the United Nations said on Thursday that the warring parties in Syria were committing war crimes by withholding food from civilians. He called for all sides to lift their sieges immediately and unconditionally “as a confidence-building gesture” ahead of peace talks scheduled for Jan. 25.

headline: Candidates for the Harvard Board of Overseers
abstract: The five candidates have a mix of political, academic, business and legal experience. One is a household name, and all attended Harvard in some capacity.
lead_paragraph: The five candidates have a mix of political, academic, business and legal experience. One is a household name, and all attended Harvard in some capacity.

headline: In Wisconsin, Efforts to End Taunting at Games Lead to Claims of Coddling
abstract: Sports officials in Wisconsin are backtracking after an effort to crack down on fan behavior drew protests.
lead_paragraph: For fans at a basketball game, there are few sights as satisfying as a rival player’s shot sailing cleanly beyond the rim and backboard.

headline: Oscars 2016: It’s a Nearly All-White Nominees’ List — Again
abstract: Only the inclusion of “The Revenant’s” Iñárritu adds a note of diversity as the absence of black nominees fuels criticism of Hollywood’s hiring record.
lead_paragraph: #OscarsSoWhite, that damning hashtag that made the rounds last year, can again, unhappily, be revived for this year’s Oscar nominations, which were announced Thursday morning.

headline: Los Angeles Opera Names First Artist in Residence
abstract: Matthew Aucoin, 25, will conduct and compose, and work with young artists over the next three seasons.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Opera announced Thursday that Matthew Aucoin, the rising young composer, conductor and librettist, would become its first artist in residence next fall, and that he would conduct, compose, and work with young artists there over the next three seasons.

headline: 1966: Succession Crisis in New Delhi
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A new air of crisis grips India in 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A wide-open race developed today [Jan. 14] for the premiership of India as a cabinet dispute erupted over the four-day-old Tashkent peace agreement with neighboring Pakistan. A new air of crisis gripped the country as reports from West Pakistan revealed that two persons were killed and 12 injured yesterday in a clash between police and students in Lahore, who were protesting the ‘‘Tashkent declaration.’’ Reports said police used tear gas against the students, who carried banners demanding ‘‘Liberation of the state from Indian rule.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 15, 1966

headline: 3 Found Guilty of Aiding $20 Million London Theft
abstract: The men were convicted of having helped a gang of four aging thieves who drilled into the side of a safe deposit building to steal a trove of gold, gems and jewelry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has been called the largest burglary in England’s history: four aging thieves who conspired to steal about $20 million in gold, jewelry and gems from Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. in London, aided by the book “Forensics for Dummies” and diamond-tipped power drills that could penetrate concrete.

headline: Symphony Space’s President to Retire
abstract: Cynthia Elliott, who led the cultural center for 13 years, will leave at the end of the 2016 season.
lead_paragraph: Symphony Space, the cultural center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, will soon have a space to fill at the top: Cynthia Elliott, its president and chief executive office, plans to retire at the end of the 2016 season, the organization announced this week.

headline: A Chess Prodigy, a Mentor and Still a Teenage Girl
abstract: Alice Dong, 17, is one of the best chess players in New Jersey, and she wants other girls to know what a confidence-booster the game can be.
lead_paragraph: There was no hurling of pawns or bishops at the second annual New Jersey All-Girls Chess Camp in Branchburg this month. But if there had been, the camp’s founder, Alice Dong, would have understood the impulse.

headline: Snape Is Dead
abstract: With the death of Alan Rickman, who played Severus Snape in the Harry Potter movies, our children will experience the curious grief that accompanies the death of someone you knew without knowing.
lead_paragraph: Snape is dead.

headline: Straddling Conventional and Alternative Cancer Treatment
keywords: ['Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Cancer', 'Chemotherapy', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Pancreatic Cancer']
abstract: Dr. Nicholas Gonzalez was a fascinating figure in the world of cancer, one whose beliefs and treatments have fierce critics but whose insights have shed light on the mysteries of the illness.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Nicholas Gonzalez died in July, there was not much notice. He did not get an obituary in The New York Times or in most other major media outlets.

headline: In Britain, Major Parties Ensnared by Internal Strife
abstract: Since the May election, both the Labour Party, which was defeated, and the Conservative Party, which won, have been at war within themselves.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s common enough, as in the United States just now, for political parties to war internally in the run-up to an election — who will be the candidate, which faction will triumph, what jobs will go to which advisers?

headline: Few Answers on True Owners of Art Found in Gurlitt Trove
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A German task force set up to determine ownership of more than 1,200 pieces of art was able to identify only five, prompting criticism from Jewish groups about the pace and intensity of the effort.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After a two-year, nearly $2 million investigation, a German government task force set up to determine ownership of an art collection amassed by a Nazi-era dealer announced Thursday that it had identified the rightful owners of just five of the works whose provenance was in doubt.

headline: Jeb Bush Takes Aim at Donald Trump in New Hampshire Ad
abstract: “When anybody disparages people with disabilities, it sets me off,” says Mr. Bush, defending calling his rival a “jerk.”
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush is highlighting his recent stump speech criticism of Donald J. Trump in a new 60-second ad titled “Enough,” which is to run in New Hampshire.

headline: New Louisiana Governor, John Bel Edwards, Is Off to a Volatile Start
abstract: Mr. Edwards, a Democrat who was inaugurated on Monday, watched helplessly as the Republican-controlled State House rejected his handpicked candidate for speaker.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — John Bel Edwards was sworn in the Deep South’s only Democratic governor this week, and already he has experienced momentous triumph — and momentous defeat.

headline: How to Watch the Republican Debate
abstract: Seven Republicans will be on the main stage in South Carolina for the party’s sixth nationally televised debate, starting 9 p.m. Thursday on Fox Business Network.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates will be in South Carolina on Thursday for the party’s sixth nationally televised debate, hosted by the Fox Business Network. Clashes among the candidates are likely to be pointed, as they seek to make their case to voters less than three weeks before the first nominating contest, the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 1.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence’s Red-Carpet Looks
abstract: Though the actress has been a proper mannequin for Dior since 2012, a style seems to be slowly emerging.
lead_paragraph: Though the actress has been a proper mannequin for Dior since 2012, a style seems to be slowly emerging.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence Is a Darling of Dior
abstract: Working with onetime protégées of the stylist Rachel Zoe, the actress will occasionally stray from the French house and wear Ralph Lauren or Schiaparelli.
lead_paragraph: When she’s not jet-skiing with Amy Schumer, discussing her lady lumps, or taking on equal pay in Hollywood, Jennifer Lawrence, a self-professed workaholic, is likely to be found on the red carpet swathed in Dior. Ms. Lawrence, 25, was just nominated for an Oscar for her role in “Joy” and is in contention for her roles in that movie and in “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2” at the Critics’ Choice Awards on Sunday. She was signed to a lucrative deal by the French luxury brand in 2012 and has, to some red carpet commentators’ lament, been a proper mannequin since.

headline: Home Builder Countryside Properties Plans I.P.O. in London
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Private Equity', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Countryside Properties, a British real estate developer majority owned by Oaktree Capital Management, expects to raise about $165 million in its offering.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Countryside Properties, a British home builder that is majority owned by the American private equity firm Oaktree Capital Management, said on Thursday that it planned to list its shares in an initial public offering in London next month.

headline: Donald Trump Disavows Actions by White Nationalist Promoting His Bid
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Donald J. Trump took the rare step of “disavowing” the endorsement of a prominent white nationalist who supports Mr. Trump’s ban on Muslim immigration and who said the United States needs more white immigrants who can assimilate.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has tapped into intense anger and anti-immigrant sentiment by part of the American electorate, exciting people who have paid little attention to politics and drawing approval from groups that some would consider to be fringe.

headline: Barrington Stage Company Announces Summer Lineup
abstract: Works include “Broadway Bounty Hunter,” a new musical by Joe Iconis, “Presto Change-O,” directed by Mark Bruni, and “The Pirates of Penzance,” from the director John Rando and the choreographer Joshua Bergasse.
lead_paragraph: A new musical by Joe Iconis (“Be More Chill”) will be mounted this summer at the Barrington Stage Company as one of several new works having premieres by that nonprofit theater in the Berkshires.

headline: Ben Carson’s Campaign Finance Chief Quits
abstract: The disarray within Ben Carson’s campaign continued as his campaign’s finance chairman resigned hours before Republican presidential candidates were set to gather in South Carolina for their next debate.
lead_paragraph: The disarray within Ben Carson’s campaign continued Thursday as his campaign’s finance chairman abruptly resigned hours before Republican presidential candidates were set to gather in South Carolina for a debate.

headline: The End of Small Talk
abstract: Why can’t we replace trivial conversations with meaningful ones, and ask each other profound questions right from the start?
lead_paragraph: When my relationship unraveled nearly two years ago, I decided to suspend my career as an actuary in Boston and take a long vacation in Costa Rica, where I planned to learn how to surf and do yoga. Yes, it was the most clichéd response possible for a heartbroken 32-year-old Westerner like me.

headline: Ragy Thomas of Sprinklr: How Naïveté Can Become a Strength
abstract: The founder of Sprinklr says he has found a naïve belief in people can bring out the best in them.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Ragy Thomas, founder and chief executive of Sprinklr, a social media software platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: 36 Hours in Quebec City
abstract: In Quebec’s capital, hip and historic exist side by side, with cultural and culinary enticements for all manner of visitors.
lead_paragraph: In Quebec’s capital, hip and historic exist side by side, with cultural and culinary enticements for all manner of visitors.

headline: Verbatim: Barack Obama on Michelle Obama’s Presidential Ambitions
abstract: “Let me tell you, there are three things that are certain in life: death, taxes, and Michelle is not running for president.” — President Obama
lead_paragraph: — President Obama to a supporter in Baton Rouge, La., who asked whether the first lady might be persuaded to run for high political office someday.

headline: How Some Would Level the Playing Field: Free Harvard Degrees
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Tuition', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Endowments', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS']
abstract: The slate of five running for the Board of Overseers, which helps set strategy for the university, was put together by a conservative advocate from California.
lead_paragraph: Should Harvard be free?

headline: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Kidney Problems
abstract: Proton pump inhibitors like Nexium, Prevacid and Prilosec may increase the risk of chronic kidney disease.
lead_paragraph: Proton pump inhibitors, or P.P.I.s, the commonly used heartburn medicines, may increase the risk for kidney disease.

headline: Why I Always Wanted to Be a Secretary
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Women and Girls', 'Workplace Environment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Typewriters and Typewriting', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: My grandmother didn’t just teach me to type, but how to rise above others’ disregard.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence, Kan. — I TOOK my first secretarial job in college, where I worked down the hall from a Triga Mark II nuclear reactor. I lasted just two lonely weeks, waiting to answer nonexistent phone calls and compulsively checking my radiation exposure badge.

headline: The Shah of Iran, the Islamic Revolution and the Mystery of the Missing Imam
abstract: A new book, “The Fall of Heaven,” offers clues on the 1978 disappearance of Moussa al-Sadr, a revered Iranian cleric in Lebanon who offered to help counter Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
lead_paragraph: Even by today’s standards, the Middle East in the 1970s was chaotic. Bombings, hijackings and assassinations were daily headlines. In the midst of the mayhem, one of the most revered clerics in the Shiite branch of Islam vanished while visiting Libya.

headline: An Early Master of the Art of Collecting
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum is opening an exhibition on Pierre-Jean Mariette, an 18th-century connoisseur who influenced how drawings are collected and presented.
lead_paragraph: The history of collecting will expand on Friday, Jan. 22, when the Morgan Library & Museum opens “Pierre-Jean Mariette and the Art of Collecting Drawings.”

headline: Sleeping Giant’s ‘Hand Eye’ to Have New York Premiere by Eighth Blackbird
abstract: The work, composed by a collective of six young American composers, was written for the instrumental ensemble and will be played at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Musicians, like highly skilled workers in many fields, have long sought strength through collective action. Sleeping Giant, a collective of six young American composers, has a more loosely creative goal in mind: This is no union; just a group of like-minded, stylistically varied composers who are generating collective works and commissions.

headline: New York Jewish Film Festival Looks to the Past
abstract: The film “The Rifleman’s Violin” will be followed by a performance by the violinist Stuart Canin, who played for Churchill, Truman and Stalin in 1945.
lead_paragraph: As the New York Jewish Film Festival (Jan. 13-26) celebrates its 25th season at the Walter Reade Theater, it’s time to look back as well as forward. High points of the retrospective within the festival include Michael Haneke’s 1997 screen adaptation of Franz Kafka’s unfinished final novel, “The Castle” (Monday, Jan. 18); Andrzej Wajda’s World War II drama “Holy Week” (Jan. 17); and “Mahler on the Couch” (Jan. 18), the 2010 drama about the marital woes of Gustav Mahler and his wife, Alma.

headline: Globalfest and Brazilian Explorative Music Come to New York
abstract: The two events will bring plenty of international performers to the city, including Lakou Mizik and Pedro Sá Moraes.
lead_paragraph: The Association of Performing Arts Presenters convention is the January thaw for music in New York — an audition for the presenters, a potential binge for the rest of us. It brings Globalfest, where 12 international performers are showcased in one building over five hours: among them this year, the New York debut of the Haitian group Lakou Mizik; deep Delta blues from the Music Maker Blues Revue; raspy-voiced and Arab-influenced Mexican cabaret from Astrid Hadad; the Arabic-flamenco-jazz reunion of the oud player Simon Shaheen’s ensemble Zafir; and Fendika, with its own twist on Ethiopian funk. (7 p.m., Sunday, Jan. 17, Webster Hall, globalfest.org.)

headline: No Comment Necessary: Paul Ryan Attacks Obama For Criticizing Muslim Ban
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: The president’s implicit criticism of the idea during his State of the Union speech “degrades the presidency,” according to Mr. Ryan.
lead_paragraph: During his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama referred to people “promising to restore past glory if we just got some group or idea that was threatening America under control,” an implicit criticism of Donald Trump and his call for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States. In an interview with USA Today on Wednesday, Paul Ryan said he also opposed such a ban. But he lambasted the president for bringing the issue up in his speech.

headline: MoMA Highlights Work of the Choreographer Jack Cole
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art is bringing his work to light with “All That Jack (Cole),” a two-week film and lecture series.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Jack Cole has flown under the radar of American dance history. A pioneer of theatrical jazz onstage and on the screen — and a performance coach to Rita Hayworth and Marilyn Monroe — he influenced the likes of Jerome Robbins, Alvin Ailey and Bob Fosse, yet we don’t hear about him much. Beginning on Wednesday, Jan. 20, the Museum of Modern Art is bringing Cole’s work to light with “All That Jack (Cole),” a two-week film and lecture series organized with the dance critic Debra Levine, a Cole scholar.

headline: Four Oscar-Nominated Actresses on Their Processes
abstract: The best things we learned from interviews with Cate Blanchett, Charlotte Rampling, Saoirse Ronan and Rooney Mara.
lead_paragraph: Upstart ingenues and heavy hitters figure equally in today’s  Oscar nominations for Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress — and in the pages of T. Read on to see what four of this year’s nominated actresses have told us about their craft.

headline: JPMorgan Results Offer Strong Case for Financial Technology
abstract: The bank is lending more and reducing drags on capital. Yet its fourth-quarter return on equity was only 9 percent. New technology could bolster revenue and savings.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s fourth-quarter results offer a compelling case for cranking up the industry’s use of financial technology.

headline: ‘American Experience’ Looks Back at Bonnie and Clyde
abstract: This PBS program explores the rise and fall of a criminal duo.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1967, the Bonnie and Clyde story received the Hollywood treatment, with Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway starring as the outlaws Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker in Arthur Penn’s film.

headline: Martin O’Malley Makes the Cut for Next Democratic Debate
abstract: Though his low polling numbers raised the possibility he would be excluded from Sunday’s Democratic presidential debate, former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland will be onstage, NBC News said.
lead_paragraph: Martin O’Malley, the former governor of Maryland who has lagged in polls by double digits as the Democratic voting contests approach, has qualified for the final debate before the Feb. 1 Iowa caucuses, NBC executives announced on Thursday.

headline: Rousing Performance at Monmouth, and That’s Just on the Bench
abstract: Justin Robinson, a junior whose only Division I scholarship offer was from Monmouth, has led the Hawks to victories over U.C.L.A., Notre Dame, Rutgers and Georgetown.
lead_paragraph: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. — Monmouth Coach King Rice was searching for talent at a high school basketball tournament in Philadelphia five years ago when he spotted a “little fellow” on an adjacent court who possessed a knack for penetrating and scoring.

headline: Chairlift on the Arias, Beats and Jazz Grooves That Fed ‘Moth’
abstract: Caroline Polachek and Patrick Wimberly talk about the eclectic influences that went into the making of their new album.
lead_paragraph: In the four years since Caroline Polachek and Patrick Wimberly last released an album as the Brooklyn electronic pop duo Chairlift, they have toured the world, written a Beyoncé song (“No Angel”), built their own studio in a former pharmaceutical factory and become real New Yorkers.

headline: Taste of Samarkand
abstract: Kosher Uzbek cooking in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Kosher Uzbek cooking in Queens.

headline: Taste of Samarkand Is a Silk Road Oasis in Queens
abstract: The kosher Uzbek restaurant, which opened last August, upholds Uzbek food traditions.
lead_paragraph: The bread looks ready to levitate. Called noni toki, it is matzo-thin, a blistered expanse 14 inches across, the edges uplifted as if in supplication. At Taste of Samarkand, this is achieved by slapping and patting dough around the inverted underbelly of a kazan, a high-sloped Uzbek frying pan akin to a Chinese wok, then baking it over the stove until hard and crisp.

headline: Pulled in 2 Directions, Marco Rubio Toughens on Immigration, a Little
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Political Advertising', 'Terrorism', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Faced with attacks from Ted Cruz and Donald Trump, Mr. Rubio has pushed stiffer policies, while still supporting a change in the law to offer a path to citizenship to illegal immigrants.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A Latin singing duo had just finished warming up the crowd for Senator Marco Rubio on Sunday here when he looked out from the stage and asked if he might offer a few words in Spanish.

headline: Strangely Self-Confident Permahawks
abstract: Always wrong, never daunted.
lead_paragraph: An odd thing about permahawks — people who have been demanding, year after year, that the Fed raise rates now now now. (The same is true, actually, about the overlapping group warning nonstop about fiscal crisis.) They are, by and large, free-market acolytes who insist that markets know best; yet they also insist that we ignore financial markets that have been telling us that inflation is quiescent and the U.S. government is solvent.

headline: New Prison Rule in Russia: No Swearing
abstract: Detainees in pretrial detention centers will be forbidden to use slang known as “fenya,” but there was no immediate indication of how the authorities intended to enforce the rule.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s prison system, the successor to the notoriously harsh gulag, has issued an edict that would have shocked even the victims of Stalin’s purges: From now on, officials say, some prisoners will be forbidden to swear.

headline: Powerball Winners, Beware: Good Fortune Can Trigger a Downfall
abstract: For some people who won the lottery, hitting it big turned out to be the worst thing that could happen.
lead_paragraph: For some people who won the lottery, hitting it big turned out to be the worst thing that could happen.

headline: Outrage
abstract: How dare Obama condemn bigotry?
lead_paragraph: Greg Sargent marvels at the spectacle of Paul Ryan, who is outraged, outraged, at President Obama for devoting part of the State of the Union to a denunciation of politicians who encourage bigotry. In fact, Ryan says that Obama “degraded” the presidency by denouncing bigotry — because that amounts to an intervention in the Republican primary.

headline: ‘Everyone Here Is a Star’: Oscar Nominees React
abstract: Thoughts from Jennifer Lawrence, Sylvester Stallone and other newly minted contenders.
lead_paragraph: Thoughts from Jennifer Lawrence, Sylvester Stallone and other newly minted contenders.

headline: My Favorite Alan Rickman Line
abstract: R.I.P.
lead_paragraph: He was wonderful in everything he did; but this was from a not especially wonderful movie, Bottle Shock:

headline: Division of Labor and Costs in a Relationship
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Babies and Infants', 'Subways']
abstract: Plus: repayment for a funeral visit, standing up for not sitting down, and deciphering backhanded compliments.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I live together. We split the cost of food and household goods 50-50. Recently, I was found to have an autoimmune problem that requires using more expensive cleaning products. My boyfriend was upset about splitting the cost. Living alone, he said, he would not use them. (He doesn’t complain that I do all the cleaning.) Still, I proposed a 75-25 split, and he accepted. Now I feel bitter. We’re only talking $20 a month, but it feels as if he doesn’t appreciate my labor or sympathize with my condition. But I have to honor the compromise I suggested, right?

headline: Turkey Strikes Islamic State Targets in Retaliation for Istanbul Bombing
abstract: Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said a major ground offensive against targets in Iraq and Syria had killed nearly 200 militants over the last 48 hours.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkish ground forces have launched a major offensive against Islamic State targets in Iraq and Syria in retaliation for a suicide bombing that killed 10 German tourists in Istanbul this week, Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said on Thursday.

headline: Tacoma Art Museum to Build New Gallery to House Major Gift
abstract: Officials of the Tacoma Art Museum say they plan to build new gallery to house a major gift of art from a collector.
lead_paragraph: The Tacoma Art Museum in Washington said Thursday that it has been given 225 works from various artists as gifts from Becky Benaroya, the widow of the Seattle-based real estate developer Jack Benaroya.

headline: With ‘Ride Along 2’ and Other Films, Will Packer Blurs the Niche Lines
abstract: Mr. Packer has reinvigorated the kinds of comedies that focus on black characters without excluding a wider audience.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Twenty years ago, freshly graduated from college, Will Packer loaded 350 newspapers into his Honda Civic every day at dawn and drove around Atlanta, tossing them onto lawns and driveways. In the afternoons, he sold subscriptions door to door.

headline: U.S. Lists Afghan Branch of ISIS as Terrorist Group
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The State Department’s listing allows American military operations against the group to fall under the counterterrorism mission agreed to by the Afghan government.
lead_paragraph: The State Department on Thursday designated the Afghan affiliate of the Islamic State, a splinter group mostly made up of former Afghan and Pakistani Taliban members, as a foreign terrorist organization.

headline: ‘Nerds,’ a Musical About Bill Gates and Steve Jobs, Heads to Broadway
abstract: The show is to begin performances on March 31 at the Longacre Theater, and opening night is scheduled for April 21.
lead_paragraph: “Nerds,” a musical satire about the rivalry between the tech pioneers Bill Gates and Steve Jobs, is coming to Broadway.

headline: New Bernie Sanders Ad, on Wall Street, Fires Back at Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The new ad for Senator Bernie Sanders claims that Mrs. Clinton’s plan to regulate Wall Street is disingenuous.
lead_paragraph: As the race in Iowa and New Hampshire tightens, the Sanders campaign is drawing its most direct contrast with Hillary Clinton in a new ad, titled “Two Visions,” running in the two early states.

headline: New Video Collections Examine Machines Modern and Less So
abstract: The documentarian Manfred Kirchheimer hails 1970s New York subway graffiti in a collection, while “The Short Films of the Quay Brothers” evokes older technology.
lead_paragraph: Early film artists were acutely aware of motion pictures as a machine-based art particularly qualified to embody the feel of modernity and the pace of urban life. Recurring preoccupations for the avant-garde of the 1920s included the mechanical man and the metropolis. Both can be found, somewhat battered by time, in the films of Manfred Kirchheimer and the Brothers Quay, contemporary artists with works newly out on disc.

headline: In Alan Rickman the Stage Actor, an Erotic Blend of Desire and Conscience
abstract: Though best known for the “Die Hard” and “Harry Potter” movies, he was even more compelling as a serpentine seducer onstage.
lead_paragraph: No man, at least not since Noël Coward, wore a dressing gown with more slippery ease or dangerous intent. When the British actor Alan Rickman appeared on Broadway in Howard Davies’s 2002 revival of Coward’s “Private Lives,” he brought a refreshing, and slightly alarming, sexual frankness to the role of Elyot, that comedy’s fast-quipping, martini-sipping hero.

headline: ‘Mad Tiger’ and Other Films Join a New Wave of Punk Documentaries
abstract: In movies like “Los Punks” and “Mad Tiger,” filmmakers have been chronicling bands and scenes from China to California, Myanmar to Texas.
lead_paragraph: In the opening images of “Los Punks: We Are All We Have,” the director Angela Boatwright’s documentary about the thriving punk scene in the backyards of South-Central and East Los Angeles, two young women in miniskirts wrestle each other to the ground. A guitarist spins on his back, naked except for a small loincloth. There are guns, booze, vomiting and brawls, all set to the high-speed beats of the punk band Street Threat. It looks like chaos; indeed, a reveler describes it as such. But others speak of the camaraderie of these shows, how they give participants a keen sense of belonging. “I don’t feel at home anywhere else,” one says.

headline: N.F.L. Divisional Playoffs: Injuries and New Blood Could Sway Fates
abstract: Kansas City, winner of 11 straight, looks to upset New England in Saturday’s early game, followed by Green Bay-Arizona. On Sunday, Seattle plays at Carolina, and Pittsburgh is at Denver.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. playoffs divisional round is this weekend. Here are the matchups and who we think will win them.

headline: The Wines of Santa Cruz
abstract: An appellation defined by elevation in the mountains of Santa Cruz.
lead_paragraph: An appellation defined by elevation in the mountains of Santa Cruz.

headline: Santa Cruz Cabernet: Wines You Never Knew
abstract: The area south of San Francisco is the least-celebrated great American region for cabernet sauvignon.
lead_paragraph: WOODSIDE, Calif. — If you poke around the subdivisions in the foothills of the Santa Cruz Mountains, you may come across the remnants of La Questa Vineyard, which 100 years ago was thought to produce the finest cabernet sauvignon in California. It was first planted in 1884 by E. H. Rixford, a lawyer who modeled his 40 acres of vines on the blend used at Château Margaux. Now, the few remaining vines survive in one of the many yards in which residents enjoy the high-status hobby of grape-growing.

headline: Review: In ‘The Confidence Game’ by Maria Konnikova, the Siren Call of the Swindler
abstract: Analyzing the double-cross step by step, Ms. Konnikova explains the psychology of the grifter and the mark.
lead_paragraph: Almost all of us are suckers for books about suckers. What’s not to like? They flatter our lofty conception of ourselves — no chumps are we, with our wits about us and our nose for baloney as fine as a butcher’s — and they satisfy the secret part of us that delights in gossip and goggles at audacity.

headline: Hurricane Alex, a Rare January Storm, Forms in the Atlantic
abstract: Hurricane Alex, a Category 1 hurricane, was on target to collide with a string of islands off the coast of Portugal.
lead_paragraph: The first January-born hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean since 1938 formed on Thursday, and headed toward Portugal’s Azores islands.

headline: A Bitcoin Believer’s Crisis of Faith
abstract: A nasty fight has torn apart the core software developers of Bitcoin, exposing fundamental differences about the virtual currency’s future direction and raising questions of its long-term viability.
lead_paragraph: Mike Hearn, a British computer programmer, holed up in his two-bedroom apartment in Zurich over several days and nights last week, writing a cri de coeur.

headline: Defense Secretary Says U.S. Sailors Made Navigational Error Into Iranian Waters
abstract: Secretary Ashton B. Carter formally acknowledged that American error resulted in Navy vessels entering Iranian territorial waters.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The American sailors detained by Iran earlier this week made a navigational error that mistakenly took them into Iranian territorial waters, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said on Thursday.

headline: Anglican Church Disciplines U.S. Episcopals Over Gay Marriages
keywords: ['Episcopal Church', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ANGLICAN CHURCHES']
abstract: The disciplinary action, which limits the church’s participation in Anglican Communion affairs, is a serious setback for the church and other Anglican provinces that support gay rights.
lead_paragraph: After 13 years of rancor over conflicting views on homosexuality, the archbishops of the Anglican Communion have voted to impose sanctions for three years on the Episcopal Church, the American branch of the Communion, for its decision last summer to allow clergy to perform same-sex marriages, church officials said Thursday.

headline: Vail International Dance Festival Announces Program
abstract: Isabella Boylston of American Ballet Theater will be artist in residence and BalletX of Philadelphia will be the company in residence at this year’s Vail International Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: The American Ballet Theater principal Isabella Boylston will be artist in residence and the Philadelphia-based BalletX will be the company in residence at this year’s Vail International Dance Festival, which announced its 2016 program Thursday.

headline: Savages Embrace Love With Controlled Chaos on ‘Adore Life’
abstract: For their second album, the members of this London band worked with more melody but retained their signature rage and dissonance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “We always have to try things that scare us a little bit,” said Ayse Hassan, the bassist in the English band Savages. A year ago, Savages spent most of January in snowy, blustery New York City, working six days a week in a shared loft and rehearsal space in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: Searching for Cancer Maps in Free-Floating DNA
abstract: A new study suggests that one day a simple blood test may tell doctors whether you have the disease and, if so, where it is.
lead_paragraph: Loose pieces of DNA course through our veins. As cells in our body die, they cast off fragments of genes, some of which end up in the bloodstream, saliva and urine.

headline: As Refugees Flee Violence in Central America
abstract: Readers and rights activists discuss the Obama administration’s plans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Foursquare Raises $45 Million, Cutting Its Valuation Nearly in Half
abstract: The company, which is also shaking up its executive ranks, is focused on its data-based advertising and developer businesses.
lead_paragraph: When Dennis Crowley helped found Foursquare in 2009, he was ahead of the pack in creating a social app that used location technology. Now Foursquare may be at the front of another coming wave: tech start-ups that are raising money at lower valuations than before.

headline: In Florence, Transforming an Old Theater Into a Technicolor World
abstract: The designer Marco de Vincenzo and the artist Patrizio Travagli have collaborated to reimagine the city’s Teatro Niccolini.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, Florence’s oldest theater, the Teatro Niccolini, will reopen after 20 years. And it will play host to a very different kind of show: a fashion presentation from the young designer Marco de Vincenzo, during Pitti Uomo, the Italian tradeshow here.

headline: Bowie Tribute Concert to Have a Second Night, at Radio City
abstract: The Carnegie Hall concert honoring David Bowie on March 31 will be joined by a second tribute show, at Radio City Music Hall on April 1.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before David Bowie’s death, Carnegie Hall announced a concert honoring the singer on March 31. Now, the event, part of the City Winery founder Michael Dorf’s annual tribute series, will be reframed as a memorial concert, and a second show has been added at Radio City Music Hall, with Michael Stipe, Laurie Anderson and Cat Power joining one or both of the lineups.

headline: Inside the Armed Standoff in Oregon: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter Julie Turkewitz describes the scene in Burns, Ore., and at a nearby national wildlife refuge that has been occupied by protesters.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — As a reporter covering the West for The New York Times, I have learned that bringing the story to readers often involves flying from my home in Colorado, driving hours through the mountains and — occasionally — hiking to reach the people whose voices we want to collect.

headline: A Cure for Cancer?
abstract: A reader writes that she gets angry when she hears such talk.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alan Rickman (1946-2016)
abstract: Alan Rickman was a magnetic stage actor who found worldwide fame in film.
lead_paragraph: Alan Rickman was a magnetic stage actor who found worldwide fame in film.

headline: Astounding Feats in Pen, Ink and Magnifying Glass
abstract: These micrographic drawings, from the collection of Ricky Jay, are signed with some variation of “Matthias Buchinger, born without hands or feet.”
lead_paragraph: Matthias Buchinger must have been some kind of genius. A draftsman, calligrapher, magician and musician, he traveled all over Northern Europe to entertain kings and aristocrats as well as hoi polloi with amazing feats of physical dexterity. Buchinger was especially noted for elaborate drawings featuring biblical passages written in letters too small to be read by ordinary naked eyes.

headline: What Serendipity Requires
abstract: An epidemiologist writes that if we want to cultivate this art, “we must give experts enough time to get distracted by random observations.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Iran vs. Saudi Arabia
abstract: An Iranian dissident says that when an Iranian official criticizes Saudi Arabia’s human rights record, it’s a case of the pot calling the kettle black.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ISIS Attack in Indonesia
abstract: Two civilians and five assailants were killed in the explosions and gunfire in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday. The Islamic State has claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Two civilians and five assailants were killed in the explosions and gunfire in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday. The Islamic State has claimed responsibility.

headline: How We Judge Women
abstract: A reader urges society to value women based on their accomplishments and character rather than their looks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Once a Republican …
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A reader asks why someone would vote against his or her own interests.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: India, Praising Arrest of Militants, to Restart Talks with Pakistan
abstract: Indian officials said diplomatic meeting will rescheduled and called Pakistan’s arrest of members of a militant group an “important and positive" step.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian officials on Thursday said they would reschedule diplomatic talks with Pakistan, originally planned for Friday, “in the very near future,” expressing satisfaction with Pakistan’s arrest of militants thought to be connected to a recent attack on Indian soil.

headline: Intel’s Earnings Fall in Fourth Quarter, but Beat Expectations
abstract: The chip maker’s revenue was up slightly from the same time period last year, but money from data center chips was up markedly.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Not that long ago, Wall Street believed that as Intel goes, so goes much of the rest of the technology industry.

headline: U.S. Proposes Spending $4 Billion on Self-Driving Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'North American International Auto Show']
abstract: A proposal announced by the transportation secretary is meant to accelerate development of autonomous vehicles and remove hurdles for automakers.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With automakers and technology companies rushing to develop self-driving cars, the Obama administration on Thursday pledged to expedite regulatory guidelines for autonomous vehicles and invest in research to help bring them to market.

headline: F.D.A. Faulted for Problems With Drug Tracking
abstract: The system the Food and Drug Administration uses to keep data on drugs after they have come to market is incomplete, outdated and often inaccurate, federal investigators said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators said Thursday that there were flaws in the way the Food and Drug Administration tracked drugs after they came to market, raising questions about the agency’s effectiveness as the country’s main drug overseer.

headline: Review: ‘Band of Robbers’ Riffs on Mark Twain Characters in Today’s Missouri
abstract: This comedy, written and directed by Aaron and Adam Nee, offers variations on “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” and “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.”
lead_paragraph: The whimsical crime comedy “Band of Robbers” might be described as a hipster’s answer to the “National Treasure” movies, made for a more sophisticated audience and outfitted with literary credentials. This comic take on “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” and “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer” is infused with a gleefully absurdist sense of humor while retaining a childlike sense of wonder.

headline: Review: Miles Okazaki Bends Conventionality to His Whims at the Jazz Gallery
abstract: Mr. Okazaki and the members of his new band, Trickster, each had a chance to display strengths during a concert at the Jazz Gallery.
lead_paragraph: “We’re not trying to trick you,” the guitarist Miles Okazaki said at the Jazz Gallery on Wednesday night. Under the circumstances, the reassurance was understandable: Mr. Okazaki was introducing his new band, Trickster, and he didn’t want to start off on the wrong footing, not with so many twists in the road ahead.

headline: Mortality Lives Again as Funeral and Cemetery Items Pique Interest
abstract: Books and auctions are embracing artifacts relating to funerals and cemeteries. And old Chinese renderings of ships and ports are for sale.
lead_paragraph: The painful subjects of mourning and burying the dead are drawing attention at museums and auction houses, while some attractions in the field are reaching the ends of their runs.

headline: Review: ‘Tommy Tune, Tonight!’ Is the Musical Autobiography of a Showbiz Trouper
abstract: Mr. Tune’s new show at the Café Carlyle includes a range of theater history and a lot of tap-dancing.
lead_paragraph: If the ageless song and dance man Tommy Tune seems to have one foot off the ground and his head in the clouds, one reason is that he stands tall (“5 feet 17¾ inches,” by his count) and can literally see over most people’s heads. At Tuesday’s opening night performance of his show “Tommy Tune, Tonight!” at the Café Carlyle, he was the suave, ebullient charmer we all know and treasure. Over the decades, this ingenuous grown-up boy from Texas has also acquired the glitter-crusted shell of a show business trouper like his “spiritual godmother,” Carol Channing.

headline: Third Gunman in Attacks in Paris Area Is Identified
abstract: The office of the Paris prosecutor said Chakib Akrouh, who blew himself up in a police raid Nov. 18, was the third jihadist involved in the terror attacks in Paris and its suburbs in November.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris prosecutor identified on Thursday a Belgian-Moroccan man as one of the previously unidentified jihadists involved in the terror attacks in Paris and its suburbs in November.

headline: Review: Barb Jungr Applies Her Emphatic Voice to the Beatles’ Music
abstract: This British cabaret singer and the Broadway musical director John McDaniel performed on Wednesday at Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Who among us isn’t familiar with the refrain “Ah, look at all the lonely people” from the Beatles classic “Eleanor Rigby”? To hear it performed by the great British cabaret singer Barb Jungr and the Broadway musical director John McDaniel at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Wednesday evening was to find it clarified as never before.

headline: A Second Chance for Sebastian Coe to Clean Up His Sport
abstract: It can be difficult to find purity at the top of international sports. Despite corruption in track and field, Coe, the I.A.A.F. president, still may be the best option.
lead_paragraph: In the world of Olympic sports, Richard W. Pound, the former chief of the World Anti-Doping Agency, is known as a straight talker who has no tolerance for corruption or doping.

headline: Donald Trump’s Popularity Hits New Heights in Latest National Poll
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s popularity has climbed to its highest level to date less than a month before the first Republican votes will be cast, according to a new national NBC/Wall Street Journal poll.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s popularity has climbed to its highest level to date less than a month before the first Republican votes will be cast, according to a national NBC/Wall Street Journal poll released Thursday that shows Republicans becoming increasingly comfortable with the idea of the billionaire businessman being their presidential nominee.

headline: An Antarctic Art Project, Complete With Fake Passports
abstract: Lucy and Jorge Orta’s “Antarctica World Passport Delivery Bureau,” which follows the pair’s expedition to the South Pole, offers visitors a (symbolic) universal citizenship.
lead_paragraph: For more than five decades, the South Pole has remained free of any one nation’s rule; rather, under the Antarctic Treaty, which includes signatures from 53 nations, Antarctic territory is a demilitarized, nuclear-free, neutral zone. Or is it? “Antarctic Flag,” a work by the artists Lucy and Jorge Orta that was first unveiled during their 2007 expedition to Antarctica, stands as a symbolic bricolage of the territory’s supporting nations and their shared values — but also raises the question of whether peaceful coexistence there is sustainable. The partners and artistic duo, also referred to as Studio Orta, based in France and internationally recognized for their socially mindful practice, are all too aware of potential danger in the region. Come 2048, a 1991 agreement protecting what lurks beneath the ice there — oil, coal and kimberlite (thus, maybe, diamonds) — will be open for review, and it’s unclear to what lengths some nations might compete to have sole ownership.

headline: Review: In ‘Turandot’ and ‘La Bohème,’ a New Depth of Emotion
abstract: Puccini’s Mimì and Turandot each have received a multilayered interpretation as Franco Zeffirelli’s productions of these works have returned to the Metropolitan Opera with new casts.
lead_paragraph: The frail seamstress Mimì and the fierce princess Turandot are two opposite poles of Puccinian womanhood, and both are characters that can seem one-dimensional. But each have received a multilayered interpretation as Franco Zeffirelli’s lavish productions of “Turandot” and “La Bohème” have returned to the Metropolitan Opera with new casts.

headline: Zane Zhou
abstract: The artist’s paired photographs capture summer nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s paired photographs capture summer nostalgia.

headline: Dreamy, Sexy Photos of Sun-Drenched Summer Afternoons
abstract: The young photographer Zane Zhou pairs moody images of young men with perfectly composed trees, seascapes and roadsides.
lead_paragraph: Lovers, friends, the smell of the sea, the warmth of the sun on the nape of your neck: Zane Zhou’s photographs, redolent of summertime nostalgia, are a reminder of the powerful, universal intimacy a photographer can create with an unknown viewer. Both aspects of Zhou’s artistic background — he studied painting in Shanghai before moving to New York to pursue fashion photography at the School of Visual Arts in 2013 — are evident in his photo pairs, which juxtapose dreamy, moody images of young men against perfectly composed trees, seascapes and roadsides. “These photographs capture the ephemeral journey of the golden moments of summer and the ways we experience and spend our youth,” Zhou says. (And if you can’t get enough of the young photographer’s work, check out his contributions for T.)

headline: Ben McAdoo Is Replacing, Not Replicating, His Boss With the Giants
abstract: While not a splashy choice for head coach, McAdoo, the team’s offensive coordinator for the last two years, is not a continuation of the Tom Coughlin era, either.
lead_paragraph: The Giants’ pool of candidates to replace Tom Coughlin was short on pizazz from the beginning. Half the candidates were brainy tacticians in headsets, the football equivalent of Sheldon from “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: Review: In Michael Bay’s ‘13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi,’ Clarity Isn’t the Objective
abstract: Mr. Bay has moderately scaled back his extreme-cinema approach for the story about the attack on the American diplomatic mission in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Slipped into “13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi,” among the torrential bullets and convulsive mayhem, is a protracted advertisement for a Mercedes-Benz S.U.V. A dramatization of the 2012 attack on the American diplomatic mission in Libya that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, the movie is a pummeling slog — 45 minutes of setup and an eternity of relentless combat. So it’s a relief when the director Michael Bay, amid this bleak fusillade, provides a little zigzagging action-movie-style relief. You can’t help but admire how well the truck holds up with its wheels aflame, like a 21st-century chariot of fire.

headline: Martha Kelly in ‘Baskets’: Funny, if You’re O.K. With That
abstract: Ms. Kelly, a longtime stand-up comic, discusses her role on a new FX show.
lead_paragraph: Martha Kelly isn’t sure why Zach Galifianakis called her “out of the blue” a couple of years ago and asked her to star in his new FX comedy, “Baskets,” which debuts Thursday, Jan. 21. But she’s pretty sure it wasn’t for her dramatic gifts.

headline: That Jeb Bush Freight Train? A Wreck, Marco Rubio Allies Chortle
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Political Advertising', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: After Mr. Bush’s “super PAC,” Right to Rise, imagined Mr. Rubio as a weathervane and Mr. Bush as a freight train by comparison, the super PAC behind Mr. Rubio, fired back.
lead_paragraph: After Jeb Bush’s “super PAC,” Right to Rise, imagined Senator Marco Rubio as a weathervane and Mr. Bush as a freight train by comparison, Conservative Solutions PAC, which is behind Mr. Rubio, fired back with this ad, acidly titled “Train Wreck.”

headline: Galleries to Mount Joint Carolee Schneemann Exhibition
abstract: P.P.O.W. and Galerie Lelong will collaborate on that show. Also, the artist Marcel Dzama is designing sets and costumes for Justin Peck’s new ballet.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the artist Carolee Schneemann may be best known for pulling a scroll out of her vagina.

headline: Review: ‘Morphia Series’ Presents a Duet of Darkness and Depth
abstract: Inspired by the god of dreams, this piece by the choreographer Helen Herbertson and the designer Ben Cobham relies more on effect than on substance.
lead_paragraph: The god of dreams is an apt subject for any dance, where reality is seldom the main focus. In “Morphia Series,” the Melbourne dancer and choreographer Helen Herbertson and the designer Ben Cobham present a morsel of a piece inspired by Morpheus, that god. Before it starts, audience members are offered an actual morsel: blue brie, passion fruit mascarpone, nectarine and a rose petal on polenta.

headline: Chipotle’s New Mantra: Safe Food, Not Just Fresh
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'E Coli (Bacteria)', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Restaurants']
abstract: An E. coli outbreak has been a particularly hard blow for a popular chain that has based its reputation on fresh food.
lead_paragraph: Not many business success stories rival Chipotle Mexican Grill’s.

abstract: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: State Street Settles Pay-to-Play Charges for $12 Million
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Money Laundering', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The S.E.C. has charged that a former State Street executive and an outside lobbyist made cash payments and campaign contributions in exchange for public pension contracts.
lead_paragraph: State Street’s banking unit will pay $12 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that an executive and an outside lobbyist operated a pay-to-play scheme to win the firm contracts from Ohio pension funds.

abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Ride Along 2,” “13 Hours” and “In the Shadow of Women.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Ride Along 2,” “13 Hours” and “In the Shadow of Women.”

lead_paragraph: More than seven years after the worst of the financial crisis, Goldman Sachs is again paying a price for the role it played.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Beirut, Russia and Indonesia.

headline: Review: ‘Maurice Hines Tappin’ Thru Life,’ a Jazz- and Tap-Filled Journey Through the Past
abstract: In this variety-style show, Mr. Hines tells the story of his career rise and that of his brother, Gregory, who died in 2003.
lead_paragraph: Any committed theatergoer knows what a difference a day makes: how much a show can change, for good or ill, from one performance to the next. But critics rarely get to see that in action before we write. We swoop in just once, and whatever is happening in the moment is what we have to go on.

headline: Review: ‘Ride Along 2’ Reloads Twin Barrels of Ice Cube and Kevin Hart
abstract: The stars reunite as mismatched police partners, now on a Miami drug lord’s trail. Ken Jeong, Olivia Munn and Sherri Shepherd lend a hand.
lead_paragraph: “Ride Along 2,” it may not surprise you to learn, is a lot like “Ride Along,” only less so. The buddy-cop action-comedy is a foolproof genre, though it’s also one that requires a fool. This franchise is lucky to have Kevin Hart in that role, and his manic comic energy is enough to make the sequel something other than a complete waste of time. But the genre is also stubbornly innovation-proof, and there’s not much new to see here.

headline: 4 Suspects Are Expected to Be Released in Brooklyn Rape Case
abstract: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, said his office needed more time as conflicting statements and videos clouded accounts of the attack last week.
lead_paragraph: Four of the five defendants suspected of raping an 18-year-old woman at a Brownsville playground on Jan. 7 were expected to be out of jail by Thursday night, after the Brooklyn district attorney alerted the court that he would not make the initial deadline to obtain indictments against them.

headline: Planned Parenthood Sues Activists Who Made Secret Videotapes
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The suit states that the defendants set up a fake company claiming to be a provider of fetal tissue to researchers, violating racketeering and state privacy laws.
lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood mounted a legal counterattack Thursday against the anti-abortion activists who used covertly taped videos to accuse the organization of trading in aborted baby parts, charging in a federal lawsuit that “anti-abortion extremists” had engaged in a three-year “complex criminal enterprise.”

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Jan. 16 Through 24
abstract: The comedian Mario Cantone will perform on Jan. 21, 22 and 23 at Levity Live, in West Nyack.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Young Republicans in New York
keywords: ['Youth', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The oldest such chapter in the country, the New York Young Republican Club is a very old club but a small one.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Wednesday evening, a young woman wandered, alone, into the dimly lighted basement of the Penny Farthing, a bar in the East Village, and cautiously asked one of the few people there, Jen Saunders, 36, if she was a Republican. She nodded; the woman looked relieved. “It’s almost like we’re a secret society,” Ms. Saunders said later, laughing.

headline: Green Bay Packers at Arizona Cardinals Preview
abstract: The Cardinals defense is short-handed, but the offense is so explosive that it may not matter against the Packers.

headline: Seattle Seahawks at Carolina Panthers Preview
abstract: The Seahawks and the Panthers seem nearly unbeatable. The Panthers, the home team, get the edge, even if it is by just a sliver.

headline: Six Artists From Iran at Grey Art Gallery
abstract: This exhibition includes fascinating work from before and after Iran’s revolution; and it looks great.
lead_paragraph: Time decides. When an exhibition scheduled for the winter slot at Grey Art Gallery at New York University wasn’t ready, a replacement had to be found, and “Global/Local 1960-2015: Six Artists From Iran,” set for a future date, was moved forward. If there was a scramble to pull it off, you’d barely know. Organized by the gallery’s director, Lynn Gumpert, the show looks great, thought through, with the improvisatory lift that adrenaline can provide.

headline: Review: ‘In the Shadow of Women’ Focuses on the Female Sides of a Triangle
abstract: This drama from Philippe Garrel depicts two filmmakers, one of whom is a philandering husband. But Mr. Garrel is more interested in the story’s women.
lead_paragraph: At first, “In the Shadow of Women,” Philippe Garrel’s slender new drama, invites you to take its title ironically. Manon and Pierre, the married couple at its center, are Parisian bohemians who embrace a traditional asymmetry in their roles. They work together making documentary films, but they are Pierre’s films. Manon, who earns money serving lunch in a school cafeteria, is proud to subordinate her own ambitions to her husband’s. “It’s not a sacrifice, it’s a choice,” she tells her skeptical mother.

headline: Amazon Subsidiary Gains Approval to Ship Ocean Freight
abstract: Amazon’s China subsidiary has received United States approval to ship ocean freight for other companies, in another move by the retailer to build out its logistics operations.
lead_paragraph: Drones might get all the attention, but Amazon’s interest in more traditional methods of moving things around is not slowing down.

headline: Painting Offered a Different Palette for David Bowie’s Talents
abstract: David Bowie grasped painting as a lifeline in the 1970s and went on to create art until the end.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One day in the early 1990s, Karen Wright, then editor of the British magazine Modern Painters, received a phone call asking if David Bowie could come to dinner with her editorial board. “We arranged to meet at the Groucho Club” in London, Ms. Wright said in a telephone interview. “When I arrived, he was looking at a Picasso catalog, and we immediately began to talk about the images, and then quickly chose a cover for my next magazine.” Mr. Bowie joined the board, and over the next few years he interviewed numerous art world figures, including Balthus, Damien Hirst, Tracey Emin, Jeff Koons and Julian Schnabel.

headline: David Bowie on His Favorite Artists
abstract: “Art was, seriously, the only thing I’d ever wanted to own,” Mr. Bowie said in a 1998 conversation about his own collections and creations.
lead_paragraph: This interview was published in The New York Times on June 14, 1998. It is reprinted here in full, with an updated introduction.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Jan. 16 Through 24
abstract: “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,” starring JC McCann, will be presented at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on Jan. 24.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Yesterday Tomorrow,’ a Meeting of Songs About Time
abstract: A Beatles ballad and an “Annie” anthem blend in Annie Dorsen’s hourlong work at La MaMa, part of the Coil festival.
lead_paragraph: The computer is the conductor, and in some respects the composer, too, in “Yesterday Tomorrow,” a haunting and strangely beautiful musical theater piece that is as simple in its emotional appeal as it is complex in its conception and execution. Created and directed by Annie Dorsen, the work, which can be seen through Saturday at LaMaMa as part of the Coil festival from Performance Space 122, is the third in what Ms. Dorsen calls her “algorithmic theater” trilogy.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Campaign Outraged by Bernie Sanders Ad on Wall Street
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s aides expressed outrage over a Bernie Sanders ad that they said violated Mr. Sanders’s pledge to never run a negative attack ad against a political opponent.
lead_paragraph: In the pantheon of campaign attack ads, this one seemed gentle enough: Senator Bernie Sanders explains his intention to regulate the financial industry, including breaking up the big Wall Street banks.

headline: ‘Concrete Cuba’ Visits a Quieter Period of Latin American Modernism
abstract: A first glimpse of what a small group of Cuban artists were up to in the 1950s and early ’60s.
lead_paragraph: The history of art is a giant puzzle that will never be complete. New pieces constantly arrive, unsettling one area or another, altering the overall shape.

abstract: WNYC and the Apollo Theater will present the 10th edition of their annual King celebration, and the choreographer Bill T. Jones will discuss the influence of activism on his work.
lead_paragraph: In 1964 the New School hosted a series of lectures called “The American Race Crisis.” In 2016 the subject still feels urgent.

headline: Yoko Ono’s ‘The Riverbed’ Has a Therapeutic Bent
abstract: Ms. Ono’s exhibition is at the Andrea Rosen and the Lelong galleries and invites visitors to participate in the artwork.
lead_paragraph: As a conceptual artist, Yoko Ono practices a vapid kind of spiritual therapy. Visiting her two-gallery exhibition is like attending a New Age summer camp program run by a bossy teacher who treats everyone like children.

headline: Stories Spill Out as Spotlight Is Shined on Sexism in Astronomy
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Female students and professionals have been using the hashtag #astroSH to share stories of how sexism has affected them.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Kirkpatrick, an undergrad student, was wearing dishwashing gloves to clean part of her research experiment when a senior member of her team walked by.

headline: ‘Zineb Sedira: Present Tense’ at the Taymour Grahne Gallery
abstract: Ms. Sedira explores the idea of cultural gain and loss in her first New York solo exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Zineb Sedira was born in Paris in 1963 to Algerian immigrants, and has lived in London since the 1980s. Widely exhibited in Europe, she now has a very fine solo of recent work, “Zineb Sedira: Present Tense,” at Taymour Grahne. The idea of cultural gain and loss, and the complications both entail, is a constant theme in her art. A substantial part of this exhibition, organized by Sam Bardaouil and Till Fellrath, is devoted to a multipart project on the subject of lighthouses built under French colonial rule along the North African coastline, and still in use, weather-battered and outdated.

headline: Sally Michel, Landscapes of Color and Texture
abstract: This exhibition presents about 30 paintings from the 1950s, mostly landscapes, of an artist who was in the shadow of her husband, Milton Avery.

headline: Review: Richard Gere, ‘The Benefactor’ Who Pulls the Strings
abstract: In ‘The Benefactor,’ Mr. Gere, who is dependent on morphine, makes others dependent on him.
lead_paragraph: Except for occasional glimpses, Richard Gere has always held his dark side in reserve, the better to embody romantic dreamboats like those in his box-office calling cards “An Officer and a Gentleman” and “Pretty Woman.” But that was then. At 66, with a snowy mane and an imperial demeanor, Mr. Gere now exerts the magnetism of a swashbuckling lion in winter.

headline: Review: ‘A Perfect Day’ About Aid Workers in the Balkans
abstract: Benicio Del Toro and Tim Robbins star in this Fernando León de Aranoa’s film set in the Balkan countryside in 1995.
lead_paragraph: Benicio Del Toro shambling around like a latter-day Robert Mitchum is the best reason to see “A Perfect Day.” A serviceable, watchable movie set someplace in the Balkans in 1995, this oddity was shot in Spain and features a tight, largely English-speaking cast — including the American veteran Tim Robbins, and two European actresses, Mélanie Thierry and Olga Kurylenko — that seems to have been tapped to reach as many film markets as possible. This talent sampler fits the movie, which primarily registers as a would-be business opportunity for investment types.

headline: For Children Listings for Jan. 15-21
abstract: Rebecca Northan used to go on blind dates, with predictably unpredictable results. Now, at least half the time, she ends up with a knight in shining armor.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Northan used to go on blind dates, with predictably unpredictable results. Now, at least half the time, she ends up with a knight in shining armor.

headline: Review: ‘Moonwalkers,’ a Conspiracy-Theory Comedy
abstract: This film, starring Ron Perlman and Rupert Grint, invests too much in the comedy potential of things that haven’t been funny for a long while.
lead_paragraph: The misguided “Moonwalkers” invests too much in the comedy potential of things that haven’t been funny for a long while. Its plot revolves around the notion — what, again? — that there was a conspiracy to fake the Apollo 11 lunar landing. And its writer, Dean Craig, and director, Antoine Bardou-Jacquet, seem to think there’s nothing more hilarious than having characters stumble around stoned.

lead_paragraph: “Intruders,” a distasteful thriller with a bludgeoning sensibility and little common sense, turns a cozy family home into a clockwork house of horrors.

headline: In Taiwan, Survivor Mentality Stymies Tech Innovation
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Innovation', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Mobile Applications', 'Start-ups']
abstract: As voters chose a new president over the weekend, a rare point of agreement between Taiwan’s fractious political parties was that the tech industry needs help.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — With its offices sporting wood flooring, a roof painted bright orange and conference rooms named after target markets in Southeast Asia, AppWorks, one of Taiwan’s few start-up accelerators, has the look and feel of the American counterparts it’s modeled on.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 15-21
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Black Comic-Book Festival (Saturday) The comic series “Watson and Holmes” is like an alternate reality of Arthur Conan Doyle’s Victorian detective duo. To start, the protagonists of these comic books are black; London looks a lot more like Harlem; and a subtitle like “A Study in Scarlet” becomes “A Study in Black.” The series is one example of many more in which black comic books have reimagined the world, or in some cases even created their own brand of speculative science fiction.

headline: Review: In ‘Norm of the North,’ a Polar Bear Takes a Stand
abstract: In this animated film, the voluble title character heads to New York to fight a proposal for condo construction in his habitat.
lead_paragraph: Of all the creatures in the animal kingdom, it is arguably the polar bear whose real-world behavior differs most starkly from that of its anthropomorphized iterations. Cartoon polar bears are almost unfailingly benign and cute; real-world polar bears will swipe your head off before you can contrive an observation of how surprisingly intimidating they appear. A real-life grizzly you might be able to run from, or successfully play dead for. With a polar bear, you’d have to be really, really good at playing dead, I reckon.

headline: A News Agency With Scoops Directly From ISIS, and a Veneer of Objectivity
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Propaganda', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The agency, Amaq, is not officially part of the Islamic State’s media apparatus — but it functions much that way, Rukmini Callimachi writes.
lead_paragraph: The San Bernardino shootings. The killing rampage this week in a Baghdad mall. On Thursday, it was the explosion that ripped through a Starbucks in Jakarta.

headline: How Pat Buchanan Has Come to Be More Than Another Trump ‘Wacko’
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2000', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mr. Trump once called Mr. Buchanan a “neo–Nazi.” But times have changed.
lead_paragraph: In one of his early flirtations with politics, Donald Trump took dead aim at a popular right-wing politician he denounced as a “neo-Nazi” and appealing to the “wacko vote” — Pat Buchanan, a conservative ideologue whose campaign for the 2000 Republican presidential nomination was laced with harsh anti-immigrant rhetoric and other bombastic foretastes of Mr. Trump’s own run this year.

headline: Review: In ‘o’ death,’ Creation Stirs Amid the Specter of Imminent Death
abstract: This solo show, from the Norwegian company Findlay//Sandsmark and part of the Coil festival, conjures apocalyptic imagery before imparting glimpses of hope.
lead_paragraph: Finding your seat at “o’ death” requires some groping in the dark. Perhaps audience members, fumbling in the faint glow of an usher’s flashlight, are meant to identify with the dancer who eventually comes into view, scrambling on the floor of the nearly lightless room. That would be Marit Sandsmark, the lone performer in this postapocalyptic work by the Norwegian company Findlay//Sandsmark, which had its United States premiere at Ideal Glass Gallery in the East Village on Tuesday. (Ms. Sandsmark choreographed the show; Iver Findlay, her husband and a Wooster Group alum, directed and designed it.)

keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — After his State of the Union address, President Obama headed to two states that voted against him, in part, aides said, because he wanted more encounters in his last year in office with people who disagree with him.

headline: Paul Kirk, Ex-D.N.C. Chairman and Ted Kennedy Confidante, Endorses Bernie Sanders
abstract: Paul Kirk Jr., a former Democratic National Committee chairman and Ted Kennedy confidante, endorsed Bernie Sanders before a rally at Dartmouth College.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H. — Hoping to build on the momentum that has led to his rise in the polls in Iowa and New Hampshire, Senator Bernie Sanders on Thursday evening announced the endorsement of Paul G. Kirk Jr., a confidante of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and a former Democratic National Committee chairman.

headline: Jets General Manager Mike Maccagnan Hints at Off-Season Plans
abstract: In a lighthearted, 30-minute session, Maccagnan was most candid in discussing his interest in re-signing Ryan Fitzpatrick, who set a franchise record with 31 touchdown passes.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets General Manager Mike Maccagnan cautiously laid out his team’s off-season plans for the first time on Thursday, skimping on the details while he tiptoed around questions about the futures of soon-to-be free agents like Muhammad Wilkerson, Damon Harrison and quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick.

headline: Sixth Republican Debate: Analysis
abstract: We provided live analysis of first Republican debate in 2016, featuring seven candidates leading in the polls.

headline: Contracts Announced for Runs to Space Station
abstract: NASA announced on Thursday the companies it had selected for a second round of contracts to take cargo to the International Space Station.
lead_paragraph: NASA announced on Thursday the companies it had selected for a second round of contracts to take cargo to the International Space Station. Two of the contracts will go to companies already performing that task: the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation of Hawthorne, Calif., better known as SpaceX, and Orbital ATK of Dulles, Va. NASA also selected the Sierra Nevada Corporation of Sparks, Nev., which has been developing a mini space shuttle known as Dream Chaser. The first mission is to fly in 2019, and each company will operate at least six cargo missions. NASA officials said the new contracts would provide many more options than they currently have. The Dream Chaser will be able to land like a plane on a runway, allowing payloads like scientific experiments to be unloaded within a few hours. The three contracts, which run through 2024, when the space station is scheduled to be retired, have a maximum value of $14 billion, but NASA officials said they did not expect to spend nearly that much.

headline: Real Madrid Says Transfer Ban Over Youth Signings Is Unfair
abstract: FIFA said that Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid could not sign new players until the summer of 2017 because they had improperly signed players younger than 18.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Real Madrid responded on Thursday to a transfer ban imposed by FIFA, soccer’s global governing body, by claiming the sanction was unfairly linked to some youth players whose relatives were already employees of the club, including two sons of its new coach, Zinedine Zidane.

headline: Morgan Stanley Heeds Its Investors
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: After long holding off on a big overhaul, Morgan Stanley is cutting hundreds of jobs on its troubled bond and commodity trading desks.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, meetings between James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, and the bank’s investors often came back to the same question: When was Mr. Gorman going to do more to deal with the bank’s most problematic business — its bond and commodity trading desks.

headline: Who Made the Smartest Comment of the Republican Debate?
abstract: Tell us what you think.
lead_paragraph: During the October 28 and December 19 debates, we asked you to tell us who made the most ridiculous comment. Tonight, we want to know the opposite — who made the most intelligent remark?

abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas calling out Donald Trump for the apparent high crime of “embodying New York values” presents us with the politics of hypocrisy.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas called out Donald Trump this week for the high crime of “embodying New York values,” which, translated into Republican primary-ese, apparently means that Mr. Trump has cooties.
