headline: As Germany Welcomes Migrants, Sexual Attacks in Cologne Point to a New Reality
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sex Crimes', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'New Year', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Before the violent assaults on women in Cologne on New Year’s Eve, the police thought their biggest worry would be pickpocketing and fireworks among the crowds.
lead_paragraph: COLOGNE, Germany — In early December, the Cologne police made their New Year’s Eve preparations. Drawing on the previous year’s experience, they identified their biggest worry as pickpocketing and fireworks among the crowds. So they increased their holiday deployment, to 142 from 88, concentrating on the banks of the Rhine River, where revelers traditionally gather for a giant fireworks display.

headline: In Climate Move, Obama Halts New Coal Mining Leases on Public Lands
abstract: The administration announced the action Friday as it considers an overhaul of the program that could lead to increased costs for energy companies and deter future extractions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced on Friday a halt to new coal mining leases on public lands as it considers an overhaul of the program that could lead to increased costs for energy companies and a slowdown in extraction.

headline: American Apparel Is Said to Reject Takeover Bid and Dov Charney Return
abstract: It was unclear whether Hagan Capital and Silver Creek would raise their offer or seek to persuade a bankruptcy judge to accept their bid.
lead_paragraph: The board of American Apparel, a struggling retailer that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in October, has rejected a takeover offer from investors aligned with the company’s ousted founder, Dov Charney, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Cuomo to Continue Shrinking State’s Share of CUNY’s Costs
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s new budget would shift one-third of the City University’s costs to the city from the state, displeasing Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Amid the billions of dollars that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo disbursed with dizzying speed in his State of the State address on Wednesday — $100 billion for infrastructure here, $20 billion for housing there — he left one half-billion conspicuously unmentioned: a third of the annual budget of the City University of New York, which Mr. Cuomo’s latest budget proposed to offload from the state’s balance sheet onto the city’s.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner on a TV Road Less Traveled
abstract: The reality TV show “I Am Cait,” which has explored transgender issues, has drawn middling audiences after a strong start.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — After the first season of E!’s “I Am Cait,” the reality series about Caitlyn Jenner’s first months as a transgender woman, there was no mistaking that it was a different show from the one she used to star on, “Keeping Up With the Kardashians.”

headline: Cuomo’s Budget Opens New Chapter in Rivalry With de Blasio
keywords: ['State of the State Message (NYS)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed on Thursday to use “any means necessary” to reverse cuts outlined in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s budget plan, which the mayor praised on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio issued a stern rebuke to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday for placing new financial strains on New York City, saying he would use “any means necessary” to restore hundreds of millions of dollars in state financing that the governor appeared to have cut from his annual budget.

headline: Investigation of SEAL Conduct in Afghanistan Is Reopened
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Detainees', 'Torture']
abstract: The N.C.I.S. has begun further inquiry into allegations that Navy SEALs and Afghan police militiamen beat several detainees, including one who died, at an isolated outpost in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The Naval Criminal Investigative Service has reopened its investigation into allegations that Navy SEALs and Afghan police militiamen beat several detainees, including one who died, at an isolated outpost in Afghanistan in 2012, agency officials said Thursday.

headline: Luis Arroyo, Baseball’s Best Reliever in ’61, Dies at 88
abstract: A left-hander with a baffling screwball, he pitched in two World Series and as a reliever helped Whitey Ford achieve his finest season with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Luis Arroyo, a stoutly built left-hander with a baffling screwball who was an All-Star in each major league, pitched in two World Series and as a reliever helped Whitey Ford achieve his finest season with the Yankees, died on Wednesday in Guayanilla, P.R. He was 88.

headline: Giorgio Gomelsky, Impresario Who Gave the Rolling Stones Their Start, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Gomelsky, who was born on a ship going from Ukraine to Italy, also worked with the Yardbirds early in their career.
lead_paragraph: Giorgio Gomelsky, a rock impresario and record producer who gave the Rolling Stones their first exposure, managed the Yardbirds and went on to champion an eclectic batch of progressive rock groups in the United States, died on Wednesday in the Bronx. He was 81.

headline: Marine Veteran Held by Iran Received Care, His Family Says
abstract: Amir Hekmati was treated for swelling in his face and neck at a hospital, relatives said, the first time he has been allowed to leave prison since he was seized in 2011.
lead_paragraph: A Marine veteran who is the longest-held American prisoner in Iran was allowed to receive medical treatment in a hospital outside his prison in recent weeks, his family said Thursday. It is unclear whether the hospital visit might be a precursor to his release.

headline: René Angélil, Who Discovered and Then Married Celine Dion, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Angélil recognized Ms. Dion’s singing talent when she was 12 and guided her career for more than 30 years.
lead_paragraph: René Angélil, the producer who discovered the singer Celine Dion at age 12 and later married her after leading her to stardom, died on Thursday at their home in Las Vegas. He was 73.

headline: A Long Way From Guyana, Near a Family He Rarely Gets to See
abstract: Frank Gaul and his wife left their native Guyana in 2010 to be closer to their daughter and her children in New York, but his night job as a security guard limits the time he can spend with them.
lead_paragraph: At his age, Frank Gaul said, he should be retired and spending his days lolling in a rocking chair. Instead, Mr. Gaul, 67, is on his feet eight hours a day, working as a security guard.

headline: Review: Michael Frayn’s ‘Noises Off’ Returns to Broadway
abstract: Mr. Frayn’s comedy depicting a company of second-tier actors performing in a British sex farce is at the American Airlines Theater through March 6.
lead_paragraph: “Where are we?” asks the dazed-looking woman in a maid’s uniform, her voice throaty with fatigue. Looking around with confused wonder, she seems to have just awakened from a yearlong nap, or gone through a carwash without a car.

abstract: In which we learn to fully appreciate a Patrick Berry puzzle.

headline: My Take on the Republican Presidential Debate
abstract: Republican candidates for president dueled in another televised debate, the modern version of gladiatorial combat. As an experiment I’m posting my tweets about it here.
lead_paragraph: Republican candidates for president dueled in another televised debate, the modern version of gladiatorial combat. Instead of writing a column, I’m collecting some of my tweets about the debate in this blog post, which I’m updating until it ends. These are raw and rushed ruminations, journalism on the fly, but it’s an attempt to hold politicians accountable instantaneously for their rhetorical stretches. I welcome your comments.

lead_paragraph: Acrobatic saves, pucks off posts, a few skirmishes and near fights. It was no surprise that the second Brooklyn battle between the Rangers and the Islanders had them all. Finally, after nearly two scoreless periods of breathless action, there were a few goals, too.

Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas sharply attacked each other on Thursday night over the Canadian-born Mr. Cruz’s eligibility to be president and Mr. Trump’s “New York values,” shedding any semblance of cordiality as they dominated a Republican debate less than three weeks before the Iowa caucuses.

lead_paragraph: He Wenjun, a teacher and Xibe language translator, sings a popular folk song, “Xiao Qiao Cried for Zhou Yu,” based on a tale from the Ming dynasty novel “Romance of the Three Kingdoms.”

headline: In Song, a Remnant of China’s Former Imperial Language
abstract: Watch a speaker of Xibe, a dialect of Manchu, sing a folk song inspired by the novel “Romance of the Three Kingdoms.”
lead_paragraph: Manchu, the imperial language of the Qing dynasty (1644-1912), may be effectively extinct, but a close cousin clings to life in an unlikely place: a collection of towns near China’s border with Kazakhstan, 2,800 miles from the language’s former stronghold in northeastern China.

headline: Ohio State in High-Priced Apparel Deal
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Uniforms', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Football', 'Football (College)']
abstract: A 15-year contract extension between Ohio State and Nike is believed to be the largest college apparel deal ever.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year contract extension between Ohio State and Nike is believed to be the largest college apparel deal ever. Once the deal goes into full effect in 2018, when Ohio State’s previous deal was to expire, its value will average $16.8 million per year. That is more than the amounts Texas and Michigan each get according to their recently signed deals with Nike, and more than Notre Dame reportedly receives in its deal with Under Armour, which went into effect in 2014. The Wall Street Journal first reported the extension.

abstract: Williams’s first opponent, Camila Giorgi, is the highest seed she could have faced in the first round, but if Williams advances, the potential threats in her half of the field are players she has dominated.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian Open draw was announced Friday morning, and in her first official match since last September, Serena Williams will face an Italian player entirely different from the one who dealt her a stunning loss in the semifinals of the United States Open.

headline: The New York Times Gets a Debate Shoutout

headline: When Beauty Strikes
abstract: Modern art has certain kinds of social value, but we have suffered the loss of an old understanding of how beauty transforms the soul.
lead_paragraph: Across the street from my apartment building in Washington there’s a gigantic supermarket and a CVS. Above the supermarket there had been a large empty space with floor-to-ceiling windows. The space was recently taken by a ballet school, so now when I step outside in the evenings I see dozens of dancers framed against the windows, doing their exercises — gracefully and often in unison.

headline: The City Takes a Hit in Mr. Cuomo’s Budget
keywords: ['State of the State Message (NYS)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Editorials']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio must defend the city’s interests in any struggle over funds from the state budget.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s new budget, released Wednesday, threw what looks like a gut punch at New York City: bam, hundreds of millions of dollars in state revenue suddenly pulled away. It was actually three punches: a proposal to withdraw state support for the City University of New York; a plan to require the city — and no other municipality — to cover the cost of increases in its Medicaid program; and potentially costly changes in how the state runs its STAR income-tax rebates. All told, the cost to the city is expected to reach nearly a billion dollars in the coming fiscal year, and keep growing.

headline: Michigan’s Failure to Protect Flint
keywords: ['Water', 'Lead', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: The state, which had played down findings of high levels of lead in the city’s water, must step in to find solutions.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan is scrambling to deal with a terrible water crisis created by his administration in the city of Flint, which is poor and has a black majority. The damage to the nearly bankrupt city and its nearly 100,000 residents by lead-tainted water caused by corrosion in the pipes has yet to be totaled, but there is no doubt that the state has a moral obligation to provide clean water immediately for the citizens and to devise a long-term solution, no matter how costly.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Broken Covenant With Patients
abstract: Prestigious medical research institutions have routinely flouted the law on reporting the results of drug trials, putting patients at risk.
lead_paragraph: As a cancer patient whose life has been miraculously extended by a clinical trial, I was shocked by Charles Piller’s Dec. 13 essay “Law Ignored, Patients at Risk” in STAT News on lapses in reporting the results of such trials. My first response was to ask: Is he a reputable journalist? Is the online venue in which the article appears legit? When the answer to each of these questions came back a resounding yes, I began worrying that cancer doctors and patients have been imperiled by irresponsible researchers.

headline: To Save Its Salmon, California Calls In the Fish Matchmaker
keywords: ['Salmon', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Breeding of Animals']
abstract: At a hatchery on the Klamath River, biologists are using genetic techniques to reduce inbreeding, though some argue natural methods are more effective.
lead_paragraph: HORNBROOK, Calif. — On a frigid morning in a small metal-sided building, a team of specialists prepared to orchestrate an elaborate breeding routine. The work would be wet and messy, so they wore waders. Their tools included egg trays and a rubber mallet, which they used to brain a fertile female coho salmon, now hanging dead on a hook.

headline: To Catch a Scammer in Madrid
abstract: Desperate attempts to track down an Internet swindler in person.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, while house-sitting outside Rome, I was supposed to be working on a school paper. Instead I spent a lot of time surfing the Internet. One day I found an eBay auction for the kind of semiprofessional camera I coveted. The starting-bid amount was one-fifth the retail price. A few days later, just shortly before the end of the auction, no one had placed a bid. It was my first auction, and my heart started pounding as I prepared to bid my savings on this camera. I typed in the amount, took a deep breath, hit ‘‘bid now’’ and closed my eyes. When I opened them again, nothing had happened.

headline: Trunk Show: A Vuitton Retrospective, From Keepall to D.J. Box
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Luggage and Packing', 'Art', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The Louis Vuitton exhibition “Volez, Voguez, Voyagez” in Paris is a trip through time — and design.
lead_paragraph: Today, Louis Vuitton is a luxury fashion label, a status symbol that usually hangs from a shoulder or elegantly dangles from a wrist by way of a leather logoed handbag. But rewind to 1835, and the name belonged to a man who left his home at the age of 14 and began walking 280 miles from eastern France to Paris. Upon arriving two years later, he worked as a box maker and packer before starting his own company in 1854, designing ergonomic trunks — or “specialty packing for fashion” as it was advertised — for the wandering elite.

headline: Prithvi Raj Singh Oberoi Knows a Bit About Luxury Travel
abstract: The head of Oberoi Hotels talks about his company’s past and future.
lead_paragraph: There are not a lot of Indian hotel chains with international recognition, but Oberoi Hotels and Resorts in New Delhi is an exception. The family-run company has 30 properties, mostly within the country but also in locations like Bali, Mauritius and Dubai. It also operates two small cruise ships on the Nile River in Egypt.

headline: Making Art on the Open Seas
abstract: While traveling the world by container ship, an artist captures an increasingly globalized world through his sketches and photography.
lead_paragraph: Ninety percent of the world’s goods travel by sea. The efficient movement of all our stuff from the vague there to the present here is made possible by container ship. The San Francisco-based artist Martin Machado has an unusual firsthand perspective on this tool of globalization: He spends several months of the year working on container ships, on routes that have taken him through the Suez Canal and to ports in cities as far-flung as Honolulu; New York; Dubai; Karachi, Pakistan; Shanghai; and Singapore.

headline: Why Cartels Are Killing Mexico’s Mayors
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drug Cartels', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Mayors', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Politics and Government', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: Forget drugs. Forget El Chapo. A new generation of gangsters is trying to take over local governments themselves.
lead_paragraph: Mexico City — ON the morning of Jan. 2, a team of hired killers set off for the home of 33-year-old Gisela Mota, who only hours before had been sworn in as the first female mayor of Temixco, a sleepy spa town an hour from Mexico City. Ms. Mota was still in her pajamas as the men approached her parents’ breezeblock house. She was in the bedroom, but most of her family was in the front room, cooing over a newborn baby. As the family prepared a milk bottle, the assassins smashed the door open. Amid the commotion, Ms. Mota came out of her bedroom and said firmly, “I am Gisela.” In front of her terrified family, the men beat Ms. Mota and shot her several times, killing her.

keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Hutu Tribe', 'International Relations', 'Tutsi Tribe']
abstract: The charge adds a brutal new twist to a nine-month crisis that has put the poor, tiny nation onto the agenda of the United Nations Security Council and the African Union.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Burundi’s security forces are engaging in gang rape during a crackdown on political opponents that has included a sharp rise in torture, killings and disappearances in the past month, the top United Nations human rights official said on Friday, sounding an alarm over the increasingly ethnic character of the violence.

headline: Daily Report: Why Intel’s Earnings Shouldn’t Be Ignored
abstract: Why the financial reports of Intel, one of the largest suppliers of chips to PCs, still matters to the broader technology industry.
lead_paragraph: The personal computer era is over, but what Intel — one of the largest suppliers of chips to PCs — reports still matters.

headline: Deleting User Accounts on a Mac
abstract: If you have an administrator account, you can delete accounts but archive their contents in case a user returns, or you can delete accounts and all their data.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I delete a user on a shared Mac that is on OS X El Capitan, and what would happen to all the photos, documents and other files in that person’s account?

headline: Jeb Bush Team Stresses to Donors That Substance, Over Style, Matters
abstract: Aides to former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida told campaign donors after the latest debate that their candidate more than held his own with the other Republicans onstage who were called “great performers.”
lead_paragraph: In a private conference call with donors immediately after Thursday night’s Republican debate, Jeb Bush’s team seemed to tacitly acknowledge one of Mr. Bush’s biggest challenges — projecting confidence and strength in the sound-bite culture of televised debates.

headline: Anger and Scrutiny Grow Over Poisoned Water in Michigan City
abstract: The state’s investigation into lead contamination of Flint’s drinking water follows the governor’s request that President Obama declare the problem a federal emergency.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Michigan’s attorney general opened an investigation Friday into lead contamination in Flint’s drinking water, and the governor asked President Obama to declare a disaster as National Guard troops fanned out across this anxious city to help distribute bottled water, water filters and testing kits.

headline: Macedonian Prime Minister Steps Down, but Tensions Over Vote Linger
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Elections']
abstract: Nikola Gruevski submitted his resignation, clearing the way for elections within 100 days, but the opposition said that was not enough time to organize a fair vote.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski of Macedonia submitted his resignation to Parliament on Friday, clearing the way for elections as the country tries to recover from a wiretapping scandal that paralyzed the Balkan nation.

headline: How the Bernanke Fed Decided to Pump Billions Into the Economy
abstract: Transcripts from Federal Reserve meetings in 2010 show, in real time, how the central bank under chairman Ben S. Bernanke came to the conclusion that the economy was in greater peril than it had initially seemed.
lead_paragraph: Transcripts from Federal Reserve meetings in 2010 show, in real time, how the central bank under chairman Ben S. Bernanke came to the conclusion that the economy was in greater peril than it had initially seemed.

headline: Retail Sales Were Lackluster in December, Signaling Fragile Economy
abstract: The Commerce Department said sales fell 0.1 percent in December, raising concerns about the economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: Gas is cheap, and while the stock markets are wavering, the job market is strong. Rising wages are putting more money in people’s pockets.

headline: Can Germany Be Honest About Its Refugee Problems?
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: It’s not enough to be welcoming. The country must grapple with the challenges of integrating a million immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Hamburg — FOR all its horror, what happened on New Year’s Eve in Cologne and other German cities might help the Germans solve a longstanding problem. The issue is not the one-million-plus refugees who have come to us in the first place. It is how to deal with problems that immigrants might be, are or will be causing.

headline: Audra McDonald to Make West End Debut
abstract: Audra McDonald is to make her West End debut this summer as Billie Holiday in “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill,” the play for which she won her sixth Tony, in 2014.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Frances Morris, the top curator of international art at Tate Modern, has been named as the museum’s next director, Tate officials said Friday.

abstract: T.J. Dillashaw and Dominick Cruz, who like so many M.M.A. stars got their start in amateur wrestling, will fight for Dillashaw’s bantamweight title on Sunday in Boston.
lead_paragraph: The much-anticipated Ultimate Fighting Championship main event on Sunday in Boston features T. J. Dillashaw, the bantamweight champion, against a former champion and No. 1 contender, Dominick Cruz. As in any mixed martial arts bout, the modes of combat will be varied: There will be punching, kicking, elbowing, grappling and submission holds.

headline: 1941: Britain Placates Brazil
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain relents on an arms shipment to Brazil in 1941.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian program of national defense is reported here to be more responsible for a recent wave of anti-British feeling here than any convictions the government may have about the European war. The British threat to the defense program which led to the trouble has since been significantly removed.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Walmart to Close 269 Stores as Retailers Struggle
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Company Reports', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: The giant retailer said about 16,000 employees would be affected by the move.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, whose supercenters once transformed the way Americans shop, announced on Friday that it would close a record number of stores in the United States and overseas, as it fights to hold its ground in a retail landscape under siege by the behemoth Amazon.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: GHETTOSIDE: A True Story of Murder in America, by Jill Leovy. (Spiegel & Grau, $16.) As a reporter for The Los Angeles Times, Leovy witnessed firsthand the impact of America’s staggering murder rates. Focusing here on one Los Angeles case, she delves into the “plague of black homicides,” including the fraught relationship between the police and civilians and the justice system’s failure to protect black citizens. (African-American men account for nearly 40 percent of the country’s murder victims.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MY NAME IS LUCY BARTON, by Elizabeth Strout. (Random House, $26.) A writer and her estranged mother attempt to reconnect during a brief visit in a Pulitzer Prize winner’s exquisite novel of careful words and vibrating silences.

headline: The Facts of Refugee Life in Fiction
abstract: Novels of recent years have brought the issue of refugees to wider attention.
lead_paragraph: This week, we review several books about global migration and fractured borders, including Ben Rawlence’s “City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World’s Largest Refugee Camp.” Rawlence’s book is nonfiction, but acclaimed and popular novels of recent years have brought the issue of refugees to wider attention by placing sympathetic fictional characters in situations much (sometimes very much) like real life.

abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

abstract: Our selection of weekly web gems includes squirrel mayhem and a wrap-up of Powerball madness.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: New Yorkers Quickly Unite Against Cruz After ‘New York Values’ Comment
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio spoke out on Friday to criticize Senator Ted Cruz’s swipe at Donald Trump and, by extension, New York, at the presidential debate on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers may be proud, ornery individuals, quick to voice their differences loudly and unabashedly.

headline: They Have Not Yet Begun To Fight
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Why I’m not yet resigned to a Trump vs. Cruz race.
lead_paragraph: In last night’s Republican debate we finally got the Donald Trump vs. Ted Cruz clash everyone has been pining for — not on policy, of course, but on the crucial questions of Cruz’s Canuckishness and Trump’s “New York values.” Cruz came prepared on both exchanges, and like others I would say that he won the night, though he did disappear for longish stretches later on and took some strafing fire from Marco Rubio (very) late in the evening. But then I also agree with the observers who think Trump fundamentally had a good night as well: The Donald has learned a lot about debating since this show started, and even when placed on the defensive he was effective and disciplined — responding to Cruz on the Canadian issue with more puckishness than bluster and then pivoting smoothly to 9/11 on the “New York values” issue. And then there was this moment, when a question about Nikki Haley’s post-SOTU critique of the party’s “angriest voices” allowed Trump to deliver — pretty calmly and evenly — what was probably the line of the night, if not of his campaign: “She did say there was anger. I’m very angry because our country is being run horribly and I will gladly accept the mantle of anger.”

headline: ‘City of Thorns,’ by Ben Rawlence
abstract: An intimate look inside the world’s largest refugee settlement, on the Kenya-Somalia border.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Ben Rawlence, then a researcher for Human Rights Watch, visited the refugee camp of Dadaab on the eastern Kenyan border, home to 300,000 people, many of whom had fled the chronic civil war in Somalia. The next year, he returned for what would be the first of seven long visits to follow the lives of nine of its inhabitants and to watch the camp grow until it became the largest refugee settlement in the world, more town than camp, with its own hospitals, cinemas and soccer teams, occupying an area the size of New Orleans. It would be good to be able to say that his story is encouraging or uplifting; but Rawlence’s “City of Thorns” is a deeply disturbing and depressing portrait of the violence, destitution, fear, sense of hopelessness and neglect in which a large number of the world’s estimated 60 million forcibly displaced people now live.

headline: Shabab Say They Overran African Union Base in Somalia, Killing Dozens
abstract: But a Kenyan military spokesman said that the attack had targeted a Somali military camp, next to the African Union base, and that most of the dead were Somalis.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Shabab militant group said on Friday that it had overrun an African Union base in a village in southern Somalia and killed dozens of peacekeepers.

headline: George Miller on ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’ and Furiosa Tattoos
abstract: The director also explains why Charlize Theron’s character had to be a woman.
lead_paragraph: One of the surprise hits in the awards race has been “Mad Max: Fury Road,” which landed 10 Oscar nominations on Thursday, including best picture and best director. The film’s momentum was one of the many unexpected turns of this season: A sequel to a sequel to a sequel, “Fury Road” seemed too much a genre flick, and for a good while, Oscar watchers didn’t consider it a contender. (Shows how much we know.)

headline: Recipes for a Long Weekend
abstract: How to use sourdough starter, plus a recipe for the best lasagna you’ll ever eat.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: New Orleans Puts Poor on ‘Waiting List’ for Lawyers, Suit Alleges
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: A lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union accuses the public defender’s office of leaving defendants in jail with no one to challenge or negotiate their cases.
lead_paragraph: The cash-starved public defender’s office in Baton Rouge faces “chronic underfunding,” a federal lawsuit contends, a situation that has led to poor people arrested in connection with crimes being placed on a “waiting list,” leaving them in jail without access to lawyers.

headline: The Greatest Hoax in Sports Reporting History (The Times Fell for It, Too)
abstract: In the 1941 season at Plainfield Teachers College, every play — like every score and every player — was a fake.
lead_paragraph: Before reviewing one of the greatest hoaxes in sports history, let’s first meet the perpetrators: Morris Newburger, Lew Krupnick and Bink Dannenbaum.

headline: Potatoes and Pregnancy
abstract: A new study suggests that the more potatoes in a woman’s typical diet, the more likely she is to develop gestational diabetes, a serious complication of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that the more potatoes in a woman’s typical diet, the more likely she is to develop gestational diabetes, a serious complication of pregnancy.

headline: Goodbye, Golf Clubs. Hello, Hiking Boots and Kayak.
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'Adventure Travel', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Elderly', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Camps and Camping']
abstract: Many retirees enjoy the physical outdoor challenges of hiking, mountain climbing and bicycling and do it on the cheap.
lead_paragraph: THEY call him “Elusive,” at least on the hiking trails. And that’s pretty much where Dave Roberts spends his time these days, crisscrossing the country by foot, by bike, even by kayak.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Alan Dean Foster’s movie novelization, new at No. 1, is the first “Force Awakens” tie-in to hit the adult hardcover list.
lead_paragraph: The List Awakens: Alan Dean Foster’s movie novelization “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” goes right to the top in its first week on the hardcover fiction list. This isn’t the only best seller to spring from Disney’s reboot — an illustrated junior novelization has spent three weeks on the middle-grade hardcover list, where it’s currently No. 2, and other titles have landed on the kids’ series list and the miscellaneous list — but it is the first “Force Awakens” tie-in to hit adult hardcover. So what, besides Chewbacca’s drunken sex scene, makes this an adult book? (I’m only kidding about Chewie — sorry! — but readers curious about the mating habits of wookies can turn to The Guardian, where an Edinburgh zookeeper reports that “I would assume they would do it pretty much the same way we do it.” If you’re like me, this will have you humming Cole Porter for days.) In fact, Foster’s novelization does contain some scenes of graphic violence missing from the movie, but the most adult thing about it may be the florid vocabulary. Here’s how it describes the villain Kylo Ren, for instance: “saturnine of aspect, lithe of build, tortured of mien and troubled of eye.” Keep the children away.

headline: Many in Jakarta Seem to Shrug Off Terrorist Attack
abstract: Many in the Indonesian capital expressed astonishment that the assailants had killed only two people, and praised the police for quickly neutralizing the attackers.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — If the militants who attacked the center of this city with explosives and guns on Thursday hoped to inspire fear and attract followers, they seem to have failed. Instead, life in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, returned to normal on Friday, with traffic jams, long lines for public transportation and hasty breakfasts at streetside food stalls.

headline: ‘Passenger,’ by Alexandra Bracken
abstract: The heroes of the first book of Bracken’s new series come from families that can leap through time and space.
lead_paragraph: In present-day New York City, a focused young woman prepares for a recital on the violin, the instrument for which she has sacrificed both her social life and a sense of closeness to her peripatetic mother. She feels the pressure of making good on her training, along with confusion about her best path to the future she desires. While not every teenager is a violin prodigy, Etta’s situation shares common themes with the lives of many driven young people, and right from the opening moments of “Passenger” there is much to like about her. When Etta’s elderly teacher, the most supportive figure in her life, becomes suddenly discouraging on the night of the recital, and Etta overhears an argument between her teacher and her mother as she is about to go onstage, the dramatic tension is ratcheted up, promising an engaging narrative about ambition and family. But this is an adventure story, the first in a new series from Alexandra Bracken, the author of the Darkest Minds books, and Bracken is only just getting started.

headline: ‘Paper Wishes,’ by Lois Sepahban
abstract: A middle-grade novel recounts a Japanese-American family’s life in a World War II detention camp.
lead_paragraph: The psychic pain from the forced removal and detention of American citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during World War II is still felt profoundly today. Case in point: a nationwide protest last April that blocked a scheduled auction of artifacts made in United States detention centers, led by descendants of the internees, who could not tolerate the idea that remnants of this dark chapter of their families’ history were up for sale to the highest bidder.

headline: What Are New York Values?
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas described Donald J. Trump as having “New York values” in the Republican debate on Thursday. What does that mean exactly?
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas described Donald J. Trump as having “New York values” in the Republican debate on Thursday. What does that mean exactly?

headline: Taller Condos on the Upper East Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Condominiums', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: After clustering around 57th Street for the last few years, super-tall condominiums are turning up in other neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: After clustering around 57th Street for the last several years, super-tall condominiums, which are coveted by buyers for their views and scorned by some others for their bulk, are turning up in other neighborhoods.

headline: Junk Bonds Go Sour, but the Question Is How Sour
abstract: Strategists say investors may be focusing too much on the role energy has played in recent declines, even as they underestimate other risks.
lead_paragraph: The tide has definitely turned against investors in high-yield debt, better known as junk bonds.

headline: ‘Strictly No Elephants,’ ‘Big Friends’ and More
abstract: Four picture books about making pals, solving disagreements and being O.K. with others’ quirks (and your own).
lead_paragraph: What are friends for? Children answer this question in a variety of telling ways, whether by opting for the safety of a playmate who might as well be a twin or the adventure of reaching out to a polar opposite or by steering some in-between course. Four new picture books offer different views of the risks and rewards for the very young of stepping outside the primal comfort zone of home and family.

headline: ‘Conquerors: How Portugal Forged the First Global Empire,’ by Roger Crowley
abstract: An account of 16th-century Portugal’s brutal grip on the East.
lead_paragraph: Afonso de Albuquerque died 500 years ago, after spending a dozen years terrorizing coastal cities from Yemen to Malaysia. He enriched thousands of men and killed tens of thousands more. Despite never commanding more than a few dozen ships, he built one of the first modern intercontinental empires. And this was just the beginning: The next step, he said, was to sail up the Red Sea, destroy Mecca, Medina and the Prophet Muhammad’s body and liberate the Holy Land. Perhaps, he mused, he could destroy Islam altogether.

headline: ‘Blood and Earth,’ by Kevin Bales
abstract: A look at unfree labor and its link to environmental damage.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Bales argues in “Blood and Earth” that ending “modern slavery” could make a big difference in the ­planet’s health. “If slavery were a country,” he ­asserts, “it would have the third-largest CO2 emissions on the planet.”

headline: ‘Midnight in Broad Daylight,’ by Pamela Rotner Sakamoto
abstract: A Japanese-American family is separated by war and migration.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Rotner Sakamoto’s engrossing book opens simultaneously in Los Angeles and Hiroshima on Dec. 7, 1941. In Los Angeles, a 21-year-old Japanese-­American gardener named Harry Fukuhara is mowing a lawn when his white employer steps out of her house and tells him, “Harry, Japan has attacked Pearl Harbor.” In Hiroshima, a 17-year-old high school student named Katsutoshi is about to board a train for a track meet when he hears a garbled shout behind him. During his race, Katsutoshi keeps turning over in his mind what he thought he heard. Had someone really shouted “our victorious assault on Hawaii”?

headline: ‘The Illegal,’ by Lawrence Hill
abstract: A marathoner enters a wealthy country illegally in Hill’s novel.
lead_paragraph: How do we stop them? How do we stop the dispossessed, the poor, the hungry, the terrified, from breaching our borders and overwhelming us with their need? How do we deal with those who have already managed to sneak in? And how do we distinguish between the truly desperate and the truly evil who hide (so we suspect) among them?

headline: ‘Your Heart Is a Muscle the Size of a Fist,’ by Sunil Yapa
abstract: Fiction inspired by the 1999 World Trade Organization protests.
lead_paragraph: With the dwindling of the anti-­globalization movement over the past decade, the 1999 World Trade Organization protests in Seattle can now look like easily mocked millennial optimism: turtles, teamsters, Wiccans, the “Free Mumia” crowd and beanie-wearing save-the-­forests types finding common cause with the victims of corporate capital and glowing with the belief in a better world. Although media coverage of what transpired over the protests’ five chaotic days in November focused on police brutality and destruction of property, in its full reality, the “Battle in Seattle” swung from hope-filled carnival to angry riot to a moment of real change — a polyvalent, ambiguous and high-stakes drama. In other words, a novelist’s dream.

headline: ‘The Blue Line,’ by Ingrid Betancourt
abstract: Betancourt’s heroine sees things through others’ eyes.
lead_paragraph: The literary style known as magic realism, incorporating fantastic elements into otherwise realistic fiction, has been deployed with much success by Latin American writers. It is also, lately, a Colombian tourism slogan. Now the Colombian politician Ingrid Betancourt, best known for a memoir describing her six years in the jungle as the hostage of ­anti-government rebels, has added her first novel to the ranks of the genre.

headline: ‘The Love of Strangers,’ by Nile Green
abstract: A story of Iranians who studied in England in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: Great was the weight placed on young shoulders in the spring of 1815 when a small group of students left their home city of Tabriz in northwest Iran and set out for “Inglistan,” the land of the English. Led by the charismatic and doggedly determined Mirza Salih, they were taliban in the truest sense of the word — seekers of knowledge. Their desire for ulum-i-­jadid, or new sciences, had become a matter of national security. Wars with Russia had battered the domain of the crown prince, Abbas Mirza, for more than a century, and he was eager to protect it from further destruction. When the young men were sent to the West, their instructions were clear, if daunting: They were to learn all they could in order to drag their country into an industrialized, czar-beating era.

headline: ‘The Kindness of Enemies,’ by Leila Aboulela
abstract: A novel pairs a Muslim’s arrest in present-day Scotland with a captivity narrative set in the Caucasian War.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps we only imagine that questions of allegiance, of belonging, are more urgent now than they ever were. The “war on terror” asks for a pledge of loyalty: Whose side are you on? The question seems straightforward, but as Leila Aboulela’s new novel reminds us, to ask where we come from, to choose where we belong, is not a simple matter at all.

headline: ‘The Invitation-Only Zone,’ by Robert S. Boynton
abstract: North Korea’s mysterious abduction program targeted Japanese citizens.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old Japanese schoolgirl ­walking home from badminton practice mysteriously disappears. So does a young couple strolling on a beach. A mother and her 19-year-old daughter also vanish on the way back from their routine grocery shopping trip. They are among at least 17 Japanese who were abducted by North Korea in the years between 1977 and 1983.

headline: Republicans Intensify Attacks After a Pitched Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s rivalry with Ted Cruz, with voting in Iowa only about two weeks away, has turned into a personal spat over each other’s values and constitutional eligibility to be president.
lead_paragraph: The battle for the Republican nomination appeared more splintered than ever between two halves of a bitterly divided party as several candidates scrambled on Friday to consolidate the support of more moderate conservatives a day after a raucous debate.

headline: The Smartest Comments of the Republican Debate: Readers Weigh In
abstract: Readers gave shoutouts to Donald Trump, Ben Carson, Chris Christie and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, we asked you who made the most intelligent comment during the Republican debate. In response, readers gave shoutouts to Donald Trump, Ben Carson, Chris Christie and Bernie Sanders. Below, some of the most popular choices for the smartest comment of the evening:

headline: You Asked, Hillary Clinton Answered
abstract: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

headline: Thoughts on a Poland in Flux: Readers Speak Out
abstract: More than 1,000 people shared their thoughts about the country’s direction under its new right-wing government. Here is a selection.
lead_paragraph: There is intense debate in Poland about the direction the country is taking under its new right-wing government, a debate that has spilled over into the European Union and that has raised questions about the direction of democracy in Eastern and Central Europe more than a quarter-century after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

headline: Sean Penn Says His El Chapo Article ‘Has Failed’
abstract: In an interview with CBS to be broadcast on Sunday, Mr. Penn said he had hoped that his interview with the fugitive would lead to a debate about the drug war.
lead_paragraph: The actor Sean Penn said he has “a terrible regret” that the capture of the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo has distracted from his article in Rolling Stone, which he had hoped would start a national conversation about the war on drugs.

headline: Short Stories
abstract: New books by Stuart Evers, Diane Williams, Amber Sparks and Valerie Trueblood.
lead_paragraph: YOUR FATHER SENDS HIS LOVEStoriesBy Stuart Evers312 pp. Norton, $24.95.

headline: The Fashion News to Know This Week
abstract: Bowie’s legacy, a study in Birkin bags and London Fashion Weekend.
lead_paragraph: And the stars look very different today

headline: Iowa’s Heartland Beyond the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: With the caucuses weeks away, a road trip reaffirms that our nation, beginning with Iowa, is full of unsung surprises.
lead_paragraph: On a Monday morning in early December I drove a rental car out of Des Moines and eventually made my way down a slender country road that cut a forthright path through cattle pastures and cornfields not yet glazed by snow. My destination was Winterset, the county seat of Madison County, whose covered bridges Robert James Waller immortalized more than 20 years ago in his best seller, “The Bridges of Madison County.” Mr. Waller’s treacly love fable is not my personal favorite, but I confess to detouring at the sign for Hogback Bridge and being stirred by the lonely spectacle of that wooden sentry crouched over the North River in an unprepossessing crease of Middle America.

headline: Oh, the Places We Tell You to Go: Inside the Travel Section’s Special Issue
abstract: Travel editors Monica Drake and Dan Saltzstein explain how they put together this year’s special issue, “52 Places To Go in 2016.”
lead_paragraph: Temples of Malta. Pine forests in Dalat, Vietnam. How about a speck of volcanic rock in the South Atlantic? Itching to get out of town? Every January, The Times Travel section publishes a “Places to Go” Issue.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘City of Thorns’
abstract: This week, Ben Rawlence discusses “City of Thorns”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Janice Y. K. Lee talks about “The Expatriates”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ben Rawlence discusses “City of Thorns”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Janice Y. K. Lee talks about “The Expatriates”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Ian Rankin’s ‘Even Dogs in the Wild,’ and More
abstract: Rankin’s latest novel illustrates the tensions between Scotland’s two major cities.
lead_paragraph: Retirement isn’t for everyone, least of all John Rebus, the hero of Ian Rankin’s mordant police procedurals set in the shadowy underworld of Edinburgh. In EVEN DOGS IN THE WILD (Little, Brown, $26), Rebus’s unorthodox friendship with the aging crime boss “Big Ger” Cafferty allows this retired detective to attach himself to a police investigation into the murder of a former lord advocate and death threats against other high-profile citizens, including Cafferty.

headline: Choreographer Revisits Epic Sanskrit Poem
abstract: In “Until the Lions,” Akram Khan offers up Karthika Naïr’s story from the “Mahabharata” from the female perspective.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — From the age of 13 to 15, Akram Khan traveled the world as a performer in the director Peter Brook’s nine-hour theatrical version of the “Mahabharata.” It’s not much of a surprise then, that Mr. Khan, now 41, and well-known in his native Britain, has returned to the epic Sanskrit poem — it contains more than 90,000 couplets and hundreds of stories and myths — for a second time in his choreographic career.

headline: Big Ticket | 146 Waverly Place
abstract: A five-story Greek Revival townhouse in Greenwich Village sold for $23.28 million.
lead_paragraph: A five-story Greek Revival townhouse in Greenwich Village sold for $23.28 million.

headline: Greenwich Village Townhouse Flipped for $23.3 Million
abstract: A fully renovated 1905 townhouse on a prime, tree-lined street in Greenwich Village was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: An investment partnership sold a gut-renovated early-20th-century townhouse on a prime, tree-lined street in Greenwich Village for $23,282,932.60, more than twice what it had paid for the property just over two years ago — a transaction that was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: You Asked, Hillary Clinton Answered
abstract: Mrs. Clinton took a reader’s question during her visit to the editorial board on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, we asked you to submit questions for Hillary Clinton. During her visit to the editorial board, she picked one of your questions from a hat to answer on camera. Watch her response below:

headline: F.T.C.’s Lumosity Penalty Doesn’t End Brain Training Debate
abstract: The federal agency said the company couldn’t back up its claims of helping with cognitive impairment, but experts on both sides weighed in.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Jennifer Perrine saw a television ad for Lumosity, an online brain training program, and decided she’d give it a try.

headline: In Online Dating, ‘Sextortion’ and Scams
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Online romance scams bilk people out of more than $200 million a year, but humans’ hard-wiring makes the frauds hard to stop.
lead_paragraph: DATING websites and apps typically see a surge in activity this time of year as people who felt lonely over the holidays try to follow through on New Year’s resolutions to find someone special with whom to share their life, or maybe just someone agreeable to share their bed on a cold winter’s night.

headline: Medical Aid Sent to Starving Syrian Town of Madaya
abstract: Aid workers witnessed the death of a 16-year-old boy in the besieged town, and they fear for the state of hundreds of thousands of people trapped in other areas.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Alarmed by starvation in the besieged Syrian town of Madaya, aid agencies sent a mobile medical clinic there on Friday and planned to increase medical support.

headline: Rams’ Move Raises Questions About Raiders and Chargers
abstract: The Chargers can join the Rams in Los Angeles or negotiate for a new stadium in San Diego. The Raiders can join the Rams if the Chargers decline, stay in Oakland or choose to move somewhere else.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, N.F.L. owners voted to allow the St. Louis Rams to return to Southern California and build a domed stadium in an entertainment district in Inglewood, a few miles from downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Review: ‘Billions’ Delivers a Dose of Charisma to Hedge Fund Titans
abstract: If anyone can save these billionaires from the cultural penalty box, it just might be Showtime and its new show starring Damian Lewis and Paul Giamatti.
lead_paragraph: Men who make lots of money and growl at one another about profits and margins and winning and losing. Remember them?

headline: Take Comfort in One-Hour Winter Vegetable Soup
abstract: Using a food mill instead of a blender results in a flavorful, colorful mixture you can almost chew on.
lead_paragraph: I still have the cheap food mill I bought from a vendor at a market on the Boulevard Raspail when I lived in Paris decades ago. The knob has come loose from the handle, but it still does the job. I pull it out every time I make this soup.

headline: What I Love | Andrew Livingston

abstract: Andrew Livingston, the majority owner of Knickerbocker Mfg. Co., a clothing company, lives in Williamsburg in a converted church.
lead_paragraph: The first thing Andrew Livingston did when he moved into his two-bedroom apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was to furnish the guest room with a good mattress. “I needed it up and running on Day 1,” he said.

headline: Monetary Economics at the GOP Debate
abstract: Cruz’s version of credibility.
lead_paragraph: There wasn’t much economics, or for that matter much connection with reality. But Ted Cruz delivered:

headline: Supernova Has Energy of Hundreds of Billions of Suns
abstract: Scientist may have found the most powerful supernova ever seen.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers have discovered a giant ball of hot gas, billions of light years away, that is radiating the energy of hundreds of billions of suns. The ball may be the most powerful supernova ever seen, a study in the journal Science reports. At the center is an object about 10 miles in diameter that scientists think might be a rare type of star called a magnetar. The gas ball, 3.8 billion light years away, was spotted through the All Sky Automated Survey for Supernovae collaboration. The project, led by researchers at Ohio State University, aims to find supernovae using various small telescopes in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.

headline: After Nuclear Test, China Resists Pressure to Curb North Korea
keywords: ['Nuclear Tests', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: President Xi Jinping has not wavered from his view that destabilizing the North would create chaos in the region, scholars and officials said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — North Korea had detonated a nuclear bomb, and the president of China was urging caution. It was the fall of 2013, and the North’s third nuclear test in seven years, carried out several months earlier, had rattled much of the world.

headline: Chipotle Will Close Stores for Food Safety Meetings After Outbreaks
abstract: All Chipotle restaurants will open later than usual on Feb. 8 so employees can discuss safety changes, the chain said.
lead_paragraph: As Chipotle Mexican Grill tries to  recover from a series of contaminations that have caused some customers and investors to flee, it said it would shut all its stores for several hours on Feb. 8 to hold food safety meetings with employees.

headline: His Strength Sapped, Top Marathoner Ryan Hall Decides to Stop
abstract: Hall, 33, whose training methods helped him run a 2:04:58 at Boston in 2011, said the training took a toll on his body: He now has extreme fatigue and chronically low testosterone levels.
lead_paragraph: REDDING, Calif. — Sprinting seven miles down a 9,000-foot mountain and then running back up to do it again may not appeal to even the most self-punishing of athletes, but Ryan Hall believes it is the kind of “experimental workout” that transformed him into the fastest American distance runner in history.

headline: Carly Fiorina Is Not Even Good at Gratuitous Insults
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lacking anything of substance to say, Mrs. Fiorina has resorted to taunts about Hillary Clinton’s marriage.
lead_paragraph: Some political candidates are great at throwing around snappy one-liners. Donald Trump has an incredible facility with sound bites. They rarely have a passing connection to reality, and often don’t even make sense, but they land well with his audiences. He knows he can just yell, “Let’s build a wall!” and his crowds will go crazy.

headline: Louvre to Start Restoring  Another Leonardo Painting
abstract: The Louvre is preparing to start the restoration of Leonardo da Vinci’s “Saint John the Baptist,” a 16th-century work that has darkened over the years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Louvre is preparing to start the restoration of Leonardo da Vinci’s “Saint John the Baptist,” a 16th-century work that has darkened over the years.

headline: Stock Market Ends Sharply Lower as Worries About Economy Surface
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The benchmark Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has slipped 8 percent this year, as concerns grow that the United States economy may be on the verge of a slowdown.
lead_paragraph: It may be time for everyone to take the markets seriously again.

headline: When Prisoners Had Ski Jumps
abstract: For about 40 years, inmates could use a run at Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., that would launch them airborne for about 50 feet.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently saw a photograph from the 1970s showing an inmate at the Dannemora state prison using a ski jump inside the prison! Can this be true?

headline: Get the Look: Luke Spiller’s Glam Rock Makeup
abstract: The products and steps required to recreate the Struts frontman’s on-stage beauty look.
lead_paragraph: The products and steps required to recreate the Struts frontman’s on-stage beauty look.

headline: Meet the Glam Rock Frontman Channeling Freddie Mercury
abstract: The Struts’ Luke Spiller wears his influences on his sleeve — and no shortage of eyeliner and women’s clothes.
lead_paragraph: Luke Spiller knows that the Struts are headed for big things. Already, the U.K. rock outfit has played in front of 80,000 people in Paris as the opener for the Rolling Stones. More recently, “Could Have Been Me,” the hard-charging lead single from band’s debut album, “Everybody Wants” (out March 4 via Freesolo/Interscope Records), has racked up more than 7 million plays on Spotify and has become a regular on rock radio. And Spiller, the Struts’ charismatic singer, has garnered comparisons to everyone from Tim Curry to the late Queen frontman Freddie Mercury (to whom he bears an almost eerie resemblance.) But today, he’s worried about just one thing: getting his makeup right. “Does it look all right?” he asks, looking in the mirror.

headline: Lawsuit Questions Ted Cruz’s Eligibility to Be President
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A trial lawyer, who said he plans to support Bernie Sanders’s bid, filed the suit about Ted Cruz’s constitutional eligibility in Federal District Court in Houston, arguing that the definition of a “natural born citizen” has never been sufficiently settled.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump predicted that the lawsuits against Senator Ted Cruz, doubting his constitutional eligibility to be president, would start trickling in as questions continued to percolate about the fact that he was born in Canada. As the Republican candidates gathered to debate in South Carolina on Thursday, one had already been filed.

headline: America’s Public Lands
abstract: A writer from Earthjustice condemns “the Bundys and their ilk” for trying to turn “public places into their own private assets.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Losing the Rams, St. Louis Wins
abstract: Stadium financing has always been a struggle for St. Louis, and the deal the city tried to put together to keep the Rams could have been financially ruinous.
lead_paragraph: Don’t cry for St. Louis, sports fans.

headline: Iowa on a Plate
abstract: The dining landscape in the state that begins the presidential nomination process.
lead_paragraph: The dining landscape in the state that begins the presidential nomination process.

headline: ​Another Reason to Caucus in Iowa: The Restaurants
abstract: The dining landscape in the state has far more to offer than local chains and dishes worthy of state fairs.
lead_paragraph: LE MARS, Iowa — To get to Archie’s Waeside, the James Beard Award-winning steakhouse here that has been run by the same family for three generations, you drive past a branch of the ubiquitous Pizza Ranch chain, cross over a set of railroad tracks and inch down an unlit road toward a low-slung and scantly marked building hard by an R.V. dump.

headline: How the Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr. Spends His Sundays
abstract: The senior pastor at First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem often talks about the teachings of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. — and encourages his congregants to participate with their phones.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr., 44, the senior pastor at First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem, wears jeans in the pulpit, rides a motorcycle and encourages posting on Twitter during his sermons. So far it has worked. Since he arrived in 2004, First Corinthian says, church membership has grown to 9,000 from 300. In 2014, he ran (unsuccessfully) for the congressional seat long held by Representative Charles B. Rangel. Known to congregants as Pastor Mike, Mr. Walrond lives in Harlem with his wife, the Rev. LaKeesha Walrond, 44, the church’s executive pastor.

headline: Annie Leibovitz’s “Women” Opens in London
abstract: The photographer kicks off a 10-city world tour with an installation at the Wapping Hydraulic Power Station.
lead_paragraph: The photographer kicks off a 10-city world tour with an installation at the Wapping Hydraulic Power Station.

headline: Annie Leibovitz’s Classic Portraits of Women, Now in Expanded Form
abstract: This week, the photographer relaunches her 1999 project at the Wapping Hydraulic Power Station in London.
lead_paragraph: Down rickety stairs in an old red-brick power plant in the East End of London, images from Annie Leibovitz’s 1999 “Women” project pulse on two giant screens. They alternate with more recent portraits: an image of the late L’Wren Scott lying across a chair, a tableau of New York’s female gallerists — even the Kardashian-Wests mid-selfie. From a third screen glows the Queen in formal pomp.

headline: New Donald Trump Ad Features Less Anger, Bold Goals and No Specifics
abstract: A conventional ad has emerged from Mr. Trump’s unconventional campaign, but its upbeat message may help with evangelical voters uneasy with his combative style.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign on Friday released its second advertisement, a conventional 30-second clip of Mr. Trump’s Jan. 4 stump speech in Lowell, Mass.

headline: Uber Not to Blame for Rise in Manhattan Traffic Congestion, Report Says
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: The report, based on a study conducted after Uber and Mayor Bill de Blasio clashed over his plan to cap the number of for-hire vehicles on New York City’s streets, recommended against such a limit.
lead_paragraph: After an uproar last year between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the ride-hailing app Uber over the company’s growth in New York City, the two sides reached something of a truce on Friday with the release of a very short — and very expensive — traffic report from the city.

headline: How I Got Ejected From a Donald Trump Event
abstract: As Donald J. Trump visited a Pizza Ranch restaurant here on Friday, a New York Times reporter was ejected by Trump staff members and a local police officer.
lead_paragraph: WAUKEE, Iowa – I was late to Donald J. Trump’s unannounced visit to a Pizza Ranch on Friday, his first drop-by of this ubiquitous Iowa chain that is standard stop for candidates, but which Mr. Trump has avoided in favor of boisterous crowds in big halls.

headline: Robust 4th Quarter Couldn’t Redeem Market After an Anxious Year
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Personal Finances', 'Credit and Debt', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: Investors were pummeled by a volatile but flat market in 2015. And with the current headwinds, the short-term economic outlook seems daunting.
lead_paragraph: The stock market withstood fierce punishment last year and had almost nothing to show for it. A strong fourth quarter healed some of the damage but as the year closed and 2016 began, the battering in the market began yet again.

headline: Dining in Thunder Bay, Where Sustainable Meets Delectable
abstract: Uptown Cut has a modern sensibility yet takes pride in the beef of Ontario.
lead_paragraph: Between the elk, venison and fish harvested by the First Nations and the pork-heavy diet of the French settlers, Canadian cuisine has always been known for its protein. But the Canadian steakhouse got a modern twist in early 2015 with Uptown Cut, a chef-focused spot that brings a tasting-menu approach to a classic concept.

abstract: The artist shares the titles he’d want most on a desert island.

abstract: The avian influenza strain, which attacked a commercial turkey flock, was different from the main strain reported last year.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Agriculture confirmed on Friday that a strain of avian influenza had hit a commercial flock of turkeys in Indiana.

lead_paragraph: Good evening, Madam Commodore. Congratulations, Madam Commodore. What are you drinking, Madam Commodore?

headline: Alphabet Shakes Up Its Robotics Division
abstract: The holding company that owns Google is moving the unit from a stand-alone division to a piece of X research and putting a new focus on robots.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s robotics division has been plagued by low morale and a lack of leadership since the unit’s founder left abruptly in 2014. Now Alphabet is cleaning it up.

headline: French Movie About Jihadis Won’t Be Released in Theaters
abstract: “Made in France,” a movie about a terrorist plot in Paris, was twice delayed after actual attacks and will now go straight to video on demand.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — From the start, the subject hit too close to home. Out of security concerns in a country still in shock after the November terrorist attacks, “Made in France,” a French film about homegrown jihadists plotting strikes on downtown Paris, will head straight to video-on-demand this month and forgo release in cinemas.

headline: Pizza, Made With a Light Hand, California Style
abstract: A seasoned pepper mixture is strewn over stretched dough, along with fresh mozzarella, before the pie slides into a hot oven.
lead_paragraph: By mid-January, I often long for something brighter than the decidedly wintry vegetable offerings at the farmers’ market. I need a reminder of summer’s sweetness. And sometimes I give in to that longing. Does that mean I’m not a seasonal cook? Or is this simply a lapsed locavore’s quandary?

abstract: Choosing which school to attend is one of the biggest financial decisions that many people will ever make. Why are some schools making it harder to compare the potential costs?
lead_paragraph: An undergraduate degree from a flagship state university often comes with a six-figure sticker price for on-campus residents. A private college could cost a quarter of a million dollars nowadays.

headline: Gains Against ISIS Bring More Deaths Elsewhere in Iraq
abstract: Following the liberation of Ramadi, Baghdad has experienced a return to the days when guerrilla tactics paralyzed the city.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When tens of thousands of civilians escaped an Islamic State onslaught on the Iraqi city of Ramadi last year, Amir Mishaan and his three children, the youngest barely a year old, were among those who settled into makeshift lives here in the capital.

headline: When Emerging Markets Roar, Stand Your Ground
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Interest Rates', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: It’s not the first time emerging-market stock funds have lost ground, so playing this volatile group of stocks for the long term may be worthwhile in the end.
lead_paragraph: While most forms of investing require a leap of faith, betting on emerging-markets stock funds this year — Chinese stocks have already had double-digit declines — may feel like jumping across the Grand Canyon.

headline: ‘Super Pac’ Backing Jeb Bush Looks to Crowdfund an Ad for the Super Bowl
abstract: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, is urging donors to contribute online to run an ad during the Super Bowl, two days before New Hampshire holds its primary on Feb. 9.
lead_paragraph: The mega-donors who helped Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, raise over $100 million aren’t exactly the typical crowdfounding type.

headline: Fund Managers Win With Tech Stalwarts and Burly Brand Names
abstract: Investments in well-known tech giants like Amazon, Microsoft and Google fueled three top-performing funds in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: Bets on the biggest purveyors of technology — companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft — powered three of the top-performing funds of the fourth quarter.

headline: Follow Your Conscience Without Losing Your Shirt
abstract: More investors are committing money to socially responsible funds, and companies are rolling out offerings. But it can be hard to determine what funds will and won’t invest in.
lead_paragraph: Investing can sometimes seem heartless. If whatever makes money is your mantra, you may find that you have put your cash into enterprises with which you fundamentally disagree.

headline: Signs of a Retail Rebound as Consumers Take On More Debt
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Consumer Behavior', 'United States Economy', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: In moderation, consumer debt can help encourage economic activity, but in excess, it can create bubbles that threaten the economy.
lead_paragraph: Consumer debt is rising. How Americans handle that load and how much cash they spend will determine the fortunes of an important stock sector.

headline: For E.T.F. Traders, Lessons From the Panic
keywords: ['Exchange Traded Funds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: Exchange-traded funds suffered huge losses when stocks plummeted in early trading on Aug. 24, revealing hidden dangers in short-term trading of the funds.
lead_paragraph: A selling point of exchange-traded funds over traditional mutual funds is that they can be traded at any time during a market session, but when stocks plunged as soon as trading began on Aug. 24 — that feature of E.T.F.s became a bug.

headline: Small, Private Insurers Face Increasing Scrutiny on Avoided Taxes
keywords: ['Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Insurance', 'Small Business', 'Taxation']
abstract: Both Congress and the I.R.S. have taken steps to prevent affluent business owners from setting up insurance companies as a way to sidestep taxes, not protect against legitimate risks.
lead_paragraph: SHOULD a Phoenix-area jeweler be able to create his own private insurance company to cover his jewelry stores against possible terrorist attacks, specifically those “relating to radioactivity from a ‘dirty’ bomb or from nuclear fuel or nuclear waste”?

headline: Investing Advice That Doubles as a Bookmark
abstract: Helaine Olen and Harold Pollack offer financial planning tips you can fit on an index card, and Jane Bryant Quinn writes about having enough money in retirement.
lead_paragraph: Mastering the basics required to put together a solid financial plan is not too hard. Getting the most out of every investment dollar is.

headline: Brownsville’s Broken Windows
abstract: Although the events that unfolded at the Osborn Playground on Jan. 7 are still unclear, what seems obvious is the inconsistency with which “broken windows” policing is practiced.
lead_paragraph: Between Thanksgiving weekend and the first week in January, when the gang rape of an 18-year-old woman in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn was reported, the neighborhood could too easily have found confirmation that it was a place doomed to lurid violence, if its broader history hadn’t proved the claim.

headline: Review: ‘Angie Tribeca,’ Steve and Nancy Carell’s Modern-Day ‘Police Squad!’
abstract: This pun-filled cop show parody on TBS stars Rashida Jones as Detective Angie Tribeca, a member of the Los Angeles Police Department.
lead_paragraph: TBS is debuting its new comedy “Angie Tribeca” on Sunday, with a 25-hour “Binge-a-Thon,” playing the whole 10-episode season on repeat, without commercials. This is both unnecessary and perfect.

headline: One Syrian’s Journey From Hometown Rebel to ISIS Bomber
abstract: A man who called himself Abu Bilal al-Homsi fought the government during the siege of his city, Homs, and briefed the media on battles. But as hunger set in, he turned to ISIS.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — IN the early years of Syria’s revolt, he filmed protests in the streets of his rebel-held neighborhood, in the historic center of the city of Homs. He chanted for dignity and freedom with a green, white and black banner, the old version of the national flag.

headline: Ronald Perelman Quits Carnegie Hall Board
abstract: His departure came less than a year after Mr. Perelman was tapped to be the chairman of Carnegie’s board, beginning a rocky era of clashes with the hall’s administration.
lead_paragraph: In a quiet coda to a period of sturm und drang at Carnegie Hall, Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire businessman, resigned from its board of trustees earlier this month, representatives of Mr. Perelman and the hall said Friday.

abstract: A glut of crude oil on the markets is pushing the price of oil down to levels not seen since the global financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A glut of crude oil on the markets is pushing the price of oil down to levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

headline: El Chapo’s Affection for Actress Is Met With Mockery Online
abstract: In facetious posts on Twitter and other social media sites, some commenters speculated on the intentions of the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera toward the actress Kate del Castillo.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Affectionate cellphone messages left by the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera for the actress Kate del Castillo have some in Mexico wondering if Mr. Guzmán, the former fugitive known as El Chapo, was interested in more than just a friendly interview with her.

headline: Stock Prices Sink in a Rising Ocean of Oil
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As an oil glut grows despite production cuts, investors worry about a slowdown in the global economy.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The world is awash in crude oil, with enough extra produced last year to fuel all of Britain or Thailand. And the price of oil will not stop falling until the glut shrinks.

headline: A Year Junk Bonds Lived Up to Their Name
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Junk Bonds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Commodities']
abstract: Top high-yield bond funds, a.k.a. junk funds, are down as much as 11 percent since summer of 2014, and market volatility points conservative investors toward safer bets.
lead_paragraph: Investors chasing high yields have been battling high anxiety.

headline: More Programs Set for Rubenstein Atrium
abstract: The space, at Lincoln Center, will roughly double its number of free performances in 2016 in a makeover that includes the introduction of new recurring programs.
lead_paragraph: The David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center will roughly double its number of free performances in 2016 in a makeover that includes the introduction of new recurring programs.

headline: Farmers Markets and Food-Borne Illness
abstract: There are correlations between them. But what does that mean?
lead_paragraph: OVER the last two decades, more and more Americans have begun patronizing their local farmers markets. From 1994 to 2014, the number of farmers markets throughout the country increased almost fivefold. Many consumers frequent these markets because they believe that the foods they purchase there are healthier and safer than the same items sold at supermarkets, posing less risk of food-borne illness.

headline: Justices to Hear Appeal by Bob McDonnell, Ex-Governor of Virginia
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: The case before the Supreme Court will test what kinds of official conduct amount to forbidden corruption.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear an appeal from Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia who was convicted of public corruption and faces two years in prison in a case that offers an important test of what kinds of official conduct amount to forbidden corruption.

headline: Ted Cruz Failed to Report a Second Campaign Loan in 2012
abstract: A loan from Citibank, in addition to one from Goldman Sachs disclosed this week, should have been reported to the Federal Election Commission.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz, already facing scrutiny for not disclosing a Goldman Sachs loan he used for his 2012 Senate campaign, also failed to disclose a second loan, from Citibank, for the same race, according to a letter he sent Thursday to federal election officials.

headline: The Rambunctious Republican Debate
abstract: Readers are largely dismayed by both the tone and content.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
abstract: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Marco Rubio Bought a Gun on Christmas Eve, Campaign Says
