abstract: Marco Rubio bought a gun on Christmas Eve at a Florida store “packed” with customers, some of whom he said were worried that President Obama would further restrict their gun-buying rights
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, NH — How did Senator Marco Rubio spend Christmas Eve?

headline: Jan. 15, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Greece, France, Taiwan and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, France, Taiwan and Spain.

headline: Portugal to Extradite Ex-C.I.A. Agent to Italy in Rendition Case
abstract: Former C.I.A. agent has denied involvement in the kidnapping of a Egyptian cleric in 2003, which took place while she was working undercover as a diplomat in Milan.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A Portuguese court has ruled that a former C.I.A. agent should be handed over to Italy after being found guilty by an Italian court of taking part in the kidnapping of an Egyptian cleric in 2003, one of the renditions ordered by the administration of former President George W. Bush.

headline: Autopsy of Chedrick Chatman
abstract: Newly released documents and videos shed light on the death of Chicago’s Cedrick Chatman, a 17-year-old who was shot and killed by police in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Newly released documents and videos shed light on the death of Chicago’s Cedrick Chatman, a 17-year-old who was shot and killed by police in 2013.

headline: Review: ‘Mercy Street,’ a Civil War Hospital Drama on PBS
abstract: This genteel six-episode melodrama is set in Alexandria, Va., where Union and Confederate, slave and free, uneasily mingle.
lead_paragraph: A stately building owned by a wealthy family whose fortunes are in jeopardy. A principled American beauty who married a European nobleman. Lavish helpings of period dresses, ball gowns and uniforms. “Mercy Street” may be the rare PBS drama that’s set in the United States, but don’t worry: “Downton Abbey” fans will find that it has some comfortingly familiar elements.

headline: Review: Philadelphia Orchestra Plays Music From Vienna
abstract: In a festival that is mostly sticking to the canon, Yannick Nézet-Séguin led his ensemble in a remarkable performance of Beethoven’s Fourth Concerto at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In crucial ways, the charismatic conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, now in his fourth season as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, is excelling in the job. The players seem energized by his leadership. The orchestra sounded terrific on Thursday at Carnegie Hall, in a concert highlighted by an uncommonly sensitive performance of Beethoven’s Fourth Piano Concerto, with the pianist Jan Lisiecki.

headline: At Least 20 Killed in Siege by Militants in Burkina Faso
abstract: Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa claimed responsibility for the attack on a hotel popular with Westerners. An official said 22 people were dead.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunmen from Al Qaeda stormed a luxury hotel frequented by foreigners in Burkina Faso’s capital on Friday night, seizing hostages and killing others while fighting with dozens of security forces who began a counterattack hours later. It was Al Qaeda’s first major attack in this landlocked sub-Saharan country, a former French colony.

headline: Rocky Road Ahead for Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A fourth-quarter fizzle for most large banks is followed by a steep drop in their market value in the first two weeks of the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: America’s too-big-to-fail cabal is nursing $130 billion in damages. That’s the amount of market value lost by the nation’s top six banks in the last two weeks. The shares of all but Wells Fargo now trade below book value, suggesting stockholders are bracing for a year or more of pain. Whether they’re right looks like a tossup.

headline: Giants Kept Ben McAdoo by Keeping Eagles Away
abstract: McAdoo, 38, who said Friday that he would retain Steve Spagnuolo as defensive coordinator, was offered the coaching job at about the same time he appeared to be moving up the Eagles’ wish list.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — By the middle of this week, Ben McAdoo had interviewed for vacant head coaching positions with the Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles. He knew that if either team was serious about hiring him, it would call him back for a second interview.

headline: 18 Carmakers Agree to Share Safety Data
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'North American International Auto Show']
abstract: The pact is part of an effort by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to improve safety practices in the auto industry.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When Mark Rosekind became the nation’s top auto safety regulator in late 2014, the industry was reeling from record recalls prompted by a vehicle defect at General Motors that was later tied to 124 deaths.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Free Spirits
abstract: If there’s a revolution in fashion, it’s about men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: If there’s a revolution in fashion, it’s about men’s wear.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Free Spirits
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Men and Boys', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: If there’s a revolution in fashion, it’s about men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: If there’s a revolution in fashion, it’s about men’s wear. Shown here are men who won’t be corralled by traditional style expectations. Two looks are at the center: a pencil-slim wrap coat in an unconventional gray, left, and a dusty pink coat shaped by exaggerated welt seams, right. The effect is such that the cloth seems to have been molded into a fitted shape. More important is the authority with which the young men wear these coats, which are far removed from the expected Wall Street uniform.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, interesting reads from Lynda Richardson, Andrew Jacobs and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Attack at Hotel in Burkina Faso’s Capital
abstract: A gun battle broke out outside the Splendid Hotel in Burkina Faso’s capital, Ouagadougou, on Friday night. The hotel, in the business district of Ouagadougou, is frequented by Westerners.

headline: Evening Hours | Dinner at the Frick and a Jazz Dance
abstract: Plus: Remembering a fashion editor.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Remembering a fashion editor.

headline: Oscars So White? Or Oscars So Dumb? Discuss.
abstract: For the second year in a row, the Academy failed to recognize any minority actors. Our chief film critics and our critic at large on what in the world is going on.
lead_paragraph: Are these the whitest Oscar nominations ever? Or just the most recent Academy Award whiteout? For the second year in a row, the nominations failed to recognize any minority actors. Movies about black lives like “Creed” and “Straight Outta Compton” did receive recognition, but their nominations were for either white writers (“Compton”) or a white performer (Sylvester Stallone in “Creed”). The black directors of each movie along with their nonwhite actors were shut out.

headline: Review: ‘Key Change’ Hears From Women in Prison
abstract: Written by Catrina McHugh, this short play at the Fourth Street Theater portrays the experiences of several female inmates during incarceration.
lead_paragraph: Although the language occasionally takes on a darkly lyrical hue, music plays no role in “Key Change,” a moving, intimate and superbly acted drama about women’s lives in (and out of, and in again) a British prison. Written by Catrina McHugh and directed by Laura Lindow, the play was “devised with” women from an actual prison, drawing specifically on their experiences both before and during incarceration.

headline: E.U.’s Open Borders Are in Danger, German Minister Warns
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble said the migrant crisis posed a threat to free travel within the European Union as border restrictions tighten.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The pressures facing Germany as it contends with record levels of migration burst into the open on Friday as the country’s finance minister warned the rest of the European Union that freedom to move within the bloc could be “close” to ending.

headline: Republicans in Congress Will Write 2016 Campaign Platform, Ryan Says
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They said they would focus on national security, the economy, health care, poverty and the Constitution after a meeting in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Republican congressional leaders said Friday that they were moving aggressively to draw up a campaign platform for 2016 so that the party would be positioned to coalesce swiftly around a nominee after a bruising primary campaign.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Flint, Coal
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Jason Craig’s ‘Longyarn’ Features a Mom Who Won’t Shut Up
abstract: Banana Bag & Bodice’s new production at the Bushwick Starr owes a debt to Beckett but is exuberantly American.
lead_paragraph: Mom is a mountain in “Longyarn,” the uninhibitedly shaggy new comedy from Banana Bag & Bodice. Her bedraggled head nearly scrapes the ceiling of the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn, where Jason Craig’s play opened on Thursday night, and her scrawny torso is attached to a Brobdingnagian skirt that defies circumnavigation.

headline: And the Oscar Goes to ... White People
abstract: How can the Academy increase diversity in nominations and awards?

headline: Gingerly, Donald Trump Tries Out Some Campaign Conventions
abstract: As some polls have tightened and voting nears, Mr. Trump is starting to balance his unique, provocative style with running “the Iowa way” and “the New Hampshire way.”
lead_paragraph: In Manchester, N.H., on Monday, after a traditional town hall-style event, the candidate who prefers dashing home from speeches on his private jet stopped by the Red Arrow Diner and ordered a cheeseburger plate piled high with French fries.

headline: Review: From Chile, ‘Escuela,’ a Drama About Education
abstract: In Guillermo Calderón’s play, the setting is a classroom, and the lesson is about guerrilla warfare.
lead_paragraph: A chalkboard is not the most cheering sight to behold upon entering a theater. Nor is a slide projector. Both are on view, aptly enough, alas, in “Escuela,” a dull, didactic drama written and directed by the noted Chilean playwright Guillermo Calderón.

headline: To Protect Against Zika Virus, Pregnant Women Are Warned About Latin American Trips
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Babies and Infants', 'Birth Defects', 'Viruses']
abstract: Pregnant women are told to avoid countries where mosquitoes are spreading the virus, which has been linked to brain damage in babies.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials on Friday advised pregnant women to postpone traveling to 13 Latin American or Caribbean countries and Puerto Rico where mosquitoes are spreading the Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in babies.

headline: He Irons. She Stitches.
abstract: Decades after taking over a Brooklyn laundry, a Chinese immigrant couple continues to uphold the unusual request made by the shop’s previous owner.
lead_paragraph: San Toy Laundry in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is marked with old-fashioned, Charlie Chan-style lettering on its dated sign out front. The space, on Seventh Avenue, has housed a string of Chinese-owned laundries dating back more than a century, and like nearly everything else inside, the handwritten sign “No Lost Tickets on Friday & Saturday” is antiquated.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Is Self-Financing Bid, Despite the Evidence
abstract: Donald J. Trump insists he is financing his own campaign, but the evidence suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to reporters after Thursday night’s debate, Donald J. Trump said, as he often does, that he was self-financing his campaign.

headline: Review: In ‘God Bless Baseball,’ Japan, Korea and America’s Pastime
abstract: Toshiki Okada’s play at Japan Society uses an allegory to dissect the relationship among these three countries.
lead_paragraph: “God Bless Baseball” at Japan Society has a few modest allegorical points to make and takes its time making them. It’s intermittently amusing and often visually arresting, but — like, some would say, the game of baseball itself — it would benefit from being sped up.

headline: Review: ‘Samedi Détente’ Looks Back at the Horrors of Rwanda
abstract: Dorothée Munyaneza uses spoken word, song and movement to revisit the genocide that forced her to flee her home as a 12-year-old.
lead_paragraph: In “Samedi Détente,” Dorothée Munyaneza uses spoken word, dance and music to explore the Rwandan genocide that forced her from her Kigali home at the age of 12. She describes how 800,000 people died in just 100 days, how she lost friends and family, how she and her father and brother escaped into the countryside, wearing lice-ridden layers of clothing and sleeping outdoors on a tarp.

headline: Aterrizando en Venezuela: En busca del rostro de Bolívar
abstract: Chávez tenía sus propias ideas sobre el hijo más famoso de Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Casey, el nuevo corresponsal de The New York Times en la región andina, compartirá en esta sección todas las vivencias de su primer mes en Venezuela.

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Offers Works by Modern Masters
abstract: The orchestra, led by Alan Gilbert, with Frank Peter Zimmermann on violin, is playing music from Respighi, Stravinsky and Magnus Lindberg.
lead_paragraph: For sheer sonic splendor, few programs could surpass the one Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic are offering at David Geffen Hall this week. It shows three modern masters — Ottorino Respighi, Magnus Lindberg and Igor Stravinsky — using their orchestral wizardry well, if, in Respighi’s case, not always wisely.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Born Again Teen
abstract: Can’t wait for the tour.
lead_paragraph: I love Lucius — their songwriting is terrific, their harmonies are exquisite, and their live performances are pure joy. Frankly, I’m not quite as fond of their records — I bought their first, of course, and have an advance of their second — which are (to my taste) overproduced. But your mileage may vary.

headline: Race, Civil Rights and Photography
abstract: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders relied on the power of photographs to persuade, enrage and motivate.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders relied on the power of photographs to persuade, enrage and motivate.

headline: Campaign Aides Defend Bernie Sanders’s Record on Gun Votes
abstract: Bernie Sanders opposed keeping background-check records tied to gun purchases for 90 days, putting him at odds with Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: As Senator Bernie Sanders soars in polls and faces criticism from Hillary Clinton over his record on gun control, his aides are finding themselves explaining his voting record over the years on the issue.

headline: Kid Fury of ‘The Read’: From Digital Realm to the Stage
abstract: Known for this podcast and his “Furious Thoughts” YouTube series, Kid Fury offers fans a comedy show on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kid Fury’s mentions on Twitter are often littered with story links and screenshots from his more than 100,000 followers, in which they ask if he has, say, seen the criticisms of the price of Michelle Obama’s clothes or a singer’s shady comment on Instagram. Their goal is to provide fodder for “The Read” — the podcast he hosts with his friend and fellow Internet personality, Crissle — or for “Furious Thoughts,” the YouTube series he started in 2010. On each platform he has built a rabid, eclectic following — blacks, whites, older people, high schoolers — who seek out his irreverent, profanity-ridden takes on the latest happenings both online and off, from viral racism to “The Real Housewives of Atlanta.”

headline: China Embraces Craft Beers, and Brewing Giants Take Notice
abstract: Chinese consumers are swapping mass-produced local beers for a bevy of imports and locally brewed brands, and a merged Anheuser-Busch InBev-SABMiller aims to capitalize.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Jin Xin first started selling imported premium beer a decade ago, his bar manager predicted that it would take a month or two just to sell a single case. But within a few years business picked up, and soon customers started frequenting the bar for its India pale ales and other European beers.

headline: Inquiry Faults Army Leadership in Anthrax Shipment
keywords: ['ANTHRAX', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Falsification of Data']
abstract: An Army report on a military laboratory that mistakenly sent live anthrax around the world singled out 12 people for possible disciplinary action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Army on Friday issued a scathing critique of the management and oversight of a military laboratory that mistakenly sent live anthrax to facilities around the world, singling out a brigadier general and 11 other people for possible disciplinary action.

headline: Dog Pants? Show a Little More Fur, Obama Says
abstract: President Obama gave interviews at the White House on Friday to three popular YouTube figures.
lead_paragraph: [Video: Watch on YouTube.]

headline: Despite Boycott Calls, Chicago Mayor’s King Day Event Goes On
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel is in deep political trouble over police misconduct, but the ire is not uniform, and he has retained support from some prominent black pastors and elected officials.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Despite calls to boycott an annual breakfast Mayor Rahm Emanuel was hosting in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a hotel ballroom was mostly full on Friday morning. The speech he delivered was greeted with polite applause. Some influential black leaders even offered friendly remarks from the stage.

headline: In Praise of Blue Notes: What Makes Music Sad?
abstract: Melancholy crosses genres. Adele, Nick Drake and Slayer are all mournful in their own ways.
lead_paragraph: The idea of sadness connects the music of Adele, Kendrick Lamar, Billie Holiday, the English folk singer Nick Drake, the metal band Slayer and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

headline: Kuwait Airways Drops Flights to Avoid Israeli Passengers
abstract: Instead of stopping the practice of blocking Israeli passengers from traveling between New York City and London, as the Transportation Department requested, the airline canceled the flights.
lead_paragraph: Kuwait Airways will operate its last flight between New York City and London on Saturday, deciding last month to drop the route after about 35 years of service rather than transport Israeli citizens between the two cities.

headline: In New Year’s Melee in Cologne, a Migrant Was One Woman’s Savior
keywords: ['New Year', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Rescues']
abstract: Unlike other women in Cologne, Germany, on New Year’s Eve, who said they were sexually assaulted by migrants, Caitlin Duncan says she was rescued by them.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Caught up in a melee of drunken revelers outside the Cologne train station on New Year’s Eve, Caitlin Duncan, a neuroscience student from Seattle, was terrified. She had somehow gotten separated from her German boyfriend, who had both their cellphones and her wallet. Ms. Duncan, 27, said that she was quickly surrounded and groped by several young men: One snatched her hat from her head, another tried to kiss her face and neck.

headline: New York to Gain 30 Acres of Parkland From Catholic Nuns
abstract: As their ranks thin with age, the Sisters of Our Lady of Christian Doctrine plan to sell some of their property in Upper Nyack to the Trust for Public Land.
lead_paragraph: UPPER NYACK, N.Y. — Sister Veronica Mendez adjusted her glasses and tried to remember the last time someone joined the religious order here. “Joined and stayed?” she pondered. “It would have been the 1970s.”

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Push on Justice Reform
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Probation and Parole', 'State of the State Message (NYS)', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Education for the incarcerated, preventive “community schools” and pardons are good, strong steps. But more should be done.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Andrew Cuomo went to Mount Neboh Baptist Church in Harlem last Sunday to give a speech on criminal justice reform, he said, “I’m going to go down in the history books as the governor who closed the most prisons in the history of the state of New York.”

headline: Death of 3 Columbia Students Raises Fears Over Trips Abroad
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Buses', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: A bus crash involving Columbia students in Honduras highlighted concerns over the safety of the many students studying or volunteering in foreign countries.
lead_paragraph: While many of their classmates were using the winter break to unwind, the 28 Columbia University students whose bus crashed in Honduras this week had chosen to spend part of their vacation volunteering by helping doctors provide basic medical care in one of Central America’s poorest countries.

headline: States Should Raise the Gas Tax
keywords: ['Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Railroads', 'Taxation', 'Gasoline Tax (US)']
abstract: Higher investment would not just improve roads and railways; it would also boost the economy.
lead_paragraph: The tumbling price of crude oil is helping many Americans save money. It also presents a good opportunity for state governments to raise their gasoline taxes to help pay for road repairs and other needed transportation investments.

headline: Putting an Environmental Price Tag on Coal
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Mines and Mining', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Coal']
abstract: The Obama administration is serious about decreasing the country’s reliance on fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: One intriguing if slightly mysterious passage in President Obama’s State of the Union address contained a pledge to “accelerate the transition away from old, dirtier energy,” in part by changing “the way we manage our oil and coal resources so that they better reflect the costs they impose on taxpayers and our planet.”

headline: Federal Reserve Started 2010 With Hope, Then Fear and Fitful Activism
keywords: ['Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Worsening economic conditions in 2010 led the Federal Reserve to act to try to avoid a new recession or a deflationary trap.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When 2010 began, the United States economy seemed to be on the mend and leaders of the Federal Reserve discussed how they would unwind their extraordinary rescue efforts  from the crisis that erupted in 2008. The term “exit strategy” was mentioned 37 times in their first two policy meetings of the year.

headline: Disney Names Bob Weis as New President of Imagineering Unit
abstract: Mr. Weis, who is replacing two executives atop the unit, helped design Disney’s Hollywood Studios park in Florida in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company on Friday installed new leadership at its linchpin Imagineering division, which is responsible for designing and building rides, hotels and restaurants across Disney’s $16 billion global theme park empire.

headline: New York Values, According to New Yorkers
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz attacked Donald J. Trump, a Queens native, for having “New York values.” Amid much debate over what that means, we invited New Yorkers to share their own definition.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz attacked Donald J. Trump, a Queens native, for having “New York values.” Amid much debate over what that means, we invited New Yorkers to share their own definition.

headline: Looking at Later Primaries, Bernie Sanders Works to Strengthen Black Support
abstract: The Vermont senator faces a daunting problem even if he wins Iowa and New Hampshire: winning over African-American voters in the more diverse states to follow.
lead_paragraph: Even if he defeats Hillary Clinton in both Iowa and New Hampshire next month, Senator Bernie Sanders faces a daunting problem when the presidential race moves on to bigger, more diverse states: winning over black voters.

headline: For Now, Anglicans Avert Schism Over Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ANGLICAN CHURCHES', 'Episcopal Church']
abstract: A truce was achieved when archbishops at a meeting in England voted resoundingly to impose restrictions for three years on the church’s American province, the Episcopal Church.
lead_paragraph: Despite threats of a walkout or even schism over the issue of gay marriage, the archbishops of the Anglican Communion, the world’s third-largest body of churches, managed to keep their church intact after a week of tense meetings that ended with a symbolic washing of one another’s feet.

headline: New Yorkers, Self-Assured and Opinionated, Defend Their Values
abstract: They are brazen, terse, edgy and carry king-size ambition through a city of extremes. On Friday, the residents took exception to Senator Ted Cruz’s recent remarks about “New York values.”
lead_paragraph: There is a broad and recognizable New York persona. It isn’t entirely enviable, not to everyone. Assured. Brazen. Unapologetic about money. There is a New York speed, and it’s rocket velocity. You want directions in the Midwest, someone will take you there, buy you a coffee, invite you later for dinner and to stay overnight. In New York it’s: “Two blocks down, take a left.” Whoosh.

headline: Jawbone Raises $165 Million at Half Its Last Valuation
abstract: Jawbone, the start-up that makes wearable devices, became the latest private company to raise money at a lower valuation than before.
lead_paragraph: Jawbone, the once-hot wearable technology start-up, said on Friday that it had raised $165 million in funding at a valuation of $1.5 billion, or roughly half the amount that the company was valued at as recently as 2014, continuing a burgeoning trend of start-ups raising money at lower values than before.

headline: Girl, 15, Killed in Fall From Rooftop in Hell’s Kitchen
abstract: The girl, Natalia Jimenez, fell five stories and was pronounced dead at a Manhattan hospital.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old girl died on Friday afternoon after she tried to jump from one rooftop to another in Midtown Manhattan and fell five stories, the police said.

headline: Oregon: Police Arrest Two Tied to Standoff at Refuge
abstract: One man connected with the armed takeover of a federal wildlife refuge in Oregon was arrested, and a second was held in the disappearance of a vehicle, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: One man connected with the armed takeover of a federal wildlife refuge in rural Oregon was arrested, and a second was held in the disappearance of a vehicle from the refuge, the authorities said Friday. Both arrests were made without incident and far from the refuge itself. Kenneth Medenbach, 62, was arrested Friday at a grocery in Burns on probable cause for unauthorized use of a motor vehicle that the police said was the property of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, about 30 miles away. Brian Cavalier, who identified himself as “Fluffy Unicorn,” and as a bodyguard of the militant group’s leader, Ammon Bundy, was arrested earlier in the week in Buckeye, Ariz., on a criminal warrant during the investigation of a suspicious vehicle. He was later released by a judge. A Buckeye police spokesman on Friday said Arizona law prevented disclosure of arrest warrant details. Protesters have occupied the refuge headquarters buildings since Jan. 2.

headline: Workers Sickened at House Office Building
keywords: ['Lead', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Several people were taken to hospitals after possibly being exposed to lead paint dust in a House office building, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Several people were taken to hospitals on Friday after possibly being exposed to lead paint dust in a House office building, the authorities said. Officials said that overnight construction at the Longworth House Office Building may have released the harmful substance in the kitchen area of the cafeteria, according to the House sergeant at arms. The area was not being used for food preparation. Ten cafeteria employees were evaluated, and most were taken to hospitals with “minor injuries,” a Fire Department official said. A favorite of House staff members, the cafeteria will remain closed while tests are conducted. The area around the Capitol was largely empty on Friday, with Congress in recess.

headline: Addressing Critics, White House Cites Diplomacy in Release of Sailors by Iran
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: As some characterized the seizure of American patrol boats as a foreign policy failure, the Obama administration said the quick release of the sailors was a benefit of nuclear diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday sought to defuse attempts by President Obama’s critics to turn this week’s overnight seizure of two American patrol boats and their crews into a symbol of what they say are the administration’s foreign policy failures and feckless relations with Iran.

headline: Hillary and Bernie, Punching
abstract: The Democrats may have strayed off the high road, but they’re a long way from Trump-Cruz territory.
lead_paragraph: There’s a Democratic debate Sunday night! The party honchos scheduled it in the middle of a three-day weekend, obviously in a bid to ensure maximum attention. The American public, perky from eight straight hours of football playoffs, will totally be in the mood for a serious policy dialogue.

headline: 16-Year-Old Charged in Brooklyn Shooting Death
abstract: The suspect, Malik Streat, was taken into police custody after the killing of Darnell Wilkerson, 18, in the East New York neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old has been charged with murder in the shooting death this week of a teenager near a Brooklyn school complex, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: U.S. Pledges to Ease Pain of Closing Coal Mines in Shift to Cleaner Energy
keywords: ['Coal', 'Federal Lands', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Global Warming', 'Energy and Power', 'Wind Power', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: The administration unveiled a plan aimed at extracting more money from companies for mining on federal land and using that revenue to help coal communities train for new jobs.
lead_paragraph: For the past five years, President Obama has denied the Republican charge that he is waging a war on coal. On Friday, with the Obama administration’s announcement that the Interior Department will halt new coal leases on public lands, Mr. Obama acknowledged that his climate change polices are hurting American miners and began offering ways to ease that economic harm.

headline: The Real Problem With Lunch
keywords: ['Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Movies', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Education (K-12)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: School meals reflect a society’s true food culture, as well as its regard for its children.
lead_paragraph: Houston — THERE’S something about comparing America’s school food to the superior meals in other countries’ schools that we seem to enjoy, in a masochistic sort of way.

headline: New England Is Abuzz (Oh, Is There a Game?)
abstract: As seems to be the norm in the region around playoff time, strange doings have focused the discussion on the on- and offstage weirdness at Gillette Stadium.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Last Sunday morning, Chandler Jones, the Patriots’ star defensive end, showed up in the parking lot of the Foxborough Police Department, inexplicably shirtless and disoriented.

headline: Starvation in Syria Galvanizes U.N., but Accountability Seems Distant as Ever
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Famine', 'Food', 'Malnutrition', 'International Relations']
abstract: Despite renewed attention to the use of starvation as a weapon of war by the Syrian government and rebels alike, accountability is arguably more elusive.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The images of gaunt, hollow-eyed children in three besieged Syrian towns this week prompted even the usually cautious Ban Ki-moon to bluntly and publicly declare that the people starving civilians on the battlefield were committing war crimes.

headline: In Life and on Field, Cardinals’ David Johnson Can Handle Traffic
abstract: Johnson, a resplendent rookie running back, emerged from a challenging youth — and a job doing asbestos removal — to thrive in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — David Johnson’s first run in traffic was memorable, but not in a way that made his mother proud.

headline: News Corp. and 21st Century Fox Won’t Move to World Trade Center
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The companies, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said they would stay in their current locations in Midtown instead of moving to the growing media hub in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: News Corporation and 21st Century Fox, two media companies controlled by Rupert Murdoch, have decided against moving their headquarters into a skyscraper at the World Trade Center, the companies said on Friday.

headline: After 85 Years in East Harlem, a Routine That Keeps Her Going
abstract: Marta Benitez, 95, says she considers herself lucky, despite the loss of her husband and only daughter to cancer.
lead_paragraph: Most Tuesday mornings, Marta Benitez walks from her apartment on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 111th Street to the food pantry at St. Cecilia’s Church on East 105th Street. With other volunteers, she assembles bags of nonperishable items to be handed out to members of the community.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Top Political Advisers Got $500,000 in 6 Months, Records Say
abstract: The new reports also show that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo received $900,000 from limited-liability companies, whose influence he is now trying to curb.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s top political consultants, some of whom also represent clients with interests before City Hall, were paid about $500,000 in the last six months by the mayor’s campaign fund and a nonprofit group created to advance his agenda, according to financial records disclosed on Friday.

headline: Venezuela Declares Emergency as Its Economy Falters
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro is seeking additional powers to bypass the National Assembly on spending matters, but the measure would have to be approved by the president’s rivals.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Venezuelan government on Friday declared an emergency to address the country’s deteriorating economy.

headline: Building Visions of Humanity’s Climate Future – in Fiction and on Campus
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Science Fiction', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: A call for fresh narratives and roadmaps aimed at charting a human journey with the fewest regrets.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week I spoke at Arizona State University on ways to pursue a least-regrets approach to human development. My talk (building on one you can watch here) launched an interdisciplinary workshop on developing the capacity to manage the climate system in the face of relentlessly rising emissions of greenhouse gases.*

headline: Sessions of Congress
abstract: Sean Dobbin offers us a thorny Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial “Heads Up For Sunday!” Alert : There will be a note on some formats of the Sunday, January 17 puzzle that reads: “The print version of the Sunday, January 17 puzzle contains small arrows between certain squares, which some formats cannot reproduce. We recommend using the Web version or the PDF.”

headline: Another Oscar Year, Another All-White Ballot
abstract: A second year with no minority actors singled out for Academy Awards leads to finger-pointing.
lead_paragraph: Is it the members who vote on the Oscars, the films, the campaigns behind them or something else?

headline: Dan Haggerty, Who Played Grizzly Adams, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Haggerty parlayed a beard and a bear into a role that endeared him to viewers of a film and television series both titled “The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams.”
lead_paragraph: Dan Haggerty, who played a gentle mountain man with a luxuriant beard and a bear named Ben in the 1974 movie “The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams” and the NBC television series of the same name, died on Friday in Burbank, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Dave Sime Dies at 79; World’s Fastest Sprinter, but Far From Its Luckiest
abstract: An injury kept Sime out of the 1956 Olympics and bad luck cost him a gold medal in 1960; he became an ophthalmologist whose patients included Richard Nixon and Ted Williams.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dave Sime, who passed up baseball and football careers to become the world’s fastest sprinter but who never won the Olympic gold medal he coveted, a victim of hard luck and the unforgiving rules of track and field, died on Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 79.

headline: Ted Cruz ‘Apologizes’ to New Yorkers, Again and Again
abstract: In a stump speech and several other places, Senator Ted Cruz issued a faux apology to New Yorkers for saying Donald J. Trump has “New York values.”
lead_paragraph: TIGERVILLE, S.C. – Senator Ted Cruz of Texas stood onstage here with a mischievous smile, setting off on a stump speech he is typically loath to change.

headline: At Fairfield Museum, Exploring Craftsmanship Across Centuries
abstract: In an exhibition at the Fairfield Museum, contemporary artisans display their works alongside pieces made by their counterparts of centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: In this era of mass-produced goods, when we can breezily purchase dishes and glassware by the set, browse for presized rugs online and “build” furniture by assembling kits from Ikea, it’s easy to take such quotidian household items for granted. But just a couple of centuries ago, the only way to create them was to fashion them by hand.

headline: Walter Weissman Photographs Celebrities
abstract: In “Portraying Artists: Photographs by Walter Weissman,” on view through Feb. 21, Mr. Weissman captures celebrities from a fly-on-the-wall perspective.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a little bit like a fly on the wall,” the photographer Walter Weissman was saying not long ago at Guild Hall in East Hampton, as he walked through an exhibition of his portraits of high-profile artists and other boldface names.

headline: Chamber Music Society Aims to Expand Its Reach
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presents programs all over the world, from Seoul, South Korea, to Pleasant Hill, Ky., and now the society plans to increase its audience upstate, too.
lead_paragraph: As the artistic directors of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, David Finckel and Wu Han have expanded the group’s reach over the past decade. Instead of just producing concerts at its home in Alice Tully Hall, the society produces and presents programs all over the world, from Seoul, South Korea, to Pleasant Hill, Ky.

headline: Review: Rye Roadhouse Maintains Its Louisiana Charm
abstract: The restaurant and bar reopened under new management in 2008. The owners decided to keep much of its charm intact.
lead_paragraph: The Rye Roadhouse is a perpetual tailgate, no coolers, koozies, propane tanks, tongs or foot warmers required.

headline: Review: Mazi, a Greek Taverna Refined by Time and Fire
abstract: After its predecessor burned down, Mazi emerged with a sleeker space and a more varied Mediterranean menu.
lead_paragraph: Built into the bar at Mazi, a new Mediterranean restaurant in Riverhead, is a copper plaque of a phoenix rising out of the ashes. In the case of Mazi, the figure is more than a metaphor.

headline: Review: Global Sensibility at the Plum and the Pear
abstract: “America is a melting pot of cultures, and so is my food,” said George Kalivas, the chef and owner of the Plum and the Pear, which opened last year in Wyckoff.
lead_paragraph: “America is a melting pot of cultures, and so is my food,” said George Kalivas, the chef and owner of the Plum and the Pear, in Wyckoff.

headline: An Ever-Changing Menu at Prospect Cafe in West Hartford
abstract: As owners seek the right balance between great food at a good price, the restaurant’s menu continues to evolve.
lead_paragraph: Goldilocks would have felt right at home at Prospect Cafe in West Hartford since its reopening four months ago.

headline: Serena Williams, Rejecting Health Doubts, Insists She’s Ready
abstract: Williams, who has not played a meaningful match in four months and has dealt with knee problems, said she was at “120, 130 percent” for the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Serena Williams has not played a meaningful match since losing in the semifinals of the United States Open in September.

headline: Matt Harvey Re-Signs With Mets
abstract: The Mets agreed to a contract with Harvey for the 2016 season, avoiding arbitration. Harvey will reportedly make $4.325 million, about seven times more than he made last season.
lead_paragraph: The Mets agreed to a contract with Matt Harvey for the 2016 season, avoiding arbitration.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Benedict Cumberbatch portrays Alan Turing in “The Imitation Game,” six teenagers are cyberstalked in “Unfriended,” and Adam Driver hosts “S.N.L.”
lead_paragraph: Benedict Cumberbatch delivers one of the best performances of 2014 as the British mathematician Alan Turing in “The Imitation Game.” Six teenagers endure some vicious cyberstalking in “Unfriended.” And Adam Driver, the latest “Star Wars” baddie, hosts “S.N.L.”

headline: Feud Adds Intrigue to Game Between Knicks and Grizzlies
abstract: As anticipation built for Saturday’s matchup, Knicks Coach Derek Fisher continued to play down his October altercation with Memphis forward Matt Barnes.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Inside their training complex on Friday, the Knicks maintained that they were more or less oblivious to the interest now surrounding their Saturday night game in Memphis, a midseason contest that did not stand out at all when the 2015-16 N.B.A. schedule was released in August.

headline: Corrections: January 16, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 16, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 16, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We may win an Oscar now and then, but an Oscar is not going to fundamentally change how Hollywood does business. I’m not talking about Hollywood stars. I’m talking about executives. We’re not in the room.”

headline: Tsai Ing-wen Elected President of Taiwan, First Woman to Hold Office
abstract: Voters were expected to give Ms. Tsai’s Democratic Progressive Party control of the legislature, giving her broad authority to push her policies in office.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Tsai Ing-wen was elected Taiwan’s president on Saturday, becoming the first woman to win the office. Voters gave her Democratic Progressive Party, which is skeptical of closer ties with China, control of Taiwan’s legislature for the first time, giving her broad authority to enact her policies in office.

headline: How El Chapo Was Finally Captured, Again
abstract: Joaquín Guzmán Loera’s meeting with the movie star Sean Penn gave the authorities a break they needed to help recapture him. So did a big order of tacos.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Stripped to his undershirt and covered in filth, the world’s most notorious drug lord dragged himself out of the sewers and into the middle of traffic.

headline: With the Rise of Justin Trudeau, Canada Is Suddenly ... Hip?
abstract: Led by a handsome prime minister and artists like Drake, the Weeknd and Sarah Polley, Canada is shaking off its polite image.
lead_paragraph: Led by a handsome prime minister and artists like Drake, the Weeknd and Sarah Polley, Canada is shaking off its polite image.

headline: David Bowie: Invisible New Yorker
abstract: Despite being a rock legend, the musician was an apparition in Manhattan, able to walk the city streets unrecognized.
lead_paragraph: About 10 years ago, the playwright John Guare got a call asking if he wanted to meet David Bowie to discuss a theater project.

headline: Airing the Evidence on Dust Mites
abstract: Keeping a home’s relative humidity low can help fight the irritating creatures, but solid made-vs.-unmade-bed evidence remains undone.
lead_paragraph: Q. Does an unmade bed kill dust mites?

headline: Eileen Myles, the Poet Muse of ‘Transparent’
abstract: The writer spent decades in the obscurity of punk poet-dom. Now, as Jill Soloway’s girlfriend, that is no longer the case.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Rocking a pinstriped Paul Smith suit and boots that she had picked up in Paris, Eileen Myles rolled into the Golden Globes here last weekend on the arm of her girlfriend, Jill Soloway, the creator of the Amazon series “Transparent,” who was outfitted in a pink tuxedo and platform sneakers. Cool? The epitome.

headline: What Donald Trump’s Plaza Deal Reveals About His White House Bid
abstract: The mogul’s purchase of the Plaza Hotel in 1988 offers insight into the methods and thinking of a deal maker turned presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: The day Donald Trump called and asked for a one-on-one meeting in the winter of 1988, Tom Barrack was a relative newcomer to the high-stakes poker game of New York real estate. He had worked for nearly two years for Robert Bass, the Texas billionaire investor, and had played an important role in winning the Plaza Hotel for his boss the year before. Mr. Trump was the country’s most quotable and ostentatious financial celebrity, a guy with a jet, a 282-foot yacht and a fondness for peach-toned marble.

headline: In Maine, Local Control Is a Luxury Fewer Towns Can Afford
keywords: ['Local Government', 'Property Taxes', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Population', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Privatization']
abstract: Faced with dwindling populations and rising costs, tiny localities like Cary Plantation find that their only salvation might be in dissolving themselves.
lead_paragraph: CARY PLANTATION, Me. — Up here, near the end of Interstate 95, a single main road ridged with stately conifers runs past the odd house that at night casts an orange glow over the snow. There is no school. No police department. Not even a stoplight.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the inside of a dinosaur to Sesame Street, in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the inside of a dinosaur to Sesame Street, in Queens.

headline: Corneliani: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 designs from Corneliani.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 designs from Corneliani.

headline: Liber8 BB-8!
abstract: Droids are people too.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I was on a panel at ComicCon — hey, who knew CES utility functions would lead me down this road? — discussing Trekonomics. Manu Saadia has a fun book on the subject, focusing on the transformative powers of replicators that make anything you want, but as we discussed, what about services? My on-the-fly take was that there was a conceptual problem: if we made machines smart enough to provide all our services, wouldn’t those machines effectively be people, deserving freedom from servitude?

headline: Ermenegildo Zegna: Fall 2016
abstract: Ermenegildo Zegna’s fall 2016 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Ermenegildo Zegna’s fall 2016 men’s collection.

headline: Oil Goes Nonlinear
abstract: Why the plunge isn’t good news.
lead_paragraph: When oil prices began their big plunge, it was widely assumed that the economic effects would be positive. Some of us were a bit skeptical. But maybe not skeptical enough: taking a global view, there’s a pretty good case that the oil plunge is having a distinctly negative impact. Why?

headline: Iran Frees Americans, Including Jason Rezaian, in Prisoner Swap
abstract: Word of the exchange came just before longstanding economic sanctions on Iran were lifted under terms of the historic nuclear deal reached in July.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran freed four Americans of Iranian descent from prison on Saturday, including a Marine veteran and a reporter from The Washington Post, in a delicately negotiated swap with the United States, which released seven Iranians who had been held on sanctions violations.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Not-So-‘Basic’ Shift in Start-Ups
abstract: Apple Music gains ground, an initiative on self-driving cars and a sensible move from Foursquare — with a twist of “cool-kid” slang.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Costume National Homme: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 designs from Costume National Homme.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 designs from Costume National Homme.

headline: Paul Giamatti Had a Busy Year of Mad Guys and Bad Hair
abstract: Roles as music-biz manipulators in “Love & Mercy” and “Straight Outta Compton” and as an angry juror on “Inside Amy Schumer” have led him to a good-guy part in “Billions.”
lead_paragraph: When Paul Giamatti is first seen in the new Showtime drama “Billions,” his character, a crusading United States attorney named Chuck Rhoades, has been bound and gagged as part of a sadomasochistic sex act. Shooting the scene last year had a curious effect on the actor. “I got really sleepy and relaxed,” Mr. Giamatti recently recalled over a cappuccino at the Lambs Club in Times Square. “I think guys who normally get tied up have the opposite reaction. Or maybe this is why they swaddle babies?”

headline: Apartments That Feel Like Saunas
abstract: This week our subjects are unbearably hot apartments; home swapping; and co-op reserve funds.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: In Tehran, Iranians Play Down Milestone
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations']
abstract: The low-key reception for the expected lifting of sanctions reflects multiple disappointments and broken promises.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — On the day that crushing international sanctions against Iran were to be lifted, state television opened its morning hourly news program with an item on children’s vaccinations. There were no flag-waving youths or cheering crowds on Tehran’s streets, just the usual Saturday morning rush hour, the start of the Iranian workweek.

headline: Exploring Des Moines and Beyond in Iowa
abstract: With the caucuses weeks away, a road trip reaffirms that our nation, beginning with Iowa, is full of unsung surprises.
lead_paragraph: With the caucuses weeks away, a road trip reaffirms that our nation, beginning with Iowa, is full of unsung surprises.

headline: Hawaii Baby With Brain Damage Is First U.S. Case Tied to Zika Virus
abstract: The case was a first for the United States, and the child’s mother, who had lived in Brazil, probably was infected by a mosquito bite there last year, the state department said.
lead_paragraph: The first case of brain damage linked to the Zika virus within the United States was reported on Friday in Hawaii.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2016
abstract: Dolce & Gabbana’s Fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Dolce & Gabbana’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Sgt. E. Castro: A Prison Peacemaker
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Ms. Castro, who works at the Folsom Women’s Facility in California, says it’s important to spend time reassuring the inmates when they’re having problems.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. E. Castro, 40, is a correctional supervisor at Folsom Women’s Facility in California. (Her full first name has been withheld for security reasons.)

headline: Marni: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall 2016 looks from Marni.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 looks from Marni.

headline: Profiles of Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmati and Jason Rezaian
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmati and Jason Rezaian are among the American citizens who have been held in Iran.
lead_paragraph: Age: 39

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2016
abstract: Jil Sander presents looks for Fall 2016.
lead_paragraph: Jil Sander presents looks for Fall 2016.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Richard Silvestri returns with a clever cryptic crossword.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — You need a different kind of a mindset to decipher cryptic crossword clues. Occasionally, you might need more than one different kind of mindset.

headline: The Place of Refuge in the West Village
abstract: For the last regular installment of At the Table, we visit the Place, a warm, stone-walled restaurant in the West Village that has a fireplace burning to chase away the chill of winter.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, it was decided that it would be fun to eavesdrop — with permission — on diners in the city as they sat in restaurants eating and talking. Since then, the At the Table column has covered group outings at grand hotels, holes in the wall, bistros, pizzerias, taquerias, dim sum palaces, barbecue joints, lunch counters, steakhouses, noodle shops, old classics and new finds, all in search of that ineffable combination of food, décor and clientele that gives a restaurant a sense of place.

headline: Unbeaten at Home, Warriors Are Still in Fight for a Playoff Edge
abstract: Golden State is off to a 37-4 start, going 19-0 at Oracle Arena, but it is not guaranteed of getting home-court advantage for the postseason: The Spurs are just two games back.
lead_paragraph: Off to a 37-3 start to the season entering the weekend, which had them tied for the best 40-game start in N.B.A. history, the Golden State Warriors have dominated most basketball conversations.

headline: Clinton Campaign Underestimated Sanders Strengths, Allies Say
abstract: Advisers to Mrs. Clinton, including the former president Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by failing to undercut Mr. Sanders’s message early in the race.
lead_paragraph: Advisers to Hillary Clinton, including former President Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by forgoing early attacks on Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and failing to undercut his archliberal message before it grew into a political movement that has now put him within striking distance of beating her in Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: In Forbes Media Sale, Five-Figure Battle Started a $100 Million War
abstract: The buyer and seller of Forbes magazine, which is famous for listing the world’s wealthiest people, have accused each other of being short on cash.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Forbes family sold control of its magazine and publishing business in 2014, Tim Forbes held a meeting in Hong Kong with one of the new owners. Mr. Forbes, younger brother of Steve Forbes, had been trying for weeks to collect an interest payment from the buyers. But in the October meeting, Mr. Forbes said his family had waited long enough for the $46,000 payment. The refusal to pay, he said, was “a disrespect to my family and disrespect to me personally.”

headline: TINA and the ACA
abstract: Health reform is what it has to be.
lead_paragraph: Lucy just snatched the football away, again. Republicans assured us that this year they really would, seriously, roll out their alternative to Obamacare. Or, maybe, not.

headline: What’s Harder Than Renting a Car? Filing a Complaint
abstract: A customer of Payless Car Rental tries to complain of a long wait and finds herself trapped in a loop of returned emails. The company’s sister division Budget, however, gets it right.
lead_paragraph: This jam-packed episode contains both a Haggler intervention and a head-scratcher of a mystery. That is called value, dear readers. The mystery, for those who can’t stand suspense, will turn up at the end of the column, and a bit like Stonehenge and the career of Nicolas Cage, it will remain a mystery.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Vision Makes Hillary Clinton Camp See Red
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s campaign denounced an ad for Bernie Sanders in Iowa and New Hampshire, calling it a negative attack — a characterization Mr. Sanders’s team denied.

headline: The Unluckiest Captain in China
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Americans Abroad', 'English Language', 'Voice and Speech', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Playing a role as the voice of ships in distress for nautical trainees gives an American living in China a sense of absurdity, and acceptance.
lead_paragraph: “Mayday. Mayday. Mayday. Call sign Alfa Bravo Charlie Delta. Mayday, Pacific Ocean. I am on fire in No. 4 hold and have dangerous goods on foredeck.” It is a Wednesday morning in Guangzhou, China, and in a recording studio on the 22nd floor of a Zhujiang New Town skyscraper, terrible things are happening to ships.

headline: Singer’s Apology for Waving Taiwan Flag Stirs Backlash of Its Own
abstract: The videotaped apology from the singer, Chou Tzu-yu, with the K-pop band Twice, was addressed in a victory speech by Taiwan’s president-elect.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A teenage singer made headlines in China and on her home island of Taiwan this weekend, but not for the winsome K-pop music that she hoped would attract fans. Instead, a glum, shaken apology after a controversy over a flag landed the singer, Chou Tzu-yu, in the maw of tensions between China and Taiwan, just as the island voted to elect an independence-leaning president on Saturday.

headline: Chris Davis’s Deal With Orioles Keeps Yoenis Cespedes in Play for Mets
abstract: The agreement to sign Davis, who accepted a seven-year, $161 million deal, may mean Cespedes, another free agent Baltimore courted, would take a short-term contract with New York.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Orioles have agreed to contract terms with Chris Davis, a development that gives the Mets a little more hope that they can sign Yoenis Cespedes to a short-term deal.

headline: Neil Barrett: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest designs from Neil Barrett.
lead_paragraph: The latest designs from Neil Barrett.

headline: Ted Cruz Goes on Multipronged Attack Against Donald Trump
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz seemed to have gotten over his reluctance to criticize Donald J. Trump, continuing to tie Mr. Trump to liberal “New York values,” criticizing his temperament and even disparaging his poll numbers.
lead_paragraph: FORT MILL, S.C. — Disparaging Donald J. Trump’s temperament, questioning his beliefs and even knocking his polling numbers, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas laid into Mr. Trump in earnest on Saturday and abandoned any reluctance to take on his popular Republican rival.

headline: Prominent Jeb Bush Donor Questions ‘Super PAC’ Strategist Over Negative Marco Rubio Ads
abstract: At a closed-door meeting Friday, a Jeb Bush donor questioned why the group Right to Rise was spending money attacking Senator Marco Rubio.
lead_paragraph: A prominent donor to Jeb Bush pressed the chief strategist of the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Bush over the group’s negative ads about Senator Marco Rubio during a closed-door meeting in Manhattan on Friday, according to three people familiar with the encounter.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: On Making College Sports Explicitly, Unabashedly Professional

headline: Soviet Star Defenseman’s Latest Turn
abstract: Sergei Starikov, the new hockey coach at South Brunswick High School, has lived many lives.
lead_paragraph: SOMERSET, N.J. — When Craig Romanok learned of his son Clayton’s new high school hockey coach this fall, he made Clayton, a goaltender on the team, sit down to watch “Red Army,” a documentary on the famed Soviet hockey team of the Cold War era. Romanok wanted to ensure that his son had the proper appreciation for the man who is now his coach.

headline: Deadly Standoff Leaves Burkina Faso Stunned
abstract: Gunfire raged through the night as armed forces from Burkina Faso, assisted by French and American forces, stormed the popular downtown area where attackers had set off explosives.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Terror came to this sleepy city this weekend, as armed fighters descended on a road nicknamed the Champs-Élysées, where friends meet for coffee and foreigners relax in a familiar hotel. After a 15-hour siege, the assailants left behind more than the dead and wounded scattered across the charred road amid shell casings.

headline: The Founders’ Intent
abstract: Readers discuss a letter from a retired diplomat that argued that the founders designed the Constitution to have “flexibility to respond to change.”

headline: How Measurement Fails Doctors and Teachers
keywords: ['Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Doctors', 'Organized Labor', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Performance metrics in medicine and education are increasingly getting in the way of quality.
lead_paragraph: TWO of our most vital industries, health care and education, have become increasingly subjected to metrics and measurements. Of course, we need to hold professionals accountable. But the focus on numbers has gone too far. We’re hitting the targets, but missing the point.

headline: When Anger Trumped Progress
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Reconstruction Era', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Reconstruction era had an oddly familiar mix of racial struggle and populist outrage that left blacks the losers.
lead_paragraph: JOHN YOUNG was born into slavery, on July 4, 1855. By 15 he was a free man and an electrifying orator, recruiting black voters around his native South Carolina to the Republican Party with “pyrotechnical” rhetoric and mustache-waggling jokes. In the late 1860s, it looked as if he might help his party make real change in the post-Civil War South.

headline: The Man Who Fell From Fame
abstract: Brett Smiley, who was poised for Bowie-like glam rock fame in the 1970s, should be mourned, too.
lead_paragraph: BRETT SMILEY was no David Bowie.

headline: Rocco Casagrande
abstract: A former weapons inspector on sci-fi books, heavy metal and the joy of chopping wood.
lead_paragraph: Rocco Casagrande, a former United Nations biological weapons inspector, is managing director of Gryphon Scientific, a consulting company that last week delivered a federally commissioned report identifying the risks and benefits of allowing research that could make certain viruses, like influenza, SARS or MERS, more dangerous.

headline: Why I Taught Myself to Procrastinate
abstract: Delaying the completion of a project may actually make you more creative.
lead_paragraph: NORMALLY, I would have finished this column weeks ago. But I kept putting it off because my New Year’s resolution is to procrastinate more.

headline: Donald Trump’s Existential Pickle
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The egomaniacal billionaire has something on the line in Iowa that no other Republican does.
lead_paragraph: IF your very candidacy and identity rest on your supposed talent for victory, can you survive a defeat?

headline: Cancer and Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Death and Dying', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: I won’t live to see how civilization gets out of this mess. But I have hope.
lead_paragraph: I’M a climate scientist who has just been told I have Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.

headline: Some Inconvenient Gun Facts for Liberals
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: Some policies pushed by advocates of gun safety laws don’t reduce gun deaths. That doesn’t mean we shouldn’t try; we just need a new approach.
lead_paragraph: FOR those of us who argue in favor of gun safety laws, there are a few inconvenient facts.

headline: Hallelujah College
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Religion and Belief', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Many evangelical undergrads are thoughtful critics of elite universities.
lead_paragraph: LAST fall, as student activists around the country protested racism on their campuses, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas dismissed secular universities as havens for “leftist, coddled kids.” The protests proved that these schools teem with “psychotic Marxists,” declared “The Daily Caller,” a conservative website.

headline: The Destruction of Progressive Wisconsin
abstract: Scott Walker has turned his state into a laboratory for the evisceration of labor.
lead_paragraph: SHORTLY after his exit from an abbreviated presidential run last fall, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin returned to a more successful undertaking: dismantling what remains of his state’s century-old progressive legacy.

headline: The Bill Clinton Question
abstract: What matters about Bill Clinton’s sexual past is what we still don’t know about it.

headline: A Picasso’s Economics Lesson
abstract: A sculpture worth tens of millions was sold twice, an art market demonstration of “phantom liquidity.”
lead_paragraph: QATAR, it seems, was gazumped.

headline: Reigning Cats and Dogs
abstract: Will Hillary govern like a man or a woman? Or, perhaps more important, a canine or a feline?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AFTER running as a man last time around, Hillary Clinton is now running as a woman.

headline: After Losing a Daughter, Mustering Strength for 3 Who Remain
abstract: Yvette Teixeira, 43, had grappled with poverty for years. But the sudden death of one of her daughters made some everyday struggles even more painful.
lead_paragraph: She called them her four M&M’s: Meghan and Mishelle, Makayla and Mya, each born a year apart, a tribe of sisters who walked in lock step and looked after each other when they got sick.

headline: C. D. Wright, Poet of Ozarks and Beyond, Dies at 67
abstract: Ms. Wright, whose work mixes the commonplace and the fantastic and was informed by her Arkansan heritage, considered poetry writing an act of social responsibility.
lead_paragraph: C. D. Wright, a MacArthur fellowship-winning poet whose work — characterized by linguistic experimentation, stylistic innovation and an ever-shifting thematic canvas — was rooted in her Southern heritage yet, at the same time, utterly beyond category, died this week at her home in Barrington, R.I. She was 67.

headline: Maria Teresa de Filippis, Pioneer of Auto Racing, Dies at 89
abstract: De Filippis, an Italian aristocrat who helped reopen a sport to women, drove in Formula 1 world championship grands prix.
lead_paragraph: Maria Teresa de Filippis, who in the late 1950s became the first woman to compete in Formula 1 world championship grands prix, widely regarded as the pinnacle of automobile racing, died on Jan. 9. She was 89.

headline: With Triple Crown Winner at Last, Sport Aims to Ride the Momentum
abstract: The Horse of the Year American Pharoah breathed new life into a struggling sport, which now turns its attention to maintaining the growth.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — As racing prepared for a widely expected coronation of American Pharoah, the first Triple Crown winner in 37 years, as its horse of the year during ceremonies at Gulfstream Park on Saturday night, the industry recognized the need to build on the enormous lift he provided.

headline: Operating on a Shoestring, Ireland Struggles to Develop First-Rate Tennis Players
abstract: Lacking the facilities and the financial backing that other countries take for granted, Irish athletes are at a disadvantage early in their careers.
lead_paragraph: More than 40 nations will be represented at the Australian Open, which begins Monday, more evidence of how truly global tennis has become.

headline: The Death Penalty Endgame
abstract: The justices are considering a petition that asks them to strike down capital punishment once and for all. What are they waiting for?
lead_paragraph: How does the death penalty in America end?

headline: Leonid Zhabotinsky, Strongman for the Ages, Dies at 77
abstract: The Big Zhabo, as he was known, set his first of 19 world superheavyweight weight-lifting records in 1963.
lead_paragraph: Leonid Zhabotinsky, a record-breaking Ukrainian-born Soviet weight lifter who picked up Olympic gold medals in 1964 and 1968 and was Arnold Schwarzenegger’s teenage idol, died on Thursday in Zaporozhye, Ukraine. He was 77.

headline: When Oil-Rich Countries Need More Cash
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing nations are relying on sovereign wealth funds because of falling oil prices.
lead_paragraph: The long slide in oil prices, which reached a 13-year low this week of less than $30 a barrel, means that oil-rich nations are not so rich anymore. And that is potentially a big problem for investors and policy makers in the United States and abroad.

headline: Keep Guns Away From Abusers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Domestic Violence', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control']
abstract: Shortcomings in federal and state law allow many domestic abusers to have access to firearms.
lead_paragraph: While the gun violence debate often focuses on mass shootings of strangers,  hundreds of Americans are fatally shot every year by spouses or partners. In 2013, 61 percent of women killed with guns were killed by husbands, ex-husbands or boyfriends. And in 57 percent of shootings in which four or more people were killed, one of the victims was the shooter’s partner or family member, according to an analysis by the group Everytown for Gun Safety.

headline: Broncos’ Movie Buff Harris Has Been Stealing the Show From Opposing Receivers
abstract: Chris Harris Jr., like an actor, applies his improvisational skills and impeccable timing to mastering one of the most demanding positions on defense: the slot cornerback.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The Oscar nominations came rolling in last week, and that afforded Chris Harris Jr., the Denver Broncos’ resident cinephile, an opportunity to handicap the race for best picture. Of the eight films nominated, he had seen most, including “The Revenant” (bloody but good), “Bridge of Spies” (fantastic) and “Spotlight,” his pick to win — though he reserved the right to change his mind, he said, after viewing them all.

headline: Linebacker Luke Kuechly Quietly Leads a Brash Panthers Defense
abstract: Kuechly, 24, is the centerpiece of the sixth-best defense in the N.F.L., which will try to stop the Seahawks on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A flashy new sign appeared in the Carolina Panthers’ locker room last week, pasted above the section where the defensive backs store their gear. It has gradations of pale blue and white and declares that the area is “Thieves Ave.”

headline: Pal Zileri : Fall 2016
abstract: Pal Zileri’s Fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Pal Zileri’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Political Prisoners', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Energy', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The United States and European nations lifted oil and financial sanctions on Iran on Saturday and released roughly $100 billion of its assets after international inspectors concluded that the country had followed through on promises to dismantle large sections of its nuclear program.

headline: With Iran Nuclear Deal Implemented, What Happens Next?
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The most immediate benefit to Iran will be access to roughly $100 billion of its own money, but some believe it could signal a slow thaw to U.S.-Iran relations in general.
lead_paragraph: The International Atomic Energy Agency declared Saturday that Iran had fulfilled requirements to limit its nuclear activities, a step that automatically lifted nuclear-related economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations, European Union and United States. The move freed Iran to sell much more oil and gain control of roughly $100 billion in impounded money, ending a prolonged isolation that has driven the country into a deep economic malaise.

headline: Versace: Fall 2016
abstract: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from Versace.
lead_paragraph: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from Versace.

headline: Alabama Player’s Misfortunes Typify Pitfalls of College Sports
abstract: The short life of Altee Tenpenny, a rising football star who was killed in October, is instructive on many levels.
lead_paragraph: I first heard the name Altee Tenpenny about 10 years ago.

headline: Maryland Takes Out Frustrations on Ohio State
abstract: The Terps lost only their second game of the season earlier in the week, and on Saturday they made the Buckeyes suffer the consequences.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — No. 3 Maryland went into its practice Thursday bruised from Tuesday’s 70-67 loss at Michigan, just its second defeat of the season. The team proceeded to have at it.

headline: Twisting One’s Words
abstract: This one by Jeff Chen will make you dizzy.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial “Heads Up!” Alert : There will be a note on some formats of today’s puzzle that reads: “The print version of the Sunday, January 17 puzzle contains small arrows between certain squares, which some formats cannot reproduce. We recommend using the Web version or the PDF.”

headline: Flamboyant Egyptian Politician Craves Public Eye
abstract: For many Egyptians, Mortada Mansour’s behavior has only confirmed their low expectations of the new Parliament, which is weak and heavily tilted in favor of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mortada Mansour, a pugnacious Egyptian politician, likes to boast that he beats his rivals with his shoe — so much, in fact, that he has lost count of the number of disputes he has settled in that manner. “I ran out of shoes,” said Mr. Mansour, who once spent time in jail for insulting a judge.

headline: Huffington Post and CNN Waited to Report U.S.-Iran Prisoner-Swap Negotiations
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism']
abstract: CNN said the government asked it not to run information about negotiations over a prisoner exchange that included a Washington Post reporter. Huffington Post said it made the decision on its own.
lead_paragraph: Two news organizations have acknowledged that they knew about the negotiations between the United States and Iran over a prisoner exchange that included a Washington Post reporter before the arrangement was announced. But they chose not to publish information about the talks.

headline: Standoff in Oregon Attracts Supporters Bearing Disparate Grievances
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Federal Lands', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: As the protest at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge has dragged on, it has become a magnet of sorts, attracting strands of diverse conservative movements from across the country.
lead_paragraph: One of the people who have joined the Bundy family on a federal wildlife sanctuary in an arid patch of Oregon is an avowed anti-Semite from Ohio. One is an anti-Islamic ideologue from Phoenix.

headline: On Paper, Italy Allows Abortions, but Few Doctors Will Perform Them
abstract: For over three decades, the procedure has been legal in the predominantly Catholic nation, but most gynecologists are conscientious objectors.
lead_paragraph: ASCOLI PICENO, Italy — After Benedetta, 35, found out 11 weeks into her pregnancy that the baby she wanted “with all myself” had extremely serious genetic problems, she made a painful decision, and asked her longtime gynecologist for an abortion.

headline: New Guidelines Nudge Doctors to Give Patients Access to Medical Records
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors', 'Privacy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In new guidelines, the Obama administration says doctors and hospitals cannot require patients to state a reason for requesting their records, and cannot deny access out of a general concern that patients might be upset by the information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is tearing down barriers that make it difficult for patients to get access to their own medical records, telling doctors and hospitals that in most cases they must provide copies of these records within 30 days of receiving a request.

headline: Before Debris Collapse in China, Safety Fears Were Discussed
keywords: ['Landslides and Mudslides', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Building (Construction)']
