abstract: China’s industrial safety record has improved in recent years, but the ruling Communist Party still struggles to impose accountability on local bureaucrats.
lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — Four days before a mountain of dirt and debris collapsed here, killing at least 69 people, the government agency in charge of the construction dump convened a meeting to discuss safety concerns. In attendance were representatives of the company with the contract to manage the site and the independent engineering firm paid to monitor its work.

headline: Virginia Man Is Accused of Trying to Join ISIS
abstract: The Justice Department said that one of the men was arrested at an airport, where he planned to begin a journey to Syria to fight with ISIS, and that the other assisted him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department charged two Virginia men on Saturday with terrorism-related offenses, one day after F.B.I. agents arrested one of them at an airport where officials believe he was planning to begin a journey to Syria to fight with the Islamic State.

headline: Patriots Methodically Clear First Hurdle
abstract: Bill Belichick, the New England coach, and his quarterback Tom Brady have now won 22 postseason games.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Two days before the first anniversary of the game that spawned a polemic controversy over deflated footballs, the New England Patriots and their fans gathered for the first playoff game since that contretemps shrouded the franchise for nearly nine months. The atmosphere was festive, with the home side clearly happy to host another mid-January postseason game. But there was also an edge in the air.

headline: I.A.E.A. Report on Iran’s Nuclear Program
abstract: The agency found that Iran has complied with the accord reached last summer and has dismantled large sections of its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: The agency found that Iran has complied with the accord reached last summer and has dismantled large sections of its nuclear program.

headline: Taiwan’s New Leader Faces a Weak Economy and China’s Might
abstract: Tsai Ing-wen, elected Saturday as Taiwan’s first female president, brings what some call a more calm and rational approach to the island’s turbulent politics.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Before Tsai Ing-wen felt the thrill of victory on Saturday by becoming the first woman to be elected president of Taiwan, she was no stranger to the sting of defeat.

headline: Donald Trump Gets Personal in Attacks on Ted Cruz at Tea Party Convention
abstract: The increasingly personal lines of attack against Mr. Cruz in a public setting mark a shift in the race for the Republican presidential nomination that started during Thursday’s debate and spilled onto the campaign trail on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — He told war stories about his old construction sites. He promised to build a beautiful “Trump Wall” along the border with Mexico. He poked some fun at Jeb Bush, saying that embracing his family name could do little to harm his low-polling campaign.

headline: Manners Fit Jeb Bush, if Not an Uncouth Race
abstract: The travails of Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign can be seen as perhaps the last, wheezing gasp of the WASP power structure.
lead_paragraph: DERRY, N.H. — Tennis. Boating. Summers at Walker’s Point.

headline: For Broadcast of Super Bowl I, NFL Network Picks Excess Over Tact
abstract: The network could have taken the spirit of 1967 and relived the first Super Bowl without 21st-century excess, but it adopted the ethic of the multi-hour Super Bowl pregame show.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who love the unearthing of old relics of sports television were excited by the NFL Films’ reconstruction of Super Bowl I. Every play was found in the NFL Films archive and stitched together for Friday night’s presentation on NFL Network, which would have stood well on its own for a 90-minute broadcast, with added graphics, factoids and interviews spread out before, after or during breaks.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Under Attack on 2005 Gun Vote, Says He Will Support Bill Rolling It Back
abstract: As Hillary Clinton attacks Senator Bernie Sanders as being weak on gun control, he said he would support a bill that would remove some protections for gunmakers.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders announced on Saturday that he is supporting legislation to amend a 2005 law on gunmakers’ liability that he voted for and that Hillary Clinton has been using to attack him as weak on gun regulations.

headline: Drug Overdoses Propel Rise in Mortality Rates of Young Whites
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Youth', 'Heroin', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The rising death rates for young white adults, ages 25 to 34, make them the first generation since the Vietnam War years to experience higher death rates in early adulthood than the previous generation.
lead_paragraph: Drug overdoses are driving up the death rate of young white adults in the United States to levels not seen since the end of the AIDS epidemic more than two decades ago — a turn of fortune that stands in sharp contrast to falling death rates for young blacks, a New York Times analysis of death certificates has found.

headline: After Forward’s Strong Words Feed Rivalry, Grizzlies Earn Anticlimactic Win
abstract: Knicks Coach Derek Fisher and Grizzlies forward Matt Barnes have a history of bad blood, but the only fireworks Saturday were provided by Marc Gasol, who scored 37 points in Memphis’s win.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Matt Barnes approached the scorer’s table midway through the first quarter, and the crowd at FedEx Forum erupted. Barnes was simply checking into Saturday night’s game for the Memphis Grizzlies, but given his sordid history with the man standing no more than 15 feet away, in front of the opposing bench, it felt like so much more.

headline: Cardinals Survive, Ending Carson Palmer’s Drought
abstract: Arizona’s thrilling victory in an N.F.C. divisional game was the first in the postseason for Palmer.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Like his signature deep throws, quarterback Carson Palmer’s football résumé covers a lot of ground: two high school championships, one Heisman Trophy and five 4,000-yard passing seasons for three N.F.L. teams. But Palmer’s professional career had called to mind a long drive that peters out inside the red zone.

headline: Among the Captives Freed by Iran, a U.S. Researcher Held for 40 Days
abstract: Matthew Trevithick, in the country to study language, was detained in December, but his arrest wasn’t previously revealed and officials haven’t explained it.
lead_paragraph: A researcher from Massachusetts who was in Iran to study Farsi was allowed to leave the country after more than a month’s detention, his family and the State Department said on Saturday.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Turn Focus to South Carolina, Courting Black Leaders
abstract: As the polls in Iowa narrow and Mr. Sanders maintains a lead in New Hampshire, both candidates have shifted attention and resources to South Carolina, which has emerged as a crucial battleground should Mrs. Clinton lose the first two nominating contests.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Senator Bernie Sanders talked about the “seemingly endless stream of tragedies” in black communities from clashes with the police, while Hillary Clinton sought to closely align herself to President Obama, as the two Democratic candidates worked to woo black leaders ahead of this state’s Feb. 27 primary contest.

headline: American Missionary Among the Dead in Burkina Faso Siege
abstract: Michael James Riddering, who moved from Florida, worked at the Les Ailes de Refuge Orphanage, about 70 miles from Ouagadougou.
lead_paragraph: Qaeda militants killed one American in an attack on two hotels and a cafe in the capital of Burkina Faso that left at least 28 people dead and 56 injured on Friday and Saturday, the State Department said on Saturday night.

headline: Assailants Yell ‘ISIS! ISIS!’ During Attack on Man in Bronx, Police Say
abstract: A man wearing traditional South Asian clothing was punched and kicked by two men as he walked near a school in the Bronx, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man wearing traditional South Asian clothing was attacked by two men shouting “ISIS! ISIS!” as he walked near a school in the Bronx on Saturday night, the police said.

headline: She Plays Hillary Clinton as Bernie Sanders Prepares to Debate
abstract: Michaeleen Crowell, the chief of staff for Mr. Sanders’s Senate office, has studied Mrs. Clinton’s posture and policy positions.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — The debate moderator looked at the woman in a dark pantsuit standing beside Senator Bernie Sanders and said, “Secretary Clinton, we’ll give you one minute for an opening statement.”

headline: Indebted Chinese Companies Increase Pressures on Government
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: Despite a raft of stimulus measures, China’s economy is faltering as companies like shipbuilders increasingly lose business.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sainty Marine Corporation started small, buying and selling a few ships in the 1980s. But Sainty Marine, a Chinese state-owned company, went on a debt-fueled binge over the last few years, opening its own shipyards and signing orders worth hundreds of millions of dollars each.

headline: Suicide Attack Kills at Least 13 in Afghanistan
abstract: The attack on Sunday apparently targeted the father of two prominent officials in Nangarhar Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber struck the home of a tribal elder in the eastern Afghan city of Jalalabad Sunday morning, killing at least 13 people, an official said. It was the latest attack in the increasingly volatile Nangarhar Province.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest designs from Bottega Veneta.
lead_paragraph: The latest designs from Bottega Veneta.

headline: A Daughter Too Kind for Her Own Good
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: What we said was “be nice.” What she heard was “you don’t matter.”
lead_paragraph: “Mommy, I was kind to her like you told me to be and she was still rude,” my daughter told me from the back seat of the car. “She even laughed before walking away.”

headline: 1941: Relief Director Tells Plight of Jews in Europe
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The head of an American Jewish organization describes the miserable conditions as the Nazis swept across the Continent.
lead_paragraph: The miserable conditions of Jews in Nazi-dominated Europe were described yesterday by Morris C. Troper, chairman of the European executive council of the Joint Distribution Committee, an American Jewish organization engaged in relief for Jews throughout the world. Mr. Troper recently returned to the United States from Lisbon where he supervised European relief work. In an interview at the offices of the committee, 100 East Forty-second Street, Mr. Troper said that 1,500,000 Jews were absolutely destitute in Poland and many of them were living in walled-up ghettos which they were not allowed to leave even during the day.

headline: 1966: Nigerian Rebels Surrender
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Insurgents surrender to the new military leader after a bloody uprising in Nigeria in 1966.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS — The leader of Nigeria’s bloody weekend uprising today [Jan. 17] surrendered his forces to the West African republic’s new military ruler, Maj. Gen. Johnson Aguiyi Ironsi. The peaceful surrender appeared to end the threat of further violence in the country and consolidated Gen. Ironsi’s position as the new strongman of Nigeria. When dissident Nigerian Army leaders rebelled Saturday, the country’s civilian government handed over administration of the country to Gen. Ironsi.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from Salvatore Ferragamo.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from Salvatore Ferragamo.

headline: 3 Freed Americans Leave Iran; U.S. Places New Sanctions
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Political Prisoners', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The Obama administration announced the new measures less than 24 hours after lifting previous sanctions on Iran, which coincided with the country’s release of several Americans.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — With three Americans long held in Iran flying to Europe on Sunday, President Obama urged young Iranians to “pursue a new path” with the West as he imposed modest new sanctions on the country for banned missile tests.

headline: Calvin Klein Collection: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall 2016 designs from the Calvin Klein Collection.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 designs from the Calvin Klein Collection.

headline: In Milan, Ermenegildo Zegna and Ralph Lauren Zero In on the One Percent
abstract: The fall 2016 men’s collections included Bottega Veneta, Salvatore Ferragamo, Neil Barrett and Versace.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Horizontal is not the only direction for market expansion in the rag trade. Increasingly, designer ambitions are turning vertical. Considered in global terms, the population of the One Percent amounts to a nationality of its own, a new reality duly reflected in Stefano Pilati’s Ermenegildo Zegna collection for men, titled Ermenegildo Zegna Couture.

headline: For Italian Men, a Return to Elegance
abstract: The Berlusconi years were tough on men’s fashion in Italy. But now there seems to be a return to traditional sartorial values.
lead_paragraph: It was vulgarity and not elegance that ruled the day in Italy when Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi was simultaneously running the country and staging “bunga bunga” bacchanals. Mr. Berlusconi was hell on traditional Italian cultural values, his years in office a prolonged populist takedown of the high-minded intellectual and aesthetic achievements that defined Italian architecture, art, industrial design and, not least, its fashion for much of the 20th century.

headline: Theatergoers, Desperate to See ‘Hamilton,’ Fall Prey to Ticket Forgers
abstract: Counterfeit tickets are rare on Broadway, but they turn up almost daily at the blockbuster hip-hop musical.
lead_paragraph: Jason arranged to meet the seller on a Manhattan street corner on Dec. 31. He bought two tickets for $600 as an anniversary gift for his wife. You’re going to love the show, the seller told him. It’s as good as everyone says.

headline: Letters and Numbers: A Watch's Typeface
abstract: Brands know that well-chosen fonts can do much to convey the style of a timepiece.
lead_paragraph: Brands know that well-chosen fonts can do much to convey the style of a timepiece.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Slow cooker pork tacos, Mario Batali’s recipe for penne all’arrabbiata and more ideas for the chilly days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Missoni: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 designs from Missoni.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 designs from Missoni.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidates will hold their fourth debate in South Carolina on Sunday night. Here is how to follow it.
lead_paragraph: We provided real-time analysis of the fourth Democratic debate and live fact checks.

headline: Short Answers to Hard Questions About Zika Virus
abstract: Why scientists are worried about the growing epidemic and its effects on pregnant women, and how to avoid the infection.
lead_paragraph: Why scientists are worried about the growing epidemic and its effects on pregnant women, and how to avoid the infection.

headline: Details of 7 Iranians Granted Clemency in Prisoner Swap
abstract: None of the seven Iranians accused or convicted of violating American trade sanctions against Iran were charged with terrorism, President Obama noted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One was an aerospace expert convicted of helping Iran launch its first satellite into space. Another was a maritime engineer found guilty of providing navigation technology to the Iranians. And three men had ties to a company accused of illegally exporting millions of dollars in American technology with military applications to Iran.

headline: At the Ready as New Yorkers Got Unbundled
abstract: Across her decades as a Manhattan coat-check clerk, Nina Rochelle saw all sides of the city’s personality in the daily flurry of furs and suedes and fleeces. And she got the summers off.
lead_paragraph: “Not at all,” Nina Rochelle said, right off.

headline: In Milan, Men’s Shows Reference Couture — and Space Travel
abstract: Zegna’s fall/winter 2016 show explored “excessive embellishment,” while Donatella Versace focused her collection around pioneers of the future.
lead_paragraph: Zegna’s fall/winter 2016 show explored “excessive embellishment,” while Donatella Versace focused her collection around pioneers of the future.

headline: Netanyahu Asserts Israel Will Be Iran’s Watchdog
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'International Relations']
abstract: At a cabinet meeting, the Israeli prime minister said, “Israel’s policy has been and will remain exactly what it has been: not to allow Iran to acquire nuclear weapons.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel warned on Sunday that his nation would ensure that Tehran never obtains nuclear weapons, while also taking credit for keeping Iran from already having them.

headline: European Antitrust Chief Takes Swipe at Privacy Issue
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Margrethe Vestager’s warning shot comes ahead of a Jan. 31 deadline for Europe and the United States to reach a new data-sharing agreement.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust chief, warned on Sunday that the collection of a vast amount of users’ data by a small number of tech companies like Google and Facebook could be in violation of the region’s tough competition rules.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: Rashida Jones cuts up in “Angie Tribeca.” Damian Lewis and Paul Giamatti spar in “Billions.” And PBS unveils “Mercy Street,” the “Downton Abbey” heir apparent.
lead_paragraph: Rashida Jones cuts up in “Angie Tribeca,” the new cop farce from Steve and Nancy Carell. Damian Lewis and Paul Giamatti spar as a hedge-fund titan and his nemesis in “Billions.” And PBS unveils “Mercy Street,” the “Downton Abbey” heir apparent.

headline: Republican Candidates Assail Iran Agreements
abstract: News of the diplomatic thaw with Iran provided the Republican presidential candidates with more fodder to attack both President Obama and Hillary Clinton over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: News of the diplomatic thaw with Iran provided the Republican presidential candidates with more fodder to attack both President Obama and Hillary Clinton over the weekend on the campaign trail and on Sunday talk shows.

headline: Peggy Anderson, Chronicler of the Nursing Profession, Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. Anderson wrote the 1978 best seller “Nurse,” which was based on interviews with a nurse. It was adapted into a TV movie and a TV series.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Anderson, who never wanted to become a nurse, like her mother, but wrote a best-selling book to correct stereotypes about the profession, died on Sunday in Philadelphia. She was 77.

headline: ‘Ride Along 2’ Is No. 1 at Box Office
abstract: This film, starring Kevin Hart and Ice Cube, ended the monthlong run of “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” at the top spot.
lead_paragraph: Amid outrage over a lack of diversity among Oscar nominees, “Ride Along 2,” aimed squarely at black and Hispanic moviegoers, arrived to a robust $34 million in weekend ticket sales. Meanwhile, ticket sales for Michael Bay’s politically divisive “13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi” were on the soft side.

headline: State of Emergency Declared Over Man-Made Water Disaster in Michigan City
abstract: In response to the water crisis in Flint, Mich., President Obama authorized FEMA to provide water, filters and other supplies for residents whose water has been poisoned with lead.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has declared a state of emergency in response to the water crisis in Flint, Mich., where thousands of residents have been exposed to toxic amounts of lead.

headline: Verbatim: Debbie Wasserman Schultz Says Democratic Debate Schedule Was Intended to ‘Maximize’ Exposure to Voters
abstract: Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, responded on CNN to criticism from some in her party that the Democratic debate schedule, which has included weekend forums, gives an advantage to Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: — Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, responding on CNN to criticism from some in her party that the Democratic debate schedule, which has included weekend forums, gives an advantage to Hillary Clinton.

headline: Prada: Fall 2016
abstract: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from Prada.
lead_paragraph: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from Prada.

headline: Netflix’s Expansion Attracts Some Unexpected Customers
abstract: Reed Hastings, the video-streaming service’s co-founder, said people on Réunion Island — a small French-governed island off the coast of Madagascar — were some of the first to sign up as new subscribers.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Just hours after Reed Hastings announced this month that Netflix, the video-streaming service that he co-founded, would become available in 190 countries, he got an unexpected surprise.

headline: David Bowie Hits No. 1 on Billboard Chart with ‘Blackstar,’ a First
abstract: “Blackstar,” released just days before Mr. Bowie died, pushed Adele out of the Billboard top spot.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie’s death has brought the legendary rocker a trophy he never had in life: a No. 1 album on the American chart.

headline: As Track Atones, Some Athletes Seek More Than an Apology
abstract: Reallocating medals has become standard practice, but a more radical approach would be paying reparations to those who were cheated to make up for lost prize money and potential contracts.
lead_paragraph: There have been many doping scandals, too many, but if allegations about the demanding and extorting of bribes to cover up test results are true, track and field’s former leader Lamine Diack and his minions and relations took the category to a new level of low by corrupting from the top.

headline: Tracy Morgan to Star in Television Pilot for FX
abstract: The yet unnamed pilot that will be written by Jordan Peele and John Carcieri.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Morgan is returning to television. The actor, who suffered severe injuries in a car crash in 2014, will star in an unnamed pilot for FX. This half-hour comedy will be written by Jordan Peele (“Key & Peele”) and John Carcieri (“Eastbound & Down”).

headline: Damir Doma: Fall 2016
abstract: Damir Doma presents looks for Fall 2016.
lead_paragraph: Damir Doma presents looks for Fall 2016.

headline: Zika Warning Spotlights Latin America’s Fight Against Mosquito-Borne Diseases
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Mosquitoes', 'Medicine and Health', 'Travel Warnings', 'Guillain-Barre Syndrome', 'Olympic Games (2016)']
abstract: The C.D.C. advisory for pregnant women to avoid more than a dozen Latin American countries comes only a few months before the start of the Olympic Games in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the campaign against mosquitoes, Brazil has deployed soldiers to destroy habitats where the insects thrive. Colombia is releasing swarms of mosquitoes treated with bacteria that limit their capacity to spread disease. Mexico is testing the first vaccine against dengue fever, a mosquito-borne virus raging throughout the region.

headline: A Closer Look at Campaign Tax Promises
abstract: American presidential candidates often promise more than they can deliver. And, if elected, they may pay a price.
lead_paragraph: Two certainties, as Benjamin Franklin wrote, are death and taxes. Add a third: On taxes, American presidential candidates often promise more than they can deliver. And, if elected, they may pay a price.

headline: Panthers Build a Big First-Half Lead, Then Outlast the Seahawks
abstract: Seattle, trailing by 31-0, came charging out of halftime, but Carolina was still able to advance to the N.F.C. championship game for the first time in a decade.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As the Carolina Panthers ran roughshod over the N.F.L. this season, finishing a league-best 15-1, questions lingered. Sure, quarterback Cam Newton was performing like a most valuable player and the team’s defense was among the league’s best, but the Panthers also had one of the easiest schedules, and they barely escaped with wins against teams like the New Orleans Saints and the Giants, who had losing records.

headline: For Now, Self-Driving Cars Still Need Humans
abstract: Vehicles are increasingly able to do routine tasks, but the problem vexing the automobile industry is how to keep drivers ready to take over the wheel when necessary.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Car enthusiasts, after hearing industry executives discussing the self-driving technology being built into their vehicles, might be forgiven for thinking robotic cars will soon drive themselves out of auto showrooms.

headline: A Safer World, Thanks to the Iran Deal
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Although there are difficult challenges ahead, President Obama’s pursuit of diplomacy with Tehran over the nuclear threat has so far paid off.
lead_paragraph: This is a moment many thought would never come: Iran has delivered on its commitment under a 2015 agreement with the United States and other major powers to curb or eliminate the most dangerous elements of its nuclear program. The world is now safer for this.

headline: Education Technology Graduates From the Classroom to the Boardroom
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Venture Capital', 'Education', 'Start-ups', 'Mobile Applications', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Much of the money pouring into ed tech is going to start-ups focused on corporate training or professional skills, creating greater financing hurdles for companies that develop apps for school use.
lead_paragraph: Judging by the number of learning apps available to classrooms around the country, the education technology market aimed at elementary through high schools is booming.

headline: Die Hard Conservatives
abstract: When politicians think they’re action heroes.
lead_paragraph: Oh, my:

headline: Richard G. Hendrickson, Who Recorded the Weather for 85 Years, Dies at 103
abstract: Mr. Hendrickson took his first weather reading from the family farm in 1930 and only retired, reluctantly, last year.
lead_paragraph: Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night could stay Richard G. Hendrickson from the swift completion of his appointed rounds. For 85 years, they were his appointed rounds.

headline: Satellite Tracking Rising Seas Launches Successfully
abstract: The Jason-3 mission will use radar to determine the height of the sea as global temperatures increase and will help to predict hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: A satellite to measure the heights of the oceans was launched successfully on Sunday from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

headline: Review: In ‘Excavation Site: Martha Graham U.S.A.,’ a Bond Is Shared
abstract: This event, part of the Coil festival, was a fusion of history and theory as performers paid tribute to a luminary of modern dance.
lead_paragraph: To Michael Kliën, choreography is more than a dance on a stage, but something akin to an archaeological dig. In “Excavation Site: Martha Graham U.S.A.,” that Austrian choreographer, with the dramaturge Steve Valk, organized a one-time event as part of the Coil festival in which 24 dancers — all but one associated with the Martha Graham Dance Company — investigated their shared bond with that luminary of modern dance.

headline: Review: In ‘In Quietness,’ a High-Powered Wife Makes Sacrifices for Her Husband’s Religious Zeal
abstract: In Anna Moench’s play a woman gives up her job to accompany her husband to a seminary, where she must learn to be a docile homemaker.
lead_paragraph: In Anna Moench’s promising, frustrating “In Quietness,” produced by Dutch Kills at Walkerspace, a high-flying consultant leaves her job, her friends and her urban life to follow her husband to a seminary. At the outset of the play, Max (Kate MacCluggage) is burning up the frequent-flier miles and piling up the bonuses when she arrives home to find her husband, Paul (Blake DeLong), sitting in the dark. He confesses to an affair with a woman in his weekly Bible study group, relating that an accident has now left her in the hospital, unresponsive.

headline: ‘Horizon Events,’ Inspired by the Parameters of a PS1 Gallery
abstract: This evening of dance pieces, overseen by Rashaun Mitchell and Silas Riener, purported to explore collisions of abstraction and representation.
lead_paragraph: Because Rashaun Mitchell and Silas Riener are superlative dancers, a dancegoer wants them only to appear in work worthy of them, or in choreography that’s at least remotely important. In their most recent show — the premiere performances of “Horizon Events,” on Friday through Sunday at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens — they gave mere glimpses of what they and their five companion dancers can do.

headline: Review: With Two Star Lutenists, Boston Early Music Festival Comes to the Morgan
abstract: Paul O’Dette and Ronn McFarlane proved a seamless duo in a concert of Italian and English music from the 16th century.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Early Music Festival traveled light for its latest concert at the Morgan Library & Museum on Friday evening, The program, “For Two Lutes,” offered just two performers playing easily portable instruments: the stellar and widely recorded lutenists Paul O’Dette (an artistic director of the festival) and Ronn McFarlane.

headline: Patriots’ Winning Philosophy: Keep the Focus on Winning
abstract: After New England secured a fifth straight A.F.C. title game berth Saturday, Bill Belichick praised his players for staying committed. “It’s what we’re here for, is to win,” he said.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — After the Patriots’ 27-20 victory Saturday over the previously scorching Kansas City Chiefs, New England’s coach, Bill Belichick, was asked how he felt about sharing a piece of football history: The Patriots, like the Oakland Raiders from 1973 to 1977, were headed to their fifth consecutive A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Review: Rockapella Sings Nostalgic a Cappella at Feinstein’s/54 Below
abstract: This group, which achieved fame on the PBS series “Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego?,” performed loose-jointed, post-Motown styles infused with jazz.
lead_paragraph: What is it about a cappella pop groups that makes their spirit so playful? As Rockapella, an influential ensemble since the early 1990s, performed a sleek set of oldies at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Friday, the show became the musical equivalent of watching the members of a basketball team happily toss a ball around. Camaraderie and comedy go together; there’s something essentially lighthearted about human voices imitating instruments.

headline: Narrowing a Gap in the Sci-Fi Universe: One Fangirl Giving a Voice to Others
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Women and Girls', 'Science Fiction', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: Her Universe Press, targeting female fans of properties like “Dr. Who” and “Star Wars,” features science-fiction and fantasy novels written by women.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Eckstein, a self-described sci-fi fangirl, believes women like her are often overlooked. So several years ago she started a company to sell apparel featuring brands like Doctor Who, Star Trek and Star Wars to other fangirls. Now, believing those same women need a voice, she is expanding into publishing.

headline: Composers’ Collectives Offer Creativity and Challenges
abstract: Composers working in collaborative groups like Sleeping Giant find that coming together offers a chance to reflect on common ground and individual differences.
lead_paragraph: The cellist Ashley Bathgate took her bow at Le Poisson Rouge last Tuesday after the premiere of “Ash,” an evening-long work inspired by Bach’s six suites for solo cello. Then she squinted into the dimmed nightclub and made the usual hand motion of a performer beckoning the composer to share in the applause.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on North Korea’s Nuclear Testing
abstract: The latest nuclear test by North Korea earlier this month drew swift condemnation from the United Nations Security Council.
lead_paragraph: The latest nuclear test by North Korea earlier this month drew swift condemnation from the United Nations Security Council.

headline: Review: ‘19-2,’ a Police Drama on Acorn TV, Is a Slow Burn
abstract: This procedural set in Montreal centers on the uneasy relationship between reluctant partners and takes its time to develop.
lead_paragraph: To watch “19-2” is to be reminded that there is more than one way to pace a police drama. This Canadian series, which becomes available on the streaming service Acorn beginning Monday, is a slow burn, and its pacing isn’t the only thing that defies expectations.

headline: At Art Students League, Air Rights and Airing Grievances
abstract: A lawsuit is challenging the way decisions are made — including selling rights to a high-rise next door — at the nonprofit art school in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: One can only imagine the debates that have flared up through the decades at the Art Students League, a 140-year-old nonprofit school on West 57th Street that counts Winslow Homer, Norman Rockwell, Georgia O’Keeffe and Mark Rothko among its alumni.

headline: ‘Hail, Caesar!’ Explores the World of the Hollywood ‘Fixer’
abstract: Ethan and Joel Coen’s coming film is a fantastical take on Eddie Mannix, a studio “fixer” at M.G.M., whose job would be too big for any one person today.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The stories begin. The stories end. But the work of Eddie Mannix will never end.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Narrow Door,’ Paul Lisicky Opens a Window on Friendship
abstract: Mr. Lisicky’s memoir focuses on relationships with his ex-husband and the novelist Denise Gess.
lead_paragraph: Almost all of us have friends who don’t submit easily to categorization. They’re our life’s towering originals, the difficult ones who infuriate us and exhilarate us in equal measure. And if we met them in our late adolescence or early adulthood, forget it — their significance is almost indescribable. We were still jelly in those years. Quivering, impressionable. How on earth to convey their outsize influence, the overlarge hand they had in molding who we became?

headline: Moncler Gamme Bleu: Fall 2016
abstract: Moncler Gamme Bleu’s Fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Moncler Gamme Bleu’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Review: Cramming ‘War & Peace’ Into a Mini-Series
abstract: It’s a passable costume drama, but nothing in it captures why the book is considered to be one of the greatest novels ever written.
lead_paragraph: Interviewer: “I’ll be frank: You’re a bit older than most of the applicants. Start by telling me what qualifies you for the job of 21st-century TV scriptwriter.”

headline: Sublime Physical Performance
abstract: Kathy Wienberg makes a sublime New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Kathy Wienberg appears to be making her New York Times debut today, so let’s welcome her. One of the things I really liked about her puzzle is that even though I didn’t have to turn any real handsprings to solve it, it kept its theme secret from me until I got to the revealer at 49 Across. And when the penny finally dropped, I laughed out loud. That’s rare for a Monday puzzle.

headline: NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon
abstract: Scenes from this year’s festival.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from this year’s festival.

headline: At NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon, New Faces Make Their Mark at Grooving Places
abstract: The showcase has a history of offering glimpses of emerging musicians, and this year’s festival was no exception. Here are some of the promising artists who appeared.
lead_paragraph: NYC Winter Jazzfest began in 2005 as a showcase, a way for arts presenters and music bookers to scope out artists for their coming seasons. The festival has outgrown that strict purpose, becoming a summit and a smorgasbord, a consolidation of talent from every tier of prominence. The options this year included two nights of artists from the ECM Records roster, performing in the handsome new 800-seat Tishman Auditorium at the New School: a distinctly aboveground setting, and a powerful lure for anyone in search of proven quality.

headline: Hot Sets and Warm Chilly Nights at NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon
abstract: The festival offered a range of emerging talents as well as jazz veterans, and a new performance space: the Tishman Auditorium at the New School.
lead_paragraph: One of the breakout stars of this year’s NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon was a piano, or the combination of a piano and a room.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 18
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, which will be held Tuesday as the markets will be closed Monday for Martin Luther King’s Birthday. The regular four-week bill auction will be moved to Wednesday.

headline: Bernie Sanders Supporters Invoke Martin Luther King Jr.
abstract: Supporters of Mr. Sanders attended church with him and sought to present his stances on race and the economy as an extension of the views of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — On the eve of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, three black supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont sought to present his stances on race and the economy as the heir to the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: 3 Americans Are Missing in Baghdad, Embassy Says
abstract: The Americans’ disappearance raised fears that Westerners were again becoming targets for militias and criminal gangs that kidnap foreigners for money or political reasons.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The American Embassy is working with the Iraqi authorities to locate three American citizens who have gone missing in the capital, an embassy spokesman said late Sunday. Their disappearance raised fears that Westerners were once again becoming targets for the myriad militias and criminal gangs that are known to kidnap foreigners for money or for political reasons.

headline: Missing Man Back in China, Confessing to Fatal Crime
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Gui Minhai, co-owner of a Hong Kong publishing company that put out salacious works about mainland leaders, is accused in a fatal drunken-driving case from 2003.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong publisher last seen in October outside his condominium in Thailand surfaced Sunday on Chinese television, tearfully confessing to violating his probation in a fatal drunken-driving accident and saying that he had voluntarily returned to China to face justice.

headline: An Adman’s Big Pitch: His Life’s Work
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: George Lois, a Madison Avenue legend who may have inspired the Don Draper character on “Mad Men,” is giving a trove of his work to City College.
lead_paragraph: “I have a Hilfiger poster that Tommy’s begging for,” said George Lois, an influential Madison Avenue art director and the creative force behind scores of famous advertising campaigns.

headline: British Labour Leader Offers Compromise on Trident Program
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Jeremy Corbyn suggested that he might support the country’s Trident submarine fleet if it was sent on patrol without carrying nuclear warheads.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Stirring a divisive internal debate over defense, Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, suggested on Sunday that he might support the continued existence of the country’s Trident submarine fleet if it were sent on patrol without carrying nuclear warheads.

headline: Fourth Democratic Debate: Analysis
abstract: We provided real-time updates on the fourth Democratic debate, featuring Hillary Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley.

headline: Peyton Manning, the Broncos’ Flickering Star, Glows Just in Time
abstract: Manning had just enough to rally the Broncos to a fourth-quarter comeback and a spot in the A.F.C. title game against the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It was getting late Sunday, the winds were swirling, and Peyton Manning grabbed his helmet from the bench, lunged twice from side to side and crept closer to the sideline. The Denver Broncos trailed by a point, and they had two, maybe three possessions remaining.

headline: Covering War at Home Costs a Yemeni His Life
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'News and News Media', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Almigdad Mojalli, a Yemeni journalist covering the civil war in his country, was killed in airstrikes outside Sana while on assignment for Voice of America.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — For Almigdad Mojalli, a Yemeni journalist covering the civil war in his country, the trip early Sunday to the site of a deadly airstrike was another episode in what had long since become a painful routine.

headline: In Rural Alabama, a Longtime Mistrust of Medicine Fuels a Tuberculosis Outbreak
abstract: Marion, Ala., is in the throes of a tuberculosis outbreak so severe that it has posted an incidence rate that is about 100 times greater than the state’s and worse than many developing countries.
lead_paragraph: MARION, Ala. — When Patricia Church, a 41-year-old warehouse worker, felt sick recently, she suspected that she had a cold. But she also feared something more deadly that has been going around this small, impoverished city: tuberculosis.

headline: Ted Marchibroda, Who Led Colts and Ravens, Dies at 84
abstract: The N.F.L. coach turned around struggling Colts teams in Baltimore and in Indianapolis, then returned to Baltimore as the first head coach of the Ravens.
lead_paragraph: Ted Marchibroda, who coached the Baltimore Colts to three consecutive N.F.L. division championships in the 1970s and later installed a high-powered no-huddle offense that helped propel the Buffalo Bills to four straight Super Bowl games, died on Saturday in Weems, Va. He was 84.

headline: Justifiable Homicides, Taken Off the Books, Alter a Murder Tally
abstract: Each year, there are a handful of shootings that are not counted by the New York Police Department as crimes, although they may have led to fatalities.
lead_paragraph: It was just after 4 a.m. when an argument outside a hookah bar in Astoria, Queens, devolved into gunfire: Three shots were fired in the direction of Christopher King, a 23-year-old Long Island man in the city for a night out. The bullets missed him.

headline: Questions on Subsidies and Local Hiring Surround Syracuse Project
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The Inner Harbor project, in which a developer has received millions in public money, has started a debate about the obligations of builders to give residents meaningful aid.
lead_paragraph: The project known as Syracuse’s Inner Harbor looked like a feast for a starving city, the harbinger of the long-awaited turnaround of upstate New York: a $342 million constellation of hotels, upscale apartments and stores along a historic canal on a swath of disused land the city had been trying to transform for decades.

headline: In 2016 Race, Local Matters Give Way to National Tone
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'News and News Media', 'Ethanol', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: The regional business issues and parochial peeves that once shaped early primary contests are rapidly losing clout in this election season.
lead_paragraph: In Iowa, corn is no longer king. In Florida, subsidies for the state’s powerful sugar producers are under attack. And almost all of the Republicans left in the 2016 presidential race want to abolish the Export-Import Bank, which has provided billions to one of South Carolina’s largest employers, Boeing.

headline: Obama’s Goal to Wipe Out Malaria May Be a Dream Too Far
abstract: Under President Obama, the President’s Malaria Initiative has grown into a $618-million program that works in 19 African countries and in Southeast Asia. Yet the disease remains a top killer of children around the world.

lead_paragraph: Contrary to conventional wisdom, Super Bowl commercials featuring celebrities often fail to connect with viewers. They can be highly effective, however, when viewers see the celebrities as having an authentic connection with the brand. That is the creative strategy Mini USA will employ during CBS’s telecast of Super Bowl 50 on Feb. 7.

Two Royals players, Alcides Escobar and Alex Gordon, would hit home runs in Game 1. There would be a David Wright homer in Game 3, and Matt Harvey would dominate in Game 5, giving up just four hits and a walk in the first seven innings.

headline: My Take on the Democratic Presidential Debate
abstract: Here are my collected tweets as play-by-play commentary on the Clinton-Sanders presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders dueled tonight in the fourth Democratic debate, and here’s my play-by-play commentary. This isn’t in the form of a column, or even a formal blog post, but simply my collected tweets from live-tweeting. This is an experiment, a bit like my similar collection of tweets from the Republican presidential debate the other day. Conclusions at the end.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Cavaliers

headline: ‘Billions’ Recap, Season 1 Premiere: Money and Sin
abstract: It’s tempting to think of “Billions” as a natural companion to the Oscar nominee “The Big Short,” but it most resembles “The Revenant.”
lead_paragraph: With Oscar nominations announced this week, it’s tempting to think of Showtime’s “Billions” as a natural companion to “The Big Short,” Adam McKay’s Best Picture-nominated film about the financial shenanigans that cratered the economy in 2008. After all, this is a show about a United States Attorney attempting to prosecute just the sort of hedge fund giant who made a fortune exploiting a system that McKay exposes as fraudulent. Adding to that impression is the presence of Andrew Ross Sorkin, the founding editor of DealBook for The New York Times, who created the show with the longtime screenwriting partners Brian Koppelman and David Levien (“Rounders,” “Ocean’s Thirteen”) and who brings a level of Wall Street credibility.

headline: Williams Lures Focus From Match-Fixing Report

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Monday was opening day at the Australian Open, and with Serena Williams already on court for her first official match in four months, tennis leaders filed into the tournament’s main interview room and tried to allay fears that the game has a major match-fixing problem.

headline: Charges Against Chinese Rights Lawyers Draw Foreign Criticism
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession', 'Detainees', 'Missing Persons']
abstract: In a letter, the presidents of foreign bar associations and lawyers call the subversion charges part of an “unprecedented crackdown” on Chinese rights defenders.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The recent arrests of Chinese lawyers and their associates on subversion charges drew sharp condemnation from presidents of foreign bar associations, prominent lawyers and former judges in a letter issued on Monday. They said the charges were part of an “unprecedented crackdown” on Chinese advocates who take up contentious human rights cases.

headline: Who Won the Democratic Debate? Viewers Lean Toward Bernie Sanders
abstract: Many commentators thought that a more aggressive Mr. Sanders gave himself a boost by taking Hillary Clinton on more forcefully.
lead_paragraph: The final Democratic presidential debate before the first states begin voting was marked by heated exchanges between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders on Wall Street regulation, guns and who would best preserve the legacy of President Obama. Many commentators from across the web thought that a more aggressive Mr. Sanders gave himself a boost by taking Mrs. Clinton on more forcefully. She scored points on his shifting positions on guns and taxes, but was not seen as dealing any decisive blows. Martin O’Malley, meanwhile, was most notable for his unsuccessful efforts to get a word in.

headline: Health Reform Realities
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare']
abstract: Should progressives re-litigate Obamacare? There are many reasons to think that it just wouldn’t work.
lead_paragraph: Health reform is the signature achievement of the Obama presidency. It was the biggest expansion of the social safety net since Medicare was established in the 1960s. It more or less achieves a goal — access to health insurance for all Americans — that progressives have been trying to reach for three generations. And it is already producing dramatic results, with the percentage of uninsured Americans falling to record lows.

headline: Shine a Light on Secret Real Estate Deals
abstract: The Treasury Department’s crackdown on shell companies is one step in addressing a big hole in financial regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department announced last week that it would start demanding the identities of the people behind the shell companies that rich foreigners use to buy real estate in Manhattan and Miami-Dade County. This is a good step that should help law enforcement agencies crack down on money laundering, tax evasion and other crimes. But the program should be broadened to cover the whole country, and it must be forcefully carried out.

headline: The Gospel According to Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Religion and Belief', 'Discrimination', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Protestant Churches', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: To him, if you’re not a mainline Protestant, you’re exotic, even sinister.
lead_paragraph: IT is no secret that Donald J. Trump’s ruinous rise in the Republican presidential primaries has been powered, in large part, by a naked agenda of religious division and fear-mongering — an agenda that will likely inform his speech today at Liberty University, a conservative Christian college in Lynchburg, Va.

headline: Stop China’s Market Manipulations
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: To protect the global economy, Washington needs to send Beijing a clear message.
lead_paragraph: Washington — THE other day while I was crossing the street in Beijing, a car almost flattened me. Both the driver and I were outraged at the other’s ineptitude. In China, if you want to avoid being hit, you keep your head down and avoid eye contact with the oncoming driver, since looking at him would signal that you saw the car and know you should let it pass. In the United States, the opposite rule applies: Making eye contact confirms that the driver has seen you and should yield to the vulnerable pedestrian.

headline: Celebrating Martin Luther King Day
abstract: Although we have many resources in our ever-growing M.L.K. Day collection, this year we want to highlight one in particular, an essay that appeared in The New York Times Magazine in September.
lead_paragraph: Like most schools across the United States, we’re off today in observance of the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A new edition of What’s Going On in This Picture? will be available early next Monday.

abstract: Emmanuel Levinas, a philosopher who survived Nazism, can help shed light on our moral obligation to refugees and others in need.

headline: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
keywords: ['Rural Areas', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Logging Industry']
abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — One of the largest wood mills in the West once belched its steam on the edge of town, sawing ponderosa pine. Out in the woods, tree fallers like Tex Ward were proud and prosperous.

abstract: A parliamentary committee considered a petition to bar Donald Trump from entering the United Kingdom because some say he has violated the country’s laws on hate speech.

headline: Animals Die in Large Numbers, and Researchers Scratch Their Heads
keywords: ['Birds', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Global Warming', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Viruses', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: Seabirds called murres are dying in Alaska, probably because of warming water. Some scientists fear that animal ‘die-offs’ are happening more often.

headline: Stabbing of Israeli Woman in West Bank Suggests Shift in Violence
abstract: A pregnant woman was attacked a day after an Israeli woman was fatally stabbed at the entrance to her home in another settlement.
lead_paragraph: TEKOA, West Bank — In a charity store packed with used clothing on the edge of Tekoa, a Jewish settlement in the beige hills of the southern West Bank, Michal Froman, 30 and pregnant, was shopping on Monday when a Palestinian teenager walked in.

headline: In Libya, U.S. Courts Unreliable Allies to Counter ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: To stop the advance of the Islamic State’s potent Libyan branch, the United States and its allies have sought potential ground forces in a patchwork of militias.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The American Special Operations forces expected a warm welcome when they landed at the Libyan air base where an allied militia was stationed. Instead, armed men from another militia at the base threatened to detain the commandos, forcing the Americans to evacuate.

headline: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Sustainable Living', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.
lead_paragraph: The waterfront district of Hammarby Sjostad, on the southern edge of Stockholm, has been heralded as a model of sustainable urban development, a place where one can already glimpse the future of city living. And the area’s growth, coupled with the steadily rising popularity of the island of Sodermalm to its immediate north, is pulling the inhabitable boundaries — if not the heart — of Stockholm southward.

headline: What to Do in Elena Ferrante’s Naples
abstract: We recently published an article about using the Neapolitan novels of Elena Ferrante as guidebooks to Naples. Here are some tips on how to navigate her city.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published an article about using the Neapolitan novels of Elena Ferrante as guidebooks to Naples. “As I discovered during a visit in September,” Ann Mah wrote, “the series of books offered a unique view of this complicated city, leading me away from popular tourist sites and helping to explain the city’s social, economic and geographic divisions. To view the Naples of Ms. Ferrante is to view Naples like a native.”

headline: The Living Dead
abstract: By studying the microscopic bacteria that bloom on our bodies after we die, scientists hope to unlock surprising mysteries of the departed.
lead_paragraph: The bright aseptic room smelled of Pine-Sol and bleach and overripe Camembert. A white-bearded man lay on a stainless-steel examination table, his face angled toward the skylight and the cold, cloudless morning. An investigator read from his clipboard: 61-year-old white male discharged from a Detroit hospital last night was found at home, shirtless, in a wheelchair, a .38-caliber handgun in his right hand. On his chest was a burn that appeared to be an exact match of the gun’s barrel. Carl Schmidt, the medical examiner, wiped the contact wound with a wet sponge.

headline: Blessed Are the Comedians
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Writing and Writers', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: The Egyptian author Ali Salem used humor — and all of its contradictions — to inspire peace in his country. Can other writers do the same?
lead_paragraph: For Middle East watchers, who are accustomed to reports of shootings and explosions, learning about a banned or suppressed book might be the closest thing to receiving good news. Suppression of a book, after all, is a perverse acknowledgment that literature holds the power to subvert the status quo — and without a single shot fired. If books that imagine peace are still able to put fear in the hearts of warmongers, isn’t it a sign that there’s some hope for us?

headline: Even Talking About Reducing Drug Prices Can Reduce Drug Prices
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A study finds that pharmaceutical companies have cut drug prices in response to political pressure.
lead_paragraph: Both Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton are pushing for lower prescription drug prices as part of their campaigns. Debates about whether and how to reduce drug prices aren’t new. But they rarely lead to legislative success.

headline: Barclays Completes Sale of Controlling Interest in Trust Business
abstract: The move signals the latest effort by the British bank to get out of underperforming areas and to focus on what it considers its core operations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British bank Barclays has completed the sale of a controlling stake in its trust business to an independent investor group led by the Nielsen and Sarikhani families for an undisclosed amount.

headline: As Freed Americans Rejoin Relatives, Mystery Surrounds One Who Stayed Put
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The reunions came as Iran remained silent about the prisoner deal, and as a mystery deepened about a freed American who chose to stay in Iran.

headline: Health Reform Is Hard
abstract: Why Sanders needed smoke and mirrors.
lead_paragraph: My column and Bernie Sanders’ plan crossed in the mail. But the Sanders plan in a way reinforces my point that calls for single-payer in America at this point are basically a distraction. Again, I say this as someone who favors single-payer — but it’s just not going to happen anytime soon.

headline: China Largely Shrugs at Shake-Up After Taiwan Elections
abstract: Tsai Ing-wen’s victory was met in China with sparse and largely critical comment, with many online commenters lashing out at the losing Kuomintang.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The election of Tsai Ing-wen as president of Taiwan was met in China on Monday with sparse and largely critical comment, suggesting both a lack of interest toward a candidate whose party’s  nativist leanings many ordinary Chinese do not understand and censorship in the news media and online forums about an outcome that the Communist Party had not wished to see.

headline: 1941: Typhus Vaccine Goes to Europe
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A typhus vaccine is brought by the surgeon general of the United States to Europe in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, sailed for Lisbon yesterday aboard the American Export liner Excalibur with 10,000 doses of a new typhus fever vaccine developed by the Health Service as this country’s contribution toward fighting the great post-war disease, which took 1,000,000 lives in eastern Europe after the last war. The vaccine will be left with the American Consul in Lisbon, and any nations wanting some can procure it through their ministers of public health. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 19, 1941

headline: Desperate for Slumber in Delhi, Homeless Encounter a ‘Sleep Mafia’
abstract: A sprawling gray market has taken shape around Delhi’s vast unmet need for shelter, with private operators controlling who sleeps where and for how long.
lead_paragraph: DELHI, India — When midnight approaches in Old Delhi and a thick, freezing fog settles over the city, the quilt-wallah Farukh Khan sits on his corner, watching the market for his services come to life.

headline: China Charges Dozen Officials Over Deadly Shenzhen Landslide
abstract: The prosecutor’s announcement was the first time that any officials have been charged in the disaster on Dec. 20 that killed at least 69 people.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have charged a dozen government officials over the deadly collapse of a mountain of construction debris in the southern city of Shenzhen last month, the state-run news agency, Xinhua, reported on Monday.

headline: Bird Brains: Smarter Than We Thought
abstract: Understanding how young zebra finches acquire their courtship songs may shed light on how all brains learn.

headline: Desert Rats Finding Meals Less Palatable
abstract: As the climate warms, wood rats in the Mojave Desert are less able to tolerate toxins in the creosote bushes they rely on for food, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Climate change may affect wood rats in the Mojave Desert in a most unusual way. A new study finds that warmer weather reduces their ability to tolerate toxins in the creosote bush, which they rely on for sustenance.

headline: 1966: Untouchables Back Gandhi
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Untouchables back Indira Gandhi in India in 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Mrs. Indira Gandhi today [Jan. 18] won the support of 80 Congress party members representing India’s untouchables in her bid to become India’s first woman prime minister. The result was a heavy blow to her chief opponent, Morarji Desai, former finance minister. He had been counting heavily on the support of the untouchables. Their support gave Mrs. Gandhi, 48, an apparently overwhelming lead in tomorrow’s election. Technically it is for leader of the Congress party, but since the party controls Parliament, its leader automatically becomes prime minister. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 19, 1966

At Ermenegildo Zegna, vests came in dizzying graphic prints, while at Salvatore Ferragamo, sweaters took on a more kaleidescopic effect. And, true to form, Missoni offered stripes that zigged and zagged every which way. In all, they made an especially convincing case for adventurous dressing next fall.

headline: Noah Rubin Upsets Benoît Paire for First Win at a Major Event
abstract: Rubin, a 19-year-old from Long Island, defeated the 17th-seeded Paire, a Frenchman, by 7-6 (4), 7-6 (6), 7-6 (5) at the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Noah Rubin said Monday was just “another day at the office.” A bit of an understatement, considering he essentially received a promotion and a raise at what was already his dream job.

headline: Two Fresh Recipes From Obicà’s New Angeleno Outpost
abstract: The Flatiron restaurant’s sister location in Santa Monica, which opened last week, shares how to make its branzino and tuna tartare.
lead_paragraph: With the opening this month of Obicà Mozzarella Bar Pizza e Cucina’s newest Los Angeles outpost, Santa Monica cheese enthusiasts can enjoy Italian mozzarella with an unprecedented level of freshness. Like its sister restaurant in New York City’s Flatiron district, which opened in 2014, the restaurant receives Mozzarella di Bufala deliveries twice a week from the practiced cheesemakers of Campania, Italy — an unusually frequent delivery schedule among restaurants in both cities. While the two menus share some dishes, the Santa Monica iteration capitalizes on the diverse agriculture and aquaculture of Southern California. Sensitive to L.A.’s appetite for more holistic dining options, native avocados and citrus lighten up the heavier dishes of the Italian kitchen canon.

headline: Review: ‘Planet Primetime’ Goes Worldwide, Investigating TV’s Wilder Side
abstract: Karla Cavalli, host of this new series on the Travel Channel, ventures to Japan for a pantyhose tug of war and to Mexico for body-slamming.
lead_paragraph: It may not be the most sophisticated sociology, but “Planet Primetime,” a new show on the Travel Channel, at least raises the energy level in what can be a sleepy genre. The series, which begins on Tuesday night with two episodes, looks at various countries through the filter of some of their most popular television shows, with Karla Cavalli as effervescent host and occasional guinea pig.

headline: Video: SpaceX Rocket Landing Ends in Explosion
abstract: The latest attempt by Elon Musk’s company to recover one of its rockets after a launch failed in a ball of fire on Sunday.

headline: Boy’s Response to Blasphemy Charge Unnerves Many in Pakistan
abstract: An imam was charged with inciting emotions to such a point that a 15-year-old who had misunderstood a question about the Prophet Muhammad cut off his own hand.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Late one night, the imam Shabir Ahmad looked up from prayers at his mosque to see a 15-year-old boy approaching with a plate in his outstretched left hand. On it was the boy’s freshly severed right hand.

headline: Review: In Vladimir Sorokin’s ‘The Blizzard,’ a Doctor’s Long and Strange Trip
abstract: A Russian doctor’s mission to deliver a much-needed vaccine in a snowstorm is plagued by dangers and temptations.
lead_paragraph: With his latest novel, “The Blizzard,” Vladimir Sorokin has written a small, strange story that has little to do with his current reputation as a Russian literary bad boy and everything to do with riffing on Russia’s fabled literary past. “The Blizzard” begins as a kind of Chekhovian tale about a doctor setting off in a snowstorm on a medical mission to a village. It soon evolves into a phantasmagorical allegory sprinkled with surrealistic scenes that recall Gogol’s “The Nose” and Bulgakov’s “The Master and Margarita.”

headline: Review: Europa Galante Tells the Story of a Musical Orphan in ‘Chiara’s Diary’
abstract: The ensemble’s concert at Zankel Hall included works by Vivaldi and Martinelli dedicated to Chiara, a virtuoso educated at the Ospedale Della Pietà, a Venetian orphanage, in the 1700s.
lead_paragraph: Vivaldi fanciers may know of the Ospedale Della Pietà, the orphanage in Venice where that composer spent much of his career, teaching music to young women. But for most music lovers, the Pietà undoubtedly remains an abstraction.

headline: Review: ‘Puffs’ Parodies Harry Potter’s World
abstract: This Matt Cox play is a romp through what its subtitle describes as “Seven Increasingly Eventful Years at a Certain School of Magic and Magic."
lead_paragraph: The wizards in training don’t dare speak the evil one’s name, but the script calls him Mister Voldy. That’s a fair gauge of the teasing affection on display in “Puffs,” Matt Cox’s spirited parody of the Harry Potter universe at the Peoples Improv Theater.

headline: Navy Releases Timeline of Iran’s Capture of U.S. Sailors
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The timeline offered few new details and left many questions unanswered, such as why the two boats deviated from their course and strayed into Iran’s territorial waters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to defuse the controversy over the brief capture of 10 Navy sailors last week, the Defense Department on Monday released a timeline of events surrounding the seizure, but the account was spare on new details and left several fundamental questions unanswered.

headline: Viewership for Democratic Debate Increased to More Than 10 Million, NBC Says
abstract: More than 10 million viewers tuned in to watch the Democratic presidential debate on Sunday night, a big jump over the party’s two most recent debates.
lead_paragraph: The increasingly close race between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders is capturing the attention of the American electorate, according to NBC, which said that more than 10 million viewers tuned in to watch the Democratic presidential debate on Sunday night.

headline: Review: ‘69 positions’ Explores the Sexual Politics in Performance
abstract: The choreographer Mette Ingvartsen led this ambitious, audacious lecture-performance of sex as a social rather than a private phenomenon, at MoMA PS1.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through “69 positions,” at MoMA PS1 on Friday, the choreographer Mette Ingvartsen, naked except for socks and sneakers, addressed her audience with a personal question: “Would anyone be interested in having a multiple collective orgasm?”

headline: A Polish E.U. Leader Seeks Middle Ground in a Dispute With Poland
abstract: Donald Tusk, a former Polish prime minister and the current European Council president, suggested that the union may have been too quick to investigate moves by Poland’s new government.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As president of the European Council — the group representing the European Union’s often-clashing 28 leaders — Donald Tusk is forever promoting a balance between national sovereignty on one hand and common values and goals on the other. On Monday, his challenge was especially personal.

headline: François Hollande Aims 2 Billion Euro Plan at France’s Economic ‘Emergency’
abstract: The president’s measure to address persistent joblessness and stagnation was immediately seized on by critics as having more political than economic meaning.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Declaring the French economy to be in a “state of emergency,” President François Hollande announced on Monday a 2 billion euro plan to subsidize job creation and temporarily move half a million unemployed people off the welfare rolls, as record unemployment threatens his bid for re-election next year.

lead_paragraph: Brioni’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Returns to Help Knicks Ward Off 76ers
abstract: Anthony, who had missed two games with a sprained right ankle, scored 19 points for the Knicks, including a tying 3-pointer with 3.4 seconds left in regulation.
lead_paragraph: After having missed the Knicks’ previous two games with a sprained right ankle, Carmelo Anthony went to the bench late in the third quarter on Monday afternoon. The Knicks had a comfortable lead over the Philadelphia 76ers, and Anthony thought — or at least hoped — that his workday was done.

headline: Maldives to Let Jailed Ex-President Go to Britain for Surgery
abstract: The former president, Muhammad Nasheed, who is serving a 13-year sentence that drew international scorn, needs treatment for back pain.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The authorities in the Maldives on Monday allowed the opposition leader and former president Muhammad Nasheed, who has been in prison for 11 months, to travel to Britain for an operation.

headline: Online Booking Makes Hotel Loyalty Harder to Keep
abstract: The same technology that makes booking a room easy also makes it easier for guests to shop around among hotels based on price or location.

headline: Review: ‘Let Me Tell You’ Has Its New York Premiere
abstract: Franz Welser-Möst led the Cleveland Orchestra in Hans Abrahamsen’s work, and the soprano Barbara Hannigan performed, at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that a performance of a challenging new piece receives the kind of ovation typically awarded star virtuosi. But that’s what happened on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall when the conductor Franz Welser-Möst led the Cleveland Orchestra in the New York premiere of the Danish composer Hans Abrahamsen’s “let me tell you.” This eerily alluring 30-minute work for soprano and orchestra was written for the remarkable Barbara Hannigan, who performed it stunningly.

headline: Wealth Inequality Rising Fast, Oxfam Says, Faulting Tax Havens
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Tax Evasion', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: Just 62 people own as much wealth as the 3.5 billion people in the bottom half of the world’s income scale, Oxfam reported. Five years ago, it took 388 billionaires to reach that mark.
lead_paragraph: Just 62 people own as much wealth as the 3.5 billion people in the bottom half of the world’s income scale, the charity Oxfam reported on Monday in its annual study of inequality, which found that the gap between rich and poor has continued to widen at an alarming rate. As recently as five years ago, the fortunes of 388 billionaires were needed to reach that halfway mark.

headline: In Argentina, Rancher’s Discovery Leads to Largest Titanosaur
abstract: A cast of the creature is now at the American Museum of Natural History. Experts hope the fossil discovery will yield new insights.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a rancher in the Patagonia region of Argentina came upon an old bone sticking out of his desert property near La Flecha.

headline: Seeking Ranchland in Texas, Where Wealth Is Measured in Acres
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ranches', 'Private Equity']
abstract: As the price of oil has declined, one investor is betting that the price of land will, too. So he is raising a $100 million private equity fund to buy Texas ranches.
lead_paragraph: Jay Ellis, an investment fund founder, may be the only person in Texas who is giddy about collapsing oil prices.

headline: National Book Critics Circle Announces Award Nominees
abstract: Ta-Nehisi Coates, Elizabeth Alexander and Colm Tóibín were among those nominated for the awards, which are to be announced on March 17.
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates, already a National Book Award winner for “Between the World and Me,” now has a chance to add a National Book Critics Circle Award for criticism to his mantel. Mr. Coates’s book, a meditation on racism in America written in the form of a letter to his son, joins works by the novelist Lauren Groff, the memoirist and critic Vivian Gornick and the poet Ada Limón among those nominated for the awards.

headline: Partisanship Barges In on John Lewis’s Dream
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: In a speech 52 years ago, the African-American congressman from Georgia wanted political parties of principle, but results have been mixed.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In 1963, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had a dream that, to the joy of millions of African-Americans, Barack Obama redeemed by winning the presidency.

headline: Globalfest Showcases the Sounds and Traditions of World Music
abstract: The show at Webster Hall on Sunday featured 12 overlapping sets that included a variety of music, much of it affirming a heritage or giving it a personal twist.
lead_paragraph: Roots were tangled, elastic and portable at this year’s Globalfest, the annual showcase for world music that started in 2003. With 12 overlapping sets on Sunday night at Webster Hall, Globalfest included dance music, protest songs, tradition, fusion, electronics, shtick, spirituality, camp and the blues. Some of the musicians were self-conscious emissaries from their homes; others were expatriates and widely traveled citizens of a connected world. Through the years, Globalfest has demolished the stereotype of world music performers as naifs playing the only music they know. Instead, it presents tradition as a choice and a resource, affirming a heritage or giving it a personal twist.

headline: Qaeda Rampage in Burkina Faso Shakes Service Employees

lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — As a receptionist at the grand Laico Hotel on the edge of downtown here, Zacharia Bagagnan, an uneducated 39-year-old, has a job his friends envy.

lead_paragraph: Palo Alto, Calif. — THE dramatic events of this past weekend mark a potential turning point in the modern history of the Middle East. Estranged for the last three and a half decades, the American and Iranian governments are talking and working with each other once again.

lead_paragraph: New York City may soon be one step closer to building a new flood protection system around Lower Manhattan to guard against another storm like Hurricane Sandy.

lead_paragraph: GENESEO, N.Y. — A former student at a state university in western New York fatally stabbed two current students, one of whom was his ex-girlfriend, early Sunday morning and then killed himself, law enforcement officials said on Monday.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two of Lebanon’s most prominent Christian politicians — one a crucial political ally of Hezbollah, the other its longtime foe — struck a surprise agreement on Monday that could help end the standoff that has left the country without a president for nearly two years.

He was inside Gucci’s show space in a repurposed railway switching station near this city’s perimeter, and he was referring to the mobs clamoring all over the city for the new social media stars.
