headline: Puerto Rico Revises Plan to Reduce Debt as Optimism Dwindles
abstract: The island’s top economic officials said they had to alter their economic strategy when they saw that tax revenues were running about $500 million lower than forecast.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Four months after announcing a grueling five-year plan for reducing the island’s vast debt and reviving economic growth, Puerto Rico’s top economic officials said on Monday that they had been too optimistic and revised the plan for the worse.

abstract: The researcher, Matthew Trevithick, is decompressing in Massachusetts after being held for 40 days, his family said, and is not ready to speak publicly about his ordeal.
lead_paragraph: HINGHAM, Mass. — The mother and stepfather of Matthew Trevithick, the American researcher who was held for 40 days in Iran before he was freed over the weekend, said Monday that Mr. Trevithick was decompressing after returning to Massachusetts on Sunday night.

headline: Dispute Over Opposition’s Seat at Table Threatens to Push Back Syria Peace Talks
abstract: The new disagreement revolves around the lingering question of who gets to represent the opposition delegation.

headline: Fairfield Ponders a Future Without General Electric
abstract: The company, which moved its headquarters to Fairfield in 1974, is departing for Boston, leaving Connecticut residents worried about the loss of tax revenue and high-paying jobs.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — As word spread last week that General Electric was moving its headquarters and some of its employees to Boston, residents of this coastal town were just beginning to absorb what it will mean for their community to lose one of the country’s largest corporations.

headline: The Knicks’ Kristaps Porzingis Is a Precious Import. Handle With Care.
abstract: As the Knicks try to balance Porzingis’s health and their long-shot playoff bid, they should realize that prudence is the best course of action.
lead_paragraph: While the Knicks narrowly avoided what would have been a most deflating defeat, there was still an inescapable lesson for them to draw from a 119-113 double-overtime victory over the lowly-yet-feisty Philadelphia 76ers on Monday at Madison Square Garden.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama flew to Boise, Idaho, for a speech last winter, he met privately with the wife of an Iranian-American pastor held prisoner in Iran since 2012. Freeing her husband, he promised, was one of his top priorities.

headline: Glenn Frey, Singer-Songwriter and Eagles Founding Member, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Frey teamed up with Don Henley in founding the Eagles, whose melodic, country-tinged rock was enormously popular in the 1970s, selling more records than any other band then.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Frey, the guitarist, singer and songwriter who co-founded the Eagles, whose country-tinged, melodic rock tunes, wistful love ballads, philosophical anthems, observations of the outlaw life and testaments to the wages of decadence made it perhaps the leading American band of the 1970s, died on Monday in New York City. He was 67.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Set for a Long Slog Against Bernie Sanders

lead_paragraph: Facing a tougher than expected challenge from Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Hillary Clinton’s campaign is preparing for a primary fight that could stretch into late April or early May and require a sprawling field operation in states and territories from Pennsylvania to Guam.

headline: China G.D.P. Growth at Slowest Pace Since 2009, Data Shows
abstract: The economy grew at a 6.8 percent pace in the fourth quarter, official data released Tuesday showed — the slowest expansion since March 2009.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s growth slowed further last year, adding to the troubling economic picture that is unsettling investors around the world.

headline: A Woman’s Mission: Teaching Her Children to Stay ‘Full of Hope’
abstract: Despite health problems and water damage to her Brooklyn apartment, Lakima Lewis draws wisdom from the Bible and seeks to instill optimism in her children.
lead_paragraph: In the apartment she shares with her children, Lakima Lewis likes to leave notes. They are written on sheets of ruled notebook paper in big looping handwriting, offering messages of wisdom and hope, drawn from hours spent poring over the Bible.

headline: Macedonia: Elections Scheduled, but Opposition Threatens Boycott
abstract: Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski submitted his resignation on Friday as part of an agreement forged by Johannes Hahn.
lead_paragraph: Macedonia’s governing coalition is moving forward with a European Union-brokered plan for elections in April even though the opposition has threatened to boycott the vote, which would be run by a caretaker government. Johannes Hahn, the European Union commissioner who took the leading role in the negotiations for ending the political crisis in the Balkan country, said he would have preferred a consensual solution regarding the date of the elections. Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski submitted his resignation on Friday as part of an agreement forged by Mr. Hahn. That agreement sought to end a political crisis that erupted last February over a wiretapping scandal.

headline: Alabama: More Test Positive for Tuberculosis
abstract: The scale of a tuberculosis outbreak in rural Perry County widened Monday when state officials said that 47 residents last week tested positive for the bacterial infection.
lead_paragraph: The scale of a tuberculosis outbreak in rural Perry County widened Monday when state officials said that 47 residents last week tested positive for the bacterial infection. Those people, who are suspected of having an asymptomatic infection, will receive additional health care services as the authorities try to stop an outbreak that has now sickened or infected 73 people in and near Perry County since January 2014. In Perry County, which has fewer than 10,000 residents, three people have died. State officials previously said that the outbreak, which has mostly affected African-Americans, was concentrated in the county seat of Marion, and that Marion’s tuberculosis incidence rate was worse than those recorded in many developing countries.

headline: Morocco: Belgian Linked to Leader of the Paris Attacks Is Arrested
abstract: The man, whom Belgian and Moroccan news sources identified as Gelel Attar, is of Belgian and Moroccan background, as were most of those who participated in the attacks.
lead_paragraph: Moroccan officials announced Monday that they had detained a Belgian man thought to be a close friend of one of the leaders of the attacks in Paris on Nov. 13. The man, whom Belgian and Moroccan news sources identified as Gelel Attar, is of Belgian and Moroccan background, as were most of those who participated in the attacks. Mr. Attar was sentenced in absentia at a trial last summer in Belgium to five years in prison for involvement in a terrorist network. Two of the Paris attackers were also sentenced in absentia in that trial: Abdelhamid Abaaoud, who helped organize the attacks, and Chakib Akrouh, one of the attackers.

headline: George Jonas, Whose Book Was the Basis of the Film ‘Munich,’ Dies at 80

lead_paragraph: George Jonas, a prominent Canadian newspaper columnist whose controversial book about Israeli counterterrorists was the basis of the 2005 film “Munich,” directed by Steven Spielberg, died on Jan. 10 in Toronto. He was 80.

headline: Greenland’s Endless (for Now) Landscape
abstract: The seemingly endless and frozen landscapes around Greenland’s indigenous villages are vanishing and with them, a way of life.
lead_paragraph: Greenland is frequently in the news these days, its melting icebergs and receding sea ice a bellwether for climate change. But when the Finnish photographer Tiina Itkonen first visited the massive Arctic island in 1995, no one spoke of such things. Instead, she was fascinated by the indigenous Inuit and Inughuit cultures, and the impossible hues of an endless landscape. She was so intoxicated by the colors that she gave up shooting in black-and-white.

headline: Fueling Homophobia in Russia
abstract: A new bill would further stigmatize and denigrate gay people.
lead_paragraph: A vaguely written “gay propaganda” law passed in 2013 created a toxic environment for gay men and lesbians in Russia. Now, some lawmakers want to further denigrate and stigmatize gay people. A new bill scheduled for debate on Friday in the lower house of Parliament would allow the authorities to impose fines and even jail time for public displays of affection between people of the same sex.

headline: Protect Female Farmworkers
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Immigrants working in the fields endure a nightmare of sexual violence, and it’s rare for their attackers to be prosecuted.
lead_paragraph: Oakland, Calif. — ACROSS the country, some 400,000 women, mostly immigrants, work in agriculture, toiling in fields, nurseries and packing plants. Such work is backbreaking and low-paying. But for many of these women, it is also a nightmare of sexual violence.

headline: You Are Stronger Than You (and Your Therapist) Think
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: The goal of treatment is to show you this — not to make you feel more secure or comforted.
lead_paragraph: I’m a psychiatrist who has spent most of the past 30 years treating patients with moderate to severe mental illness. But I’ve also administered care for the Massachusetts Department of Mental Health, Harvard Medical School and several insurance companies, and so I’m often asked for advice by colleagues who feel their patients need more help than an insurer is willing to pay for. In addition to offering technical advice, I often become, in essence, the therapists’ therapist, at least in terms of their treatment choices. And sometimes those interactions are as intense as therapy itself.

headline: Reducing Unnecessary C-Section Births
keywords: ['Caesarean Section', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Malpractice', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: A pilot project in hospitals in California finds ways to avoid Caesarean sections when the expense and risks are not medically necessary.
lead_paragraph: You are about to give birth. Pregnancy has gone smoothly. The birth seems as if it will, too. It’s one baby, in the right position, full term, and you’ve never had a cesarean section — in other words, you’re at low risk for complications.

headline: The Best Missions for a Moonshot
abstract: Even if hopes for a "victory" against cancer are unrealistic, how can government best be used to reduce its threat and lethalness?

headline: Underestimating Cruz and Trump: A Post-Mortem
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Many journalists and political professionals were fooled by history. Occasionally, the basic laws of presidential politics can change.
lead_paragraph: Several journalists have taken to using the turnover of a new year as a time to look back on what they got wrong in the previous year. It’s a good idea. Journalists are supposed to analyze what’s happening in the world, and there is no way to do so with perfect foresight. But when we are surprised, we owe it to readers to be honest and reflective about why.

headline: Why 2016 Is Different From All Other Recent Elections
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2008']
abstract: The campaign has reached the point at which the eventual nominee is usually near the top of the polls — spots still held by Donald Trump and Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 Republican primary began as many Republican presidential campaigns do, with a few unexpected names atop the polls. In recent cycles, the names have included Herman Cain, Rick Santorum and Pat Buchanan. This year, they’ve been Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and Ben Carson.

headline: Chinese Students and U.S. Universities Connect Through a Third Party

abstract: What events occurred last weekend in regard to U.S. and Iranian diplomacy?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “3 Freed Americans Leave Iran; U.S. Places New Sanctions.”

headline: Ellie Goulding Shares Her Beauty Routine
abstract: The pop star on hair extensions, spray tans and lots and lots of faux lashes.
lead_paragraph: The English singer and songwriter Ellie Goulding, 29, is clearly hitting her stride. Her third album, “Delirium,” was hailed as the iTunes top pop album of 2015, while the hit single “Love Me Like You Do” earned a Golden Globe nomination (it was on the “Fifty Shades of Grey” soundtrack) and two Grammy nominations — her first. Aside from her music, Ms. Goulding has been collaborating with MAC Cosmetics on a makeup collection, which is in stores now. Below, she shares her beauty regimen for on and off the stage.

headline: Week of Attacks, Scores of Civilian Deaths and a Question: Why Them?
abstract: The seemingly random killings last week in Burkina Faso, Indonesia, Iraq and Turkey highlighted the strategy of militants determined to sow fear in disparate corners of the world.
lead_paragraph: A family of Canadian volunteers dedicated to alleviating poverty in Africa. A group of intrepid German retirees on a tour of Turkey and the Middle East. An Iraqi who had gone to Baghdad seeking refuge from the jihadist violence of his hometown. A Canadian audiologist who had fallen in love with Indonesia.

headline: China’s Fading Factories Weigh on an Already Slowing Economy
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The economic slump has created a tricky situation for Beijing, as it tries to shepherd the economy through a transition.
lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — Walking around an abandoned furniture factory, Fang Minghua pointed out the workshops where several hundred employees once toiled, transforming sheets of raw wood into TV stands or wardrobes for the aspiring middle class in China and other emerging economies.

headline: Film Shows Clinton Aide’s Own Struggle With Anthony Weiner Scandal
abstract: A documentary about Anthony D. Weiner and his wife, Huma Abedin, a top aide to Hillary Clinton, comes at an uncomfortable time for Mrs. Clinton’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: In May 2013, Huma Abedin and Anthony D. Weiner allowed filmmakers full access to his mayoral campaign with the hopes that the result would document a spectacular political comeback, with Mr. Weiner being sworn in as mayor of New York having emerged from a scandal centered on explicit texting that forced him to resign from Congress.

headline: Student Question | Under What Conditions Do You Do Your Best Work?
abstract: What are the ideal parameters for an assignment that help you do your best work?
lead_paragraph: I do my best work under pressure.

headline: Chris Christie Offers a Key to Marital Success: Fight in a Walk-In Closet
abstract: In a new book, the Republican presidential hopeful describes marriage counseling with his wife in the early years and retreating to a walk-in closet to argue.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and his wife, Mary Pat, underwent marriage counseling to wrestle with what he called “really challenging times” in their relationship. They waited seven years to have children to ensure they “definitely liked each other.” And to this day they retreat to a walk-in closet to loudly argue away from their children’s earshot, according to a new book.

headline: ‘Why the Right Went Wrong’ and ‘Too Dumb to Fail’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two new books by very different authors agree that the buffoonery on the right is bad not just for conservatism but for America.
lead_paragraph: “May you live in interesting times” is said to be a Chinese curse. The same kind of curse may apply to people who support interesting parties. There is no doubt that the Republicans are more interesting than the Democrats at the moment — their rhetoric is more incendiary, their divisions more profound, their behavior more outlandish. But the very antics that encourage people to tune in to the presidential debates also discourage them from pulling the voting lever: Hillary Clinton’s chances of winning the White House in November seem to be getting higher largely because she is a safe pair of hands.

headline: Explosion, Said to Be Suicide Bombing, Kills 8 in Northwest Pakistan
abstract: A senior official of the Khyber tribal region said the attacker had detonated an explosive vest at a militia checkpoint just outside the northern city of Peshawar.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An explosion, said to be a suicide bombing, at a militia checkpoint just outside this Pakistani city killed eight people and wounded at least 11 on Tuesday morning, a senior official of the Khyber tribal region said.

headline: ‘Dark Money,’ by Jane Mayer
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Dark Money” argues that the Koch brothers and a small number of allied plutocrats have essentially hijacked American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen eighty was a year of hope for conservatives in America, but it was a hope diminished by decades of consistent failure at the grass roots. Republicans hadn’t controlled either chamber of Congress, or a majority in state legislatures, for a quarter-century. Most governors were Democrats, as had been true since 1970. Not only was the Republican Party overmatched at winning elections, but those with the strongest ideological convictions — “movement conservatives,” as they liked to call themselves — were a faint voice even within Republican ranks.

headline: Q. and A.: Bei Ling on the Missing Hong Kong Booksellers
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Books and Literature', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Writing and Writers', 'Censorship']
abstract: Bei Ling, an exiled Chinese poet, discusses the five men’s fate and why Hong Kong is a center for provocative books about the Chinese political elite.
lead_paragraph: The disappearance of five Hong Kong booksellers in recent months has attracted international attention and raised concerns that civil liberties the city retained after its return to Chinese rule in 1997 under the so-called one country, two systems formula might be under threat. That the five men were all connected to Mighty Current Media, a publisher of exposés on Communist Party leaders, has led to suspicions that the Chinese authorities might have played a role.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Network Outages', 'Social Media']

lead_paragraph: Twitter experienced global disruptions on Tuesday that prevented many of its 300 million users from staying connected or from logging on to the social network in the first place.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Microsoft acquired the creator of the game Minecraft in 2014, the giant software company instantly got a cachet bump with children, picking up a blockbuster game app for a generation that didn’t depend on its products the way their parents did.

headline: Seven Years Later, Verdasco Comes Through Against Nadal

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a moment that not every loser would have chosen to revisit: a marathon versus Rafael Nadal in 2009 that could have put Fernando Verdasco in the final of the Australian Open.

abstract: On the second day of a five-day tour, Mr. Cruz, who has called his Spanish “lousy,” could not resist addressing a group of Spanish speakers in the language that his rivals Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Jeb Bush speak much more readily.
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, N.H. — At virtually every campaign stop, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas tells the tale of his father’s exodus from Cuba. He is less likely to speak the country’s official language.

headline: Jeb Bush to Speak at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York
abstract: Mr. Bush will highlight his message of national security and somber foreign policy in a high-profile speech that will emphasize both his implicit and explicit campaign trail theme: that he is best prepared to be commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: From almost the first day he entered the 2016 race, Jeb Bush has cast himself as the cerebral, wonky adult in a room full of colorful, bombastic Republican candidates.

abstract: On Tuesday morning, Mr. Sanders will leave Des Moines for a day packed with events across Iowa, where he has closed the gap with Hillary Clinton, and which is critical to his 2016 chances.
lead_paragraph: With just two weeks until the Iowa caucuses, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is hitting the road and stepping on the gas.

headline: Getting in Shape This Year? Hotels Offer Deals to Help You.

abstract: Exercise classes, personal training and unlimited sports are part of new packages that emphasize exercise.
lead_paragraph: Making a new year’s resolution to get healthy is easy. Sticking to that goal as the months go by? Not so much. Next month, a number of hotels are trying to help keep their guests motivated by introducing long-term fitness initiatives and packages.

headline: Rachel Bloom’s Twisted Comedy
abstract: “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” — the subversive series that just won the actor a Golden Globe — somehow manages to set women’s uncomfortable truths to music.
lead_paragraph: Quietly and without much notice, last fall the CW network aired what was most likely broadcast television’s first-ever depiction of anal waxing. The scene, on the show “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend,” was not explicit, yet neither was it ambiguous. A young woman in her bathroom, wearing a short robe, leans forward and then reaches toward her backside with a wax strip in her hand. There is the sound of something ripping, a scream and then a cut to the spattering of blood on the side of the tub, like a shot from a slasher flick in which all the horror is implied.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump returns to Iowa on Tuesday amid a deepening faith-focused feud with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s Internet companies, in recent years, have been the shining stars of growth, with Alibaba and Tencent rivaling in size some of their most formidable global competitors.

lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Faulkner said, “The writer’s only responsibility is to his art.” This week, Zoë Heller and Francine Prose discuss the obligations of artists.

headline: Here’s Someone You Never Heard of. Read On.
abstract: An overreliance on anecdotal openings can make our prose feel shopworn rather than vivid. This is particularly true when readers encounter strangers at the top of two or more adjacent stories, whether in print or online. Here are a few recent examples.
lead_paragraph: It may seem churlish to speak ill of strangers. And I’m sympathetic to reporters’ efforts to humanize their news stories with vivid examples and memorable characters.

headline: Why Green Bay Should Have Chosen Boldness
abstract: The Packers, with a recent record of playing it “safe” in the playoffs, fell short again after not trying for a two-point conversion.
lead_paragraph: Green Bay lost to Arizona in overtime without getting a possession, marking the second consecutive season in which the Packers have taken a playoff game to the fifth quarter and then lost without touching the ball. But don’t blame the N.F.L. overtime format for Green Bay’s woes — blame the conservative tactics of Coach Mike McCarthy.

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts Profit as It Charts a New Course
abstract: The bank says it is planning to exit entire areas of the fixed-income business that are “not strategically significant.”
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley swung from a loss to a better-than-expected profit in the fourth quarter compared to a year ago — at the same time that it announced a new strategic plan for improving profitability even more.

headline: Ayatollah Khamenei Warns Iran’s Government Against U.S. ‘Deceptions’
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: In a letter to Iran’s president, the supreme leader cautiously welcomed the completion of the nuclear deal and end to economic sanctions but said the United States breaks its promises.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, cautiously welcomed on Tuesday the completion of the nuclear deal and the lifting of economic sanctions last weekend, while at the same time dashing any expectations that the event marked the beginning of a détente with the United States.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire investor, has returned to London, less than three years after his former firm, SAC Capital Advisors, closed its office in London amid an insider trading investigation by authorities in the United States.

headline: 1916: France Welcomes Hostages
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: French hostages are welcomed back in Paris in 1916.
lead_paragraph: Paris gave an enthusiastic welcome yesterday evening to the ten French hostages, mayors and prominent residents in the invaded departments taken prisoners early in the war, upon their arrival at the Gare de Lyon at 7.25. A great crowd assembled outside the station and the platform was lined with friends and relatives and many deputies and government officials. As the train steamed into the station, the crowd raised a great cry of ‘‘Vive la France!’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 20, 1916

headline: Caitlyn Jenner to Publish a Memoir About Her Transformation

lead_paragraph: Caitlyn Jenner — the reality TV star and prominent transgender activist — will publish a memoir about her highly public transformation from the Olympic track star and motivational speaker Bruce Jenner into a glamorous transgender woman, Caitlyn Marie Jenner.

headline: U.N. Quantifies the Suffering in an Iraq Divided and Under Attack
abstract: A report says that from January 2014, when ISIS started taking territory, to October 2015, nearly 19,000 people were killed and more than three million displaced.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — It was weeks ago that Iraqi and United States officials declared the city of Ramadi liberated from the Islamic State, yet the fighting has dragged on in some neighborhoods. As Iraqi commandos advance slowly, house to house and under American air cover, hundreds of civilians are still fleeing the violence, many of them malnourished.

headline: The Conductor Andrew Litton, Finding a Different Tempo
abstract: Mr. Litton, New York City Ballet’s new music director, makes the transition from leading a symphony orchestra to conducting a ballet.
lead_paragraph: Midway through his first rehearsal as music director of the New York City Ballet Orchestra, the conductor Andrew Litton did something audacious. He asked the musicians to change how they played a score that they must hold some kind of record for performing: Tchaikovsky’s “The Nutcracker,” which they have presented dozens of times each year for decades.

headline: Josef Frank: Celebrating the Anti-Design Designer
abstract: The Austrian Museum of Applied Arts/Contemporary Art has mounted the biggest exhibition of the designer's work in 30 years, hoping to burnish his reputation.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Toward the end of his life, the Austrian designer Josef Frank made dozens of meticulously detailed paintings of houses. Each was in a recognizably Modernist style, usually in a rural setting, with an elegant garden and large windows carefully positioned to capture the daylight.

headline: Viacom in Cross Hairs of Activist Investor
abstract: Eric Jackson of SpringOwl Asset Management outlined a plan — including replacing Viacom’s management and board — that he said could increase the stock price 135 percent.
lead_paragraph: To Eric Jackson, an activist investor with SpringOwl Asset Management, Viacom appears to be a textbook-style target.

headline: Can Iran Change?
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister on the danger Iran poses to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Riyadh, Saudi Arabia — THE world is watching Iran for signs of change, hoping it will evolve from a rogue revolutionary state into a respectable member of the international community. But Iran, rather than confronting the isolation it has created for itself, opts to obscure its dangerous sectarian and expansionist policies, as well as its support for terrorism, by leveling unsubstantiated charges against the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

headline: Leila Alaoui, Photographer Wounded in Burkina Faso Siege, Dies at 33

lead_paragraph: Leila Alaoui, a French-Moroccan photographer whose hauntingly beautiful photographs explored themes of migration, cultural identity and displacement, died on Monday night from injuries sustained during a terrorist attack in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. She was 33.

headline: Who’s Taking On Ethics in Albany? Not the Ethics Panels

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — On this, the leaders in New York’s Capitol can all agree: Something must be done about ethics. Reforms must be passed, the public trust once again earned.

keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation']

headline: Sticking With Windows 7
abstract: Microsoft has been enthusiastically recommending upgrading to its Windows 10 operating system. But what if you’d rather not?
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it true that Windows 10 will be a mandatory upgrade for Windows 7 and Windows 8 users this year? I have been getting the “invitation” to upgrade my Windows 7 computer for months, but have been avoiding it because I like my current system.

headline: Weakened at Bernie’s
abstract: Disappointing on finance and health.
lead_paragraph: With the release of Bernie Sanders’ health plan — or actually, health “plan” — the Democratic primary is coming into much better focus. Sanders is still a long shot for the nomination, but is a serious enough contender that he deserves some real scrutiny. And it’s important to be aware that there are bigger problems with his candidacy than lack of political realism.

headline: Univision Buys a Stake in The Onion to Reach Millennials
abstract: Univision, the Spanish-language media company, is trying to expand its reach to as diverse an audience of millennials as possible.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish-language media giant Univision Communications announced Tuesday that it had acquired a large stake in The Onion, the comedy and satirical digital media group, as part of the company’s efforts to extend its digital reach and strengthen its portfolio of comedy outlets.

headline: 1941: Nazi Raiders Reported Active
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Nazi raiding ships are reported active in the Pacific in 1941.
lead_paragraph: MANILA, P.I. — Ninety-eight Filipino survivors of German raids on shipping in the Pacific arrived here today on the Japanese ship Kamo Maru and reported that at least twelve Nazi raiders were operating in those waters. They said that Germans on board the ships on which they had been imprisoned said that twelve more vessels were being outfitted in Japanese ports for raiding purposes. Survivors of three British ships sunk by Nazi raiders in December, the Filipinos told of having come into contact with three German raiders, including the 10,000-ton Narvik, which they said was known as the ‘‘Black Ship,’’ painted black from stem to stern and bearing no insignia to show its nationality. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 20, 1941

headline: British Fashion Council/Vogue Fund Names 2016 Award Finalists
abstract: Emilia Wickstead, Mother of Pearl, Osman, Prism and Sophia Webster appear on the shortlist.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the evermore volatile retail climate for small fashion brands and behemoths alike, the importance of winning industry prizes has become paramount to fledgling designers. Few outside the business are aware of how even household names can teeter on the edge of bankruptcy, or how putting on a catwalk show in a bid to catch industry attention can take a heavy toll on finances in a brand’s early years.

headline: East Coast Snowstorm Expected to Hit This Weekend
abstract: Meteorologists predicted that the season’s first significant storm would head up the coast on Friday into Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Days after a snowfall on the East Coast, any hope of a return to 60-degree winter was officially dashed on Tuesday as meteorologists warned that the season’s first significant winter storm could be fast approaching.

headline: Appeals-Court-on-Insider-Trading
abstract: The court affirmed the convictions of an executive at Foundry Networks for tipping about the impending acquisition of the company.
lead_paragraph: The court affirmed the convictions of an executive at Foundry Networks for tipping about the impending acquisition of the company.

headline: Chocolate by the Book
abstract: Also, a mac-and-cheese muffin, a floating thermometer, an elegant moonshine, the flavors of Africa, and dragon bowls.
lead_paragraph: Georg Bernardini, a German chocolate expert, has evaluated chocolates from more than 500 companies worldwide and shares the results, A to Z, in a comprehensive tome that has been translated from German into English and is now available in the United States. He is forthright, referring to the chocolate from one company as having an “annoying” taste, and admits to disliking chocolate that contains vanilla. Among the more compelling features is a rundown of what should be listed on the labels of good dark, milk and white chocolate. He also describes the levels of processing, from serious bean to bar (he is not particularly a fan of Mast Brothers) to simple repackaging, and tells you what each company does: “Chocolate – The Reference Standard” by Georg Bernardini (Georg Bernardini, $60), thechocolatetester.com.

headline: At New Digital Lenders, Math Rules
abstract: Lending start-ups that rely on data-driven algorithms could widen the availability of credit and reduce costs for borrowers. But the new math raises questions of effectiveness and fairness.
lead_paragraph: Miguel Jimenez, a 20-year-old amateur musician in Appleton, Wis., had his eye on a classic Rickenbacker bass guitar last year. He searched the Internet and found Reverb, an online marketplace for musical instruments, which had the bass guitar he wanted. But the price tag was $1,600.

headline: Is It Better to Die in America or in England?
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Cancer', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Despite all the talk of over-treatment and high costs, end-of-life care in the United States isn’t as bad as you might think.
lead_paragraph: WE frequently hear complaints about how people near the end of life are treated in America. Patients are attached to tubes and machines and subjected to too many invasive procedures. Death occurs too frequently in the hospital, rather than at home, where the dying can be surrounded by loved ones. And it is way too expensive. Each year, the care of dying seniors consumes over 25 percent of Medicare expenditures.

headline: Twins and Grandparents Killed in Maryland Fire
abstract: The fire in house in Chillum , in Price George’s County, broke out in a home that appears to have had no smoke detectors, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Twin toddlers and their grandparents died in a fire in a suburban Maryland house early on Tuesday, and investigators said they were trying to determine the cause of the blaze. The home appears to have had no smoke detectors, the authorities said.

headline: A Military Wife During Deployment Is Asked, ‘Is It Worth It?’
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A 5-year-old’s wail at a family party: “I don’t want YOUR daddy. Not Finley’s daddy, or Addie’s daddy, I want MY daddy.”
lead_paragraph: We sat around my sister’s dining room table, laughing so hard we had tears in our eyes, reliving and rehashing the events of the night before. My aunt and uncle “fishing” for each other on the dance floor. My brother’s hilarious toast to the bride and groom (my other brother). My cousin’s Russian girlfriend responding to someone’s question of “Where did he find you?” with “Amazon Prime.”

headline: Part of Sierra Leone’s History Is Being Dismantled Board by Board
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Slavery (Historical)']
abstract: Freetown’s board houses are as old as the city itself, but they are fast disappearing amid rapid urbanization and a growing preference for concrete.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — On a busy roundabout in the heart of this nation’s capital stands an ancient cotton tree, marking the spot where Freetown was founded by freed slaves from North America more than 200 years ago. Walk for a few minutes toward the southeast, past the vendors who line the derelict remains of Victoria Park and through the bustling streets of the city center, and you will find at the corner of two rutted dirt roads a house that looks more suited to the American South than to a steamy West African capital.

lead_paragraph: Alessandro Michele’s fall/winter 2016 men’s collection mixed patterns and decorative styles, for what he called an “alchemical reaction.”

Below are some of the most popular choices for most intelligent comment of the evening:

headline: Can a Book Threaten Israel’s Jewish Identity?

lead_paragraph: Tel Aviv — The Israeli novelist Dorit Rabinyan has hit the jackpot: First, her latest book, “Borderlife,” became an issue of fierce debate and controversy. Then it became a symbol of liberty and progress. And then, of course, it became a best seller.

headline: Afghan Woman’s Nose Is Cut Off by Her Husband, Officials Say
abstract: Reza Gul was attacked by her husband in a village in northern Afghanistan, the police said, and is hoping to travel to Turkey for reconstructive surgery.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A young woman has been hospitalized in northern Afghanistan and is hoping to travel to Turkey for reconstructive surgery after her husband cut off her nose, the police and the woman’s family said on Tuesday.

headline: Five Teams Still Seeking Their First N.C.A.A. Tournament Berth
abstract: William & Mary, Army, Northwestern, St. Francis of Brooklyn and the Citadel are all original members of Division I that have never played in the tournament. That could change this year.
lead_paragraph: For a men’s basketball team like Duke, with 20 straight trips, going to the N.C.A.A. tournament is a given. Other teams have waited for a return to the tournament for years: Columbia since 1968, and Rice since 1970.

headline: Ice Cube and the Obstacles Facing ‘Compton’
abstract: The producer and N.W.A. member says the film was heavily promoted to Academy voters, but he worried the subject of gangsta rap would be an issue.
lead_paragraph: Let’s do a throwback Tuesday to last week, a few days before the Oscar nominations were announced, unleashing a torrent of fury over the omission of black actors and films about black characters. The prospects for “Straight Outta Compton,” directed by F. Gary Gray, looked bright: many forecast it would receive a best picture nomination (it did not). Ice Cube, a producer on the film, which depicts the rise of his group, N.W.A., met with the Bagger at the Roosevelt Hotel in Hollywood. He talked about his son O’Shea Jackson Jr., who plays Cube in the film, the therapeutic value of gangsta rap, and what would be lost if “Compton” did not get a nomination. Here are excerpts from the conversation:

keywords: ['Fugitives', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Prosecutors said they had linked three former members of the far-left guerrilla group to at least one failed robbery last year.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German police have intensified their decades-long search for three members of the Red Army Faction, believed to be on the run since their far-left guerrilla group disbanded in 1998, after prosecutors said on Tuesday that they had linked them to at least one botched robbery last year.

headline: Ai Weiwei’s Latest Canvas: A Luxury Emporium in Paris
abstract: The Chinese dissident artist unveiled “Er Xi,” or “Child’s Play,” an exhibit that fills display windows and the atrium of the Bon Marché Rive Gauche.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Sunday evening, Ai Weiwei — Chinese dissident artist, human rights activist and, now, European scenester — was holding court on the cosmetics floor of the Bon Marché Rive Gauche, the Paris department store. The event was the invitation-only opening of “Er Xi,” or “Child’s Play,” an exhibit of his work that fills 10 display windows and the store’s atrium through Feb. 20.

headline: New Writings by Donald Judd Coming to Light
abstract: A new collection of art essays and criticism will include more than 40 pieces that will be published for the first time, and some previously published only in limited editions.
lead_paragraph: The artist Donald Judd, who died in 1994, remains known for many things – his sculpture, his spare architectural interventions, his exacting and obdurate personality. During his lifetime he was also known and widely revered for his writings – criticism and essays that took the measure of many of his contemporaries and helped set the terms for Minimalism, the movement he never quite claimed as his own. But for more than two decades, Judd’s collected writings, originally published in 1975, have been extremely hard to come by, with copies sometimes trading on used book sites for hundreds of dollars.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men’s Wear, Come Undone
abstract: Several men’s shows, including Prada, Etro and Vivienne Westwood, embraced a casual dishabille.
lead_paragraph: Precise tailoring is usually the main attraction at the Milan men’s shows — but this season, a handful of designers have embraced a more undone look in their fall/winter 2016 collections. At Prada, plackets, collars and cuffs dangled from shirts and jackets, while at Gucci, Marni, Etro and Damir Doma, knits, trousers and coats came down the runway with frayed hems. And at Vivienne Westwood — certainly a patron saint of the unkempt — a patchwork sweater was cut open at the sleeves. It all makes one consider taking a pair of shears to one’s own clothes for next winter.

headline: Gun Debate at the O.K. Corral (Or Somewhere)
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The chief executive of the N.R.A. has challenged President Obama to a debate — but he sounds more like he’s calling for a duel.
lead_paragraph: “The American people know a liar when they see one,” declared Wayne LaPierre, chief executive of the National Rifle Association, calling out President Obama for a one-on-one television debate on gun controls in a macho direct-address video that sounded more like a challenge to a duel. “Let’s see if you’re game for a fair debate,” said Mr. LaPierre. “It’s your chance to show the American people you’re not afraid to meet the NRA on neutral ground.”

headline: Rethinking College Admissions
abstract: A new report suggests that we’re on the cusp of important, necessary changes in the way colleges evaluate applicants.
lead_paragraph: Over recent years there’s been a steady escalation of concern about the admissions process at the most revered, selective American colleges. And little by little, those colleges have made tweaks.

headline: Supreme Court Will Hear a California Insider Trading Case
abstract: The court refused in October to address the issue of what prosecutors need to prove to obtain convictions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to resolve a dispute about what prosecutors need to prove to obtain insider trading convictions. The question has divided federal appeals courts, and the justices declined to address it in October.

headline: Why Donald Trump’s Shadow Looms Over Davos
abstract: The presidential candidate will not be at the World Economic Forum. But the force behind his unlikely campaign for the White House will be a focus.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s presence will be felt at the World Economic Forum this year, even though he isn’t actually expected to attend.

headline: A Romantic Weekend for Two: Solving a Crime
abstract: The plot of the Headlands Gamble, set in a series of secluded Marin County towns, revolves around the fictional mystery of a missing racehorse.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a more intriguing description of a weekend escape than “like being the detective in Twin Peaks,” which is how Gabe Smedresman likes to advertise his latest offering, the Headlands Gamble. Smedresman calls himself a producer of “mixed-reality entertainment” — his prior projects include the pseudo-stock-market game Pretweeting (a way to make the most of the Times Newswire API) and the Hearst Collection, “a real-life maze in which people who enter try to steal works of art without tripping laser alarms,” reported the journalist Harold Goldberg in 2013. The Headlands Gamble pulls together these key themes as the inaugural trip of First Person Travel, Smedresman’s new “immersed-narrative travel agency.”

headline: A Push for Gender Equality at the Davos World Economic Forum, and Beyond
abstract: Investments are expected to be diversified so why is that logic not applied to gender, asks Theresa Whitmarsh, one of the women leading an initiative for parity in finance at the elite gathering.
lead_paragraph: As a top executive in the financial industry, Theresa Whitmarsh is accustomed to being the only woman in the room. That was the case the last two years when she attended the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, a conclave for the world’s most powerful leaders and tycoons.

Trump in Iowa, the former Alaska governor posted on Twitter a link to a comment from her daughter Bristol slamming Senator Ted Cruz, who holds a slim lead over Mr. Trump in the polls there.

headline: Turkish Sweets Are the Essence of a Nation
abstract: Sweet desserts in Turkey are both an important feature of daily life and an entrenched part of religious and secular rituals. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: On a recent trip to Istanbul, I crossed the Bosporus by ferry, watching dusk fall over historic Sultanahmet and silhouette the skinny minarets that frame Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. To my right, illuminated in the distance, loomed modern skyscrapers. Sea gulls swirled overhead amid emerging stars, diving for bits of bagel-like simit tossed to them from the deck.

headline: Imagination Worth the Added Price at Midtown’s La Chine
abstract: From its caviar-filled eggs to its chocolate cake with sesame ganache, the upscale Chinese restaurant in the Waldorf Astoria offers sophisticated surprises.
lead_paragraph: In a nest of dried grass and feathery moss sat an eggshell, its top neatly lopped off. Caviar and a crinkle of gold leaf shone just inside the rim. Underneath were layers of custard and hairy crab, a seasonal freshwater treat from China whose taste is a lot more seductive than its name. The rich, smooth pleasure in each spoonful almost made my head pop.

abstract: Despite a step forward in a process aimed at bringing together the country’s warring parties, the formation of a single government still faces significant hurdles.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libyan officials nominated 32 people on Tuesday to serve as cabinet members in a proposed unity government, marking a step forward in a United Nations-backed process aimed at bringing together the country’s warring parties after years of political divisions and civil war, diplomats said.

headline: In Chelsea, a Trio of Galleries Bring Cuba Stateside
abstract: Following the Bronx Museum’s “Cuba Libre!” show last spring, several New York galleries are showcasing Cuban artists — past and present.
lead_paragraph: When the U.S. loosened travel restrictions to Cuba in 2014, Havana jumped to the top of everyone’s cultural bucket list. And the New York art scene has caught the fever: A rash of exhibitions this winter are devoted to the island’s art community. A timely follow-up to last spring’s contemporary-focused “Cuba Libre!” exhibition at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, David Zwirner’s “Concrete Cuba” offers one of the first looks at the island’s pre-revolutionary art, with a comprehensive show of the sculptures and paintings of Los Diez Pintores Concretos (the Ten Concrete Painters), a group of geometrically inclined artists that operated under that collective moniker for a brief moment between 1959 to 1961. Taking up the second story of the gallery’s 20th Street tower, the historical work has a pleasingly human scale. A celebration of medium and color rather than content, the concretist compositions share more conceptual similarities with the process-based artists of today than with the abstract expressionists who were working in Europe and the U.S. at that time.

headline: New Jersey Creates Retirement Savings Plan, Modified by Christie
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Small Business', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Personal Finances', 'Savings']
abstract: The law, which was significantly revised after Gov. Chris Christie vetoed the original, is intended to make it easier for small businesses to offer a tax-deferred savings program to employees.
lead_paragraph: As more states explore ways to encourage workers to save for retirement, New Jersey recently decided on its own approach: The state will create a retirement plan marketplace, intended to make it easier for small businesses to select a tax-deferred savings program for employees.

headline: Martin Shkreli Seeks New Legal Team in Securities Fraud Case
abstract: Mr. Shkreli’s law firm, Arnold & Porter, notified the court to say the pharmaceutical executive was retaining new lawyers.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, the former hedge fund manager turned pharmaceutical executive who was charged with securities fraud, is in the market for a new lawyer.

headline: Sarah Palin Endorses Donald Trump, Which Could Bolster Him in Iowa
abstract: The backing of Mrs. Palin, the former Alaska governor and 2008 vice-presidential nominee, provides Mr. Trump with a potential boost less than two weeks before the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and 2008 vice-presidential nominee who became a Tea Party sensation and a favorite of grass-roots conservatives, endorsed Donald J. Trump in Iowa on Tuesday, providing him with a potentially significant boost just 13 days before the state’s caucuses.

headline: College Towns Get New Housing, but It’s Decidedly Not Dorms
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Near campuses around the country, developers are building housing for the staff, tapping into the desire among some younger workers to live in walkable, urban communities.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A block from Drexel University, a glassy new rental building offers residents a roof deck with a heated saltwater pool, a fire pit and outdoor televisions — amenities that would make for a raucous college party, if college students could live there.

headline: Zhang Shuai Breaks Through Against Simona Halep, a No. 2 Seed
abstract: With her parents in attendance, Zhang, a qualifier who said she came close to retiring from tennis in the fall as her ranking fell to 200th, notched her first Grand Slam win.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For Zhang Shuai, a possible departure point became a long-awaited arrival.

headline: A Deadly Deployment, a Navy SEAL’s Despair
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Fellow officers saw the death of Cmdr. Job W. Price, which was ruled a suicide, as a cautionary tale of how men were ground down by years of fighting and losing comrades.
lead_paragraph: It was his last night of what his men were already calling a cursed deployment in Afghanistan.

headline: ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ Kills It in Final Week on Broadway
abstract: The musical played to near-capacity before closing.
lead_paragraph: “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” the unlikely hit with an unwieldy title, closed its Broadway run Sunday on a high note, playing to 99 percent full houses during its final week.

headline: The Improvised Shakespeare Company’s Couplets Off the Cuff
abstract: The five-man cast of the Improvised Shakespeare Company builds word-drunk and spot-on parodies of comedies and tragedies right on the spot.
lead_paragraph: In its second show of a doubleheader on Sunday night in the East Village, the Improvised Shakespeare Company built a spot-on parody of the word-drunk sexual innuendo of Falstaff’s world, a five-man cast making up the script on the spot, piling one filthy pun atop another.

headline: Casual Italian at Lilia in Williamsburg
abstract: Also, Brian Loiacono takes over at Acme; channeling Marie Antoinette at Le Boudoir; and ramen at Nakamura.
lead_paragraph: Lilia Missy Robbins, who has worked consulting gigs since leaving A Voce nearly three years ago, now has her own place to hang her toque. Hers is not the first New York restaurant to inhabit a former auto-body shop. And, as in the others, industrial elements grab the eye. But skylights and an open kitchen fitted with a wood grill and rotisserie brighten the setting for Ms. Robbins’s casual Italian, pared down to its simplest elements. Dishes include winter-vegetable bagna cauda, grilled clams with chiles and bread crumbs, whole-wheat spaghetti with smoked ricotta, and pike with salsa verde and roasted potatoes. A retail area for takeout becomes a bar in the evening: 567 Union Avenue (North 10th Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-576-3095, lilianewyork.com.

headline: Microsoft to Donate $1 Billion in Cloud Services to Nonprofits and Researchers
abstract: Microsoft hopes to give away its cloud services to 70,000 nonprofits in the next three years.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft plans to give away $1 billion in cloud services to nonprofits and university researchers over the next three years, as the company updates its philanthropic initiatives to reflect shifts in technology.

headline: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan Apologizes in Flint Water Crisis
abstract: “I’m sorry, and I will fix it,” he said in a State of the State address in which he focused on an issue that has consumed the state and drawn national attention.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan issued a sweeping apology on Tuesday to the residents of Flint for a contaminated water supply. He pledged to promptly release his emails about the issue, and laid out more specifics than had previously been known about the state’s handling of the matter.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Poll Ratings Rise as He Adjusts His Image
abstract: A new survey conducted by Quinnipiac University came as New York’s mayor was working to counter criticism about his leadership abilities.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s approval rating has ticked up amid his concerted effort to convey a more forceful public image, and he now receives positive marks from half of New York City voters, a Quinnipiac University poll released on Tuesday found.

headline: IBM Reports Declines in Fourth-Quarter Profit and Revenue Despite Gains in New Fields
abstract: The computing giant’s new areas, such as data analytics, its Watson software and cloud computing, have yet to grow fast enough to supplant company’s eroding legacy products.
lead_paragraph: IBM delivered fresh evidence on Tuesday of the financial challenge it faces in navigating a difficult transition to new technology businesses. Yet the company’s leaders insisted its performance also showed that its strategy was succeeding.

headline: In Milan, Fendi Focuses on a Cozy Life at Home
abstract: Silvia Venturini Fendi said her men’s fall/winter 2016 collection was inspired by staying in — while remaining connected.
lead_paragraph: Silvia Venturini Fendi said her men’s fall/winter 2016 collection was inspired by staying in — while remaining connected.

headline: How to View Five Planets Aligning in a Celestial Spectacle
abstract: For the first time in more than a decade, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Saturn and Jupiter will be simultaneously visible to the naked eye through Feb. 20.
lead_paragraph: Five planets paraded across the dawn sky early Wednesday in a rare celestial spectacle set to repeat every morning until late next month.

headline: Ecuador’s Barcelona
abstract: Barcelona Sporting Club’s highs and lows resonate in Ecuador in the same way that F.C. Barcelona’s wins and losses touch all of Spain.
lead_paragraph: Barcelona Sporting Club’s highs and lows resonate in Ecuador in the same way that F.C. Barcelona’s wins and losses touch all of Spain.

headline: Sharing a Name With Barcelona, if Not Its Fortunes
abstract: In Ecuador, the name Barcelona is associated with a club founded in Guayaquil that resonates much as Messi & Company do in Spain. But lately the team has struggled financially and on the field.
lead_paragraph: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador — In his sparsely decorated corner office overlooking the field at Estadio Monumental, Juan Alfredo Cuentas sought to explain the power of the brand he has inherited as Barcelona Sporting Club’s new vice president for finance. Outside, the once-manicured grass lay vacant for the off-season, slowly spoiling in the January heat.

headline: Remembering ASAP Yams
abstract: Scenes from a tribute concert at Terminal 5 in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a tribute concert at Terminal 5 in Manhattan.

abstract: The range of performers at Terminal 5 on the first anniversary of his death testified to how wide Yams’s umbrella truly was.
lead_paragraph: His mother wore Coogi.

headline: ISIS Magazine Confirms ‘Jihadi John’ Death
abstract: The most recent issue of the militant group’s online publication, Dabiq, included a eulogy for Mohammed Emwazi, a British citizen.
lead_paragraph: A eulogy for the Islamic State’s most notorious executioner appeared online in the group’s official, English-language magazine on Tuesday, confirming that the militant known as “Jihadi John” was killed in an airstrike last year in northern Syria.

headline: Proposed Legislation Would Add Scrutiny of Wall Street Regulators
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Critics warn that the legislation is intended to create additional burdens and delays in the regulation process.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A congressional effort to put regulators under the microscope when they write new rules for Wall Street is gaining momentum, potentially creating new obstacles to the closer oversight of financial risk taking.

lead_paragraph: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Crimea, Georgia and the United States.

headline: Netflix Faces a U.S. Slowdown, Despite Global Growth
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Company Reports', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: The company missed growth forecasts, adding just 1.56 million subscribers, a decline from the 1.9 million it added during the same period the previous year.
lead_paragraph: The Netflix fourth-quarter results paint two different pictures of the company: one achieving record global growth, the other facing a slowdown in the United States, where its already high penetration is making it increasingly difficult to add new subscribers.

headline: Kygo Delivers Dance Beats, With a Side Order of Pan Flute
abstract: The producer and remixer, who as been commissioned to remix Coldplay, gained attention by remixing known tracks and putting them on SoundCloud.
lead_paragraph: In September 2014, the organizers of the inaugural TomorrowWorld dance festival near Atlanta made a significant adjustment to the main stage lineup. Avicii, the superstar Swedish ambassador of electronic dance music, known as E.D.M., had canceled because of illness; his replacement was the lesser-known Norwegian producer-D.J. Kygo, born Kyrre Gorvell-Dahll, who’d picked up attention for a series of remixes he’d posted on his SoundCloud page and a performance at Tomorrowland, the event’s parent in Belgium, a couple of months earlier.

headline: Bernie Sanders Widens Lead Over Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Three weeks before New Hampshire’s presidential primary, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has jumped out to a 27 percentage point lead over Hillary Clinton in a new CNN/WMUR poll of likely Democratic voters there released on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks before New Hampshire’s presidential primary, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has jumped out to a 27 percentage point lead over Hillary Clinton in a  poll of likely Democratic voters there released by CNN/WMUR on Tuesday evening.

headline: Review: Eighth Blackbird Ensemble Plays Sleeping Giant’s Suite
abstract: The Sleeping Giant composers’ collective was commissioned to create this six-part collaboration, which had its premiere on Monday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Composers tend to be proprietary about their pieces. They may openly acknowledge the influence of masters, teachers and colleagues on their work, but when it’s finished, the writer claims the credit.

headline: ‘All That Jack (Cole),’ a Homage to a Forgotten Choreographer
abstract: A Museum of Modern Art retrospective highlights 18 films featuring dance numbers by Jack Cole, a performance coach to Rita Hayworth and Marilyn Monroe.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes” and “Gilda,” you’ve seen the work of the choreographer Jack Cole. And yet he’s hardly a household name, despite being one of the first to bring the energy and rhythmic attack of jazz to musical theater. Even so, Cole’s work has long languished in the archives, along with the often second-rate movies he worked on in the 1940s and ’50s. Now, in the Museum of Modern Art’s retrospective “All That Jack (Cole),” which opens on Wednesday, 18 of these films will return to the screen, many for the first time in decades.

headline: ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Receives a Cool Reception in China
abstract: The film has collected about $98 million from theaters in China, since opening there Jan. 9, but was beaten in its second week by the animated “Boonie Bears III,” a local production.
lead_paragraph: With $1.8 billion in global ticket sales and counting, “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” is an unqualified box office smash. Even so, Walt Disney Studios, which released the movie, is contending with a perception — Disney would say misperception — that Chinese audiences have given the space adventure a cool reception.

headline: America’s Best Days May Be Behind It
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality', 'Innovation']
abstract: A new book argues that the great strides in American innovation and prosperity made from 1920 through 1970 are unlikely to be repeated.
lead_paragraph: Take a look back at some of the most popular TV programs of the mid-1960s — “The Dick Van Dyke Show,” “Bewitched,” even “The Beverly Hillbillies” — and what do you see?

headline: Airdrops Called Too Risky a Way to Help Starving Syrians
abstract: American officials said that the Syrian government’s antiaircraft weapons posed a threat and that dropping aid to a populated area could hurt the very people it was meant to help.
lead_paragraph: Civilians in besieged Syrian cities are still starving. Though two humanitarian convoys reached Madaya on Thursday, for example, they were the first to do so in months, and the United Nations says five more people there have died from starvation in the past week.

headline: Iran Compensation Case Pits Congress Against the Supreme Court
abstract: Iran does not want to pay up to $2 billion to American victims of terrorism, and has appealed to the justices to disapprove legislation ordering the payments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For most observers, the main issue raised in the Supreme Court case Bank Markazi v. Deborah Peterson was whether victims of some of the bloodiest terrorist attacks of the 20th century would finally be paid reparations.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
abstract: The making of the myth of Bonnie and Clyde; Captain America turns 75; and some personal trainers get fat, intentionally.
lead_paragraph: "American Experience” examines the making of the myth of Bonnie and Clyde. Captain America turns 75. And some personal trainers get fat, the better to feel their clients’ pain.

headline: Review: Arturo Ripstein’s ‘Bleak Street,’ the Story of a Mexican Murder Case
abstract: This film is a fictionalized chronicle of the deaths of Alberto and Alejandro Pérez Jiménez, small wrestlers who were killed in a botched robbery in 2009.
lead_paragraph: “Bleak Street,” Arturo Ripstein’s new film, turns a lurid tabloid true-crime story into a somber, surreal, monochromatic dream. Based on a murder case that shocked Mexico in 2009, the film is less interested in sensationalism or sleuthing than in the operations of fate. When characters invoke destiny, they sometimes have happy outcomes in mind, but every gray-shadowed, elegantly grotesque frame points in the opposite direction, toward death and other sorrows.

headline: Trudeau, Macri and Biden Are Among the Big Names at Davos
abstract: Among the biggest draws at this year’s gathering are some of the newest members of the global leadership club.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Though the World Economic Forum may draw more than a thousand veteran boldface names — many who have attended countless times — among the biggest draws at this year’s gathering are some of the newest members of the global leadership club.

headline: In Break From Big Rallies, Bernie Sanders Hits Iowa Plains by Bus
abstract: In the two weeks left before the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Sanders is traversing the state the old-fashioned way, and bringing with him an arsenal of poll numbers.
lead_paragraph: FORT DODGE, Iowa — After filling arenas on the coasts, reaching out to voters through social media and facing off with Hillary Clinton in nationally televised debates, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont began a critical leg of his surging campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination the old-fashioned way, traveling on Tuesday across frozen and whitewashed Iowa plains in a campaign bus.

headline: Expect Some Unicorns to Lose Their Horns, and It Won’t Be Pretty
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The market downturn will force highly valued start-ups to regroup and seek money at lower valuations, pitting employees, founders and investors against each other.
lead_paragraph: The unicorn wars are coming, as the downturn in the market will force these onetime highfliers to seek money at valuations below their earlier billion-dollar-plus levels, known as “down rounds.”

headline: Freshii Will Offer Half-Off Promotion to Lure Chipotle Customers
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Discount Selling']
abstract: The Canadian restaurant chain will cut the price of its Mexican-style menu items on the day Chipotle plans to close down during lunchtime for an employee meeting on food safety.
lead_paragraph: Freshii plans to make lemonade out of Chipotle’s lemons.

headline: Review: A ‘Mother Courage’ Deployed to Africa
abstract: Kecia Lewis stars in the Classic Stage Company production, which shifts Brecht’s antiwar drama to the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: Bertolt Brecht’s Mother Courage doesn’t fit the mold of a conventional heroine, or even the mold of a conventional antiheroine. But Kecia Lewis, who plays the role in the Classic Stage Company’s terrific production of “Mother Courage and Her Children,” certainly deserves some sort of badge of honor. Ms. Lewis’s commanding performance would be impressive under any circumstances, but the drama surrounding her undertaking the part makes the achievement all the more remarkable.

headline: U.S. Acts to Spur Development of High-Tech Reactors
abstract: The Energy Department will provide X-energy and Southern Company up to $40 million each for development of new nuclear power technologies to be used in coming decades.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is providing seed money for two advanced nuclear reactor designs, part of its effort to keep nuclear power in the nation’s energy mix over the next several decades.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates Criticizes Bernie Sanders Over His Opposition to Reparations
abstract: Ta-Nehisi Coates, a National Book Award winner who often writes on racism, said Senator Bernie Sanders’s argument that reparations could not make it through Congress could also be said about much of his platform.
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates, a writer for The Atlantic and a National Book Award winner who often focuses on racism, published a stinging critique of Senator Bernie Sanders on Tuesday over his opposition to reparations for slavery.

headline: Falling Deficit to Reverse Course in 2016 as U.S. Ages
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office reported that deficits, in decline for six years, will begin expanding again sooner than expected, posing tricky questions for presidential candidates of both parties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A six-year trend of declining federal budget deficits will end this year, sooner than expected, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office reported on Tuesday — a development that injects new questions into the presidential race for candidates proposing trillions of dollars in new tax cuts or spending.

headline: Anger in a Palestinian Town Feeds a Cycle of Violence
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Assaults', 'Youth', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Twelve young Palestinians killed over three months in clashes with Israelis were from a West Bank town known as the hotbed of the latest wave of stabbings.
lead_paragraph: SA’IR, West Bank — Raed Jaradat was 22, an accounting student from a well-to-do family here, already working part time with his father in his stone quarry and construction business. After Dania Ersheid, 17, was shot and killed by Israeli soldiers who said she had pulled a knife at the Ibrahimi Mosque in Hebron, a version disputed by Palestinians, Mr. Jaradat wrote an angry post on Facebook: “Imagine if this were your sister!”

headline: Russian Strikes in Syria Hit Area of Suspected Massacre
abstract: The air attacks occurred in the eastern province of Deir al-Zour, where the Islamic State had been accused of killing perhaps hundreds of people over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russian airstrikes hit Islamic State militants Tuesday in the eastern Syrian province of Deir al-Zour, in the village where the extremist group had been accused of massacring as many as hundreds of people over the weekend, the Russian military said.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Plan on Horse-Drawn Carriages Keeps Gaining Critics
abstract: A day after the mayor declared the matter closed, his proposal to limit the hansoms to Central Park drew more criticism, with pedicab drivers chanting “one-term mayor” outside City Hall.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio declared the matter of the horses closed.
