keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Ms. McLean, 47, is the chief of Edens, which develops, operates and manages 120 retail shopping centers along the East Coast and in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Ms. McLean, 47, is the chief executive of Edens, which develops, operates and manages 120 retail shopping centers along the East Coast and in Texas. The company is based in the Washington area.

headline: E.R. Doctor at Mt. Sinai Hospital Charged With Sexual Abuse of 2 Patients
abstract: A prominent emergency room doctor at Mount Sinai Hospital on the Upper East Side was arrested and accused of drugging, groping and masturbating on a female patient and groping another.
lead_paragraph: A prominent emergency room doctor at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan was arrested on Tuesday and accused of drugging, groping and masturbating on a female patient and groping another in separate episodes several months apart, the authorities said.

headline: The Supreme Court, the Nativists and Immigrants
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: President Obama’s action to protect undocumented parents from deportation was well within his authority.
lead_paragraph: As soon as 26 states took it upon themselves to sue President Obama over the sensible, humane executive actions he took in late 2014 to protect millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation, it was inevitable that the lawsuit would land on the Supreme Court’s doorstep.

headline: BBC Journalist Turned Away From Flight to U.S. Because She Was Born in Iran
abstract: Amid confusion over new U.S. visa rules intended to deter terrorists, Rana Rahimpour was unable to fly to New York because she was born in Iran.
lead_paragraph: Amid confusion over new United States visa rules intended to deter terrorists, a British journalist who works for the BBC was denied permission to board a flight to New York at Heathrow Airport on Tuesday because she was born in Iran.

headline: Prisoner Swap With Iran Doesn’t Necessarily Mean Iran Gets Anyone
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Six of the seven freed by the United States are naturalized or native-born Americans with dual citizenship. Most, if not all, have no immediate plans to move to Iran.
lead_paragraph: The agreement for the mutual release of prisoners by the United States and Iran last weekend has been officially described as a humanitarian swap. But there was no physical exchange of people, as seen in movies.

headline: Grammy Awards to Air Live, Even on West Coast
abstract: Bowing to complaints about spoilers on social media, CBS agreed to make broadcast delays for the Pacific and Mountain time zones optional this year
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards’ television broadcast is going live this year — really live.

headline: Alarmed Clinton Supporters Begin Focusing on Sanders’s Socialist Edge
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Political Advertising', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Backers of Hillary Clinton, nervous about a surging Senator Bernie Sanders, are warning that he could send other Democrats in tight races to defeat.
lead_paragraph: Democrats backing Hillary Clinton, nervously eyeing Senator Bernie Sanders’s growing strength in the early nominating states, are turning to a new strategy to raise doubts about his candidacy, highlighting his socialist beliefs to warn that he would be an electoral disaster who would frighten swing voters and send Democrats in tight congressional and governor’s races to defeat.

headline: Oil Market Tests Banks’ Ability to Weather Losses
abstract: While plummeting oil prices are cutting into profits, they are not threatening big banks’ capital cushions, analysts say, thanks to rigorous regulation.
lead_paragraph: Low oil prices are rattling global markets and destabilizing economies around the world. They are also posing one of the first big tests to the United States banking system since the financial crisis.

headline: Microchip Technology to Buy Atmel for Nearly $3.6 Billion
abstract: The acquisition is the latest in a series of mergers and acquisitions in the semiconductor industry as chip makers combine to cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Microchip Technology agreed to acquire a fellow chipmaker, the Atmel Corporation, for about $3.6 billion, part of a wave of mergers and acquisitions within the semiconductor industry.

headline: Practice Fusion Said to Hire JPMorgan Chase to Explore I.P.O.
abstract: The electronic health records startup asked JPMorgan Chase last year to explore an I.P.O. in 2017, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Practice Fusion, an electronic health records start-up, hired JPMorgan Chase last year to explore an initial public offering in 2017, according to people with knowledge of the matter, though the discussions are now in flux because of market volatility.

headline: C.D.C. Urges Zika Testing for Some Who Are Pregnant
abstract: The guidelines, though seen as imperfect, offer a way to proceed with worried patients who have recently lived in or traveled to an area where the mosquito-borne virus is being transmitted.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who feel sick and have visited countries in which the Zika virus is spreading should see a doctor soon and be tested for infection even though the tests are imperfect, federal health officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Standoff on Oregon Land Inspires a Counterprotest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal Lands', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: The advent of a new assortment of outside protesters, many opposed to the antigovernment protesters’ own efforts, has again shifted the dynamics of the situation at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Oregon — Tensions have run high in eastern Oregon since an armed group seized the headquarters of a national wildlife refuge early this month, but the primary opponents in the standoff have been pretty clear cut: The antigovernment protesters are facing off against law enforcement agents, who are trying to figure out a peaceful end to the illegal occupation.

headline: Diplomacy and Sanctions, Yes. Left Unspoken on Iran? Sabotage.
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: An American covert sabotage program that began in the Clinton administration and steadily escalated over the next 15 years also played a critical role in persuading the Iranians.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry have a simple explanation for their surprising success in getting Iran to dismantle much of its nuclear infrastructure, ship out 98 percent of its nuclear fuel and release five American prisoners: Patient diplomacy, backed by escalating economic sanctions, accomplished more than military action ever could have.

headline: Exodus Refugee Ship Flag Finds Safe Haven at Holocaust Museum
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Museums', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A flag from the Exodus, a ship carrying 4,500 Jewish refugees that was turned away from Palestine by the British in 1947, has been donated to the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bill Silverstein walked into the Holocaust Memorial Museum here Tuesday with a small cardboard box under his arm and the plight of refugees on his mind — not only those now fleeing Syria, but also those from another crisis that held the world’s attention nearly seven decades earlier.

headline: Charity’s Suit Contests Will of Creator of ‘Dick Tracy’ and Other Radio Shows
abstract: The Radio Drama Network alleges that a lawyer duped Himan Brown into signing papers ensuring that the bulk of Mr. Brown’s $100 million estate would go to a charitable trust under the lawyer’s control.
lead_paragraph: Six years before he died, Himan Brown, the creator of the radio dramas “Dick Tracy” and “Inner Sanctum Mysteries,” signed papers ensuring the bulk of his $100 million estate would go to a charitable trust under the sole control of his longtime lawyer.

headline: Iran Negotiations Add to Special Envoy’s Reputation as ‘a Doer’
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Brett H. McGurk, who served under President Bush and is now a special envoy for President Obama, worked tirelessly for 14 months to negotiate the exchange of prisoners with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brett H. McGurk, President Obama’s lead negotiator in a secret prisoner swap with Iran, choked up as he boarded a Swiss government jet in Geneva on Sunday night and greeted three Americans who had just arrived from years of detention in Tehran. More than anyone else, he was responsible for their freedom.

headline: Ex-New York Officer Pleads Guilty in Conspiracy Case
abstract: Joseph P. Dwyer, who participated in a scheme to pay a police sergeant to gain access to a restricted database, could be sentenced to prison this spring.
lead_paragraph: A former New York City police officer who worked as an investigator for defense lawyers pleaded guilty on Tuesday to participating in a scheme to pay a police sergeant to gain access to a restricted law enforcement database that contained information about witnesses in cases that the former officer was working on.

headline: President Obama May Require Federal Contractors to List Campaign Gifts
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Campaign Finance', 'Corporations', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The directive, known as the “dark money” executive order, would mandate that government contractors publicly report their contributions to groups that spend money to influence campaigns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is seriously considering an executive order that would require companies doing business with the federal government to disclose their political contributions, White House officials said on Tuesday, a step long awaited by activists to reduce the influence of secretive corporate donations in elections.

headline: Friend Gave to de Blasio Just as Client Won Permit to Stage Festival

headline: Mr. Obama’s Wise Call on a Prisoner Swap
abstract: The Iran case showed that the use of diplomacy was the best course.
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable that the prisoner exchange with Iran would be questioned as soon as it was announced — and not just by Republicans who mechanically assail anything President Obama does. The notion of making concessions to a hostile adversary to secure the release of one’s fellow citizens has always been controversial, pitting the innate longing to win their freedom against the risk that handing over money or releasing prisoners in exchange will only encourage the captors to seize more. This dilemma has bedeviled many presidents and governments through history, with no simple or single answer. In this case, President Obama did the right thing.

headline: Unequal Lives, Unequal Deaths
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Elder Care', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospice Care']
abstract: Death may be humanity’s great equalizer, but there are vast inequalities in how we die.
lead_paragraph: In my first year of practice in palliative medicine, I made house calls to patients in South Los Angeles. My patients all lived in neighborhoods that ranked among the city’s lowest in both income and life expectancy. In these neighborhoods, people die an average of 10 years earlier than those who live less than 10 miles away. Many of my patients felt that they had barely lived their lives when I showed up, ostensibly to help them “die with dignity.”

headline: Why Is It So Difficult for Syrian Refugees to Get Into the U.S.?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Of the 4.5 million people who have fled the Syrian war, only 2,647 have been taken in by the United States.
lead_paragraph: ‘We aren’t the kind of family that sends our daughters to work,’’ Mahmoud al-Haj Ali told me one evening this fall. He’d just returned to the family’s dingy second-floor apartment in Aurora, Ill., from the warehouse where he and his 19-year-old daughter, Sham, sorted boxes. At work, Mahmoud tried to keep her in sight. ‘‘I saw how tired she was,’’ he continued. ‘‘It’s more than she can take.’’ Sham’s English classes provided only a shaky foundation in the language, and she struggled to negotiate basic conversations. Mahmoud also spoke little English — we were sitting with an interpreter — but he could manage the essential. Mahmoud work tomorrow, Mahmoud no work tomorrow, he said in self-parody. But he, too, was tired. He rolled up his sweatpants to reveal a swollen leg. In Syria, Mahmoud, 57, who once owned a flourishing locksmith business in the Emirates, would have already retired.

headline: In Search of Japan’s Hidden Culinary Revolution
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Restaurants', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Sushi', 'Seafood', 'Food']
abstract: From Tokyo to Kanazawa in this food-obsessed nation, sampling the culinary wizardry of a new wave of creative chefs.
lead_paragraph: I was on the Shinkansen bullet train and roaring north toward the Japan Sea at 125 miles per hour when I passed through the wormhole in space-time. The wormhole was on the far end of a long, unlit tunnel. Three-quarters of an hour earlier, in the midst of a sunny winter’s day, I’d boarded the train at the loud, insanely complex and many-leveled Tokyo main station, accompanied by my friend Bob Sliwa. We were bound for the coastal town of Kanazawa, sometimes known as the hidden pearl of the Japan Sea and famed for the freshness and variety of its fish-based cuisine.

headline: ‘The Triumph of William McKinley,’ by Karl Rove
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Rove’s account of William McKinley’s 1896 campaign presents him as an exemplary candidate.
lead_paragraph: Writing six decades after the election of 1896 brought the retired Ohio governor William McKinley to the White House, the political scientist V. O. Key Jr. identified the Democratic defeat as “so demoralizing and so thorough that the party could make little headway in regrouping its forces until 1916.” The scale of this Republican success — a moment that ushered in a period of Republican Party ascendance that lasted until the election of Franklin Roosevelt in 1932 — draws the attention of the prominent political strategist Karl Rove, who also views McKinley’s victory over the charismatic William Jennings Bryan as pivotal. Rove is in awe, rightly so, of McKinley’s political achievement, and his richly detailed, moment-by-moment account in “The Triumph of William McKinley” brings to life the drama of an electoral contest whose outcome seemed uncertain to the candidate and his handlers until the end.

headline: David Greenberg’s ‘Republic of Spin’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How Americans came to perceive carefully composed images of their current and future presidents.
lead_paragraph: When George Washington was president, our forebears did not wonder what spurred his occasional ghostwriter, Alexander Hamilton, to make a particular argument in the general’s 1796 farewell address. Nor did many voters in 1860 try to deconstruct why Abraham Lincoln’s propagandists chose to present him as a backwoods rail-splitter, which he had not been for a very long time, instead of the well-heeled corporate lawyer he had, thanks to hard work and talent, become.

headline: When Your Child’s Friend Is in Crisis
abstract: When your son stays up through the night to text with a buddy who is falling apart, you need to step in. But how?
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual for teenagers to need adult guidance on caring for their friends who have problems. Though teens are often characterized as being persistently self-centered, or for girls in particular, mean, anyone who spends a lot of time with adolescents can tell you that those stereotypes aren’t fair. Teenagers are devoted to their friends and, more often than not, they will sacrifice their time and comfort to buoy a friend who is sinking.

headline: How the ‘Perfect Storm’ Became the Perfect Cop-Out
abstract: Invoking an act of God to explain a human-made tragedy has become the go-to excuse in public life.
lead_paragraph: When a grand jury decided late last month not to indict the two police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Tamir Rice, the 12-year-old whose killing outside a Cleveland recreation center became a cause célèbre of the Black Lives Matter movement, the task of announcing the verdict fell to the Cuyahoga County prosecutor Timothy J. McGinty. McGinty, who is in the midst of a heated Democratic primary race, appeared decidedly unhappy to be handling the case. When he presented himself to the TV cameras on Dec. 28, he shifted from foot to foot and often looked fixedly at his prepared statement. He said he told Rice’s mother that what happened to her son was ‘‘undeniably tragic.’’ Nevertheless, he went on, ‘‘Given this perfect storm of human error, mistakes and miscommunication by all involved that day, the evidence did not indicate criminal conduct by police.’’

headline: Should I Help My Sister End Her Life?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Workplace Environment', 'Families and Family Life', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s ethicist on a sibling’s struggle, favors in the workplace and secrets between friends.
lead_paragraph: I have a 50-year-old sibling with multiple medical conditions (uncontrolled epilepsy, a stroke that left her physically and mentally impaired, paranoid schizophrenia, to name a few) that have left her isolated and miserable. My 80-plus-year-old parents are her caretakers. She has the very best doctors, social workers and therapists — but none can give her a fulfilling life. She calls me crying every night, often threatening to commit suicide, a threat she has tried to make good on dozens of times. I’m struggling to know if I should stop talking her out of suicide and instead give her options for a death with dignity. If she were dying of a terminal illness, the discussion could be more frank. But what of these chronic conditions with no end in sight? Name Withheld

headline: Why Are Corporations Hoarding Trillions?
abstract: It's an economic mystery — but it might tell us something important about how C.E.O.s and investors think about the future.
lead_paragraph: There is an economic mystery I’ve been struggling to understand for quite some time, and I’m not the only one who’s confused: Among financial experts, it is often referred to as a conundrum, a paradox, a puzzle. The mystery is as follows: Collectively, American businesses currently have $1.9 trillion in cash, just sitting around. Not only is this state of affairs unparalleled in economic history, but we don’t even have much data to compare it with, because corporations have traditionally been borrowers, not savers. The notion that a corporation would hold on to so much of its profit seems economically absurd, especially now, when it is probably earning only about 2 percent interest by parking that money in United States Treasury bonds. These companies would be better off investing in anything — a product, a service, a corporate acquisition — that would make them more than 2 cents of profit on the dollar, a razor-thin margin by corporate standards. And yet they choose to keep the cash.

headline: A Kasich Surge? Even a Suspect Poll Can Help This Time of Year
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']

lead_paragraph: The final couple of weeks before Iowa and New Hampshire are often among the most volatile of the primary season. The candidates start attacking one another, voters start making up their minds, and even the smallest shifts can bring a wave of media coverage that reshapes the race at a crucial stage.

lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs made a strong commitment to its Wall Street business model on Wednesday after announcing lower revenue and profit for the fourth quarter.

abstract: A spokeswoman for Condé Nast said she would become “creative editor at large,” doing “several” stories a year for the glossy and exploring outside opportunities.

headline: 1941: First 3-Term U.S. President
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Franklin Roosevelt is sworn into office for a third term in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the first Chief Executive in the history of the United States to be inaugurated for a third term in office, was sworn into office on the Capitol’s veranda at noon today [Jan. 20] and delivered a sixteen-minute inaugural address in which he made plain his belief that the fate of the United States is inextricably tied up with the outcome of the war now raging in Europe. “In the face of great perils never before encountered,’’ the President said, ‘‘our strong purpose is to protect and to perpetuate the integrity of democracy.’’ ‘‘We do not retreat,’’ he said. ‘‘We are not content to stand still.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 21, 1941

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Condemns Mob Attack on Saudi Embassy

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s highest leader strongly denounced on Wednesday a mob attack on Saudi Arabia’s embassy in Tehran this month, saying the event was “very bad” and “detrimental to the country and Islam.”

abstract: Mrs. Palin returned to the campaign trail with her rousing speech in support of Donald J. Trump. But some of her expressions left the audience puzzled.

headline: Daily Report: IBM Caught Between the Old and the New
abstract: The transition from older, shrinking markets to new areas is proving difficult for tech’s most venerable companies. But that does not mean they won’t be able to reinvent themselves.
lead_paragraph: For the tech industry’s venerable giants, the new stuff just doesn’t seem to be worth as much as the old stuff.

headline: Ann Liv Young on Elektra, a ‘More Primitive Version of Myself’
abstract: Ms. Young, the choreographer and artist, talks about playing Sophocles’ heroine in her new work at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: The provocative choreographer and performance artist Ann Liv Young loves a good revenge tale. In “Elektra,” her latest dance-and-song adventure, which has its United States premiere at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, she mines Greek drama to retell the tale of Sophocles’ Elektra. Her brazen approach to performance, which mixes text, pop songs and vigorous movement, is rarely gentle. “I need to feel like I’m being heard, and I need to know that you’re with me,” she said. “How can I wake you up without looking you in the eyes or touching you?”

keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Spanish Civil War (1936-39)', 'Algerian War (1954-62)', 'International Relations', 'Romani People']
abstract: The ruins of an internment camp at Rivesaltes, where for decades waves of refugees and others persecuted in wars were once held, have been turned into a memorial.
lead_paragraph: RIVESALTES, France — The barracks, with caved-in roofs and crumbling walls blackened by humidity and spray-painted with graffiti, sit in a ghostly silence, interrupted only by the distant drone of cars.

lead_paragraph: When we meet Richie Finestra, the protagonist of the new HBO drama “Vinyl,” his situation is dire. It’s 1973, and this beleaguered record-label executive, played by Bobby Cannavale, has lost faith in the music industry, squandered his sobriety and gotten himself in serious trouble.

abstract: The cost of higher education is very much on the minds of many voters these days, and it's an issue among politicians from both sides of the aisle.

keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'News and News Media', 'Sex Crimes', 'Television', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The Taliban targeted employees of a media company after threatening in October to attack it. At least seven people were killed and dozens wounded.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban served notice in October that they would begin targeting the two largest Afghan television networks for attack, accusing them of having falsely reported that insurgents had raped female students during their capture of the northern city of Kunduz.

headline: ISIS Has Destroyed One of Iraq’s Oldest Christian Sites
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Satellite images show that monastery of St. Elijah, a sanctuary more than 1,400 years old, was probably razed to rubble in August or September 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State destroyed one of the oldest Christian sites in Iraq as part of its campaign against ancient sites in the country, according to satellite photographs published by The Associated Press on Wednesday and confirmed by Iraqi officials and historians.

headline: Obama, Visiting Detroit, Lauds Auto Industry Recovery
abstract: With record U.S. car sales last year, the trip is something of a victory lap. But the president was also expected to discuss the water crisis in Flint.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — President Obama, starting the final year of his presidency by reminding the public of the high points of the first seven, traveled here Wednesday to claim credit for the resurgence of the American automobile industry, defending his record against what he called a Republican “fiction” that “America is in decline.”

headline: Hong Kong’s Missing Booksellers
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Missing Persons', 'Censorship', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Why is Beijing using brute force to close down a tiny publisher of two-bit political gossip?
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong publisher specializing in books banned in China has disappeared mysteriously, sowing fear among Hong Kongers that the Chinese government is growing bolder about encroaching on their liberties. As the saga continues to unfold, Beijing is reacting bizarrely, and in ways that suggest that the story is the extension of a long-running power struggle at the highest levels of the Chinese Communist Party.

abstract: Globally, 2015 was the warmest year in recorded history.
lead_paragraph: Globally, 2015 was the warmest year in recorded history.

headline: 2015 Was Hottest Year in Historical Record, Scientists Say
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Two Thousand Fifteen', 'Records and Achievements', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Floods']
abstract: The bulk of the record-setting heat, NASA and NOAA say, is from long-term planetary warming caused by human emissions of greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: Scientists reported Wednesday that 2015 was the hottest year in the historical record by far, breaking a mark set only the year before — a burst of heat that has continued into the new year and is roiling weather patterns all over the world.

headline: HPV Vaccination Rates Highest Among Hispanic Girls in Poorer Areas
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Teenage girls living in poorer neighborhoods are more likely to be vaccinated against human papillomavirus than those who live in richer areas.
lead_paragraph: Teenage girls living in poorer neighborhoods are more likely to be vaccinated against human papillomavirus, or HPV, than those who live in richer areas, researchers report. HPV is the cause of almost all cases of cervical cancer and some cases of other cancers.

headline: Share Your Thoughts on Recent Terrorist Attacks and Memories of Victims

headline: Big Snowstorm Forecast Sends a Shiver Up the East Coast
abstract: New York and New England could be spared the brunt of the storm, but Washington is squarely in its path, meteorologists say.
lead_paragraph: New York and New England could be spared the brunt of a snowstorm that meteorologists say is likely to reach the mid-Atlantic Northeast states beginning Friday, but residents of the Washington, D.C., area might not be so lucky.

headline: ‘The Magicians,’ Based on Lev Grossman’s Fantasy Trilogy, on Syfy
abstract: Quentin Coldwater is propelled into a university entrance exam where an instructor demands that he perform magic.
lead_paragraph: “The Magicians” — the first novel in Lev Grossman’s fantasy trilogy, and the foundation for the Syfy spinoff starting Monday, Jan. 25, at 9 p.m. — has been simplistically described as “Harry Potter for grown-ups,” if Harry were a clinically depressed Ivy Leaguer unable to confront life without his meds. That sums up Quentin Coldwater (Jason Ralph), who, when first we meet him, has checked out of a hospital and sought refuge with one of the five Narnia-like “Fillory and Further” books that have captivated him since childhood.

headline: 2016 Grammy Awards Performers Include Adele and Kendrick Lamar
abstract: The Weeknd and Little Big Town will also play the ceremony, on Feb. 15, but organizers haven’t announced plans for a David Bowie tribute yet.
lead_paragraph: Adele, Kendrick Lamar, the Weeknd and Little Big Town will be among the performers at the 58th annual Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 15, the show’s organizers announced on Wednesday morning.

headline: Sondra Radvanovsky, the Tudor Queen in ‘Maria Stuarda’ at the Met
abstract: This soprano portrays Mary, Queen of Scots, in the second work in Donizetti’s Tudor trilogy.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from her riveting portrayal of King Henry’s ill-fated queen in “Anna Bolena,” an interpretation notable for her coloratura technique and emotive power, the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky turns her attention to “Maria Stuarda,” the second work in Donizetti’s Tudor trilogy. Based on a Friedrich Schiller play that explores the rivalry between Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots, played by Ms. Radvanovsky, the opera meshes fact and fiction and includes a confrontation in which Mary calls Elizabeth a “vile bastard.”

headline: Watanabe Will Return to ‘King and I’ on Broadway
abstract: The actor will play opposite Kelli O’Hara for seven weeks, and then Daniel Dae Kim will assume the role for eight weeks.
lead_paragraph: The line of succession for Broadway’s Siamese throne is long this season.

headline: In ‘Quicksand,’ an Opera-Novel Takes a Mysterious Form
abstract: This work, the only major collaboration between the composer Robert Ashley and the choreographer Steve Paxton, merges music, light and dance.
lead_paragraph: In general, dances in operas are tacked on: divertissements unrelated to the story. In the premiere of “Quicksand,” an opera-novel told in the form of a mystery by the composer Robert Ashley (who died in 2014), the choreographer Steve Paxton abides by that approach; his movement may color the text, but it doesn’t describe it. He’s keeping the choreography, in his words, “low-key.” Mr. Ashley met Mr. Paxton in the 1960s, and though they worked together, “Quicksand” — a merging of music, light and dance — is considered their only major collaboration.

headline: How the N.B.A. 3-Point Shot Went From Gimmick to Game Changer
abstract: In the 3-point shot’s first year, 1979-80, N.B.A. teams averaged less than three attempts a game. Now they’re averaging 24, and the shot is a vital part of every offense.
lead_paragraph: Larry Bird and Magic Johnson were rookies. Bill Walton’s move to the Clippers — the San Diego Clippers — was making headlines. Some N.B.A. finals games were still being broadcast on tape delay. And the league tried something new: a 3-point shot.

headline: How to Cook Salmon
abstract: Our new soup-to-nuts salmon guide and Turkish sweets from Melissa Clark.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: In Pakistan, a Final Push to Wipe Out Polio
abstract: Last year, Pakistan’s 51 cases of wild poliovirus represented the bulk of all 70 cases reported in the world. This year just might see the disease vanquished there.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI — With nearly all of the rest of the world on the brink of being free of polio, the disease’s persistence in Pakistan has long challenged health experts both inside and outside the country. Last year, the 51 cases of wild poliovirus reported here represented the bulk of all 70 cases reported throughout the world.

headline: G-Eazy, ASAP Ferg and Nef the Pharoah at Terminal 5
abstract: These hip-hop artists are part of a diverse lineup performing at Terminal 5.
lead_paragraph: Vallejo, Calif., is a small city with an outsize hip-hop footprint. For almost three decades, it’s been home to signature stylists like E-40 and Mac Dre, clever rappers who sound different from each other, and from everyone else, too. That’s a lot of history hanging over Nef the Pharoah, the city’s latest prospect, who in November released a bouncy self-titled EP (on Sick Wid It, E-40’s label). He’s a liquid, witty rapper, but not quite as kinetic as his elders — his nasal, lethargically casual vocal presence recalls a young Snoop Dogg.

headline: Ninth Planet May Exist Beyond Pluto, Scientists Report
abstract: Two professors at the California Institute of Technology laid out an argument for the existence of a planet perhaps 4,500 times the mass of Pluto.
lead_paragraph: There might be a ninth planet in the solar system after all, and it is not Pluto.

headline: Apps to Manage Passwords So They Are Harder to Crack Than ‘Password’
abstract: Evaluating the merits of Dashlane, 1Password, LastPass and other methods of keeping long lists of increasingly complex passwords safe and accessible.
lead_paragraph: IT became official again this week: We are awful at passwords.

headline: ‘The Eccentrics’ Reveals Offbeat Modes of Being at SculptureCenter
abstract: This circuslike exhibition of artworks and performances by an international roster of eight artists is in Long Island City, Queens.
lead_paragraph: In Russia, “eccentric” is a word for circus performer, a figure seen by the writer Walter Benjamin as an avatar of creative deviance. Following Benjamin’s lead, the SculptureCenter curator, Ruba Katrib, has organized “The Eccentrics,” a circuslike exhibition of artworks and performances by an international roster of eight artists that promises to reveal novel, offbeat and liberating modes of being. It opens on Sunday, Jan. 24, in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: 1966: College Students Face Draft
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: College students face being drafted for Vietnam in 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — College students will be drafted beginning next fall unless peace comes in Vietnam, the director of the Selective Service system announced last night [Jan 19]. Lt. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey’s grim statement directly affects the 2.2 million students now holding college deferments. Under present Selective Service policies, college students are merely required to be doing satisfactory work while enrolled full-time at a properly accredited college or university to escape the draft. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 21, 1966

headline: As Supreme Court Clerk, Ted Cruz Made Death Penalty His Cause
abstract: Mr. Cruz became known among his fellow clerks for his death penalty advocacy and for dwelling on the lurid details of murders in his case summaries.
lead_paragraph: The memos of Supreme Court clerks evaluating death row petitions usually consist of a brief review of the facts and then a dispassionate legal analysis as to whether the court should hear the case.

headline: A Ninth Planet Once Again?

lead_paragraph: An animation explains the case for the presence of a ninth planet-size object deep in the solar system, beyond the orbit of Neptune.

headline: Kenya Rattled as Shabab Turns Sights on Somalia Military Targets

lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The attackers burst into the Kenyan military base in Somalia before dawn, blasting through the gate with a truckload of explosives.

lead_paragraph: IN THE MAGIC HOUR

headline: Pope Asks Davos Elite to Remember the Poor
abstract: In a letter to the World Economic Forum, Pope Francis wrote that “useful and dignified employment” opportunities had dwindled.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The power brokers assembled here discuss the marvels and potential of what ever-new software and robots can bring in terms of efficiency and productivity, but the Vatican has issued a more sobering message.

headline: Snipping Apart Dollar Bills, for Art’s Sake
abstract: For his latest solo outing, the artist Yuken Teruya applied his paper-cutting technique to cash, Monopoly boards and leaves.
lead_paragraph: The artist Yuken Teruya has sliced and diced Prada shopping bags, McDonald’s sacks, toilet-paper rolls and the front page of The New York Times into lush landscapes; for his upcoming solo exhibition at Pippy Houldsworth Gallery in London, he adds to this running list. Teruya took his X-Acto knives to vintage Monopoly boards, currency and cards, leaves that he collected in autumn and rolled-up wads of American dollar bills, citing an interest in the intersection of nature and value, “in all of its abstract levels.”

headline: With Vigor and Momentum, Donald Trump Urges Iowans to Caucus
abstract: Donald J. Trump, fresh off his endorsement from Sarah Palin and an attack by Iowa’s Republican governor against his top rival, Ted Cruz, implored people in the first voting state to support him in the Feb. 1 caucuses.
lead_paragraph: NORWALK, Iowa — Donald J. Trump basked in the glow of his Sarah Palin endorsement on Wednesday, proclaiming that her support, combined with criticism of Senator Ted Cruz from Iowa’s Republican governor, was a turning point for him in the state ahead of the caucuses.

headline: In Palau, Taking the Bait to Swim With Jellyfish
abstract: Learning to let go allows a visitor to enjoy a surreal playtime in a saltwater lake in the Pacific archipelago nation.
lead_paragraph: Given the opportunity, who wouldn’t jump into a lake packed with millions of jellyfish — if, of course, you knew they could not sting you?

headline: Lupita Nyong’o and Other Stars Join Oscar Protest
abstract: As Spike Lee explains he did not call for a boycott, the actress questions “unconscious prejudice,” and George Clooney and Whoopi Goldberg speak out.
lead_paragraph: Spike Lee clarified his position regarding this year’s all-white Oscar nominees in the acting categories, telling ABC on Wednesday that he never called for a boycott of the ceremony on Feb. 28, and that he and his wife would instead catch a Knicks game that night.

headline: CrossFit Promoter Accused of Defrauding Investors Reaches Plea Deal
abstract: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey said in a court filing that an agreement with Joshua Newman was reached after months of negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Joshua B. Newman, a New York entrepreneur charged last year with defrauding investors in several CrossFit training ventures, has reached a plea deal with federal prosecutors in New Jersey.

headline: An Insider Trading Case Heads to the Supreme Court
abstract: The Salman case may be a better vehicle than a previous case for the Justice Department to argue that the court should take a broader view in finding that the passing of inside information is illegal.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department got its wish on Tuesday, at least in a backhanded way, when the Supreme Court unexpectedly granted review of an insider trading conviction.

headline: App Smart | Day Trackers
abstract: A selection of apps, including Reporter, Instant and Sleep Cycle, that help you log your daily activities.
lead_paragraph: A selection of apps, including Reporter, Instant and Sleep Cycle, that help you log your daily activities.

headline: Video Feature: ‘Quantified Self’ Apps to Help Track Habits and Identify Patterns
abstract: As using technology to monitor sleep and other activities rises in popularity, these mobile applications can help you gather and assess this information.
lead_paragraph: THIS year, I’m trying to keep better track of my life. That includes tallying how much I exercise, how often I use my phone and how well I sleep. To do all of that, I’ve turned to a trend called “quantified self,” which is essentially using technology to monitor many daily activities. Not surprisingly, I’m relying on a bunch of apps for this.

headline: Chasing Votes for Hillary Clinton Among Iowa’s Undecided and Indifferent
abstract: Cindy Pollard, a star canvasser in Newton, has so far knocked on 1,500 doors in a quest to gather support for the Clinton campaign in a town where the reaction ranges from enthusiastic to hostile.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Iowa — On the coldest day of winter so far, Cindy Pollard skittered up icy walkways in her white nurse’s sneakers, trying to persuade undecided, indifferent and sometimes hostile voters to caucus for Hillary Clinton.

headline: Squabbles Persist Over Who Should Be at Syria Peace Talks

headline: Stocks Are Potential Bright Side to Lower Wall St. Compensation

lead_paragraph: It’s bonus day at Goldman Sachs. It also happens to be the day that the Wall Street company reports earnings for the final quarter of 2015.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Bolsters Ability to Build Class Actions
abstract: In a 6-3 vote, the justices ruled that courts cannot dismiss such lawsuits simply because a defendant has offered to give the lead plaintiff everything he sought.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a victory for class-action plaintiffs, the Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled by a 6-to-3 vote that courts may not dismiss lawsuits simply because a defendant has offered to give the lead plaintiff everything he sought. A contrary decision would have allowed companies accused of minor but mass wrongdoing to pick off plaintiffs one by one, frustrating their ability to band together to sue over their claims.

headline: The Fashion Blogger Behind We Wore What
abstract: Danielle Bernstein has turned her college fashion blog into a growing lifestyle brand.
lead_paragraph: Name Danielle Bernstein

headline: Inside the Louise Bourgeois House
abstract: The recessed, cluttered Chelsea townhouse where this artist lived for decades will soon open for visitors.
lead_paragraph: The recessed, cluttered Chelsea townhouse where this artist lived for decades will soon open for visitors.

headline: A Look Inside the Louise Bourgeois House, Just How She Left It
abstract: The Manhattan townhouse where this wildly original artist lived for 50 years will be opening for tours.
lead_paragraph: Unlike Paris, where the homes and studios of Auguste Rodin, Eugene Delacroix and Gustave Moreau are on the standard tourist itinerary, New York has a paucity of artist’s house museums. Painters and sculptors in Manhattan have typically inhabited lofts, and when they move on, others take over the spaces. One of the few examples is 101 Spring Street, the Donald Judd house in SoHo, which is open by reservation for tours. A pristine cast-iron building, with sunny rooms that accommodate beautifully installed Minimalist art and Judd-designed furniture, it stands as a shiny, bright masculine yang. At long last, it has its corresponding yin: the recessed, cluttered Chelsea townhouse that was occupied by Louise Bourgeois.

headline: Marco Rubio ‘Super PAC’ Portrays Ted Cruz as Fickle
abstract: The ad is intended to undercut Mr. Cruz’s efforts to present himself as a true, unwavering conservative, and focuses on his changing stances on immigration, refugees, ethanol and trade.
lead_paragraph: The “super PAC” supporting Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has turned its sights on Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, releasing two ads with companion websites attacking him, including this one, titled “Calculated.”

headline: Lessons From Vermont
abstract: Why getting to single-payer is so hard starting from here.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Kliff has a very helpful account of Vermont’s attempt to create a state-level single-payer health care system, and why it failed. It’s a bit like the old joke about the farmer, asked for directions, who says “Well, I wouldn’t start from here.”

headline: How to Make Sense of Plummeting Global Markets
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Recession and Depression', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Stock, bond and especially commodity markets have swung in ways that suggest this is a perilous time, but the cause is puzzling.
lead_paragraph: If you look only at the global economy, and what leading forecasters think it will do in 2016, things look to be in a reasonably solid state. The world economy will grow 3.4 percent this year, economists at the International Monetary Fund projected this week, up from 3.1 percent in 2015. Private sector forecasters mostly have similar expectations.

headline: Guide for Refugees in Germany Mocked as How Not to Instruct Foreigners
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Social Media']

lead_paragraph: Faced with the task of integrating hundreds of thousands of newcomers into German society, government agencies, private foundations and the state broadcast network have all been looking for ways to explain the country’s history and traditions to refugees in easily understandable public information campaigns.

headline: Prehistoric Massacre Hints at War Among Hunter-Gatherers
abstract: A dig in Kenya has uncovered the remains of a slaughter from 10,000 years ago, suggesting that warfare may have existed even before humans began agriculture.
lead_paragraph: The scene was a lagoon on the shore of Lake Turkana in Kenya. The time about 10,000 years ago. One group of hunter-gatherers attacked and slaughtered another, leaving the dead with crushed skulls, embedded arrow or spear points, and other devastating wounds.

abstract: Plus: Fivestory offers the Australian label Ellery, and discounts at Editorialist.
lead_paragraph: Escape the cold at Nike SB Garage, a pop-up indoor skate space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where you can hit the decks and try out the pro skateboarder Ishod Wair’s new shoe, the Nike Dunk Low Pro Ishod Wair ($95), which offers a retro-cool silhouette with a flexible rubber outsole for enhanced grippy traction. lead_paragraph: PARIS — The United States will convene a meeting next month of defense ministers from 27 countries participating in the fight against the Islamic State to discuss how each member of the coalition could contribute more to defeating the extremist group, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter announced on Wednesday.

headline: Rajat Gupta to Finish Insider Trading Sentence at His Home
abstract: Mr. Gupta, a former managing director of McKinsey & Company who was convicted of insider trading in 2012, will remain a federal inmate and confined to his apartment until March 13.
lead_paragraph: During Rajat Gupta’s heyday as a globe-trotting management consultant, one of the highlights of January was the World Economic Forum’s annual gathering of global business titans in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: As Water Problems Grew, Officials Belittled Complaints From Flint
abstract: Residents’ complaints about their water’s foul odor and odd color were met with irritation from Michigan officials, according to emails released by the governor.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — A top aide to Michigan’s governor referred to people raising questions about the quality of Flint’s water as an “anti-everything group.” Other critics were accused of turning complaints about water into a “political football.” And worrisome findings about lead by a concerned pediatrician were dismissed as “data,” in quotes.

headline: Senate Blocks Bill on Tougher Refugee Screening
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Vetoes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The measure, opposed by the White House, would have required officials to confirm that immigration applicants from Syria and Iraq posed no threat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bill that would have greatly tightened screening procedures on refugees from Syria and Iraq failed on a procedural vote in the Senate on Wednesday, saving President Obama from another vexing veto scenario on an issue that has divided the country.

headline: Next Installment of ‘Star Wars’ Pushed Back to End of 2017
abstract: The decision appears to have been made because of the success that “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” recently enjoyed over the Christmas and New Year holidays.
lead_paragraph: Walt Disney Studios on Wednesday created a large disturbance in Hollywood’s release calendar, delaying the next installment in the “Star Wars” series from May 2017 to December of that year – on a date that Steven Spielberg and Warner Bros. had already staked out for their “Ready Player One.”

headline: Bob Dole Warns of ‘Cataclysmic’ Losses With Ted Cruz, and Says Donald Trump Would Do Better
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bob Dole said that the Republican Party would suffer “cataclysmic” and “wholesale losses” if Ted Cruz were the Republican nominee, and that Donald J. Trump would fare better.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dole, the former Kansas senator and 1996 Republican presidential nominee, has never been fond of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. But in an interview Wednesday, Mr. Dole said that the party would suffer “cataclysmic” and “wholesale losses” if Mr. Cruz were the nominee, and that Donald J. Trump would fare better.

headline: Spread of Zika Virus Prompts Travel Advisories
abstract: Women who are pregnant or are trying to become so should talk to their doctors about the risks of traveling to areas where Zika infections have been found.
lead_paragraph: Travel warnings about the Zika virus, especially for pregnant women, are very much in the news now, but the germ was discovered more than a half century ago, and you may have already visited places where it flourishes.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2016
abstract: Haider Ackermann’s fall 2016 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Haider Ackermann’s fall 2016 men’s collection.

headline: Castleton Festival to Go on Hiatus
abstract: The festival, founded by the late conductor Lorin Maazel, announced this week that it is canceling most of this summer’s offerings due to financial difficulties.
lead_paragraph: The Castleton Festival, which the conductor Lorin Maazel founded in 2009 on his estate in rural Virginia, announced this week that it is canceling most of this summer’s offerings in what festival officials described as a “temporary hiatus” brought on by financial difficulties.

headline: Sending the Trisha Brown Legacy Back Into the World
abstract: After stops at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and in Seattle, the ailing choreographer’s company will focus on intimate works and education.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, a choreographer made dances, and extraordinary ones at that. Her works, full of wit and rigor, unfolded on rooftops and rafts and even on the sides of buildings as well as in lofts and galleries, and later on proscenium stages. And then she couldn’t make them anymore.

headline: Five Tips for Curing Winter Skin, From a Cult Facialist
abstract: From what you sip to how often you exfoliate, Kristina Holey believes both internal and external wellness work together for a great complexion.
lead_paragraph: The cult facialist Kristina Holey, whose holistic approach to skincare favors healthy habits (eating well, exercising, sleeping) over a medicine cabinet full of topical antidotes, might be the beauty industry’s worst nightmare. Her modus operandi — that there is no universal rule for the skin, and each person requires a unique regimen — rejects the idea of any products touted as a quick fix cure-all. Yet it is this long-term strategy towards skincare that has seen Holey become San Francisco’s most sought-after facialist (she opened her own skincare center in June), with clients also clamoring to see her in Los Angeles and New York, where she works out of the West Village boutique Calliope.

headline: Early-Music Ensembles: Praised as Pure, but Seeking More
abstract: Descriptions of female singers can be narrow, with purity a recurrent concept. But that’s not how the artists see it.
lead_paragraph: When the female vocal quartet Anonymous 4 retired last month, it left behind a discography spanning a thousand years of music. But the core of its repertory was medieval music in which, in plainchant passages, the four women’s voices seemed to melt together into one silky, unison line.

headline: Smart Guns and Shifty Politics As Governor Christie Runs for President
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'State Legislatures', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Governor Christie has pocket-vetoed a measure designed to encourage the development of smart guns.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has been softening his past record on gun controls with each visit to gun friendly states as he vies for the Republican presidential nomination. As rival candidates on the gun lobby’s A-list questioned his devotion to the cause, Mr. Christie reversed his previous support for an assault weapons ban — a position he strongly voiced in his earliest days of politicking for New Jersey office. In another reversal, he vetoed a ban that would have kept the controversial, armor-piercing .50-caliber rifle out of the hands of civilians.

headline: Lesson Plan | Teaching ‘Star Wars’ With The New York Times
abstract: If you’re looking for ways to bring “Star Wars” into your classroom, we offer teaching ideas for subjects across the curriculum — from analyzing Yoda’s syntax to investigating the economic consequences of destroying the Death Star.
lead_paragraph: Are your students “Star Wars” fanatics? Are you?

headline: Review: ‘Dark Net’ Explores the Digital Age’s Toll on Us
abstract: This eight-part series, which begins on Thursday on Showtime, digs into whether and how aspects of technology might be changing us as a species.
lead_paragraph: The scariness of the digital age has been the peg for a number of newsmagazine segments and docu-series, many of them not going, conceptually, much beyond “Can you believe what some people are using the Internet for these days?” “Dark Net,” an eight-part series that begins on Thursday night on Showtime, goes further, using examples of unsettling digital phenomena to ponder larger questions, like whether and how the digital age might be changing us as a species.

headline: Review: ‘London Spy’ Follows an Unlikely Investigator With Love on His Mind
abstract: This five-part BBC America mini-series, written by Tom Rob Smith and directed by Jakob Verbruggen, is a loopy mix of romance and conspiracy thriller.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard not to care about a character played by Ben Whishaw, an actor whose nimble intensity has enlivened roles from Richard II, in “The Hollow Crown” cycle, to Q in the Bond movies. But during BBC America’s “London Spy,” a five-episode mini-series (beginning on Thursday) that’s a loopy mix of love story and conspiracy thriller, you may find yourself managing it for long stretches.

headline: Review: On ‘Mad Dogs,’ an Amazon Series, Male Bellicosity Rules
abstract: This testosterone-fueled series, adapted from a British drama, focuses on the adventures of four middle-aged American men.
lead_paragraph: “American men, you love to fight,” a supporting female character observes in the very male dark-comic thriller “Mad Dogs,” whose 10-episode first season debuts Friday on Amazon Prime.

headline: Dover Street Market’s (Almost) Overnight Transformation
abstract: Twice annually, Dover Street Market undergoes what it calls a “New Beginning” — in which elaborate visual displays and new brands are installed, with select departments strikingly reconfigured. Here is how it happens.
lead_paragraph: Twice annually, Dover Street Market undergoes what it calls a “New Beginning” — in which elaborate visual displays and new brands are installed, with select departments strikingly reconfigured. Here is how it happens.

abstract: This Chicago instrumental band flirted for a while with structures easier to recognize. On its new album, it rediscovers its metier: covering its tracks.
lead_paragraph: “The Catastrophist”

headline: Russian Strikes in Syria Have Stabilized Assad, Top U.S. General Says
abstract: Russia’s campaign in Syria has probably given President Bashar al-Assad a stronger hand to play in talks next week in Geneva, American officials said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Russia’s campaign of airstrikes against opponents of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has stabilized Mr. Assad’s government, America’s top general said Wednesday. That has probably given Mr. Assad a stronger hand to play next week, when negotiations toward a political solution to the conflict will begin in Geneva, American officials said.

headline: New York City Is Set to Adopt New Approach on Policing Minor Offenses
abstract: The measures would affect low-level offenses such as littering, public urination and public consumption of alcohol, in some cases removing them from the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: New York City is poised to reshape how it treats many so-called quality-of-life offenses, softening its stance toward low-level infractions like public urination and drinking alcohol in public by steering those cases away from the criminal court system.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Vegetables', 'Currency', 'Cauliflower', 'Commodities', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Steamed, sautéed or stir-fried, cauliflower is standard fare on many dinner tables. In Canada, it is a luxury.

headline: Animal Deaths Down and Adoptions Up Amid Reforms at New York Shelters
abstract: Euthanasia rates dropped 36 percent for dogs and 25 percent for cats in 2015 as adoptions climbed 17 percent, according to statistics from the agency that runs New York’s three animal shelters.
lead_paragraph: For a place often associated with confinement, suffering and death, the city animal shelter in Manhattan was a pretty happy spot last Friday afternoon, at least in the backyard.

abstract: Ms. Palin used the incident to talk about President Obama’s relationship to the military.

lead_paragraph: David H. Koch, a philanthropist who has given millions of dollars to the American Museum of Natural History in New York but whose businesses in energy and other industries have drawn criticism from climate scientists and environmental groups, has left the museum’s board after serving on it for 23 years.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In a surprise earnings announcement, Deutsche Bank on Wednesday evening reported a huge yearly loss of 6.7 billion euros ($7.3 billion) as the cost of past wrongdoing continued to weigh on its earnings.

headline: Bette Midler, Glowin’, Crowin’, Goin’ Strong and Ready for ‘Hello, Dolly!’
abstract: The newest Broadway revival of Jerry Herman’s beloved musical, starring Ms. Midler, is set to open in the spring of 2017.
lead_paragraph: Bette Midler has never seen “Hello, Dolly!” onstage.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C.’s Patrick Vieira Acknowledges ‘Long Learning Process’
abstract: Introduced on Wednesday as New York City F.C.’s second head coach, Vieira, 39, was confident he would overcome his lack of coaching experience and unfamiliarity with M.L.S.
lead_paragraph: For the previous 11 hours, Patrick Vieira had been asked questions. But at the final stop of his daylong media marathon, which included a news conference and a dozen or so interviews, he was the one asking the questions.

headline: Review: ‘The Yid,’ Paul Goldberg’s First Novel, Taunts Stalin
abstract: The heart of this story imagines a response to the Soviet leader’s final acts of anti-Semitism in 1953.
lead_paragraph: Paul Goldberg’s provocatively titled first novel, “The Yid,” is set in the Soviet Union and begins in late February 1953, just as staggering change is about to occur. Only a small part of what the book describes is a matter of record: Joseph Stalin died on March 5 at his dacha just outside Moscow. He spent enough of his final hours unattended to give a vindictive alternative historian some wiggle room.

headline: The Sundance Film Festival Trains Its Sights on the Gun Debate
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Several selections at this year’s festival are joining the national discussion about mass shootings and gun control.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Gun violence can be an awkward subject at the Sundance Film Festival. Over the years, the event has helped popularize — some would say glamorize — extreme gun imagery in movies; Quentin Tarantino was incubated and hatched here.

headline: Review: New York City Ballet’s Winter Season Blends Movement and Music
abstract: The company performs “Barber Violin Concerto,” “Fancy Free” and “Who Cares?” under the musical direction of Andrew Litton.
lead_paragraph: In ballet, sight meets sound. When the alchemy is right, this often trivial art takes off into the stratosphere. On Tuesday, New York City Ballet, the world’s foremost specialist in this music-movement fusion, opened its six-week winter season at the David H. Koch Theater with welcome new aspects of aural accompaniment inside the auditorium (the new music director, Andrew Litton, was conducting a program of American scores, admirably) and new aspects of design around the theater’s other spaces (Marcel Dzama redecorated the main upstairs foyer with ostentatious triviality).

headline: Review: Tackling Bach, Debussy and Prokofiev at Spectrum
abstract: The pianist Taka Kigawa and the cellist Eric Edberg performed sonatas at this book-lined space on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: More important than the question of whether Bach should be played on historical or contemporary instruments is the general approach performers bring. The music always needs a buoyant touch and rhythmic vitality, elements missing from a heavy-handed interpretation of Bach’s Sonata for Viola da Gamba and Harpsichord in G (BMW 1027) by the pianist Taka Kigawa and the cellist Eric Edberg on Tuesday evening. The duo performed on modern instruments at Spectrum, a cozy, book-lined space on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: On the Milan Runway, Assembled Fragments and Disconnected Thoughts
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: A review of the fall 2016 men’s wear collections from Moncler Gamme Bleu, Canali, Calvin Klein, Prada, Etro, Gucci and Armani.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — When models start quoting Baudrillard, the creative director at Gucci name-checks Walter Benjamin and Miuccia Prada makes prints depicting Freud in a wrestling match, you know the world is upside down.

headline: Philanthropist Donates to Smithsonian’s African-American Museum
abstract: Philanthropist David M. Rubenstein has agreed to donate $10 million to the Smithsonian’s new National Museum of African American History and Culture, scheduled to open next fall.
lead_paragraph: The businessman and philanthropist David M. Rubenstein is donating $10 million to the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture, the Smithsonian announced Wednesday.

abstract: Michigan's governor released hundreds of pages of emails regarding Flint's lead-contaminated water supply.
lead_paragraph: Michigan's governor released hundreds of pages of emails regarding Flint's lead-contaminated water supply.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
