headline: Davos Participants Seek Out ‘Stardust’ Moments
abstract: For the ultrarich and influential, the value of the World Economic Forum is not so much hearing about the next big thing. It is the opportunity to network.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — At the World Economic Forum here, heads of state, billionaire investors and corporate chiefs meet to discuss the state of politics and regulation, and tackle the biggest challenges facing societies globally. This year, they are sending warning signals about the state of the markets.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Sarah Palin, Pakistan, Flint
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Be a French Girl. Or Just Look Like One.
abstract: The cultish Repetto has opened its first boutique in the United States, in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: “The fog comes on little cat feet,” Carl Sandburg wrote in a 1916 poem, and he might have been talking about Kate Moss slinking around London for the last two decades in her trusty black ballet flats. The shoe itself has a feline cast — it rounds the foot into a pawlike shape — but there’s also something feline about the women, like Ms. Moss, who have popularized ballet flats over the years.

headline: Happy Hour Without the Booze
abstract: Without the fog of alcohol, young professionals focus on meditation, massage, music and the exchange of business cards.
lead_paragraph: On a recent rainy afternoon over veggie burgers at NeueHouse, the co-working space in the Flatiron district, three Vedic meditators were discussing drink options for a new kind of happy hour they were organizing.

headline: Where Wearable Technology Ends Up (Hint: Not Your Wrist)
abstract: Smartwatches, fitness trackers and other devices are supposed to better our lives, but the gadgets often sit idle and collect dust.
lead_paragraph: The junk drawer in my home used to look just like yours, filled with loose change, batteries and birthday candles. But over the last year, a new category of junk has started to accumulate there: wearable devices.

headline: ‘Races of Mankind’ Sculptures, Long Exiled, Return to Display at Chicago’s Field Museum
abstract: A new exhibition explores a series of works that were once denounced as “white racist pseudo anthropology.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For decades, the bronzes created by the artist Malvina Hoffman for the Field Museum’s “Races of Mankind” exhibit have had a ghostly afterlife at the institution. Hailed at their unveiling in 1933 as “the finest racial portraiture the world has yet seen” and viewed by millions of visitors, the sculptures were banished to storage in 1969, embarrassing relics of discredited ideas about human difference.

headline: The Many Lives of Limelight
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Maybe a many-chambered Chinese “vibe dining” experience will succeed where several other restaurants, another nightclub and an urban mall have failed.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Harry Chapin going into Cat Stevens into the Beatles into James Taylor into Bob Marley, and then around 10, 11 o’clock, Jay Z and Guns n’ Roses escalating the whole vibe,” Stratis Morfogen said on a recent evening.

headline: Treasury Secretary Visits Puerto Rico and Urges Fast Action
abstract: Jacob J. Lew said, “Only Congress can enact the legislative measures necessary for Puerto Rico to resolve this problem.”
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — On his first official visit to the commonwealth, the Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, said the financial crisis on the island was deepening and he urged Congress to act quickly to give the government the power it needs to restructure all of its debt.

headline: Obama Relaxes Rules for Striking ISIS in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Terrorism', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: The change reflects growing concerns within the government about the militant group’s emerging role in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has made it easier for the military to get approval for strikes in Afghanistan targeting militias that have sworn allegiance to the Islamic State, according to several government officials.

headline: Crumbling, Destitute Schools Threaten Detroit’s Recovery
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: Detroit’s public schools are failing academically and nearly insolvent, leaving residents to wonder how the city can recoup its lost population.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In Kathy Aaron’s decrepit public school, the heat fills the air with a moldy, rancid odor. Cockroaches, some three inches long, scuttle about until they are squashed by a student who volunteers for the task. Water drips from a leaky roof onto the gymnasium floor.

headline: To Fight ‘Superbugs,’ Drug Makers Call for Incentives to Develop Antibiotics
abstract: In a declaration to be released at the World Economic Forum, more than 80 companies say government help and better reimbursement is needed to fight the problem of drug-resistant germs.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 pharmaceutical and diagnostic companies from around the world are calling for new economic models to spur development of badly needed new antibiotics and to fight the rising global threat of drug-resistant “superbugs.”

headline: How New York's Shelters Keep Animals Alive
abstract: The euthanasia rate for animals at three city shelters has plummeted to 13 percent, from more than 60 percent in 2003.
lead_paragraph: The euthanasia rate for animals at three city shelters has plummeted to 13 percent, from more than 60 percent in 2003.

headline: My Sarah Palin Romance
abstract: Palin, Trump and the search for a decent right-wing populism.
lead_paragraph: As a political journalist, you never forget the first time you stop just covering a politician and start identifying with her. The first time you wed your high-minded vision of what politics should be to a real candidate’s perishable breath.

headline: Ex-Rikers Guard Sentenced to Jail in Attack on Inmate Causing Vision Loss
abstract: Victor Rodman was sentenced to 90 days in jail for beating a Rikers Island inmate, who sustained a broken nose and lost vision in one eye.
lead_paragraph: A former New York City correction officer was sentenced to 90 days in jail on Wednesday for beating a Rikers Island inmate, who sustained a broken nose and lost vision in one eye.

headline: Panel Backs Janet DiFiore for New York Chief Judge; Senate Puts Off Vote
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'State Legislatures', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The full chamber is expected to take up Ms. DiFiore’s nomination to lead the Court of Appeals on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Everything seemed primed on Wednesday for the Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, to receive its new chief judge. There were words of praise for the nominee, Janet DiFiore, and a unanimous vote of approval from the State Senate Judiciary Committee.

headline: California Said to Target Exxon in Climate Inquiry
abstract: California appears to have joined New York in weighing Exxon Mobil’s honesty in admitting to the risks posed by climate change.
lead_paragraph: California’s attorney general is investigating Exxon Mobil on whether the company lied to the public and shareholders about the risks of climate change, and whether the company’s statements over the years constitute violations of securities laws and other statutes.

headline: Officials Object to Plan to Turn Hart Island Burial Site Over to Parks Dept.
abstract: New York City’s potter’s field is run by the Correction Department and visits are restricted, involve paperwork and are limited to relatives.
lead_paragraph: It was a vision to beguile many New Yorkers: an all-but-forgotten island in Long Island Sound that a noisy city would transform into its most tranquil park. And there was a concurrent vision for the families of the dead long buried there, on Hart Island: a cemetery now run like a prison would become a place to freely mourn.

headline: Pay Cuts for Top Leaders at Viacom
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: In a filing, Viacom said it cut the pay of its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, about 85 percent, while also cutting the pay of the chief executive, Phillipe P. Dauman.
lead_paragraph: Viacom cut the annual pay for its executive chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, by 85 percent during the 2015 fiscal year, the company disclosed on Wednesday, in the face of growing questions about whether Mr. Redstone, an ailing 92-year-old, should continue in his role at the company.

headline: U.S. Drops Bombs Not Just on ISIS, but on Its Cash, Too
keywords: ['Currency', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: American warplanes have struck nine depots where the group is believed to have stashed tens of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With sanctions, blacklists and other measures doing little to financially break the Islamic State, the United States has turned to a far simpler tactic to empty the group’s coffers: It is literally blowing them up.

headline: Colleagues Express Disbelief Over Arrest of Doctor With Picture-Perfect Life
abstract: Dr. David H. Newman, accused of groping patients in an emergency room in Manhattan, was a prominent advocate of health care reform.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David H. Newman seemed to have it all: an impressive post in emergency medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital, a prominent and growing public presence as an expert in health care reform, a wife who is a doctor, two young sons, and a gracious home in the New Jersey suburbs.

headline: Jack Dorsey Juggles Twitter and Square, Both Caught in Downdraft
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The volatility of the companies’ shares have hit Jack Dorsey in the wallet. Twitter will report its earnings on Feb. 10, and Square will reveal its first public earnings in March.
lead_paragraph: It is not shaping up as a happy new year for Jack Dorsey and his two companies.

headline: A Queens Nun With a Talent for Begging
abstract: Sister Elisabeth Anne has been visiting the Hunts Point Produce Market for more than 35 years, soliciting donations of food to help the Queen of Peace Residence in Queens.
lead_paragraph: To some of the workers at the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx, it is a familiar sight: a nun or two darting around the concrete loading docks every Wednesday. Sister Elisabeth Anne, 76, has been making the weekly trip to the large industrial market for more than 35 years to pick up food for the older adults at the residence where she lives and works.

headline: Wilkes Bashford, Clothier to Affluent San Franciscans, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Bashford’s clothing emporium catered to elegance-conscious San Franciscans for a half-century.
lead_paragraph: Wilkes Bashford, a clothier whose eponymous emporium is famous for having dressed affluent, elegance-conscious San Franciscans for the last half-century, died on Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 82.

headline: Efforts to Drop Charges Against Cosby Are Meritless, Prosecutor Says
abstract: A district attorney in Pennsylvania hit back at attempts by Bill Cosby’s legal team to drop criminal charges against the entertainer.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania prosecutor on Wednesday hit back at efforts by lawyers for Bill Cosby to have the criminal charges against Mr. Cosby dismissed, describing their claim that a former district attorney made a promise not to prosecute the entertainer a decade ago as meritless.

headline: Big 5 Teams Celebrate Milestone With Throwback Doubleheader at Palestra
abstract: The Big 5 staged a 60th anniversary celebration in a fitting way, with a doubleheader at the Palestra, a tradition that had not taken place since December 2004.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — More than 50 years later, the memory remains as clear as ever for Don DiJulia. He will never forget Feb. 20, 1965, when a men’s college basketball game between St. Joseph’s and Villanova was interrupted after the police received a call at halftime saying a bomb had been planted in the stands.

headline: Two Sides of Ted Cruz: Tort Reformer and Personal Injury Lawyer
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Legal Profession', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: The candidate, a strong supporter of tort reform, reaped big payouts defending multimillion-dollar personal injury awards as an appellate lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz says his uncompromising purity as a conservative crusader helped propel him to the top of the Republican presidential field. But his history suggests that when the cameras are off, a different Mr. Cruz emerges.

headline: Ettore Scola, Italian Film Director of Satire and Farce, Dies at 84
abstract: In more than 40 films directed over 40 years, Mr. Scola focused on people always haplessly swept along by the tides of their times.
lead_paragraph: Ettore Scola, a Golden Globe winner and five-time Oscar nominee who was considered among the great directors and screenwriters of Italian cinema, died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 84.

headline: Buffalo Adds Woman to Coaching Staff
abstract: Kathryn Smith, named as Buffalo’s special teams quality control coach, becomes the first full-time female member of an N.F.L. coaching staff.
lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Bills hired the first full-time female coach in the N.F.L. on Wednesday when Kathryn Smith was appointed their special teams quality control coach.

headline: Michel Tournier, French Novelist Who Fused Myth and Philosophy, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Tournier’s “Ogre,” the story of a French prisoner of war who procured boys for an elite Hitler youth camp, won the Prix Goncourt, in 1970.
lead_paragraph: Michel Tournier, a French novelist who blended myth and philosophy in prizewinning novels that revisited “Robinson Crusoe,” Goethe’s elf king and the biblical tale of the Three Magi, died on Monday at his home in Choisel, near Paris. He was 91.

headline: Republicans Unseat Mississippi Democrat Who Drew Winning Straw After Race Ended in Tie
abstract: A veteran Democratic lawmaker was removed from office by a Republican-dominated House on a technicality, giving Republicans the ability to pass revenue-related bills.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — First, the re-election bid of State Representative Blaine Eaton II of Mississippi ended in a statistically improbable tie. Then — bizarrely, but in keeping with Mississippi statute — the outcome was decided by a drawing of straws, which he won.

headline: 2 Lawyers Leaving Paul, Weiss to Form Boutique Firm
abstract: Beth Wilkinson and Alexandra Walsh are founding Wilkinson Walsh + Eskovitz with Sean Eskovitz of Munger, Tolles & Olson.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent lawyers at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison are breaking away and forming their own litigation boutique with lawyers from other firms.

headline: Film Academy, Under Fire, Is Expected to Take Steps to Improve Oscar Diversity
abstract: One change might be an immediate return to a 10-film field of best picture nominees, some people briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is expected to announce as early as next week measures aimed at making its Oscar choices more diverse, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Is Closing to Become a Ballroom
abstract: The Ziegfeld, which will reopen next year for galas and corporate functions, has been a movie theater, which replaced the 1927 theater built by Florenz Ziegfeld.
lead_paragraph: The famed Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan will close its doors in the coming weeks, and reopen next year as an event space that caters to galas and corporate functions, the building’s owner said on Wednesday.

headline: Trial Explores Whether Towns Discriminate Against Nonmembers of Polygamous Sect
keywords: ['Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Polygamy']
abstract: A federal complaint accuses the towns of Colorado City, Ariz., and Hildale, Utah, of discriminating against people who are not members of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When an unfamiliar car drives into the small neighboring towns of Colorado City, Ariz., and Hildale, Utah, private security agents working for the polygamist sect that dominates the towns ask the local marshals, who act as the police for both towns, to run the license plates to see who is passing through, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Executive in U.N. Corruption Case Pleads Guilty
abstract: Shiwei Yan was part of a scheme to funnel bribes to an Antiguan diplomat who served for a year as president of the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese-born executive accused of helping to funnel more than $800,000 to a top United Nations official pleaded guilty to bribery on Wednesday, the second guilty plea in a week in the government’s continuing investigation of corruption at the United Nations.

headline: Misnomer on Skates: John Scott, N.H.L. All-Star, Is Neither in N.H.L. Nor a Star
abstract: A successful Internet campaign landed Scott, a Coyotes brawler, a captaincy in the N.H.L. All-Star Game. The problem? He was then traded to the Canadiens and sent to the minor leagues.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — The captain of the Pacific Division team for the N.H.L. All-Star Game skated onto the ice of a less-than-half-full minor league arena on Wednesday, wearing a St. John’s IceCaps jersey. The game against the Bridgeport Sound Tigers was just another stop on his wacky road to becoming an N.H.L. All-Star.

headline: Hillary Clinton Dismisses Bernie Sanders’s Criticism of Groups Backing Her
abstract: Mrs. Clinton defended Planned Parenthood, the Human Rights Campaign and other Democratic-leaning organizations and labor unions that have endorsed her candidacy.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Iowa — Hillary Clinton on Wednesday defended Planned Parenthood, the Human Rights Campaign and other Democratic-leaning organizations and labor unions that have endorsed her candidacy and that her main opponent, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, has deemed part of the “establishment.”

headline: Among N.F.L. Coaches, a Lack of Diversity Trickles Up
abstract: The number of minority head coaches has stagnated, and new research suggests this is due to a shortfall in the hiring of minority assistant coaches.
lead_paragraph: The usual scramble of firing and hiring N.F.L. coaches displayed perhaps a touch more impatience this year: Some coaches were dismissed even before the season ended.

headline: Donald Trump Is Forcing Ted Cruz to Rewrite His Playbook
abstract: On the campaign trail, Mr. Cruz has been testing several strategies to dent Mr. Trump’s popularity. But true to form, Mr. Trump has complicated his path.
lead_paragraph: WHITEFIELD, N.H. — Ted Cruz did not have to say a cross word about Scott Walker. Rick Perry and Bobby Jindal faded on their own. And when Ben Carson briefly rocketed to the top of the Iowa polls, Mr. Cruz and his team stayed cool, confident that the neurosurgeon’s support would wither.

headline: Filing Alleges Bias at Success Academy Network Against Students With Disabilities
abstract: Parents of 13 current and former students of Success Academy filed a complaint against the charter school network with the federal Department of Education.
lead_paragraph: Parents of 13 current and former students of Success Academy filed a complaint with the Office of Civil Rights with the federal Education Department on Wednesday, accusing the charter school network of discriminating against students with disabilities by denying them accommodations and in some cases pushing them out.

headline: Central African Republic: Hunger Threatens Population, U.N. Warns
abstract: Nearly half the people in the country are now facing hunger, the main food aid agency of the United Nations said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 2.5 million people in the Central African Republic — half the population — are now facing hunger, double the figure from a year ago, the main food aid agency of the United Nations said Wednesday. The agency, the World Food Program, attributed the increase to years of conflict and insecurity that have kept people from tending their fields and livestock, exacerbated by a poor harvest. “This is not the run-of-the-mill emergency,” Guy Adoua, the agency’s deputy director for the country, said in a statement. “People are left with nothing.” The agency called for an emergency cash infusion of $41 million from donor countries to deal with the crisis.

headline: Attorney General Seeks Funding for Tighter Gun Rules
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: Republicans showed little sign of finding any common ground with Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch on solutions to gun violence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans warned on Wednesday that they would fight President Obama’s attempts to impose tougher gun restrictions in the wake of the San Bernardino shooting, and they accused him of doing an “end run” around the Second Amendment.

headline: Massacre Came as Pakistan University Honored a Hero of Nonviolence
keywords: ['Pashtun (Ethnic Group)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Terrorism', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: At least 20 people were killed amid preparations for a poetry recital in honor of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, a peaceful Pashtun leader for whom the school was named.
lead_paragraph: The university attacked by the Pakistani Taliban on Wednesday was named for a towering figure in Pakistani history — a nonviolent Pashtun activist who became known as the “Frontier Gandhi” for his advocacy of nonviolent resistance to British colonial rule.

headline: Review: ‘Our Mother’s Brief Affair,’ a Play About Unmoored Lives
abstract: Richard Greenberg juxtaposes a generational then and now to consider how little we know about the lives that shape our own.
lead_paragraph: Every mother is Greta Garbo to her children, at least upon occasion. The woman you were closest to in the world, the one who weaned and wiped you, could suddenly seem so ravishingly remote it was scary. What was really on her mind those nights she tucked you into bed, deliciously lipsticked and perfumed for an evening out?

headline: Amtrak Says New York Region’s Rail Projects Could Cost Up to $23.9 Billion
abstract: The largest share of about $7.7 billion would go toward building the new Hudson tunnel and repairing the existing tunnel.
lead_paragraph: Amtrak officials on Wednesday provided the most detailed public account yet for the projected costs of building a new Hudson River rail tunnel and improving other critical parts of the rail infrastructure in the New York region.

headline: Off-the-Record Discussion
abstract: In which we try to figure out David Phillips’s central point.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’ve watched every episode of “L.A. Law” and selected parts of “Perry Mason” on YouTube, so I consider myself to be somewhat of a legal expert. This expertise came in handy today as I tried to solve David Phillips’s crossword about SIDEBARS, because I was able to recognize that, from a totally legal and professional point of view, a SIDEBAR is one of the most efficient ways to inject drama into an otherwise mundane court proceeding, second only to pounding one’s fist on the table and shouting “Objection, Your Honor!” At least on television.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says He Would Defend U.S. ‘Responsibly’
abstract: The commercial stresses Mr. Sanders’s opposition to the war in Iraq, as well as the human toll from the conflicts that are raging in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Income inequality and greedy billionaires are neither seen nor heard from in Senator Bernie Sanders’s sober-minded new foreign policy ad, “Defend This Nation.”

headline: De Blasio Backer, Convicted of Sexual Abuse, Fails to Show Up for Jail Sentence
abstract: Ari Noe, who was found guilty in 2013, helped organize Mayor Bill de Blasio’s two-day visit to Israel in October.
lead_paragraph: One of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s leading supporters in New York’s Orthodox Jewish community failed to appear in court this week to begin a 15-day sentence on a previously undisclosed conviction for misdemeanor sexual abuse, and a warrant has been issued for his arrest.

headline: With a New Child, Laying Claim to the Comforts of Home
abstract: Kayla Medina lived with nine foster families in five years. After the birth of her son, she found a place she could finally call her own.
lead_paragraph: Kayla Medina’s apartment in Harlem, where she lives with her infant son, Kayden, is simple and small. He crawls around their living room floor, his interest shifting among his toys. He will turn 1 in April; Ms. Medina turned 21 this month.

headline: Scarsdale Woman Is Stabbed to Death in Her Home
abstract: A 58-year-old woman was killed in the Westchester County suburb, and a man who lived with her, possibly her husband, was detained by the police, officials said.
lead_paragraph: SCARSDALE, N.Y. — A 58-year-old woman was fatally stabbed on Wednesday inside her home in this Westchester County village, the authorities said. A man who also lived in the home, possibly the woman’s husband, was detained by the police, officials said.

headline: Mets Add Antonio Bastardo to Bullpen
abstract: Antonio Bastardo, a left-handed reliever, appeared in 66 games for the Pirates, striking out 64 in 571/3 innings with a 2.98 E.R.A.
lead_paragraph: It was not a splashy move, but the Mets made a ripple in the free-agent waters on Wednesday. They reached an agreement with Antonio Bastardo, a left-handed reliever, on a two-year, $12 million contract.

headline: As Amir Hekmati Sat in an Iranian Prison, Michigan Supporters Kept His Name in the News
abstract: While Mr. Hekmati did not know about the level of support for him, Representative Dan Kildee said, Iranian government officials were constantly made aware of it.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — After four and a half years in an Iranian prison, Amir Hekmati will return to a community where people he never knew fought to make sure the world knew his name.

headline: Cavaliers, Coming Off a Drubbing, Dish Out Punishment Against the Nets
abstract: The Cavaliers pounded the Nets in an unattractive game on Wednesday. After a 34-point drubbing by the Golden State Warriors on Monday, it was the result they had to have.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. regular-season schedule presents many challenging markers for every team from October to April, including difficult games on consecutive nights, cross-continental trips and fierce division rivalry games.

headline: Porzingis, Lured by Pump Fake, Learns Lesson as Knicks Prevail
abstract: Gordon Hayward baited Porzingis into fouling him on a 3-point attempt, allowing Utah to tie the game and force overtime, but the Knicks survived to even their record at 22-22.
lead_paragraph: It was late on Wednesday night, much later than usual, when Derek Fisher’s postgame news conference finally wound down.

headline: Asian Markets Follow U.S. Stocks Downward
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Fears about China and oil that had sent global markets down on the previous day affected Asian markets again on Thursday, but European and American markets were higher.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Markets in Asia sank on Thursday, as traders surrendered to the fears that had sent shares tumbling in Japan, Europe and the United States the previous day.

headline: Centenarians Proliferate, and Live Longer
abstract: The number of Americans age 100 and older — those born during Woodrow Wilson’s administration and earlier — is up by 44 percent since 2000, federal health officials reported Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Move over, millennials. The centenarians are coming.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | brocade
abstract: This word has appeared in 51 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: brocade • \bro-ˈkad\ • noun and verb

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The whole system is warming up, relentlessly.”

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: Undercover lovers in “London Spy,” Glenn Frey soars in “History of the Eagles” and Zach Galifianakis clowns around in “Baskets.”
lead_paragraph: A man investigates his undercover lover in “London Spy,” BBC America’s latest espionage mini-series. Glenn Frey recounts his time soaring in “History of the Eagles.” And Zach Galifianakis tries to elevate clowning to an art in “Baskets.”

headline: ‘The X-Files’: David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson Return to the Paranormal Beat
abstract: They gained fame as Mulder and Scully more than 20 years ago. Now, they seem more comfortable than ever in their roles.
lead_paragraph: NORTH VANCOUVER, British Columbia — There they were in the midst of what looked like a spooky old-growth forest (Princess Park, actually, mere blocks from upscale suburban homes here), surrounded by clumps of moss, overgrown ferns and gigantic Douglas firs, looking for clues of yet another allegedly paranormal crime, the kind they used to solve almost every week. They addressed each other, as they always had, by only their last names.

headline: Who Is Leading the South Carolina Polls
abstract: A look at the latest results for Iowa and New Hampshire, and how this year compares to previous election seasons.
lead_paragraph: A look at the latest results for Iowa and New Hampshire, and how this year compares to previous election seasons.

headline: European Central Bank Says It’s Ready for New Stimulus — but Not Yet
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: Saying “conditions have worsened,’’ Mario Draghi, the central bank president, indicated that new measures might come in March.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank’s president, Mario Draghi, issued a stronger-than-expected signal on Thursday that his policy team could step up its stimulus program as early as March in response to stubbornly low inflation and turbulence in the financial markets.

headline: Among North Africa’s Berbers
abstract: Ferhat Bouda has made it his mission to document his people, the Berbers, whose culture and language have been suppressed over the centuries.
lead_paragraph: Ferhat Bouda has made it his mission to document his people, the Berbers, whose culture and language have been suppressed over the centuries.

headline: 미래의 창업가 키우는 데 힘 쏟는 미국 대학들
abstract: 취업이 쉽지 않고, 실리콘 밸리에서 계속해서 들려오는 스타트업 성공 사례에 고무된 학부생들은 대학 교육을 통해 아이디어를 성공적인 비즈니스로 키우는 법을 배우고자 한다.
lead_paragraph: 휴스턴 — 1891년에 작성된 라이스대학 헌장을 보면 문학과 과학, 예술을 창달하기 위해 학교를 세웠다고 쓰여 있다. 요즘 라이스대학을 보면 차세대 마크 저커버그를 키워내는 데도 그만큼 많은 힘을 쏟고 있는 것 같다.

headline: Putin ‘Probably Approved’ Litvinenko Poisoning, British Inquiry Says
abstract: The finding represented by far the most damning official link between the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, an ex-K.G.B. officer, and the highest levels of the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the dank, dark days of November 2006, as Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer turned foe of the Kremlin, lay dying in a London hospital, he and his associates composed a deathbed missive to President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Self-Driving Cars May Get Here Before We’re Ready
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Urban Areas', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Only a few states have passed laws relating to the testing of autonomous cars, and no state expressly allows a completely unmanned vehicle on the road.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIME in the future — although no one quite knows when — your morning commute may look something like this: Open an app, summon a car and wait for the arrival of a driverless vehicle that will whisk you to work like a ghost chauffeur.

headline: The Republican Establishment Is Losing at Its Own Game
abstract: The party, seemingly helpless to stop Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, is not taking advantage of the strengths that usually allow it to be a power broker.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a month ago, Ted Cruz tweeted: “The Establishment’s only hope: Trump & me in a cage match.”

headline: Among North Africa’s Berbers
abstract: Ferhat Bouda has made it his mission to document his people, the Berbers, whose culture and language have been suppressed over the centuries.
lead_paragraph: The first day Ferhat Bouda picked up a camera, he found his calling.

headline: Palin, Trump, Cruz and Corn
abstract: Sarah surfaces and Ted gets trounced for the wrong reason.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin is really falling apart.

headline: Kentucky’s Bizarre Attack on Health Reform
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Gov. Matt Bevin’s pointless show of defiance could harm thousands of people.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Matt Bevin of Kentucky is dismantling the state’s highly successful exchange on which people buy private health insurance policies or enroll in Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. His shortsighted and pointless show of defiance against the Obama administration’s health care reforms could harm thousands of people in Kentucky, who may fall between the cracks as the state shifts their coverage from its own exchange, known as Kynect, to the federally run exchange at HealthCare.gov.

headline: The Poisoning of Flint’s Water
keywords: ['Poisoning and Poisons', 'Water', 'Lead', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: It is hard to imagine such a thing happening in a city that didn’t have this particular demographic profile — mostly black and disproportionately poor.
lead_paragraph: In November, I was the guest speaker at the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan’s annual dinner. Before I spoke, the group called to the stage a longtime investigative journalist who had done tremendous work bringing the Flint water crisis to light. His name was Curt Guyette. He, in turn, recognized the scientists, doctors, politician, lawyers and activists who had helped in that quest.

headline: Scalia’s Putsch at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: In recent years, the Supreme Court has waved the First Amendment banner ever higher to undermine long-accepted governmental regulatory authority.
lead_paragraph: IN his vitriolic dissent last June from the Supreme Court’s same-sex marriage decision, Justice Antonin Scalia accused the majority of having carried out a “judicial putsch.” Justice Scalia should know. He and his four conservative colleagues were then in the process of executing one themselves.

headline: An Important Win in the Supreme Court for Class Actions
abstract: The justices properly ruled that companies can’t avoid class actions by buying off individual plaintiffs.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court gave an important victory to regular Americans, ruling that companies may not avoid class-action lawsuits by offering to buy off the individual plaintiffs before they can establish a class of similarly harmed people.

headline: America the Unfair?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We need to leverage populist frustration into constructive postelection policy. It’s been done before.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders don’t agree on much. Nor do the Black Lives Matter movement, the Occupy Wall Street protests and the armed ranchers who seized public lands in Oregon. But in the insurgent presidential campaigns and in social activism across the spectrum, a common thread is people angry at the way this country is no longer working for many ordinary citizens.

headline: Republicans Ignore a Poisoned City
abstract: Republicans talk about their commitment to the poor. So why haven’t we heard the party’s candidates talk about the crisis in Flint, Mich.?
lead_paragraph: EVER since I became a conservative as a teenager growing up in the city of Flint, Mich., I’ve heard again and again from Republican leaders about their commitment to minorities and the poor. Even today, we are told that conservative solutions exist for persistent poverty, for joblessness, for the masses of people, like those in my hometown, who live lives of quiet despair. House Speaker Paul Ryan has been especially eloquent on this point. If only Republicans would get a chance to prove it.

headline: Does Iran Remain a Threat?
abstract: Despite the accord that reduced its ability to build nuclear weapons, is it still a threat to safety and stability of the region?

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Barclays plans to scale back its operations in Asia, end its physical presence in several countries and eliminate what could be hundreds of jobs in the latest reshaping of its investment bank under a new chief executive, James E. Staley.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Volkswagen is staking out an aggressive response to its emissions-testing crisis in Europe, where most of the affected vehicles were sold, by essentially saying: We didn’t cheat here.

headline: Viewing Los Angeles Through a Creole Lens
abstract: The segregation that was a vestige of slavery caused many to leave New Orleans. But why Los Angeles?
lead_paragraph: The pulse of the train on the tracks sets a rhythm as its passenger cars seem to skim over Lake Pontchartrain in New Orleans. These six miles of nothing but sky above and water below are the gateway into the city by rail. Next come the cemeteries at the edge of New Orleans, and all of a sudden, a day and a half of travel ends at the Amtrak terminal in the business district. I had just completed the first leg of my cross-country journeyby sleeper train, starting in New York, and was beginning the second: a foray into the cultural ties between the Crescent City and California.

headline: ‘Let the People Rule,’ by Geoffrey Cowan
abstract: How conventions ceased to be the means for choosing presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: The 1912 presidential contest was the first in which many of the delegates to a party convention were nominated directly by voters in primaries rather than by party insiders in a number of states. Thirteen states held Republican primaries, and Theodore Roosevelt won nine of them. “The right of the people to rule,” he said at Carnegie Hall, is “the great fundamental issue now before the Republican Party.”

headline: Full Report of the Litvinenko Inquiry
abstract: Findings by Robert Owen, a retired High Court judge in Britain, present the most damning official link between the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko in 2006 and the highest levels of the Kremlin.

headline: Acupuncture Offers No Benefits Over Placebo for Hot Flashes of Menopause
abstract: Women receiving acupuncture showed some easing of menopausal symptoms, but the effects were no better than that of a sham treatment.
lead_paragraph: Acupuncture is no more effective for menopausal hot flashes than a sham version of the procedure, a randomized trial has found.

headline: The Right Way to Stretch Before Exercise
abstract: A new review of studies suggests that those forsaken static stretches of old may not be so bad after all.
lead_paragraph: For generations, gym students were taught to stretch before working out or playing games. Then the practice fell out of favor: Studies seemed to show that such ‘‘static’’ stretching (holding a pose for anywhere from a few seconds to several minutes) temporarily reduces muscular power, weakens athletic performance and increases the risk of injury. So most fitness experts currently advise against static stretches before exercise. But now a comprehensive new review of decades’ worth of research indicates that they might not be such a bad idea after all.

headline: At Pravue Cafe, Albanian Home Cooking in Queens
abstract: Family recipes share the menu with dishes that lean to the West.
lead_paragraph: The fries at Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill taste as if they have taken a tumble in a perfect bowl of ramen and have somehow still emerged crisp. First fried, then baked, they arrive slightly sticky with a truffle glaze and pecorino Romano gone lax in the oven. But the verve comes from Vegeta, a synthesis of salt, sugar, spice and dehydrated vegetables engineered a half-century ago in Yugoslavia.

headline: Ways to Be Free
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: On paper, the world is freer than ever. Yet minds feel more crimped, fear more pervasive, escape more elusive.
lead_paragraph: When you grew up in an unmapped, unwired world and find yourself in this one — observing the panic when GPS fails or the extent of online status anxiety — you can’t help wondering if somewhere along the way freedom got lost.

headline: Pearson, Ex-Owner of Financial Times, to Shed 4,000 Jobs
abstract: The move comes as the troubled British publisher, which makes the bulk of its sales from its educational-testing activities in the United States, forecast weaker profit.
lead_paragraph: Pearson, the troubled British publisher, said on Thursday that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs worldwide as part of a continuing restructuring by the former owner of The Financial Times and The Economist to shift its focus primarily to its international education business.

headline: Rockefeller Foundation to Take Food-Waste Fight to Davos
abstract: The group plans to announce a $130 million initiative to tackle the problem, including reducing the amount of thrown-out crops and excess food at the dinner table.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The World Economic Forum suffers from no shortage of lofty goals — its theme two years ago was no less than “reshaping the world” — and the gathering of global power players still lends itself to high-minded ideals.

keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While most Republican presidential candidates are intent on bashing Congress and its members, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, who served 18 years in the House, has played up his relationships forged on Capitol Hill, sometimes reaching far back.
lead_paragraph: With Congress so unpopular, most Republican presidential candidates are intent on bashing the institution and its members. Not so with Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, who served 18 years in the House before leaving in 2001 and evidently has fond memories of his Capitol Hill years.

abstract: The joys of project cooking in the winter.
lead_paragraph: Cooking is not always about simplicity and ease. Sometimes, particularly when it’s cold outside and the dark comes early, what you want in the kitchen is a project, a culinary jigsaw puzzle to solve. There is no greater one than cassoulet.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Tech-Firm Snacks
keywords: ['Snack Foods', 'Workplace Environment', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Free Doritos don’t transform a workplace into a cool pad.
lead_paragraph: Tom writes: I work for a big tech firm that offers its employees free snacks. A colleague of mine thinks it’s acceptable to conceal his favorite snacks behind other items to retrieve them later. I think this is unfair. All of us should have the chance to serendipitously discover a delicious treat.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Sleep, ‘Dopesmoker’
abstract: An epic stoner-metal song that is almost religious in its ambition.
lead_paragraph: The origin story of ‘‘Dopesmoker’’ sounds like a light-bulb joke co-written by Nancy Reagan and Sisyphus: Three California stoners decide to write a song about how much they love marijuana, but they’re so high that it takes them four years. When they finally deliver the song to their record label, the label refuses to release it. And so the band breaks up without the world hearing their wonderful heavy-metal jam about weed. Don’t do drugs. The end.

headline: Kamasi Washington’s Giant Step
abstract: With his popular, political, uncategorizable jazz, the young saxophonist has become something his genre rarely produces anymore: a celebrity.
lead_paragraph: On a late October afternoon in South Central Los Angeles, Kamasi Washington was facing what is for him an increasingly familiar problem: making a lot of big ideas fit into a single space, even one as large as the nearby Club Nokia, a rock-star-size venue where he would be performing in December. His recent triple album, ‘‘The Epic,’’ is a nearly three-hour suite for a 10-piece jazz band, backed by a 32-piece orchestra and a 20-person choir. Washington’s show promised to be a typical swirl of activity, a sprawling procession of dancers, musicians, DJs and singers unified by the magisterial sound of Washington himself, a 34-year-old tenor saxophonist who has emerged as the most-talked-about jazz musician since Wynton Marsalis arrived on the New York scene three decades ago.

headline: Let Me Tell You About My Big Baby

lead_paragraph: With the help of the Simon and Garfunkel song “America,” Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has released a powerful 60-second commercial in Iowa that seeks to remind his supporters how far he, and they, have come — and to inspire them anew to caucus for him on Feb. 1.

headline: ‘Grease: Live’ Prepares for the Small Screen

Going first, second, third isn’t easy.”

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Why Use an Old Photo?
abstract: An editor explains the reason behind publishing a 2002 photo with a news story about a recent Jakarta bombing.
lead_paragraph: A reader, Alyssa Pack, wondered about the use of a 14-year-old photograph to accompany a recent news story about a bombing in Jakarta. She called it disappointing and potentially misleading to readers. Ms. Pack added: “There are several photos from the most recent attack, so I do not understand the purpose of using the one from 2002.”

headline: 1891: King Kalakaua Is Embalmed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The body of King Kalakaua of Hawaii is embalmed in San Francisco in 1891.
lead_paragraph: The body of the late King Kalakaua was embalmed at San Francisco last night, and to-day the remains were placed in a metal casket hermetically sealed, and conveyed to the mortuary chapel in Trinity Church, where they will be guarded by United States soldiers. The remains will not lie in state, and will not be exhibited to the public. At one o’clock on Thursday afternoon funeral services will be held at Trinity Church. King Kalakaua’s body will be taken from San Francisco by Rear-Admiral Brown to Honolulu in the United States cruiser Charleston. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 22, 1891

headline: Republicans Take Aim at Marco Rubio With Negative Ads

headline: Editing a Gmail Inbox Trip Bundle
abstract: When incorrect information strays into a Trip Bundle, there is a way to remove it, and Google has recently made that easier to do.
lead_paragraph: Q. I generally like the way Gmail Inbox collects all the messages related to travel, and groups them together so I have my flight information, hotel and rental car under one heading on my Android phone. However, I noticed that for a coming trip, the collected information has me listed in the completely wrong hotel. I don’t know how this happened, but can I get rid of the incorrect information in the Trips grouping?

headline: Kelly Zutrau of the Band Wet Has Plenty to Say
abstract: The group will release its debut album and set out on tour. “I’m not scared that we won’t have things to write about anymore,” Ms. Zutrau says.
lead_paragraph: The band Wet is obsessed with endings. “I think we better quit while we’re ahead,” the songwriter and singer Kelly Zutrau announces on the single “You’re the Best.” But this is only the beginning of the road for this moody New York and Massachusetts electro-R&B trio. After building buzz last year with a barrage of immaculate singles and appearing on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon,” the band will release its debut album, “Don’t You,” on Friday, Jan. 29, on Columbia Records. It will also tour the United States and Europe, with stops at the Bowery Ballroom on Jan. 28 and Rough Trade in Brooklyn on Jan. 29; unannounced major festival dates are looming on the horizon.

headline: ‘The Body of an American’ Visits Battle Zones of the Field and the Heart
abstract: The poet-playwright Dan O’Brien has a collaborative bond with the former war photographer Paul Watson, manifested in “The Body of an American.”
lead_paragraph: One body you won’t see in the seats for “The Body of an American,” Dan O’Brien’s play at the Cherry Lane Theater starting Feb. 10, is its main subject and inspiration, the Canadian war reporter and photographer Paul Watson. Not because Mr. Watson, 57, is dead or incapacitated — he has cooperated happily with Mr. O’Brien’s requests for documents and recordings from his work and life, and he participates willingly in post-show talk-backs when he can.

headline: Lincoln Center Festival Announces Summer Season
abstract: The festival, which will feature 49 performances at seven different venues at Lincoln Center and beyond, will run from July 13 through 31.
lead_paragraph: The Lincoln Center Festival announced Thursday that its summer lineup would include the familiar and the new, including Noh theater, Shakespeare, music by Steve Reich, ballet, and, for the third time, appearances by Goran Bregovic, a Balkan musician and composer, and his Wedding and Funeral Orchestra.

headline: Assessing the Road to the Syrian Peace Talks
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: A look at the hurdles and the possibilities related to the negotiations diplomats hope to begin on Monday.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Diplomats have been working nonstop this week to set the groundwork for Syrian peace talks that were scheduled to, but will not, begin on Monday in Geneva. On Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry and Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, met in Zurich to discuss the matter, but the meeting broke up inconclusively. On Thursday, Mr. Kerry said that the talks would take place soon, delayed by a day or two, but that the rivals would not sit in the same room. It was a stark measure of the gulf between them.

headline: Brooklyn Rider Gets a New Cellist
abstract: Michael Nicolas will replace Eric Jacobsen, a co-founder of the group who is leaving to concentrate on conducting.
lead_paragraph: One-fourth of the innovative string quartet Brooklyn Rider will soon change: Eric Jacobsen, its cellist, plans to leave to concentrate on conducting, the group said on Thursday. He will be replaced by Michael Nicolas, a classmate of his at the Juilliard School who has played with other groups dedicated to new music, including the International Contemporary Ensemble

headline: Ted Cruz Mines Donald Trump’s Twitter Feed for Policy Shifts
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media']
abstract: Ted Cruz, who is fending off attacks from Donald J. Trump on his policies and personality, has been digging around in Mr. Trump’s Twitter archives and pointing to inconsistencies in the billionaire developer’s stances on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz, who is scrambling to come up with ways to fend off sustained attacks from Donald J. Trump on his policies and personality, has been digging around in the archives of Mr. Trump’s Twitter feed.

headline: As Jeb Bush Struggles, Some Allies Blame His ‘Super PAC’
abstract: Right to Rise has raised more than $100 million to help Mr. Bush secure the Republican nomination. Critics say it has little to show for it.
lead_paragraph: When Jeb Bush and his allies began helping the “super PAC” supporting him raise more than $100 million last year, his bid for the Republican nomination seemed like a safe bet. But as Mr. Bush’s campaign continues to lag, his backers are increasingly turning their frustrations over his floundering candidacy on the group, Right to Rise, and its inability to influence the race.

headline: Review: ‘Youngblood,’ an Urgent Novel About the Iraq War
abstract: The book, by Matt Gallagher, looks at what young American soldiers experienced during their deployments.
lead_paragraph: Matt Gallagher’s 2010 memoir, “Kaboom: Embracing the Suck in a Savage Little War,” grew out of a popular blog he wrote while stationed in Iraq for 15 months, beginning in 2007. By turns thoughtful and irreverent and darkly funny, that book possessed an electric immediacy — a you-are-there sense of what it was like to be a grunt in the hot desert sands outside Baghdad, hunting for I.E.D.’s and bomb factories, negotiating with local sheikhs and frightened civilians, and grappling with the absurdities of military bureaucracy.

headline: China Uses Foreigners’ Televised Confessions to Serve Its Own Ends
keywords: ['Propaganda', 'Confessions', 'Television', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: A Swedish man’s confession on state television is the latest case of China broadcasting self-criticism as propaganda for an audience of hundreds of millions.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For seven years, the young Swedish man had directed a nongovernmental organization in Beijing that offered legal aid to Chinese citizens in trouble. Now he was a captive of China’s legal system, forced in police detention to speak on video about his so-called crimes.

headline: 1941: U.S. Lifts Embargo on Russia
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The State Department lifts a “moral embargo” against the Soviet Union in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a surprise move late tonight [Jan. 21], the State Department announced the lifting of President Roosevelt’s ‘‘moral embargo’’ against the Soviet Union by which American manufacturers were prevailed upon not to ship airplanes, aeronautical equipment and materials essential to airplane manufacture to nations resorting to unrestricted aerial warfare against civilian populations. There is a catch remaining, however, in the fact that, although the ‘‘moral embargo’’ has been lifted against Russia, all the articles covered by the embargo are now subject to the export license system. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 22, 1941

headline: Below the Line: Designing ‘The Martian’
abstract: A look at the production design for life on Mars in “The Martian.”
lead_paragraph: The secret to building a believable-looking Mars on screen? Rocks, plenty of rocks.

headline: Works Sighted: Ursula Le Guin on the Oregon Occupation
abstract: “Ammon Bundy and his bullyboys aren’t trying to free federal lands,” the novelist and longtime Oregon resident wrote, “but to hold them hostage.”
lead_paragraph: Ursula Le Guin, the author of the famous “Earthsea” series and a longtime Oregon resident, was displeased with The Oregonian’s coverage of the armed occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge. In a letter to the editor of the paper, she wrote:

headline: Donald Trump or Ted Cruz? Republicans Argue Over Who Is Greater Threat
abstract: Conservative intellectuals fear Mr. Trump will spell the end of conservatism, while the cadre in Washington fears Mr. Cruz will build a new party machine and bypass them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz battling for the Republican nomination, two powerful factions of their party are now clashing over the question: Which man is more dangerous?

headline: Kevin Spacey an Unusual Davos Suspect
abstract: Global leaders have attended the World Economic Forum in the past. This year, the actor who plays the president on “House of Cards” is making the scene.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — President Obama may not be here at the World Economic Forum, shaking hands with fellow dignitaries as the snow flurries swirl. But another American president — albeit a fictional one — has been a talk of the town this week.

headline: Key Findings From the Litvinenko Report
abstract: A summary of the report by Robert Owen, a retired High Court judge in Britain, on the killing of Alexander V. Litvinenko.
lead_paragraph: A summary of the report by Robert Owen, a retired High Court judge in Britain, on the killing of Alexander V. Litvinenko.

headline: Video Review: Chevy Volt Impresses With Tech, Design and Driving Pleasure
abstract: The second-generation Chevy Volt, a plug-in hybrid available this spring, is more efficient than its predecessor, looks better and is about $1,000 less expensive. It’s also fun to drive.
lead_paragraph: THE concept of the first Chevrolet Volt was simple — drive 40 miles or so on battery power alone and then continue the journey with a gas-powered generator. In short, driving to Duluth could be a drop-of-the-hat decision. From Anchorage.

headline: Iggy Pop and Josh Homme Team Up for ‘Post Pop Depression’
abstract: The album, which reflects on memories and offers advice and confessions, is scheduled to be released in March.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Now that you’re all greased up, how about ‘Lust for Life’?” Iggy Pop said in a voice that was part Midwestern twang, part grizzled prospector to his new band as they rehearsed at a North Hollywood studio. Although it was Mr. Pop’s first time singing with the group, which had been preparing on its own, the mood shifted quickly from tension to elation. After each song, Josh Homme of Queens of the Stone Age, who assembled the musicians, asked Mr. Pop if he wanted to wrap up, but Mr. Pop kept calling for more: first new songs and then oldies from “The Idiot” and “Lust for Life,” his two late-1970s collaborations with David Bowie. Mr. Pop, 68, wore a dark, patterned shirt, baggy black pants and sandals. He had started the rehearsal seated, conserving his energy, but by the end he was strutting.

headline: Kent State Professor Investigated for Possible Ties to ISIS
abstract: The F.B.I. is investigating Julio Pino, an educator in the history department known for incendiary remarks like “death to Israel.”
lead_paragraph: An associate professor at Kent State University in Ohio is under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation over possible involvement with the Islamic State.

headline: How Much Should a University Have to Reveal About a Sexual-Assault Case?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Football (College)', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']
abstract: I sued the University of Montana to find out — and the implications of the case reach far beyond the state.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the United States Department of Education got serious about addressing campus rape. In a 19-page “Dear Colleague” letter that was sent to almost every American college and university, the department reminded institutions of their obligation, under the federal law known as Title IX, to protect students from sexual violence. Universities that failed to take “prompt and effective steps” to investigate and adjudicate allegations of sexual assault, the letter warned, risked losing millions of dollars in federal funding. Most institutions took heed and adopted the policies laid out by the department.

headline: Dresses Our Brides Have Worn
abstract: A selection of wedding day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.
lead_paragraph: A selection of wedding day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Refuses Offer of Release After 14 Years in Prison
abstract: Mohammed Ali Abdullah Bwazir balked at the last minute, afraid to go to a country where he has no family, his lawyer said. Two others were freed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three Guantánamo detainees were slated to leave the American prison in Cuba this week after about 14 years in captivity. But early Wednesday morning, only two were willing to board the plane.

headline: Sarah Palin’s Facebook Fans Say Backing Donald Trump Is Disingenuous
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Endorsements', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Sarah Palin maintains a community of millions of Facebook fans, and while some cheered her endorsement of Donald J. Trump this week, others called her a sellout of conservatism who was only seeking another moment in the political spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin made her return to national politics this week with a rousing endorsement of Donald Trump, praising the billionaire developer for his penchant for “going rogue” and lashing out at Republicans who say he is not sufficiently conservative.

headline: High-Rise Living Linked to Lower Survival After Cardiac Arrest
abstract: The higher the floor you live on, the lower your chance of surviving a cardiac arrest, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: The higher the floor you live on, the lower your chance of surviving a cardiac arrest, according to a new study.

headline: ‘Dear Yeti’ and ‘The Thing About Yetis’
abstract: In two charming new picture books, the abominable snowman has been entirely defanged.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, the Yeti — who back then went by the more formal and forbidding name “abominable snowman” — was a creature capable of stirring up serious fear. Like the Loch Ness monster, this gigantic people-eating being actually existed, we children knew. There were, predictably, adult doubters. That made the question of whether he was merely mythical a topic every curious child had to investigate. My own research resulted in a habit of mind I’ve carried with me all these years, swinging between a creeping horror at all the unsettling supernatural realities most adults are too thick-headed to even acknowledge, and that feeling that comes after a good debunking — a mixture of emotional comfort, intellectual pleasure and condescending pity aimed at the still benighted myth-believers.

headline: Lydia R. Diamond’s ‘Smart People’ Begins Previews at Second Stage
abstract: Ms. Diamond’s play, having its New York premiere, focuses on four racially diverse characters with connections to Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Lydia R. Diamond, whose “Stick Fly” was seen on Broadway in 2011, dives again into thorny territory in “Smart People,” which begins previews Tuesday, Jan. 26, at Second Stage Theater. Set just before President Obama’s first election, the play explores the romantic interactions and careers of four racially diverse characters, all with ties to Harvard University.

headline: Platonic, Until Death Do Us Part
abstract: How I reached another level of love and respect by allowing myself to be comfortable in a relationship.
lead_paragraph: Please check out the newly launched Modern Love: The Podcast.

headline: The Beauty Parlors of Bangladesh
keywords: ['Beauty Salons', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A blow-dry is never just a hairdo here. It’s a rich signifier of status and aspiration.
lead_paragraph: Dhaka, Bangladesh — EVERY winter, I return here to my hometown, and every year, I feel a little shabbier. This time, when I was meeting a few old school friends at a neighborhood cafe, I finally understood why: the blow-dry. Everyone else had one. Everyone else had gone to the beauty parlor, and I hadn’t.

headline: Building the Future in Israel
abstract: The Jewish state is most secure when its Arab citizens share in the promise of prosperity.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Dizengoff Street in Tel Aviv is always bustling. Youngsters, families and tourists fill its shops, cafes and bars. On Jan. 1, this boulevard became the site of another terrorist attack on Israelis. First, two young men were gunned down in a bar; then, as he fled the scene, the terrorist killed a taxi driver. Several others were injured.

headline: Former Academy President Says Film Industry Needs More Diversity
abstract: The former president, Hawk Koch, called for the formation of diversity committees by all of the various Hollywood craft and business groups to “extend opportunities to those without it.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Thursday suggested in an unusual open letter to the entertainment industry that calls for an Oscar boycott be superseded by a broad effort to hire “African-Americans, Hispanics, Asians, women, LGBTs, the disabled and all under-represented groups.”

headline: A Pinot Noir From Argentina That Stands Out in a Sea of Malbecs
abstract: Bodega Chacra, a biodynamic estate in northern Patagonia, is producing wines that are rare in the region.
lead_paragraph: MAINQUÉ, Argentina — The flat, dry Río Negro Valley on the northern end of Patagonia won’t strike anybody as a glamorous wine region. For one thing, apple and pear orchards, along with platoons of poplar trees, far outnumber grapevines. For another, the restaurants, hotels and the usual camp followers of the winemaking life are nowhere to be found.

headline: Dov Charney Argues in Court for His Return to American Apparel
abstract: Mr. Charney, who was fired from American Apparel in 2014, said that the board conspired to wrest control from him and that his alliance with investors was the only way to save the company.
lead_paragraph: Dov Charney, the colorful ousted founder of American Apparel, made a last-ditch effort to wrest back control of the company on Thursday, accusing former partners of stealing away his multimillion-dollar empire and declaring that his new alliance with investors was the only way to save it.

headline: Marco Rubio, After Hitting Chris Christie, Is Suddenly All Too Glad to Go at Jeb Bush
abstract: Showing the jumbled state of the race for right-of-center Republican primary voters in New Hampshire, Senator Marco Rubio was more than happy to assail the conservative heterodoxy of his onetime mentor, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has directed much of his fire on the campaign trail in recent weeks at Gov. Chris Christie, using town halls in this state and in Iowa to unfurl a long list of the New Jersey governor’s deviations from conservative orthodoxy.

A third employee, whose child died of an illness last year, often posted pictures of his surviving child on Facebook in hopes of a brighter future.

headline: A Prolific New York Photographer Comes Back Into Focus
abstract: Saul Leiter, who documented fashion and street life for seven decades, is the subject of a new retrospective in London.
lead_paragraph: “You could almost say he had a lifetime of being continually rediscovered,” says Margit Erb, the director of the Saul Leiter Foundation. Leiter, who died in 2013, just shy of his 90th birthday — had a varied seven-decade career, and gained his most significant recognition in the last years of his life, with the 2006 publication of his book “Early Color.” “I think his rise back to fame was because people just couldn’t help stumbling over and over him, and realizing that the world needed to know him,” Erb says.

headline: Zika Virus May be Linked to Surge in Rare Syndrome in Brazil
abstract: Brazilian officials said that Zika, a virus linked to brain damage in infants, may be causing an increase in the number of cases of Guillain-Barré, an autoimmune condition.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to severe brain damage in infants may be causing another serious health crisis as well, Brazilian officials and doctors warn: hundreds of cases of a rare syndrome in which patients can be almost completely paralyzed for weeks.

headline: The Past Haunts Oxford Debate Over Rhodes Statue
abstract: Is the campaign to remove the statue about unhealed colonial wounds or fear among Westerners that their version of history may be sacrificed?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — High above a main thoroughfare in the city of Oxford, in an alcove framed by twirly columns, a statue of Cecil John Rhodes, the archimperialist who shaped Britain’s empire and the destiny of its far-flung subjects in Africa, peers down inscrutably on the people below. If you weren’t looking for it, you might miss it.

headline: Marco Rubio Steps Up Attacks On Ted Cruz, Calling Him a Flip-Flopper

keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

headline: De Blasio Vows Better Coordination as New York Prepares for Snowstorm

headline: Review: ‘Aferim!’ Traverses an Unforgiving Romania in the 1800s
abstract: Romania’s entry for consideration at the Academy Awards for best foreign-language film, Radu Jude’s historical drama has resonance in our present age.
lead_paragraph: Do you need another reason to be mad about the Oscar nominations? Well here’s one, expressed as tradition demands in the form of a hashtag: #WhataboutAferim! “Aferim!” — the title translates more or less as “Attaboy!” — is Radu Jude’s sublime new feature, a funny and brutal costume drama with a potent contemporary kick. Officially submitted for consideration as Romania’s official entry in the best foreign-language film sweepstakes, it was omitted from the final list of five nominees.

headline: Cow Is Captured by the Police After Running Loose in Queens
abstract: The cow, which had escaped from a slaughterhouse, was corralled by officers after it darted into a parking garage.

headline: Husband of Scarsdale Doctor Is Charged in Her Fatal Stabbing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: Jules Reich, a partner in a financial services company, was charged in the death of his wife, Dr. Robin Goldman, the first murder in the Westchester County village in over 40 years.
lead_paragraph: SCARSDALE, N.Y. — Robin Goldman was a doctor who made a career caring for children, and a teacher who showed young doctors how to do the same. But her own children said it was her role as mother that she seemed to covet most.
