abstract: Yohji Yamamoto’s fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Yohji Yamamoto’s fall 2016 show.

headline: Pacino Leads ‘China Doll’ to Broadway Profitability
abstract: Despite negative reviews, David Mamet’s play has recouped its investment.
lead_paragraph: “China Doll,” a critically panned but commercially successful new David Mamet play starring Al Pacino, has recouped its $3.7 million investment costs.

headline: Review: ‘Prescription Thugs,’ a Confessional Documentary on Substance Abuse
abstract: Chris Bell, using his own family as a window onto the subject, examines why Americans take far too many prescription drugs.
lead_paragraph: Even before a “do as I say, not as I do” twist costs it all credibility, “Prescription Thugs” is a not very good documentary about a very important subject.

headline: Rate of Birth Defect of Abdominal Wall Increasing, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The rate of gastroschisis has increased about 30 percent since 1995, the agency reported. For young black mothers, the increase was 263 percent.
lead_paragraph: A serious birth defect is appearing in maternity wards with increasing frequency, and experts do not know why, federal researchers reported on Thursday.

headline: Review: Vanessa Williams, Strong and Steady, Without Taking Chances
abstract: In her concert, which opened Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, Ms. Williams projected the persona of a hard-working, self-possessed entertainer.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Williams operates in so many arenas, it has always been difficult to figure out who she really is — beyond being an attractive, disciplined, highly competent singer and actor who seems equally comfortable in front of a camera, in a recording studio and on the stage. In her 90-minute concert on Wednesday evening at the Appel Room, which opened Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, the persona she projected was a hard-working, self-possessed entertainer with a clear perspective on her show business lineage.

headline: Marc-André Hamelin Gradually Ups the Ante at Carnegie Hall
abstract: This acclaimed pianist’s recital ranged from Mozart, Ravel and Liszt to the New York premiere of his own “Pavane Variée.”
lead_paragraph: In a delightfully perverse bit of programming, the esteemed pianist Marc-André Hamelin opened his Carnegie Hall recital on Wednesday evening, after a hero’s welcome from the audience, with Mozart’s unassuming Sonata in C (K. 545) — in the composer’s words, “a little piano sonata for beginners.”

headline: U.S. Tightens Visa Rules for Some European Visitors
abstract: Travelers who hold dual citizenship from Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria, or have visited one of those countries in the last five years, may no longer participate in the visa-waiver program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced changes to a visa-waiver program that would make it harder for travelers to enter the United States from Europe if they had dual citizenship from Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria, or had visited one of those countries in the last five years.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs: How the Four Conference Championship Teams Match Up
abstract: On Sunday, with a trip to Super Bowl 50 at stake, the Patriots will face the Broncos and the Cardinals will face the Panthers.
lead_paragraph: 3:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS. Line: Patriots by 3.

headline: Review: Wet Ink Ensemble Pays Tribute to Anthony Braxton
abstract: At National Sawdust, a headlong performance drawn from more than two decades of Mr. Braxton’s long career.
lead_paragraph: A marching tune that dissolves into frenzy, a big-band jamboree with an ethereal voice hovering over it: The dense, wild, yet artfully controlled tribute to Anthony Braxton at National Sawdust on Wednesday evening bore a striking resemblance to his dense, wild, yet artfully controlled music.

headline: Frank Lloyd Wright House in Los Angeles Will Be Auctioned
keywords: ['ANTIQUES', 'Design', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Auctions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Art', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze']
abstract: The 1,200-square-foot home, built in 1939 in the city’s Brentwood section, will be offered separately from most of its period furnishings.
lead_paragraph: A 1,200-square-foot house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed to perch on a Los Angeles hillside will be auctioned next month, with most of its contents sold separately.

headline: Review: ‘Martyrs,’ a Slashing Remake, Centers on Two Friends
abstract: This film features women caught up in revenge, torture and the supernatural.
lead_paragraph: For those who care deeply about the provenance of their entertainment (and I am sometimes among them), the filmmaking brothers Kevin and Michael Goetz describe their new project, “Martyrs,” as a “reimagining” of Pascal Laugier’s 2008 original of the same name. Without seeing the earlier movie, I can’t comment; but after enduring this one, I can only wonder why the brothers would cop to any creative input at all.

headline: This Time, Cheaper Oil Does Little for the U.S. Economy
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Economy', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Oil’s downturn may not have helped the economy because more oil is being produced domestically, and consumers may not be spending their windfalls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been a truism of the American economy for decades: When oil prices rise, the economy suffers; when they fall, growth improves.

headline: 36 Hours in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic
abstract: More than simply a base for the beaches, this energetic city combines a vibrant night life with graceful, centuries-old buildings.
lead_paragraph: More than simply a base for the beaches, this energetic city combines a vibrant night life with graceful, centuries-old buildings.

headline: The Italian Artist Enrico Baj at Luxembourg & Dayan
abstract: A survey of the artist’s work reflects a postwar mood of absurdity.
lead_paragraph: “Enrico Baj” at Luxembourg & Dayan is a hoot and an eye-opener. Surveying about 16 years of works in several modes, the exhibition reintroduces the Italian artist Enrico Baj (1924-2003) to New York after an absence of three or four decades. This townhouse gallery is overflowing with his works, which confirms quite emphatically that there is more to postwar Italian art than the relatively pure abstraction of artists like Lucio Fontana, Piero Manzoni and Alberto Burri.

headline: Elisabeth Moss and Boyd Holbrook’s Sundance Tips and Truths
abstract: The actors, starring in “The Free World” at this year’s festival, share thoughts on making the most of Park City — and some “Making a Murderer” theories.
lead_paragraph: Among the most anticipated titles in competition at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival, kicking off today and running through Jan. 31 in Park City, Utah, is “The Free World,” an atmospheric drama from first-time filmmaker Jason Lew. The film stars Boyd Holbrook as a man wrongfully imprisoned for a grisly crime he didn’t commit who, upon his release, meets an equally scarred woman (played by Elisabeth Moss of “Mad Men”) who again turns his life upside down. The two actors and friends are no strangers to Sundance — Holbrook first attended in 2011 with the drama “Higher Ground,” directed by Vera Farmiga, and Moss made her first trip in 2013 for the Sundance Channel series “Top of the Lake.” Here, they share a few things they’ve learned along the way.

headline: Ann Veronica Janssens Casts Strong Beams at Bortolami
abstract: In this exhibition, the artist’s first solo show in America, six works display Ms. Janssens’s gift for manipulating light and texture.

headline: Freeport-McMoRan Battles the Oil Slump
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze', 'Gold', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Commodities', 'Metals and Minerals']
abstract: Once an aggressive bidder for trophy assets, the company now finds itself in the position of a desperate seller as the price of oil and other commodities falters.
lead_paragraph: For a look at the damage that the plunging price of commodities — especially oil — is inflicting on the global economy, consider the plight of the venerable Freeport-McMoRan.

headline: Here’s How an Artist Plays the Stock Market
abstract: Sarah Meyohas sits in a Chelsea gallery trading on her laptop, charting her performance on the wall.
lead_paragraph: In her first Manhattan solo exhibition, Sarah Meyohas inventively recycles the genre of the artist performing live in a gallery. Wearing her own elegant design of a businesswoman’s suit, with gold pinstripes on sheer gray fabric, Ms. Meyohas sits at a chic, all-glass desk in the middle of 303 Gallery. Hanging on the gallery walls around her are 10 blank white canvases.

headline: Walking the Walk in Hamilton’s Old Stomping Grounds
abstract: Jimmy Napoli, a New York City tour guide and Alexander Hamilton expert, is leading a new tour focusing on his favorite founding father.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Napoli is not throwing away his shot.

headline: Dana DeGiulio and Molly Zuckerman-Hartung Make an Emphatic Statement in ‘Queen’
abstract: This exhibition at Lyles & King showcases the work of two painters who are both obsessed with gesture and meaning.
lead_paragraph: Two painters, long based in Chicago, have moved to New York, and “Queen,” their joint exhibition at Lyles & King, is a dramatic statement signaling their arrival. This is Dana DeGiulio’s first show in New York; Molly Zuckerman-Hartung, who was  in the last Whitney Biennial, had a solo here in 2011. For both, however, this is a notable group of works.

headline: A Step Toward Measuring California’s Water
abstract: New regulations will require farmers and others to track how much water they take from the state’s rivers and streams.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest problems facing California during its drought has been its failure to accurately measure water use, especially by farms. New regulations adopted by the state’s water board on Tuesday are a big step toward a solution.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Open Up Strong Leads in Iowa, Poll Shows
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump have opened up solid leads in Iowa less than two weeks before the state’s caucuses kick off the 2016 presidential nominating contests, according to a new poll.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump have opened up solid leads in Iowa less than two weeks before the state’s caucuses kick off the 2016 presidential nominating contests, according to a poll released Thursday.

headline: And You Thought You Loved Broadway
abstract: Stories and photos from some of the several thousand enthusiasts set to attend the first BroadwayCon in New York.
lead_paragraph: Stories and photos from some of the several thousand enthusiasts set to attend the first BroadwayCon in New York.

headline: Money Grows on Anniversary Trees
abstract: Plus: a right to email privacy; questions regarding a mother’s dementia; and wearing one’s credentials.
lead_paragraph: My daughter surprised my husband and me with an awesome 25th anniversary party. On her invitation, she asked guests to give money toward our second honeymoon instead of gifts. All gave generously. We know our daughter meant well, but we are so embarrassed. My husband wants me to return the money with notes of apology. But my friend says, “Why steal people’s joy in giving?” I don’t know what to do.

headline: Review: ‘Tosca,’ From NYCO Renaissance, Puts a Grand Ambition to the Test
abstract: The company that reorganized New York City Opera presents its first production, starring Kristin Sampson, at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Seldom has so much ridden on a single production of Puccini’s “Tosca.” After months of legal wrangling over the fate of the New York City Opera, which filed for bankruptcy protection in late 2013, a group called NYCO Renaissance won approval for its plan to reorganize the company. It began the effort Wednesday night with the opening of a six-performance run of “Tosca” at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 men’s collection from Dries Van Noten.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 men’s collection from Dries Van Noten.

headline: Brady vs. Manning
abstract: On Sunday in Denver, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning will face off in the N.F.L. playoffs for the fifth and possibly final time. Here’s a look at their previous postseason meetings.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday in Denver, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning will face off in the N.F.L. playoffs for the fifth and possibly final time. Here’s a look at their previous postseason meetings.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Big, Baggy Pants
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: At the Paris men’s shows, designers including Christophe Lemaire, Dries Van Noten, Gosha Rubchinskiy and Rick Owens have emphasized volume.
lead_paragraph: Volume has been a big theme at the men’s shows this season, with several collections featuring oversize silhouettes and exaggerated proportions. Big fur coats popped up in London, and already throughout the first two days of Paris Fashion Week, designers including Y/Project and Raf Simons have shown extra-large knits and coats with long, trailing sleeves. But perhaps the most practical interpretation of volume is evident in slouchy pants — which this season have been cut wide through the legs. At Rick Owens, the baggy style (complete with cargo pockets) resembled that of a ’90s raver. Christophe Lemaire deftly balanced his creased-front trousers with tailored coats, while Dries Van Noten paired a double-breasted blazer with generous trousers. And at Gosha Rubchinskiy, sweatpants — worn high, à la Al Bundy — came with a tucked in T-shirt and military shirt. Finally, we may just see the demise of the bare ankle in 2016.

headline: Ted Cruz Goes Local in Latest South Carolina Ad
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The senator appeals to the state’s Army-minded voters in a new commercial that highlights his promise to be tough on terrorists by investing more in the military.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is appealing to potential voters in South Carolina’s Midlands region in a new advertisement called, simply, “Midlands.”

headline: Britax Car Seats Recalled After Handle Breaks
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Child Car Seats', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: Britax Child Safety said it is recalling 71,000 infant car seats in the United States, citing one report of the handle breaking and a baby being injured.
lead_paragraph: Britax Child Safety is recalling about 71,000 child car seats in the United States because the carrying handle may break, allowing the infant carrier to be dropped, the company reported on Thursday in a regulatory filing.

headline: Review: Dark Suspicions in Jumps and Gestures in ‘The Winter’s Tale’
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s take on Shakespeare’s play, a co-production of the Royal Ballet and the National Ballet of Canada, comes to the Kennedy Center.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Christopher Wheeldon’s “The Winter’s Tale” — the first ballet to dramatize that Shakespeare play — achieves an extraordinary amount. Movingly, over three acts, it takes us on a great arc of emotion and experience, capturing the play’s themes of death and regeneration, hostility and reconciliation. When it takes liberties with aspects of the story, it does so persuasively. Its five leading roles — three for women, two for men — are marvelously distinct, while never seeming like copies of other roles in the repertory.

headline: Events That Led to Flint’s Water Crisis
abstract: Timeline of the critical moments leading to the public health emergency.
lead_paragraph: Timeline of the critical moments leading to the public health emergency.

headline: Review: David Parsons Shares the Stage at Joyce Theater
abstract: Parsons Dance, which returned to the Joyce Theater for a two-week run, included dances by two former company members, Robert Battle and Katarzyna Skarpetowska.
lead_paragraph: This season, David Parsons shares the wealth — or, at least, the stage of the Joyce Theater — by including dances by two former company members: “Train” (2008), by Robert Battle, now the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater — a percussive jolt of a dance, powered by raw, manic athleticism; and the world premiere of “Almah,” by Katarzyna Skarpetowska, a subtle look at her Polish roots.

headline: New Biggest Prime Number = 2 to the 74 Mil ... Uh, It’s Big
abstract: A prime number is one that can be divided by only 1 and itself. A PC at a Missouri university has found one with more than 22 million digits.
lead_paragraph: The largest known prime number, newly discovered, is almost five million digits longer than the previous record-holder.

headline: A Multitude of Fans, With a High Regard for Broadway
abstract: Thousands from around the world are arriving in New York for BroadwayCon, a theater-themed variation of the popular Comic-Con.
lead_paragraph: THE intense global and commercial nature of contemporary pop culture fandom is catching up with Broadway, and with it comes people like the 19-year-old Helen Fredstam, who arrived from Sweden this week to meet face to face with those who share her passion.

headline: U.S. Presses for Haiti Runoff Vote Amid Fears of Violence and Fraud
keywords: ['Elections', 'United States International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Many in the country denounced the first round and one of the two candidates in a runoff set for Sunday has dropped out, making it a one-person race.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — After spending more than $33 million on a widely discredited election in Haiti, the United States has been pressing the country’s leaders to go ahead with a presidential runoff election this Sunday, despite a growing chorus of warnings that the vote could lead to an explosion of violence.

headline: Alexander Litvinenko and the Banality of Evil in Putin’s Russia
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'International Relations', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: A decade ago, the ex-spy’s murder captivated the country. Now it’s just background noise.
lead_paragraph: Today, a retired British High Court judge named Robert Owen published a 328-page report on the 2006 death in London of Alexander Litvinenko, a former agent of Russia’s Federal Security Service, the F.S.B. Nine years after Litvinenko went bald and wasted away in a London hospital bed, from poisoning with a rare radioactive isotope, Owen’s report found that there was “strong circumstantial evidence of Russian state responsibility” and that the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and the head of the F.S.B. likely sanctioned the murder.

headline: At the Outsider Art Fair, the Creative Impulse Is in Its Raw Glory
abstract: Now in its 24th year, the fair features works by familiar names like Henry Darger as well as lesser-known artists.
lead_paragraph: Now in its 24th year, the fair features works by familiar names like Henry Darger as well as lesser-known artists.

headline: Court Rejects a Bid to Block Coal Plant Regulations
keywords: ['Coal', 'States (US)', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Air Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A lawsuit by at least 27 states to stop the rule, which could eventually shut down hundreds of coal-fired power plants, is to be heard on June 2.
lead_paragraph: In a significant victory for President Obama, a federal appeals panel on Thursday rejected an effort by 27 states and dozens of corporations and industry groups to block the administration’s signature regulation on emissions from coal-fired power plants while a lawsuit moves through the courts.

abstract: Since the museum opened to great fanfare in 1877, it has drawn millions of visitors, including the dinophiles who are lured by the fearsome giants in the Dinosaur Hall.
lead_paragraph: The titanosaur that clomped into the American Museum of Natural History last week has big footprints to fill, and not just those of the Barosaurus it booted.

headline: With These Cards, Every Hand’s a Winner
abstract: Exquisitely drafted playing cards from the 15th and 16th centuries — most of them from Germany — are on display at the Cloisters.
lead_paragraph: PICK up a deck of cards. Shuffle, cut, deal. Now, take a look at your hand. It may be a winner or a loser. That’s up to chance. But it is a dead certainty that the visual spectacle will be dull. Diamonds, clubs, spades and hearts are the same from deck to deck, printed uniformly. The king, queen and jack wear more or less the same costume. Boring.

headline: Laszlo Nemes Narrates a Scene From ‘Son of Saul’
abstract: The Hungarian director discusses the opening sequence of his debut feature, which received an Oscar nomination for best foreign language film.
lead_paragraph: “Son of Saul” begins with a long, out-of-focus shot. A man (Geza Rohrig) walks toward the camera until he’s suddenly in sharp close-up. And just as suddenly, the camera is following him through a chaotic outdoor scene.

headline: We Asked, You Answered: Your Favorite Blizzard Things
abstract: Tell us three things you look forward to when you’re planning to stay inside and watch the snow fall.
lead_paragraph: Tell us three things you look forward to when you’re planning to stay inside and watch the snow fall.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Top Cleric Forbids Chess, but Players Maneuver
abstract: The country’s grand mufti said the game was “the work of Satan,” like alcohol and gambling, despite its long history in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia’s top cleric has declared the playing of chess “forbidden,” calling it a waste of time and money that creates hatred between players.

headline: After Delay, Janet DiFiore Is Confirmed as New York’s Chief Judge
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Ms. DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney, was approved to lead New York’s highest court, the Court of Appeals, by a full vote of the State Senate.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The morning after a procedural hiccup left New York’s highest judicial post vacant for an extra day, the nominee, Janet DiFiore, was confirmed by a full vote of the State Senate.

headline: Republicans Say Government Mismanaged Health Care Co-ops
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Twelve of the 23 health insurance cooperatives set up with $2.5 billion in federal funding have shut down, rather than spur competition as intended.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican senators charged Thursday that the Obama administration had missed warning signs of financial distress at nonprofit health insurance cooperatives that failed last year, but a top federal official denied that the government had been negligent in its supervision.

headline: Why Donald Trump Keeps Lying About Unemployment
abstract: His goal is not to inform. It’s to inflame.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump received four Pinocchios this week from fact checkers at the Washington Post who vetted his claim that the unemployment rate in the United States is really 23 percent – which would be about as bad as it was in the depth of Great Depression of the 1930s.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 22-28
abstract: The winter storm forecast for Saturday may affect whether events will be held. Readers should check online or by phone for possible cancellations.
lead_paragraph: The winter storm forecast for Saturday may affect whether events will be held. Readers should check online or by phone for possible cancellations.

headline: Refracting Race Through the Comic Lens of Richard Pryor
abstract: Glenn Ligon’s show at Luhring Augustine Bushwick consists of a multipart video work focused on Mr. Pryor, who like Mr. Ligon, focused his art on the hard realities of race.
lead_paragraph: Much of the art that interests me most is art that’s made under pressure: social, emotional, intellectual, spiritual, political. Pressure of a kind different from that required to land a gallery or make a sale.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Jan. 22-28
abstract: Wave Hill, the Bronx garden, would like to introduce you to some neighbors. They may not be the friendliest New Yorkers, but they’re still good citizens. And they do like to hang out at night.
lead_paragraph: Wave Hill, the Bronx garden, would like to introduce you to some neighbors. They may not be the friendliest New Yorkers, but they’re still good citizens. And they do like to hang out at night.

headline: U.S. Awards $281 Million to New York Region for Hurricane Protection
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: The largest single award, $176 million, will go to New York City to help build a new flood protection system around Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Federal housing officials will award about $281 million to the New York region, including the states of Connecticut and New Jersey, to better protect communities from natural disasters like Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Verbatim: Donald Trump Says He Is No Longer Worried About Ted Cruz
abstract: At a campaign rally in Las Vegas, Donald J. Trump said of Ted Cruz, “He had his moment and he blew it.”
lead_paragraph: — Donald J. Trump, speaking at a rally in Las Vegas while listing the results of polls showing him ahead of Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: As ‘The X-Files’ Returns, Do We Still Want to Believe?
abstract: Two TV critics at The Times discuss the legacy of the show and a new mini-series that begins on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: IN 2002, after 202 episodes of government conspiracies, bright lights in the sky, black oil, creepy monsters and sexual tension, “The X-Files” said goodbye. On Sunday on Fox, the F.B.I. agents Fox Mulder (David Duchovny) and Dana Scully (Gillian Anderson) return for a six-part mini-series.

headline: Review: ‘Rabid Dogs,’ a Road Trip With French Robbers
abstract: Éric Hannezo’s film serves up gun battles, hostage-taking and a lot of swagger.
lead_paragraph: The illuminated title frames, laden with symbols and cast in a ruby light, promise thrills. And the first 10 minutes of the French film “Rabid Dogs” deliver nonstop action — and carnage — in an urban plaza, a shopping mall and a warehouse.

headline: Lasting Beauty, Even in Shards
abstract: The New York Ceramics and Glass Fair features a range of works, from the traditional to the modern to the odd.
lead_paragraph: There is still a divide in the contemporary art world’s recent embrace of ceramics and glass. You will find, for the most part, many traditional wares at the New York Ceramics and Glass Fair, now in its 17th incarnation. And yet, among 30 vendors, there is a great range of work here, from sophisticated haut-craft and modernist vessels to objects that will please the seeker of oddities. There are also a handful of lectures with juicy titles like “Demolition Man: Peter Voulkos, 1950-1970” and “Ming Goes Bling and the Slightly Satirical Aroma of Eucalyptus.” Here are some highlights.

headline: The New Cherries on Top of the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden
abstract: The garden is set to undergo a two-year, $10 million face-lift, which will include 16 new works.
lead_paragraph: When the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden opened in 1988 — the first partnership of its kind between a city parks department and a museum — the architecture critic Paul Goldberger wrote that few things were “as desirable to integrate with cities as sculpture, and as difficult.” But the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis pulled it off, he said, creating “the finest new outdoor space in the country for displaying sculpture,” and a link in a “complex chain of urban events, not an isolated place unto itself.”

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Jan. 23 Through 31
abstract: The Big Takeover, a reggae band, will perform this month at the Bearsville Theater.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Synchronicity’ Plays With Time and Love
abstract: This Jacob Gentry film faces challenges as it tries to tell a menacing sci-fi story on a tight budget.
lead_paragraph: Every so often in the science-fiction movie “Synchronicity,” Michael Ironside enters a scene and promisingly begins roughing it up, like a guy who’s had enough of whatever nonsense is on tap. The combustible Mr. Ironside vaulted into movie immortality as the antagonist in “Scanners,” David Cronenberg’s down-and-dirty, exploding-head anti-classic. “Synchronicity,” a low-budget misfire about time and love, could use some exploding heads, dialogue and ideas.

headline: Why Is It So Difficult for Syrian Refugees to Get Into the U.S.?
abstract: Of the 4.5 million people who have fled the Syrian war, only 2,647 have been taken in by the United States.
lead_paragraph: Of the 4.5 million people who have fled the Syrian war, only 2,647 have been taken in by the United States.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Jan. 23 Through Jan. 31
abstract: Bruce Springsteen’s River Tour 2016 will stop by the Prudential Center on Jan. 31 at 7:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Chance to Dance for Minority Ballerinas
abstract: The International Association of Blacks in Dance is bringing young ballerinas from around the country together with companies in an audition in Denver.
lead_paragraph: The lack of female African-American dancers in ballet companies is a subject that both frustrates and galvanizes Denise Saunders Thompson, the chairwoman and executive director of the International Association of Blacks in Dance, an organization that’s been around for 25 years.  On Sunday, in conjunction with the association’s annual conference in Denver, Ms. Thompson is holding auditions  for minority women seeking contracts with American companies — the group’s first such event. Ballet Memphis, Pennsylvania Ballet, San Francisco Ballet and Washington Ballet, among others, are sending representatives. Training institutions, including the Pacific Northwest Ballet School and the School of American Ballet, will also attend.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Jan. 23 Through 31
abstract: The funk and soul group Robert Randolph and the Family Band will perform on Jan. 29 at 9 p.m. at the Warehouse, Fairfield Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: To Be Young, Gay and Muslim in Bed-Stuy
abstract: The Islamic taboo against homosexuality weighs on two 18-year-old Muslim best friends who are closeted in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The endearing title characters of Jay Dockendorf’s film “Naz & Maalik” are 18-year-old best friends who recently became lovers, living in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a Brooklyn neighborhood in the throes of gentrification. Naz (Kerwin Johnson Jr.) and Maalik (Curtiss Cook Jr.) are closeted and Muslim, and especially for Naz, the Islamic taboo against homosexuality weighs heavily.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Jan. 23 Through Jan. 31
abstract: John Carlin and Mary McGloin are in “Dead Accounts,” a comedy by Theresa Rebeck being presented by the Hampton Theater Company at Quogue Community Hall in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Naz & Maalik’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Naz & Maalik.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Naz & Maalik.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Synchronicity’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Synchronicity.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Synchronicity.”

headline: Review: ‘Wide Awake Hearts’ and the ABC’s of Infidelity
abstract: In a cruel manipulation, a film director casts his wife opposite the actor friend he believes she is enamored with.
lead_paragraph: “He’s your oldest friend,” the woman says to her husband.

headline: Flash Factory, a New Techno Music Club, Takes a Populist Approach
abstract: The 10,000-square-foot space, frrom the night-life impresarios Michael Satsky and Brian Gefter, will focus on experimental electronic music with some indie rock.
lead_paragraph: Like much of Manhattan’s creative class, dance music purists have long moved their parties to Brooklyn or beyond — even as electronic dance music, or E.D.M., has grown into a multibillion dollar industry, reviving some New York club culture from the ’90s.

headline: Break Dancer Finds Footing While Trying to Heal a Rift
abstract: As a teenager, Jonathan Diaz danced for money on New York City’s streets and subway trains. He has switched to acting, while trying to mend a relationship whose rupture left him out on his own.
lead_paragraph: In the heyday of Jonathan Diaz’s break-dancing career, the A line from West 59th to 125th Street and its captive audience of riders made for a surefire source of income.

headline: Off the Court, Justin Gimelstob’s Life Is Still at 100 M.P.H.
abstract: Among Gimelstob’s duties, some call them conflicts, are coaching John Isner, working television broadcasts and serving on the ATP Tour board of directors.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — As the sun rose Thursday morning, Justin Gimelstob was relaxing the only way he knows how, by sifting through more than 300 combined unread email and text messages on his smartphone while burning 857 calories riding a stationary bicycle for an hour.

headline: Review: ‘Monster Hunt’ Features a Baby Beast on the Run With Its Surrogate Parents
abstract: Raman Hui’s live-action and computerized hybrid, a runaway hit in China, conjures a cute newborn creature pursued by other beasts and by human bounty hunters.

headline: With ‘The Seasons,’ Ben Wendel Redefines the Musical Encounter
abstract: The vividly imagined collection of duets by the saxophonist and bassoonist was one of the standout jazz records of 2015. But it was never released in album form.
lead_paragraph: “The Seasons,” a vividly imagined collection of duets by the saxophonist and bassoonist Ben Wendel, was one of the standout jazz records of 2015. But it was never released in album form, and took the entire year to hear in full.

headline: A Former Mexican Governor Is Arrested, but Not by His Own Country
abstract: The news that Humberto Moreira, who governed Coahuila, was being charged with corruption came with an asterisk: It was the Spanish police who succeeded in building a case against him.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The anticorruption police swooped in on Humberto Moreira, a former Mexican governor notorious for multiplying his state’s debt by 100 times in six years. The accusations were severe: among them, money laundering and misuse of public funds.

headline: Georgia Police Officer Indicted for Murder of Unarmed Black Man
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A grand jury has indicted a white officer on six counts, including felony murder, in last year’s shooting of Anthony Hill, 27, who was naked and behaving erratically.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — A white police officer was indicted here Thursday on six counts, including felony murder, in the fatal shooting last year of an unarmed black man who was naked and described as acting in an erratic manner.

headline: In Philadelphia, Batteries on Transit System Power More Than Just the Trains
abstract: In an experimental system, every time the trains pull into certain stations, they channel the energy created by the friction of their brakes to battery banks at one of two substations.
lead_paragraph: Along Philadelphia’s busy Market-Frankford subway line, the trains behave like those of any transit system, slowing to halt at the platforms and picking up passengers.

headline: Pedicab Operators See Loss of Livelihood in de Blasio’s Central Park Plan
keywords: ['Pedicabs and Rickshaws', 'Carriages', 'Horses', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Pedicab operators, who say they are already scorned and powerless, face the prospect of losing customers if they are banned from Central Park below 85th Street.
lead_paragraph: If someone were going to lose in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s horse carriage deal, pedicab drivers were an easy mark.

headline: Review: ‘Mojave’ Looks at the Corrosive Effects of Hollywood
abstract: The film, written and directed by William Monahan, finds a celebrity in the desert, then under siege.
lead_paragraph: The dyspeptic amusement “Mojave” opens with a snapshot of Hollywood narcissism at its most unconscious. Thomas (Garrett Hedlund), a Los Angeles demigod with artfully tousled hair and the morals of, well, just wait, is talking into a camera as if for a celebrity interview. “I’ve been famous one way or another since I was 19,” he says, shrugging the words off with the indifference that only years of stardom can bring. From his indolent delivery to his slouch (he can’t bother to sit up), he comes off as supremely self-absorbed. It’s all about him.

headline: Staging Apartments: Before and After
abstract: See how apartments were professionally made over to attract bids.
lead_paragraph: See how apartments were professionally made over to attract bids.

headline: Review: In ‘All Mistakes Buried,’ an Addict Battles to Retrieve a Precious Necklace
abstract: Directed by Tim McCann, the film stars Sam Trammell as a reprobate who takes on dangerous criminals in an effort to save his marriage.
lead_paragraph: “All Mistakes Buried” opens by following Sonny (Sam Trammell of “True Blood”), a once-respectable businessman now reduced to an addict’s existence, on his busy schedule. He sleeps off the night before in a skanky motel, drinks heavily and smokes dope just to steady his nerves, hustles to his dealer for some crack and dimly remembers that there’s something he needs to do.

headline: Funds Roll In for Start-Up Harnessing Bitcoin Tech
abstract: A high-profile former JPMorgan Chase executive has raised $52 million from several big banks for a start-up built on the technology underlying the Bitcoin virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: A well-known former JPMorgan Chase executive, Blythe Masters, has raised $52 million from several big banks for a start-up built on the technology underlying the Bitcoin virtual currency.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Cable Acquisitions by Charter Communications Face Rising Opposition
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television']
abstract: If approved, the deals are likely to include provisions meant to prevent Charter from using its market power to hurt rival streaming services.
lead_paragraph: Comcast’s failed $45 billion merger with Time Warner Cable collapsed last year under pressure from regulators, who found that the combined company would have had both the power and incentive to inhibit the future of streaming video.

headline: Edmonde Charles-Roux, Novelist and Editor of French Vogue, Dies at 95
abstract: Ms. Charles-Roux’s first novel, “To Forget Palermo,” won the Prix Goncourt, France’s biggest literary prize, in 1966, four months after the magazine ousted her.
lead_paragraph: Edmonde Charles-Roux, a longtime editor of French Vogue and the author of the novel “To Forget Palermo,” winner of the Prix Goncourt, France’s biggest literary prize, in 1966, died on Wednesday in Marseille. She was 95.

headline: Raid on Militant Hide-Out Near Egypt’s Pyramids Ends in Deadly Blast
abstract: At least nine people, including police officers, were killed during a raid on an apartment building as technicians tried to defuse booby traps, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A large explosion in an apartment building near the Pyramids killed at least nine people on Thursday evening, including at least three police officers, during what the authorities said was a security raid on a suspected militant hide-out.

headline: By Finding a New Home for Carriage Horses, Solving a Problem That Doesn’t Exist
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ill-conceived plan to house commercial animals in Central Park is a costly solution in search of a problem.
lead_paragraph: Friday is Day 751 of the Mayor Bill de Blasio era, and the City Council is prepared to take up a matter that he said would be dealt with on Day 1: driving the horse-carriage industry from the streets of Manhattan.

headline: Twenty20, a Faster Variant of Cricket, Gets Players to Stay Home
abstract: Australia’s traditional Boxing Day test match drew 127,069 over four days, but a Twenty20 match in the new Big Bash League this month drew 80,883.
lead_paragraph: Unlike most sports, cricket traditionally has revolved around international play, regarded as more prestigious and lucrative than domestic competition. It is not just glamour in which domestic play lags; it is often subsidized by the money received from international play, too.

headline: U.N. Finds South Sudan Increasingly in Turmoil
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Sex Crimes', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Child Soldiers']
abstract: A 45-page United Nations report describes a murderous struggle between government and opposition forces that includes disturbing new levels of sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The murderous struggle between the government and opposition forces in South Sudan has already resulted in widespread atrocities and left thousands of people on the brink of starvation, yet in the past year, both sides intensified and spread the conflict, the United Nations said Thursday.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Jan. 22, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Naz & Maalik,” “Synchronicity” and “Prescription Thugs.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Naz & Maalik,” “Synchronicity” and “Prescription Thugs.”

headline: Review: In ‘Ip Man 3,’ Donnie Yen Brawls With Mike Tyson and Others
abstract: Fists fly as usual in this installment of the ‘Ip Man’ series, which pits Mr. Yen’s character against a brutal gang while his wife is threatened by illness.
lead_paragraph: In Bruce Lee’s unfinished film “Game of Death,” there is a classic bout between Lee and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. “Ip Man 3,” the latest installment in a series  starring Donnie Yen as Lee’s fabled instructor, offers similar stunt casting, in a fight between Mr. Yen and the former pro boxer Mike Tyson, who plays a gang boss. As rewarding as the matchup is — pile-driver force meeting the graceful kung fu style wing chun — it is not the movie’s climax, and ends in a stalemate.

headline: Taliban Attack Shows Limits of Pakistan’s Military Crackdown
abstract: The Taliban’s attack on a university shows that all it takes to restart the cycle of fear is a determined commander, a few willing attackers and a list of accessible targets.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Only a few months ago, Pakistan’s military leaders openly boasted they had the Taliban on the run. A punishing, yearlong offensive had ousted the insurgents from their most prized tribal sanctuary. The movement’s various factions were riven by violent rivalries, and attacks on Pakistan’s towns and cities had largely ceased.

headline: Aroldis Chapman, the Yankees’ New Closer, Avoids Charges, but May Face Discipline
abstract: Chapman’s case is one of three that are being scrutinized as baseball implements its policy on domestic abuse cases.
lead_paragraph: Aroldis Chapman will not face criminal charges that were brought against him by the state attorney in Broward County, Fla., but he could be disciplined by Major League Baseball, and the punishment could include a suspension.

headline: Review: The Aliens Are Coming! The Aliens Are Coming!
abstract: The extraterrestrial Others are conquering Earth. Feisty, if under-informed, teenagers decide to fight back.
lead_paragraph: Adapted from Rick Yancey’s young adult novel, the glossy if muddled “The 5th Wave” blends the alien overlord airships of “Independence Day,” the natural disaster effects of “The Day After Tomorrow” and the auto-wreck-strewn highways of “Zombieland” with a dusting of “Invasion of the Body Snatchers.”

headline: Russia and U.S., While Pushing for Peace Talks, Jockey for Position in Syria
abstract: The two countries are digging in for a battle that will continue regardless of any peace deal: the fight against the Islamic State extremist group.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Russian military is expanding its footprint in Syria, setting up operations at an airfield in a northeastern, mostly Kurdish province across the country from its main coastal base. In an adjacent province, locals say the United States is intensifying its aid to Kurdish militias, even taking over a small agricultural airport; Pentagon officials denied this. And some Syrian fighters say Russia has reached out to Sunni tribes, offering to help them fight the Islamic State extremist group in the east after similar American efforts failed.

headline: Lou Michaels, All-Purpose Player, Dies at 80; Missed Kicks in ‘69 Super Bowl
abstract: The former All-American, all-purpose football player missed two field-goal attempts during the New York Jets’ upset of the Baltimore Colts.
lead_paragraph: Lou Michaels, a former All-American, all-purpose football player whose two missed field goals for the Baltimore Colts helped the New York Jets win the Super Bowl in 1969 in a historic upset, died on Tuesday at his home in Swoyersville, Pa. He was 80.

headline: Courses for a New Year
abstract: For those resolved to learn new skills in 2016, the city is filled with free or inexpensive lessons in media production, improv and languages.
lead_paragraph: Only a few weeks into the new year and gyms across the city are thinning out, Powerball mania has spoiled prudent financial plans and the Miser’s attempt at more bookish pursuits has seen “Crime and Punishment” replaced by “Making a Murderer.”

headline: McConnell Clears Path for Debate on Giving Obama Broad Powers to Combat ISIS
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)']
abstract: Aides to Mr. McConnell said the bill would provide a new platform for showcasing what Republicans view as Mr. Obama’s failings in combating the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and majority leader, has set the stage for debate on a bill that would give President Obama broad authority to use military force against the Islamic State.

headline: Mr. Putin and the Poisonous London Tea Party
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'International Relations']
abstract: Britain’s inquiry into the death of Alexander Litvinenko further strains international relations with Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin’s deserved reputation as an autocrat willing to flirt with lawlessness in his global ventures has taken on a startling new aspect, with a finding by British authorities that he “probably approved” the poisoning of a former Russian spy and defector in London in 2006.

headline: A Question of Environmental Racism in Flint
abstract: Civil rights advocates say that the Michigan city’s health crisis smacks of the kind of discrimination that causes the disproportionate exposure of blacks to polluted air, water and soil.
lead_paragraph: If Flint were rich and mostly white, would Michigan’s state government have responded more quickly and aggressively to complaints about its lead-polluted water?

headline: New York City Marathon Challenged Over Lottery
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'Lotteries', 'Marathon Running', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Two Utah men said in a lawsuit that the New York Road Runners is running an illegal lottery because of the $11 fee it charges everyone who enters the drawing.
lead_paragraph: Two Utah men claimed in a lawsuit filed Thursday that the annual drawing by the New York Marathon to qualify to enter the race constitutes an illegal lottery.

headline: David Brock, Ally of Hillary Clinton, Skewers New Bernie Sanders Ad
abstract: David Brock, a longtime Clinton supporter who founded the “super PAC” backing her, said the ad, released in Iowa, focused too much on white Americans.
lead_paragraph: The race between Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Hillary Clinton ramped up Thursday with a top Clinton ally criticizing a new Sanders ad as focused too much on white Americans.

headline: Yemen: Airstrikes Kill 18, Including a Hospital Worker
abstract: An ambulance driver working at a hospital supported by Doctors Without Borders was among the casualties.
lead_paragraph: Multiple airstrikes on a town in northern Yemen on Thursday killed at least 18 people, including civilian rescuers and an ambulance driver working at a hospital supported by Doctors Without Borders, according to a statement by the group and the hospital director. At least three hospitals supported by Doctors Without Borders have been destroyed or damaged since October in the war between Houthi rebels and government forces backed by Saudi Arabia. Muhammed Hajr, the director of the Jumhuriya Hospital in Saada Province, said that the ambulance had just picked up people wounded in an airstrike in the Dhayan district when another airstrike destroyed the ambulance, killing everyone inside. Other airstrikes killed at least 12 people who arrived to help, Mr. Hajr said.

headline: At 22, Rangers Forward Is Already Having a Signature Season
abstract: J.T. Miller, the Rangers’ first-round draft pick in 2011, has been “more assertive and more physical” this season. He has 10 goals and 12 assists.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — J. T. Miller may be only 22, but he has already had a wealth of experience with the Rangers, who made him a first-round draft pick in 2011.

headline: Flint Fallout: A Resignation, a Hearing and U.S. Aid
keywords: ['Water', 'Lead', 'Water Pollution', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: As President Obama announced that $80 million in aid would be available to Michigan, a regional E.P.A. official resigned and a congresswoman announced hearings on the tainted water.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Fallout from the drinking water crisis in Flint, Mich., spread Thursday as a high-ranking Environmental Protection Agency official resigned and the agency’s chief administrator said it would take over monitoring of Flint’s water supply for lead contamination.

headline: Postwar German Nickname
abstract: Paula Gamache returns with a fun and elegant themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial New Feature Alert! We’re trying something new — a separate, weekly place to gather and discuss the “A Little Variety” puzzles (which includes the Spelling Bee) that publish online on Thursdays and appear in the Sunday Magazine. If there seems to be enough interest and discussion, this will become a permanent part of the Wordplay rotation. Starting Saturday, January 23, a post for these puzzles will appear at 9:00 a.m. Eastern.

headline: Review: ‘The Glory of the World,’ About Thomas Merton
abstract: Thomas Merton’s birthday party may be divine, but his operating mode was more contemplative than this all-male play would have you believe.
lead_paragraph: Whose birthday is this, anyway? Thomas Merton’s? Or a gay circuit-party promoter’s?

headline: Judge in Bill Cosby Case Dismisses Pittsburgh Woman’s Defamation Suit
abstract: The court said statements made by Bill Cosby, his wife and lawyer did not defame the woman, Renita Hill, who accused the entertainer of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: Statements made by Bill Cosby, his wife and his lawyer at the time to counter accusations that he had sexually assaulted women were not defamatory, a federal judge ruled Thursday as he dismissed a Pittsburgh woman’s defamation lawsuit against the entertainer.

headline: Bronx Priest Suspended in Abuse Case
abstract: The Rev. Richard Gorman is director of prison chaplains for the Archdiocese of New York, and has also been chairman of Community Board 12 in the northeast Bronx.
lead_paragraph: A Roman Catholic priest also active in Bronx politics has been suspended from priestly duties because of allegations that he sexually abused minors three decades ago, church officials said on Thursday.

headline: Hillary Clinton, With Help From Demi Lovato, Treads on Bernie Sanders Turf in Iowa
abstract: Mrs. Clinton campaigned with confidence in Sanders country during a rally with the singer Demi Lovato at the University of Iowa.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY, Iowa — Hillary Clinton campaigned with confidence in Bernie Sanders country on Thursday night, taking a couple of gentle jabs at her political rival during a rally with the singer Demi Lovato at the University of Iowa in this liberal hotbed.

headline: Mississippi Republicans Face Hard Tax Cut Choices
abstract: The vote to unseat Blaine Eaton II, a Democrat, and replace him with his Republican rival, Mark Tullos, is likely to exacerbate a tension that defines much of modern-day policy making in the South.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Blaine Eaton II, the Mississippi state representative who won a tie election by pulling a long green straw in a state-sanctioned ceremony — only to be removed from office by the Republican-controlled House — was back on his farm in Taylorsville on Thursday, feeding his cows and licking his wounds.

headline: Family Recalls Concerns After Fatal Stabbing of Teenager
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: Before the attack, the victim, Jovani Cubias, received threatening calls and text messages after his girlfriend was involved in a fight, his sister said.
lead_paragraph: A bloody handprint stained the sidewalk on Lorimer Street in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, just across from Sternberg Park, where Jovani Cubias sometimes played basketball, his family said, outclassing his friends on the court as he grew lankier. Other red blotches marked the spot where Jovani, 17, was fatally stabbed on Wednesday afternoon. He was attacked, the police said, following an argument with another male.

headline: Government to Reveal Colleges With Title IX Waivers
keywords: ['Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Critics say the waivers sought by religiously affiliated institutions enable them to discriminate against gay and transgender students.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Education said on Wednesday that it would create a searchable database that reveals the names of colleges and universities that have received exemptions on religious grounds from federal civil rights protections.

headline: Realization at Ziegfeld Theater: Only Name Is Constant
abstract: The current Ziegfeld, which was not designed to accommodate live performances, was a technological marvel when it opened as a movie theater in 1969.
lead_paragraph: The Ziegfeld Theater opened 46 years ago with “Marooned.” It is closing marooned, though “deserted” is probably a better word. Not even “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” which has packed movie theaters nationwide since it opened last month, drew much of a crowd at the Ziegfeld on Wednesday night.

headline: Alabama: Judge Censured for Coercing Blood Donors
abstract: A Circuit Court judge was censured Thursday after he was accused last year of threatening defendants with jail time if they did not pay fines or participate in a blood drive.
lead_paragraph: A Circuit Court judge was censured Thursday after he was accused last year of threatening defendants with jail time if they did not pay fines or participate in a blood drive. Judge Marvin Wiggins, whose jurisdiction includes five impoverished counties, accepted the punishment as part of a settlement with the State Judicial Inquiry Commission. More than 40 defendants donated blood after Judge Wiggins told them, “Consider that as a discount rather than putting you in jail, if you do not have any money.” The judge’s supporters said he had chosen his words poorly and that he did not intend to jail anyone, but critics like the state commission said his comments “were so coercive as to be reprehensible and inexcusable.”

headline: Death of New York Officer Imperils Gun Case in Which He Was Crucial Witness
abstract: Officer Randolph Holder, who was fatally shot last fall, was the only police officer in a 2014 gun-possession case who saw the weapon in the defendant’s hands.
lead_paragraph: When a police officer dies in the line of duty, there is an often-unseen consequence: The cases the officer has pending before the courts are suddenly in jeopardy.

headline: New York’s Week in Pictures: Jan. 22
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York and the region include the site of the New York City Farm Colony on Staten Island and mourners at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York and the region include the site of the New York City Farm Colony on Staten Island and mourners at Columbia University.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | unprepossessing
abstract: This word has appeared in 28 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: unprepossessing • \ˌən-pri-pə-ˈzes-iN also -ˈses\ • adjective

headline: Forrest McDonald, Historian Who Punctured Liberal Notions, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. McDonald, a conservative who opposed intrusive government, lionized the founding fathers as uniquely intellectual and wrote over a dozen books.
lead_paragraph: Forrest McDonald, a presidential and constitutional scholar who challenged liberal shibboleths about early American history and lionized the founding fathers as uniquely intellectual, died on Tuesday in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 89.

headline: Faint Praise for Bernie Sanders From Bill Clinton: ‘His Slogans Are Easier to Say’
abstract: The former president distinguished his wife, Hillary Clinton, from Mr. Sanders on college tuition, foreign policy, tone, and their responses to the water crisis in Flint, Mich.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS – The last time a Hillary Clinton presidential campaign ran into trouble – in 2008, when she ran and ultimately lost to Barack Obama – she turned to Bill Clinton, her husband and the former president, as a campaign surrogate. And with polls suggesting Mrs. Clinton is struggling again, this time against Bernie Sanders, Mr. Clinton has returned to the place he likes best: the campaign trail.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: Male angst goes on vacation in “Mad Dogs.” Anna Netrebko makes a Met debut. And the Marvel gang is back.
lead_paragraph: Feeling angsty? Check out “Mad Dogs” and breathe a sigh of relief that your week probably wasn’t as bad as the one these guys are having. Meanwhile, Anna Netrebko makes a Met Opera debut. And the Marvel gang is back.

headline: 1905: Bloody Sunday in Russia
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The aftermath of a massacre in St. Petersburg.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 22, 1905, soldiers of the Imperial Guard in St. Petersburg, Russia, fired upon demonstrators as they marched to the Winter Palace to petition Czar Nicholas II.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a feedback between financial markets and the economy. You might think markets are irrational, but even if they are, that spills over into the real economy.”

headline: Corrections: January 22, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, January 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: SPORTS

headline: Donald Trump Pushes Back Against Criticism by National Review
abstract: Donald J. Trump called an impromptu news conference Thursday night in Nevada to criticize National Review, the conservative magazine that published a series of essays denouncing his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump called an impromptu news conference on Thursday night in Nevada to criticize National Review, the conservative magazine that published a series of essays denouncing his candidacy.

headline: Magic and Mystery on São Paulo’s Streets
abstract: Victor Dragonetti’s street scenes are colorful, and complex, with an air of mystery that evokes different responses from viewers.
lead_paragraph: Victor Dragonetti’s street scenes are colorful, and complex, with an air of mystery that evokes different responses from viewers.

headline: Stance on Migrants Leaves Merkel Isolated at Home and in Europe
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is under increasing pressure to change course on her refugee policy as more allies at home and abroad abandon her on the issue.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Dozens of lawmakers from her own conservative party signed open letters against her this week. A nationalist right-wing party is gaining in strength. Speculation, building since the fall, now runs rife that she should even be replaced. On Sunday, the top circulation Bild Zeitung headlined an eight-page spread on her political troubles: “Is Merkel Still the Right One?”

headline: Magic and Mystery on São Paulo’s Streets
abstract: Victor Dragonetti’s street scenes are colorful, and complex, with an air of mystery that evokes different responses from viewers.
lead_paragraph: If you ever get cynical about photography, go talk to Victor Dragonetti. O.K., just going to where he lives – São Paulo – will lift anyone’s spirits given the weather in the Northeast. But this young photographer’s enthusiasm about photography is not just heartwarming, but also infectious. His smile is enough to remind you of the moment when you realized that taking pictures was magical.

headline: Justin Trudeau Carries His ‘Look to Canada’ Image to Davos
abstract: The prime minister brings his youthful appeal and optimistic messages to the World Economic Forum.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The Davos man who attends the World Economic Forum here each year is a member of the global elite — say, a banker or a politician — whose status is reinforced by an exclusive white badge that gives him access to V.I.P. lounges away from the masses at this alpine resort.

headline: Still Recovering From Hurricane Sandy
abstract: With reconstruction about to begin, funds from the Neediest Cases helps a woman move to temporary housing.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Oct. 29, 2012, Linda Vergara looked out the front door of her home in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, and thought: “This is not good. We better get out of here.” Hurricane Sandy had arrived a few hours earlier, and Ms. Vergara, like thousands of New Yorkers, assumed she was in a safe zone and would not need to evacuate. Then the surge came. By the time she got her coat on and headed out to the street, the water was up to her waist. She saw cars and other debris floating around and joined some of her neighbors as they struggled to reach higher ground.

headline: Depraved Indifference Toward Flint
abstract: Newly released emails reveal an appalling lack of urgency in responding to Flint’s water problems.
lead_paragraph: The 274 pages of emails released under pressure on Wednesday by Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan show a cynical and callous indifference to the plight of the mostly black, poverty-stricken residents of Flint, who have gone for more than a year with poisoned tap water that is unsafe to drink or bathe in. There is little doubt that an affluent, predominantly white community — say Grosse Pointe or Bloomfield Hills — would never face such a public health catastrophe, and if it had, the state government would have rushed in to help.

headline: How Change Happens
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Idealism is nice, but it’s not a virtue without tough minded realism.
lead_paragraph: There are still quite a few pundits determined to pretend that America’s two great parties are symmetric — equally unwilling to face reality, equally pushed into extreme positions by special interests and rabid partisans. It’s nonsense, of course. Planned Parenthood isn’t the same thing as the Koch brothers, nor is Bernie Sanders the moral equivalent of Ted Cruz. And there’s no Democratic counterpart whatsoever to Donald Trump.

headline: The Eight-Second Attention Span
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Are you still reading this? Great. What about now?
lead_paragraph: This weekend, I’m going to the Mojave Desert, deep into an arid wilderness of a half-million acres, for some stargazing, bouldering and January sunshine on my public lands. I won’t be out of contact. I checked. If Sarah Palin says something stupid on Donald Trump’s behalf — scratch that. When Sarah Palin says something stupid on Donald Trump’s behalf, I’ll get her speaking-in-tongues buffoonery in real time, along with the rest of the nation.

headline: The Anxieties of Impotence
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The sense of powerlessness that is sweeping our nation and the world can only be addressed by rebuilding our institutions.
lead_paragraph: In 1936 George Orwell wrote a magnificent essay called “Shooting an Elephant.” Orwell had been working as a British police officer in Burma, enforcing colonial rule. An elephant had gone “must,” broken its chains, trampled some homes and killed a man.

headline: When Will the Candidates Start Talking About the Economy?
abstract: With markets tumbling, politicians need to get real about fixing the issues that threaten our stability.
lead_paragraph: SIDELINED by homeland security, foreign policy and immigration, the economy is about to become a major topic in the race for the White House. Since the start of the year we have seen precipitous drops in the stock market and oil prices, combined with the threat that a slowing global economy may drag the United States down with it.

headline: Sanders Makes a Rare Pitch: More Taxes for More Government
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Taxation', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Exploring the details of how Bernie Sanders’s single-payer health plan would be paid for.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders’s health care plan is advancing a notion that has long been out of fashion in American politics: that the federal government should provide a new, expensive service to most Americans, and that it should levy significantly higher taxes on most Americans to provide that service.

headline: Making Peace With Violence: Camus in Algeria
abstract: The philosopher and author of “The Rebel” recognized that killing was, at times, unavoidable.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago today, Albert Camus gave the speech of his life. It was a speech, in fact, that nearly cost him his life, as well as one that failed in its goal of saving the lives of countless civilians, Arabs and French alike, caught in the vise of terrorism employed by both sides in Algeria’s war of independence. The reasoning behind the speech, as well as the reasons Camus gave it, cast important light on the “war on terror” now being fought in the West.

headline: Japan Economy Minister Fights Accusations of Selling Favors
abstract: Akira Amari responded to allegations that he had received funds from a construction company that sought his help in settling a public contract dispute.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Japanese economy minister, Akira Amari, a high-profile supporter of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s policies on trade and the economy, is fighting potentially damaging accusations that he received funds from a construction company in return for political favors.

headline: Global Markets Continue to Rally as Investors Seek Bargains
abstract: Japan’s benchmark Nikkei 225 index staged a forceful rebound, closing 5.9 percent higher, and the momentum carried over to Europe. Oil was also up.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Surging Japanese shares led a strong rebound in markets across Asia on Friday, and Europe had its second consecutive day of gains, as investors buffeted by days of volatility saw opportunity amid the recent sell-offs.

headline: Philips Calls Off Sale of Controlling Stake in LED Business
abstract: The Dutch electronics giant said in October that United States regulators had raised “unforeseen concerns” about a deal to dispose of 80.1 percent of the unit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Friday that it had terminated an agreement to sell a controlling stake in its automotive and LED components business because of regulatory concerns raised in the United States.

headline: News Q’s | How the N.B.A. 3-Point Shot Went From Gimmick to Game Changer
abstract: How did the shot transform from being a “rarely used weapon” to a “vital part of every team’s offense”?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “How the N.B.A. 3-Point Shot Went From Gimmick to Game Changer.”

headline: ‘This Should Be Written in the Present Tense,’ by Helle Helle
abstract: A novel tracks a young woman’s ranging thoughts and sexual wanderings.
lead_paragraph: For the last 20 years, Helle Helle’s novels and short stories have made her a star in her native Denmark, where she regularly receives awards and acclaim. Denmark is also where, according to her biography, Helle “lives in a forest.” What a fittingly magical dwelling for Helle, who — judging from her first novel to be translated into English, “This Should Be ­Written in the Present Tense” — has enchanting gifts as a storyteller.

headline: ‘Liberty and Coercion,’ by Gary Gerstle
abstract: As government’s role has grown, power has increasingly shifted from the states to the federal domain.
lead_paragraph: Between 1913 and 1920, Americans amended the federal Constitution four times. Each amendment solidified a major reform: the direct election of senators, the first federal income tax, votes for women, the banning of alcohol nationwide. Taken together, they reflected the progressive view that the Constitution was a living document, able to be adapted to and updated for the nation’s needs. A century ago, most Americans seemed to agree that new circumstances required new tools, and that the federal government would have a key role to play in meeting the challenges of the modern age.

headline: The Art of Home Staging
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Orderliness and Clutter', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The practice of home staging has long elicited strong reactions. But as staging has evolved, more real estate professionals stress its importance.
lead_paragraph: Like many sellers, Fran Sarro and David Waite were initially reluctant to stage their apartment.

headline: From the Highway to the Great White Way
abstract: A rat abandoned on the West Side Highway last summer reaches the bright lights of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: A rat abandoned on the West Side Highway last summer reaches the bright lights of Broadway.

headline: Sheldon Silver’s Lawyers Seek Acquittal or Retrial in Corruption Case
abstract: In a letter to a judge, the lawyers of Mr. Silver, the former New York State Assembly speaker, claimed his conviction relied on circumstantial evidence.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Sheldon Silver, the former New York State Assembly speaker convicted of federal corruption charges, asked a judge on Thursday to acquit their client or grant him a new trial, arguing that “no rational juror” could find that the charges had been proved beyond a reasonable doubt.

headline: Student Question | Should Colleges Find a Better Way to Admit Students?
abstract: Are there better ways to find the best candidates without jeopardizing high school students’ mental health?
lead_paragraph: Concern has been growing about how the current admissions process at the nation’s most selective colleges “warps the values of students,” promotes a “competitive frenzy” and encourages an unhealthy piling on of Advanced Placement classes and extracurricular activities. Should colleges rethink their emphasis on applicants’ grade point averages, SAT and ACT scores, A.P. course loads and extracurricular participation?

headline: Fugitive in Bronx Slasher Case Leaves a Trail of Fear and Taunts
abstract: After Ronald Plaza fled his trial in the Bronx, the wife of his victim reported receiving menacing phone calls and said their relatives in the Dominican Republic had been targeted.
lead_paragraph: The day after a man accused in a slashing episode jumped bail during his trial, the Bronx prosecutor handling the case was browsing the man’s Instagram page when he came upon the stately, bearded face of Don Juancho Nieto Meléndez, a 19th-century Venezuelan spirits connoisseur.

headline: Older Drivers Hit the Road for Uber and Lyft
keywords: ['Part-Time Employment', 'Retirement', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Elderly', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting']
abstract: Seniors are turning to ride-sharing services for the extra income and flexibility they provide, but there are concerns about possible exploitation.
lead_paragraph: When Carol Sue Johnson, 73, wheels her silver Mazda S.U.V. out of her driveway in suburban Minneapolis, she doesn’t know how much money she will make driving for the ride-hailing service Uber, but she’s sure she will have an adventure.

headline: Chris Christie and His Ambitions: A New Jersey Vanishing Act
abstract: Mr. Christie continues to pursue his long-shot campaign for the White House, he has nearly vanished from the State Capitol and has scaled back his legislative goals.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie’s return to New Jersey was swift and efficient: He flew to his home state on Monday night after a campaign trip to Iowa. The next day, he sliced through a towering pile of legislation awaiting his signature, approving 93 bills and blocking 62 others from becoming law.

headline: A G.O.P. Majority in New Hampshire Pipes Up: We’re Not for Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: These are the lamentations of the 68 Percent — the significant majority of Republicans in the state who are immune to Donald J. Trump’s charms and entreaties.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, N.H. — Jeanne Cleveland, a retired teacher, pursed her lips sourly at the mention of his name and tried to summarize her distaste in diplomatic terms.

headline: A Late Love
abstract: Sonny and Cher costumes for a 1970s throwback party helped Sandy Jacobson and Paul Fischer move beyond the sadness.
lead_paragraph: Sonny and Cher costumes for a 1970s throwback party helped Sandy Jacobson and Paul Fischer move beyond the sadness.

headline: Rose the Rat on Broadway
abstract: Rose, one of a group of white rats abandoned near the West Side Highway, was adopted by an animal trainer and has become an actor in a hit show.
lead_paragraph: Rose, one of a group of white rats abandoned near the West Side Highway, was adopted by an animal trainer and has become an actor in a hit show.

headline: From the Ashes of Loss, Love Grows
keywords: ['Vows (Times Column)', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: When Sandy Jacobson’s husband and sister died in quick succession, she found support and later romance with her brother-in-law Paul Fischer.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Jacobson calls it “that terrible year,” measured in doctors’ visits, chemotherapy treatments and funerals. It began in 2011.

headline: Enter Rose, a Broadway Rat With a Past
abstract: Abandoned next to the West Side Highway, taken in by an animal trainer, a white rat replaced a sick regular in a hit show ... you know the rest.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of 500 rats on the West Side Highway and one who ventured east.

headline: ‘The Past,’ by Tessa Hadley
abstract: Four siblings reunite to decide the fate of the family’s crumbling rectory.
lead_paragraph: Pity poor Roland Crane, one of the central characters in Tessa Hadley’s most recent novel, “The Past.” Like other males who populate Hadley’s fiction, Roland grew up in a family of vivid, sexually flamboyant women who considered him “slightly ridiculous.” Today, however, he is a public intellectual, with a gratifying position writing about film for the national newspapers. When he shows up for a summer holiday with his three grown sisters, driving a vintage Jaguar and wearing a white linen suit, accompanied by his glamorous new wife and his lovely 16-year-old daughter by a previous marriage, you might expect Roland to have earned a little domestic peace and adulation. But no. Not only do his sisters, who “could remember him in short trousers, when his ­glasses were mended with sticking plaster,” still consider him a ­“buttoned-up” puritan, but his sway over his wife and daughter is about to be assailed from the most unexpected quarters. The point about the past, in Hadley’s fiction, is that it’s always there to trip you up. Your parents (whether dead or alive), your siblings (whether successful or resentfully needy) will inevitably threaten to suck you back into that sticky-sweet limbo of childhood myth and trauma.

headline: Snowstorm Bears Down on the East Coast
abstract: More than two feet of snow could hit the Washington region starting Friday. The storm is moving north, with a foot or more of snow expected in New York.
lead_paragraph: More than two feet of snow could hit the Washington region starting Friday. The storm is moving north, with a foot or more of snow expected in New York.
