headline: When Alcohol Intrudes in the Workplace
abstract: A worker is worried about a colleague’s drinking off-site and its effect on performance. In another question, a worker wants to carefully avoid drinking socially.
lead_paragraph: I work at a nonprofit with fewer than 10 employees, where we all need to pull our weight. Recently, there have been several instances of a particular colleague getting so drunk on weeknights that he can’t make it to work until the following afternoon, if at all. I know that he is hung over, not sick, because he has admitted it in emails canceling meetings with me.

headline: North Korea Says It’s Holding U.S. Student for ‘Hostile Act’
abstract: The University of Virginia student has been accused of entering the North to bring “down the foundation of its single-minded unity.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — North Korean state news media said Friday that a university student from the United States who had entered the country as a tourist was being held for “a hostile act.”

abstract: At least 14 civilians were killed and dozens were wounded after the Islamist militants struck the Lido beachfront restaurant in Somalia’s capital.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least 14 civilians were killed and dozens were wounded after Islamist militants struck a popular beachside restaurant Thursday night in Somalia’s capital that had become a symbol of the city’s struggling renaissance, officials said Friday.

lead_paragraph: Washington is bracing for a potential shutdown this weekend, and, this time, it won’t be Senator Ted Cruz of Texas’ fault.

headline: 1996 | ‘In Gamble, Newspapers Push Into On-Line Publishing’
abstract: A year after explaining to readers in elementary language what the World Wide Web was, The Times jumped in for itself. It hasn’t been the same since.
lead_paragraph: “The Web,” Peter H. Lewis explained to readers of The New York Times on Jan. 18, 1995, “allows even computer novices to easily search the global Internet network for text, pictures — and, in some cases, sounds — and analysts say it is rapidly emerging as the point-and-click prototype for the information superhighway.”

lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: ‘The Dogs of Littlefield,’ by Suzanne Berne
abstract: Dog poisonings are only a symptom of a deeper sickness in a place where everything’s supposed to be perfect.
lead_paragraph: Leafy, prosperous Littlefield sounds too good to be true. An idyllic Boston suburb, it ranks No. 6 on The Wall Street Journal’s list of the 20 Best Places to Live in America. Band concerts, well-tended Victorian houses, enlightened citizens — what could go wrong?

lead_paragraph: RONALD REAGANBy Jacob Weisberg185 pp. Times Books, $25.

headline: Dozens of Migrants Drown as European Refugee Crisis Continues
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'International Relations']
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France warned that the huge numbers of migrants still entering the Continent could destabilize European societies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than 40 people — including 17 children — died when two wooden boats full of migrants trying to reach Greece sank early Friday morning, as a continued flow of asylum seekers, even in dangerous winter weather, put new pressure on European leaders to address a crisis that seems likely to intensify again come spring.

headline: Vietnam’s Sacred Turtle Dies at an Awkward, Some Say Ominous, Time
abstract: The news that a legendary turtle in Hanoi’s central lake had died prompted an outpouring of sadness across the deeply superstitious and Confucian country.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — A giant turtle, a mythic symbol of Vietnamese independence and longevity that had quietly paddled around Hanoi’s central lake for decades — some say centuries — is dead, official state news media has reported.

headline: ‘The Sleep Garden,’ by Jim Krusoe
abstract: Krusoe’s latest follows the residents of a subterranean apartment building.
lead_paragraph: Jim Krusoe’s sixth novel, “The Sleep Garden,” is a labyrinth of different narratives. Or, to be exact, a burrow — the Burrow, as Krusoe calls the surreal underground apartment building where his five central characters dwell (part reality show setup, part Plato’s cave, part grave) in a state of stasis and frustrated ambition. Their aspirations — for sex, love, money, celebrity — are familiar, though their milieu is not: the claustrophobic Burrow, filled with mirrors that “multiply the dark.”

headline: Q. and A.: Shawna Yang Ryan on the 1947 Incident That Shaped Taiwan’s Identity
abstract: The author of “Green Island” says the story of the massacre is little understood outside Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In “Green Island,” the novelist Shawna Yang Ryan tells the story of how the Tsais, a Taiwanese family, survive the “February 28 Incident” of 1947 and precariously navigate the decades that follow as Chiang Kai-shek’s Kuomintang, or Nationalist Party, rules the island under martial law.

headline: The 1.10.16 Issue
abstract: Readers react.
lead_paragraph: RE:DUPONT

headline: How to Get Squirrels Out of the Attic
keywords: ['Squirrels', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ANIMALS', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Don’t fall victim to the repellent racket. Cut off their entry points.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘The first thing you’ll notice is the noise,’’ says David Seerveld, a wildlife-removal specialist in Orlando, Fla. If you hear daytime scratching, you probably have squirrels; most other rodent intruders are nocturnal. According to Seerveld, attic squirrels are ‘‘the most common nuisance-wildlife problem.’’ They can bite through plastic water pipes and cause leaks; gnaw at electrical wires and spark fires; and at times even chomp through the ceiling until they fall, panicked, into living quarters.

headline: ‘Transmission’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh, by John Lahr. (Norton, $19.95.) This deeply researched biography opens at the 1945 Broadway premiere of “The Glass Menagerie,” the work that heralded an era of critical acclaim for Williams (1911-83). In Lahr’s telling, Williams was an artist who flourished in spite of repression, a process that our reviewer, Blake Bailey, saw as “the triumph of art over life — the alchemy whereby a miserable childhood, and the enduring alienation that followed, were made into something sublime.”

headline: Stamped for Posterity
abstract: Correspondence is a vulnerable part of a literary legacy.
lead_paragraph: This week, John Sutherland reviews the letters of Iris Murdoch. Publishing such collections has become a routine step in completing an author’s legacy. In an email interview, Sutherland said the poet Alexander Pope, who published a book of his letters in 1737, was one of the first writers to realize that “his correspondence would monumentalize his reputation for posterity.”

headline: The ‘Tourist’
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Pedicabs and Rickshaws', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Gaming the system for a kilo of rice in India.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, while visiting my parents in Lucknow, India, I decided to go out and take pictures of the sights in the city. I lived there for the first 30 years of my life and never bothered to photograph these places, but now that I live in the States, I missed my home. In Lucknow, famous for its politeness, poetry, perfume and embroidery, there are many interesting buildings, built by both Mughal and British rulers. So I set out, strolling through a historic part of town with an SLR camera hanging from my neck, looking just like a tourist.

headline: Salonen Makes Clear He Won’t Lead New York Philharmonic
abstract: Esa-Pekka Salonen, a conductor and composer, reiterated that he will not succeed the orchestra’s music director, Alan Gilbert, despite speculation.
lead_paragraph: Esa-Pekka Salonen, the innovative Finnish conductor who is the composer in residence at the New York Philharmonic, will not be the orchestra’s next music director, disappointing some fans and a number of prominent critics who had favored him for the post.

headline: In Fast Transition, Maryland Excels Under New Rules
abstract: A part of the rise of the No. 3 Terrapins, who face No. 11 Michigan State on Saturday, lies in successfully adapting to the various rules changes in men’s basketball.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Mark Turgeon, the men’s basketball coach at Maryland, casually dribbled a ball between his legs during the Terrapins’ practice Monday at Xfinity Center. The team spent several minutes on a transition drill during which the shot clock was set to a parsimonious 20 seconds.

headline: What Pegi Vail Knows About Backpackers
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Movies', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Biodiversity', 'Budget Travel']
abstract: An anthropologist looks at tourism’s impact, both good and bad, on communities and biodiversity.
lead_paragraph: Pegi Vail, 53, an anthropologist and the associate director of the Center for Media, Culture and History at New York University, studies backpacker subculture and the impact of travel on communities and on biodiversity. Her documentary, “Gringo Trails,” has been shown at dozens of festivals and in more than 20 countries since 2014, and recently was released on DVD (it is also available on iTunes and Amazon Video). Here are edited excerpts from an interview with her.

headline: A San Francisco Super Bowl Experience, With or Without a Ticket
abstract: The N.F.L. has turned the event into a weeklong affair, with happenings that appeal to football fans, as well as the non-fans who are tagging along.
lead_paragraph: Attending the Super Bowl in person is a bucket-list item for sports fans that seems to get more out of reach every year.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF THORNS: Nine Lives in the World’s Largest Refugee Camp, by Ben Rawlence. (Picador, $26.) The lives of forcibly displaced people the world over are illuminated in this disturbing portrait of a huge refugee camp in Kenya.

headline: Jonathan Anderson for Loewe: ‘A Purist Kind of Thing’
abstract: The British designer’s latest collection for the Spanish luxury goods house includes oversize bags, beanies and hand-painted leather jackets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jonathan Anderson, a.k.a. J. W. Anderson, the reigning British designer of the year for both women’s wear and men’s wear, is one busy guy.

headline: Keeping Dr. Paul Kalanithi’s Voice Alive
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Books and Literature', 'Medicine and Health', 'Lung Cancer', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Dr. Lucy Kalanithi made sure Paul’s final thoughts led to the book “When Breath Becomes Air,” and has continued his conversation on living and dying.
lead_paragraph: On March 9, 2015, two years after learning he had metastatic lung cancer, Dr. Paul Kalanithi, 37, a neurosurgeon at Stanford University, died. He left behind his wife, Dr. Lucy Kalanithi, their 8-month-old daughter, Cady, and a file on his computer labeled Kalanithi-Ms-20Feb.docx. His wife took that document, shepherded its contents to publication, and the resulting book, “When Breath Becomes Air,” became an instant best-seller this month. Dr. Kalanithi, 36, is a general internist at Stanford, where she helps lead efforts to improve the quality and efficiency of care. She recently folded herself into a leather armchair in her home in the San Francisco Bay Area, the same spot where her husband sat while he wrote, and talked about her own experience — as a young widow in grief, as her husband’s literary stand-in, and as a physician who witnessed at intensely personal range the end to an extraordinary man’s life. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: ‘On the Edge,’ by Rafael Chirbes
abstract: Trapped in Spain’s recession, this novel’s protagonist embodies the effects of his country’s corruption.
lead_paragraph: “On the Edge” is not a book you want to read in fits and starts. It is an anti-tweet, a brick of dense prose, that 70-year-old uncle who corners you at a holiday party, grabs you by the lapels and demands you hear him out. Your eyes sometimes glaze over, and you occasionally have to wipe a fleck of whitish spit off your face, but once you give yourself over to his story, you find there are plenty of rewards.

headline: ‘Russell Kirk: American Conservative,’ by Bradley J. Birzer
abstract: The ground-breaking political philosopher Russell Kirk worked a fascination on thinking Americans of all leanings.
lead_paragraph: “I’m so happy to find that you’re little, too!” the political philosopher Leo Strauss said when he first met Russell Kirk in Chicago in the mid-1950s. “From your books, I had feared that you might be a great, tall, fierce man.” Kirk can still seem great and fierce. It was his book “The Conservative Mind” (1953) that first used the word “conservative” to classify various currents of antiprogressive dissidence that ran from the French Revolution to the 20th-century heyday of social democracy. Kirk’s book was an event. After a recommendation from Whittaker Chambers, Time magazine devoted the entire book review section to it. And Kirk had other gifts. He was a capable writer of ghost and fantasy novels. He founded and edited two prestigious journals. Not just Strauss and Chambers but also T. S. Eliot and Ray Bradbury esteemed him. In 1955, Flannery O’Connor, scarcely able to walk, traveled 340 miles in hopes of seeing him lecture in ­Tennessee.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest designs from Junya Watanabe.
lead_paragraph: The latest designs from Junya Watanabe.

headline: Jason Rezaian Travels to U.S. on Washington Post Owner’s Plane
abstract: Mr. Rezaian left an American military hospital in Germany, the last of the three Americans who flew there from Iran on Sunday to return home.
lead_paragraph: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter who was among the American citizens freed by Iran last weekend in a prisoner deal, left an American military hospital in Germany on Friday bound for the United States, accompanied by his wife and mother aboard his boss’s personal jetliner.

headline: Under No Certain Search Terms
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Research', 'Archives and Records', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: It’s called “research rapture” — the moment you slip the bonds of the present and follow a detail into the past.
lead_paragraph: When you’re writing a book based on archival research and you have two children who come home from school at 3, no matter how much you love libraries, you become grateful for Google. For three years, I sat down most mornings at my dining room table in my slippers and read newspapers printed in the 1870s. No need to travel to distant archives, or spend fruitless hours turning the wrong pages. I could open a browser, punch in a range of dates and a few search terms, and within seconds have a presorted queue of articles, every one of which was relevant. I could feel confident that when it came to coverage of, let’s say, an embassy of Japanese statesmen arriving in San Francisco in 1872, I hadn’t missed a single mention. I blessed the librarians who had digitized their holdings, and got to work.

headline: Donald Trump’s War With Ted Cruz Turns to the Airwaves
keywords: ['Eminent Domain', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The increasingly fragile détente between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas crumbled on Friday in a burst of negative advertisements and counter-attacks. The sparring came as Mr. Trump moved aggressively to derail Mr. Cruz’s chances of winning the Iowa caucuses in 10 days.
lead_paragraph: The waning alliance of convenience between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas collapsed on Friday in a burst of negative advertisements and counterattacks, as Mr. Trump moved to try to derail Mr. Cruz’s chances of winning the Iowa caucuses in 10 days.

headline: G.E. Reports Strong Quarterly Profit but Sales Are Below Forecasts
abstract: The industrial conglomerate said lower sales for its oil-field equipment unit hurt revenue, but other units, like jet engines and locomotives, were strong.
lead_paragraph: Depressed oil prices, financial market worries and sluggish global growth threaten the industrial sector. But General Electric, the nation’s largest industrial company, seems to be weathering the challenges so far. The company on Friday reported solid fourth-quarter profit and delivered a cautiously optimistic outlook for 2016.

headline: As Sharapova Reaches Milestone, Group of Young Russians Rises
abstract: Four of Maria Sharapova’s protégées joined her in the third round of the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Maria Sharapova has been winning professional tennis matches for half her life, which makes her feel as if time is a passing shot whizzing by her. She was 14 years old when she won her first International Tennis Federation match, and she followed that less than a month later with her first WTA Tour victory.

headline: Donald Trump and the ‘Rivers of Blood’
abstract: America, beware. The bigotry stirred by Enoch Powell’s notorious 1968 speech lasted decades in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Until recently, Donald J. Trump was best known in Britain for “The Apprentice” television series, the Miss Universe contest and a controversial golf course development in Scotland. And most Britons would probably have viewed his decision to enter the presidential race with no more than mild envy: Why can’t British elections be as much fun as American ones?

headline: Two Films, One Designer: The Costumes of ‘Carol’ and ‘Cinderella’
abstract: Sandy Powell is in the rare position of being nominated twice in the same category this year.
lead_paragraph: With 12 Oscar nominations for costume design and three wins, Sandy Powell, is no stranger to awards season. This year is no exception as she finds herself in the remarkable position of getting nods for two films, “Carol” and “Cinderella.”

headline: In the ‘Martyrs’ Remake, French Punishment Is Done American Style
abstract: Pascal Laugier’s 2008 French-language thriller has been adapted for American audiences, with a few script tweaks. Some fans of the original are not pleased.
lead_paragraph: When horror fans dare horror rookies to watch a movie, it’s usually a classic frightfest like “The Exorcist” or a more recent white-knuckler like “It Follows.” When horror fans dare other horror fans to watch a movie, it’s “Martyrs.”

headline: A Drug to Cure Fear
abstract: After one round of treatment, the arachnophobes held the spiders in their bare hands.
lead_paragraph: WHO among us hasn’t wanted to let go of anxiety or forget about fear? Phobias, panic attacks and disorders like post-traumatic stress are extremely common: 29 percent of American adults will suffer from anxiety at some point in their lives.

headline: Clinton-Sanders Battle in Iowa May Be Decided by O’Malley Supporters
abstract: If the former Maryland governor does not receive 15 percent support in the caucuses, his supporters will then be up for grabs by Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Martin O’Malley has rarely broken above 5 percent in Iowa polls, but on caucus night he could be the most popular person in the room — or, rather, his supporters will be, as activists for Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders desperately try to scoop them up.

headline: ‘Operation Thunderbolt,’ by Saul David
abstract: Forty years after a hostage rescue, a detailed account of the challenges, players and planners.
lead_paragraph: On June 27, 1976, an Air France plane took off from Ben-Gurion International Airport in Lod, Israel, heading for Paris with a stopover in Athens, carrying 228 passengers of Israeli, French and various other nationalities. Security at the Lod airport was famously tight — but in Athens, where security was lax, four hijackers boarded the Airbus carrying large black bags that held guns and hand grenades, took over the plane and forced the pilot to divert to Entebbe Airport, on the shore of Lake Victoria in Uganda. Six days later, a team of Israeli Special Forces personnel attacked the airport in a daring and ingenious raid, named Operation Thunderbolt, and freed the hostages.

headline: Maison Margiela: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from John Galliano.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from John Galliano.

headline: Carefully Considering Pension Payment Options
abstract: Deciding whether to take a pension as a one-time payout or a monthly payment for life is a decision that can have major financial consequences.
lead_paragraph: Companies are increasingly offering retirees and former employees the option of taking their pensions in a lump-sum payment, rather than as a traditional monthly payment over a lifetime.

headline: Sympathy Lies With the Pets
abstract: Seeking a mourning card, a shopper discovered that it was easier to find a printed expression of grief if the dear departed weren’t human.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Living on Paper: Letters From Iris Murdoch, 1934-1995’
abstract: Murdoch set aside most afternoons for letters, sending thousands through the years to friends, lovers and fans.
lead_paragraph: At 17, Iris Murdoch was asked what she intended to do with her life. She gave a one-word answer: “Write.” Sixty years on, what may have been Dame Iris Murdoch’s last coherent words as she was sucked into the darkness of Alzheimer’s disease were: “I wrote.”

headline: Hillary Clinton to Highlight Core Supporters on Anniversary of Roe v. Wade
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: As the Democratic presidential primary race has taken a harsher turn in the last few days, Hillary Clinton will try to focus on the group of supporters she hopes will lift her candidacy — women — as she campaigns in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: As the Democratic presidential primary race has taken a harsher turn in the last few days, Hillary Clinton will try to focus on the group of supporters she hopes will lift her candidacy — women — as she campaigns in New Hampshire.

headline: Fashion Wants Alber Elbaz to Start His Own Line
abstract: There’s always talk about designers stepping out on their own, but the former Lanvin designer actually might be able to do it.
lead_paragraph: What should the former Lanvin designer Alber Elbaz do next? As men’s wear goes into high gear in Paris and the city prepares for couture, that is a question that keeps coming up. Though there was a movement last fall, in the immediate wake of his firing, to draft him to be creative director of Christian Dior, the post left vacant by Raf Simons, that talk has died down, and there is now a groundswell of support for him starting his own line.

headline: 1941: British Forces at 4 Million Men
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British armed forces number 4 million men in 1941
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Declaring that the size of the army was at the root of all questions of man power, Prime Minister Winston Churchill revealed to the House of Commons today [Jan. 22] that the British Empire’s armed forces, including the Home Guard, now numbered 4,000,000 men. This army, he explained, was ‘‘a very large and formidable force, both fighting overseas and for defense.’’ Great Britain’s vast industrial establishment, he continued, had been set up in 1939 to provide the army with ‘‘all the equipment it required in continuous action on the Continent of Europe against the German enemy.’’

headline: Dire Warnings Along East Coast as Snow Piles Up
abstract: Millions of people along the East Coast braced for travel disruptions and possible power losses. In some areas, as much as two feet of snow may fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A massive winter storm that threatens to dump two feet of snow on the nation’s capital began pummeling the East Coast on Friday afternoon, as millions of people from the Carolinas to New York braced for a weekend of severe winds, power losses and coastal flooding. Thousands of flights were canceled; governors and mayors warned people to stay indoors and off the roads.

headline: Amit Singh of Google for Work: A Respectful Clash of Ideas
abstract: The president of Google for Work says it’s important to create a culture where people can present diverse points of view.

abstract: A firebrand director stages “Eugene Onegin” in Berlin; an exhibition in London looks at artistic depictions of gardens; and a touring music festival brings indie groups to cities in Australia and beyond.

headline: Daily Report: Airbnb Urges Mayors to ‘Please Tax Us’
abstract: The global head of policy for the room-booking service told his audience at the United States Conference of Mayors: Work with us, and we will collect millions of dollars in taxes.
lead_paragraph: For a company that once resisted collecting local taxes, Airbnb has taken a decidedly pro-tax turn.

headline: Pet Amenities for New York’s Lucky Dogs
abstract: Many pet amenities have sprung up in residential buildings throughout New York in a bid to entice renters and buyers devoted to their pets.
lead_paragraph: It’s morning at Mercedes House, the apartment complex on West 54th Street in Manhattan, and the little ones are frolicking in the loft area, near a big caterpillar-shaped play structure. Later, they might be taken out for a walk. And when they’re all tuckered out, they can curl up on cots.

headline: The Bundy Gang’s Latest Stunt
abstract: The group occupying federal land in Oregon now claims to be concerned about the storage of Native American artifacts.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons to be disturbed by the fact that a band of armed thugs has occupied federal land in Oregon for nearly three weeks with hardly more than a shrug from the authorities. For one thing, if the ringleader were named Hassan instead of Bundy, the right-wing circus on the presidential campaign trail would have been demanding a nuclear response long ago.

headline: Tunisia Sets Nationwide Curfew Amid Growing Unrest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Curfews', 'Unemployment', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Interior Ministry imposed the measure after protests over unemployment across the country turned violent in some cities.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The Tunisian government imposed a nationwide curfew on Friday after protests against unemployment spread across the country and grew more violent, in an echo of the Arab Spring uprising five years ago.

headline: Israeli Forces Remove Dozens of Settlers From Hebron Homes
abstract: Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon said the Jewish settlers had not been granted the permits required to carry out real estate deals in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli troops forcibly removed about 80 Jewish settlers on Friday from two houses in Hebron, in the West Bank, a day after they moved into the buildings they said had been purchased from Palestinians.

headline: Making the Screen Easier to Read
abstract: Most web browsers and operating systems have settings and features that should be able to make low-contrast type more readable.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a way to view all pale gray type as black on the computer? Sad to say, we are not all 19 years old with perfect sight!

headline: Replicas of Ghiberti Doors to Be Unveiled in Florence
abstract: The gilded bronze Baptistery doors with their 28 panels have been replaced with a replicas made by a team of artisans using the materials and techniques mastered centuries ago in a Renaissance workshop.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For nearly 600 years, Lorenzo Ghiberti’s panels depicting scenes from the life of Christ on the north doors of the Baptistery in Florence were exposed to the elements and other vicissitudes of time.

headline: How Larry Page’s Obsessions Became Google’s Business
abstract: Mr. Page is hardly the first Silicon Valley chief with a case of intellectual wanderlust, but to a rare degree he has made his company a reflection of his personal fascinations.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Charles Chase, an engineer who manages Lockheed Martin’s nuclear fusion program, was sitting on a white leather couch at Google’s Solve for X conference when a man he had never met knelt down to talk to him.

headline: Film Forum Presents a 15-Film Coen Brothers Retrospective
abstract: The program includes Ethan and Joel Coen’s “Fargo,” “Raising Arizona” and “No Country for Old Men,” as well as their newest, “Hail, Caesar!”
lead_paragraph: It’s high time. On the eve of their latest opus, the sibling writers-directors Ethan and Joel Coen are receiving a 15-film retrospective at Film Forum, encompassing their first feature, the neo-noir “Blood Simple” (1984), and their new “Hail, Caesar!,” a satire of studio-system Hollywood, on Feb. 4 (it opens in other theaters the next day). Also present are the thrillers (“No Country for Old Men”), the comedies (“Raising Arizona”) and the cult favorites (“The Big Lebowski”), laden with the Coens’ pungent plots and morbid humor.

headline: Lincoln Center Will Create a Performing Arts Hall of Fame
abstract: The first class of honorees for the “Legends at Lincoln Center” initiative will be chosen next month, with an induction ceremony planned for June.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center announced on Friday that it was moving forward with plans to create a performing arts hall of fame, with its first honorees to be chosen next month, an induction ceremony planned for June, and firms selected to design related installations across the campus.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Judge Judy, Best Countries, Unlikely Job Hunts
abstract: Our selection of web gems also looks at bike sharing and death.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Elizabeth Strout’s novel “My Name Is Lucy Barton” is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Primal Bond: Readers of Elizabeth Strout’s novel “My Name Is Lucy Barton” — new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 1 — may not be surprised that the story involves a troubled mother-daughter relationship.

headline: Voice for Hazaras Laments Lost Chances in Afghanistan’s Tumult
abstract: As insurgent groups gain territory, Azizullah Royesh, an education leader in Afghanistan, expressed regret that, despite progress in schools, the government remains unchanged.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — AFTER his return to Afghanistan from exile, in 1986, Azizullah Royesh immediately became a tireless advocate of education as a bridge over the divisions that have made his country a battleground for decades.

lead_paragraph: This week, Jane Mayer discusses “Dark Money”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; David Greenberg talks about “Republic of Spin”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Liability for Products', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']

headline: Does Jeb Bush Want His Family’s Help? It’s Hard to Say, Even for Him

lead_paragraph: EIGHT years ago, Eric Suder decided he wanted to use some of the fortune he had made in telecommunications technology to help students who were the first in their families to attend college.

headline: Where the Stars Get Their Rides
abstract: If major league stars want reclining chairs, wraparound leather couches and big-screen televisions in their vehicles, they know where to go.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Pablo Sandoval pulled up to a custom car shop here on a recent Friday afternoon hoping to do some business. He wanted to trade in the Porsche Panamera he was driving, order new sets of rims for his two Range Rovers, pick up the gray one that was being worked on and discuss the next car he would buy — a 2016 Rolls-Royce Ghost.

headline: Winter Antiques Show Offers a Collection of Recent and Rare Works
abstract: The collisions of art worlds at this year’s show at the Park Avenue Armory are greater than ever because the cutoff date for material has been moved to the present from 1969.
lead_paragraph: The Winter Antiques Show is a short-lived galaxy of colliding worlds. Nearly every booth provides a glimpse into some areas of visual culture, from Egyptian antiquities to American folk art to postwar Italian art glass.

headline: Men’s Wear, Poetically: Rick Owens, Raf Simons, Dries Van Noten and Louis Vuitton
abstract: The designers reveled in fashion’s storytelling trend, offering both clothes and long lists of inspirations.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fashion has a serious case of narrative mania. Designers and their fans alike are so stoned on storytelling and the seductions of reference that one starts to yearn for the preliterate — or pre-Internet, anyway — world.

headline: Essential Home Staging Tips
abstract: The pros share their strategies for making your home enticing to buyers.
lead_paragraph: The practice of staging homes for sale has evolved over the past decade. Some ideas have changed, while others remain the same. The following is a list of current staging tips from the pros:

headline: Russian Fund Under Scrutiny for Loan to Company Linked to Kremlin
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Private Equity', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: The government-backed Russian Direct Investment Fund is in the spotlight for making a big loan to Sibur, two of whose major owners have ties to President Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When a new government-backed investment fund opened five years ago, Moscow wanted to send a simple message: Russia was ready to take the politics out of business.

abstract: Need a weekend project? Try Sam Sifton’s recipe for the classic French dish.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Some Evangelicals Struggle With Black Lives Matter Movement
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Many Christian groups have become active in the movement, but conservative evangelicals are uncomfortable with its embrace of liberal politics, associated with Democrats.
lead_paragraph: For some Christians, support for the Black Lives Matter movement is a no-brainer. After all, Jesus opposed violence, opposed the taking of life and opposed racial distinctions. As the apostle Paul taught in his letter to the Galatians, there is neither slave nor free, for “you are all one in Christ Jesus.”

headline: Flight Canceled Because of the Winter Storm? What You Need to Know
abstract: With a blizzard in the Northeast expected to disrupt travel, passengers should review airline policies regarding flight cancellations.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of unusually warm, occasionally downright balmy, weather, a blizzard watch is in effect for the tri-state area from Saturday morning through Sunday afternoon. The National Weather Service, which issued the alert, is predicting “extremely dangerous travel” because of heavy snowfall and strong winds. If you’ve planning to fly this weekend, take a moment now to refresh your memory about what you’re entitled to — a hotel room? food vouchers? — should your flight be canceled.

headline: Many Moves, One Borough
abstract: Arthur Miller spent much of his time in Brooklyn moving from one place to the next, with many of his residences within blocks of each other.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Miller spent much of his time in Brooklyn moving from one place to the next, with many of his residences within blocks of each other.

headline: Arthur Miller’s Brooklyn
abstract: The playwright, who was born in 1915 and died in 2005, found inspiration in the borough’s neighborhoods, from Midwood to the Heights, where he lived.
lead_paragraph: When Arthur Miller first visited his country cousins in Brooklyn in the early 1920s, Midwood was not just a neighborhood, it was a description. Patches of woods stood thick enough near their East Fifth Street home that the boys could hunt squirrels, rabbits and other small game. There were muddy paths and tomato fields, and big sacks of potatoes in the cellar.

headline: U.S. Moves to Limit Emissions of Planet-Warming Methane
keywords: ['Methane', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: The rules, aimed at gas and oil drilling on public lands, are intended to curb the release of methane, which contributes to global warming.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Friday proposed a new rule aimed at curbing emissions of planet-warming methane from oil and gas drilling on public land. It would force companies to use equipment to capture leaked gas and raise the costs they pay for extracting fuel on government property.

headline: Grigor Dimitrov, a Federer-Like Player, Loses Again to the Real Thing
abstract: Dimitrov, 24, who rose to No. 8 in 2014 but has regressed to No. 28, has long been compared to Federer, 34, who eliminated him from the Australian Open on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — From the beginning of Grigor Dimitrov’s career, his stylistic similarities to Roger Federer were obvious. But as he has stagnated over the past 18 months, their differences are becoming more apparent.

headline: Michigan Governor Says Race Had No Role in Flint Water Response
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder acknowledged failures on the state’s part in the lead contamination of the majority-black city’s water but rejected the label of “environmental racism.”
lead_paragraph: The governor of Michigan said on Friday that race was not a factor in the state’s response to lead contamination in the drinking water in Flint, a poor, majority-black city where the supply has been tainted for more than a year, but for much of that time, state officials insisted that it was safe to drink.

headline: The Price of Requiring Regulators to Do More Cost-Benefit Analysis
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation']

lead_paragraph: A bipartisan, if mildly conservative, group of senators has indicated that it will introduce legislation intended to increase the rule-making requirements on Wall Street regulators like the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Consumer Financial Protection Board.

headline: Donald Trump, Challenging Political Correctness, Strikes a Chord
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Donald J. Trump has regained momentum in Iowa two weeks before the state’s caucuses, and many voters cite his bravado and willingness to assail political correctness, more than his policy proposals, as the main reasons.
lead_paragraph: At a rally in Iowa this week, Donald J. Trump explained in bold terms and broad brush strokes the many ways he would improve the United States as president: building a wall, rebuilding the military, beating China on trade. When a protester chimed in to question how the Republican would do the things that he promised, Mr. Trump decided that instead of removing the man from the audience, he would respond.

headline: At Lille Hotel, Meeting the Countess’s Standards
abstract: With its tranquil garden and sophisticated revival of 18th-century charms, the Clarance is a chic home base for exploring one of France’s most scenic northern towns.
lead_paragraph: From 200 euros a night, or about $215 at $1.07 to the euro.

headline: At Chicago Restaurant, Foraging Fuels the Kitchen
abstract: Arbor, with an urban farm and part of a sustainable business hub, transcends being just another office building coffee shop.
lead_paragraph: “I grew those sunchokes,” our waiter said, referring to the purée under my son’s grass-fed, espresso-cured hanger steak. Then he grabbed his phone to show my daughter pictures of a mushroom he had foraged.

abstract: Ahead of this weekend’s impending snowstorm, we round up the slickest, furriest, most desirable designs from the fall/winter ’16 runways.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Gloria Steinem
abstract: The activist and author shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the activist and author Gloria Steinem, who shares her list exclusively with T. She adds: “If I were marooned on a desert island, I would want a book on edible plants and building a raft, but here are 10 I would choose for the pleasure of big and new understandings.”

headline: Opposition and Confusion at Hearing on Mayor de Blasio’s Horse Plan
keywords: ['Horses', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Carriages', 'Pedicabs and Rickshaws']
abstract: A crowd gathered in City Hall to hear the de Blasio administration present its plan to limit horse carriages to Central Park and ban pedicabs from the park’s southern section.
lead_paragraph: Men in the telltale top hats of a horse-carriage driver. Campaign pins declaring love for animals. Pedicab drivers packed into the balcony of the City Council’s main hearing room.

headline: Bill Johnson, U.S. Olympic Downhill Skiing Champion, Dies at 55
abstract: Johnson, a brash competitor, delivered on his promise to win gold in 1984, at Sarajevo, but was severely injured in a 2001 comeback at age 40 aimed at winning back his ex-wife.
lead_paragraph: Bill Johnson, a swaggering skier who in 1984 became the first American man to win an Olympic gold medal in downhill skiing, but whose life took a sharp, precipitous turn soon afterward, died on Thursday at an assisted-living facility in Gresham, Ore. He was 55.

headline: The Snow Goose, a Welcome Stop Sign in Winter
abstract: Nature in New York City can still stop traffic, even in winter. Adult and juvenile snow geese collect in massive flocks, offering something to marvel at on the road.
lead_paragraph: Nature in New York City can still, quite literally, stop traffic: 30-pound snapping turtles hauling themselves from swamps onto six-lane expressways, mallard ducklings blithely following their mothers across the Bronx River Parkway at rush hour, a rainbow arching between Brooklyn and Staten Island.

headline: Pakistan’s Unnecessary Martyrs
abstract: We’re being told the students killed by the Taliban laid down their lives for the sake of our future. But weren’t they our future?
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — According to our security analysts, the massacre of students and teachers at Bacha Khan University in Charsadda on Wednesday proves that we are winning against terrorism.

headline: Berluti Livens Up Its Leather — With a Little Help from a Tattoo Artist
abstract: The men’s wear brand enlisted Scott Campbell to create five original designs for its fall/winter 2016 shoes, leather goods and clothing.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn tattoo artist Scott Campbell has inked marquee fashion designers like Marc Jacobs, A-list celebrities such as Jennifer Aniston and the late Heath Ledger, and more recently, a certain T editor. Over the past few years, he’s expanded into the art world, applying his designs to a surfeit of unconventional surfaces including ostrich-egg shells, dollar bills and burned tortillas. And now, as part of a collaboration with the storied luxury shoemaker and men’s wear brand Berluti, Campbell brings his artistic eye to another kind of skin — the house’s signature leather.

headline: Group Backing Jeb Bush Draws on ‘Jeopardy’ to Attack John Kasich
abstract: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Bush, uses Mr. Kasich’s record as a governor and congressman from Ohio to paint him as out of step with New Hampshire values.
lead_paragraph: Sensing a possible surge by John Kasich in New Hampshire, Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, has unveiled a game-show-style attack ad against the Ohio governor.

headline: What a Million Syllabuses Can Teach Us
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Textbooks', 'Books and Literature', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Research', 'Academic and Scientific Journals']
abstract: New insights about teaching, publishing and intellectual history.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE course syllabuses are curious documents. They represent the best efforts by faculty and instructors to distill human knowledge on a given subject into 14-week chunks. They structure the main activity of colleges and universities. And then, for the most part, they disappear.

headline: Charlotte Rampling Says Oscars ‘Boycott’ Is ‘Racist Against Whites’
abstract: The best-actress nominee drew widespread condemnation online.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Charlotte Rampling, an Academy Award nominee for best actress, on Friday waded into the furor over the lack of diversity in the Oscar acting categories, saying that the supposed calls to boycott the ceremony were “racist against whites.”

headline: Taxi Dave Rides the Airwaves
abstract: David Pollack, who was born in his father’s cab, he says, and followed his family into the business, hosts a taxi-themed radio show.
lead_paragraph: David Pollack, a.k.a. Taxi Dave, settled behind a microphone last weekend in the TriBeCa studios of WOR-AM (710) for his taxi-themed talk radio show, which has become popular with New York City cabbies and other listeners at 8 p.m. Sunday nights.

headline: Japanese Chicken and Root Vegetable Stew
abstract: This nimono, or braised root vegetable stew, is the perfect way to use up the last of your winter C.S.A. box.
lead_paragraph: This nimono, or braised root vegetable stew, is the perfect way to use up the last of your winter C.S.A. box.

headline: 1891: American Pork Is Vindicated
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German politicians praise the quality of American pork in Parliament in 1891.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – How proud the American hog would feel if he had been present at the discussion to-day [Jan. 22]. Herr Barth, in a speech full of sense and statistical arguments, certified to his healthfulness and cheapness. Witness England, Holland and Belgium; witness the 400,000lb. smuggled into Germany under the Dutch seal without bad results except to the man caught smuggling.

headline: A Japanese Stew Puts Root Vegetables to Good Use
abstract: In a nimono, they’re all simmered in a tasty broth for a winter-weather antidote. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: After years of shopping at the farmers’ market in the depths of winter, I finally have my root-vegetable game down. I’ve figured out the perfect way to braise turnips (lots of butter, a small amount of chicken stock), mastered the too-many-parsnips conundrum (roast with olive oil and cumin salt), and even gotten my 7-year-old to appreciate the finer points of kohlrabi (sliced thin and eaten raw).

headline: ‘Too Big to Fail’ Banks Thriving a Few Years After Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Despite the endless complaining about how difficult Washington has made things for bankers, Wall Street has entered a Golden Age.
lead_paragraph: Nearly eight years after the onset of the financial crisis, its unintended consequences continue to startle and amaze.

headline: Arrest of Leftist Israeli Activist Underlines Political Split
abstract: Ezra Nawi has become a symbol in the battle between advocacy groups on opposite sides of Israel’s political spectrum, and the debate over the nature of Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ezra Nawi, an Israeli Jewish plumber, has a long history as a left-wing activist helping Palestinians in their struggle against Israel’s occupation of the West Bank. Now he is under arrest in Israel, after a right-wing activist surreptitiously filmed him bragging about exposing Arab brokers who tried to sell Palestinian land to Jewish settlers. Such sales are a capital crime under Palestinian law.

headline: Jane Jacobs and Other Shrewd Observers
abstract: Dispelling the condescending and sexist contemporary view that Ms. Jacobs’s canonical book on cities was a housewife’s collection of home remedies.
lead_paragraph: Jane Jacobs was so consumed in the late 1950s by the writing of her manifesto, “The Death and Life of Great American Cities,” that her hair turned from auburn to white. In “Becoming Jane Jacobs” (University of Pennsylvania Press, $34.95), Peter L. Laurence dispels the sexist and condescending contemporary view that her canonical book was a collection of home remedies from a housewife whose only credentials were as an amateur observer of the city’s sidewalk ballet.

headline: How Stories Drive the Stock Market
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Recession and Depression', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Narrative psychology suggests that popular narratives, particularly human-interest stories, are fundamental drivers of motivation.
lead_paragraph: Since the stock market began falling at the beginning of this year, there seems to have been a palpable change in the stories we have been hearing. Suddenly there is more willingness to entertain the possibility of a major stock market correction, or of an economic recession.

lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton defended her paid speeches to Wall Street firms, rejecting the idea that the millions of dollars she earned in fees would sway her views on financial firms.

headline: Netflix and Blizzard: What to Watch During the Storm
abstract: A list of some worthy streaming video options, organized into four categories.
lead_paragraph: The winter storm in the Eastern United States might make it difficult or inadvisable for many to leave their homes this weekend. But instead of viewing this as a snowtastrophe, let’s think of it as an opportunity to finally catch up on movies and TV. Here’s a list of some worthy streaming video options, organized into four categories. Consider watching any or all of these, preferably while nestled under a warm blanket with the heat cranked up to 11.

headline: A Picture of the Blizzard’s Aftermath
abstract: A satellite image from NASA shows the extent of the huge winter storm that blanketed the East Coast with snow on Saturday.

headline: After Preparing for the Snowstorm, Prepare to Shovel

lead_paragraph: This storm, if the forecasts prove accurate, could not be better timed for most New Yorkers.

headline: Man Who Tried to Attack Paris Police Acted Alone, Germany Finds
abstract: A man shot to death by the French police was not part of a wider terrorist organization when he approached a station on Jan. 7, German investigators said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A man shot to death by French police officers this month acted alone and not as part of a wider terrorist organization when he approached a Paris police station armed with a meat cleaver and fake explosives, the German authorities said on Friday.

headline: Chicken Tacos Let You Think Fast
abstract: Build them to order and devour them immediately. Bliss on a plate, and nothing fancy.
lead_paragraph: A roasted chicken, or the remains thereof, is a wonderful thing to have on hand. So is a boiled one. I often simmer the chicken till done, remove the meat and toss the bones back into the broth to enrich it. Sometimes I simmer a few thighs for the same purpose.

headline: Panoramic Hudson Views for $13.17 Million
abstract: A loft-like apartment on the seventh floor of 150 Charles Street in the West Village was the week’s biggest closed sale.
lead_paragraph: A loft-like apartment on the seventh floor of 150 Charles Street, the Witkoff Group’s condominium in the West Village that sold all 91 luxury units just a few weeks after sales opened three years ago, officially closed for $13,172,500.71, according to city records, and was the most expensive sale of the week.

headline: Sotheby’s Announces $12 Million Loss Over Taubman Sale
abstract: On Friday, Tad Smith, the auction house’s president, attributed particular fourth-quarter results to a combination of a sales shortfall and related expenses.
lead_paragraph: For months, the art world had been wondering: Would the biggest guarantee in auction history pay off? Would Sotheby’s come out ahead, break even or be left holding the bag on a $515 million commitment to the collection of its disgraced former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman?

headline: How the Snow Storm Is Affecting Travel
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Railroads', 'Buses', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: Thousands of flights have been canceled, a travel ban is in place in New York, and some hotels are offering specials for snowed-in travelers.
lead_paragraph: The winter storm that has hit the East Coast this weekend has scrambled travel plans, leading to 10,850 flight cancellations and more than 5,000 delays since Friday, according to FlightAware. Airlines, ground transportation providers, hotels and attractions are all adjusting their schedules and policies. The following is what’s happening so far.

headline: At Wyckoff’s Corner Pharmacy in Cobble Hill, It’s Personal
abstract: The drugstore opened a decade ago in Brooklyn and its reputation for personal service spread quickly.
lead_paragraph: The city can sometimes seem like a battlefield for chain pharmacies, where the last vestiges of vintage apothecaries can be found only in kitsch restaurants that open in former pharmacies. But actual mom-and-pop drugstores still exist, even in gentrified Brooklyn neighborhoods like Cobble Hill, where Wyckoff’s Corner Pharmacy has endured for the past decade.

lead_paragraph: The staff at California New York Express Movers are well acquainted with Megan Hilty. After all, Ms. Hilty, who just opened in a Broadway revival of the farce “Noises Off,” has had her worldly goods hauled across the country five times. So far.

abstract: Prospective public companies are postponing initial offerings in the face of an uncertain stock market, given the ready availability of private investment.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The market for initial public offerings has been all but dead since late last year. Don’t expect that freeze to lift anytime soon, according to two top officials for the United States’ biggest stock exchanges.

lead_paragraph: The Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan said Friday that its director, Glenn Adamson, 43, would step down at the end of March “to work on exhibition, research and institutional development projects.”

headline: Rape by Strangers
abstract: While it is possible to know, within microseconds, instances of grand larceny, the Police Department does not make public a map of where and when stranger rapes have occurred.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, a Brooklyn judge sentenced a 26-year-old man, Dexter Bell, to a minimum prison term of 100 years for raping four women in the course of one week during the spring of 2013. In each instance, Mr. Bell had approached his victim in late afternoon or early evening, briefly initiating conversation before dragging her into an alleyway or stairwell and waging his assault. The B12 bus route between Crown Heights and Canarsie was a preferred corridor for his predations; his youngest victim was 15.

headline: An American Designer Takes Cerruti Back to Its Roots
keywords: ['Paris Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Jason Basmajian worked fast to put together what he calls a “very masculine” collection in time for the Paris men’s wear presentation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was both a new beginning and a return to the past for the designer Jason Basmajian, who presented his first collection for Cerruti 1881 on a dark, rainy Friday afternoon in a showroom off the Place Vendôme. “At least it’s not snowing,” said one of the attendees as he shook the rain from his expensive-looking blazer, a reference to the snowstorm working its way up the East Coast that many of the Americans here for men’s fashion week seem to be obsessing over.

headline: Some Charges Against Former Penn State Officials Thrown Out
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A Pennsylvania appeals court dismissed some serious criminal charges against three administrators over their handling of the Sandusky child molestation scandal.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania appeals court on Friday threw out some of the more serious criminal charges against three high-ranking former Penn State administrators whose handling of the Jerry Sandusky child molestation scandal continues to be a flash point for the state’s flagship university.

headline: How Cynthia Rowley, Fashion Designer, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Rowley unwinds by doing “extreme activities” — working out, go-kart racing, sledding — with her husband and their two daughters.
lead_paragraph: To judge from the society pages, the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley and her husband, Bill Powers, seem to be out on the town six days a week. But on the seventh day, the couple downshifts (slightly) into the rhythms of family life. Which is to say, “We do extreme activities,” said Ms. Rowley, 57, for whom family means her husband, a 48-year-old writer and art dealer, and two school-age daughters, Kit and Gigi. If your idea of unwinding is racing go-karts or singing Iggy Pop songs, then let them be your relaxation counselors. If not, try to hang on until the rocket returns to home base, a house in the West Village.

headline: Sundance Officially Sidesteps Oscar Controversy, but Its Opening Film Doesn’t
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The festival’s founder and its director declined to weigh in on this year’s all-white slate of actor nominees, but a documentary on Norman Lear tackled the race issue.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — The Sundance Film Festival, which has long championed diversity, both behind cameras and in front of them, did its best on Thursday, the festival’s opening day, to stick to its knitting and avoid getting drawn into the #OscarsSoWhite controversy.

headline: Pentagon Chief on Turkey, ISIS and Asia
abstract: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said that he wanted to see Turkey do more in the fight against the Islamic State. He also discussed peace in Asia.
lead_paragraph: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said that he wanted to see Turkey do more in the fight against the Islamic State. He also discussed peace in Asia.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Is One Victory From Downhill Skiing Record

lead_paragraph: CORTINA D’AMPEZZO, Italy — Elite female ski racers, coaches and technicians sip cappuccino on the sun-drenched deck of the Rifugio Duca d’Aosta lodge while gazing in awe at the Schuss, the most harrowing section of Cortina’s Olympia delle Tofane downhill course.

lead_paragraph: Residents of New Jersey who have been missing Gov. Chris Christie during his presidential bid now know what it takes to bring him home: the threat of a big snow.

headline: Central Park Carriage Horses, Steady as They Go
abstract: The photographer Julie McGuire captured images of the carriage horses of Central Park, finding a sureness of step amid the chaos of the city and the changes coming to their industry.
lead_paragraph: After Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan this week to reduce the size of the Victorian-era carriage-horse industry and relocate carriage horses to Central Park, virtually the only parties involved not heard from were the horses themselves. As ever, they maintained a dignified silence amid the hubbub.

headline: Haiti Postpones Presidential Runoff as Violence Rises

headline: Review: Chelsea Handler Chats Up Racism, Marriage and More
abstract: Ms. Handler wrestles with, and chuckles about, marriage, racism, Silicon Valley and drugs in four talk-show-like documentaries on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: If you let someone with a talk-show background make documentaries, what you get, apparently, are talk-show-like documentaries — ones that ramble and lack focus and are more akin to visiting with a topic than to making a point about it.

headline: Kansas Court of Appeals Voids Restrictive 2015 Abortion Law
abstract: The blocked law, adopted last April, would ban the most common method used in second-trimester abortions, known as dilation and evacuation.
lead_paragraph: In a split decision, the Kansas Court of Appeals on Friday held that the state Constitution, like the federal one, protected a woman’s right to an abortion and affirmed a lower court order blocking enforcement of a restrictive 2015 law.

headline: U.S. May Put Forces at Iraqi Bases in Effort to Retake Mosul
abstract: The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said American and Iraqi officials had begun discussion on how to “integrate” Americans with Iraqi military units.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — American commanders are considering whether to establish a presence at Iraqi military outposts and bases north of Baghdad ahead of a looming fight against Islamic State militants in Mosul, defense officials said Friday.

headline: At Dries Van Noten, Psychedelic Cues Meet Military Tailoring
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The designer was inspired by the graphic designer Wes Wilson’s ’60s posters, synonymous with the peace movement of the time.
lead_paragraph: The designer was inspired by the graphic designer Wes Wilson’s ’60s posters, synonymous with the peace movement of the time.

headline: New Suspect in Paris Attacks Is Detained, Belgian Officials Say
abstract: The prosecutor’s office said it had detained a new suspect and released one who had been detained, though the man who was released will be required to appear before a judge.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian prosecutor’s office announced on Friday that it had detained a new suspect in the attacks in Paris and had released one who had been previously detained. But it said it would still require the man who was released to appear before a judge and limit his activities.

headline: True Scandal of Deflategate Lies in the N.F.L.’s Behavior
abstract: A scientific consensus that deflation of footballs in the 2015 A.F.C. title game could be explained by physics has not done anything to mitigate the Patriots’ punishment.
lead_paragraph: John Leonard is a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who roots for the Philadelphia Eagles, listens to sports talk radio when he is exercising, and teaches a course called Measurement and Instrumentation. When the Deflategate story broke after last year’s A.F.C. championship game between the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts, he found himself fixated on it, yearning to dig into it from a scientific point of view.

headline: Gainsbourg and Birkin, Fearless on Film at Lincoln Center
abstract: Daughter and mother talk about their penchant for risk-taking on the eve of a program devoted to their work.
lead_paragraph: “Charlotte?”

headline: The Timeshare Hard Sell Comes Roaring Back
abstract: High-pressure practices by Diamond and others have prompted lawsuits and led to predictions that regulators will increase oversight of the industry.
lead_paragraph: For more than 25 years, Mary Ann Gutierrez, 77, has spent several weeks a year at on the southern shore of Lake Tahoe, Calif., often playing host to her children and grandchildren at one of two timeshare units she owns.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Ron Lieber, C.J. Chivers and others.

headline: Opposing Factions Take to Facebook in Oregon Wildlife Refuge Dispute
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal Lands', 'Native Americans', 'Social Media']
abstract: The occupiers and federal officials are trading volleys over who is better at protecting and conserving American Indian artifacts.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — As more people beg the armed antigovernment protesters who took over the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge here three weeks ago to go home, the protesters this week embarked on a new quest: a search for allies.

headline: Cavaliers, No. 1 in the East, Fire Coach David Blatt
abstract: Cleveland fired Coach David Blatt despite the team’s 30-11 record. General Manager David Griffin said the team was regressing.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Cavaliers own the best record in the Eastern Conference and are one season removed from appearing in the finals, but no jobs are ever safe in the coaching profession. The Cavaliers made that clear on Friday afternoon by firing Coach David Blatt in an organizational shake-up three weeks before the All-Star break.

headline: Snow Starts to Spread Across the Country
abstract: As the East Coast prepared for a major winter storm, many parts of the United States were already being blanketed by snow.
lead_paragraph: As the East Coast prepared for a major winter storm, many parts of the United States were already being blanketed by snow.

headline: With Calm and Experience, John Kasich Connects in New Hampshire
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After appearing lost in a crowded Republican field, the Ohio governor has been enjoying a wave of attention in the first primary state as a serious and nonangry candidate.
lead_paragraph: WOLFEBORO, N.H. — At a Rotary Club meeting in Laconia, N.H., on Thursday, a woman confided that she feared whether the United States would be safe for her children and grandchildren, citing dangers like the Islamic State.

headline: Four Killed in Saskatchewan School Shooting
abstract: Others were wounded in the shooting in the northern Saskatchewan town of La Loche, but the police offered few details.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Four people were killed and an unknown number were injured in a school shooting in a small town in northern Saskatchewan on Friday, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said.

headline: Donald Trump Blasts Ted Cruz Using the Senator’s Own Words
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Political Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mr. Trump, in a new negative commercial, assails Mr. Cruz over immigration using footage from Mr. Cruz’s past that shows him uncomfortable and off-script.
lead_paragraph: Fighting neck-and-neck in the Iowa polls with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, Donald J. Trump has gone negative, with a 60-second advertisement assailing Mr. Cruz over a hot-button issue with conservatives in Iowa: immigration.

headline: ‘Art From the Holocaust’: The Beauty and Brutality in Forbidden Works
abstract: An exhibition opening at the German Historical Museum in Berlin shows 100 works clandestinely created by Jews in Nazi-occupied territories.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Nelly Toll was 8 years old, during World War II, she rewrote the Cinderella fairy tale with a feminist twist. Instead of Prince Charming, a powerful princess invited Cinderella to live in her castle and enjoy a pianist performing in a sun-drenched room.

headline: Berluti: Fall 2016
abstract: Berluti presents men’s wear looks for next fall.
lead_paragraph: Berluti presents men’s wear looks for next fall.

headline: Abortion Opponents Rally in Washington
abstract: Anti-abortion activists took part in a March for Life event near the National Mall on the anniversary of the decision in Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Anti-abortion activists took part in a March for Life event near the National Mall on the anniversary of the decision in Roe v. Wade.

headline: Review: John Epperson Steps Out, Leaving the Diva at Home
abstract: “An Evening With Lypsinka’s Maid,” Mr. Epperson’s new show at Feinstein’s/54 Below, features him without his female alter ego.
lead_paragraph: One thing we’ve learned from the Superman myth is that the Man of Steel has a mild-mannered alter ego, Clark Kent, who few suspect has any connection to that heroic crusader. A similar relationship exists between the drag actor, singer and pianist John Epperson and his brilliant, brassy creation Lypsinka, one of the greatest creatures to emerge from the New York club scene.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spotted
abstract: The cat family doesn’t change its colors but the fashion world is in a playful mood with one of its most popular patterns: the leopard print.
lead_paragraph: The cat family doesn’t change its colorsbut the fashion world is in a playful mood with one of its most popular patterns: the leopard print. It’s intriguing to see all the variations of black and gray, some of them with an overlay of subtle color. One wearer highlighted her coat with creative details, such as a gold-bronze envelope bag; a necklace that blended with the coat, and a color cast of pale pink and aqua; and leopard-print fingerless gloves. Perhaps surprisingly, this fashion lover works in investment banking; her personal style of dress is her hobby.

headline: Review: ‘Elektra’ Runs Wild, With Ann Liv Young
abstract: A loose interpretation of Sophocles that features a live pig, this show at New York Live Arts in Chelsea also includes “Elektra Cabaret.”
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine Ann Liv Young and company doing what they did on Wednesday night more than once, let alone eight times, the length of their run at New York Live Arts in Chelsea. The brutal rawness and immediacy that we’ve come to expect from Ms. Young, a divisive performer and choreographer, reaches new heights — or newly disturbing depths — in her “Elektra,” which had its United States premiere alongside its even rowdier companion piece, “Elektra Cabaret.”

headline: Review: ‘The Book of Disquiet,’ Opera as One Man, With Films
abstract: Presented at Montclair State University, this piece by the Dutch composer Michel van der Aa adapts a hard-to-classify work by the Portuguese writer Fernando Pessoa.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — O.K., opera lovers, try this one on for size: No one sings live. The only two vocal numbers are rendered on film by a Portuguese fado singer. The lone figure onstage, apart from the small orchestra, speaks throughout. The drama is all internal and mostly philosophical.

abstract: Photos from Serbia, Ukraine, India and the United States.
