headline: Review: ‘Dirty Grandpa’ Features Robert De Niro on the Prowl
abstract: In this comedy directed by Dan Mazer, Mr. De Niro’s character cajoles his grandson to take a road trip to Florida with him in time for spring break.
lead_paragraph: Dan Mazer’s crude, mindless “Dirty Grandpa” is like watching a friend’s mediocre improv troupe do an extended spring-break sketch. And your friend just happens to be Robert De Niro.

headline: Review: Daniel Wohl’s ‘Holographic’ Is Performed for the First Time
abstract: Mr. Wohl’s multimedia piece for string quartet and percussion had its debut at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Unsurprisingly, in a digital age, multimedia performances have become pervasive at both uptown and downtown spaces. While contemporary works are most often accompanied by visuals, the standard repertory is not immune: A coming series at the 92nd Street Y will offer multimedia takes on Beethoven violin sonatas, among other pieces.

headline: Review: ‘The Boy,’ in Which a Doll May be Alive, or the Heroine May Be Mad
abstract: Lauren Cohan stars in this small-cast thriller, directed by William Brent Bell, which has enough scary moments to satisfy horror fans.
lead_paragraph: A creepy doll and a creepy house are the main ingredients of “The Boy,” a small-cast horror movie that spends a lot of time building itself into a psychological thriller, only to veer in a more literal direction at the end. It still has enough scary moments to satisfy horror fans, but you’re left wondering whether it might have been more disturbing had it stayed on its original path.

headline: Review: Keanu Reeves Undertakes an Investigation in ‘Exposed’
abstract: The appearance of angels, an unexpected birth and a violent death coincide in this drama, written by Gee Malik Linton.
lead_paragraph: “Exposed,” starring Keanu Reeves, opened on Friday in the 23rd of 25 theaters in a New York City multiplex, with little fanfare and no screenings for critics.

headline: Julien Duvivier, a Gallic Auteur at Home, and Jacques Feyder, One Abroad
abstract: The two directors are the subjects of new collections: Duvivier in an Eclipse set of four films, and Feyder in two Hollywood films starring Ramón Novarro.
lead_paragraph: Perennially ripe for rediscovery, Julien Duvivier (1896-1967) was a prolific if uneven filmmaker with a five-decade career that included a short stint in Hollywood and encompassed a variety of genres.

headline: Philips Halts Sale of Controlling Stake in LED Business
keywords: ['Electronics', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Foreign Investments', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Philips, the electronics giant, said it had terminated an agreement to sell a controlling stake in its automotive and LED components business because of regulatory concerns in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Friday that it had terminated an agreement to sell a controlling stake in its automotive and LED components business because of regulatory concerns raised in the United States. A group led by GO Scale Capital, an investment fund sponsored by GSR Ventures of China and Oak Investment Partners, agreed in March to acquire an 80.1 percent stake in the Philips unit, called Lumileds, for as much as $2.9 billion. Philips combined the lighting and LED components operations into a stand-alone company in 2014. Philips said in October that the closing of the deal was “uncertain” after the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, an interagency body that includes representatives from the Treasury and Justice Departments, raised “unforeseen concerns” about the deal. GO Scale Capital has offices in Beijing, Hong Kong and California. It has said that its goal is to “scale up its investments in China for global markets.”

headline: Fears About China’s Economy Fester at Davos
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: As fingers point to China as a source of economic concern, its supporters note its potential for growth.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — At the World Economic Forum here, chief executives and investors are blaming China for a slump in global markets.

headline: Steven Moffat Leaving ‘Doctor Who’ in 2017
abstract: Mr. Moffat, the lead writer and an executive producer of the popular BBC science-fiction series, will leave after the 2017 season.
lead_paragraph: After six seasons of overseeing the exploits of a centuries-old alien adventurer, Steven Moffat plans to move on to other parts of the space-time continuum.

headline: Anger in Michigan Over Appointing Emergency Managers
abstract: The water in Flint and the schools in Detroit have people asking whether Michigan has appointed too many emergency managers in largely black jurisdictions.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — In the spring of 2013, Detroit was groaning under the weight of its troubles. It had accumulated billions in debt, was riddled with crime and had seen much of its affluent tax base disappear. A former mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, was convicted of racketeering and fraud.

headline: Storage of Records of Background Checks Shifted After Last Year’s Security Breach
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Computer Security', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Employees']
abstract: A major component of the overhaul will be the creation of a new agency that will process federal background checks, called the National Background Investigations Bureau.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday said that the Defense Department would take over the storage of records from federal background checks, part of an overhaul prompted by a colossal cybersecurity breach at the Office of Personnel Management.

headline: In Case of Blizzard, Do Nothing
abstract: A snowstorm rewards indolence and punishes go-getters, which is why it’s the best natural disaster there is.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1985 my hometown, Buffalo, was engulfed in a blizzard — not an uncommon occurrence for the region, which is justly famed for epic snows. But this was a big one, and the city’s blustery Irish-American mayor, Jimmy Griffin, was at pains to persuade people to stop trying to go about their business as conditions deteriorated. He urged Buffalonians to “relax, stay inside and grab a six-pack,” which must be the best advice any elected official ever gave the public in an emergency situation.

headline: On The Road (Personal and Trivial)
abstract: Why the radio silence.
lead_paragraph: Just a note on radio silence: I’ve been traveling — back home yesterday, and then basically fleeing the New York area, moving up a family-related car trip so as not to get trapped by snow. Destination safely reached, but bandwidth very limited, so no posts, musical or otherwise, today.

headline: Community Gardens Imperiled by New York’s Affordable Housing Plans
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Land Use Policies', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Many of the gardens occupy plots of land owned by the City of New York, leaving residents who have tended them for years with few options to oppose the changes.
lead_paragraph: Apart from a colorful hand-painted sign, there is little to suggest that the Mandela Community Garden in Harlem, a lot piled with pieces of pavement and bounded by graffitied walls and a chain-link fence, is a garden at all. The volunteers who pulled up the concrete had made plans for the spring, however: to pepper the dirt with wildflower seeds, make sculptures from the rubble and turn the lot into a verdant little oasis.

headline: Google Pays Britain $185 Million to Settle Back Taxes
abstract: The technology giant says it will change how it calculates its tax payments in Britain so they are based on a percentage of local sales derived from the country.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google on Friday agreed to pay 130 million pounds, or about $185 million in back taxes to Britain, making it the latest United States technology company to settle claims that it does not pay its fair share of taxes in Europe.

headline: Judge Orders Medical Examination of Sumner Redstone
abstract: In a reversal, a judge said the examination of Sumner Redstone, executive chairman of Viacom, was needed to obtain sufficient evidence in a case questioning his mental competence.
lead_paragraph: A California judge has ordered the ailing 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone to undergo a medical examination, a major development in the continuing legal battle over his mental competence.

headline: 2 Women Hurt in Robbery at Hotel Near J.F.K. Airport
abstract: A woman and her daughter are both listed in stable condition after they were robbed outside a hotel near the airport, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A woman who had traveled to New York with her daughter was shot and her daughter injured after they were robbed outside a hotel near Kennedy International Airport, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Their Boss Stays on the Sideline, but Obama Aides Tilt to Clinton
abstract: The White House is working with Hillary Clinton’s campaign in ways large and small. Their two staffs consult on issues and the positions she takes on the president’s policy priorities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two leading Democratic contenders for president are competing to wrap President Obama in a tight embrace. He is hugging only one of them back.

headline: Biking Through a Snowstorm in Washington
abstract: Follow the Times video journalist A. J. Chavar as he takes a bike ride to the Capitol as a blizzard took hold of Washington on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Follow the Times video journalist A. J. Chavar as he takes a bike ride to the Capitol as a blizzard took hold of Washington on Friday.

headline: Mosquito-Borne Zika Virus Found in 3 New York State Patients
abstract: Health officials said the people infected with the pathogen, which is spreading in Latin America and the Caribbean, had been abroad.
lead_paragraph: State health officials said on Friday that three people in New York State, including one from Queens, tested positive for Zika, a mosquito-borne virus that has prompted concern as it has spread rapidly, mostly in Latin America and the Caribbean.

headline: The Oscars and Hollywood’s Race Problem
abstract: I love the movies. I don’t love how no one ever seems to look like me.
lead_paragraph: WHEN we talk about diversity, or the lack thereof, we refer to it as “a problem.” This or that industry, organization or group has a gender problem or a race problem or some other kind of diversity-related problem. We identify the problem and discuss it, exhaustively, often contentiously, because the problem is significant, pervasive, and for those of us who are most affected, the problem is personal.

headline: Sarah Palin, This Is What PTSD Is Really Like
abstract: It’s dangerous and damaging to assume that violence is a symptom of this disease.
lead_paragraph: AS a veteran, I want politicians and public figures to try and understand what military deployment is like, and to relate to my experiences. But I’m not sure I want Sarah Palin weighing in.

headline: UConn Undaunted by Uneven Start (It’s Not March Yet)
abstract: The Huskies, 13-5 with a key matchup with Georgetown looming, won the national championship in 2014 after an indifferent regular season.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — In the $40 million basketball practice center at UConn, there are subtle and more obvious reminders of the Huskies’ most recent men’s basketball glory: a giant banner commemorating the 2014 national championship team, and the folding chairs scattered throughout the gym taken from that year’s Final Four.

headline: Who Needs Assassins When You’ve Got Hackers?
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The Litvinenko killing was old school. Russia is now relying on character assassination online to attack opponents with impunity.
lead_paragraph: Moscow — A BRITISH inquiry announced this week that Alexander V. Litvinenko, a Russian security officer turned defector who died in a London hospital of polonium poisoning in 2006, was “probably” murdered on the instructions of President Vladimir V. Putin. That’s little surprise. For more than eight years the world has suspected that the Kremlin was behind the assassination. (Just as surely, Mr. Putin has denied his responsibility. His spokesman Dmitri Peskov denounced the inquiry as a “quasi investigation” and an expression of the “elegant British sense of humor.”)

headline: Clues Emerge on Robert Levinson, C.I.A. Consultant Who Vanished in Iran
abstract: Newly disclosed documents conflict with Iran’s claim it knew nothing about the consultant Mr. Levinson who disappeared in Iran in 2007.
lead_paragraph: When the United States and Iran swapped prisoners last week, nothing was said to resolve the mystery about another captive: Robert A. Levinson, a Central Intelligence Agency consultant who disappeared in Iran in 2007.

headline: Academy Members Respond to Swift Changes for Board
abstract: Reactions were varied after the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said it was taking steps to double the number of female and minority members by 2020.
lead_paragraph: The reaction to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences saying on Friday that it was taking steps to double the number of female and minority members by 2020 was varied.

headline: France Plans a New Keyboard to Shift Control to Typists
abstract: The Azerty keyboard, whose shortcomings make it hard to type common characters, has never been standardized, and the Culture Ministry has asked for changes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bad spelling? Incorrect grammar? It’s all in the keyboard.

headline: ‘Boxer’ Sells for $785,000 at Christie’s
abstract: William Edmondson’s limestone sculpture “Boxer” brought $785,000 in the Outsider Art sale at Christie’s on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Looks like a knock-out.

headline: The Fading Two-State Solution
abstract: The American ambassador was right to prod Israel about the direction it is heading.
lead_paragraph: Given the brittle relations between the Obama administration and Israel, even truth-telling can ignite a firestorm. That happened this week when Daniel Shapiro, Washington’s ambassador in Tel Aviv, delivered a speech that drew unfair rebukes from Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his right-wing government.

headline: A Waiting List for Justice in New Orleans
abstract: The city’s overburdened public defender system was right to stop taking new cases until the government provides proper funding.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the New Orleans police arrested Deonca Kennedy after her 3-year-old grandson was killed by a bullet fired from a gun under her pillow as the two slept.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ in the Age of Truthers
abstract: The show was best when it left us with doubts, not answers.
lead_paragraph: To watch “The X-Files” in 2016 is a strange thing. The original television show was so much a child of the peaceful ’90s that it’s easy to forget it actually limped along until 2002. Its best seasons aired after the Gulf War and before 9/11, and took place in a version of the United States where the government apparently had so few terrestrial problems to deal with that its highest priority was keeping its citizens in the dark about aliens.

headline: Ted Cruz Condemns Donald Trump for His Use of Eminent Domain
abstract: In a new ad, Senator Cruz attacks Mr. Trump over a decades-old battle to expand his casino in Atlantic City, portraying his wealth as a product of government overreach.
lead_paragraph: Attacked first in a Donald J. Trump ad, Senator Ted Cruz swiftly responded on Friday with a commercial assailing Mr. Trump over his real estate background.

headline: Coming to Terms with Donald
abstract: Trump doesn’t look so bad when the alternative is Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Americans of all races, creeds and political persuasions are united today in the realization that, good grief, Donald Trump actually could become the Republican presidential nominee.

headline: Success Academy Founder Defends Schools Against Charges of Bias
abstract: Eva S. Moskowitz says her network of charter schools has room to improve in how it serves students with disabilities but does not discriminate against them.
lead_paragraph: Eva S. Moskowitz defended her Success Academy charter schools on Friday, two days after a group of parents filed a federal complaint accusing the network of discriminating against students with disabilities.

headline: Mythological Subject for Leonardo, Correggio and Rubens
abstract: Kameron Austin Collins brings the old and the new together in today’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Important PRINT solving Alert! Due to a production error, there is a clue missing at 58 Down in the Sunday, January 24 crossword puzzle in the Magazine. Apologies in advance for the “spoiler,” but that clue should be “Follower of upsilon.”

headline: Spain’s Acting Prime Minister Declines Invitation to Form Government
abstract: Mariano Rajoy’s decision, after an week of talks between King Felipe VI and the leaders of Spain’s main parties, prolongs the country’s political deadlock.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s acting prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, on Friday turned down an invitation by King Felipe VI to try to form a new government, prolonging the country’s political deadlock after inconclusive elections in December.

headline: Lois Weisberg, Chicago’s Cultural Connector, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Weisberg spent decades as a city administrator responsible for organizing public arts projects, earning recognition as a “type of person who seems to know everybody.”
lead_paragraph: Lois Weisberg, a whirlwind of civic enthusiasm whose decades of shepherding public arts projects to fruition deepened the cultural life and reputation of Chicago, died on Jan. 13 at her home in Miami. She was 90.

headline: Clarence Reid, Singer and Songwriter Also Known as Blowfly, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Reid and his Blowfly alter ego had success on two different fronts: soul and pre-rap music.
lead_paragraph: Clarence Reid, a soul singer, songwriter and producer who under the alias Blowfly was a proto-rap innovator and a leading light of American outsider music, thanks to decades of parody songs, sexual and scatological in nature, died on Jan. 17 in hospice care in Lauderdale Lakes, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Death of Man in Brooklyn Fire Is Called a Homicide
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Firefighters found the body of Romulo Heras, 61, inside an apartment in East New York shortly after 9 a.m. on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The death of a man discovered inside a burning apartment in Brooklyn on Friday morning has been ruled a homicide by the police, who said his throat was slashed and his body was covered with stab wounds.

headline: Knicks Lose Their Cool, and a Game Slips Away
abstract: After a foul was called on Robin Lopez and he was ejected from the game, the Knicks withered. The Clippers went on to win, 116-88, at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks watched Clippers center DeAndre Jordan put together a highlight reel for two and a half quarters before tempers finally boiled over.

headline: Flood of Support After Bronx Councilman James Vacca Reveals on Twitter He Is Gay
abstract: The councilman, a Democrat, posted his coming out statement to Twitter on Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: James Vacca, a city councilman from the Bronx, had a message on Friday for his constituents — and the sundry users of the Internet: He is an out and proud gay man.

headline: In Surprise, Mets Agree to a Deal With Cespedes
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes, a 30-year-old Cuban-born outfielder, was a key factor in the Mets’ run to the postseason last season.
lead_paragraph: The Mets had spent the entire off-season leaving the strong impression that they did not expect the right-handed-hitting slugger Yoenis Cespedes to be with the team in 2016.

headline: Review: At Communal Kitchen, a Local Harvest Through All Seasons
abstract: Communal Kitchen’s changing menu makes the most of fresh ingredients sourced from the Hudson River Valley.
lead_paragraph: If you live on the east side of the Tappan Zee Bridge and head west to Nyack — which draws diners with its lively restaurant row — you’re in for a show: The construction of the new bridge, alongside the existing span, features one of the world’s largest floating cranes, lit up like a Zipper ride on a midway. Called the Left Coast Lifter, the crane can hoist the equivalent of 12 Statues of Liberty.

headline: Review: Laurel & Sage in Montclair Takes a Global Approach
abstract: The nearly one-year-old restaurant in Montclair, N.J., is run by a husband-and-wife team that focuses on “globally inspired, locally sourced cuisine.”
lead_paragraph: Talk about tough acts to follow: Laurel & Sage opened last March at the address of the widely lauded restaurant CulinAriane, which closed in 2014 when its owners decamped to Verona.

headline: Review: Da Legna, a Pizza Contender’s Secret Weapon in New Haven
abstract: A maker of Neapolitan-style pies hopes to rise in a tough field with a sourdough starter the chef has been nursing for the past 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Some might say that the very act of opening a pizzeria in New Haven — the pizza capital (to locals, at least) of New England — takes serious audacia. This is, after all, the same town where hallowed institutions like Sally’s Apizza, Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana and Modern Apizza have for decades vied for the most critical raves and fervently devoted fans.

headline: Cespedes Deal Proves Mets May Know a Thing or Two
abstract: The Mets’ front office — shockingly — may have pulled off a coup by signing Yoenis Cespedes to a three-year deal.
lead_paragraph: We have seen the Mets rebuild. It worked. They are the reigning National League champions. They have done some things right.

headline: Two Teenagers Charged in Hate Crime Attack Against Muslim Man in the Bronx
abstract: Two boys, 14 and 15, shouted “Isis! Isis!” during the assault last week on a man wearing a traditional South Asian garment, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Two teenage boys were arrested on Friday and charged with assaulting a Muslim man in the Bronx last week while shouting “Isis! Isis!,” the police said.

headline: Two Mets Reach Deals
abstract: The Mets reached agreements with Lucas Duda and Jenrry Mejia, avoiding arbitration with both of them, a person in baseball said.
lead_paragraph: The Mets reached agreements with Lucas Duda and Jenrry Mejia, avoiding arbitration with both of them, a person in baseball said. Duda, a first baseman who has hit 57 home runs over the past two seasons, could be called upon to provide much of the power in the team’s lineup in 2016. Mejia, a relief pitcher, missed most of the 2015 season because of two suspensions after he tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. The Mets will not have to pay him until his suspension ends midway through the season.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: The “Entourage” gang is back, and the R&B singer Toni Braxton shares her heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Like a thruway pileup, Saturday is ripe for bottlenecking — whether the antics of the “Entourage” guys or the rise and fall of some R&B legends. Meanwhile, the comedians Whitney Cummings and Chelsea Handler assume the warrior position in the battle of the sexes.

headline: Review: Venetian Warmth at Bacaro Italian Tavern
abstract: Located in Massapequa Park, this Italian restaurant opened in November and offers entrees like a panko-crusted pork chop and a lightly blackened salmon.
lead_paragraph: “This is my kind of restaurant: warm and friendly, with good food, large portions and moderate prices,” said one of my dining companions about Bacaro Italian Tavern in Massapequa Park, which opened in November.

headline: Senior Care Facilities With World-Class Art
abstract: ‘The idea was to bring the museum to them,’ says a curator at a nursing and rehabilitation center in the Bronx, where art by Warhol and Chagall adorns the walls.
lead_paragraph: Artworks by Robert Rauschenberg, Ellsworth Kelly, Marc Chagall and Alex Katz adorn the walls. There is a fabric and paper collage by Romare Bearden, and a drawing by Diego Rivera. A corridor is lined with 10 silk-screened portraits by Andy Warhol and a few of William Wegman’s photolithographs of his bedecked Weimaraner dogs.

headline: Review: Passions Ignite in ‘Lives of Reason’ at Two River Theater
abstract: In “Lives of Reason,” a play by Robert Rechnitz and Kenneth Stunkel having its world premiere in Red Bank, several academics compete for a deanship .
lead_paragraph: It is likely that Robert Rechnitz and Kenneth Stunkel enjoyed some chuckles while collaborating on “Lives of Reason,” their play being presented in a world premiere at Two River Theater in Red Bank.

headline: Review: At Hartford Stage, Friendship Forged Through Somalia War
abstract: Dan O’Brien’s play “The Body of an American,” featuring two men talking mostly by email, is an immersion in the nature of isolation and connection.
lead_paragraph: The current Hartford Stage production depicts two men — one of them representing the playwright — talking mostly by email, with some bare-bones dramatization of a few of their stories.

headline: The Art of Maxfield Parrish
abstract: The Nassau County Museum of Art is showing vintage prints and paintings by Parrish, one of 20th-century America’s most popular and successful illustrators.
lead_paragraph: For much of the first half of the 20th century, a quarter of American homes were decorated with art by Maxfield Parrish, said Judy Goffman Cutler and her husband, Laurence S. Cutler. They are the curators of “Maxfield Parrish: Paintings and Prints From the National Museum of American Illustration,” an exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor.

headline: Corrections: January 23, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We are watching all this with alarm. It is clear that the government lacks the necessary resources to give us a normal life.”

headline: Talks to Restructure Puerto Rico Power Company’s Debt Collapse
abstract: Creditors blamed the Puerto Rican utility for the failure late Friday of talks to restructure about $9 billion worth of its debt.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — Negotiations to restructure roughly $9 billion of the debt of Puerto Rico’s power company collapsed late Friday, according to a statement from a group of creditors involved in the talks.

headline: In an Ancient Tomb, a Hierarchy of the Dead
abstract: A Neolithic community buried its members in layers. Those on top died unhappily, it appears.
lead_paragraph: A 6,000-year-old tomb in Northern Spain provides valuable information about an ancient Neolithic community, according to a new study in the journal PLOS One. The tomb holds the remains of 47 individuals, laid to rest in several layers. Individuals in the bottom tomb were closely related, and family members were buried side-by-side, DNA analysis suggests. In layers above, however, the bodies appear to be missing skeletal parts, including skulls. The bones were manipulated, possibly for ritualistic purposes. . The analysis also showed that the community relied on cereals and other plant-based food for sustenance.

headline: The Cult of Marie Kondo
abstract: Marie Kondo, sparking yet more joy as she tours for her new book on “compassionate organizing.”
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, the tidy and the would-be tidy sat very still on the fourth floor of the Barnes & Noble bookstore at Union Square in Manhattan, craning to hear the soft voice of Marie Kondo, the Japanese author of “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up,” as she demonstrated her folding technique on ever more complex garments. She was balletic and masterly. When done, Ms. Kondo received a standing ovation.

headline: Review: ‘Remaking the American Patient’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors']
abstract: Few of the modern complaints about American health care are really new, the historian Nancy Tomes writes in her book.
lead_paragraph: Does any modern American doctor or patient get through a day without thinking wistfully of simpler times? The process of providing or securing even basic health care is so endlessly complicated now, so perilous and frustrating, so entrepreneurial and expensive. Everything was so much easier in the old days. Just beam us back, someone, please.

headline: The New Side Job for Actors and Artists in Los Angeles: Driving
keywords: ['Part-Time Employment', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Art', 'Movies', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Instead of becoming waiters, as cliché would have it, the creative class are hitting the road as Uber and Lyft drivers when work is scarce.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Lauren McKnight, 27, isn’t appearing on television shows for VH1 and ABC, she’s driving a black Scion xA, picking up Hollywood executives on their way to the airport.

headline: Alice Walker and Colm Toibin, and Their Trail of Words
abstract: The authors of “The Color Purple” and “Brooklyn” compare notes on Hollywood, others adapting their work, and how real life has informed their fiction.
lead_paragraph: One of the special pleasures of movies and plays based on great novels is the way they lead us back to their literary roots. Playing the images and emotions from stage or screen against the ones in our head while reading the original creates a doubled experience.

headline: Palestinian Girl With Knife Killed by Israeli Guard, Police Say
abstract: The police in Israel said the 13-year-old girl was shot by a civilian guard outside a West Bank settlement after running at him with a knife.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A 13-year-old Palestinian girl was fatally shot by an Israeli security guard at the entrance to a West Bank settlement on Saturday after she ran at him with a knife, according to the Israeli police.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the campaign trail to the aptly named Jellyfish Lake.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the campaign trail to the aptly named Jellyfish Lake.

headline: Snowstorm Sends Heavy Snow Across East Coast
abstract: More than 25 inches of snow fell on parts of Washington and New York by the end of Saturday.
lead_paragraph: More than 25 inches of snow fell on parts of Washington and New York by the end of Saturday.

lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 designs for Kenzo from Humberto Leon and Carol Lim.

lead_paragraph: Men’s wear designs for next fall from Sacai.

headline: As Frustrations With Mexico’s Government Rise, So Do Lynchings
abstract: The actions are born of a sense of hopelessness and impotence in the country, where 98 percent of murders go unsolved and many crimes are not even reported.
lead_paragraph: AJALPAN, Mexico — The lynching began around 7:20 p.m., not long after the brothers had finished conducting their final interviews on tortilla consumption.

headline: Major Cities Grind to a Halt and Face Days of Digging Out Snow
abstract: In New York, the National Weather Service said 26.8 inches of snow had fallen on Central Park by midnight, making this the city’s second-biggest snowstorm since 1869.
lead_paragraph: Making up for a remarkably mild winter, the first major snowstorm of the season charged up the East Coast on Saturday, a blizzard propelled by tropical-storm-force winds that brought much of the Northeast to a standstill and left more than two feet of snow in New York City, where Mayor Bill de Blasio called it “very likely one of the worst snowstorms in our history.”

headline: ‘A Little Variety': We Welcome Your Comments
abstract: New! Discuss the “A Little Variety” puzzles here.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY — We’re trying something new — a weekly place to gather and discuss the “A Little Variety” puzzles that publish online on Thursdays and appear in the Sunday Magazine. You are welcome to talk about the puzzles in the comments section.

headline: Wonks and Minions
abstract: News flash: progressive can honestly disagree with your candidate’s positions.
lead_paragraph: One of the differences between right and left in America is that the progressive infrastructure includes a contingent of genuine wonks — commentators on policy who really do make models and crunch numbers, and sometimes come up with answers that aren’t fully predictable from their politics. The list includes Ezra Klein, Jonathan Cohn, Jonathan Chait, Mike Konczal, myself some of the time, and others. Right now the wonk brigade has been weighing in on Bernie Sanders, and is in general not too impressed on either financial reform or health care.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Chatter on Messaging Apps
keywords: ['Instant Messaging', 'Text Messaging', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The future of messaging apps may be as a catchall for shopping, booking rides, talking to customer service agents and more.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: An App Helps Teachers Track Student Attendance
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Absenteeism and Truancy']
abstract: Kinvolved, whose users include a Harlem school, lets teachers take attendance and inform parents by text message if a student is absent or late.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Etta Covington, a science teacher at Wadleigh Secondary School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Harlem, has seen her share of students who routinely show up late to class, cut classes or skip school altogether.

headline: Bloomberg, Sensing an Opening, Revisits a Potential White House Run
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, is once again weighing a third-party bid for the presidency, frustrated by what he sees as a race gone haywire, associates said.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg has instructed advisers to draw up plans for a potential independent campaign in this year’s presidential race. His advisers and associates said he was galled by Donald J. Trump’s dominance of the Republican field, and troubled by Hillary Clinton’s stumbles and the rise of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on the Democratic side.

headline: To Own or Lease?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Cooperatives', 'Wills and Estates', 'Laundry and Laundromats', 'Mitchell-Lama Projects']
abstract: This week ‘s subjects include buying vs. renting; getting into Mitchell-Lama housing; and charges for washers and dryer in co-ops.
lead_paragraph: Buying Financial Security

headline: Terrorism Charges in Bangladesh for 14 Men Deported From Singapore
abstract: A group of men deported on suspicion of involvement with militant networks were charged, though Bangladesh said there was no evidence that they were planning an attack.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladeshi authorities have filed terrorism charges against 14 Bangladeshi construction workers deported from Singapore on suspicion of involvement with Islamic militant networks.

abstract: The fall 2016 collection from Dior Homme.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 collection from Dior Homme.

abstract: Mr. Williamson, an arborist at Duke Energy Corporation, identifies trees near transmission lines that need to be either trimmed or removed.
lead_paragraph: Cordy Williamson, 74, is a senior vegetation manager at Duke Energy Corporation in Florence, S.C.

headline: S.E.C. Is Criticized for Lax Enforcement of Climate Risk Disclosure
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Coal']
abstract: Critics say the Securities and Exchange Commission’s oversight of disclosure of the risks of the effects of climate change has waned, costing shareholders millions.
lead_paragraph: As recently as 2011, shares in Peabody Energy, the world’s biggest private sector coal company, traded at the equivalent of $1,000. Today, they hover around $4 each. Over that time, investors who held the stock lost millions.

headline: U.S. Student’s Detention by North Korea Was a Surprise, Tour Group Says
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: There were no signs that an American student, Otto F. Warmbier, who is being held in North Korea, had engaged in “anti-state” behavior, a tour group member said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An American student who is being detained by North Korea did nothing obvious during a five-day trip to the country that would have angered the authorities, a member of his tour group said Saturday.

headline: Bing Xie of Texas Instruments: Simplicity and a Sense of the Familiar
abstract: As a senior vice president of worldwide sales, Bing Xie surrounds himself with reminders of his family, his culture and his mentors.

headline: U.S. Relies Heavily on Saudi Money to Support Syrian Rebels
keywords: ['Series', 'United States International Relations', 'Arms Trade', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A joint arming and training program between the C.I.A. and Saudi Arabia reflects the enduring alliance between the nations even as their relationship and the kingdom’s place in the region are in flux.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama secretly authorized the Central Intelligence Agency to begin arming Syria’s embattled rebels in 2013, the spy agency knew it would have a willing partner to help pay for the covert operation. It was the same partner the C.I.A. has relied on for decades for money and discretion in far-off conflicts: the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

headline: Variety Puzzle: A Thoughtful Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon give us something to think about.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Think carefully before you answer this question: What is the difference between the mind and the brain? You might not believe that there is a difference and, for some, the answer delves into spirituality. But for me, the brain is the THREE-POUND MASS OF JELLY inside our human skulls, and the mind is the consciousness that enables us to both CONTEMPLATE INFINITY and decide what we want to have for lunch. It makes us who we are individually, and it separates us from other species.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: The Enduring Fascination Of Imaginary Teams

headline: Shoveling Snow Through the Decades
abstract: The snow itself has remained the same but the methods for clearing it have evolved over the last century.
lead_paragraph: The snow itself has remained the same but the methods for clearing it have evolved over the last century.

headline: Federer Is Aging Gracefully, but Australian Ken Rosewall Set the Standard
abstract: Rosewall set the standard for enduring tennis excellence, reaching the final at Wimbledon in 1974, when he was 39 years old.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Marvel at Roger Federer, who last year reached the Wimbledon final at age 33 and the United States Open final at age 34.

headline: The Hairy Face of a Most Unlikely Winning Streak
abstract: John Shurna’s beard became the unofficial mascot of Valencia’s 28-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Spain — Five or 10 or 20 years from now, when all those who care about the basketball team here talk about the gloriously unexpected winning streak that began in October, stretched until mid-January and covered 28 games in six countries, they will talk about the upset in Madrid that started it all. Or the late comeback in Germany. Or maybe the overtime game against Bilbao.

headline: How To Make Donald Trump President
abstract: Bloomberg is on it.
lead_paragraph: Step 1: Democrats nominate Bernie Sanders. I don’t think Sanders is unelectable, but when you look at polling, remember that Hillary Clinton’s numbers reflect her standing after more than two decades of constant character assassination, whereas Republicans haven’t even begun to go after him.

headline: Levels, Rates, and Sweden
abstract: More disappointment from economists.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been unhappily surprised by a lot of what has gone on within the economics profession since the 2008 crisis. But one of the most depressing things, in a way, has been the extent to which well-known economists seem confused about the difference between levels and rates of change. Unfortunately, you see this all the time — for example, in the constant assertions that because some country posted a year of pretty good growth after several years of austerity, this proves that austerity doesn’t actually depress the economy.

headline: A Streaky Hitter, a Poor Center Fielder and an Appealing Signing
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes is an above-average left fielder with a powerful right-handed bat who does not take enough walks, strikes out a great deal and goes through extreme slumps.
lead_paragraph: At the height of the mania that surrounded outfielder Yoenis Cespedes after his trade to the Mets last season, some people talked of a $200 million contract in his future and debated whether he should be considered for the National League’s Most Valuable Player Award despite having played in the league for just two months.

headline: Status of Airports, Trains and Other Services in the New York Area
abstract: What is open and closed as the New York region copes with its first big snowstorm of 2016.
lead_paragraph: What is open and closed as the New York region copes with its first big snowstorm of 2016.

headline: Suspect, 19, Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Brooklyn Teenager
abstract: The deadly confrontation started with an exchange of text messages, according to a spokesman for the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Police officials on Saturday announced the arrest of a man wanted for the stabbing death of a teenager in Brooklyn last week that investigators now believe was the culmination of a quarrel over an exchange of text messages.

headline: Boban Marjanovic Is Entering Fans’ Hearts, if Not the Spurs’ Lineup
abstract: Marjanovic, a 7-foot-3 Spurs center from Serbia, has gained a following, even among opponents’ fans, despite little playing time.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The Bobinator is a cartoon figure created by a friend of Boban Marjanovic’s back in Serbia. The Bobinator’s green skin matches the Incredible Hulk’s, but his face and left arm — which is metallic and culminates not in a hand but in a hook that grabs a basketball — is a reference to his primary inspiration.

headline: David Stoliar, Survivor of World War II Disaster, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mr. Stoliar was the only survivor among nearly 800 Jews fleeing Romania’s Holocaust aboard a ship that was barred from Palestine, interned by Turkey, set adrift and torpedoed by a Soviet submarine.
lead_paragraph: (The death of David Stoliar, in 2014, received little attention outside Oregon, where he lived. The New York Times, which had prepared an obituary, learned of his death on Friday.)

headline: With Players in Better Shape, the Sun Is Setting on the Morning Skate in the N.H.L.
abstract: A four-decade N.H.L. tradition is falling out of favor as players and coaches emphasize the benefits of rest and recovery before games.
lead_paragraph: Joe Watson was in his eighth N.H.L. season, his sixth as a defenseman with the Philadelphia Flyers, when Coach Fred Shero, a mystical innovator known as the Fog, transformed the team’s game-day routine.

headline: Balmain: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest designs from Olivier Rousteing’s Balmain.
lead_paragraph: The latest designs from Olivier Rousteing’s Balmain.

headline: Clinton, Trump and Sexism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: It’s a measure of progress that Hillary Clinton is able to run for president as a feminist. But not everyone has evolved.
lead_paragraph: FOR most of her career, Hillary Clinton suffered for being a feminist.

headline: Out of N.F.L. in Early Fall, Now Essential to Carolina Panthers
abstract: Defensive backs Robert McClain and Cortland Finnegan, who joined Carolina late in the season, will be trying to stop the Cardinals’ potent passing attack.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As he waited for a team, any team, to call him, Robert McClain grew to love the jogging trails around Buford, Ga. He ran daily, always on his own, unless you count Melo, his 6-year-old German shepherd.

headline: Danger May Lurk in Denver for New England Patriots
abstract: A record of weak performances at Mile High against the Broncos and a troubled offensive line give New England reason to take pause.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — What could possibly go wrong for the New England Patriots?

headline: One Republican Candidate Wouldn’t Mind Seeing Michael Bloomberg in the Race
abstract: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, who has been appealing to centrist voters in New Hampshire, called Mr. Bloomberg a “good mayor” and said, “If he wants to run, he probably will stimulate the debate.”
lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio offered welcoming words to Michael R. Bloomberg on Saturday, suggesting that an independent run by the former New York City mayor could have a positive effect on the presidential race.

headline: A Canadian Threat to Alaskan Fishing
keywords: ['Salmon', 'Water Pollution', 'Gold', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: Mining projects endanger the state’s salmon rivers.
lead_paragraph: Sitka, Alaska — FROM fall through spring, the fleet of commercial fishing boats here in the panhandle of Alaska stalk winter king salmon. In the mornings prisms of ice sparkle beneath the sodium lights of the docks, where I live on a World War II tugboat with my wife and 8-month-old daughter. This winter I’ve been out a few times fishing on the I Gotta, catching pristine wild salmon, torpedoes of muscle. But the work is slow, five fish a day, and my skipper recently traveled down to Reno, Nev., for knee surgery.

headline: A Colleague Drank My Breast Milk and Other Wall Street Tales
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Accusations of discrimination are hashed out in conference rooms, and silenced with a check.
lead_paragraph: I STILL think about a female job applicant I interviewed more than a decade ago, when I was a managing director at Bear Stearns and she was fresh from the Wharton School of Business.

headline: Stranded in the Snow, Travelers Camp in Cars and Make Do
abstract: The thousands trapped on roadways included students returning from an anti-abortion rally in Washington, a college gymnastics team and a men’s basketball team.
lead_paragraph: Sabrina Swidergal was among hundreds of Catholic high school and college students returning from an anti-abortion rally in Washington who started their weekend stranded on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

headline: Is Warfare in Our Bones?
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'War and Revolution', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY']
abstract: The discovery of skeletons in Kenya that showed signs of a violent death is certain to stir up a debate about human nature.
lead_paragraph: The discovery of what looks like the aftermath of a brutal clash between two groups of prehistoric hunter-gatherers on the shore of an African lake is certain to stir up a debate about human nature that goes all the way back to Adam and Eve.

headline: Home vs. Hospital Births
abstract: Readers discuss the risks and benefits of both settings.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the risks and benefits of both settings and suggest ways to improve care.

headline: The Way to Stop Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: To pry voters from the frontrunner, attack his brand, not his ideas.
lead_paragraph: THIS is, of course, a pointless column. The Republican presidential race is over, as you may have heard. Donald Trump has the nomination wrapped up — in the most luxurious, velveteen packaging you’ve ever seen. You’ve seen his polling lead: It’s yuge. You’ve watched his rallies: They’re even yuger. You’ve heard from the insiders, the panjandrums, the grand poo-bahs: He’s a man they can do business with; Bob Dole guarantees it. You’ve heard from Sarah Palin, and when has her political judgment ever failed?

headline: Facts, Fairness, and the Election­
abstract: As voters prepare to cast their first ballots, a look at how The Times is covering the race.
lead_paragraph: When you’re Donald Trump, bashing The New York Times must always seem like a good idea.

headline: U.N. Can Seal the Peace in Colombia
abstract: International observers could play a crucial role as the country’s largest guerrilla group lays down its arms.
lead_paragraph: The government of Colombia and the country’s largest guerrilla group have made an unusual joint request to the United Nations Security Council. Nearing the final stages of an armistice negotiation, the two sides asked the Council to set up a mission of international experts to oversee a critical part of the proposed agreement: disarming the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist-inspired insurgency.

headline: Sarah Palin Saves Feminism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Veterans', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: She’s helped recast outmoded assumptions, and now a woman can stumble and babble without taking down the whole gender.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IT’S a tough call to figure out which place is more benighted: Hollywood or Saudi Arabia.

headline: Tom Lutz
abstract: The editor of The Los Angeles Review of Books on reading a lot, golden pianos, securing the perimeter and following the unbeaten path.
lead_paragraph: Tom Lutz is editor in chief of The Los Angeles Review of Books.

headline: Fix Flint’s Water System, Now
abstract: Both Michigan and Washington need to step up to the plate.
lead_paragraph: The conditions on the ground in Flint still do not seem to have sunk in at the Michigan statehouse. Thousands of residents are still relying on trucked-in water, as if they were in a war-zone refugee camp, while worrying that their children may suffer developmental and other health problems from a water system poisoned by lead. Gov. Rick Snyder has been busy apologizing, but the tiny steps he is taking to repair the damage shrink beside the urgency of the problem.

headline: Can Shame Be Useful?
abstract: The often-derided emotion can be a tool against addiction.
lead_paragraph: MODERN American culture is down on shame — it is, we are told, a damaging, useless emotion that we should neither feel ourselves nor make others feel. This is particularly the case when it comes to drug and alcohol addiction. The nation’s drug czar, Michael Botticelli, has led a well-intentioned campaign to eradicate feelings of shame in addicted people by, in part, likening addiction to cancer, a disease outside of people’s control.

headline: Our Insane Addiction to Polls
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Voter surveys are contradictory and unreliable, and may well warp election outcomes. But we’re awash in them as never before.
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the poll last week that had Bernie Sanders ahead of Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire by three points?

headline: Did the Man I Sentenced to 18 Years Deserve It?
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: I had the chance to learn if a prisoner’s remorse was strong enough to overcome his past.
lead_paragraph: IN 2006, I sentenced a man to 18 years in prison. I have been wrestling with that decision ever since.

headline: Race, History and Baptist Reconciliation
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: “The Gospel demands that we not only preach but also practice reconciliation."
lead_paragraph: WITH the protests in Ferguson, Mo., the Black Lives Matter movement and the massacre of black churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., on their minds, the presidents of the nation’s two major Baptist groups — one predominantly white, one predominantly black — decided it was time for a bold gesture. The Southern Baptist Convention, founded by slaveholders and their supporters before the Civil War, is now the nation’s second-largest Christian denomination after the Roman Catholic Church. Black Baptists formed their own churches and in 1880 founded what eventually became the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A.

headline: No Split Between Simon and Garfunkel Over Bernie Sanders’s Use of Their Song
abstract: In a CNN interview, Art Garfunkel said that the idea to use “America” in an ad came from the campaign, and that the duo, both liberal-leaning, “acquiesced” to the request.
lead_paragraph: Art Garfunkel is a “Bernie guy.”

headline: Failed Talks Raise Specter of Biggest Default in Puerto Rico Crisis
abstract: Negotiations to restructure about $9 billion of the debt of Puerto Rico’s power company collapsed, raising the prospect of the biggest default yet in the island’s debt crisis.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Negotiations to restructure roughly $9 billion of the debt of Puerto Rico’s power company collapsed late Friday, raising the prospect of the biggest default yet in Puerto Rico’s deepening debt crisis.

headline: Negative Words for Negative Ads From Bush-Aligned ‘Super PAC’
abstract: At a town-hall-style event in New Hampshire, a Jeb Bush supporter complained of being inundated with mailers attacking Mr. Bush’s opponents.
lead_paragraph: BOW, N.H. — Some of Jeb Bush’s major donors have been worried about the negative tone that Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Bush, has taken in criticizing his Republican rivals. They aren’t the only ones concerned.

headline: #Blizzard2016 on Instagram
abstract: From Alabama to New York, people ventured out in the snow and shared it with the world on social media.
lead_paragraph: From Alabama to New York, people ventured out in the snow and shared it with the world on social media.

headline: ‘Hillarycare’ Failed, but Hillary Clinton Reminds Voters She Tried
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: While criticizing Senator Bernie Sanders’ universal health care plan as impractical, Hillary Clinton is reminding voters she tried something similar during her husband’s first term.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of criticizing Bernie Sanders’s plan for a single-payer “Medicare for all” health care system as budget busting and unrealistic, Hillary Clinton over the past few days has a new message for voters: Universal health care was her idea first.

headline: The Y Embarks on Its First National Advertising Campaign
abstract: New commercials aim to show how the former YMCA benefits communities by offering more than a gym and swimming pool, and to raise charitable funds.
lead_paragraph: The Y.M.C.A. — or the Y as it is now known — has existed for more than 160 years and has never felt the need to advertise. After all, even without the help of the ubiquitous song from the Village People, most people know what the Y is.

headline: Duquesne Basketball Team, Stuck on Turnpike, Plays Cards and Makes a Snow Angel
abstract: The bus carrying the men’s basketball team became stranded on the Pennsylvania Turnpike on Friday night and was not freed for more than 22 hours.
lead_paragraph: When the team bus lurched to a halt around 9:15 p.m. Friday, Brian Baudinet, the player development coach of the Duquesne men’s basketball team, assumed that an accident on the Pennsylvania Turnpike had caused the disruption.

headline: For Many Workers, Staying Home Is Not an Option During Blizzard
abstract: For much of New York’s labor force — including police officers, nurses, plow drivers, bartenders and shopkeepers — the blizzard meant anything but a snow day.
lead_paragraph: There were the workers who boarded a Manhattan-bound subway train before sunrise in boots and denim shirts, looking for a place to sit between the men sprawled out and sleeping on the benches who had no other place to spend the night.

headline: Hermés: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from Hermés.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from Hermés.

headline: Health Scare Eclipses Action on Courts; Bottom of Draw Offers Path for Azarenka
abstract: Nigel Sears, Ana Ivanovic’s coach and Andy Murray’s father-in-law, was taken to the hospital after collapsing at the Australian Open, and Victoria Azarenka defeated Naomi Osaka.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Ana Ivanovic was leading her third-round match against Madison Keys, 6-4, 1-0, on Saturday night at the Australian Open when a disturbance in her player’s box caught her eye. Nigel Sears, 58, had collapsed on a staircase inside Rod Laver Arena.

headline: Milos Raonic Wins Match While Grieving for Victims of a Shooting in Canada
keywords: ['Tennis', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Australian Open (Tennis)']
abstract: Raonic, a Canadian, reached the fourth round of the Australian Open and dedicated his victory to the four killed in a Saskatchewan school.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Milos Raonic’s compatriots at Melbourne Park chanted his name and waved Canadian flags and handmade signs decorated with the country’s symbol, the maple leaf. If Raonic won his third-round match against Viktor Troicki, he decided, he would return the nationalistic show of support.

headline: U.S. Prisoner Who Stayed in Iran Was F.B.I. Consultant, Expatriate News Service Says
abstract: The prisoner, Nosratollah Khosravi, was the only American prisoner who did not depart Iran after a deal to swap prisoners was announced a week ago.
lead_paragraph: An American prisoner recently freed by Iran, but about whom little is known, is a former California-based carpet seller and F.B.I. consultant, a news service run by expatriate Iranian journalists reported on Saturday. It said Iranian officials might have believed the man had links to the case of Robert A. Levinson, an American who went missing in Iran nearly nine years ago.

headline: Crackdown by Egypt Draws Attention to an Anniversary It Aimed to Avoid
abstract: Many in Egypt are baffled by the scale of a clampdown aimed at preventing any protest commemorating the Jan. 25, 2011, uprising that toppled former President Hosni Mubarak.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The normally invasive Egyptian authorities had long left Studio Emad Eddin alone, seeing no threat from a performance space that houses rehearsal studios and offers classes in set design and drama.

headline: Afghan Officials, Voicing Security Fears on Facebook, Are Fired for Their Trouble
abstract: Complaints on social media by two deputy governors besieged by Taliban, Qaeda and Islamic State fighters were not viewed kindly by the government of President Ashraf Ghani.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the fate of Helmand Province hung in the balance last month during a withering Taliban offensive, the province’s deputy governor, Mohammad Jan Rasoolyar, found his urgent pleas for help from the central government going unheeded. So he did what millions of other people do every day: He ranted on Facebook.

headline: Initial Turn
abstract: Francis Heaney and Brendan Emmett Quigley turn our Sunday around.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Important PRINT solving Alert! Due to a production error, the print version of the Sunday, Jan. 24 crossword puzzle in the Magazine is missing the clue at 58 Down. That clue should be “Follower of upsilon.”

headline: Iraqi Leader Asks U.S. for Help to Train Police Forces, Officials Say
abstract: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said that even minimal training significantly enhanced their ability to maintain control of Ramadi.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq privately asked Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter this week for additional help training Iraqi police forces used to secure cities that have been retaken from the Islamic State, senior Defense Department officials said.

headline: Donald Trump Would ‘Love’ to See Michael Bloomberg Run
abstract: Donald Trump called Michael Bloomberg, a former mayor of New York, a friend and said he would “love the competition” in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa — Donald J. Trump’s reaction to the potential run of Michael R. Bloomberg in the presidential race was simple: Bring it on.

headline: La Loche, the Canadian Town Where 4 Were Killed, Has a Bleak History
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Native Americans']
abstract: The community has high levels of unemployment and addiction to drugs and alcohol, and there have been waves of suicides, mostly among young residents.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Sudden deaths in La Loche, Saskatchewan, where shootings at two locations left four people dead and seven wounded on Friday, are an all too familiar event. But before Friday, suicide was the main cause of such deaths.

headline: Des Moines Register Endorses Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton
abstract: The Register, the largest newspaper in Iowa, announced Saturday night that it had endorsed Senator Marco Rubio in the Republican race and Hillary Clinton in the Democratic race.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa – The Des Moines Register, the largest newspaper in Iowa, announced Saturday night that it had endorsed Senator Marco Rubio in the Republican race and Hillary Clinton in the Democratic race.

headline: El Salvador Advises Against Pregnancy Until 2018 in Answer to Zika Fears
abstract: The rapid spread of the mosquito-borne virus, which has been linked to a surge in malformed infants, has forced Latin America to take extreme health measures.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — Reacting to the rapid spread of the Zika virus in Latin America and the Caribbean, health officials in El Salvador are urging women not to get pregnant until 2018 in an effort to halt a surge of birth defects that are suspected to stem from the mosquito-borne disease.

headline: In Support of Ted Cruz, Glenn Beck Slams Donald Trump
abstract: Appearing at a mostly full college gymnasium in Iowa, Mr. Beck delivered a forceful case for Mr. Cruz as the only viable option for conservatives.
lead_paragraph: ANKENY, Iowa — Such is the state of the 2016 election that the following, apparently, needs to be said: “I have no intention of shooting anybody in this campaign,” Ted Cruz told reporters here on Saturday, with a now-official attack dog at his side.

headline: In Surprise Showing, Iowa’s Senior Senator Appears at Donald Trump Rally
abstract: Senator Charles Grassley did not endorse Donald J. Trump but his appearance on stage with him could help him in his duel with Senator Ted Cruz for the lead in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa – The 2016 presidential election just keeps surprising.

headline: After a Double About-Face, Yoenis Cespedes Is Back in Queens
abstract: The Mets, after saying they would probably not sign Cespedes, are paying him the highest average annual salary of any free-agent position player this off-season.
lead_paragraph: Late Friday night, David Wright was circling the room at his annual charity fund-raiser, a Vegas Night, in his hometown, entertaining the partygoers and making sure the end of the poker tournament was going smoothly, when his phone started buzzing in his pocket.

headline: At Givenchy, Riccardo Tisci Celebrates the Freedom of Dress
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: For a second season, the designer showed women’s couture looks during the men’s wear presentation. A cobra motif snaked through all the designs.
lead_paragraph: For a second season, the designer showed women’s couture looks during the men’s wear presentation. A cobra motif snaked through all the designs.

headline: When the Water Turned Brown
abstract: As every major decision was made over more than a year, officials at all levels of government acted in ways that contributed to the public health emergency in Flint, Mich.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Standing at a microphone in September holding up a baby bottle, Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha, a local pediatrician, said she was deeply worried about the water. The number of Flint children with elevated levels of lead in their blood had risen alarmingly since the city changed its water supply the previous year, her analysis showed.

headline: The Big Four in Saudi Arabia’s Government
abstract: Brief background information on the most powerful figures in the kingdom, and how they stand in the sometimes complicated order of succession.
lead_paragraph: Brief background information on the most powerful figures in the kingdom, and how they stand in the sometimes complicated order of succession.

headline: Gas Leak in Los Angeles Has Residents Looking Warily Toward Flint
abstract: Thousands of families have fled the Porter Ranch neighborhood, and many say they are not sure they will return.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Health officials have tested the air and deemed it safe. Yes, the awful smell from a huge natural gas leak near the Porter Ranch neighborhood may cause vomiting, nosebleeds and other short-term symptoms, they say, but they have assured residents that it does not pose long-term health risks.

headline: Donald Trump Says Megyn Kelly Should Skip Debate; Fox Says She’ll Be There
abstract: Donald J. Trump continued his criticism of Megyn Kelly of Fox News, who pointedly asked him about his treatment of women at the first Republican debate.
lead_paragraph: Since Megyn Kelly’s pointed question to Donald J. Trump about his treatment of women in the first Republican debate, he has been attacking her regularly, through Tweets and on the campaign trail.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Fans Embrace Tune of ‘America’ in Ad Free of Attacks
abstract: A one-minute spot, featuring a Simon and Garfunkel song, shows Iowa farmers, city dwellers and fans of Mr. Sanders, without saying a word about his platform or his rivals.
lead_paragraph: For a blissful minute, the cacophony of political ads on Iowa television sets vanishes altogether. No speeches, no slurs, only the warm harmonies of Simon and Garfunkel singing “America” can be heard, as down-to-earth Iowa landscapes and scenes of daily life accompany the famous song, in a new ad from Senator Bernie Sanders with the same title.

headline: Bernie Sanders Courts Elusive Voters: Young Iowans
abstract: Mr. Sanders has struck a chord with young people, but his campaign acknowledges that beating Hillary Clinton in Iowa will require overcoming their history of dismal attendance.
lead_paragraph: UNDERWOOD, Iowa — With the Iowa caucuses just over a week away, the Bernie Sanders youth brigade is on the move.

headline: A Day of Endorsements for Presidential Candidates in Iowa
abstract: The Des Moines Register backed Senator Marco Rubio of Florida for the Republicans; and Hillary Clinton for the Democrats. And Senator Charles E. Grassley shared a stage with Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa — After nonstop candidate traffic in Iowa for a full year, the gun was sounded on the final lap before the Feb. 1 caucuses, as the leading candidates in both parties crisscrossed the snowy plains and the state’s largest newspaper announced its endorsements.

headline: In Return to Iowa, Bernie Sanders Picks Up Where He Left Off on Wall Street and Clinton
abstract: Mr. Sanders told supporters that he does better than Hillary Clinton in national polls versus Donald J. Trump, and that it was making Wall Street nervous.
lead_paragraph: MAQUOKETA, Iowa — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont tied himself to Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton to Wall Street as he returned to Iowa on Saturday for a weekend tour through the state.

headline: Knicks Show Little but Midseason Malaise in Loss to Hornets
abstract: A day after the Knicks’ worst defeat of the season, an aching Carmelo Anthony scored only 9 points and sat out the final quarter in Charlotte.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When Carmelo Anthony warmed up before the Knicks played the Charlotte Hornets on Saturday, something, he said, felt off. He couldn’t make the ball do the things he typically can. He couldn’t sink baskets with the ease that he normally does.

headline: Stephanie Schneider, Matthew Schwartz
abstract: A class exercise on the first day of law school turned into a first date.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Paige Schneider and Matthew Joseph Schwartz were married Jan. 22 at the Brooklyn Heights home of the bride’s parents, Harriet R. Weinberger and the late Frederic P. Schneider. A. Gail Prudenti, a former chief administrative judge of New York State, officiated. The couple celebrated their marriage the following day at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in Manhattan, where David Gilman, a retired judge who is now a judicial hearing officer in the Bronx, led the couple in their wedding vows.

Alexander, also of Houston. The Rev. Neil A. Willard, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church.

Greenberg and Gary A. Greenberg of Ambler, Pa. Rabbi Yisrael Pinson officiated at 501 Union, an events space in Brooklyn.

headline: Julia Groeblacher and Daniel Castillo: They’ll Always Have Baghdad

Daniel Lee Castillo, the son of Dahlia S. Castillo and Francisco A. Castillo of South Padre Island, Tex. Gary Shaw, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the District of Columbia to preside, officiated in a Federal-style house in Georgetown that’s part of the L’Enfant Trust.

headline: Bruce Gober, Donald Ratner

lead_paragraph: Hena Nadia Daniels and Andrew Ronald Doba were married Jan. 23 at the Society Room of Hartford, an event space in Hartford. Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, a friend of the groom, officiated.

headline: Maria Sharapova Looks to End 17-Match Losing Streak Against Serena Williams
abstract: The last time Sharapova beat Williams, Barack Obama had just been elected a senator and Lindsay Davenport – now a mother of four — was No. 1.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Sven Groeneveld was camped out in the media seats in Rod Laver Arena on Sunday, shifting his experienced gaze from his smartphone to Serena Williams, who was thumping winner after winner down below.

abstract: The Serbian player has not failed to reach that stage in a Grand Slam event since 2009. Roger Federer also advanced with a straight-set victory.

headline: Looking for Signs That Apple’s Runaway Growth Is Waning
abstract: With iPhone sales projected to decelerate, investors will be scouring Apple’s earnings report on Tuesday for signs of how fast the company’s downshift is happening.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Investors have long relied on Apple to deliver one crucial attribute: growth. Now they are beginning to wonder whether Apple’s days as a growth stock are coming to an end.

headline: After East Coast Blizzard, the Cleanup and the Workweek Begin
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Mid-Atlantic States (US)', 'Transit Systems', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: New York City emerged from the weekend’s blizzard with relatively little damage, but the toll along the East Coast was more sobering: 29 deaths, thousands of homes without power and serious flooding.
lead_paragraph: Bounded by mountains of snow and slush-covered roads and sidewalks, millions of people along the Eastern Seaboard slogged to work on Monday morning, one day after one of the biggest blizzards ever recorded swept through the region, dumping more than two feet of snow in many cities.

headline: Drone Lobbying Heats Up on Capitol Hill
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The efforts in the halls of Congress are part of a multifront intervention by advocates for broader drone use as well as by their opponents, who argue that the machines pose significant safety and privacy risks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time Congress weighed in on rules for nonmilitary drones, in 2012, the flying machines were hardly a hit with consumers. And companies said little about using them for commercial purposes.

headline: 1941: Minister Says British Gains Aided Palestine
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A British minister says the Palestinians can look forward to a bright future if American Jews support Britain in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Declaring that British victories in Egypt and Libya have thrust the danger of attack upon Palestine by the Axis powers ‘‘well into the background,’’ Neville Montagu Butler, newly appointed Minister to the United States from Great Britain, said in a message today [Jan. 24] to Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, that Palestine can look forward to a bright future if American Jews do their utmost in support of Britain and the program of rebuilding the Jewish national home in Palestine.

headline: For Those With ‘Hamilton’ Tickets, a Storm of Disappointment
abstract: They had the toughest ticket in town, but the snow foiled their plans. Some will get refunds, but what they really want is tickets for another show.
lead_paragraph: Don and Naiema Frieson flew up from northwest Arkansas, treasuring the “Hamilton” tickets they had bought for $1,500, eager to experience the musical they had heard so much about. Jessica Pride came in from San Diego, excited to see the show with her husband, who bought a pair of tickets for $1,450 as a Christmas gift. And Tamiko Brooks traveled from Los Angeles, the event an expensive birthday present from her husband.

headline: Marriage, Poverty and the Political Divide
abstract: Married couples are generally more prosperous, so most lawmakers agree on the value of strong families, but not on how to help them avoid poverty.
lead_paragraph: There remains some argument among lawmakers over which Americans should be able to marry, but nearly everyone agrees that marriage itself offers stability and economic benefits to couples and to society at large.

keywords: ['Heroin', 'Police', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Approaching addiction as a disease, the Gloucester Police Department became the unusual law enforcement agency offering heroin users an alternative to prison.

headline: Candidates React to Bloomberg With Dismissals and Differences
abstract: The presidential candidates greeted word of Michael R. Bloomberg’s possible presidential run with attacks on his record, and in some cases, praise for the former mayor.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio dismissed Michael R. Bloomberg as “just a private citizen who owns a big company.” Hillary Clinton said she would “relieve” Mr. Bloomberg of any need to enter the presidential race. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was uncharacteristically charitable, calling Mr. Bloomberg “a good mayor” of New York City.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Senator Charles Grassley Wants ‘to Defeat Me’
abstract: Hillary Clinton on Sunday accused Iowa’s senior Republican senator, Charles E. Grassley, of trying to undermine her presidential candidacy by leaking negative information about her tenure as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – Hillary Clinton on Sunday accused Charles E. Grassley, the senior Republican senator from Iowa, of trying to undermine her presidential campaign by leaking negative information about her tenure as secretary of state. She also criticized him for showing up at an Iowa rally for Donald J. Trump on Saturday “for the simple reason to defeat me.”
