headline: Chris Christie Attacks Marco Rubio Over Blizzard Remark
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey angrily scolded Senator Marco Rubio Sunday for his sarcastic remark about the blizzard that crippled much of the Northeast this weekend, calling it a sign of his “immaturity” and inexperience.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey angrily scolded Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Sunday for his sarcastic remark about the blizzard that crippled much of the Northeast this weekend, calling the comment a sign of his “immaturity” and inexperience.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: “The X-Files,” all night long. Not in the mood? Check out “Amy,” Asif Kapadia’s Oscar-nominated documentary about Amy Winehouse.
lead_paragraph: Mulder and Scully are back, and if their chemistry in the newfangled iteration of “The X-Files” isn’t immediately evident, sit tight, because the mini-series gets better, says the New York Times critic James Poniewozik. The snowbound can brush up by streaming the original shows. Not in the mood? Check out “Amy,” Asif Kapadia’s Oscar-nominated documentary about the troubled chanteuse Amy Winehouse.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs: How the Arizona Cardinals and Carolina Panthers Match Up
abstract: On Sunday, with a trip to Super Bowl 50 at stake, the Cardinals will face the Panthers.
lead_paragraph: 6:40 p.m., Fox. Line: Panthers by 3.

headline: Republicans Risk Repeating Mistake on Hispanic Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voting and Voters', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Demographic trends and the outcome of the 2012 presidential election don’t bode well for a Republican approach highlighting hostility to immigration.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, high-level Republicans declared that after losing the popular vote in five of the past six presidential elections, the party needed to appeal more to Latinos to win the White House. Immigration was a threshold issue.

headline: 1966: Indira Gandhi Becomes Prime Minister
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Indira Gandhi becomes prime minister of India in 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Mrs. Indira Gandhi was sworn in today [Jan. 24] as India’s third prime minister and the first woman to lead the nation’s millions. The 48-year-old daughter of India’s first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, took the brief oath before turbaned President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan in the same room where he administered the same oath 19 months earlier to Lal Bahadur Shastri. Fifteen other cabinet ministers were sworn in at the same time by Mr. Radhakrishnan, including Gulzarilal Nanda, home minister; Y. B. Chavan, defense; Chidambaram Subramaniam, food; and the Untouchables leader, Jagjivan Ram, labor and employment.

headline: Broncos 20, Patriots 18: A.F.C. Championship Highlights
abstract: Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos knocked off Tom Brady and the defending champion New England Patriots in the A.F.C. Championship. Highlights and analysis.

headline: Umit Benan: Fall 2016
abstract: Umit Benan’s fall 2016 men’s wear collection.
lead_paragraph: Umit Benan’s fall 2016 men’s wear collection.

headline: At Sundance, a Focus on Fetishes and Flatulence
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Some attendees, especially distributors, are wondering if the film festival has fallen too deep into the art house rabbit hole.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — It will be hard to beat “Swiss Army Man,” a comedic drama centered on an extremely flatulent, sexually aroused corpse, as the most warped entry at this year’s Sundance Film Festival here.

headline: ‘The Revenant’ Tops the Box Office
abstract: On a stormy weekend in the East, the Oscar nominations leader with a very snow landscape drew audiences.
lead_paragraph: With theaters in major cities like New York, Washington and Philadelphia closed on Saturday because of a severe winter storm, new wide-release films — all with terrible reviews — arrived to modest box-office results.

headline: Manhunt for Three Escaped Inmates in Southern California
abstract: Officials said the men, who are thought to be dangerous, cut through steel bars and rappelled from the roof of the Orange County Central Men’s Jail in Santa Ana.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — A manhunt spanning Southern California was underway Sunday for three inmates described as “very dangerous” who escaped from a maximum-security jail in Orange County, using tools to cut through steel bars and then rappelling from the jail’s roof with makeshift ropes made of linens.

headline: Chris Christie Warns New Hampshire Against Voting for Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Christie warned voters against using their vote as an “expression of anger” against Washington, saying that voting for Donald J. Trump could lead to Hillary Clinton winning the presidency.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey warned primary voters in New Hampshire that their ballots must be more than “an expression of anger,” and that picking Donald J. Trump as their candidate could hand the White House to Hillary Clinton.

headline: Panthers vs. Cardinals: N.F.C. Championship Highlights
abstract: Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers advance to Super Bowl 50 after dominating the Arizona Cardinals, 49-15, in the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Studio in a School Expands Arts Education Nationwide
abstract: The new Studio Institute will bring visual arts programs to schools that serve low-income families.
lead_paragraph: Studio in a School, a New York City nonprofit that enlists professional artists to teach visual arts to public school students, is expanding its mission and scope by creating a Studio Institute to bring its program to the rest of the country.“These are programs that can be replicated,” said Agnes Gund, the organization’s founder and chairwoman. “They have substance, they work for children in schools that don’t have many opportunities. Art is the first thing that’s cut.”

headline: Thom Browne: Fall 2016
abstract: See what Thom Browne dreamt up for fall 2016 men’s.
lead_paragraph: See what Thom Browne dreamt up for fall 2016 men’s.

headline: Europe’s Top Digital-Privacy Watchdog Zeros In on U.S. Tech Giants
abstract: Whether or not negotiators reach a pact by Feb. 1 on how companies like Google and Facebook use Europeans’ online data, Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin is in a position to propel privacy protection efforts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The latest standoff between Europe and American tech companies runs through a quiet street just north of the Louvre Museum, past chic cafes and part of the French national library, to the ornate office of Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin.

headline: As Jack Dorsey Tries to Reshape Twitter, Revolving Door Takes Another Spin
abstract: The social networking company will undergo a major overhaul of its top ranks in the next few weeks, from its eight-member board to key executives in engineering and product.
lead_paragraph: Jack Dorsey began his tenure last year as Twitter’s chief executive with layoffs and a string of new personnel appointments. It turned out those moves were just a prelude.

headline: ISIS Video Appears to Show Paris Assailants Earlier in Syria and Iraq
abstract: The video appears aimed at making it clear that the assailants — nearly all of whom had European passports — had been carrying out atrocities in the group’s name long before their return into Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Islamic State released a video on Sunday apparently showing footage of the men who carried out the November attacks in Paris while they were in Syria and Iraq, where they are pictured carrying out executions, including beheadings.

headline: Italy Divided Over Effort to Legalize Civil Unions for Gays
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Surrogate Motherhood']
abstract: Years after a similar effort failed, lawmakers are confronting an issue that remains a wide divide between Italy and most of the rest of the West.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Six years ago, Andrea Rubera married his partner in Canada, where the couple later became parents of three young children. But when they returned to their native Italy, a transformation occurred. Mr. Rubera suddenly became a single man, and his legally recognized husband in Canada became his single male roommate in Italy. Italian law also divided custody of their children.

headline: Making a Haute Couture Look: Atelier Versace
abstract: A closer look at the construction of one hand-crocheted mini dress, designed to celebrate a strong female figure, and its accompanying jacket.
lead_paragraph: On the above image, we take a closer look at the making of this spring 2016 Atelier Versace haute couture look.

headline: Review: In Pairing of ‘Pagliacci’ and ‘Cavalleria Rusticana,’ One Rises Above the Other
abstract: David McVicar stages Leoncavallo and Mascagni’s operas in the same Sicilian village square, two world wars apart at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Of course the audience at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday clapped at the end of “Vesti la giubba,” a pivotal moment in Leoncavallo’s “Pagliacci.” As the cuckolded and heartbroken clown Canio, the tenor Roberto Alagna had invested the aria with self-destructive despair, pushing his muscular voice close to the breaking point. But when applause broke out, he turned with a start and fixed the crowd with a look of blank horror.

headline: Review: ‘The Velveteen Rabbit’ Is a Tribute to the Less Flashy Toy
abstract: This play, an adaptation of Margery Williams‘s 1922 book, features the bond between a boy and a stuffed toy he receives for Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember the toy you most adored? A blanket? A doll? Some shabby bit of plush and stuffing? Unicorn Theater’s “The Velveteen Rabbit,” a stage adaptation of Margery Williams’s beloved 1922 picture book at the New Victory Theater, pays sweet and occasionally sorrowful tribute to every plaything loved, gnawed and hugged into tatters.

headline: Carson Palmer’s Memorable Season Ends With a Forgettable Night
abstract: Palmer, who was pegged for stardom early on but endured some trying seasons, threw four interceptions in his first conference title game as the Cardinals were routed by the Panthers.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Heading into Sunday’s N.F.C. championship game, Arizona’s Carson Palmer had been the forgotten man of the playoffs.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 25
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump Hears a Lesson in Humility at Church
abstract: Mr. Trump attended a church service in Iowa on Sunday and later told people at a rally that “we talked about humility in church today.”
lead_paragraph: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump is not usually a candidate who invokes the words of evangelical voters. But on Sunday, he went to church in eastern Iowa, where he studied “humility,” he later told attendees at a rally.

headline: Versace: Couture
abstract: Donatella Versace’s vision for couture 2016.
lead_paragraph: Donatella Versace’s vision for couture 2016.

headline: Tech Giants’ Earnings, the Fed Meets and a Deadline on a Data-Sharing Deal
abstract: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will announce their quarterly reports, the Fed will gather for the first time this year, and American and European negotiators have until Sunday to reach an agreement.
lead_paragraph: This week’s quarterly earnings announcements will include results from three of the technology sector’s most important companies: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon. Investors on Tuesday will try to divine from Apple’s numbers just how quickly the company’s growth is decelerating. Their focus will be on iPhone sales. On Thursday, Microsoft and Amazon investors will want to see strong growth in both companies’ computing services businesses. Although Microsoft is an important software maker and Amazon is one the world’s most successful e-commerce businesses, those companies also run two of the largest cloud services companies, selling remote computing services and information storage. —Katie Benner

headline: Match-Fixing Suspicions Raised at Australian Open After Site Stops Bets on Match
abstract: With tennis already under scrutiny over possible match fixing, money poured in on what would normally be an obscure mixed doubles match, leading Pinnacle Sports to suspend betting on it.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A major sports gambling website suspended betting on Sunday for a mixed doubles match at the Australian Open, raising suspicions of match fixing at one of the world’s most prestigious tennis tournaments.

headline: Review: Loudon Wainwright III Offers Tart Folk-Song Sentiments at Appel Room
abstract: A patriarch in a folk-singing dynasty, who is now 69, offered songs of rue, aging and sarcasm, many — but not all of which — he wrote himself across decades.
lead_paragraph: How did it happen? All at once, it seems, the enfant terrible of yesteryear is a grand older man. Or in the language of Loudon Wainwright III, the singer-songwriter who was mislabeled a “new Bob Dylan” four decades ago, he has become the graying “patriarch” of a distinguished folk music clan.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Taiwan’s New President, Tsai Ing-wen
abstract: Voters gave Tsai Ing-wen and her Democratic Progressive Party, which is skeptical of a closer relationship with China, control of Taiwan’s legislature for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Voters gave Tsai Ing-wen and her Democratic Progressive Party, which is skeptical of a closer relationship with China, control of Taiwan’s legislature for the first time.

headline: Winter Wonderland in Manhattan’s Heart
abstract: Snowflakes started falling at Central Park on Friday night, forming a smooth white blanket that by Sunday would wrap the area in the pristine quiet of winter.
lead_paragraph: Snowflakes started falling at Central Park on Friday night, forming a smooth white blanket that by Sunday would wrap the area in the pristine quiet of winter.

headline: Review: ‘The Magicians,’ on Syfy, Draws Students Into a Fantasy That’s Real
abstract: This series is set on a supernatural college campus where the Beast is a threat.
lead_paragraph: Young magicians joining forces against a malevolent, balance-of-life-threatening adversary? Check. A picturesque, hard-to-find campus where young mages learn to harness their skills? Check. Quidditch? No, thank god.

headline: Egyptian Museum Officials Face Tribunal for Damaging King Tutankhamen’s Mask
abstract: Eight Egyptian officials are to face a disciplinary tribunal for their role in a botched repair job that caused lasting damage to the famed burial mask.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Eight Egyptian museum officials are to face a disciplinary tribunal for their role in a botched repair job that caused lasting damage to the famed golden burial mask of King Tutankhamen, one of the country’s most prized artifacts, the country’s administrative prosecutor has said.

headline: For the Love of Broadway
abstract: Despite a massive storm, the show went on at the first BroadwayCon, a theater-themed fan convention in New York.
lead_paragraph: Despite a massive storm, the show went on at the first BroadwayCon, a theater-themed fan convention in New York.

headline: BroadwayCon Carried On, Even as Broadway Went Dark
keywords: ['Theater', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: The theater-themed fan convention drew nearly 6,000 people for the three-day event at the New York Hilton Midtown, despite a massive snowstorm that shut down Broadway.
lead_paragraph: There were pops of “Wicked” green and “Sweeney Todd” red among the whiteout conditions in Manhattan over the weekend at the first BroadwayCon, a theater-themed fan convention that hopes to do for Broadway devotion what Comic-Con International, in San Diego, has done for superhero worship. Nearly 6,000 people from around the world, most of them young women, turned out for the three-day event at the New York Hilton Midtown, according to event organizers.

headline: Knoedler Gallery Heads to Trial in Sale of a Fake Rothko
abstract: The gallery and its director are accused in a $25 million lawsuit of knowingly selling a fake painting that was one of many fraudulently commissioned by a Long Island dealer.
lead_paragraph: No scandal in recent years has hung over the art market as heavily as the Knoedler & Company forgery case.

headline: Despite Decades of Stealth, Sticking Points Bedevil F-35 Jet
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'F-35 Airplane']
abstract: As the price keeps rising for the Joint Strike Fighter, the world’s costliest weapon, the program has raised questions of whether it will ever be ready, or effective.
lead_paragraph: One of the earliest stealth weapons on record was a stone used by the young Israelite David to kill the Philistine giant Goliath. In the biblical account, David shunned the conventional armaments of his time: sword, helmet, armor. Instead, he went forth with a slingshot and a few stones, kept undetected in a pouch. As any schoolchild knows, one well-aimed fling was all it took to put Goliath down for good. The big guy never saw it coming.

headline: Review: In ‘Cure,’ Accepting the Mind’s Role in a Body’s Health
abstract: Jo Marchant, who holds a Ph.D. in genetics and microbiology, crisscrossed the globe to study the latest in mind-body research.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost 40 years since Jeff Goldblum appeared in “Annie Hall” as an unnamed party guest who couldn’t remember his mantra. Mr. Goldblum has done very well since then; mantras, alas, have had a rougher go of it. But perhaps it’s time to ask: Must the mantra be forever impugned?

headline: Betting That Rock Is Back (Again)
abstract: The “Now That’s What I Call Music!” series has released its first modern rock album, a counterintuitive choice that may nonetheless mesh with the audience for the series.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, “Now That’s What I Call Music!” has churned out what passive pop consumers want to hear — compilations of hit songs of the moment. In the United States, there have been 56 volumes, plus spinoff Latino versions, Christmas collections and more than a dozen country albums.

headline: Review: On ‘Lucifer,’ a Fox Drama, the Devil Tries to Fit In
abstract: This new series, starring Tom Ellis, features the fallen angel as a nightclub owner in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Even Satanists will be reaching for the remote when …

headline: Puppy Amuser
abstract: Ian Livengood would like us to meet his relatively new arrival.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Guess who got a puppy! No, not me. Ian Livengood, today’s constructor, got a puppy, her name is Josie and she’s adorable. I’m sure that, in no time at all, Josie will have Mr. Livengood and his wife properly trained to obey each and every one of her commands. Let’s congratulate him.

headline: Review: City Ballet Celebrates Balanchine and Heeds Mother Nature
abstract: The storm caused the company to cancel Saturday’s performance, an unfortunate interruption of momentum built in the first week of its winter season.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet had planned to celebrate the birthday of George Balanchine as usual, with performances and demonstrations of his works. Instead, Mother Nature showed up on Saturday with the kind of enchanting yet hazardous gift common to fairy tale ballets: a waltz of the snowflakes voluminous enough to cause transit shutdowns that forced the troupe to cancel performances for the first time this century. Climatically, this may have been a climax, but for the company, it was an unfortunate interruption of the momentum built in the first week of its winter season.

headline: Pentagon Wants Psychologists to End Ban on Interrogation Role
keywords: ['Interrogations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: The American Psychological Association has been asked to revisit its “blanket prohibition” on the involvement of psychologists in national security interrogations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has asked the American Psychological Association to reconsider its ban on the involvement of psychologists in national security interrogations at the Guantánamo Bay prison and other facilities.

headline: Public Divide on Police Hangs Over Brooklyn Officer’s Manslaughter Trial
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Statements during jury selection for the trial of Officer Peter Liang, who shot an unarmed man in a housing project, point to the public debate after several high-profile killings by the police.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the final day of jury selection in the trial of Peter Liang, the New York police officer charged with manslaughter in the shooting of an unarmed man in the stairwell of a Brooklyn housing project, a prosecutor asked jurors if they thought the charges were “heavy-handed.”

headline: Tyco International and Johnson Controls Are Said to Be Merging
abstract: The deal, which might be announced as soon as Monday, could be for as much as $20 billion, a person briefed on the discussions said.
lead_paragraph: Tyco International, the remnant of the industrial conglomerate that was marred with corporate scandal and later broken up, is in late-stage discussions to merge with Johnson Controls for as much as $20 billion, a person briefed on the discussions said on Sunday.

headline: Broncos’ Defense Bruises Tom Brady, Lifting Peyton Manning to Super Bowl
abstract: Denver advanced to its second Super Bowl in three seasons, sacking Brady four times and holding off New England in the A.F.C. championship game.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — His Broncos teammates came bounding through the tunnel, dispensing hugs and high-fives, and then here came Peyton Manning, shadowed by boom mikes and television cameras and mayhem.

headline: A Beloved Bronx Teacher Retires After a Conflict With His Principal
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: Tom Porton, who has taught at a Bronx high school for 45 years, says he does not like where modern education is headed.
lead_paragraph: Tom Porton is used to drama: Since arriving at James Monroe High School as an English teacher 45 years ago, he has taught and staged plays. Outside, in the Bronx River neighborhood where the school is, there was plenty of drama in the 1980s, when AIDS and crack ravaged the area. His response then was to establish a group of peer educators who worked with Montefiore Medical Center to teach teenagers about H.I.V. prevention. His efforts earned him awards, including recognition from the City Council and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and led to his induction into the National Teachers Hall of Fame.

headline: Fishing for Donations, With a Coat Hanger in Hand
abstract: Robert Krah, who is to be released from prison this week, was caught rooting around in the poor boxes of a church and a synagogue in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Ioannis Amanatidis — known to his customers as Johnny the Greek — would drive to his busy corner of Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, in the morning with his food cart in tow. Lunch was still hours away, but every day for six or seven years, he said, an older man would be waiting when he arrived.

headline: Precipitous Rents in Ski Country Push Workers to Edges
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Skiing']
abstract: Soaring home prices have created a housing crisis in ski country, one that has people piling into apartments, living out of trailers and sleeping in shifts.
lead_paragraph: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo. — On nights when she could not crash on a friend’s couch or unroll a sleeping mat on an attic floor, Chelsea Lilly tucked her silver Subaru into a supermarket parking lot or a dark spot along a mountain pass, wrapped herself in a green Army blanket and watched movies on her phone until she fell asleep.

headline: China Considers Larger Role in Afghanistan Peace Process
abstract: One reason for China’s engagement is that a stable Afghanistan could become a critical transportation hub and market for Chinese goods.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As a  bloody offensive by the Taliban spreads in Afghanistan and with American combat operations there officially ended, anxious Chinese leaders find themselves under pressure to take a more active role in the long-stalled peace process, according to scholars and current and former diplomats.

headline: Aboriginal Brass Band Offers Burst of Hope in a Bleak Community
abstract: In its own modest way, a band created during a time of Aboriginal oppression is helping to heal deep racial wounds in Australia.
lead_paragraph: YARRABAH, Australia — This remote stretch of coastline in north Queensland has much to offer: pristine beaches dotted with mango and palm trees, tropical breezes, an azure ocean.

headline: China Deepens Its Footprint in Iran After Lifting of Sanctions
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations']
abstract: The countries’ strategic pact gives China a western gateway to Middle East markets, and has saved Iran from international isolation and economic ruin.
lead_paragraph: ZARRINABAD, Iran — Rising from the yellowish, treeless plains so typical for central Iran stands a square labyrinth of pipes and conveyor belts, topped by a silver chimney that glitters in the summer sun.

headline: Fighting to Preserve the White Barn Theater
abstract: In Norwalk, Conn., a historic property is at the center of a dispute between a developer and preservationists led by the grandnephew of Lucille Lortel, the actress who founded the theater.
lead_paragraph: NORWALK, CONN. — Lucille Lortel, an actress and theater producer who was known as the queen of Off Broadway, staged hundreds of plays during her lifetime at her theater on Christopher Street in the West Village.

headline: In Portugal, Voters Pick Center-Right President
abstract: The new president, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, won 52 percent of the votes, with 98 percent counted.
lead_paragraph: Portugal’s voters elected a veteran center-right politician and television commentator as their new president on Sunday, two months after a Socialist administration took office following inconclusive parliamentary elections.

headline: A Struggle to Quell Investor Fears Over Unsettled Emerging Markets
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Foreign Investments', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Traders and portfolio managers worry that sophisticated institutional investors, who generally tend to take a longer-term view, have been the ones driving the selling over the last six months.
lead_paragraph: Currency turmoil in China and fears of a global slowdown have led investors to abandon emerging markets in droves, rattling the large asset management firms that have long promoted such investments in their hunt for higher returns.

headline: Southern Jersey Shore Hit With Severe Flooding by Snowstorm’s High Tides
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Floods', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: The southern end of the Jersey Shore, which was largely spared by Hurricane Sandy, suffered the most severe flooding in the state during the weekend blizzard.
lead_paragraph: The southern end of the Jersey Shore, which was largely spared by Hurricane Sandy three years ago, had the most severe flooding in the state during the weekend blizzard, as high tides sent icy water rushing into darkened homes and businesses.

headline: Second-Year Super Bowl Advertisers Face Their Own Pressures to Succeed
abstract: Avocados From Mexico and at least two other advertisers, Skittles and Wix.com, have decided to return to the Super Bowl, indicating that live television remains important for advertisers.
lead_paragraph: To say Alvaro Luque, the president of Avocados From Mexico, was nervous during last year’s Super Bowl would be an understatement. His company had decided to advertise during the game for the first time, and millions of dollars were at stake.

headline: Employee Wellness Programs Use Carrots and, Increasingly, Sticks
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Workplace Environment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Discrimination', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Workers at many companies now face stiff financial penalties for refusing to undergo health screenings.
lead_paragraph: It may be an offer employees simply can no longer refuse.

headline: Protesters in Haiti Demand That President Quit
abstract: One day earlier, officials had bowed to widespread civil unrest and postponed a single-candidate presidential runoff election that was to be held on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Volcy Assad, a Haitian political activist, stood before an enormous plume of black smoke emanating from a pile of burning tires and made it clear that the demands of protesters had changed.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Battle for Party’s Future
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Income Inequality', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: With many Democrats torn between pragmatism and liberalism, the question of whether the party’s left wing can become a true force again in presidential politics will soon have its first test, in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The race between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders, which voters will begin deciding a week from Monday, is not just about the White House anymore. It has intensified into an epochal battle over their vastly different visions for the Democratic Party.

headline: Mother and Son, 1, Die of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning in Car During Snowstorm
abstract: The woman and her baby were in the car, whose tailpipe was blocked by snow, as her husband worked to shovel it out in Passaic, N.J. Her daughter, 3, was also in the car and was in critical condition.
lead_paragraph: A woman and her 1-year-old son died of carbon monoxide poisoning in Passaic, N.J., on Saturday after sitting in their parked car with the engine running, the police said.

headline: French Jews Fear a New Strain of ISIS-Inspired Anti-Semitism
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The third attack on a Jew in Marseille since October — this time by a radicalized teenager who tried to decapitate a teacher — has evoked old fears in France.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — It was the heavy leather-bound volume of the Torah he was carrying that shielded Benjamin Amsellem from the machete blows.

headline: Broncos’ Defense Keeps Patriots Off Rhythm
abstract: All game, the Broncos showed Tom Brady and the Patriots why they led the league in fewest total yards allowed and fewest passing yards allowed.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady was already having a day to forget by the time Denver Broncos safety Darian Stewart intercepted a pass late in the first half of the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Peyton Manning Is Primped and Primed for, Perhaps, a Final Showdown
abstract: On Sunday, old Peyton Manning was the Peyton Manning of old. His joints didn’t creak and his passes weren’t all weak. He led the Broncos over the Patriots in a game to remember.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — After the Denver Broncos won the A.F.C. championship game on Sunday to make it to the Super Bowl, Peyton Manning primped.

headline: Donald Trump Means Business in Iowa: Night in Motel, and a Day in Church
abstract: Donald Trump, who has said he really wants to win Iowa, is laser-focused on it as the caucuses draw near, even sleeping in a Holiday Inn Express and showing up for church services.
lead_paragraph: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump spent the last seven months saying he wanted to win. Now he is really acting like it.

headline: Bob Bradley Climbs the Global Soccer Ladder With an Impediment: He’s American
abstract: Bradley, a former coach of the U.S. national soccer team, is teaching a new group of players on France’s north coast in the hopes that it will lead him to one of the top European leagues.
lead_paragraph: LE HAVRE, France — In the conference room of a smart hotel in the center of this port city, four Frenchmen were talking loudly over one another and gesticulating toward a flip chart in front of a row of empty chairs.

headline: A Resurgent Marco Rubio Sprints to the Finish in Iowa
abstract: A string of key endorsements, including from the state’s largest newspaper, has the Florida senator’s campaign optimistic for a strong third-place finish.
lead_paragraph: MARION, Iowa — For months, it was the biggest question nagging at the Rubio campaign here: “Where’s Marco?”

headline: Bobby Wanzer, 94, Hall of Fame Player From N.B.A.’s Early, Patient Days, Dies
abstract: Mr. Wanzer, a guard, led the Rochester Royals to the 1951 N.B.A. championship, the only league title of that much-traveled team, whose modern-day successor are the Sacramento Kings.
lead_paragraph: Before the arrival of the 24-second shot clock in 1954 turned pro basketball into a fast-paced game, many a victory came from clever passing and ball-handling in the backcourt that set up good shots.

headline: Jeb Bush on the Stump Sounds Different From the TV Version

lead_paragraph: BERLIN, N.H. — Expectations are not always high at Jeb Bush’s campaign events, where impressions of his halting performances in debates and other TV appearances often precede him.

headline: Donald Trump Did Stay at a Holiday Inn Express on Friday Night
abstract: “It was good, it was clean,” said Mr. Trump of his stay at a hotel in Iowa, where he is making a heavy push for votes in the Feb. 1 caucuses.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t a Trump-branded hotel, but Donald J. Trump found the Holiday Inn Express in Sioux Center, Iowa, to be a perfectly suitable stand-in for Trump Tower or Mar-a-Lago.

headline: Shutting Down Aboveground Subway Service in New York, and Learning From Previous Missteps
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority cut off service to 196 aboveground subway stations, about 40 percent of the entire system, a first-time experiment in the agency’s history of contending with extreme winter weather.
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, riding the subway is an underground experience, calling to mind dark tunnels and fluorescent-lit stations. But the blizzard over the weekend was a reminder of just how much of the system runs aboveground.

headline: Boston Globe Endorses Hillary Clinton
abstract: The newspaper calls Mrs. Clinton “someone who can keep what Obama got right, while also fixing his failures, especially on gun control and immigration reform.”

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Clash on Issues and Vie for Votes of Iowa Women
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', "Women's Rights", 'Keystone Pipeline System']
abstract: As hundreds of volunteers fanned out across the state to knock on doors, the Democratic candidates campaigned in vote-rich counties in eastern Iowa.
lead_paragraph: NORTH LIBERTY, Iowa — From universal health care and paid family leave to college costs and the Keystone XL oil pipeline, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders challenged each other’s priorities and courted female voters on Sunday as they began the final week of their increasingly hard-fought campaign to win the Iowa caucuses next Monday.

headline: Panthers, Led by Flashy Cam Newton, Swamp Flailing Cardinals

The U2 song “Sunday Bloody Sunday” rang through the loudspeakers, and towels waved, and it continued to feel, justifiably, as if the Carolina Panthers were on the verge of another score.

headline: Over 200 Educators in New York Receive Erroneous Scores Linked to Student Performance
abstract: The error could be another blow to the practice of linking teacher performance to student exams, a system that has come under fire in recent years.

headline: Return to Normalcy Will Be Halting as Mid-Atlantic Starts Digging Out
abstract: Officials said a recovery would take days as travel remained treacherous and some spots recorded up to 40 inches of snow.
lead_paragraph: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — In Washington, there was a massive snowball fight in Dupont Circle, and on Capitol Hill, families went sledding. But in suburban Rosslyn, Va., Lila Hertz, 22, fell down in the snow Sunday as she struggled to find transportation to her job at a popular lunch spot two blocks from the White House. She was rescued by a passing cab — and was the only person who showed up for work.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10 Premiere: A Crazier Mulder Than Usual
abstract: The classic sci-fi series returns with a muddled and revisionist first episode.
lead_paragraph: When I heard that “The X-Files” was coming back to TV, it was like hearing that I would see some dear old friends again. I spent every Friday night of my young adulthood with Agents Fox Mulder and Dana Scully. News of their coming six-week mini-series started me on a mega rewatch — I mainlined the original episodes in five-hour chunks.

headline: The Cigarette Smoking Man of ‘The X-Files’ Resurfaces
abstract: The sci-fi supervillain, played by William B. Davis, was last seen in the 2002 series finale of “The X-Files.” Now, with Fox’s new mini-series, a conversation with the actor.
lead_paragraph: When we last saw the Cigarette Smoking Man, in “The X-Files” series finale in 2002, he was living as a guru in an old Anasazi settlement in New Mexico. Or at least he was, until a couple of black helicopters blew it and him to smithereens, seemingly ending his run as the story’s nefarious conspirator and prime concealer of whatever truths may, in fact, be out there.

headline: Updates on Schools, Subways and Commuter Rails After the Storm

On Monday morning, however, New York schools are open and subway and commuter rails are mostly up and running. Here is what else to expect on Monday:

headline: Alone, in a Crowd, With Gregory Crewdson
abstract: Gregory Crewdson’s photographs almost always project solitude and intimacy, even if his images take a team to organize. The subject of one of his images looks back at the experience.
lead_paragraph: One push through a revolving door and I was in complete darkness. I walked to the right to get a sheet of resin-coated paper and then turned toward the enlarger, where I could finally rest my mind. The most sacred moments were when I could just stand there and dissolve into the test prints. There were no New York hospitals, no expectations of my father’s recovery or death. Not even the constant companion of intensive care beeping sounds, those Montefiore monitors I couldn’t get out of my head.

abstract: Ideology and the neglect of public health.
lead_paragraph: In the 1850s, London, the world’s largest city, still didn’t have a sewer system. Waste simply flowed into the Thames, which was as disgusting as you might imagine. But conservatives, including the magazine The Economist and the prime minister, opposed any effort to remedy the situation. After all, such an effort would involve increased government spending and, they insisted, infringe on personal liberty and local control.

headline: Ending the Horror of Myanmar’s Abuse of Muslims
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Editorials']
abstract: Once in power, the new government must free the Rohingya Muslim minority and end years of abuse.
lead_paragraph: The government of Myanmar’s departing president, Thein Sein, oversaw the systematic persecution of the country’s Rohingya Muslim minority — a human rights debacle that one study has described as genocide. Mr. Thein Sein also signed four bills into law last year regulating interfaith marriage, birth spacing and religious conversion that clearly targeted Myanmar’s Muslim minority.

headline: Drug Deaths Reach White America
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Heroin', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lawmakers are starting to acknowledge that addiction is a problem that knows no racial barriers.
lead_paragraph: Congress has historically treated drug abuse as a malady afflicting mostly poor, minority communities, best dealt with by locking people up for long periods of time. The epidemic of drug overdose deaths currently ravaging white populations in cities and towns across the country has altered this line of thinking, and forced lawmakers to acknowledge that addiction is a problem that knows no racial barriers and can be best addressed with treatment.

They share another distinction: Since their trials, they have both applied for their state pensions. Sadly, they have every right to do so.

lead_paragraph: Back in the 1960s there was a briefly popular wave of “futurism,” of books and articles attempting to predict the changes ahead. One of the best-known, and certainly the most detailed, of these works was Herman Kahn and Anthony J. Wiener’s “The Year 2000” (1967), which offered, among other things, a systematic list of technological innovations Kahn and Wiener considered “very likely in the last third of the 20th century.”

headline: 1891: Another Indian Outbreak
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New trouble on the Red Lake reservation in 1891.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — An Indian outbreak is reported to have occurred yesterday afternoon [Jan. 24] on the Red Lake reservation, near St. Pane. 1,200 Chippewas broke out with war and ghost dances and are robbing and plundering the whole country. The settlers are fleeing, and the Governor has ordered out the militia.

headline: 1941: Rome Concedes Loss of Tobruk
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Rome admits heavy loss at Tobruk in 1941.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Loss of 20,000 men at Tobruk and complete occupation by the British of that fortified zone was finally admitted today [Jan. 25] by the Italian high command. To give the people of this country some cheerier word, however, the military communique asserted that an Italian submarine had sunk the British armed merchantman Eumaeus, said to have been loaded with troops at the time, and that German airmen had dropped a large caliber bomb on an enemy heavy cruiser in the central Mediterranean. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 26, 1941

Now known as Mississippi Roast, it would eventually become one of the most popular recipes on the web, an unlikely star with unlikely ingredients, a favorite of the mom-blog set.

keywords: ['Couture (Fashion)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Guests had been told to bring identification for entry to the shows, but for the most part, it hasn’t been needed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The City of Light was plunged into darkness on a mild night last November, when 130 people were killed in terrorist attacks across Paris. Two months later, France is still in a state of emergency, with security barriers and increased patrols of police officers and soldiers carrying automatic weapons a common sight, even though residents say the fear that hung over the city before Christmas is less palpable now.

headline: Another High-Profile Endorsement, as Rick Perry Backs Ted Cruz

headline: Monkeys Built to Mimic Autism-Like Behaviors May Help Humans
abstract: Scientists in Shanghai are trying to locate the deficiency in the ‘brain circuits’ responsible for autism-like behavior found in genetically engineered monkeys.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have genetically engineered monkeys so that they exhibit behaviors similar to autism, with a goal of testing potential therapies on the animals in hopes that their resemblance to humans will yield more answers about the disorder.

headline: During Market Turmoil, Just Listen to Your Financial Plan
abstract: There are many reasons having a financial plan is valuable, but maybe the most significant is that it can help you understand how to react to volatile markets.
lead_paragraph: Every year, right around this time, all the big brokerage firms, economists and banks come out with projections of what’s supposed to happen next in the financial world. This year is no exception. Especially prominent in the news has been the Royal Bank of Scotland warning, in no uncertain terms, that people should “sell everything” and prepare for a “fairly cataclysmic year ahead.”

But in Paris, as of Sunday, fashion was still championing the preindustrial art of couture: garments made entirely by the human hand, to order, for one client at a time.

headline: Round Robin

(Dr. Moriconi also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Ciência Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or “What’s the Problem?”)

headline: Vincent Price’s Cookbook Lives On
abstract: Also, peppery watercress; a halvah makeover in Chelsea Market; treats from a chocolate lab; da Vinci’s diet; and online lessons from Wolfgang Puck.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, Vincent Price, the actor and connoisseur of art and food, wrote a cookbook with his wife, Mary, featuring recipes from restaurants in destinations including New York, California, France, Italy and England. The book became a collector’s item; now a 50th-anniversary edition has been published with the help of the Prices’ daughter, Victoria, who has written the preface. The Proust in all of us will relish the profiles of ghosts like Le Pavillon and the Forum of the Twelve Caesars in New York, the original La Pyramide in France and Bali in Amsterdam. Reproductions of menus, with prices like $3.25 for Lüchow’s Wiener schnitzel and $5.95 for roast duck at the Four Seasons (soon to be another fond memory) will give you pause. There are well-detailed, pre-food-processor recipes, including an unapologetic quiche Lorraine calling for eight egg yolks: “A Treasury of Great Recipes: 50th Anniversary Edition” (Dover, $50).

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Efforts on Managing Electricity Use Through Pricing
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The justice ruled that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission could encourage electricity users to adopt “demand response” programs.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that federal regulators may encourage electricity users like schools, hospitals and shopping centers to reduce consumption at peak times in exchange for price breaks. The regulatory approach, known as “demand response,” lowers costs for consumers and lessens the risk of system failures that can cause blackouts.

headline: An Artist’s Monograph That Tests the Limits of Language
abstract: A new book by the filmmaker and performer Wu Tsang explores — and challenges — the ways in which people communicate.
lead_paragraph: “Language,” notes the filmmaker and artist Wu Tsang, “is always present in my work.” And as her first monograph, “Not in My Language” (Walther König, $50), makes clear, how we say things extends beyond simply the words we use. Intended as a companion to Tsang’s 2015 group exhibitions at the Kunsthalle Düsseldorf and the Migros Museum in Zurich, the publication surveys the artist’s prodigious output and highlights themes recurrent throughout her work. Combining stills and reproduced screenplays from six of her films — including “DAMELO TODO,” 2010, centering on the story of an El Salvadorian teenage refugee who finds sanctuary in L.A.’s transgender community, and her documentary “Wildness,” 2012, which profiles the habitués of Silver Lake’s legendary trans bar the Silver Platter and was included in the 2014 Whitney Biennial — “Not in My Language” foregrounds Tsang’s interest in communities and subcultures often relegated to the margins of society.

headline: Guardian to Slash Costs and Renew Online Focus
abstract: The newspaper’s parent outlined a three-year plan to increase revenue from readers and improve advertising offerings, among other steps.

headline: Michigan Attorney General Picks Investigator for Flint Water Case
abstract: A former county prosecutor, Todd Flood, will assess whether state laws were broken when Flint switched the source of its drinking water.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The attorney general of Michigan said Monday that a former county prosecutor would lead his office’s investigation into the water crisis in Flint, where a 2014 switch of the city’s drinking water source led to contamination and widespread health concerns.

headline: Emotional Accounts of Financial Struggle at a Bernie Sanders Event
abstract: Bernie Sanders asked people at a campaign event in Iowa to describe relying on Social Security checks, paying for increasingly expensive medicine, and what it’s like to live on minimum-wage work.
lead_paragraph: IOWA FALLS, Iowa — Carrie Aldrich, 46, wept Monday as she told Senator Bernie Sanders and 200 other people about her struggles cycling though minimum-wage jobs, fighting to get disability checks for a joint disorder, and having to rely on her elderly parents for survival.

headline: Missouri Professor Who Called for ‘Some Muscle’ at Protest Is Charged
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Assaults', 'News and News Media', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Melissa A. Click, an assistant professor who tried to remove journalists from a campus protest last year, was charged with misdemeanor assault on Monday.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — A University of Missouri assistant professor who called for “some muscle” as she tried to remove journalists from a campus protest last year was charged on Monday with misdemeanor assault, court documents showed.

headline: Arguments Over North Carolina Voter ID Law Begin in Federal Court
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Identification Devices', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The law in North Carolina requires voters to produce one of six types of identification, but opponents, including the Justice Department, say it suppresses votes.
lead_paragraph: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. — The bitter dispute about North Carolina’s elections laws returned to a federal courtroom here on Monday as the state’s voter identification requirement went on trial.

headline: The Bugs Sharing Your Home (Get Out a Calculator)
abstract: An unsual survey identifies many of the bugs living with us in our houses.
lead_paragraph: Humans share their homes with hundreds of species of flies, spiders, beetles, lice and other arthropods, a new study reports.

abstract: In experiments with zoo animals, relative brain size was the best clue to problem solving ability in carnivores.
lead_paragraph: In experiments with zoo animals, relative brain size was the best clue to problem solving ability in carnivores.

headline: Some Carnivores Are Better Than Others at Unlocking Dinner
abstract: Researchers tested 39 species of carnivores in zoos to see which were best at opening a puzzle box containing a treat.
lead_paragraph: Spotted hyenas are the animals that got Sarah Benson-Amram thinking about how smart carnivores are and in what ways.

headline: New York Officer Charged in Akai Gurley’s Fatal Shooting Goes on Trial
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The prosecution and the defense presented opening statements in the trial of Peter Liang, who in 2014 shot his gun down an unlit stairwell in a housing project, killing Mr. Gurley, who was unarmed.
lead_paragraph: At about 11 o’clock on the night of Nov. 20, 2014, Melissa Lopez was in her kitchen in the Louis H. Pink Houses in East New York. Her partner was getting ready for his workday, which started at midnight, and her two girls were in their rooms.

headline: Review: ‘Outsiders,’ the Latest Iteration of the American Family as Criminal Enterprise
abstract: The moonshine-making Farrell family of Kentucky fights to keep its land in this 13-episode series on WGN America.
lead_paragraph: To the line of television shows that imagine the American family as an embattled criminal enterprise — “The Sopranos,” “Sons of Anarchy” — add “Outsiders,” a 13-episode series starting Tuesday on WGN America. Like the New Jersey wiseguys and drug-dealing California bikers in those shows, the Farrells, the moonshine-making Kentucky clan in “Outsiders,” are morally compromised but representative of traditional American values. They may engage in armed robbery, vandalism and matricide, but it’s because they really just want to be left alone.

headline: If Bloomberg Enters the Presidential Race …
abstract: One reader says as a “moderate pragmatist” he’s a “sensible choice”; another says his candidacy “would only worsen the political dysfunction.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Giambattista Valli’s couture show.
lead_paragraph: Giambattista Valli’s couture show.

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View After a Winter Storm
abstract: Drone and aerial footage show a peaceful, snow-covered Northeast after a winter storm coated parts of Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey and several other states.
lead_paragraph: Drone and aerial footage show a peaceful, snow-covered Northeast after a winter storm coated parts of Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey and several other states.

headline: Justices Expand Parole Rights for Juveniles Sentenced to Life for Murder
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The Supreme Court clarified a 2012 ruling and created the possibility of release for some older inmates serving life sentences for killings committed when they were young.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that its 2012 decision banning mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juvenile killers must be applied retroactively, granting a new chance at release for hundreds of inmates serving life sentences without the possibility of parole for murders they committed in their youth.

headline: ‘The Skinny,’ About Bulimia, to Debut at Sundance
abstract: This comedic web series from Jessie Kahnweiler is about a feminist YouTube star who struggles with bulimia.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — A couple of years ago, Jessie Kahnweiler was interning at Bad Robot, the movie and television company owned by J. J. Abrams. But she found herself wanting something else. Finally, all around her in Hollywood, or so it seemed, were intrepid women making boundary-pushing shows: “Girls,” “Broad City,” “Transparent.”

headline: Rock Is Back as Panic! At the Disco Tops Billboard Chart
abstract: Panic! At the Disco achieves the relatively rare feat these days of topping the Billboard chart with a rock album.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that a rock album tops the Billboard album chart, but Panic! At the Disco did it this week with its new release, “Death of a Bachelor” (Fueled by Ramen/DCD2), which sold 169,000 copies and had 17 million streams, according to Nielsen.

headline: New From Hilton: Midpriced Hotels Geared Toward Millennials
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Millennial Generation']
abstract: A new hotel brand, Tru by Hilton, will attempt to be the first design-forward hotel chain in the midscale category where rooms start at $80.
lead_paragraph: Hilton Worldwide has announced a new hotel brand today, Tru by Hilton, that is positioned to be the first design-forward hotel chain in the midscale category where rooms start at $80.

headline: Review: Donny McCaslin’s Quartet, Fresh Off the Release of Bowie’s ‘Blackstar’
abstract: In a nod to his quartet’s role on that new album, Mr. McCaslin invoked Mr. Bowie’s influence and memory at the Village Vanguard.
lead_paragraph: Donny McCaslin dedicated an untitled new song at the Village Vanguard on Sunday night to someone he said had been a great influence in his life, “someone who recently passed away.” The song, which began in a hush, sounded faintly familiar: The brooding dignity of its melody, carried by Mr. McCaslin on tenor saxophone against a spooky stir of keyboards, bass and drums, evoked the mood of David Bowie’s last album, “Blackstar.”

headline: Palestinian Assailants Are Killed After Knife Attack on 2 Israeli Women
abstract: The attack, in which one of the women was critically wounded, was the third inside a West Bank settlement in eight days.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Two Palestinian assailants stabbed two Israeli women in a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank on Monday, wounding one of them severely, before being fatally shot by a security guard, according to the Israeli police.

headline: J. Crew Puts Its Own Spin on Classic Sunglasses Shapes
abstract: The brand launches its first full-fledged collection, for women and men, tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: “Every time I see myself in a picture and I’m wearing aviators, I think ‘ugh,’” says Jenna Lyons, the president and creative director of the J. Crew Group. “They have a tendency to tilt down, so that the top of the glass lifts away from your eyebrow and the bottom hits the top of your cheek. They aren’t that flattering in photos — I know that sounds silly, but for us, it’s a big thing.”

headline: Dior’s Couture Show Has a Different Look
abstract: The radiant faces of its campaign stars and A-list Hollywood actresses were missing from the front row.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Traditionally, the front row of the Dior couture show, which was held Monday in the gardens of the Musée Rodin, has bloomed with the radiant faces of its campaign stars and A-list Hollywood actresses. Emily Blunt, Lupita Nyong’o and Charlize Theron are just a handful of stars who have attended in recent seasons.

headline: Linking Arthritis to Old Injuries
abstract: Post-traumatic arthritis is a leading cause of disability, especially for wounded soldiers, but a way to prevent it has not been proven.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why does arthritis tend to develop in joints that have experienced trauma earlier in life?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: E.U. Ministers Spar as Bloc’s Promise of Free Movement Wavers
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The question hanging over a meeting is whether the bloc can agree on a collective approach to limit the influx of migrants and avoid an every-country-for-itself scramble.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — European Union interior ministers clashed on Monday over how to check the flow of migrants across their countries’ borders amid growing concern that the Continent’s commitment to the free movement of people within the bloc is at risk of collapse.

headline: Facts & Figures: What Democrats and Republicans Want From Politicians
abstract: Do elected officials need to compromise more? Your answer might depend on your party affiliation.
lead_paragraph: A recent Monmouth University poll asked respondents which caused more problems in the federal government: elected officials’ failure to compromise, or their failure to stand by their principles. Sixty-eight percent of Democrats said lack of compromise was the bigger problem, while 25 percent chose failure to stand on principle. Among Republicans, meanwhile, 54 percent said failure to stand on principle was the bigger issue, and just 36 percent picked lack of compromise.

headline: Hillary Clinton Holds Fire on Bernie Sanders, Taking Aim at Republicans
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Glass-Steagall Act (1933)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton shifted from attacking Mr. Sanders to a stump speech delivered in December that criticizes Republicans and praises the Vermont senator as her “esteemed” rival.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Hillary Clinton’s remarks on the campaign trail a week before the Iowa caucuses are harking back to a simpler time in her candidacy: last month.

headline: Opposition Groups in Moldova Unite to Protest New Government
abstract: More than 15,000 people demonstrated on Sunday after a new prime minister, Pavel Filip, was named to lead the country’s third government in a year.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Frustration with the political establishment is boiling over again in Moldova, where more than 15,000 people took to the streets of the capital on Sunday to vent their anger at the new government that was sworn in just last week.

headline: Where the Wild Things Aren’t: A Sendak Museum
abstract: In his will, Maurice Sendak called for his home to become “a museum or similar facility,” but four years after his death there is no consensus plan.
lead_paragraph: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — The characters of Maurice Sendak may live in the imaginations of children around the world, but many of those characters were born in a wooded residential neighborhood on the outskirts of this small town, in a rambling shingle house where Mr. Sendak lived and worked beginning in the early 1970s.

headline: Review: Milton Babbitt Inspires a Focus! Festival Tribute
abstract: The opening concert of this weeklong centennial event featured the New Juilliard Ensemble in an improbable world premiere.
lead_paragraph: Street crime, of all things, might have been what caused the brainy composer Milton Babbitt to abandon his Concerti for Violin, Orchestra and Synthesized Sound in 1976. That’s what Joel Sachs, the founding director of the New Juilliard Ensemble, suggested to the audience that nearly filled the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the school on Friday for the opening concert of the 32nd Focus! festival, a free weeklong centennial tribute to Babbitt.

headline: In Napa Valley, Future Landscapes Are Viewed in the Past
abstract: Ecologists restoring parts of San Francisco Bay are guided by tattered maps, old snapshots, even paintings of a vanished world.
lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — San Francisco Bay, the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta and the watershed that feeds them make up one of the world’s largest estuary systems, a wildly varied tableau of beaches, river, creeks, grasslands and tidal marshes. Forty percent of the land in California drains into this rich ecosystem.

headline: Ted Cruz on Feud With Donald Trump: He Started It
abstract: Mr. Cruz said his sudden antagonism toward Mr. Trump was in response to the real estate developer insulting him every day.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas suggested a simple explanation on Monday for his sudden antagonism toward Donald J. Trump in recent weeks: The other guy started it.

headline: Billy Donovan’s One-on-One Game Plan to Connect With Thunder Players
abstract: Donovan, hired as Oklahoma City’s coach last year, has emphasized communication and building relationships, and the result has been high-level basketball, with 22 wins in his last 27 games.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Billy Donovan became coach of the Oklahoma City Thunder last spring, he had a member of his staff reach out to the players. The team had scuffled through an injury-marred season, and most of the players had scattered for the approaching summer. Steve Novak, for example, was home in Wisconsin when he got the phone call.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, France and England
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, France and England

headline: As Population Ages, Where Are the Geriatricians?
abstract: Amid a rising tide of older adults, there are fewer specialists to treat them. Most residents would rather do something else.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Ruth Miles, 83, sat in a wheelchair in a small exam room, clutching a water bottle, looking frightened and uncomfortable.

headline: Jan. 25, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from the United States, France, Israel and London.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, France, Israel and London.

headline: Review: ‘Drunk Shakespeare,’ Where the Tipsy and the Sober Take Liberties
abstract: Each night the Drunk Shakespeare Society gathers with audience members on a library-like set, whereupon one actor downs alcohol, and the play commences.
lead_paragraph: It seems inevitable that soon all performing will be done either plastered or stoned. Among the early adopters of this trend, probably no one is applying more verve to the conceit than the members of the Drunk Shakespeare Society. Here’s hoping others learn from their sloshy example.

headline: Joni Ernst, Standing Next to Marco Rubio, Is Not Endorsing Anyone
abstract: Ms. Ernst, Iowa’s freshman Republican senator, has promised not endorse anyone in the presidential race, but that didn’t stop her from appearing with Mr. Rubio, her “good friend.”
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa wants you to know that she is remaining neutral in next week’s caucuses.

headline: Celebrities and Their Sundance Style
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: Sundance fashion doesn’t have to be Canada Goose puffers, hats and bulky boots. Here are celebrities who are stepping out stylishly in the Utah weather.
lead_paragraph: Sundance fashion doesn’t have to be Canada Goose puffers, hats and bulky boots. Here are celebrities who are stepping out stylishly in the Utah weather.

headline: Citadel Punishes Students for Costumes Evoking the K.K.K.
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia']
abstract: The school said in a statement that the students donned the pillowcases to sing Christmas carols.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen cadets at the Citadel in Charleston, S.C., were disciplined on Monday after several of them appeared last month in photographs wearing white pillowcases on their heads. The pillowcases evoked a likeness to the hoods worn by the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Some Areas Hit by East Coast Blizzard Can Only Crawl Toward Recovery
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Mid-Atlantic States (US)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: In several states, many government offices and schools remained closed on Monday, many roads had not yet been cleared and trash pickup was postponed.
lead_paragraph: The storm is over. But as millions of people from North Carolina to Massachusetts tried on Monday to dig out from the weekend’s massive snows, it was clear that for many of them it could still be several days before life returns to normal.

headline: Review: Young Pianists Offer Rich Duos
abstract: The Chamber Society of Lincoln Center fielded four young pianists, Juho Pohjonen, Orion Weiss, Wu Qian and Alessio Bax, at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Music may not offer a better mixture of grandeur and intimacy than the piano duo. Just two people on stage, yes, but each playing this instrument of fearsome potency. In range of colors and sheer volume, the combination surely has no equal in the chamber repertory.

headline: Review: Peter Bergen’s ‘United States of Jihad’ Surveys Homegrown Terrorism
abstract: In his new book, Mr. Bergen finds that most jihadists in the United States are not who we imagine them to be. Some seem to be well-adjusted Americans.
lead_paragraph: Since Sept. 11, 2001, Peter Bergen reports in his new timely book, 330 people in the United States have been charged with some kind of jihadist terrorist crime, and a startling four out of five of them were American citizens or legal permanent residents.

headline: Bill de Blasio Not Keen on a Bloomberg Presidential Run
abstract: The New York mayor said he did not believe Americans would turn to billionaires like his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, or Donald J, Trump “to solve problems created by billionaires.”
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York weighed in Monday on a potential presidential run by his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, saying he did not believe Americans would “turn to billionaires to solve problems created by billionaires.”

headline: 2 Abortion Foes Behind Planned Parenthood Videos Are Indicted
abstract: A grand jury cleared Planned Parenthood of allegations of misconduct, instead indicting its opponents on charges including tampering with a governmental record.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A grand jury here that was investigating accusations of misconduct against Planned Parenthood has instead indicted two abortion opponents who made undercover videos of the organization.

headline: Sarah Palin, Rage Whisperer
abstract: She is the American politician most fluent in anger, and she paved the way for Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: DONALD J. TRUMP has made a shrewd bet. For the first time since he descended an escalator in Trump Tower last June to announce that this time, he really was running for president, he ceded control of his campaign message. He handed the Trump-bedecked podium over to Sarah Palin.

headline: Zika Virus: Two Cases Suggest It Could Be Spread Through Sex
abstract: The evidence is slim, but some experts want scientists to investigate whether a virus linked to birth defects and commonly transmitted by mosquitoes could be spread sexually.
lead_paragraph: Zika virus has already been linked to brain damage in babies and paralysis in adults. Now scientists are facing another ominous possibility: that on rare occasions, the virus might be transmitted through sex.

headline: A Space Station, With Surveillance Cameras for Hire
keywords: ['International Space Station', 'Cameras', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Satellites', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Two cameras owned by the Canadian company UrtheCast are available for surveillance jobs from their low-earth orbit on the International Space Station.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two cameras sit on the Russian part of the International Space Station. They are named Theia and Iris. And they are available to hire out for “space-based video surveillance.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Mailing in Iowa Defends His Record on Guns
abstract: The Sanders campaign has mailed Iowa voters literature that outlines his record on gun control, suggesting how much he is on the defensive on the issue with the caucuses only a week away.
lead_paragraph: The rah-rah atmosphere at campaign events for Senator Bernie Sanders is often punctured, if only momentarily, by a sharp question from a voter asking him to explain his record on gun regulation and his vote affording special legal protection to the gun industry.

headline: Review: ‘The Burial at Thebes,’ a Vicious but Poetic Tale Retold
abstract: Seamus Heaney’s adaptation of Sophocles’ “Antigone,” at the Irish Repertory Theater, was written in response to the American invasion of Iraq.
lead_paragraph: A few things feel off in “The Burial at Thebes.” But one big thing — the script — is on, and that saves this version of “Antigone” from failure.

headline: Looks from Schai’s fall/winter 2016 collection
abstract: The military-inspired line is also an homage to her team.
lead_paragraph: The military-inspired line is also an homage to her team.

headline: For One Designer, Inspiration That Began With Hand-Me-Downs
abstract: Suk Chai of the brand Schai studied clothes she inherited from her brothers and sister before launching her own line.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the designer Suk Chai describe a garment in thorough detail is almost like seeing it and touching it for yourself. She fine-tuned her fashion vocabulary as a child, watching items that originally belonged to her eldest brother get passed to her second-oldest brother, then to her older sister, and finally to her. “I waited for this particular tweed coat and red beret for at least six years,” says Chai, now 43, who was born in Korea and raised in Seattle. Her first non-hand-me-down came in the form of a white, crew-neck, short-sleeved, all-cotton dress with patchwork and a poofy skirt (the occasion: her second-grade piano recital). “Both outfits were special,” she remarks. “The tweed coat — I had my eye on that for a long, long time, and I loved it and knew it’d eventually be mine; but I did like having my own clothes.”

headline: New York Weddings Blanketed in White
abstract: Some couples were in denial about how disruptive one of the biggest blizzards in the city’s history would be.

headline: How to Build Affordable Housing in New York City
abstract: Recent projects in which public housing was renovated by private developers could show a path forward.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy was the last straw for many residents of Ocean Village, a housing project in the Rockaways. Heralded as state of the art when it opened in 1972, this beachside campus of high-rises and four-story townhouses had, over the years, taken a nose dive, the victim of bad management, crime and rot. Sandy left homes flooded, and poor tenants bereft of electricity and hot water. Residents who could, fled.

headline: As Iowa Caucuses Near, Jeb Bush Goes to Nevada
abstract: Six days before the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Bush plans to campaign in Elko, Nev., to show Nevadans that his campaign is taking their state seriously.
lead_paragraph: Iowans head to their local caucus precincts a week from Monday — and Jeb Bush on Tuesday is headed to … Elko, Nev.

headline: Budget Office Lowers Its Forecast for Obamacare Enrollment
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Two years in, it’s clear that progress in reducing the rate of the uninsured is going to be slower than proponents hoped. But the news isn’t all bad.
lead_paragraph: When the Affordable Care Act was drafted, the Congressional Budget Office expected people to sign up quickly for new health insurance.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Personal on Christ and Her Faith
abstract: At an event in Iowa, Mrs. Clinton elaborated on her views on Christianity and the Bible, a subject she rarely talks about when campaigning.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Hillary Clinton is Methodist, but she rarely talks about her faith on the campaign trail.

headline: The Best Women’s Looks — on the Men’s Runways
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: As the fall/winter 2016 men’s shows wrap up in Europe, a look back at a surprising trend: the inclusion of women’s wear.
lead_paragraph: As the fall/winter 2016 men’s shows wrap up in Europe, a look back at a surprising trend: the inclusion of women’s wear.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Battling in Iowa, Turns Warm Under Pressure
abstract: In trying to win the Iowa caucuses in a race that has become much tougher than she expected, Mrs. Clinton has tried to be more open and personable with Iowans.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Iowa — At big ballroom dinners on the campaign trail, Hillary Clinton often emerges from behind a curtain to deliver a speech, then disappears again behind the folds when finished.
