headline: Consultant Gets $7 Million More to Plan Reform at Rikers Jails
abstract: The consultant, McKinsey & Company, which was first hired by New York City in 2014, reported that morale in the Correction Department might be the worst it had seen in any organization.
lead_paragraph: In the latest indication of how daunting it has been to remake the troubled New York City jails, the de Blasio administration is spending an additional $7 million on an international consulting firm that it first hired in 2014 to develop a blueprint for reform.

headline: Marvin Minsky, Pioneer in Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 88
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Professor Minsky laid the foundation for the field by demonstrating the possibilities of imparting common-sense reasoning to computers.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Minsky, who combined a scientist’s thirst for knowledge with a philosopher’s quest for truth as a pioneering explorer of artificial intelligence, work that helped inspire the creation of the personal computer and the Internet, died on Sunday night in Boston. He was 88.

headline: Seeking to End Gerrymandering’s Enduring Legacy
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Advocates in several states are trying to change the strict political control of the congressional map-drawing process, which has a long history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Buried less than two miles from the Capitol is the man many blame for the toxic partisanship infecting Congress today even though he died 202 years ago.

headline: Argentina Scrambles to Fight Biggest Plague of Locusts in 60 Years
abstract: Warm, wet winters spawned a locust infestation in dry northern forests. In 10 days, the insects will be mature enough to form flying swarms that devour crops.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Farmers and fumigators in Argentina are running out of time as they scramble to control the country’s worst plague of locusts in more than half a century, officials warned on Monday.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Backed by Image of a Bright Horizon, Lays Out His Vision
abstract: In highly idealistic terms, Mr. Sanders details his goals and appeals to Iowans a week before their presidential caucuses.
lead_paragraph: In Part 2 of his closing argument to Iowans, Senator Bernie Sanders lays out his vision and explicitly asks Democrats to caucus for him.

headline: Three Styling Take-Aways from Dior Couture
abstract: Inventively layered knits, undone hair — and even ankle bracelets — appeared on the spring/summer 2016 haute couture runway today in Paris.
lead_paragraph: With Raf Simons gone, Dior’s spring/summer 2016 haute couture collection, which showed today in Paris, was left to studio heads Lucie Meier and Serge Ruffieux. Though Simons’s modern sensibility was certainly felt in Meier and Ruffieux’s designs, the duo introduced small styling suggestions in several looks that were entirely fresh. Here, three tricks from the show that were cool, laid back — and far more approachable than is typical for couture.

headline: Atelier Versace’s Athletic-Inspired Haute Couture Collection
abstract: For spring 2016, Donatella Versace celebrated strength and femininity with ergonomic lines, sporty hues and cutout silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: For spring 2016, Donatella Versace celebrated strength and femininity with ergonomic lines, sporty hues and cutout silhouettes.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Far Ahead in New Hampshire, Poll Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A poll released Monday showed Mr. Sanders and Mr. Trump with commanding leads two weeks before the New Hampshire primary.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump appear to be the candidates to beat in New Hampshire, according to a poll released Monday that showed them with commanding leads two weeks before the state’s primary.

headline: Iran Still a Leading Executioner of Minors, Report Says
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Children and Childhood', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Amnesty International said Iran had executed 73 juvenile offenders since 2005, despite pledging in 1994 to end the death penalty for those under 18.
lead_paragraph: Iran is one of the leading executioners of juvenile offenders, despite its improved legal protections for children and a pledge more than two decades ago to end the death penalty for convicts younger than 18, Amnesty International said Monday.

headline: Tumult in World Markets Damps Conviction at Davos
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The yearly gathering of moguls was more sober this year, as China’s deceleration, pitching markets and a depression in oil prices shadowed the mood.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The World Economic Forum has long been a citadel for corporate chieftains and government officials to bask in their collective stature, coming together to chat about what they can do as leaders about the world’s troubles.

headline: Pope Francis, Catholics and Lutherans Will Recall Reformation
abstract: Pope Francis will participate in a joint worship service in Sweden as part of a series of events to commemorate the 500th anniversary of the Reformation.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 500 years ago, Martin Luther nailed his 95 theses to the door of a German church, beginning the Protestant Reformation that led millions to break with the Roman Catholic Church and ushered in more than a century of conflict and war.

headline: 2 Offices Won’t Investigate New York Constitutional Amendment on Adirondack Mining
abstract: Protect the Adirondacks, an environmental group, requested inquiries into the 2013 amendment that allowed NYCO Minerals to conduct open-pit mining on state land.
lead_paragraph: The offices of the New York attorney general and inspector general have declined to open investigations into the 2013 constitutional amendment that allowed a private company, NYCO Minerals, to conduct open-pit mining on state land in the Adirondack Mountains.

headline: The Supreme Court Says Again: Juveniles Are Different
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Probation and Parole', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Editorials', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The justices should take the final step and outlaw life sentences without parole for children.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has ruled repeatedly over the last decade that it is morally and constitutionally wrong to equate offenses committed by emotionally undeveloped adolescents with crimes carried out by adults. It made this point again on Monday when it ruled that people who were sentenced to mandatory life in prison without the possibility of parole as juveniles have the right to seek parole.

headline: Comforts of a Hotel That’s Close to Home in Dangerous Weather
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Weather']
abstract: Bad weather often causes cancellations at hotels, who then make up for lost revenue by offering a discounted rate to local residents.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Kruszka of Virginia saw last weekend’s storm heading for the Washington area, he did not hesitate to find a place where he and his family could stay warm and comfortable — the nearby Hyatt Regency Tysons Corner Center.

headline: Quintonio LeGrier’s Three 911 Calls
abstract: Audio released Monday of calls placed to the Chicago police by Mr. LeGrier on Dec. 26. Mr. LeGrier was fatally shot by officers as he emerged from a home holding a baseball bat.
lead_paragraph: Audio released Monday of calls placed to the Chicago police by Mr. LeGrier on Dec. 26. Mr. LeGrier was fatally shot by officers as he emerged from a home holding a baseball bat.

headline: California: Help Sought to Find Escapees
abstract: Two of the three inmates who escaped Friday from a maximum security jail in Orange County are believed to be members of Vietnamese gangs, and could be embedded within the county’s sizable Vietnamese community.
lead_paragraph: Two of the three inmates who escaped Friday from a maximum security jail in Orange County are believed to be members of Vietnamese gangs, and sheriff’s officials said on Monday that they believe the men could be embedded within the county’s sizable Vietnamese community. Officials identified Jonathan Tieu, 20, and Bac Duong, 43, as likely members of Vietnamese gangs, which they declined to name. Officials put out a message in Vietnamese asking for any information about the fugitives. The family of Mr. Tieu spoke to a local television station, and asked him to turn himself in. The two men and a third inmate, Hossein Nayeri, 37, have not been seen since the Friday morning head count at the Orange County Central Men’s Jail in Santa Ana. It is unclear if they had help from jail employees or contractors.

headline: Dean Skelos and His Son, Convicted on Corruption Charges, Seek New Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Mr. Skelos, a former majority leader of the New York Senate, and his son, Adam, filed a motion arguing government prosecutors failed to submit enough evidence.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Dean G. Skelos, the former New York State Senate majority leader, and his son, who were convicted on federal corruption charges last month, filed a motion on Monday seeking a judgment of acquittal and a new trial.

headline: Climate Deal’s First Big Hurdle: The Draw of Cheap Oil
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: For the accord to work, governments must resist ever more affordable fossil fuels in favor of policies that encourage and, in many cases, require the use of renewable energy sources.
lead_paragraph: Barely a month after world leaders signed a sweeping agreement to reduce carbon emissions, the global commitment to renewable energy sources faces its first big test as the price of oil collapses.

headline: Yemen: Top Judge and 6 Relatives Are Killed in Airstrike
abstract: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led military coalition hit the home of a senior judge in Sana, killing the judge along with his relatives.
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led military coalition on Monday hit the home of a senior judge in Sana, Yemen’s capital, killing the judge along with six relatives, according to witnesses and medics. The judge, Yayha Alrubaid, who headed a court that dealt with national security matters and terrorism, had recently prosecuted members of Yemen’s Saudi-backed government in exile for high treason, officials said. Saudi Arabia entered Yemen’s civil war in March on the side of President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, who was driven from power by Houthi rebels last year. Coalition airstrikes have routinely hit civilian targets and killed hundreds of people, according to human rights workers. The Obama administration, which has supported the Saudi-led campaign in Yemen, issued an unusual statement on Saturday, criticizing recent airstrikes that killed a Yemeni journalist and an ambulance driver working with Doctors Without Borders, though the statement made no mention of Saudi Arabia or the coalition.

headline: So Far, Amazon and Netflix Are Sundance’s Top Buyers
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Movies']
abstract: At the 2016 Sundance Film Festival, the big streaming services, not the traditional studios, are driving the deal-making.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — It was the independent film equivalent of a crack of thunder.

headline: Zephyr Teachout Announces Bid for New York Congressional Seat
abstract: Ms. Teachout, who campaigned in 2014 for the Democratic nomination for governor, is now running for federal office in a district that was heavily contested two years ago.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Zephyr Teachout has a name that can be both hard to remember and, for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, probably hard to forget.

headline: El Salvador’s Advice on Zika Virus: Don’t Have Babies
abstract: Grappling with a mosquito-borne virus linked to brain damage in infants, El Salvador is advising all women in the country not to get pregnant until 2018.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — When in human history has an epidemic become so alarming that a nation feels compelled to urge its people not to have children for two years?

headline: A Tidal Wave of Corporate Migrants Seeking (Tax) Shelter
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Corporations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Johnson Controls is just the latest corporation to flee America for greener, lower-tax pastures. And until lawmakers reform the tax code, the exodus will continue.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2008, with General Motors and Chrysler on the precipice of bankruptcy, executives at the car parts supplier Johnson Controls flew to Washington. The company’s president testified before a Senate panel and implored lawmakers to bail out the auto industry.

headline: Upset Over Megyn Kelly, Donald Trump Says He May Skip Debate
abstract: Saying he does not think Ms. Kelly, the Fox News host who is one of the debate moderators, can treat him fairly, Mr. Trump said he might opt out of the event on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: With anticipation building over the final Republican debate before the Iowa caucuses next week, one candidate is contemplating skipping it: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Police Presence in Egypt Mutes Most Protests on 5th Anniversary of Uprising
abstract: Egyptians marked the fifth anniversary of the uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak with a handful of flash protests but none of the violence or anger that drove the uprising.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The few dozen protesters seemed to emerge from nowhere, surging down a narrow street and waving a four-finger salute that identified them as likely supporters of Egypt’s outlawed Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Libya: Parliament Rejects Cabinet Plan
abstract: Lawmakers in Libya overwhelmingly rejected a proposed United Nations-backed unity cabinet on Monday, dealing a blow to diplomatic efforts.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Libya’s internationally recognized Parliament overwhelmingly rejected a proposed United Nations-backed unity cabinet on Monday, dealing a blow to diplomatic efforts to swiftly reconcile the country’s splintered factions. Parliament, which sits in the eastern city of Tobruk, rejected the 32-member cabinet out of concern that it was too large and that its members had been chosen not for their competency but to satisfy various regional factions, according to Abu Bakr Buera, an influential lawmaker. Diplomats have been urging Libyan officials to bridge the divisions that emerged after the 2011 revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Budget Office Sharply Cuts Health Exchange Estimate
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The number of people who get insurance this year through the Affordable Care Act’s public marketplaces is expected to be 13 million, down from a prior projection of 21 million.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office on Monday sharply reduced its estimate of how many people would get health insurance this year through the Affordable Care Act’s public marketplaces, to 13 million, from a prior estimate of 21 million.

headline: Central African Republic: Court Invalidates Legislative Election
abstract: The Central African Republic’s constitutional court scrapped results from a legislative election, citing irregularities like illegible ballots and poor training for election workers.
lead_paragraph: The Central African Republic’s constitutional court certified presidential election results Monday but separately scrapped results from a legislative election, citing irregularities like illegible ballots and poor training for election workers. The court’s validation sets the stage for a runoff for the presidential election that pits Anicet-Georges Dologuélé against Faustin Archange Touadera, two former prime ministers. They will face each other in a vote scheduled for no sooner than Feb. 7. Election observers said that redoing the legislative vote, which took place simultaneously with the presidential vote, would be costly. Candidates were puzzled by the court’s decision. “This is illogical,” said Lydie Nzengou, the communications officer for Karim Meckassoua, a presidential candidate. “Why would the results for the presidential vote be more credible than those of the legislative vote?”

headline: Donald Trump to New Hampshire: Give Me a Mandate
abstract: Donald J. Trump asked New Hampshire voters Monday to hand him a victory so big, so beautiful, that only one word in the political lexicon could describe it: mandate.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGTON, N.H. – Donald J. Trump asked New Hampshire voters on Monday to hand him a victory so big, so beautiful, that only one word in the political lexicon could describe it.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10, Episode 2: That’s More Like It
abstract: It’s only with this second episode that it feels like “The X-Files” is actually back.
lead_paragraph: Part human, part alien siblings who can shatter glass; stolen babies; evil parents; our heroes in danger; and suits for everyone. “The X-Files” is back!

headline: Online, Egypt’s Internet Activists Mourn Their Stifled Revolt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners', 'Social Media']
abstract: The anniversary of the Jan. 25 revolution was commemorated quietly by some of those who helped drive millions of Egyptians to the streets in 2011.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Declan Walsh reports from Cairo, a crackdown by Egypt’s security forces managed to suppress even the slightest echo of the massive street protests that began on this date in 2011 and led, 18 days later, to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Chris Christie’s Momentum Tested as Opponents Attack
abstract: Mr. Christie fought his way into contention in New Hampshire, though his opponents are questioning his campaign story line, testing his momentum.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON FALLS, N.H. — Gov. Chris Christie has seized every chance to show voters that he is a man with true grit. In a summer of Black Lives Matter protests, he cast himself as a flinty defender of the police. He responded to the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., by campaigning as a fearless former antiterrorism prosecutor.

headline: Libyan Lawmakers Reject U.N.-Backed Unity Government
abstract: The internationally recognized Parliament voted down a proposed 32-member cabinet in a blow to international efforts to help form a unified government.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Lawmakers in Libya’s internationally recognized Parliament overwhelmingly rejected a proposed United Nations-backed unity cabinet on Monday, dealing a blow to diplomatic efforts to swiftly reconcile the country’s splintered factions.

headline: Obama Bans Solitary Confinement of Juveniles in Federal Prisons
abstract: The practice can lead to “devastating, lasting psychological consequences,” he said in an opinion article in The Washington Post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday banned the practice of holding juveniles in solitary confinement in federal prisons, saying it could lead to “devastating, lasting psychological consequences.”

headline: Waiting in the Sky
abstract: Sam Ezersky helps us remember an icon.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The world lost DAVID BOWIE, one of its most innovative musical artists, recently. More than that, we lost someone who made it acceptable to be just who you happened to be at the time: fluid, sparkly, experimental without fear, both human and alien at once. He made it easier for kids who were discovering their own styles and their own sexuality to be themselves, and we will not see his kind again. We’ve lost our Starman.

headline: Man Killed by Chicago Police Called 911 Before Being Shot
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)']
abstract: Audiotapes of the three calls released Monday showed that Quintonio LeGrier was treated curtly by dispatchers, one of whom hung up on him.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A man who was fatally shot by the police in December as he emerged from a home with a baseball bat had called 911 seeking help from the police three times in the minutes before the shooting, but was met with curt dispatchers, according to audio of the calls made public on Monday. One of the dispatchers hung up on him when he was unwilling to elaborate on what was wrong.

headline: Red Wings Halt Islanders’ Momentum
abstract: The Islanders, who had won three of their last four, lost their last game before the All-Star break, with Detroit capitalizing on two quick second-period goals.
lead_paragraph: Playing for only the third time in 11 days and skating in their last game before the All-Star break, the Islanders had a chance on Monday to vault into the winter break in style.

headline: Bernie Sanders a Target of Ads by Republican Donor
abstract: A “super PAC” founded by the former TD Ameritrade executive Joe Ricketts is spending more than $600,000 on a television ad in Iowa lashing Senator Bernie Sanders as “too liberal.”
lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” founded by the former TD Ameritrade executive Joe Ricketts is spending more than $600,000 on a television ad in Iowa lashing Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont as “too liberal” in the final days of his close race against Hillary Clinton in the state’s caucuses.

headline: Trial Begins in Art Forgery Case Against Knoedler Gallery
abstract: The gallery is accused of selling dozens of fake works that it said were by master artists, including a purported Rothko purchased by Domenico and Eleanore De Sole for $8.3 million in 2004.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most anticipated trial exploring the art market in recent years began Monday in United States District Court in Manhattan with a lawyer for a couple that bought a fake Rothko asserting in her opening argument that Knoedler & Company, a once-celebrated Manhattan gallery that is now defunct, had deceived its customers while selling them dozens of fake works that it said were by master artists.

headline: Suspect in Machete Killing in the Bronx Said Neighbors Spied on Him, Officials Say
abstract: Angel Feliz-Volquez, 26, was charged on Monday with killing Carmen Torres-Gonzalez, 59, with the 20-inch weapon outside her mother’s apartment in a Bronx public housing project.
lead_paragraph: A 26-year-old man who told the police his neighbors in a Bronx public housing complex were spying on him was charged on Monday with killing a 59-year-old woman in a machete attack outside her mother’s apartment, the authorities said.

headline: Serena Williams Rolls Past Maria Sharapova at Australian Open
abstract: Williams earned her 18th straight victory against Sharapova, the fifth seed, to advance to a semifinal against another player she has dominated, Agnieszka Radwanska.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Maria Sharapova gives herself and her public plenty of time to think as she takes her now-characteristic long pause between first and second serves.

headline: Traffic Comes to a Halt, and a Kitten Is Saved

lead_paragraph: Stopped at a light on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, a block from her house in Windsor Terrace, Geraldine Cassone saw a little black kitten run in front of her car.

lead_paragraph: Coach Alain Vigneault stepped briskly to a lectern two hours before his Rangers were to face the last-place Buffalo Sabres on Monday in their final game before the N.H.L. All-Star break and announced that Rick Nash had sustained only a bruised left knee Friday.

headline: Film Academy Gives Guidance on Oscar Voting Rights
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences late Monday disclosed guidelines meant to settle at least some questions surrounding new diversity-oriented rules.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As its members struggled to understand new diversity-oriented rules that may cost many their Oscar voting rights, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences late Monday disclosed guidelines meant to settle at least some questions about who remains in and who may be out of Hollywood’s exclusive professional association.

headline: Miley Cyrus Joins the Cast of Woody Allen’s Amazon Series
abstract: For his first foray into television, Mr. Allen is relying on one of his tried and true formulas — casting an attention-grabbing young actress alongside himself. This time it’s Ms. Cyrus.
lead_paragraph: For his first foray into streaming television, Woody Allen is relying on one of his tried and true formulas — casting an attention-grabbing young actress alongside himself. In this case, Miley Cyrus, the former Disney kid turned outré pop star, will appear in his coming streaming series for Amazon.

headline: Judge Upholds Gun Arrest Made by New York Officer Who Was Later Killed

lead_paragraph: One of the last gun-possession arrests made by a New York police officer who was killed in the line of duty last year remained intact on Monday, after a state judge denied a request by the defense to exclude the weapon from evidence.

lead_paragraph: Two people from New York were found dead in their cars on Monday, and the authorities were investigating whether their deaths were related to the weekend blizzard.

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Malaysia’s attorney general said on Tuesday that he had closed an investigation into transfers of hundreds of millions of dollars into Prime Minister Najib Razak’s personal bank accounts because no laws had been broken.

headline: Amid Bay Area Gentrification, One Man’s Three-Year Struggle
abstract: A chance encounter with a man trying for a new start in Oakland led to a complex, three-year tale with no easy answers.
lead_paragraph: Amid the political and cultural fervor a half-century ago, Oakland and the Bay Area were once home to founding members of the Black Panthers, Beats and hippie movements. These days it’s attracting many white middle-class residents who bring with them rising rents and displacement. When Sam Wolson moved to Oakland, he became keenly aware that he was a part of that influx.

headline: What Voters Want
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why the tallest candidate, with a name near the beginning of the alphabet, may triumph.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re discussing the presidential election with a group of friends who live in Iowa or New Hampshire. You ask them who they intend to vote for next month.

headline: Opening a New Front Against ISIS in Libya
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Military intervention in Libya could lead to expanded American involvement in other countries in Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon is ramping up intelligence-gathering in Libya as the Obama administration draws up plans to open a third front in the war against the Islamic State. This significant escalation is being planned without a meaningful debate in Congress about the merits and risks of a military campaign that is expected to include airstrikes and raids by elite American troops.

headline: Stay Sane America, Please!
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: There are many good reasons to think Trump, Cruz and Sanders won’t make it past the primaries, much less the conventions.
lead_paragraph: In January of 2017 someone will stand at the U.S. Capitol and deliver an Inaugural Address. This is roughly the place where Abraham Lincoln, Franklin Roosevelt, Dwight Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan once stood. I am going to spend every single day between now and then believing that neither Donald Trump nor Ted Cruz nor Bernie Sanders will be standing on that podium. One of them could win the election, take the oath, give the speech and be riding down Pennsylvania Avenue. I will still refuse to believe it.

headline: The Punctual Patient
abstract: She was never late, or even early. What was that about?
lead_paragraph: It was two years into the treatment, and T., a retired executive, still continued to fantasize about being my ideal and favorite patient. She repeatedly attempted to please me by trying to say whatever she thought I would like to hear, despite the fact that I kept reminding her that this was her treatment, not mine.

headline: Democracy on Hold in Haiti
abstract: With the presidential runoff thankfully put off indefinitely, what’s needed is a transitional government leading to fair elections.
lead_paragraph: A runoff election on Sunday for president in Haiti was postponed indefinitely late last week. The decision made sense, because with protesters in the streets, violence and gunfire and the torching of electoral offices, it was clear that any vote would be marred by bloodshed and chaos.

headline: EKG Screening for College Athletes
abstract: Those who play certain sports should have their hearts tested.
lead_paragraph: LAST March, the N.C.A.A.’s chief medical officer, Brian Hainline, announced that he was going to recommend that all male college basketball players undergo an electrocardiogram, which measures the electrical activity in the heart, presumably as a requirement for being cleared to play competitively. He said his action was in response to research suggesting that the risk of sudden cardiac death in Division I basketball players was about one in 5,200 per year, much higher than previously thought.

headline: Afghan Police Officer Suspected of Helping Taliban Kill 10 Comrades
keywords: ['Poisoning and Poisons', 'Attacks on Police', 'Terrorism', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The officer escaped with the militants in the second insider attack on the police in the southern province of Oruzgan in less than two weeks, an official said.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Ten police officers in the southern Afghan province of Oruzgan were poisoned by a rogue colleague and shot in the head by Taliban fighters the officer was working with, the second insider attack on the police in the province in less than two weeks, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Evangelical Gamble
abstract: The candidate’s strategy to win the White House depends on turning out millions of new religious voters.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 13, 2013, one year after his son was elected to the United States Senate, the pastor Rafael Cruz delivered a speech at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va. The topic — ‘‘What does the Bible say about why Christians need to be involved in the political arena?’’ — was one of his favorites, and notably appropriate for a school founded by Jerry Falwell, who also founded Moral Majority, the once-powerful political action committee. Over the course of a 30-minute speech that touched on everything from the need for school prayer to the similarities between President Obama’s Washington and Fidel Castro’s Havana, the question of why slowly gave way to the question of who. The pastor concluded by telling his audience, ‘‘God is saying to you: ‘Vote for righteous people.’ ’’

headline: In Race for FIFA President, Two Front-Runners and Many Possibilities
abstract: With a month to go before the election, plenty of speculation remains about voting support, back-room deals and campaigning tactics.
lead_paragraph: The election to select the next president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, is a month away. On Feb. 26, a special — the official word is extraordinary — congress of FIFA’s 209 member associations will be held in Zurich, and the successor to the now-suspended Sepp Blatter will be chosen. While some of the five official candidates have trumpeted commitments recently, plenty of speculation remains about voting support, back-room deals and campaigning tactics. Through interviews with federation officials and people connected to the candidates, all of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity, here is a look at the state of the race with a month to go:

headline: Free the Nipple?

Trump or Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: The Wreck of Amtrak 188
abstract: What caused the worst American rail disaster in decades?
lead_paragraph: From 30th Street Station, the train glided northwest out of Philadelphia, tracing the arc of the freeway. Near the old Schuylkill River Bridge, it jogged right, gathering speed, bound for the New Jersey border. Had you been standing anywhere near the tracks, you would have heard Amtrak 188 before you saw it, in the hum of the rail bed and the metallic shiver of the electricity in the overhead catenary wires. And then you would have felt it, in the vibration of the earth: the combined weight of a 98-ton locomotive and seven 50-ton cars, carrying a total of 258 people, eight of them employees.

headline: Working, and Assimilating, on New York Farms
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Dairy Products']
abstract: Twenty-three Bhutanese refugees have taken part in a state program, learning to be milkers at a state college and then getting jobs on local farms in Western New York.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three Bhutanese refugees have taken part in a state program, learning to be milkers at a state college and then getting jobs on local farms in Western New York.

headline: From Bhutan to New York’s Dairy Heartland
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Dairy Products', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A state training program has connected about two dozen Bhutanese refugees who wanted familiar agrarian jobs with farms that needed labor to fuel the yogurt boom in western New York.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, N.Y. — Purna Gurung and Hem Gurung stood in dung-slopped boots and rubber gloves, the heady perfume of wet cow, raw milk and manure permeating the room. They washed down the dirty stalls in the rotary milking parlor at Noblehurst Farms in western New York, some 7,500 miles from their birthplace in Bhutan.

headline: The Fight to Free the Nipple
abstract: An outdoor book club in Brooklyn garners stares and glares in its literal support of the Free the Nipple movement.
lead_paragraph: On a warm fall day, members of a literary group gathered in Prospect Park to soak in the sun and snack on chocolate pretzels. Most book clubs in a park in Brooklyn wouldn’t cause much of a stir, but as the mostly female group read, men gawked and children stared. Police officers were called to the scene. The members of the Outdoor Co-ed Topless Pulp Fiction Appreciation Society are used to such attention. They are part of a larger movement called Free the Nipple, and see themselves as proponents of gender equality.

headline: Guo Pei, Creator of Rihanna’s Met Gala Gown, Is Ready for Paris
abstract: The Beijing-based designer will make her debut on the couture calendar on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Until nine months ago, Guo Pei was a Chinese haute couturière known by millions in the East yet virtually unheard-of in the West. That all changed last May when the pop star Rihanna wore one of Ms. Guo’s designs to the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute gala in New York, after finding her work on the Internet. The look in question, a 55-pound canary-yellow fur-trimmed gown and cape, took seamstresses 50,000 hours and more than two years to make and landed on the cover of American Vogue — and Ms. Guo on the haute couture schedule in Paris.

headline: In Toronto Cafes, Board Games Rule
abstract: Spaces for playing table-top games, with drinks and snacks, are ubiquitous in Toronto, making geek culture more mainstream and promoting conviviality.
lead_paragraph: Even on a sunny afternoon at Snakes & Lattes Annex,  many Torontonians didn’t mind acting like kids inside. A few months ago, an elderly man traded pawn moves with a school-age girl. A cluster of millennials dug into the German-style strategy classic Carcassonne. Up front, where board games are sold, an Ottawa entrepreneur held a stack of boxes under one arm as he consulted Steve Tassie, one of the cafe’s game-teaching gurus, on what to stock in his own board-game cafe.

headline: How ‘-Phobic’ Became a Weapon in the Identity Wars
abstract: The suffix has become a way to call bigotry a disease — and to antagonize ideological opponents.
lead_paragraph: It started, innocently enough, at Hooters. A waitress who goes by Zola got to talking with a diner named Jessica. The two bonded over a shared romantic philosophy (each had a ‘‘sugar daddy’’ at home) and career focus (each moonlighted as an exotic dancer), and when Jessica invited Zola on a road trip to Florida to strip at some local clubs, Zola strapped in. Little did Zola know, she was hurtling toward the center of a backwater psychodrama in which she would face off against a series of pimps, johns, kidnappers, one very weepy white boy and Jessica herself, who had pulled her new friend into this nonconsensual weekend tour of the underground sex trade.

lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Little daylight sits between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas in Iowa, according to a new poll that shows the two presidential candidates essentially deadlocked less than a week before Republicans head to the caucuses.

headline: 1916: Spain to Intern German Troops
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Spain plans to intern German troops in Guinea in 1916.
lead_paragraph: The British successes in Cameroon are likely to be of indirect consequence to this country. In December last the Spanish Government, wishing to prevent any possible breach of Spain’s neutrality, entered into correspondence with the German, French and British Governments. Even at that time it appeared evident that the Germans would eventually be defeated in Cameroon, and Spain insisted upon a German assurance that, should the German troops be forced to take refuge in Spanish territory at Guinea, they would consent to be disarmed and interned. After lengthy negotiations, Germany reluctantly gave this assurance, with a rider to the effect that a German defeat was ‘‘impossible.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1916

headline: Netanyahu Chides Ban Ki-moon for Settlement Remarks

lead_paragraph: Tom Lubbock, the chief art critic for the English newspaper The Independent, had alert blue eyes, a big laugh and terrible teeth. He was said to be a world-class mimic. His beard, a colleague recalled, “gave him the air of a 19th-century Russian anarchist.” People liked to be around him.

headline: Undoing Years of Progress in Turkey
abstract: The country’s war on the Kurds is destroying culture and heritage, and sabotaging a newly revived pluralism.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Entire towns and districts are under siege. Tanks ram through narrow alleys closed off by barricades and trenches. Residents are trapped indoors for weeks because of curfews. Those who venture outside risk sniper fire. Their bodies lie on the streets for days before they can be collected. Bullets fly in through windows and buildings collapse under shelling, killing those seeking shelter at home.

headline: 1941: Nazi Flyer Escapes Canada
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Nazi pilot arrives in New York after his escape from a Canadian prison train in 1941.
lead_paragraph: A garrulous young German aviator with taped ears and an exuberant grin arrived in Grand Central Terminal early yesterday, eager to tell the world how he escaped from a Canadian prison train. Baron Franz von Werra found no time for conversation, however. A brusque German consular attache shouldered his way down platform 32 when the train from Ogdensburg pulled in at 6:45 a.m. and collared the twenty-six-year-old pursuit pilot as soon as he alighted. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1941

headline: When ‘Made in Israel’ Is a Human Rights Abuse
keywords: ['Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Tucked into a piece of legislation are a few words that will change how American officials treat Israeli settlements in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Just before Christmas, Ron Dermer, Israel’s ambassador to the United States, sent the White House a box of holiday gifts with a pointed political message. Inside were items (body lotion, halvah, olive oil) produced in Jewish settlements in the West Bank. Or rather, as Mr. Dermer put it in an accompanying letter, in Judea and Samaria — the term used by religious nationalists who see the settlements as no less a part of Israel than the Galilee or Tel Aviv.

headline: Super Bowl Spotlight on Santa Clara Reveals How It Has Changed
abstract: A reporter recalls how the modest town where she grew up differed from the high-priced city that will host Super Bowl 50 on Feb. 7.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Santa Clara hosting Super Bowl 50 is a miracle along the lines of the Catch. Before the 49ers moved their practice center here in 1988, it would have been hard to fathom the N.F.L. champion being crowned here, even for someone with an imagination like mine, which grew as wild as the cottontail plants along the Guadalupe River trail.

headline: ‘Antibirth,’ Natasha Lyonne and Chloë Sevigny’s Sundance Reunion
abstract: The actresses discuss their film, directed by Danny Perez, which aims for cult horror territory.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — There was a time when Natasha Lyonne and Chloë Sevigny personified the Sundance circus. It was 2003, and the festival was becoming more of a celebrity party zone than a film showcase. The film that brought the two gregarious actresses to Sundance that year was even called “Party Monster.”

headline: Activist Investors May Have Met Their Match: A Down Market
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Activist hedge funds invest in troubled companies, push for change and make millions in profits, but when the market declines, those risky bets tumble.

headline: ‘In a Different Key: The Story of Autism,’ by John Donvan and Caren Zucker
abstract: How autism came to be viewed not as an exotic disorder but as part of the human condition.
lead_paragraph: Through history, the commandment to act with empathy has been more honored in the breach than in the observance. In their new book, John Donvan and Caren Zucker chart America’s path to recognizing autism as part of the human condition, making a case that the arts as well as advocacy have been central to the process. The authors come from the world of television news — Donvan is a correspondent for ABC, and Zucker is a journalist and producer — and their book is crafted like a tightly edited news special: The prose is vivid, the tempo rapid and the perspective intimate, as if each character has been filmed with a hand-held camera. They depict history through biography, recounting the stories of individuals with autism and their families, physicians and psychologists — focusing on those who challenged traditional concepts of cognitive and behavioral debility and led the way to broader acceptance of autism.

headline: Argentina and Aramco Are Deals for Difficult Times
abstract: Talk of two potential big transactions dominated in Davos. Given the world’s parlous state, there are reasons to hope that both deals are made.
lead_paragraph: Two big deals dominated the agenda in Davos, Switzerland, last week: Argentina’s negotiations with holdout creditors and Saudi Arabia’s potential sale of a piece of its national energy leviathan, Saudi Aramco.

headline: Danish Law Requires Asylum Seekers to Hand Over Valuables
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']

The move underscored an anti-immigration backlash that has prompted several European countries to seek ways to discourage migrants from entering.

headline: Poké, a Hawaiian Specialty, Emerges in Chelsea
abstract: Also, Alain Coumont opens Le Botaniste, a vegetarian wine bar, on the Upper East Side, and Claus Meyer is presenting a pop-up bakery in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Wisefish Poké Not that restaurants are any more reliable than finance, but Drew Crane and Bryan Cowan have fled the world of money management to bring their passion for poké (poh-kay), the Hawaiian specialty they encountered in the islands, to New York. “We love poké and saw that it has exploded on the West Coast,” Mr. Crane said. “We want to make it acceptable here.” (Actually, New York now has a number of poké options.) The dish is simple: raw fish, often tuna, diced in a bowl with rice, garnishes and dressings. And it is well suited to “fast casual” dining; bowls, in three sizes, are assembled at a counter according to set combinations or the customer’s choice of ingredients: 263 West 19th Street, 212-367-7653, wisefishpoke.com.

headline: How to Get Five Planets Into a Single Photograph
abstract: The trickiest aspect of capturing Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn in the same image is knowing where to look.

The rare celestial performance is set to repeat every morning until late February, creating stellar photo ops for early morning risers.

headline: Don’t Distract Me
abstract: Is productivity a method for freeing up more time to do what we want or a virtue to be pursued for its own sake?
lead_paragraph: In 1893, Grover Cleveland’s doctor peered into the president’s mouth and discovered a tumor. He deemed it a “bad-looking tenant” and recommended immediate surgical removal. I’m reminded of this every time I spot my iPhone on my desk or bedside table, or hurtling around in my purse. The iPhone is a bad tenant: It makes disturbing noises, it keeps me up at night, it devours my attention, it costs me dearly. It should be banished from my life, yet I do not have the courage to evict it.

He was 94, having outlived by about 34 years an erroneous report of his death that made him a cult figure.

In the show notes, they described the collection’s shapes: “Volumes are freestyle, the Bar jacket changes appearance depending on whether it is worn closed or loose; the shoulder is sensual, bare.” On the above image, we take a closer look at the making of one Dior haute couture look.

headline: 'X-Files' Ratings Stay Strong
abstract: The second episode was Monday night’s highest-rated network series in the 18-to-49 year old demographic.
lead_paragraph: Fox’s revival of “The X-Files” has come crashing out of the gates with some big ratings. For its premiere Sunday night, it drew 16.2 million viewers, following Fox’s broadcast of the NFC Championship Game. On Monday night, the second episode attracted an audience of 9.7 million viewers. It also drew a 3.2 rating in the 18-to-49 year old demographic important to advertisers, which was the highest rating in that bracket on network television for the night.

abstract: The production of August Wilson’s play, at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, tells the story of an African-American family in 1936.

headline: At Dior, a (Surprise) Matte Red Lip
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Couture Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Couture (Fashion)']
abstract: The makeup director Peter Philips put a few models in bright lipsticks — a nod to Christian Dior’s “coup de Trafalgar.”
lead_paragraph: There wasn’t a single red lip on Christian Dior’s spring 2016 couture runway — which was presented yesterday in Paris — until well into the show. After a sea of models with nude lips, the makeup director Peter Philips sent out the vibrant beauty look, which was inspired by the house’s founder. “Christian Dior had this idea: Halfway through the show when people were getting bored, he’d do a surprise — and quite often it was a red dress that suddenly came out of nowhere,” Philips said, referring to what has come to be known as the “coup de Trafalgar.” He lined a handful of models’ lips with a Dior lip pencil in Rouge Royale before painting them with Diorific lipstick in Fabuleuse. To get the same soft edges, another classic trick: gently blot.

headline: Judge Approves Settlement in Head Injuries Suit Against N.C.A.A.
abstract: The agreement does not contain cash settlements for the plaintiffs in the proposed class-action suit, but mandates a new national protocol for head injuries.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge granted initial approval of a settlement Tuesday between the N.C.A.A. and a group of athletes who sued the association over its handling of head injuries. The agreement, which still needs N.C.A.A. approval, does not contain cash settlements for the plaintiffs in the proposed class-action suit, but mandates a new national protocol for head injuries sustained by players.

headline: Japanese End Drought in Sumo Wrestling, Their National Sport
abstract: Kotoshogiku won a top-level tournament in Tokyo over the weekend, the first for a Japanese sumo wrestler in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: In Tokyo on Sunday, the sumo wrestler Kotoshogiku won the first of the year’s six top-level tournaments. The result was big news because of his nationality: Japanese.

headline: Apple Says Sales of iPhones Have Slowed
abstract: The company’s quarterly revenue fell short of Wall Street forecasts, and it issued a disappointing forecast for the current period.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The iPhone fueled Apple’s ascendance into the world’s most valuable company. But even iPhone sales have their limits.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
abstract: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Dangers for Female Prison Guards
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Workplace Environment', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: An investigative video shows that female correctional officers around the country face many threats in the workplace, including at the hands of their co-workers.
lead_paragraph: An investigative video shows that female correctional officers around the country face many threats in the workplace, including at the hands of their co-workers.

headline: Harassment and Attacks From Fellow Officers in U.S. Prisons
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Female officers regularly face sexual harassment by colleagues and superiors, and a fear of retaliation stops many from reporting incidents.
lead_paragraph: In America’s hidden world of prisons and jails, officers are unarmed and outnumbered by inmates: Their peers are their only protection.

headline: Jan. 26, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Indonesia, Paris and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Indonesia, Paris and South Africa.

headline: Sri Lanka Destroys Illegal Elephant Tusks
abstract: Officials crushed 1.5 tons of ivory, making Sri Lanka the first South Asian nation to publicly destroy ivory obtained through elephant poaching.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — A group of saffron-robed monks chanted as officials crushed more than 300 elephant tusks in a seaside ceremony on Tuesday, as the new government of President Maithripala Sirisena sought to differentiate itself from its predecessor by sending a powerful message of intolerance for elephant poaching.

headline: Familiar Faces Lend Star Power to Video Game Voices
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Voice and Speech', 'Movies', 'Television', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: The growing popularity of this industry has given stars like Mark Hamill creative ways to reach new fans.
lead_paragraph: To “Star Wars” fans he has been the face of one of the most beloved characters in film, Luke Skywalker. To video-game players, though, Mark Hamill is the unmistakable voice of the Joker in Batman: Arkham Asylum and its sequels.

headline: Face in the Crowd: Iggy Azalea at Armani
abstract: The Australian rapper explains her love for Armani and for Paris.
lead_paragraph: The Australian rapper Iggy Azalea, known for her singles including “Fancy” and “Goddess,” held court in the front row of the Armani Privé show in Paris Tuesday next to the actresses Charlotte Rampling and Juliette Binoche.

headline: Touring the Ruins of St. Peter’s Seminary in Scotland
abstract: The ruins of the modernist St. Peter’s Seminary in Scotland will open for atmospheric tours as part of an architecture tour in March.
lead_paragraph: A night tour of one of Scotland’s most famous modern ruins, St. Peter’s Seminary, above, will open the country’s first Festival of Architecture. For the ticketed event, called Hinterland, held March 18 to 27, audiences will walk through woodlands to explore the derelict buildings, backed by moving light installations and a specially commissioned recorded choral work performed by St. Salvator’s Chapel Choir of the University of St. Andrews. Built 50 years ago, the structure was heralded as a modernist masterpiece of glass and concrete, but fell into disrepair after being deconsecrated in 1980. A planned restoration will transform it into an arts facility.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Makes New York City’s Fiscal Case to a Wary Legislature
abstract: The mayor asked for state funding for city public housing and homelessness prevention programs, while some lawmakers argued that the city should receive less help from Albany.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Mayor Bill de Blasio arrived here on Tuesday with a substantial wish list for the State Legislature, urging lawmakers to deliver money for several of New York City’s needs, including public housing, infrastructure and health care.

headline: MoMA Trims Back Some Features of Its Planned Renovation
abstract: Construction begins next month on the project, which will add 50,000 square feet of new exhibition space and reduce congestion in the museum’s lobbies at a cost estimated at up to $400 million.
lead_paragraph: Gone is the “Art Bay,” with a glass garage-like door that would have allowed visitors to enter galleries straight from the street.

headline: The Panettone That Big Chefs Can’t Get Enough of
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', "Valentine's Day", 'Chefs', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: Roy Shvartzapel’s holiday breads were so good that his discerning devotees wouldn’t change a thing. But now he has a Valentine’s Day version.
lead_paragraph: It’s beginning to look a lot like — Valentine’s Day? Barely a month after launching his virtual luxury bakery From Roy with two Christmas panettones — one scented with candied orange and raisins, the other a less traditional chocolate-streaked loaf — the pastry chef Roy Shvartzapel has unveiled a third in honor of the holiday at his workshop in Los Gatos, Calif. The news is cause for celebration among Shvartzapel’s discerning devotees — many of the country’s most respected chefs among them. His domed wonders are unworldly in their featherweight texture: the tender crumb dissolves on your tongue, almost like cotton candy, were cotton candy spun from butter. They seem paradoxically rich and ethereal at the same time.

headline: Migrant Influx in Germany Raises Fears of Anti-Semitism
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Apprehension is growing over the arrival of thousands of Muslims raised in countries where anti-Semitism and anti-Israeli sentiment are virulent.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — These days, all talk here is of the ramifications of taking in more than one million asylum seekers who arrived over the past year.

headline: Octo Telematics, Whose Technology Monitors Driving, Prepares I.P.O.
abstract: Octo Telematics of Italy, whose devices help auto insurers set rates, is preparing its United States offering at a difficult time for market debuts.
lead_paragraph: In a market that has scared off potential initial public offerings of stock, one company whose purpose is to manage risk is taking steps toward a market debut.

headline: A Pair of Cousins Who Make Furniture, and Sometimes Partner With Daft Punk
abstract: Cédric and Nicolas Hervet opened Hervet Manufacturier on Thursday, and the musician Thomas Bangalter documented the process.
lead_paragraph: The cousins Cédric and Nicolas Hervet first partnered on a construction project as teenagers; their fathers, who are brothers, both had workshops filled with machinery that the boys used in an attempt to recreate the hoverboard they’d seen in “Back to the Future II.” “We took the entire thing seriously, sketching and welding an aluminum box that was filled with helium,” Nicolas says. “Our grandfather ran over the prototype with his car. Of course, in the end, it didn’t work anyway.”

headline: Egyptian Satirist Threatened for Giving Police Condom Balloons
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Hoaxes and Pranks']
abstract: Egypt’s police might want to beware of satirists bearing gifts, after a comedian managed to smuggle some dissent into Tahrir Square on Monday.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian comedian who works as a correspondent for a popular satirical television program could be in legal trouble for handing balloons made of inflated condoms to police officers in Tahrir Square on Monday, the fifth anniversary of the uprising against former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Bernie Sanders Won’t Attack Hillary Clinton, but He’ll Point Out Her Ties to Wall Street
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders reiterated his commitment to not personally attack Hillary Clinton but said that he would continue to point out her ties to big commercial banks.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont reiterated his commitment Tuesday to not personally attack Hillary Clinton but said that he would continue to point out her ties to big commercial banks.

headline: Slush Puddles, the Scourge of New York Walkers
abstract: When snow falls, the streets get prompt attention, except where pedestrians cross. In the “most walkable large city in America,” why is that so?
lead_paragraph: THE day after it stopped snowing in New York City last weekend, I took my daughter sledding in Prospect Park. Despite the near record blizzard, things were, remarkably, back to normal in my part of Brooklyn — thanks to stalwart efforts by city employees. The streets were plowed and salted to glistening blackness. The subway arrived seconds after we did. On Prospect Park’s circular drive, cyclists serenely spun past.

headline: A Woman on the $10 Bill, and Everyone Has 2 Cents to Put In
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Millions have weighed in with suggestions, reflections on the worth of women and views on the relative merits of Alexander Hamilton and Andrew Jackson.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew was not aware that Americans have strong opinions about what, and who, is in their wallets, he certainly is now.

headline: Florida Beachgoers Cling to a Right to Make the Sand Their Driveway
abstract: It’s a seaside tailgating tradition, one that’s been slowly whittled by Daytona Beach laws. Now, leaders want to further curtail it in favor of development.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — On sunny weekends, when busy schedules yield to bygone notions of leisure, Greg Gimbert and his 9-year-old son jump into a silver sport utility vehicle packed with a pop-up canopy, a cooler, chairs, surfboards and boogie boards and drive a short distance to the beach, where Mr. Gimbert parks on the sand and sets up his gear.

headline: With Punch, Blake Griffin Breaks Hand and Will Miss Time
abstract: The five-time All-Star got into an argument with the Clippers’ assistant equipment manager on Saturday at a restaurant during a team road trip, according to an ESPN report.
lead_paragraph: Blake Griffin of the Los Angeles Clippers was involved in a physical altercation Saturday in Toronto that left him with a broken right hand, which could keep him out of action for a month or more.

headline: Grandson of Ayatollah Khomeini Is Excluded From Election Panel
abstract: The grandson, Hassan Khomeini, is a Shiite Muslim cleric of a lower rank than his famous grandfather and is associated with the reformist faction in Iran.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A grandson of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the first supreme leader of the Islamic Republic of Iran, has been barred from helping to choose the next one, according to a family member’s posts on Instagram.

headline: The Street Meets Luxury at Hermès, Berluti and Dior Homme
keywords: ['Paris Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: A note to those fashion designers who play the high-low game: Don’t forget the irony.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than half of the 48 looks Véronique Nichanian showed for her fall 2016 Hermès men’s wear collection — staged against the inky-blue night sky of Paris as seen through the glass-walled Maison de la Radio — were worn with sneakers in Hermès orange. The high-end trainers are a new introduction at the luxury leather-goods house founded as a saddlery to the French carriage trade.

headline: At Giambattista Valli, a Garden of Earthly Delights
abstract: For his spring/summer 2016 haute couture presentation, the designer took inspiration from the gardens of Paris.
lead_paragraph: For his spring/summer 2016 haute couture presentation, the designer took inspiration from the gardens of Paris.

headline: Vindication for Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Now that two members of an anti-abortion group have been indicted, politicians should back away.
lead_paragraph: One after the other, investigations of Planned Parenthood prompted by hidden-camera videos released last summer have found no evidence of wrongdoing. On Monday, a grand jury in Harris County, Tex., went a step further. Though it was convened to investigate Planned Parenthood, it indicted two members of the group that made the videos instead.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'First Ladies (US)']
abstract: Footage from Mrs. Clinton’s career — from Arkansas to the Senate to the State Department — is used to show her record on children and families.
lead_paragraph: The Hillary Clinton campaign is using four decades worth of footage to show her extended record on families and children in a new 60-second spot running in Iowa.

headline: A Conversation With Eric S. Margules
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: Mr. Margules, 56, is founder, president and chief of Margules Properties, a New York-based company that specializes in residential rental buildings.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Margules, 56, is the founder, president and chief executive of Margules Properties, a New York-based company that specializes in residential rental buildings, many of which are rent-stabilized or rent-controlled walk-ups. He founded the company in 1992.

headline: Lead in Ohio Villages’ Water Went Uncurbed for Months, State Says
keywords: ['Lead', 'Water', 'Falsification of Data', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Officials took action against the operator of the water treatment plant in Sebring, who they said delayed raising an alarm and might have falsified documents.
lead_paragraph: Lead contamination in tap water went unchecked for months in a cluster of Ohio villages, state officials said Tuesday, as a local official waited too long to raise an alarm, caused more delays with shoddy paperwork, failed to do required testing and might have even falsified documents on water quality.

headline: Some Officers Bristle at Recall of Military Equipment
keywords: ['Police', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'September 11 (2001)', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: A federal order will deprive local authorities of critical tools in an age of heightened fears about terrorism and mass shootings, some law enforcement leaders say.
lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — On the day a heavily armed couple fatally shot 14 people and wounded more than 20 others in San Bernardino, Calif., last month, Michael J. Bouchard, a sheriff here in the Detroit area, got an order to return his department’s 14-ton armored personnel carrier to the federal government.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Nominating Obama to the Supreme Court: ‘Great Idea’
abstract: While not actually saying she would name Mr. Obama to the Supreme Court, Mrs. Clinton didn’t dismiss the idea either, saying “I love that.”
lead_paragraph: DECORAH, Iowa – Hillary Clinton is sometimes asked what kind of people she would want to put on the Supreme Court – but not who. During a campaign event here in northeast Iowa on Tuesday, one attendee had a nominee in mind: President Obama. Would she name him?

headline: Former Morgan Stanley Banker to Revive Phibro Name
keywords: ['Commodities', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Simon Greenshields, the former co-head of Morgan Stanley’s commodities business, has acquired the name and assets of the commodities trading firm.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices may be depressed, but they have not stopped the longtime commodities trader Phibro from being resurrected.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Damon Darlin, Kate Phillips and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: C.T.E. Is Found in an Ex-Giant Tyler Sash, Who Died at 27
abstract: Tyler Sash, who played on the 2012 Super Bowl team, was found dead in September after an accidental overdose of pain medication. His family said his behavior had become increasingly erratic.
lead_paragraph: When the former Giants safety Tyler Sash was found dead at age 27 of an accidental overdose of pain medications at his Iowa home on Sept. 8, his grieving family remained consumed by a host of unanswered questions about the final, perplexing years of Sash’s life.
