keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Six Cleveland Officers Fired for Role in Killing of Couple
abstract: The discipline against the officers concluded a lengthy series of investigations into the police chase and gunfire that killed Timothy Russell and Malissa Williams.
lead_paragraph: Cleveland officials fired six police officers on Tuesday for their roles in a fatal 2012 pursuit in which 137 rounds were shot at a car with two unarmed black people.

headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign Says He’ll Skip Debate
abstract: Moments after Fox News announced the lineup for Thursday’s Republican debate, Donald J. Trump said Tuesday it is pretty “irrevocable” that he will skip the event, which takes place just days before the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Moments after Fox News announced the lineup for Thursday’s Republican debate, Donald J. Trump said Tuesday that it was pretty “irrevocable” that he would skip the event, which takes place just days before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Feeling South Africa’s Beat in Pantsula
abstract: Pantsula, a dance that is more like a way of life, captivated Chris Saunders, who set out to document a subculture with roots in jazz and hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Pantsula, a dance that is more like a way of life, captivated Chris Saunders, who set out to document a subculture with roots in jazz and hip-hop.

headline: Suspect Is Charged in Milwaukee With Planning a Mass Shooting
abstract: The suspect, Samy Mohamed Hamzeh, 23, was charged with illegally buying a machine gun and a silencer to carry out the attack at a Masonic temple in the city.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors on Tuesday announced the arrest of a Milwaukee man who they said was planning a mass shooting at a Masonic temple in the city.

headline: Hundreds Vanishing in Egypt as Crackdown Widens, Activists Say
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Missing Persons', 'Detainees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Torture']
abstract: Many suspected of opposing the government have disappeared into secretive detention centers for weeks, rights groups said, and some have later turned up dead.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After the security forces raided the home of Islam Khalil, a 26-year-old salesman, last summer, he seemed to vanish without a trace.

headline: Broadway Box Office Feels Storm’s Sting
abstract: Broadway’s box-office grosses dropped by a bruising 39 percent last week, the result of a blizzard that prompted the cancellation of all Saturday matinee and evening performances.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s box-office grosses dropped by a bruising 39 percent last week, the result of a blizzard that prompted the cancellation of all Saturday matinee and evening performances.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign Says He Would Sit Out Unsanctioned Debate
abstract: His campaign manager said Mr. Sanders did not want to participate in an unsanctioned debate Feb. 4 in New Hampshire because he could risk being denied participation in future debates.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Weaver, the campaign manager for Senator Bernie Sanders, said on Tuesday evening that Mr. Sanders did not want to participate in an unsanctioned debate next month because he could risk being denied participation in future debates.

headline: Rat Who Escaped Peril and Made It on Broadway Dies in a Fall
abstract: Rose, a white rat who survived a roadside dumping and poison, died at home, just four days after she started acting in “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time.”
lead_paragraph: Rose, a white rat who escaped poison and roadside peril for a life in the theater, died in a fall at home on Monday night, just four days after she started acting in a Broadway hit.

headline: Still Buried in Baltimore, Some Dig Their Own Path
abstract: Though Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake said the city was clearing its 5,000 miles of road lanes as fast as possible, she and other officials could not say when most streets would be plowed.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — None of those snowplows that Baltimore leaders keep talking about ever made it to the 1200 block of West 37th Street in Hampden, a middle-class rowhouse community northwest of downtown.

headline: A Charged Blend of Law and Politics in a Texas Planned Parenthood Case
abstract: Devon Anderson, the Harris County, Tex., prosecutor has tried to walk a line as a by-the-book lawyer and an outspoken Republican conservative.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A deputy had been shot and killed at a suburban gas station here the night before in an unprovoked attack. The Harris County district attorney, Devon Anderson, stood that Saturday afternoon in August next to the sheriff, on the verge of tears.

headline: Ted Cruz and Allies Work to Halt Donald Trump’s Gains
abstract: The Texas senator’s campaign is being tested as never before as Mr. Trump has pulled ahead in polls in Iowa, and it is showing signs of strain.
lead_paragraph: OTTUMWA, Iowa — On the campaign trail, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas assures Iowa Republicans that they can finally ignore the barrage of political attack ads on television.

headline: Zika Testing Is Urged for Some Newborns
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Babies and Infants', 'Viruses', 'Mosquitoes', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Birth Defects', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: A range of birth defects, not just small heads, may be linked to infection with the virus, federal health officials said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Newborns should be tested for infection with the Zika virus if their mothers have visited or lived in any country experiencing an outbreak and if the mothers’ own tests are positive or inconclusive, federal health officials said Tuesday.

headline: Indictment Deals Blow to G.O.P. Over Planned Parenthood Battle
abstract: A grand jury’s indictment of two abortion opponents who recorded Planned Parenthood officials is the latest sign that a campaign against the group has run into trouble.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A grand jury’s indictment on Monday of two abortion opponents who covertly recorded Planned Parenthood officials is the latest, most startling sign that a Republican campaign against the group has run into trouble.

headline: Bill de Blasio Set to Campaign for Hillary Clinton in Iowa
abstract: Mayor de Blasio will head to Iowa this weekend in support of Mrs. Clinton in the final days of her close race against Senator Bernie Sanders in the state’s presidential caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio will fly to Iowa this weekend to campaign for Hillary Clinton, a fellow Democrat and his former boss, in the final days of her close race against Senator Bernie Sanders in the state’s presidential caucuses.

headline: How Iran Rejoined the World’s Economy in Just 10 Days
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani is visiting Europe, meeting the pope, inking business deals and signaling that Iran is again engaging with the world.
lead_paragraph: What a difference 10 days make.

headline: Donald Trump Conducts Rare News Conference, and It Turns Testy
abstract: The candidate excoriated a reporter who was trying to ask him about his previous pro-abortion rights stance at a raucous news conference before a campaign event.
lead_paragraph: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Donald J. Trump on Tuesday night devoured another in the dwindling news cycles before the Iowa caucuses, as he excoriated a reporter for several minutes who was trying to ask him about his previous pro-abortion rights stance at a raucous news conference before a campaign event.

headline: Thornton Dial, Outsider Artist Whose Work Told of Black Life, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Dial was a self-taught artist whose paintings and assemblages fashioned from scavenged materials found their way to the permanent collections of major museums.
lead_paragraph: Thornton Dial, a self-taught artist whose paintings and assemblages fashioned from scavenged materials told the story of black struggle in the South and found their way to the permanent collections of major museums, died on Monday at his home in McCalla, Ala. He was 87.

headline: What Happened to Jane Mayer When She Wrote About the Koch Brothers
abstract: Ms. Mayer, a New Yorker writer and author of the new book “Dark Money,” says she was falsely accused of plagiarism and investigated by the firm of Howard Safir, ex-New York police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Out of the blue in the fall of 2010, a blogger asked Jane Mayer, a writer with The New Yorker, how she felt about the private investigator who was digging into her background. Ms. Mayer thought the idea was a joke, she said this week. At a Christmas party a few months later, she ran into a former reporter who had been asked about helping with an investigation into another reporter on behalf of two conservative billionaires.

headline: Several Days Later, Newark Is Still Feeling Blizzard’s Effects
abstract: With schools closed for a second day and many side streets still clogged with snow, Newark residents expressed frustration on Tuesday with the slow place of recovery from the weekend storm.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Three days after a sprawling blizzard hit the East Coast, officials here said on Tuesday that they had made progress in restoring life to normal.

headline: Bernie Sanders and President Obama to Meet in Oval Office Wednesday
abstract: The president, who has spoken highly of Hillary Clinton recently, will meet with Senator Bernie Sanders, whom he does not have much of a relationship with.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will meet in the Oval Office on Wednesday with Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, offering presidential face-time just days before voting in the presidential campaign begins next week, White House officials said Tuesday evening.

headline: Who Needs Megyn Kelly? Ted Cruz Says He’ll Debate Donald Trump One on One
abstract: Jumping on the news that Donald Trump was sitting out Thursday night’s debate, Senator Ted Cruz playfully challenged Mr. Trump to a two-man showdown.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Iowa — Seeking to insert himself into the latest Donald J. Trump-created campaign controversy, Senator Ted Cruz on Tuesday night challenged Mr. Trump to a “mano a mano” debate, suggesting that if the Republican front-runner was too frightened to face Fox News’s Megyn Kelly, the two candidates could face off without a moderator.

headline: Start Swimmin’
abstract: Adam G. Perl spins a new puzzle theme.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — A good protest song should be general enough to call for the perpetual need for societal change, but passionately specific enough to allow generations upon generations take it as their own anthem. There were many that came out of the turbulence of the 1960s, but Bob Dylan’s “THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN'” is probably the Platonic ideal of this genre.

headline: Former Twitter Executive Kevin Weil Is Expected to Join Instagram
abstract: Mr. Weil, Twitter’s former senior vice president for product, will become head of product for Instagram, one of Twitter’s biggest competitors.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Weil, a longtime Twitter executive, will soon join the photo-sharing service Instagram, according to two people familiar with the matter, joining the ranks of a company many consider one of Twitter’s main competitors.

headline: Police Testify on Housing Project’s Dangers at Officer’s Manslaughter Trial
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Two police officers, who responded to a radio call after Officer Peter Liang shot and killed a man in Brooklyn, gave testimony in Officer’s Liang’s trial.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn housing project where a police officer fatally shot an unarmed man, Akai Gurley, was notoriously dangerous, according to testimony drawn out on Tuesday by lawyers for the officer, Peter Liang.

headline: Albany Ethics Commission Adopts New Fund-Raising and Disclosure Rules
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'News and News Media', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: One rule is meant to restrict some campaign donations, and another widens the disclosure rules for public relations consultants who speak to journalists.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In its nearly five years in existence, the Joint Commission on Public Ethics has often battled a poor public image, a problem rooted in its odd voting rules and perceived lack of activity, something recently exemplified by its continuing six-month search for a new executive director.

headline: Ammon Bundy and 7 Oregon Protesters Held; LaVoy Finicum Is Reported Dead
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal Lands', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Mr. Bundy, the leader of an antigovernment group that occupied a federal wildlife refuge, was among those detained during a traffic stop, where shots were fired.
lead_paragraph: JOHN DAY, Ore. — Ammon Bundy, the leader of an armed seizing of a federal wildlife refuge in rural eastern Oregon, was arrested and one person was killed Tuesday afternoon in a traffic stop in rural Oregon, the F.B.I. and the Oregon State Police said.

headline: Bronx Mother Charged in Death of Infant Whose Body Was Left in Woods
abstract: Danielle Whyte pleaded not guilty of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide and her companion, Jose Feliciano, pleaded not guilty of murder and manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx mother whose conversation with a hospital worker led to the discovery of her 7-week-old son’s body north of New York City last month has been indicted on charges of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, prosecutors said.

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Allows Killing of Snowy Owls Near Kennedy Airport
keywords: ['Birds', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Owls', 'Animal Migration', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey could kill the birds when a plane and its passengers are endangered.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that airport officials had the authority to kill migratory birds that posed a threat to planes at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Thornton Dial (1928-2016)
abstract: Thornton Dial was a self-taught artist whose work from scavenged materials told the story of black struggle in the South.
lead_paragraph: Thornton Dial was a self-taught artist whose work from scavenged materials told the story of black struggle in the South.

headline: Psychic Who Bilked Man of More Than $550,000 Is Set Free
abstract: Priscilla Kelly Delmaro served eight months in jail for her crime, but her victim, in a letter, railed against the terms of her plea agreement.
lead_paragraph: A court officer removed the handcuffs that bound the thin wrists of the former fortuneteller, and she raised her hands to wipe away tears, about to leave the courtroom a free woman.

headline: Knoedler Gallery Director’s Lawyer Says Other Experts Were Duped by Fake Rothko
abstract: Ann Freedman and the Knoedler & Company gallery are being sued by Domenico and Eleanore De Sole, who paid $8.3 million in 2004 for what they thought was a Rothko work, “Untitled, 1956.”
lead_paragraph: The director of the Knoedler & Company gallery in Manhattan, which sold dozens of fakes as the work of modern masters, was not duplicitous, but duped by paintings so expertly forged that they also escaped detection by several prominent art experts, a lawyer for the director, Ann Freedman, told jurors in court on Tuesday.

headline: Without Carmelo Anthony, Knicks Dig In but Fade in Stretch Against Thunder
abstract: Although Anthony was ruled out about two hours before tipoff, and although Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook posted extraterrestrial totals, the Knicks hung in until overtime.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony had expressed a desire to renew acquaintances with Kevin Durant on Tuesday night. The Knicks, too, were cautiously optimistic that the soreness in Anthony’s left knee — his surgically repaired left knee — would dissipate enough to allow him to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.

headline: Angelique Kerber, the Higher Seed, Upsets Victoria Azarenka
abstract: After six straight losses to Azarenka, a former world No. 1, Kerber defeated her to advance to her third career major tournament semifinal.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The rankings suggest that Angelique Kerber’s 6-3, 7-5 victory over Victoria Azarenka in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open on Wednesday was not an upset. At No. 6 in the WTA’s world rankings, Kerber was 10 spots higher than Azarenka.

headline: Donald Trump, in Feud With Fox News, Shuns Debate
abstract: Mr. Trump and Fox News faced off again, this time over the anchor Megyn Kelly’s inclusion as moderator for Thursday’s debate.
lead_paragraph: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Donald J. Trump and Fox News, the candidate who has reordered the Republican presidential race and the cable network of choice for many of the party’s voters, stared each other down on Tuesday over his demand that the news anchor Megyn Kelly be dumped from moderating Thursday’s debate, the last before Monday’s caucuses.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | inerrancy
abstract: This word has appeared in one New York Times article in the past year.
lead_paragraph: inerrancy • \(ˌ)i-ˈner-ən(t)-se\ • noun

headline: Jets Lineman Avoids Jail
abstract: Sheldon Richardson will not be imprisoned for resisting arrest after a high-speed chase in his native Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Richardson will not go to jail for resisting arrest after a high-speed chase in his native Missouri, but he still faces a possible suspension from the N.F.L. for violating its personal-conduct policy. Richardson was sentenced to two years of probation and 100 hours of community service after he pleaded guilty in St. Charles County to reduced charges stemming from a July incident in which the police clocked him driving at 143 miles per hour.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday
abstract: Mike’s web of lies finally unravels in “Suits.” Child refugees talk about escaping war in Syria. And Jerry Seinfeld takes his weekly drive.
lead_paragraph: The end is near — or is it? Five seasons in, Mike’s web of lies finally unravels in “Suits.” Child refugees talk about escaping war in Syria. And Jerry Seinfeld takes his weekly drive.

headline: 7th-Ranked Xavier Hangs on to Top No. 10 Providence
abstract: The Musketeers improved to 18-2 over all and 6-2 in the Big East after staving off a rally by the Friars (17-4, 5-3), who had beaten No. 6 Villanova in their last game.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The Providence Friars played their 750th game at Dunkin’ Donuts Center on Tuesday night, a run dating to 1972, but it was the very first to feature two top-10 teams, the 10th-ranked Friars and No. 7 Xavier.

headline: John Jay Hooker Jr., Political Gadfly and Perennial Litigant, Dies at 85
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide']
abstract: Although Mr. Hooker repeatedly lost his races for elective office in Tennessee, he managed to advance a progressive agenda through his candidacies and as a plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: After John Jay Hooker Jr. learned he had metastatic melanoma in January 2015, he began the last crusade of his quixotic career. He persuaded a Tennessee legislator to introduce a bill granting what Mr. Hooker called the “ultimate civil right” by legalizing doctor-assisted suicide. Typically, he also sued the state.

headline: Corrections: January 27, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, January 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: ‘블랙박스 사고법’ 과 ‘실패:과학이 성공적인 이유’
abstract: 실수를 전화위복의 계기로 만드는 방법과 실패가 돌파구로 이어지는 방식에 대해 논한 두 권의 신간을 소개한다.
lead_paragraph: 지난 반세기 이상에 걸쳐 인지 편향에 대한 많은 사실을 밝혀왔음에도 불구하고, 노벨상을 받은 심리학자 대니얼 카너먼은 인간이 자신의 행동을 바꿀 수 있는 능력을 갖추고 있는가에 대해 매우 비관적이다. 2014년 <가디언>과의 인터뷰에서 카너먼은 심리학자인 스티븐 핑커 하버드대 교수에게 “인간의 본성에 타고난 결함이 있다는 가설은 인간이기에 지니고 있는 비극적인 면과 일맥상통하며, 인간으로 살아간다는 것은 곧 이 같은 비극을 안고 살아간다는 것을 뜻한다”고 말한 바 있다. 당시 핑커 교수는 카너만이 자신에게 미친 영향을 인정하면서도, 같은 자료로부터 180도 다른 주장을 끌어냈다. “인간은 교육, 제도, 계몽과 같이 우리의 한계를 극복할 수 있는 수단을 갖고 있다”는 것이 핑커의 의견이었다. 인간이 이성으로 저급한 본능을 억누를 수 있다는 핑커의 낙관주의는 2011년 저작 <우리 본성의 더 선한 천사들(The Better Angels of Our Nature)>의 기저에 깔린 주제이기도 하다.

lead_paragraph: Pantsula, a dance that is more like a way of life, captivated Chris Saunders, who set out to document a subculture with roots in jazz and hip-hop.

headline: Iowa Will Go Down to the Wire for Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, Poll Suggests
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders remain deadlocked in Iowa less than a week before the caucuses, according to a new poll that shows the first nominating contest going down to the wire.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont remain deadlocked in Iowa less than a week before the caucuses, according to a new poll that shows the first nominating contest going down to the wire.

headline: South Africa’s Pantsula Dancers Bring Life to the Streets
abstract: Pantsula, a South African dance that is more like a way of life, captivated Chris Saunders, who set out to document a subculture with roots in jazz and hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Pantsula isn’t just a dance, but a way of life in Johannesburg’s townships. Small surprise then, that for the South African photographer Chris Saunders, a two-month magazine assignment to document it led to a six-year journey through his homeland.

headline: Lyft Agrees to Settle Class-Action Lawsuit With California Drivers
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The ride-hailing service said it would pay $12.25 million but continue to categorize its drivers as independent contractors, not full-time employees.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, ride-hailing companies have fought with their drivers over the drivers’ employment status. Now, one of those companies has found a way to bury the hatchet.

headline: Friends and Refugees in Need
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A tidal wave of people threatens to overwhelm our top ally, the E.U.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Now in his last year in office, President Obama is in legacy mode. He has much to be proud of. But if he doesn’t want his achievements muddied by foreign policy, he’ll spend his last year redoubling his efforts to contain the Middle East refugee crisis before it goes from a giant humanitarian problem to a giant geostrategic problem that shatters America’s most important ally: the European Union.

headline: Henry Worsley and the Urge to Explore
abstract: The longing to test oneself against the extreme and the unknown seems as powerful as ever.
lead_paragraph: When asked why he sought to cross the Antarctic unassisted and unsupported — with no supply drops or help from dogs, sails or any other source — Henry Worsley would say it was to raise money to help wounded soldiers. It indeed was that, and his adventure raised more than 100,000 pounds (about $142,000) for that worthy cause. But like the great explorers Mr. Worsley so admired, the quest that took his life was far greater and far harder to define.

headline: Boom or Gloom?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Unemployment', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The deep divide between optimistic and pessimistic economists has profound implications for the next occupant of the White House.
lead_paragraph: Whether the winner of the 2016 presidential election emphasizes optimism or pessimism, he or she will face some sobering economic developments.

headline: Subprime Reasoning on Housing
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The bursting of the bubble did not cause the recession. The Fed did.
lead_paragraph: IT has become part of the accepted history of our time: The bursting of the housing bubble was the primary cause of a financial crisis, a sharp recession and prolonged slow growth. The story makes intuitive sense, since the economic crisis included a collapse in the prices of housing and related securities. The movie “The Big Short,” which is based on a book by Michael Lewis, takes this cause-and-effect relationship as a given.

headline: The Twinned Egos of Cruz and Trump
abstract: The Republican front-runners are quite the self-infatuated pair. What does that say about the future of politics?
lead_paragraph: OSCEOLA, Iowa — For a few minutes I wondered if I’d wandered into the wrong barn.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Pardon Problem
abstract: To function properly, the clemency process needs to be removed from the grasp of the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: The sudden resignation of the federal pardon attorney, Deborah Leff, an Obama appointee, is the latest evidence that until the clemency process is pried from the grip of the Justice Department, it will remain broken.

headline: The Ethics of a Child Pornography Sting
abstract: Should the F.B.I. have continued to operate a website to ensnare predators even though that allowed illicit images to be seen and spread?

headline: Britain’s Johanna Konta Credits Mind-Set for Her Rapid Rise
abstract: Australia-born Johanna Konta is “very happy, very pleased” to represent Britain and is the first British woman in a Grand Slam semifinal in 33 years.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The last Australian-born player in this year’s Australian Open main draw engendered no exuberant bursts of “Aussie, Aussie, Aussie, oy, oy oy” from the Rod Laver Arena crowd during her quarterfinal victory Wednesday. As much as the local populace yearned to stake its claim to that player, Johanna Konta, she is the Grand Slam title contender who got away.

headline: When the Hospital Is Not a Haven
abstract: Had I prolonged my Indian grandmother’s suffering with my stubborn belief in the power of medicine to fix things?
lead_paragraph: There were ants crawling on my grandmother’s feet in the hospital. My mother and I slapped towels at the insects, scoured the rusted metal legs of the bed, moved my unconscious grandmother’s limbs to search every wrinkle of the dingy sheets. The ants were a portent, I thought. This was all my fault. My grandmother was going to die in this filthy hospital, far from everything she knew and loved, because of me and my insistence on medical intervention.

headline: Scalping Tickets to the Doctor? Woman in Beijing Has Had Enough
abstract: A video of a woman denouncing those who resell hospital access for a profit was widely circulated online this week, inciting outrage among many.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ticket scalpers can be a headache in China, raising the prices of concerts, train trips and more. But no scalpers are more detested than those selling tickets for hospital visits. A video of a woman in Beijing denouncing the practice circulated widely this week, as many others shared their own experiences.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “These guys are so busy fighting one another that they’re only continuing to facilitate the rise of Trump and Cruz.”

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Donatella was not the only Versace to present a collection during the couture shows this week.

headline: 7 Days, 1,500 Miles in Namibia
abstract: A seven-day journey by four women through a surreal desert landscape yields awe-inspiring sights, and hard-won lessons (know how to change a flat).
lead_paragraph: I woke to the gentle prodding of a flight attendant asking me to raise my window shade for the landing in Windhoek. I complied, and was immediately assailed: a bolt of white fury forced my eyelids to contract in submission, never to open again. Or, at least, not until it was time to deplane.

headline: Siri, Alexa and Other Virtual Assistants Put to the Test
abstract: Virtual assistants from tech behemoths including Apple, Microsoft, Amazon and Google are graded on their abilities to actually be of assistance.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I asked Alexa earlier this week who was playing in the Super Bowl, she responded, somewhat monotonously, “Super Bowl 49’s winner is New England Patriots.”

headline: Discovery of Burial Ground Backs a Less Conventional Version of Harlem’s History
abstract: The find should help rewrite the history that portrays Harlem as a white enclave until the 20th century, when African-Americans began moving there in great numbers.
lead_paragraph: Harlem’s African roots are at last coming to light.

headline: Iranian Released in Prisoner Exchange Finds Fault With Its Handling
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Nader Modanlo, released by the United States this month in a prisoner exchange with Iran, was reluctant to accept the deal because it required him to abandon an appeal of his conviction.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a federal prison, the Iranian-American former aerospace executive felt optimistic after years of frustration and despondency. His lawyers had filed what they regarded as a strong appeal, and he had reason to believe that his 2013 conviction, on illicit business dealings with Iran, might soon be reversed.

headline: Bernie Sanders at a Crossroads: Attack Hillary Clinton or Stay Positive?
abstract: Mr. Sanders, who has prided himself on avoiding a negative campaign, is wrestling with whether to use a tougher line of ads, which some say may be his only path to win Iowa.
lead_paragraph: MASON CITY, Iowa — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and his top advisers returned to Iowa on Wednesday evening having confronted a decision that will have lasting consequences for his presidential campaign and his political image: whether to open a new, tougher line of advertising against his rival Hillary Clinton in the closing days of the race for Iowa.

headline: Southport, Conn.: Historic, With an Aristocratic Air
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The coastal enclave of Southport, part of the town of Fairfield, offers a rich array of 18th- and 19th-century architecture that reflects the area’s affluence during its heyday as a seaport.
lead_paragraph: The coastal enclave of Southport, Conn., is part of the town of Fairfield, but its identity is very much its own. More than 150 of its buildings, mainly houses, are protected within the Southport Historic District. The rich array of 18th- and 19th-century architecture, including many grand examples of Federal and Greek Revival styles, reflects the area’s affluence during its heyday as a seaport, and preserves the aristocratic air that still sets Southport apart.

headline: Student Question | What Are Your Healthy Habits?
abstract: What healthy habits do you already have — and what habits do you wish you had?
lead_paragraph: Do you knit? Did you know that knitting can counter stress by inducing a relaxed state?

headline: Taliban Sabotage Cuts Major Power Source for Afghanistan Capital
abstract: The destruction of an electrical tower exposed a vulnerability in the nation’s infrastructure at a time when rebels have government forces thinly stretched.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have sabotaged a major power line in the northern province of Baghlan, officials said on Wednesday, cutting a supply of electricity from Uzbekistan to Kabul, the Afghan capital, and exposing a vulnerability in the nation’s rickety infrastructure at a time when the insurgency has government forces thinly stretched.

headline: R.B.S. Expects to Report an Annual Loss for 2015
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland, which is based in Edinburgh and is in the middle of a large restructuring plan, has not posted an annual profit since 2007.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Wednesday that it would report an annual loss for 2015 after taking a series of charges to close a deficit in its pension plan and to resolve past misconduct.

headline: Vietnam’s Communist Party Gives Old-Guard Leader a New 5-Year Term
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The reappointment of Nguyen Phu Trong is unlikely to alter the country’s strategic balance in relations with China and the United States.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — The Communist Party of Vietnam has chosen the incumbent general secretary as the country’s top leader for a second five-year term, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Wednesday.

headline: Bill Bryson’s ‘The Road to Little Dribbling’
abstract: Twenty years after “Notes From a Small Island,” Bryson again takes stock of his adopted country, Britain.
lead_paragraph: “I watched the rain beat down on the road outside and told myself that one day this would be 20 years ago.” Why on earth would the weary traveler who consoled himself with this notion, marooned in a shuttered-tight, sodden Welsh mining town, even consider hitting the road again? Anyone who followed Bill Bryson on his trek around Britain in “Notes From a Small Island,” published here exactly 20 years ago, will instantly understand. From the very beginning, Bryson, an American from Iowa who has lived and worked and established a family on the far side of the Atlantic, has responded to his British surroundings with an irresistible mix of frustration and fascination. That first travelogue was inspired by what turned out to be a temporary move back to the United States. This new one, which begins with Bryson taking a challenging (and, he mischievously observes, not entirely accurate) test to qualify for dual citizenship, has him questioning how much he really understands modern Britain, “a country that I don’t altogether recognize.” Has he just become older and crankier? Or have the places he first knew as a young man really changed? There’s a simple way to find out.

headline: ‘The Age of Stagnation’ and ‘The Only Game in Town’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Two new books address slow economic growth from different perspectives.
lead_paragraph: Even more than income inequality, slow growth sits firmly atop the leader board of global economic worries. Among the most prosperous countries — the Group of 7 — not a single nation is achieving an acceptable rate of expansion. Once formidable emerging countries are in disarray: Brazil and Russia have fallen into deep recessions, and China is, at best, decelerating; only India emits a soupçon of positive energy.

headline: Milos Raonic Crashes the Australian Open Semifinals Party
abstract: Raonic beat Gaël Monfils on Wednesday to advance to play Andy Murray on Friday. Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer are matched in the other semifinal.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — His serve might be a brute, but Milos Raonic has a sophisticated side.

headline: To Prevent Back Pain, Orthotics Are Out, Exercise Is In
abstract: Back belts and orthotics were almost completely ineffective in preventing a new bout of back pain, but regular exercise helped, and it didn’t really matter what kind of exercise it was.
lead_paragraph: Lower back pain is an almost universal if unwelcome experience. About 80 percent of those of us in the Western world can expect to suffer from disruptive lower back pain at some point in our lives. But if we begin and stick with the right type of exercise program, we might avoid a recurrence, according to a comprehensive new scientific review of back pain prevention.

headline: Arrests and a Death in a Confrontation With Ammon Bundy and the Police
abstract: Mr. Bundy, the leader of a seizure of a federal wildlife refuge in Oregon, was arrested and one person was killed in a traffic stop, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bundy, the leader of a seizure of a federal wildlife refuge in Oregon, was arrested and one person was killed in a traffic stop, the authorities said.

headline: Obama to Attend Event at Israeli Embassy Honoring Americans
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mr. Obama is to appear at the embassy to remember Americans who risked their lives to save Jews during the Holocaust, his latest move to show solidarity with Israel after a historic rupture over the Iran accord.
lead_paragraph: Take President Obama, add the Oscar-winning director Steven Spielberg and some stories of Holocaust heroism made for the silver screen, and throw in Ambassador Ron Dermer, who has had a somewhat tumultuous relationship with the White House over the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: Democrats Hope to Turn Tables on Republicans Over Planned Parenthood Indictments
abstract: House Democrats, who have found themselves on the defensive over their support for Planned Parenthood, have called on Republicans to disband a special committee investigating it after two anti-abortion activists who conducted a sting on the organization were indicted in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Democrats who have found themselves on the defensive over their support for Planned Parenthood say they believe they can now turn the tables on Republicans after two anti-abortion activists who conducted a sting on the organization were indicted in Texas.

headline: Studies Point to Inequalities That Could Strain Chinese Society
abstract: Two new reports suggest that while Chinese people remain wedded, though not always blissfully, to the status quo, President Xi Jinping confronts a persistent undercurrent of discontent.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping calls it his “China Dream” — a vision of a cohesive, equal society, increasingly wealthy and healthy, and happily wedded to Communist Party rule, ardent patriotism and traditional values. That vision, splashed on television and billboards everywhere here, has driven Mr. Xi’s vow that under his administration, Chinese society will become more equal and just.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Ad Features Cameo From Budding Baseball Star: His Grandson, 4
abstract: In a new ad, Mr. Sanders can be seen throwing an underhand pitch to his grandson, who showed his potential as a future baseball star.
lead_paragraph: In the most recent ad from the Sanders campaign, sandwiched between scenes of Iowans going about their daily lives, is a quick clip of a small child crushing a pitch tossed underhand by Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: Donald Trump Stirs the Pot, Again
abstract: We sent our reporter Trip Gabriel to live in Iowa. Here’s what he’s watching for as the caucuses near.
lead_paragraph: Good morning from Iowa, where, five days from the caucuses, there are no politics-free zones, especially now that Donald J. Trump’s decision to boycott Thursday’s Fox News debate is sure to dominate conversations on Wednesday.

headline: Maison Margiela: Couture
abstract: John Galliano presents couture for Maison Margiela.
lead_paragraph: John Galliano presents couture for Maison Margiela.

headline: We’ve Mapped Where Mainstream G.O.P. Candidates Are Most Popular (It’s Not the South)
abstract: The support is concentrated in Florida, the Northeast and across much of the West.
lead_paragraph: Even as many Republican voters flirt with outsider candidates, a large minority of Republicans still supports one of the mainstream, traditional conservatives: Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, John Kasich and Carly Fiorina.

headline: Can I Call My Nonbiological Twins Black Because My Husband Is?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Parenting', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how we define race and whether you should disclose a friend’s struggle with depression.
lead_paragraph: I’m a Caucasian woman married to an African-American man. Shortly after we married, I discovered that I couldn’t conceive my own biological children. We opted to ‘‘adopt’’ two embryos. (Couples who have successfully undergone in-vitro fertilization and don’t wish to have more children can donate remaining embryos to other couples.) I was soon pregnant and gave birth to twins. Based on the records of the fertility clinic, we know that our children are genetically mixed Hispanic and Caucasian. I am not comfortable being open about the origin of my children, except with family and close friends, until they are old enough for me to explain it to them. However, several times in the last three years, I’ve been asked about their race, most recently on a pre-K school application form. On this form, there is no option of ‘‘mixed race’’ or ‘‘other.’’ Therefore, I identified my children as black. Was this the right choice? Name Withheld, Chicago

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster
keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'Identification Devices', 'Religion and Belief', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Atheism']
abstract: The court rules in favor of those faithful to the omnipotent food clump.
lead_paragraph: Sarah writes: My husband is an atheist. He recently informed me that for his next driver’s-license photo, he plans to wear a colander on his head and will claim to be a member of the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster. Please order him not to do this.

headline: Readers Respond: Oscars So White? Or Oscars So Dumb?
abstract: After critics weighed in on the furor over the all-white acting nominations, readers joined the debate, with many arguing that the academy got it right.
lead_paragraph: #OscarsSoWhite or #OscarsSoDumb?

headline: Laura Poitras Prepares ‘Astro Noise’ for the Whitney Museum
abstract: Nothing is what it seems in the exhibition by Ms. Poitras, which opens Feb. 5.
lead_paragraph: The images that open “Astro Noise,” Laura Poitras’s coming exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, are striking, pleasing, and at first impossible to decipher. One shows rows of horizontal stripes intersected by curved lines swooping down diagonally; another looks to be some kind of airborne vehicle with a burst of light, or explosion, in front of it; a third has the vague suggestion of sound waves across the canvas.

headline: In Rio, the Work Goes in Before the Party Goes On
abstract: Samba schools in Rio de Janeiro are more like social clubs, fulcrums of community spirit tucked deep into a neighborhood, many in ramshackle favelas.
lead_paragraph: Near midnight on a steamy weeknight in January, midsummer in Brazil, a stretch of Estrada do Galeão in Rio de Janeiro was closed to traffic. On the crowded sidewalk, in the ghoulish light of streetlamps and shadows, vendors sold beer in bottles and meats on sticks. Above the graffiti-marked doors of storefronts shuttered until morning, silhouettes stood on balconies and in windows.

headline: Buffalo in the City
abstract: Once an icon of masculinity, the plaid pattern has become an accidental camp classic.
lead_paragraph: The paparazzi must be pleased with the vogue for buffalo plaid — with all the acres of fabric, deep red and black thickly crisscrossing, marking their quarry clearly. Have you recently breezed through the celebrity-photo pages? Reese Witherspoon snapped, leaving her car in a parking lot, while wearing a buffalo-plaid shirt and a smart skirt. Gwen Stefani, spotted toting her toddler to church, has bundled the boy in a logger shirt. Here we have Kylie Jenner — that ‘‘Keeping Up With the Kardashians’’ fixture — in a buffalo-plaid shirtdress of shocking blue. Pictures of the dress stimulated such demand that its manufacturer rushed it back into production.

headline: China Urging Afghanistan to Restart Peace Talks With Taliban
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A statement from the Chinese Foreign Ministry suggested that Beijing was asserting a commitment to the peace process.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese officials are urging the government of Afghanistan to restart peace talks with the Taliban after the last round of discussions collapsed, the Chinese Foreign Ministry has said.

headline: The Right-Wing Attack on India’s Universities
abstract: The R.S.S., a Hindu nationalist organization, is making a play for control of Indian intellectual life.
lead_paragraph: Varanasi, India — I met Sandeep Pandey days after he was sacked from his position as a visiting professor at a prestigious technical institute at Banaras Hindu University. We sat in a dreary guesthouse on the university campus. Mr. Pandey had just finished a long train ride. With his wrinkled kurta pajama and rubber slippers, he was every bit the picture of an old-fashioned Indian leftist.

headline: Donald Trump’s Shunning of Fox Debate Could Be Seen as Fight or Flight
abstract: The Trump show played for at least one final time on Tuesday before the Iowa caucuses. As has often been the case, the reviews were mixed.
lead_paragraph: The Trump show played for at least one final time on Tuesday before the Iowa caucuses. As has often been the case, the reviews were mixed.

headline: Tour and Hotel News: Culture in Portugal, Movie Scenes in Jordan
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including a food and wine festival in Carmel and a Passover package in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: EXPLORING THE CULTURE OF PORTUGAL, PAST AND PRESENT

headline: ‘2666,’ a Most Difficult Novel, Takes the Stage
abstract: A five-hour adaptation of Roberto Bolaño’s nearly 900-page book will begin performances at the Goodman Theater in Chicago in February.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “2666,” the Chilean writer Roberto Bolaño’s darkly enigmatic, wildly digressive, sometimes densely philosophical and above all extremely long final novel, has awed, mesmerized, baffled and exasperated readers around the world since its posthumous publication in 2004.

headline: John Kerry Urges China to Curb North Korea’s Nuclear Pursuits
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The secretary of state, in Beijing, warned that if necessary, the United States would take security steps China’s leaders have strongly opposed.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Secretary of State John Kerry warned China on Wednesday that North Korea was moving ahead with an effort to manufacture a nuclear weapon small enough to fit atop a long-range missile that could reach American shores, and said the United States “will do what is necessary to protect the people of our country.”

headline: Another Kind of Girl
abstract: In this short documentary, a 17-year-old Syrian films an intimate portrait of life in her refugee camp.
lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, a 17-year-old Syrian films an intimate portrait of life in her refugee camp.

headline: Another Kind of Girl
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: In this short documentary, a 17-year-old Syrian films an intimate portrait of life in her refugee camp.
lead_paragraph: When I arrived at the Za’atari refugee camp in Jordan three years ago, I was overwhelmed. My family left our village in the region of Syria where the revolution began, after the area was bombed. My mother and six younger siblings and I suddenly became eight of the world’s 4.5 million Syrian refugees, and we have been living with 80,000 of them in our camp ever since.

headline: His Guardian Angel Was Packing
abstract: Riding up a long escalator with a hostile person, a nervous rider was watched by a protector.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Shell Shareholders Approve Acquisition of BG Group
abstract: The deal, one of the first struck with the price of oil in free fall, will create the global leader among public companies in liquefied natural gas.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one of the first energy mergers in the era of low oil prices, Royal Dutch Shell shareholders on Wednesday approved the acquisition of the BG Group, the Britain-based oil and gas producer, for about $50 billion.

headline: Ai Weiwei Says He’s Closing Danish Exhibition in Protest of Refugee Law
keywords: ['Art', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Faurschou Foundation, a contemporary art gallery in Copenhagen, confirmed on Facebook and Instagram that Mr. Ai’s “Ruptures” would end ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: The dissident artist and activist Ai Weiwei said on Wednesday that he would close his current exhibition at the Faurschou Foundation in Copenhagen in protest of a new law allowing Denmark to confiscate refugees’ valuables to help pay for their stay in the country.

headline: John Kasich Is Called an ‘Obama Republican’ in New Hampshire Ads
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The American Future Fund, a conservative group, plans to spend $1 million on ads in New Hampshire that brand John Kasich an “Obama Republican.” Mr. Kasich has been gaining ground in recent polls before the Feb. 9 New Hampshire primary.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has steadily gained ground in the New Hampshire polls, drawing few attacks from his opponents as they have fought among themselves.

headline: The Meat Mavens' Waiting Game
abstract: The five-hour line at Franklin Barbecue in Austin, Tex., has become a rite of passage and a bonding experience for meat connoisseurs far and wide.
lead_paragraph: The five-hour line at Franklin Barbecue in Austin, Tex., has become a rite of passage and a bonding experience for meat connoisseurs far and wide.

headline: Want Some of This Texas Barbecue? Get in Line. For 3 Hours or Longer.
abstract: Waiting for hours in the food line at Franklin Barbecue in Austin, Tex., is a rite of passage for the famished and the faithful from all over.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — At Franklin Barbecue, people pull up at dawn or shortly thereafter and spend their breakfast hours waiting for lunch.

headline: Elie Saab: Couture
abstract: Elie Saab’s couture 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: Elie Saab’s couture 2016 collection.

headline: Facebook Building a Network for Virtual Reality
abstract: Facebook’s video audience is rapidly growing. But it is only a step toward a great vision for virtual reality.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — When Facebook releases its fourth-quarter earnings results on Wednesday, it is likely to announce it shows well over eight billion videos a day. It is certainly a big number, but video is most likely a means to an end for Facebook.

headline: French Justice Minister Quits Over Plan to Strip Citizenship From Terrorists
abstract: The resignation of Christiane Taubira, widely known as an independent spirit with a bent more leftist than that of the Socialist government, came abruptly.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French justice minister, one of the most outspoken and progressive voices in the government, resigned on Wednesday after a clash over a proposal to strip the citizenship of French-born dual nationals convicted of terrorism.

headline: Rihanna Releases ‘Work’ From Long-Awaited Album ‘Anti’
abstract: The track, which features Drake, is an indication that the pop star’s first album since her 2012 LP “Unapologetic” is coming soon.
lead_paragraph: For most of her career, Rihanna has been an artist on a tight schedule. Between 2005 and 2012, the pop star released an album each year except one (2008), with the last four coming like clockwork every November.

headline: New York Philharmonic Taps Jaap van Zweden as Its Next Maestro
abstract: The appointment of Mr. van Zweden ends nearly a year of speculation about who would succeed Alan Gilbert as music director when he steps down next year.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic announced on Wednesday that it was turning to Jaap van Zweden, an intense, exacting Dutch conductor, to be its next music director and guide it through the costly renovation of its hall, two seasons of exile and, if all goes well, a triumphant return to Lincoln Center.

headline: What You Need to Know About the New York Philharmonic’s Next Music Director
abstract: Here are some key facts about the Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden, starting with how to pronounce his name.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic announced on Wednesday that the Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden would be its next music director. Here are some key facts about him.

headline: Jaap van Zweden and the Future of the New York Philharmonic
abstract: The Times’s chief classical music critic on the appointment of Mr. van Zweden as the next music director at the Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: When Alan Gilbert said in February that he would step down as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2017, one of the first names bandied about was Jaap van Zweden. On Wednesday, Mr. van Zweden was announced as Mr. Gilbert’s successor, a decision I wouldn’t have anticipated last year.

headline: Trevor Noah Writing a Memoir About His Youth in South Africa
abstract: A memoir from Trevor Noah, host of “The Daily Show,” is due in November.
lead_paragraph: You’re not really a late-night satirist until you’ve parlayed your television gig into a lucrative book deal, and now Trevor Noah can say that he is truly a member of the club.

headline: Archaeologists in England Tackle Mystery of Prehistoric Village’s Rapid Demise
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Bronze Age']
abstract: The Must Farm site in Cambridgeshire, destroyed by fire 3,000 years ago, is considered so rich that it has been compared to Pompeii.
lead_paragraph: WHITTLESEY, England — No one knows why a catastrophic fire tore through the small settlement that rose by a river channel, incinerating the homes of several families and sending burning timbers crashing into the marsh below. It might have been an accident, an attack by enemies or even some sort of ritual.

headline: German Cabinet Backs Measures to Ease Deportation of Criminals
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Deportation', 'Sex Crimes', 'Law and Legislation', 'Crime and Criminals', 'New Year']
abstract: The legislation would allow the authorities to send back anyone convicted of homicide, bodily harm, sexual assault, violent theft or serial shoplifting.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German cabinet endorsed measures on Wednesday that would make it easier to deport many noncitizens convicted of crimes, responding to outrage over the sexual assault of hundreds of women by foreigners on New Year’s Eve and growing skepticism about the government’s ability to accommodate more than one million asylum seekers.

abstract: Built in 1910, this three-bedroom house is on the market for $2.73 million.
lead_paragraph: Built in 1910, this three-bedroom house is on the market for $2.73 million.

lead_paragraph: A VILLA IN DUBROVNIK WITH SEA VIEWS

headline: No Need to Fret, Apple Is Doing Fine
abstract: If Apple is hitting a plateau because of slower iPhone growth, it’s one of the highest plateaus ever reached in the business world.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way first: Despite what you may have heard, the iPhone is not dying. Neither, by extension, is Apple.

headline: Nexstar Clinches Deal to Acquire Media General
abstract: The transaction was contingent on Meredith Corporation bowing out from its own attempt to combine with Media General.
lead_paragraph: After months tangled in a three-way merger drama, the Nexstar Broadcasting Group has agreed to acquire Media General for more than $2.1 billion.

headline: Daily Report: The iPad’s Blaze of Glory
abstract: It is striking to think about the device’s trajectory since its introduction six years ago.
lead_paragraph: Remember the iPad?

headline: Under Pressure, SunEdison Gives David Einhorn’s Fund a Board Seat
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power']
abstract: After pressure from hedge funds, Claire Gogel, a former Greenlight executive, will join the board of the struggling renewable energy company.
lead_paragraph: SunEdison, the renewable energy company, was once the darling of the hedge fund world. Big-name investors like Steven A. Cohen, Leon G. Cooperman and David Einhorn rode the stock as it soared to ever increasing heights. And then it crashed.

headline: 1891: Rave Reviews for Fabre Drama
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A new drama, “Jeanne d’Arc,” receives rave reviews in Paris in 1891.
lead_paragraph: Over four thousand patriotic Frenchmen and Frenchwomen enthusiastically applauded ‘‘Jeanne d’Arc,’’ a drama by M. Joseph Fabre, music by M. Benjamin Goldard, which was given last night at the Châtelet. The plot of necessity follows the story of the Maid of Orleans, from her departure to arouse the King from his lethargy to the stake at Rouen. It is treated in a poetic way and the tirades placed in the heroine’s mouth are of the loftiest strain and full of the most patriotic spirit. All of this is set in the midst of a splendid mise-en-scène. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 28, 1891

headline: Protecting Personal Information From Virtual Assistants
abstract: In order to be of use, assistants like Cortana and Siri need to know a lot about you. Reading the companies’ privacy statements can give you an idea of how much.
lead_paragraph: Q. I was going to try Cortana, Microsoft’s version of Siri, but to use it, you have to allow Microsoft access to your location, your contacts, voice input, information from email and text messages, browser history, search history, calendar details “and other information.” Naturally, I declined. Why does Microsoft need so much personal information and what does Microsoft do with it?

headline: An Invitation Into the Shadowy World of Match Fixing
abstract: After writing about match fixing in tennis last year, I was contacted electronically and asked whether I was interested in going farther down that rabbit hole.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — I was walking to my neighborhood Starbucks in Washington one morning last year when I received a Facebook message request from “Ben Rotenberg.”

headline: That’s Not Just a Bear You Hear in ‘The Revenant’
abstract: How the sound team of “The Revenant” used horse and camel audio to bring the film’s bear to roaring life.
lead_paragraph: The river, the battles, that bear. Most distinctly that bear. The sound editors and mixers on “The Revenant,” about a frontiersman’s battle for survival, had many elements to consider when crafting the sonic universe of the punishing 19th-century West in Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s film. Their work has paid off with several Oscar nominations.

headline: New York City Ballet to Perform in Paris in Summer
abstract: The company is to have a three-week engagement at the Théâtre du Châtelet as part of Les Etés de la Danse.
lead_paragraph: There are about to quite a few more Americans in Paris, dancewise.

headline: Let It Snow, Let It Snow … and Paul Ryan’s Live Stream Captured It
abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan, who has a camera on his House balcony to capture events, recorded live footage of the snow as it fell in Washington, drawing half a million viewers.
lead_paragraph: Paul D. Ryan, the speaker of the House, has a nifty camera set up on his Capitol Hill balcony, which is used to live-stream all of his events. So it was decided that last weekend’s snowstorm would be streamed, too.

headline: Food Testing Start-Up Looks to Stand Out With a New Wrinkle
abstract: Invisible Sentinel says its food testing technology offers a faster, easier and cheaper way to test for pathogens and spoilage in foods.
lead_paragraph: Nothing unnerves consumers more and drives them away from a restaurant, food or beverage faster than a flurry of headlines about people being sickened by dreaded bacteria like E. coli or listeria.

headline: Donald Trump Aide Is More Conditional About Skipping Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s campaign manager used slightly less absolute words about his candidate’s plans to skip Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate, saying he didn’t “think” there was any way Mr. Trump would change his mind
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign manager used slightly less absolute words on Wednesday about Mr. Trump’s plans to skip Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate, saying he didn’t “think” there was any way the candidate would change his mind about attending the event on Fox News.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Some Americans Might Have to Pay More Into Social Security
abstract: To preserve Social Security, Hillary Clinton said that one option is lifting the current cap on income subject to Social Security tax, though she did not specify who would pay more.
lead_paragraph: DECORAH, Iowa – Hillary Clinton said on Tuesday that new revenue was needed to shore up Social Security and openly mused about lifting the cap on income subjected to Social Security taxes, a position championed by Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Try to Interview Google’s Co-Founder. It’s Emasculating.
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Books and Literature', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Conor Dougherty provides a look at how he covers Google and its elusive chief executive, Larry Page.
lead_paragraph: I started as The New York Times’s Google beat reporter in August 2014. Shortly thereafter, I told the company’s public relations people that at some point I would love to interview Larry Page, the company’s co-founder. I’ve been waiting ever since.

headline: Italy’s Strange Choice to Hide Its Art
abstract: During a visit to Rome by President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, Italian officials made the absurd decision to cover up nude statues.
lead_paragraph: Anyone receiving a special visitor understands the desire to be a gracious host. But there’s no point in beating around the bush here: Italian officials have gone to an absurd length in kowtowing to President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on his first visit since the lifting of economic sanctions as a result of the nuclear deal.

headline: Living in Southport, Conn.
abstract: The coastal enclave offers a rich array of 18th- and 19th-century architecture that reflects the area’s affluence during its heyday as a seaport.
lead_paragraph: The coastal enclave offers a rich array of 18th- and 19th-century architecture that reflects the area’s affluence during its heyday as a seaport.

headline: 5 Ex-Brokers Cleared in London Libor Trial
abstract: A jury acquitted five former brokers of charges that they helped a one-time trader at UBS and Citigroup manipulate a benchmark interest rate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a major setback for British prosecutors, a jury on Wednesday acquitted five former brokers of charges that they helped a onetime trader at UBS and Citigroup manipulate an important benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: Italians Mock Cover-Up of Nude Statues for Iranian’s Visit
abstract: To avoid offending President Hassan Rouhani on his visit to Rome, one critic wrote, “we offended ourselves.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — A decision to cover up nude statues from Roman antiquity during a visit by President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has drawn ridicule and scorn in Italy — much of it directed at the Italian government — and spurred a debate about the national identity.

headline: Should The Times Have Been a Tougher Watchdog in Flint?
abstract: The Times wrote early about the problems, but then dropped the subject for many months
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4 p.m.

headline: Red Bulls Defender Matt Miazga Likely Headed to Chelsea
abstract: Miazga, 20, had been in training with the United States national team this month.
lead_paragraph: Defender Matt Miazga, who became a regular in the Red Bulls’ lineup as a teenager and made his United States national team debut in November at age 20, is set to be acquired by Chelsea of England’s Premier League, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Recipes for Midweek (and Mozart)
abstract: For dinner tonight, a no-recipe recipe for roasted fish with capers and lemon and strudel for dessert. Later this week, make pizza.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Human Rights Watch Denounces Europe Over Migrant Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'International Relations']
abstract: European governments have allowed fears about migration and terrorism to erode their commitment to civil rights, the group said in a new report.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European governments have allowed widespread fears about migration and terrorism to erode their commitment to civil rights and liberal ideals, according to a new report by the advocacy group Human Rights Watch.

headline: With Corbis Sale, Tiananmen Protest Images Go to Chinese Media Company
keywords: ['Photography', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Visual China Group’s purchase means the company will control famous images of Marilyn Monroe, Rosa Parks and — troubling to watchdogs — the 1989 crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Corbis, the photography archive owned by Bill Gates that includes some of the most famous pictures ever made, has sold its image and licensing division to a Chinese company.

headline: Introducing Sutton Foster, the 40-Year-Old Ingénue of ‘Younger,’ Again
abstract: The star of the stealth hit sitcom has stood out on Broadway, but she is having her TV breakout moment.
lead_paragraph: It’s the rare ingénue who gets to play the newbie role twice. But Sutton Foster, the star of the stealth hit sitcom “Younger,” is having her breakout moment as a spunky young heroine on the rise — some 13 years after she was plucked from chorus-line obscurity for an award-winning turn on Broadway.

headline: Super Bowl Challenges Wisdom of Crowds and Oddsmakers
abstract: In the last 10 Super Bowls that had betting line movement, the teams that bettors supported had a record of 5-5.
lead_paragraph: When the betting line was first announced for this year’s Super Bowl, the Carolina Panthers were favored by 3½ points in many places. Quickly that line moved to 4 and then to 4½, and it is even listed at 5 or 5½ in some places.

headline: 1941: French Leaders Must Take Oath
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Vichy French leaders are required to take an oath of allegiance in 1941.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — All French Cabinet ministers, secretaries of state and other high functionaries and notables will henceforth take an oath of allegiance personally to and in the presence of the Chief of the French state, binding themselves to ‘‘discharge their duties for the welfare of the state according to the laws of honor and probity.’’ This is provided for by a constitutional law, promulgated by Premier Marshal Henri Pétain today [Jan. 27]. By virtue of this act the highest state officials will be personally responsible to the Chief of State for their official acts and will be liable to suffer in their persons and in their property for their misdeeds in office. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 28, 1941

headline: Pardon Plea by Adolf Eichmann, Nazi War Criminal, Is Made Public
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Letters', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: Israel released the handwritten letter by Mr. Eichmann in which he denies guilt, saying Nazi officials like him were “mere instruments in the hands of leaders.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After he was convicted and sentenced to death in Israel for his role in the annihilation of millions of Jews by Nazi Germany, Adolf Eichmann pleaded for his own life.

headline: Shooting at Seattle Tent City Coincides With Mayor’s Homelessness Speech
abstract: Five people are shot, two of them fatally, in what the city authorities are calling a target attack, possibly linked to low-level drug activity.
lead_paragraph: As Seattle’s mayor delivered a speech about homelessness on Tuesday night, a grim reminder of the crisis was unfolding in another part of the city as five people were shot — two fatally — at a makeshift homeless encampment known as the Jungle.

headline: ‘One Minute Sculptures’ Invade the Schindler House
abstract: Erwin Wurm’s “One Minute Sculptures,” blueprints for visitors to enact their own short performances, is coming to the MAK Center for Art and Architecture.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the participatory vein of Yoko Ono’s instruction pieces but decidedly less dreamy, Erwin Wurm’s “One Minute Sculptures” are blueprints for visitors to enact their own short performances, using directions and household props — a bucket, board, shoe or sweater, for instance — provided by this Vienna-based artist. For nearly two decades he has been staging these so-called sculptures mainly in galleries and museums, where the absurdity of placing a bucket on one’s head disrupts the rite of fine art consumption. Now he is bringing the series to the MAK Center for Art and Architecture here, with an exhibition in its historic Schindler home from Thursday through March 27.

headline: Oklahoma Resists Push for Enrollment in Affordable Care Act Coverage
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Supporters of the law regularly encounter stony skepticism in the state: “Obamacare is toxic,” said Craig W. Jones of the Oklahoma Hospital Association.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — A resolute band of insurance counselors, undeterred by the politics of health care in this staunchly conservative state, is increasing its efforts to find people who are uninsured and enroll them in coverage before the Affordable Care Act’s third annual open enrollment period ends on Sunday.

headline: Mrinalini Sarabhai, Indian Classical Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 97
abstract: Ms. Sarabhai brought ancient South Indian dance forms into the 20th century and infused her work with social commentary.
lead_paragraph: Mrinalini Sarabhai, an Indian dancer and choreographer who brought ancient South Indian dance forms into the 20th century and infused her work with social commentary, died on Jan. 21 at her home in Ahmedabad, in western India. She was 97.

headline: Elton John, Still Rocking Out (and Speaking Out) With a Flourish
abstract: Mr. John is set to release his 33rd studio album, “Wonderful Crazy Night,” and says he still likes to rock out.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After 47 years in the spotlight, more than 250 million albums sold, six Grammys, a Tony, an Oscar and a knighthood, Elton John still gets the jitters when he steps onstage. Striding to his piano at the Wiltern here in a blue, rhinestone-dusted suit to play songs from his new album, “Wonderful Crazy Night,” for the first time, he surveyed the crowd of die-hard fans and music-industry insiders fretfully.

headline: Black Drivers in Florida Face Far Stricter Seatbelt Enforcement, Report Says
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Racial Profiling', 'Seatbelts', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Black motorists were given tickets for not wearing seatbelts nearly twice as often as white motorists in 2014, an American Civil Liberties Union report said.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Black drivers in Florida were stopped and given tickets for not wearing seatbelts nearly twice as often as whites who drove on the state’s roads in 2014, according to a report by the American Civil Liberties Union released Wednesday.

headline: Bach, Reich, Bartok, Beethoven and More
abstract: A roundup of recent classical recordings, featuring musicians like the pianist Ingrid Andsnes and Third Coast Percussion.
lead_paragraph: BEETHOVEN, HAGEN: ’33+1’

headline: Robert Tuggle, Longtime Archivist of the Metropolitan Opera, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Tuggle helped create a digital database that includes details from every performance since the Met opened with Gounod’s “Faust” on Oct. 22, 1883.
lead_paragraph: Robert Tuggle, who as the longtime archivist of the Metropolitan Opera helped create a digital database that includes details from every performance since the Met opened with Gounod’s “Faust” on Oct. 22, 1883, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Video Review: The New XF, a Jaguar Light on Its Feet
abstract: This luxury performance sedan is, on average, 200 pounds lighter than the outgoing model, with a bonded and riveted aluminum platform instead of steel.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE 2008, Jaguars with more than two doors had distinct designs as British as Highclere Castle. Then the XF arrived. Crisp and contemporary, it quickly became Jaguar’s best-selling car. Now, for its second generation, it has taken the approach that less is more.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Couture
abstract: The latest couture designs from Jean Paul Gaultier.
lead_paragraph: The latest couture designs from Jean Paul Gaultier.

headline: Irregular Heartbeats? Coffee May Not Be So Bad for You
abstract: People with irregular heartbeats are often advised to give up caffeine, but a new study suggests they may not have to forgo their coffee.
lead_paragraph: People with irregular heartbeats are often advised to give up caffeine, but a new study suggests they may not have to forgo their coffee.

headline: Review: ‘Imagining the Imaginary Invalid,’ About Absence and Art Making
abstract: This large-cast elegy from the experimental companies Mabou Mines and Trick Saddle mingles Molière with more recent memories.
lead_paragraph: Like a slightly dotty professor addressing a lecture hall, Marylouise Burke paces the stage and talks of Molière. He wanted to be a tragic actor, she tells us in her cartoon voice, but his stutter sent him into comedy instead.

headline: Mike Birbiglia Has a New Show at the Lynn Redgrave Theater
abstract: Mr. Birbiglia’s new one-man show, “Thank God for Jokes,” is an ode to the joke.
lead_paragraph: The stand-up comic Mike Birbiglia has earned a reputation as a great storyteller, through performances on the podcast “This American Life” and in his Off Broadway show (and later, movie) “Sleepwalk With Me,” but this might have obscured his skill as a joke teller.

headline: 3 More Arrests in Oregon as Protest Leader Says ‘Go Home’
abstract: Mr. Bundy, the protest leader, asked remaining occupiers at an Oregon wildlife refuge to “please stand down.” The F.B.I. later said three had surrendered.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — The armed occupation of a wildlife refuge in eastern Oregon, which flashed into violent confrontation with law enforcement on Tuesday when eight members of the group were arrested and one was killed, appeared to be unraveling on Wednesday night when the jailed leader of the siege advised his followers to go home.

headline: Saying ‘We Are All Jews,’ Obama Honors Americans’ Lifesaving Efforts in Holocaust
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States International Relations', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: President Obama marked International Holocaust Remembrance Day at the Israeli Embassy, holding up the honorees as symbols of the values Israel and the United States share.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a German prison camp 71 years ago, Master Sgt. Roddie Edmonds stared down the barrel of his Nazi captor’s pistol and refused to say which of his fellow prisoners of war were Jewish.

headline: New and Old at Armani Privé and Maison Margiela
abstract: There were couture shorts at Armani, some military themes at Margiela, spangles from Elie Saab and John Paul Gaultier’s customary party on the runway.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Taxi cab drivers are striking in Paris, protesting the rise of Uber. On Tuesday, the air traffic controllers were, too. By the catwalks, editors and clients were arguing over whether Giorgio Armani’s new favorite color was mauve, as his Armani Privé show notes claimed, or lilac, as it seemed, or maybe even lavender. Shades of the notorious Internet dress dispute of almost a year ago. Plus ça change, and all that. What’s new?

headline: Report Faults E.C.B. in Irish Banking Collapse
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: A parliamentary report accused the central bank of threatening to withhold aid to Irish banks if the government forced senior bond investors to share in the losses.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The European Central Bank placed an “inappropriate” debt burden on Irish citizens in 2010 when it refused to force bond investors to share losses from troubled banks, a parliamentary committee report on the country’s banking collapse said on Wednesday.

headline: Facts & Figures: Donald Trump’s Long Obsession With People Laughing at America
abstract: He’s brought up the issue at least 103 times over nearly thirty years, according to a Washington Post analysis.
lead_paragraph: Just how much does Donald Trump talk about people abroad laughing at America? The Washington Post went back through his public statements and found he’s brought up the laughing issue at least 103 times, starting as early as 1987.

headline: French Justice Minister Steps Down
abstract: A French government spokesman reacted to the resignation of Justice Minister Christiane Taubira after she clashed with others in government over a controversial counterterrorism proposal.
lead_paragraph: A French government spokesman reacted to the resignation of Justice Minister Christiane Taubira after she clashed with others in government over a controversial counterterrorism proposal.

headline: Caity Lotz Comes Back From the Dead as the White Canary
abstract: Ms. Lotz discusses playing the resurrected Sara Lance in “DC’s Legends of Tomorrow,” CW’s latest production adapted from comics.
lead_paragraph: In CW’s “Arrow,” Caity Lotz played Sara Lance, a.k.a. the bloodthirsty Canary, who met her demise in Season 3. But it turns out that her character is more like a cat with nine lives.
