headline: British Tax Deal With Google Puts Government on Defensive
abstract: The technology company agreed to pay $185 million on revenue generated in a 10-year period, a deal the government called a “major success.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When it was announced last Friday, Google’s agreement to pay 130 million pounds in back taxes was welcomed by the country’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, as a “major success.”

headline: Rights Groups Seek Inquiry of Revoked Passports at U.S. Embassy in Yemen
abstract: In at least 20 cases, naturalized United States citizens have had their passports confiscated after coercive encounters at the embassy in Sana, lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn bodega owner, a naturalized citizen from Yemen, spent more than two years in stateless limbo after the United States Embassy in Sana confiscated his passport in 2013.

headline: Sugar-Coated Specialties for 90 Years
abstract: Schmidt’s Candy, in the Woodhaven section of Queens, has served handmade sweets since the current proprietor’s grandfather opened it in 1925.
lead_paragraph: Schmidt’s Candy, in the Woodhaven section of Queens, has served handmade sweets since the current proprietor’s grandfather opened it in 1925.

headline: How to Experience David Bowie’s New York
abstract: Bookstores, theaters, cafes and concerts — a guide to following in the Manhattan footsteps of the late David Bowie (songs included).
lead_paragraph: David Bowie was a New Yorker for over 20 years. In Bowie years, that is practically an eternity considering the multitude of lives he lived — musically, geographically and otherwise — since he set out to become a star in the late 1960s.

headline: Scientists Move Closer to Understanding Schizophrenia’s Cause
keywords: ['Schizophrenia', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Brain', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: A new study provides researchers with their first biological handle on the disorder, and helps explain why it often begins at a relatively young age.
lead_paragraph: Scientists reported on Wednesday that they had taken a significant step toward understanding the cause of schizophrenia, in a landmark study that provides the first rigorously tested insight into the biology behind any common psychiatric disorder.

headline: Schmidt’s Candy, a Sweet Spot in Queens
abstract: Schmidt’s Candy in Woodhaven opened in 1925, and the founder’s granddaughter is still hand-dipping chocolates and handing out lollipops.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in Woodhaven, Queens, there is a man with a wife named Zaida. Margie Schmidt of Schmidt’s Candy on Jamaica Avenue may not remember his name, but she knows what Zaida wants for Valentine’s Day. “Butter crunch, graham, milk-chocolate-covered pretzels, pretzel nuggets,” according to a list taped to a wall in the store’s back room.

headline: Lady Leshurr Brings Her Haughty English Rap to New York
abstract: The English rapper stars in “Queen’s Speech,” a popular series of five videos in which she administers crisp put-downs.
lead_paragraph: There’s Lady Leshurr, walking toward the camera through single, continuous takes in her series of five videos, “Queen’s Speech,” collectively watched more than 37 million times last year. A deft rapper from Birmingham, England, real name Melesha O’Garro, Lady Leshurr keeps a conversational, demure tone as she administers put-downs and Internet meme jokes to the camera; crisp and haughty, she cracks on your hygiene, your friends, your whole world. (“I can’t stand girls who take their heels off when they’re in a rave,” she raps in Episode 3. “I’ll step on your big toe, just to remind you how to behave.”) Grime — English rap — remains fairly obscure in the United States, despite flickers of interest from Kanye West and others. (Last August, Erykah Badu put up Episode 3 on her Facebook page with the message “ILL.”) But Lady Leshurr, making mixtapes since 2009, is packaged and ready. She makes her New York debut at the Gramercy Theater at 8 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 6. (venue.thegramercytheatre.com.)

headline: Beethoven String Quartet Cycle at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Jerusalem, Miró, Orion, Escher and Danish string quartets perform this cycle at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center through Feb. 21.
lead_paragraph: While it’s hard to argue that the world — especially the little slice of it known as New York City — needs another Beethoven string quartet cycle, only the most churlish will be able to resist the draw of the one opening this week at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. For the encyclopedically minded, the chronological order will be reassuring. For those craving variety, there’s the appeal of watching five different ensembles tackle this marathon in relay formation.

headline: A Radical Reinterpretation of ‘Swan Lake’
abstract: The South African choreographer Dada Masilo tinkers with sexual convention in her version of this ballet.
lead_paragraph: Choreographers keep peering into “Swan Lake,” searching for new themes in its symbolic waters. The latest to do so is Dada Masilo of South Africa, whose “Swan Lake” combines Tchaikovsky’s old ballet with modern realities. Although Ms. Masilo’s version, to a collage combining Tchaikovsky and contemporary music, establishes a carnival atmosphere and satirizes balletic conventions, it focuses on sexual politics.

headline: A Television Movie Revisits Charles Manson
abstract: “Manson’s Lost Girls” focuses on the women he gathered into his circle nearly 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost 47 years since the murders orchestrated by Charles Manson in California. For younger generations to know about those crimes and understand the shock of them requires some passing-down of the story. A made-for-TV movie on Saturday, Feb. 6, on Lifetime tries to do this, and its cast embodies a passing-down tradition of its own: It includes several young actors following in a parent’s footsteps.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld Presents an Eco-Friendly Chanel Haute Couture Collection
abstract: The designer showed a series of nature-inspired looks, with organic accents and embellishments.
lead_paragraph: The designer showed a series of nature-inspired looks, with organic accents and embellishments.

headline: The Metropolitan Museum Turns Detective With Jan van Eyck
abstract: The museum looks at “The Crucifixion” and “The Last Judgment” in an attempt to solve some mysteries.
lead_paragraph: In 1435, Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy, praised his Flemish court painter, Jan van Eyck — one of the early Renaissance’s masters of pinpoint, every-hair-is-there realism — as having no equal in “art and science.”

headline: Adolf Eichmann’s 1962 Letter to President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi of Israel
abstract: A handwritten letter dated May 29, 1962, by Adolf Eichmann to the president of Israel asking for a pardon and commutation of his death sentence for war crimes was released to the public for the first time on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A handwritten letter dated May 29, 1962, by Adolf Eichmann to the president of Israel asking for a pardon and commutation of his death sentence for war crimes was released to the public for the first time on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The cable set-top box, long a scourge of consumers and a moneymaker for cable companies, appears set for a makeover.

headline: Spanish Supreme Court Orders Bankia to Repay 2 Investors in Its I.P.O.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: The ruling could be a boon to thousands of other investors suing the bank for failing to disclose the loan problems that nearly caused the bank’s collapse.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish Supreme Court ordered Bankia on Wednesday to reimburse two small investors for misleading them during its 2011 initial public offering.

lead_paragraph: Viktor & Rolf presents couture 2016.

lead_paragraph: Corbis sold its enormous archive, which includes a treasure house of famous historical photographs, to a Chinese company, Visual China Group.

abstract: Social media reaction seemed negative to the casting of a white actor in the half-hour TV show, “Elizabeth, Michael & Marlon.”

headline: Senate Begins Debate on Comprehensive Bipartisan Energy Bill
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Energy Efficiency']
abstract: The proposed energy legislation focuses on protecting and improving the power grid and updating the oil and gas infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday started debating its first comprehensive energy legislation since the George W. Bush administration, a bipartisan measure meant to update the nation’s power grid and oil and gas transportation systems to address major changes in the ways that power is now produced in the United States.

headline: Warming Up to Sale at Artists & Fleas
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Art', 'Fleas', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants']
abstract: A book signing at the Shop at the Standard, new labels at Bergdorf Goodman and a new footwear line at Rag & Bone.
lead_paragraph: The weather outside is frightful, but merchants are making shopping this week so delightful. Shake off the cold at Artists & Fleas, which is ringing in the last days of its “Not So Secret Sale” with a Last Chance Sip and Shop event Thursday from 6 to 9 p.m. Scoring deep discounts of up to 70 percent on items like sea glass necklaces ($22, originally $38) and photo prints of vintage toys ($13, originally $26) from a variety of clothing, accessories, art and home-goods vendors will be even nicer with a glass of bubbly or a Sixpoint beer in hand. At Chelsea Market, 88 10th Avenue.

headline: Letter by Adolf Eichmann to President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi of Israel
keywords: ['Letters', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Capital Punishment', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A handwritten letter dated May 29, 1962, by Adolf Eichmann asking for a pardon and commutation of his death sentence is translated by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Handwritten in blue ink on lined paper, the 1962 letter from Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi war criminal who oversaw the lethal logistics of the Holocaust, to the president of Israel, Yitzhak Ben-Zvi, repeats part of Eichmann’s defense from his four-month trial: He was a lower-level official following orders, and he should not be held accountable for the crimes of his superiors. The letter was written in German on the day that Eichmann’s appeal was denied by Israel’s Supreme Court. Here is an English translation:

headline: Facebook Video Gives Account of Oregon Arrests
abstract: A man who claims he was a driver, Mark McConnell, gives his version of events, but it is unverified.
lead_paragraph: A man who claimed he was traveling with members of a protest group during a fatal traffic stop in Oregon on Tuesday said the man who was shot dead, LaVoy Finicum, had charged at police officers.

headline: A January Pause, but Fed Affirms Plan for Gradual Rate Increases
abstract: The Federal Reserve, which raised its benchmark interest rate last month for the first time in years, acknowledged weak global growth but said it still expected to increase rates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve entered 2016 with a fairly straightforward plan to gradually increase its benchmark interest rate so long as job growth remained strong.

headline: France Restricts ‘Salafistes,’ Film on Islamic Radicals
keywords: ['Movies', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Ratings (Parental Guidance)', 'Terrorism', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The Culture Ministry said that the documentary was unsuitable for minors because of its images of violence and that it gave a platform to propaganda.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Culture Ministry ruled Wednesday that a new documentary film on Islamic radicals was unsuitable for minors, saying that it offered images of violence that were “sometimes unbearable” and interviews with members of Al Qaeda and other extremist figures that provided a platform for propaganda.

headline: A Director Follows Acclaim for ‘Tangerine’ With a Film for Kenzo
abstract: Sean Baker, the director, teams up with the LVMH label.
lead_paragraph: Sean Baker, a filmmaker whose fame has hitherto resonated mostly underground, broke the surface in 2015. “Tangerine,” his microbudget Los Angeles picaresque tale about two transgender women of color working an unbecoming strip of Santa Monica Boulevard near Highland Avenue, found its way onto year-end best-of lists and has been steadily collecting awards and nominations.

headline: Health Wonks and Bernie Bros
abstract: Everyone is corrupt!
lead_paragraph: So Charles Gaba, whose excellent site ACA Signups has been a huge secret resource for those of us covering health reform, is getting the Bernie Bro treatment. Never mind his long service to the cause of covering the uninsured (and his declaration that he’ll support either candidate in the general): his carefully laid-out explanation of his support for Hillary Clinton’s incremental approach means that he’s a corrupt tool of the oligarchy.

headline: Wounded Warrior Project Spends Lavishly on Itself, Insiders Say
abstract: The charity, which raised $372 million in 2015, has embraced aggressive styles of fund-raising, marketing and management — and has spent a significant proportion on overhead.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In 2014, after 10 years of rapid growth, the Wounded Warrior Project flew its roughly 500 employees to Colorado Springs for an “all hands” meeting at the five-star Broadmoor hotel.

headline: Chris Hemsworth Is the New Face of Australia
abstract: The hunky actor is introduced as a global ambassador for tourism in his country at a party in Bryant Park.
lead_paragraph: “Would you rather dance naked for Donald Trump, or would you rather have Donald Trump dance naked for you?” Curtis Stone, an Australian chef and television personality, asked a countryman, the film star Chris Hemsworth, on Monday night.

headline: Alphabet Program Beats the European Human Go Champion
abstract: DeepMind, a research organization, said that a program combining two separate algorithms had soundly defeated a high-ranking professional Go player.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence researchers are closing in on a new benchmark for comparing the human mind and a machine. On Wednesday, DeepMind, a research organization that operates under the umbrella of Alphabet, reported that a program combining two separate algorithms had soundly defeated a high-ranking professional Go player in a series of five matches.

headline: Key Measure of a 5-9 College Star: 25.3 Points a Game
abstract: Kahlil Felder, a 5-foot-9 point guard for Oakland University, ranks third in Division I in scoring and first in assists.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, Mich. — There is a moment in nearly every Oakland University basketball game when Kahlil Felder stuns everybody in the arena. It can be a fast-break block from behind on a taller opponent, when Felder’s outstretched hand reaches halfway up the backboard square. Or an ankle-breaking crossover dribble that leaves an opponent tumbling to the floor. Or Felder’s cleanly swishing a 3-pointer, only four steps in from the halfcourt line, over a frozen defender.

headline: Donald Trump Finds New City to Insult: Brussels
abstract: “It’s like living in a hellhole right now,” Donald J. Trump told the Fox Business Network anchor Maria Bartiromo.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Federal Lands']

lead_paragraph: JOHN DAY, Ore. — A week into the armed occupation of a wildlife refuge in eastern Oregon, LaVoy Finicum, an Arizona rancher and father of 11 who became a de facto spokesman for the protesters, took a seat in the compound and contemplated how the standoff might end for him.

abstract: Spats over trespassing, privacy and air rights are heating up as the little copters become more popular.

abstract: In this lesson, we provide a primer on the presidential nomination process using resources from The New York Times and around the Web, so students won’t just understand how candidates get nominated, but they will be challenged to think deeply about how the system works.

abstract: The company confirmed on Wednesday that Ms. Chiquet was departing “due to differences of opinion about the strategic direction of the company.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Twenty-four hours after Chanel’s Paris couture show was called among the best of the season, the company confirmed that Maureen Chiquet, chief executive of Chanel and one of the few women at the helm of a global luxury business, would leave at the end of this month.

headline: For Bloomberg, Ambition Vies With Caution

lead_paragraph: ONCE again, Michael R. Bloomberg is eyeing a run for the White House. Once again, he’s got the political world buzzing, the pundits pontificating. Once again, the country is waiting for him to decide yea or nay.

headline: Trial of Ivory Coast’s Laurent Gbagbo Will Test International Criminal Court
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The former leader of Ivory Coast will be the first ex-president to be tried by the court when it opens on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — To some of his countrymen, Laurent Gbagbo is nothing more than an executioner who oversaw the killings and rapes of dozens of people. To others, he has become a martyr and a hero who deserves freedom.

headline: One-Thing Shops: Pop-Up Books, Madrid
abstract: José Luis Pereira, the proprietor of Tres Rosas Amarillas in the city’s Malasaña neighborhood, encourages lingering at his little shop of wonders.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by Borges and Chandler, José Luis Pereira dedicated almost a decade to writing short stories, with works published in various literary anthologies — “but like every writer, I wanted to have my own bookshop, too,” he says. “And not just a generic bookshop, but a place of wonders where I could offer fellow literature lovers much more than the usual best sellers.” For four years, he did just this, running a small store specializing in short story collections and hosting occasional readings and workshops in the inner-city Malasaña neighborhood of Madrid. “Then the economic crisis began,” he recalls.

headline: Returning, Again, to American Drawing in the 1960s
abstract: A Dominique Lévy Gallery exhibition builds on a seminal 1976 MoMA show.
lead_paragraph: “Starting in the late ’60s, I think that drawing took a new form,” says the abstract painter Dorothea Rockburne. “For the most part, but not always — certainly not with Matisse — drawing had been a way of pre-thinking the structure in a painting. But drawing is not the orphan child of painting; it is a deep, material way of working.” Rockburne eyes the catalogue for the Museum of Modern Art’s 1976 exhibition “Drawing Now,” organized by Bernice Rose, folded over the armrest of her couch. “Drawing is exquisite, and Bernice picked up on that in her show, and Kate did, too.”

headline: App Smart | The Dating Game
abstract: Apps like Happn, Bumble and Glimpse offer an alternative to Tinder.
lead_paragraph: Apps like Happn, Bumble and Glimpse offer an alternative to Tinder.

headline: Video Feature: Finding a Valentine, With a Tap or a Swipe
abstract: Whether you’re looking for a date for Valentine’s Day or a long-term relationship, dating apps can make it easier to find a match.
lead_paragraph: ALL the cute red hearts, chocolates, flowers and poetry can get irritating this time of year if you’re searching for someone special. It doesn’t have to be that way. Technology continues to make it easier to find a romantic match, and many of the best tools are mobile apps.

headline: Europe Raises Pressure on Greece to Tighten Its Borders
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations']
abstract: European Union authorities filed a report saying Athens needs to slow the flow of migrants, the first step toward allowing countries to the north to extend border controls.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities on Wednesday raised pressure on Greece to step up its efforts to slow the flow of migrants and tighten control of the bloc’s external borders, the first step in a process that would allow some countries to its north to extend their border controls for up to two years.

abstract: At least 12 victims have been attacked by men wielding knives or razors in separate and seemingly random assaults in recent months.

headline: News Analysis: Why Donald Trump Walked

abstract: Donald J. Trump gave one reason for his decision to bolt from Thursday night’s debate on Fox News. There may have been others.

headline: Department of Justice Reaches Agreement With Ferguson
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An agreement between federal officials and leaders in Ferguson, Mo., released Wednesday seeks to overhaul the city’s beleaguered justice system. It calls for ending unlawful arrests, ensuring that the courts are independent of prosecutors and preserving people’s right to film police officers.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Germany, Poland, Greece and China.

headline: Review: Facing Marriage and Befriending a Squirrel in ‘The Portable Veblen’
abstract: Elizabeth McKenzie’s second novel examines the quirks of its title character, a serial appeaser named after a Norwegian economist, who approaches her nuptials.
lead_paragraph: One of the great pleasures of reading Elizabeth McKenzie is that she hears the musical potential in language that others do not — in the manufactured jargon of economics, in the Latin taxonomy of the animal kingdom, even in the names of our own humble body parts (who knew about the eye’s “zonule of Zinn”?). Her dialogue has real fizz and snappity-pop. It leaves a bubbled contrail.

headline: Review: Matan Porat Plays an Improvised Score to ‘The General’
abstract: The pianist performed at the 92nd Street Y as part of the Seeing Music Festival, which runs through Feb. 18.
lead_paragraph: Timing, momentum and pluck: That’s pretty much all that the young hero of Buster Keaton’s silent movie “The General” has going for him as he sets off to retrieve his locomotive, his girl and his honor in this madcap Civil War comedy from 1927. Timing, momentum and fierce technical chops were the main qualities the pianist Matan Porat brought to the stage on Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y when he performed an improvised score  to “The General” that was as propulsive, vivid and fun as the film itself.

headline: Talking to Christo About His Floating Piers
abstract: The artist spoke to high school students in Chelsea about the project, which is to open to the public in a northern Italian lake in June.
lead_paragraph: Christo, the artist known for large-scale public works like “The Gates” in Central Park, wasn’t exactly sure how to begin his lecture at a Manhattan school on Tuesday night. “I’m thinking of what Jeanne-Claude would say,” he said, referring to his wife and artistic partner, who died in 2009. “I miss her all the time, because my English is very poor, and my French is very poor. She was always talking.”

headline: With Purchase of BG Group, Shell’s Chief Bets on Oil Resurgence
abstract: Ben van Beurden’s $50 billion takeover of the BG Group, approved by Shell shareholders on Wednesday, needs $60-a-barrel oil to create economic value.
lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch Shell’s chief executive, Ben van Beurden, can breathe easier after shareholders backed his big gamble that oil prices would rebound. Only 17 percent of investors voted against his $50 billion takeover of the BG Group on Wednesday.

headline: The Oscars and Race: A Stir Over Rules to Change the Academy
abstract: Older members say a diversity initiative for the Oscars creates a new problem: ageism.
lead_paragraph: When the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences unveiled 20 all-white acting nominees this month, the furor was immediate. The #OscarsSoWhite hashtag, created last year, returned in force, and there was talk of an Oscar boycott. Then, last week, the academy declared that it was doubling its diversity push and ending guaranteed lifelong voting rights.

headline: Manhattan Construction Worker Injured in Fall Down Elevator Shaft
abstract: The man was not wearing safety equipment when he lost his balance at the site on West 17th Street, the New York City Buildings Department said. He was listed in critical condition.
lead_paragraph: A worker was critically injured at a construction site in Manhattan on Wednesday after he lost his balance on a ladder and fell into an elevator shaft, plummeting four stories and landing on metal bars, the authorities said.

headline: Review: ‘All Balanchine II’ by New York City Ballet
abstract: The performance, which used the cast from a canceled show on Saturday, showcased the dancers Sara Mearns and Tiler Peck.
lead_paragraph: Shall we blame the weather? The all-Balanchine program that New York City Ballet performed at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday went on as planned, but with a different cast — the one that had been slated for the preceding Saturday’s matinee. That show was canceled at the last minute because of the blizzard. Might this extremely rare change of plans have thrown the dancers off a little? The brilliance of the evening flickered.

headline: At Giorgio Armani Privé, a Delicate Couture Collection in Shades of Mauve
abstract: The designer’s feminine spring/summer 2016 collection included tulle, organza, silk — and jewels on everything from crinoline lace dresses to socks and stockings.
lead_paragraph: The designer’s feminine spring/summer 2016 collection included tulle, organza, silk — and jewels on everything from crinoline lace dresses to socks and stockings.

headline: Guo Pei: Couture
abstract: Couture from the designer who created Rihanna’s gown for the 2015 Met Gala.
lead_paragraph: Couture from the designer who created Rihanna’s gown for the 2015 Met Gala.

headline: Review: Emily Wells Layers Art-Pop, Filament by Filament
abstract: Ms. Wells’s new album, “Promise,” is dramatic and gothic, and full of ghostly sighs.
lead_paragraph: “Promise”

headline: Theranos Lab May Pose Threat to Patient Safety, Regulator Says
abstract: A federal regulator has given the blood-testing company 10 days to correct the problems, one of which it said posed a threat to patient safety.
lead_paragraph: A federal regulator has found that a lab run by Theranos, the Silicon Valley laboratory that promised to perform blood tests with a simple finger stick, violated several clinical standards, including one it said posed a threat to patient safety that had to be immediately corrected.

headline: Review: Florist Offers Skeletal Songs That Find Strength in Damage
abstract: The band’s first full-length album bubbles with an anxiety about mortality that flows from the singing and writing of Emily Sprague.
lead_paragraph: “The Birds Outside Sang”

headline: Review: Alessia Cara, Voice for Outsiders, Becomes an Insider
abstract: Ms. Cara, a young Canadian singer who got her start on YouTube, headlined at Webster Hall on Tuesday behind her 2015 debut album, “Know-It-All.”
lead_paragraph: Wallflowers have a champion in Alessia Cara, the 19-year-old Canadian singer and songwriter who headlined Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Ms. Cara’s lyrics pivot from self-doubt to self-affirmation in songs like “Wild Things,” which declares, “Don’t wanna hang around the in crowd/The cool kids aren’t cool to me.” The hit that sold out the club for Ms. Cara is “Here”: a jazzily sung, finely detailed depiction of a party she wishes she’d never attended. She calls herself an “antisocial pessimist” and sings on the chorus, “I ask myself, what am I doin’ here?” It’s far and away the best song on her 2015 debut album, “Know-It-All” (Def Jam).

headline: Bernie Sanders Insists He’ll Keep Pledge to Release Medical Records Before Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has said he plans to release his medical records before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has said that he plans to release his medical records before the Iowa caucuses on Monday. But with just five days to go, his campaign is not saying when exactly those records will be made public.

headline: January Letter From Government Regulators
abstract: A federal investigation of Theranos found in January that it violated several clinical standards, including one that it said posed an immediate threat to patient safety.
lead_paragraph: A federal investigation of Theranos found in January that it violated several clinical standards, including one that it said posed an immediate threat to patient safety.

headline: Review: In ‘This Is Acting,’ Sia Adheres to Her Victim-to-Victory Formula
abstract: The singer-songwriter’s new album is front-loaded with piano-centered ballad-anthems, all going for the biggest buildup.
lead_paragraph: “This Is Acting”

headline: Review: ‘You, Me and the Apocalypse’ Looks at the End
abstract: This new series on NBC stars Rob Lowe and Jenna Fischer in a story about the coming end of the world.
lead_paragraph: There has been so much apocalyptic television over the years that once in a while the genre needs a blast of fresh air to disperse some of the gloom and earnestness. Last winter, the offbeat Fox comedy “The Last Man on Earth,” created by and starring Will Forte, provided it. On Thursday night, “You, Me and the Apocalypse” takes on the task, making the end of the world an unpredictably enjoyable ride, as it ought to be.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Oregon, Bernie Sanders, Donald Trump
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Drake’s Secret Weapon Is All Set to Break Loose
abstract: Majid Jordan, a Toronto R&B duo, is about to release its first full-length album via Drake’s label, OVO Sound.
lead_paragraph: Most musicians perform live for the first time in front of a few close friends. Majid Jordan’s live debut came before a televised crowd of millions.

headline: Cate Blanchett to Make Broadway Debut in Play Directed by John Crowley
abstract: The work, “The Present,” is a new adaptation of a lesser-known Chekhov play that is often called “Platonov.”
lead_paragraph: Cate Blanchett, one of the most acclaimed actresses of her generation, will make her Broadway debut next season in a new adaptation of a lesser-known Chekhov play.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Fox News vs. Trump: Setting Free the Golden Goose
abstract: An argument for why Donald Trump’s war on Fox News is part of a battle against the power structure of the G.O.P. and against Fox as an extension of it.
lead_paragraph: Who would win in a fight: a Fox or a golden goose? We’re about to see.

headline: Ben Carson’s Campaign Beset With Frustration, Disappointment and Grief
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Once a front-runner in Iowa, Mr. Carson has faded as his advisers have quarreled, his grasp of foreign policy has been questioned, and a campaign worker was killed in a traffic accident.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — As Ben Carson got ready for a television interview beside the pulpit of a Pentecostal church this week, campaign aides asked his supporters to move across the room and sit in the empty pews behind him.

headline: Donald Trump Details His Debate Night Plans
abstract: Donald J. Trump is moving forward with his Thursday night campaign event, which will serve as counter-programming for the Republican presidential debate that he is skipping.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is moving forward with his Thursday night campaign event, which will serve as counter-programming for the Republican presidential debate that he has decided to skip.

headline: Samantha Hunt’s ‘Mr. Splitfoot,’ and More
abstract: New fiction by Ms. Hunt, Rachel Cantor, Belinda Bauer, Stuart Evers, Diane Williams and Tahar Ben Jelloun.
lead_paragraph: MR. SPLITFOOTBy Samantha Hunt 322 pages. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $24.

headline: Spotify Is Said to Be Seeking $500 Million in New Funds
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The streaming music service is seeking more money to better compete with rivals like Apple and Pandora, according to a person briefed on the plans.
lead_paragraph: Spotify is looking to raise at least $500 million in new funding to continue its global expansion and compete with powerful outlets like Apple, Pandora and Google, according to a person briefed on the company’s plans.

headline: The Supreme Court Rules for Common Sense in Electricity Case
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The decision will save consumers money and improve the reliability of the power grid.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court earlier this week upheld a federal regulation that encourages factories, shopping malls and other users of electricity to reduce their consumption during periods of high demand, like hot summer afternoons. The well-reasoned decision will save consumers money and improve the reliability of the electricity grid.

headline: Few Answers on When Flint Will Have Clean Water Again
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder would not say at a news conference when residents could begin to drink tap water, or when lead service lines would be replaced.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — More than three months after officials declared that Flint residents should not drink the lead-tainted water from their taps, people who live here are still lugging bottled water from a Walmart or firehouse back to their homes, where they use it to drink, prepare food, brush their teeth and bathe their children.

headline: Chris Christie Ratchets Up Attacks on Marco Rubio
abstract: Mr. Christie has long criticized Mr. Rubio for lacking executive experience, but he has dialed up his attacks, deriding the senator as a political lightweight in a tone that verges on contempt.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, smarting from weeks of negative commercials against him in New Hampshire, has struck back at several Republican opponents in animated appearances on the campaign trail this week.

headline: In Oregon, ‘This Is Less the End Than It Is the Beginning’
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: After Tuesday’s arrests and shooting of an anti-government protester near the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, what happens next?
lead_paragraph: “Why would the F.B.I. even want to come in here and risk bloodshed?” Jason Patrick, one of the armed protesters occupying the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon, wondered aloud to me a week and a half ago, as we stood smoking in the snow, watching the daily flow of trucks carrying volunteers and supplies into the compound. “Over a marsh with some birds in it? I don’t see it.”

headline: Report Exposes Widespread Abuses in Ticketing Industry in New York
abstract: The report from the New York attorney general portrays a complex business in which technologically adept ticket brokers are able to profit at the expense of ordinary fans.
lead_paragraph: Free tickets to an appearance by Pope Francis were resold for thousands of dollars, in ways that most likely violated New York State law.

headline: Ex-Department of Justice Lawyer Faces Penalties in Leak of N.S.A. Program
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The District of Columbia bar is pursuing ethics charges against Thomas M. Tamm, who said he told a New York Times reporter about warrantless wiretapping.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia bar is pursuing ethics charges against a former Department of Justice lawyer who has said he was one of the sources for a 2005 article in The New York Times about the National Security Agency’s program of wiretapping without warrants.

headline: M.T.A. Bans Hoverboards on Transit System
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Self-Balancing Two-Wheeled Boards', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Railroads', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)', 'Buses', 'Subways']
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is banning the motorized scooters from all buses, subways, train stations and commuter railroads amid reports of batteries exploding on the devices.
lead_paragraph: First it targeted manspreading. Now hoverboards.

headline: Gilead Faces Fights Over Hepatitis C and H.I.V. Drugs
keywords: ['Sovaldi (Drug)', 'Harvoni (Drug)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Hepatitis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The company may face legal action in Massachusetts unless it drops prices for its hepatitis C drugs. In California, it is being sued over patents for an H.I.V. treatment.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general of Massachusetts said on Wednesday that she had opened an inquiry into whether Gilead Sciences had violated state consumer protection laws by charging too much for its hepatitis C drugs.

headline: Anna Laerkesen, Danish Ballerina With Poetic Originality, Dies at 73
abstract: Ms. Laerkesen had huge success in the title role of “La Sylphide,” in which she was partnered by Erik Bruhn, Peter Martins and Rudolf Nureyev.
lead_paragraph: Anna Laerkesen, a leading ballerina in the Royal Danish Ballet who, breaking a traditional mold, won international acclaim for her poetic originality as a dancer in the 1960s and later as a choreographer, died on Jan. 14 in Copenhagen. She was 73.

headline: New Engineering Firm Called Upon to Fix Squibb Park Bridge
abstract: Park corporation officials said they were suing the firm of the bridge’s designer over the $4.1 million footbridge, which has been closed to the public since August 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation has finally acknowledged what everyone else has known for months: The $4.1 million Squibb Park Bridge, closed for 17 months, is not reopening anytime soon.

headline: Concepcion Picciotto, Who Kept Vigil by White House for Three Decades, Dies
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Ms. Picciotto maintained a peace vigil in Lafayette Park for more than 30 years in what is considered the longest political protest in American history.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s closest neighbor died on Monday, just a few days after vacating the peace vigil encampment behind the White House that she had occupied for more than 30 years in what was considered the longest political protest in American history.

headline: Rihanna’s New Album, ‘Anti,’ Is Leaked Online
abstract: The 13 songs appeared briefly, apparently by mistake, on Jay Z’s streaming service, Tidal.
lead_paragraph: The surprise release of a new Rihanna single, “Work,” went smoothly on Wednesday morning as the song shot to the top of the iTunes charts in dozens of countries. But by 7 p.m. Eastern time, what appeared to be her entire eighth album, “Anti,” had leaked online, another misstep in an already fraught rollout.

headline: Deprivation in Syria Deepens as U.N. Talks Loom
abstract: About half a million people are at risk of starving and more areas are cut off from aid, United Nations relief officials say.
lead_paragraph: Two top United Nations relief officials expressed growing frustration on Wednesday over the organization’s inability to deliver aid to destitute Syrians trapped by war, saying that the number of besieged areas has risen to 18 from 15 in the past few weeks and that nearly half a million people may be at risk of starving to death.

headline: Lawyers Assail ‘Runaway Grand Jury’ in Indictments of Abortion Opponents
abstract: A move is afoot to ask the district attorney not to proceed with the case against the two indicted figures in the Planned Parenthood case.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Lawyers for anti-abortion activists, including one who was a leading figure in the defeat of the city’s anti-discrimination ordinance last year, on Wednesday called this week’s indictments of Planned Parenthood critics legally flawed. They said they would ask the district attorney not to proceed with the case.

headline: Open Subway Cars May Come to New York City as Early as 2020
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could award a contract as early as next year to build 10 of them, officials said, bringing to life an idea that has been debated for years.
lead_paragraph: Moving from one subway car to another is no easy task.

headline: Other Candidates May Join Donald Trump Away From Debate
abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign manager said he had heard from other candidates about attending the event Mr. Trump will hold at the same time as the presidential debate he is skipping.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Donald J. Trump may have some company from other candidates at his counterprogramming event here on Thursday night during the Fox News-hosted Republican presidential campaign debate.

headline: Water Pollution in Hoosick Falls Prompts Action by New York State
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo directed two agencies to use testing, filtration systems and Superfund money to address a toxic chemical in the upstate village’s water supply.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Scrambling to contain an environmental scare in the small upstate village of Hoosick Falls, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo directed two New York State agencies on Wednesday to use Superfund money, filtration systems and testing to address the presence of a toxic chemical in the local water supply.

headline: Jets Become Latest N.F.L. Team to Settle a Wage Lawsuit Filed by Cheerleaders
keywords: ['Football', 'Cheerleaders', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: The Jets agreed to pay a total of $325,000 to 52 of the team’s dancers who worked from 2011 to 2013 for fixed pay that some said violated minimum wage laws.
lead_paragraph: The Jets have become the fourth team in the N.F.L. to settle a class-action lawsuit over wages paid to their cheerleaders.

headline: 100 Pounds of Heroin Found in Truck in Queens
abstract: Authorities from a drug enforcement task force said the drugs, with an estimated street value of $14 million, had been molded to fit in axle casings and a drive shaft in a truck bed.
lead_paragraph: Investigators this week found 100 pounds of heroin, with an estimated street value of $14 million, hidden in an axle and drive shaft casings in the bed of a pickup truck pulled over after a drug task force stakeout in Queens, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Sotheby’s Narrows Its Loss in Final All-Taubman Sale
abstract: The auction house sold $24,128,750 worth of Old Mastes artworks from the collection of its former chairman. That left it with a loss of $3 million, resulting from the hefty guarantee it had given his heirs.
lead_paragraph: In its final auction devoted wholly to its former chairman’s collection, Sotheby’s sold $24,128,750 worth of Old Master artworks on Wednesday night, right in the middle of the $21 million to $30 million it had projected.

headline: With Deals in Baseball, Opting Out Is Very In
abstract: This has been the winter of the opt-out clause. The Mets’ three-year, $75 million deal with Yoenis Cespedes, which allows him to make $27.5 million if he opts out after 2016, is the latest instance.
lead_paragraph: Dave Dombrowski had never given an opt-out clause. He had never seen a benefit for his team and had never faced the choice that confronted him this winter, his first as president of baseball operations for the Boston Red Sox. Dombrowski could give an opt-out to the free agent David Price or miss out on the ace his team needed.

headline: With No Détente, Donald Trump’s Feud With Fox Takes Center Stage
abstract: With Mr. Trump declaring he will skip Thursday’s debate, the most potentially consequential fight is no longer between him and his fellow Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: For months, Donald J. Trump had kept up a relentless and sometimes personal barrage against the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly, in retaliation for the tough — and, he said, unfair — questioning she submitted him to in the first Republican debate last summer. And for months, Fox News and Ms. Kelly had avoided taking the bait, intent on sticking to Ms. Kelly’s vow to avoid becoming part of the story.

headline: Marvin Lipofsky, Ceramist Who Elevated Blown Glass to Fine Art, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Lipofsky worked glass into small-scale biomorphic shapes with a dazzling array of surface textures produced by cutting, grinding and sandblasting.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Lipofsky, a founder of the studio-glass movement, which took blown glass from the realm of interior decoration and functionality and showed its potential as a fine-arts medium, died on Jan. 15 in Oakland, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Mets Got Cespedes With a Give-and-Take: More Money but Fewer Years
abstract: The Mets’ agreement with the slugger Yoenis Cespedes and his agent came together “very late,” the team’s general manager, Sandy Alderson, said.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the agent for Yoenis Cespedes, Brodie Van Wagenen, called Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson and requested a more substantive conversation, setting in motion the process that brought Cespedes back to the Mets.

headline: Reports of Zika-Linked Birth Defect Rise in Brazil
abstract: Health authorities said reported cases of microcephaly — a condition in which newborns have abnormally small heads — had climbed to 4,180 since October. Brazil typically has 150 cases annually.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s health ministry issued new figures on Wednesday about the Zika virus that offered reason for continued concern, but also a glimmer of hope.

headline: Walt Williams, Outfielder Known as No Neck, Dies at 72
abstract: Williams, a free-swinging outfielder who played most of his career with the White Sox, was probably best known for the unusual physique that earned him an unusual nickname.
lead_paragraph: Walt Williams, a high-energy, free-swinging outfielder who played for four major league teams but who was probably best known for the unusual physique that earned him the nickname No Neck, died on Saturday in Abilene, Tex. He was 72.

headline: New York Will Shed Clock for Some Statewide Tests
abstract: The English and math exams given to third- through eighth- grade students will no longer be timed, the State Education Department said, ending the call of “pencils down.”
lead_paragraph: Statewide exams given to third- through eighth-grade students in New York will no longer be timed, the State Education Department said on Wednesday, ending the call of “pencils down.”

headline: Change of U.S. Command Set in Afghanistan
abstract: President Obama nominated Lt. Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr. to lead American military operations, replacing Gen. John F. Campbell.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Lt. Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr. to lead American military operations in Afghanistan, where the United States is at a critical juncture in the fight against the Taliban, the Pentagon said on Wednesday.

headline: Review: ‘I and You’ Is Lauren Gunderson’s Sentimental Character Study
abstract: This play revolves around two high school students and a link to Walt Whitman.
lead_paragraph: If you have dipped into the tear-filled pools of young adult literature — or the films inspired by it — you have probably encountered a couple like Caroline and Anthony. They’re the sparring, sparking high school students in “I and You,” Lauren Gunderson’s perky two-character study in adolescent confusions and cosmic mysteries, which opened on Wednesday at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Party Staple
abstract: Elizabeth C. Gorski throws a party.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Let me float this by you: It’s Thursday, so it wouldn’t be out of place for there to be some sort of “trick” today, right? As “tricks” go, a rebus is not a terribly complicated one, but what if, in addition to the rebus, there was an extra layer of goodness?

headline: A Fox News Host Implores Donald Trump to Debate. It’s Still No.
abstract: Bill O’Reilly said he thought Mr. Trump had erred in skipping the final face-off before the Iowa caucuses and defended Megyn Kelly, but he couldn’t change the candidate’s mind.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, boycotting the Fox News debate but not one of the network’s hosts, insisted to Bill O’Reilly on Wednesday night that he wasn’t “walking away” from a tough situation even as Mr. O’Reilly said he thought Mr. Trump had erred in skipping the final face-off before the Iowa caucuses and pleaded with him to change his mind.

headline: Donald Trump, Barely Mentioning Debate, Returns to the Comfort Zone of a Large Rally
abstract: Speaking near the South Carolina capital, Donald J. Trump made only a brief mention of his dispute with Fox News and its anchor Megyn Kelly.
lead_paragraph: GILBERT, S.C. — The political world was still shaking with the news that Donald J. Trump would sit out the next debate, but on Wednesday night the candidate himself, full of self-flattery and short on time, barely mentioned it.

headline: Unsealed Complaint: United States v. Bundy, et al
abstract: The criminal complaint against eight arrested on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The criminal complaint against eight arrested on Tuesday night.

headline: Serena Williams Routs Radwanska and Nears a 22nd Major Title
abstract: Williams, who dominated Agnieszka Radwanska, 6-0, 6-4, needs one victory to capture her seventh Australian Open championship and tie Steffi Graf’s Open-era record of 22 Grand Slam singles titles.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — As Serena Williams recovered from a run at history that ended with the finish line in sight, Agnieszka Radwanska spent the months following the 2015 United States Open chasing titles all over Asia, winning in Japan, China, the Women’s Tennis Association finals in Singapore and, at the start of this year, again in China.

headline: Queens Man Sought in Shooting Death of His Girlfriend
abstract: The police said Tyquan Long, 29, shot Joann Gravette, 36, after accusing her of cheating on him, and then wounded a neighbor.
lead_paragraph: The police on Wednesday were searching for a man who they said shot and killed his 36-year-old girlfriend in their Queens apartment, then wounded a neighbor whose son he thought was having an affair with her.

headline: Obama Takes First Step in a Cancer ‘Moonshot’
keywords: ['Cancer', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: President Obama signed a presidential memorandum creating a White House task force on cancer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed a presidential memorandum on Thursday creating a White House task force on cancer, the first step in what Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has called a “moonshot” to cure the disease, administration officials said.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | augury
abstract: This word has appeared in four New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: augury • \ˈȯ-gyə-re, -gə-\ • noun

headline: New York Arts Organizations Lack the Diversity of Their City
abstract: New York’s cultural sector is still more diverse than arts institutions on the national level, according to a survey released by the city’s Cultural Affairs Department.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s cultural sector does not match the demographic diversity of the its population, though the sector is more diverse than arts organizations on the national level, according to a survey released on Thursday by the city’s Cultural Affairs Department.

headline: Fox Names Golf Analyst
abstract: Fox Sports named Paul Azinger its lead golf analyst, a week after the company parted with Greg Norman.
lead_paragraph: Fox Sports named Paul Azinger its lead golf analyst, a week after the company parted with Greg Norman. Azinger has worked for ABC and ESPN for a decade; Norman was a novice at broadcasting when Fox hired him last year.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: “You, Me, and the Apocalypse” plays doomsday for laughs. Josh Gad touches himself in “Lip Sync Battle.” And Danny starts to unravel Alex’s identity in “London Spy.”
lead_paragraph: “You, Me, and the Apocalypse” plays doomsday for laughs. Josh Gad makes like Donald Trump and rides a wrecking ball in “Lip Sync Battle.”

headline: Corrections: January 28, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, January 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: After Factory Closing, Iowans Live Realities of Global Economy
abstract: When Electrolux closed its factory in an Iowa town, residents learned how globalization is more than just a buzzword tossed about during presidential caucuses.
lead_paragraph: When Electrolux closed its factory in an Iowa town, residents learned how globalization is more than just a buzzword tossed about during presidential caucuses.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “They keep telling us, ‘We don’t know when you can drink it again.’ How much longer can we keep doing this, using bottled water for everything?”

headline: After Factory Closing, Iowans Live Realities of Global Economy
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Photography', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: When Electrolux closed its factory in a small Iowa town, residents learned how globalization is more than just a buzzword tossed about during presidential caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Every fourth winter, Iowa’s cities and small towns become the center of nonstop attention from political elites as presidential hopefuls court voters while media scrums record closely stage-managed campaign events. For photojournalists, this process of recording campaign set pieces can lead to a distorted and shallow view not just of the candidates but also of Iowans (who are pretty much left alone after the quadrennial spotlight).

headline: Zika Virus Requires an Urgent Response
abstract: The World Health Organization must coordinate a broad international response to the spread of the virus.
lead_paragraph: No sooner was the Ebola virus subdued in Africa than another virus, Zika, began sweeping through South and Central America. It has been linked to serious birth defects and is threatening to invade the United States. It is imperative that the World Health Organization not repeat its sluggish response to the Ebola crisis and act urgently this time to mobilize international action.

headline: Deconstructing Hillary and Bernie
abstract: Let’s look at how the two Democratic candidates — Martin who? — differ.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential race hasn’t been getting as much attention as the Republican side. This is for the same reason that professional wrestling gets more viewers than “Book TV.” There’s something compelling about a lot of grunting and body slams.

Bush did something fascinating: On the campaign trail he preached “compassionate conservatism,” telling wealthy Republicans about the travails of Mexican-American immigrants and declaring to women in pearls that “the hardest job in America” is that of a single mother.

abstract: Wall Street won’t like it, but a transaction tax on the trading of stocks, bonds and derivatives would serve the public.
lead_paragraph: A financial transaction tax — a per-trade charge on the buying and selling of stocks, bonds and derivatives — is an idea whose time has finally come. It has begun percolating in the Democratic presidential campaign, with all three candidates offering proposals.

Most recently, she won a Golden Globe and has been nominated for an Academy Award for her role as a Polish-Armenian computer marketing guru (“Steve Jobs”).

headline: Couture Season Ends With Valentino and Guo Pei
abstract: The diversity — from Beijing, Russia, the Netherlands and that legendary house in Rome — illustrates how couture is quietly expanding.

keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The presidential campaign was the talk of Congress on Wednesday, as, among other things, Harry Reid, the Democratic leader from Nevada, went to the floor to retract previous joking comments he had made to reporters that he was “kind of pulling for” Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: With the Iowa caucuses just days away, the fractious presidential primary campaign was the talk of Capitol Hill on Wednesday. Senator Harry Reid, for one, probably wishes he had stayed quiet on the subject of Donald J. Trump.

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The match that broke a 22-22 tie started out as a mismatch.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: Reading the Donald Trump Tea Leaves

lead_paragraph: Good morning from Iowa, where seven Republicans are preparing for Thursday night’s debate, the last one before Iowans caucus, and where one high-profile abstainer is not.

headline: Hugh Hewitt Doesn’t Care for Billionaires
abstract: The radio host talks about moderating the presidential debates, Trump rallies and limiting wealth.
lead_paragraph: When CNN announced that you would join the team moderating its Republican presidential debates, you justified your inclusion, despite being a partisan journalist, by saying that conservative-specific issues are not the standard issues we hear about. Do you think your presence has changed the debates? Yes. And the debates are working. They’re working very, very well, in fact. A very sophisticated group of voters is absorbing information. I compare it to the way you combat a serious illness. You accumulate information about the illness as you go along. The country’s really sick, so we’re getting a lot of information.

headline: Helen Macdonald: By the Book
abstract: The author of “H Is for Hawk” and, most recently, “Shaler’s Fish” says “reading mystery novels is hugely comforting when you’re freaking out about your own writing.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “H Is for Hawk” and, most recently, “Shaler’s Fish” says “reading mystery novels is hugely comforting when you’re freaking out about your own writing.”

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Cracker Barrel
abstract: Can you love the South but loathe what it was built on? The restaurant chain and I, we try.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, my family went on a road trip from Houston to Toronto — the place where my parents first lived when they immigrated from the Philippines — and along the way, we stopped at every single Cracker Barrel we saw. I can’t remember exactly why we did this, but its effects on my psyche have proved long-lasting. Even now, a Cracker Barrel works on me like Vegas on gambling addicts or Disney World on children: I know the optimism is fleeting and the fantasy is imagined, but I never manage to keep my cool.

headline: Review: ‘The Finest Hours’ Stars Chris Pine, Leading a Mission Against All Odds
abstract: Based on a real-life 1952 rescue of men aboard a tanker in a brutal storm, this nostalgic film also features Casey Affleck as a heroic shipboard engineer.
lead_paragraph: The waterlogged disaster movie “The Finest Hours” is a moderately gripping whoosh of nostalgia that shamelessly recycles the ’50s cliché of the squeaky-clean all-American hero. In this Disney movie, adapted from a book by Michael J. Tougias and Casey Sherman and based on real events in February 1952, Bernie Webber (Chris Pine), a Coast Guard sailor based in Chatham, Mass., leads a next-to-impossible rescue mission during the most fearsome nor’easter this side of “The Perfect Storm.”

headline: In Vermont, the Lure of Skiing in the Mad River Valley
abstract: The Mad River Valley in central Vermont is home to two of the most prized ski areas in the Eastern United States: Sugarbush and Mad River Glen.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I was skiing high above the Sugarbush resort in Vermont with John Egan, a legend of extreme skiing 20 years before the genre had even been identified. Mr. Egan has starred in audacious ski movies from Argentina to Siberia and everywhere in between. He could live almost anywhere, his teaching skills and reputation making him welcome at dozens of skiing resorts. But he has instead called Mad River Valley in central Vermont home for decades.

headline: The Generosity in Senegalese Stew
abstract: Learning how to cook chicken mafe includes unexpected lessons in hospitality.
lead_paragraph: Rama Dione rubbed chicken with heady garlic and ginger before simmering it with onions and tomato paste. She thickened the pot with a serious amount of peanut butter, and when the sauce cooked to a blanketing gravy, I marveled at the deep, nutty flavor of the dish called chicken mafe. It’s believed to have origins in Mali, then to have spread to the rest of West Africa, and from there across the Atlantic to the American South, where it evolved into Virginia peanut soup. I asked Rama’s husband, Papa Diagne, why he thought this dish became so popular in his native Senegal, hoping to find a little homesick romance. ‘‘We have a lot of peanuts,’’ he said. ‘‘We had to find something to do with them.’’

headline: In ‘Kung Fu Panda 3,’ a New Dad Who Talks Like Bryan Cranston
abstract: The film’s central character, voiced by Jack Black, reunites with his long-lost father just as all of China is menaced by a fearsome beast.
lead_paragraph: “Kung Fu Panda 2,” in 2011, ended with a surprise: The title panda, genial Po (Jack Black), wasn’t an orphan, after all. So we knew that when “Kung Fu Panda 3” inevitably came along, it would be about Po’s reunion with the father he hadn’t seen since he was a cub.

headline: Anticipating the Metrics of a Trumpless Debate
abstract: The hypothetical question of what would happen at the Republican debates without Donald J. Trump has loomed over the first six face-offs. That question is about to be answered.
lead_paragraph: The hypothetical question of what would happen at the Republican debates without Donald J. Trump has loomed over the first six face-offs. That question is about to be answered.

headline: What Does a Parrot Know About PTSD?
abstract: An unexpected bond between damaged birds and traumatized veterans could reveal surprising insights into animal intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years ago, Lilly Love lost her way. She had just completed her five-year tour of duty as an Alaska-based Coast Guard helicopter rescue swimmer, one of an elite team of specialists who are lowered into rough, frigid seas to save foundering fishermen working in dangerous conditions. The day after she left active service, the helicopter she had flown in for the previous three years crashed in severe weather into the side of a mountain, killing six of her former crewmates. Devastated by the loss and overcome with guilt, Love chose as her penance to become one of the very fishermen she spent much of her time in the Coast Guard rescuing. In less than a year on the job, she nearly drowned twice after being dragged overboard in high seas by the hooks of heavy fishing lines.

headline: The Challenger Space Shuttle Disaster, 30 Years Later
keywords: ['Challenger (Space Shuttle)', 'Space Shuttles', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, remains one of the worst accidents of the American space program.
lead_paragraph: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, remains one of the worst accidents of the American space program.

headline: Williams vs. Graf, and Graf’s Disciple

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The previous hour had been a blur for Angelique Kerber, who was digesting a lot on Thursday: the first Grand Slam semifinal victory of her 14-year professional career, a postmatch meal and sound bites rationed to the news media. She had one more treat to savor, which she waited to open until after fulfilling her news media obligations.

headline: Patients, and Doctors, Aren’t Dying at Home
abstract: Doctors, it turns out, aren’t much different than everyone else when it comes to where they die.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of one of my long-time patients recently pulled me aside to ask, uncomfortably, “What do I do if … when … my mother dies at home?” Her mother was 90 and had been hospitalized, again, for difficulty breathing. We were able to get her back home and, thankfully, avoid the intensive care unit. She’d already signed a do-not-resuscitate order and had specified that she did not want intubation.

headline: Zika Virus ‘Spreading Explosively’ in Americas, W.H.O. Says

Those aboard were startled, news reports said, and the pilot decided to fly back to London.

headline: The Four Big Questions About Donald Trump’s Chances
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: To win the nomination, he will have to meet the challenges of turnout, negative advertising, a winnowed field and possible hostility from party elites.

Some prominent members of the party’s beleaguered establishment have backed him against Ted Cruz, and Mr. Trump now leads in Iowa. It gives him a chance to run the table in the early states over a still divided field of mainstream candidates.

headline: Review: Rihanna, Blissfully Adrift, Juggles Styles on ‘Anti’
abstract: Depending on the moment, she is an electric vocalist or an indifferent one, an emotional savant or a naif, Jon Caramanica writes. And this is her eighth album.
lead_paragraph: There are vocal powerhouse pop stars, who dominate with the sheer magnitude of their gift; kaleidoscopically vivid pop stars, who dazzle with enthusiasm and energy; diligent pop stars, who chip away at success until they strike oil; cheeky pop stars, who understand the absurdity of the situation but manage to convincingly stay the course.

headline: Russians Learn the Ways of the Cowboy From American Ranch Hands
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Cowboys and Cowgirls', 'Cattle', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Russian landowners trying to increase domestic agriculture production are using trainers from the United States to teach workers about riding horses and herding cattle.
lead_paragraph: VALUETS, Russia — A visibly tiring but stubborn Aberdeen Angus cow sank all of her four feet in the rich black mud of central Russia, refusing to budge. Try as they might, the two Russians yanking on the rope lassoed around her wide, wet neck could not pull that massive body out of the icy December slush.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s Lucrative Long View
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg has told investors over and over: Don’t expect Facebook to focus much on quarterly earnings. The company is taking the long view. But that long view is sure looking spectacular in quarterly earnings.
