headline: Disconnecting From a Virtual Private Network
abstract: If you do not want your VPN app to start up every time you use the Internet, you can adjust its settings.
lead_paragraph: Q. I installed a virtual private network program on my iPhone to use for protection when public Wi-Fi was the only connection option around, but now I can’t turn it off. In the iPhone’s connection settings, I keep flipping the VPN button to Off, but it turns itself back on. What do I do?

headline: 24 Die After Iraqi Kurdish Refugees’ Boat Sinks Off Greek Island
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Kurds', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: More than 3,700 migrants died while trying to enter Europe via the Mediterranean last year, and the latest accident was a reminder that the flow has not stopped.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At least 24 people drowned and 11 others were missing after a boat carrying Iraqi Kurds sank off the Greek island of Samos in the Aegean Sea, close to the Turkish coast, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Ford’s Annual Profit Surges to $7.4 Billion
abstract: Lifted by strong sales in North America, the automaker said that it earned $1.9 billion in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Record sales in the American auto industry last year translated into big profits for Ford Motor, which on Thursday said that it earned $7.4 billion in 2015 primarily because of strong sales in the United States market.

headline: Must Rhodes Fall?
abstract: Campus iconoclasm has come to Oxford. But scrubbing awkward facts from history is a dangerous trend.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When America catches a cold, Britain sneezes — eventually. The argument about the proper limits of free speech and “political correctness” that has raged for years on American campuses has arrived at British universities with a vengeance.

headline: Washington Gives $1.3 Million in Parking Fines During Snowstorm
abstract: People who did not move their cars from snow emergency routes during the storm received $250 fines, and even more if their cars were towed.
lead_paragraph: During its six-day snow emergency, the city of Washington, D.C., reportedly issued thousands of parking tickets carrying $1.3 million in fines.

headline: A Paul Taylor American Modern Dance Program for $5
abstract: Tickets for a triple bill by Paul Taylor American Modern Dance on March 15 will cost $5.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor American Modern Dance has added a performance to its coming season: a triple bill that, while resembling other programs of Taylor favorites, differs in one key respect. All tickets cost $5.

headline: Todd Haynes Collects Images to Guide the Feel of His Films
abstract: The director of “Carol” and other films creates image books that later influence what is seen on the screen.
lead_paragraph: The first shot of the drama “Carol” begins on a subway grate and tilts up to reveal the bustling streets of 1950s New York. That shot and the many that follow show art deco hotels, crowded and meticulously designed department stores, beautiful suburban homes, and smart fashions, and they sometimes feel as if they were taken from the pages of magazines or photography books that depicted the period. And in a way, they were.

headline: 1941: Axis Forces Rally in Italy
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New life flows into the Axis war machine in the Mediterranean in 1941.
lead_paragraph: ROME — New life, vigorous and confident, is flowing into the Axis’s war machine in the Mediterranean zone, and while neither the daily communiques of the high command nor the Italian press gives any hint of it, a mighty counter-offensive against the Greco-British forces in Albania is being carefully prepared. The Fascist regime has more reason now to be confident that the tide of battle may shortly turn against the British in the Mediterranean region than it had before the recent meeting between Fuehrer Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini in Germany. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 29, 1941

headline: Corporate Lawyers Say They Are Spending More In-House
abstract: A study says the increase is a result of more regulatory scrutiny as corporate dealings become increasingly multinational.
lead_paragraph: Chief legal officers at corporations in 41 countries say they are spending more — and hiring more staff members — in-house, according to a new study by the Association of Corporate Counsel, a legal professionals membership group, that asked 1,300 corporate lawyers and chief legal officers.

headline: Art Institute of Chicago Names New Director: James Rondeau
abstract: Mr. Rondeau, the curator of modern and contemporary art at the institute, will succeed Douglas Druick.
lead_paragraph: James Rondeau, a contemporary-art curator who has organized several highly regarded exhibitions over the last decade, has been named the new director of the Art Institute of Chicago, where he has worked for 18 years and recently helped to usher in one of the museum’s largest art donations.

headline: Barbie Adds Curvy and Tall to Body Shapes
abstract: Mattel has unveiled curvy, petite and tall versions of its fashion doll whose unrealistically thin shape has drawn criticism for decades. Sales have plunged as Barbie has struggled to remain relevant.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Barbie’s body, it will no longer be one size fits all.

headline: José Limón Dance Foundation Appoints New Artistic Director
abstract: Colin Connor, a former soloist with Limón Dance Company who went on to a career in choreography and education, returns, to the foundation.
lead_paragraph: Colin Connor, a former soloist with Limón Dance Company who went on to a career in choreography and education, is returning to the José Limón Dance Foundation as its artistic director.

headline: Russian Dissident Artist Is Said to Be Sent for Psychiatric Evaluation
abstract: Pyotr Pavlensky was taken to a hospital notorious for giving insanity diagnoses to political dissidents in the Soviet period, raising worries about a revival of politicized psychiatry.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian prosecutors have sent a dissident performance artist best known for having nailed his scrotum to Red Square to a psychiatric hospital for evaluation, his partner, Oksana Shalygina, said on Thursday.

headline: For House Democrats, Support for Obama Agenda Came at a Cost
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The first time the president met with House Democrats, in 2009, there were 257 of them. Now there are 188. Some point a finger at him.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When President Obama addressed the annual retreat for House Democratic lawmakers in 2009, the event had the buoyant exuberance of a pep rally as he urged his party’s robust majority — then 257 members strong — to help muscle through his economic stimulus plan.

headline: It’s Still Bill Clinton, but the Old Magic Seems to Be Missing
abstract: As the former president tries to energize his wife’s campaign, even some of his admirers wonder about his more subdued style and faded magnetism.
lead_paragraph: MASON CITY, Iowa — Bill Clinton came to vote-rich Mason City on Wednesday night and recounted his wife’s life experiences, recited her policy ideas, and ripped into the Republicans a bit. But what Mr. Clinton used to do so well, and what Hillary Clinton needs only days before the Iowa caucuses on Monday, was nowhere to be found: a polished, piercing critique of an opponent, in this case Bernie Sanders.

headline: ‘Making a Murderer’ Town’s Answer to Netflix Series: You Don’t Know
keywords: ['Web-Original Programming', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Television', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: A reporter goes back to Manitowoc County, Wis., where residents who considered the 10-year-old case settled are being second-guessed about Steven Avery’s return to prison.
lead_paragraph: MANITOWOC, Wis. — In the tourism office here, where workers are accustomed to cheery inquiries about Manitowoc County’s best jogging paths and beach views, the questions have suddenly turned dark: How could you possibly promote tourism in such a corrupt town? Why would anyone visit here?

headline: Marsannay, Modest but Fully Realized Burgundy
abstract: These French reds are good values and excellent introductions to the possibilities of a wine that has sealed its status as a luxury commodity.
lead_paragraph: Of the many beautiful things about good red Burgundy, the most striking is the way the wine keeps changing before you. From the moment you open a bottle and pour the first glass, a cascade of elusive aromas and flavors captures your attention.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Etna Rosso
abstract: Inviting readers to taste fresh, energetic reds that are pure, elegant, subtle and vivacious.
lead_paragraph: From the ancient vineyards of Burgundy, we travel to the newly emerging region of Etna in Sicily.

headline: The Coming Mess in Venezuelan Debt
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: With oil prices low, and $10 billion in debt due this year, many challenges to a restructuring await.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always considered sovereign debt to be as much about politics as debt.

headline: The Meaning Behind ‘Bernie’s Yearning’
abstract: Ben Cohen, a co-founder of Ben & Jerry’s, explained the company’s new Bernie Sanders-themed ice cream flavor.
lead_paragraph: Ben Cohen, a co-founder of Ben & Jerry’s, explained the company’s new Bernie Sanders-themed ice cream flavor.

headline: 1966: Attack on Vietnam Policies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Senator Fulbright leads a revolt on President Johnson’s Vietnam policy in 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sen. J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, sparked an open revolt on Capitol Hill against President Johnson’s Vietnam policies. In a four-hour inquisition of Secretary Dean Rusk, Sen. Fulbright joined other Democratic members of his committee in questioning the basic assumptions of U.S. policy in Southeast Asia during the last 15 years. Committee members said the interrogation was the sharpest grilling that Mr. Rusk had ever received in Congress during his entire five-year career as secretary of state. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 29, 1966

headline: In Greece’s Populism, Precious Lessons for Europe
abstract: Anyone who thinks Warsaw or Budapest will give in to pressure on issues of national sovereignty should look at how far the Greeks were prepared to go.
lead_paragraph: Athens — It may just be coincidence, but in the year since a radical left movement and an extreme right-wing party joined forces to govern Greece, the resilience of the European Union has been tested. But it may be also that the forces released in Greece have emerged in many other countries, poisoning relations among member states.

headline: How the Zika Virus Is Affecting Travel
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Cruises', 'Travel Warnings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: As alarm grows over Zika, airlines are allowing passengers to change flights or receive refunds, and some tour companies are seeing cancellations.
lead_paragraph: The travel industry is beginning to react as vacationers rethink their trips amid growing concern over the Zika virus, the mosquito-borne disease that experts say is possibly linked to microcephaly in babies. The spread of the virus has led the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to warn pregnant women and those planning to become pregnant against travel to affected areas, including popular Caribbean tourist destinations like Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands and Barbados, as well as Mexico, Brazil and Panama.

headline: A Menu With Perfume at Its Core
abstract: To celebrate smells both natural and synthetic, chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten recently created dishes based on the scent notes of a line of perfumes.
lead_paragraph: Chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten put another perfume blotter to his discerning nostrils — the eighth of 26 he would sniff on a recent afternoon. His eyes rolled up in concentration, looking beyond the dining room ceiling of his flagship restaurant. What was his encyclopedic mind of flavors seeing? “Berries,” he guessed tentatively.

headline: Rouhani Goes Shopping in Europe as Iran Enjoys New Economic Freedoms
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With the lifting of sanctions, President Hassan Rouhani is on a state visit to Europe, signing multimillion-dollar deals for goods that Iran was unable to buy for years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Europe, whose economic struggles have grown that much greater with recent problems in crucial markets like China and Russia, is rushing to do business with a newly accessible and eager, if still problematic, partner: Iran.

headline: How to Watch the G.O.P. Debate
abstract: The Republican presidential candidates debated in Des Moines on Thursday night. Here is how to follow it.
lead_paragraph: Following is immediate real-time analysis of the seventh Republican debate. Read additional fact checks here.

headline: Candidates and God on the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Exactly how much does religion matter to American voters?
lead_paragraph: The expectation from organized church groups that political candidates must bear emphatic witness to a belief in God is giving rise to a rich array of candidate comments this time around the primary circuit.

headline: Berlin Show Features German Ethnologist’s Copies of Art From Prehistoric Times
abstract: The Martin-Gropius-Bau is showing “Art of Prehistoric Times: Rock Paintings from the Frobenius Collection” through May 16.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Among the exhibitions at the fledgling Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1937 was a show of 150 watercolor copies of prehistoric rock paintings and engravings that, the museum noted, had been selected by its director, Alfred H. Barr Jr.

headline: On the Beat of Black Lives and Bloodshed
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Gun Control', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The exhausting dance between black death and black scribe is journalism and catharsis.
lead_paragraph: IN my early years as a police reporter, I often pulled up to a crime scene minutes before the homicide detectives arrived. Too many times to count I’d find a young black man my age or younger dead with a halo of blood or brain matter splashed on the pavement. Often there were shell casings sprinkled around freshly fallen bodies.

headline: Protecting Water and Wildlife
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The president of American Rivers opposes a House bill that he says would “stack the deck for powerful energy companies.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bomb Kills 8 in Yemen Near President’s Residence
abstract: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi was unhurt in the blast, which hit a checkpoint nearby. But it underscored the government’s tenuous hold on security.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — A bomb-packed car driven by a suicide attacker exploded at a checkpoint near the presidential palace in the southern city of Aden on Thursday, and security officials said at least eight people were killed.

headline: To Text or Not to Text: A Dating Conundrum
abstract: The promise of a romance was disrupted by a guy who seemed content to let his fingers do the talking.
lead_paragraph: Check out our new Modern Love podcast.

headline: Phil Jackson’s Vision for the Knicks: How It Looks in Year 2
abstract: In his first full season as Knicks president, Jackson said his experiment had “fallen flat on its face.” After a year of progress, the team can be seen as a sturdy rebuild.
lead_paragraph: One year ago this week, Phil Jackson sat down in a Midtown Manhattan restaurant to discuss the sorry state of the Knicks and spoke what might have been the most humbling words of his charmed professional life.

headline: Iowa’s Republican Governor Warms Even More to Donald Trump
abstract: Iowa’s Republican governor, Terry E. Branstad, declined to criticize Donald J. Trump for his decision to skip Thursday night’s presidential debate, but he also marveled at what he described as the Trump phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, a Republican and the longest-serving governor in American history, is something of a guardian of the Iowa presidential caucuses.

headline: Armed Man Arrested at Disneyland Paris
abstract: A 28-year-old man carrying two guns, ammunition and a Quran was arrested at a hotel in Disneyland Paris, adding to security fears in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A 28-year-old man carrying two guns, ammunition and a Quran was arrested at a hotel in Disneyland Paris on Thursday afternoon, according to a Disney executive, raising a new round of fear two months after 130 people were killed in a coordinated series of terrorist attacks on the French capital.

headline: Riding in Shepard’s Posse: Actors Talk About ‘Buried Child’
abstract: Sam Shepard’s play has had two major New York productions; a third is coming to the New Group. Cast members in each have something to say about it.
lead_paragraph: Actors who have worked on the three major New York productions of Sam Shepard’s “Buried Child” — the 1978 Theater for the New City premiere; the 1996 Broadway run; and the New Group revival that begins performances on Tuesday, Feb. 2 — share stories about performing in the play. ALEXIS SOLOSKI

headline: Senate Democrats Seeking Federal Aid for Flint Crisis
abstract: The lawmakers said they would request $600 million in federal aid to help Michigan address the contaminated water emergency in the city.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats said Thursday they would seek $600 million in federal aid to help Michigan clean up the contaminated water emergency in the city of Flint, the most far-reaching financial solution proposed to manage the crisis.

headline: N.R.A. Victories in Congress Grow With Chief Lobbyist’s Role
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: Chris Cox, who leads the National Rifle Association’s political action committee, has emerged as the group’s point man in pushing to defeat new gun control laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after the massacre last month in San Bernardino, Calif., Senate Democrats, sensing an opportunity, rushed to pass a measure denying guns to anyone on the no-fly terrorism watch list. The timing of the vote and the nature of the bill gave them reason to hope that they could, for once, thwart the gun lobby.

headline: At Paris Couture, Viktor & Rolf’s Wearable Art — and Giant Cubist-Inspired Masks
abstract: The house’s all-white collection was inspired by a simple polo shirt and culminated in a theatrical show that included outsize sculptures over models’ heads.
lead_paragraph: The house’s all-white collection was inspired by a simple polo shirt and culminated in a theatrical show that included outsize sculptures over models’ heads.

headline: Sam Shepard Takes Stock of ‘Buried Child’ and the Writer’s Life
abstract: Mr. Shepard comments on his play, soon to have its third major production in New York; his upbringing; and the limitations he finds in his own oeuvre.
lead_paragraph: “You change,” the playwright and actor Sam Shepard said. “You go through all kinds of contortions. But the play is the same.”

headline: In a First, the Rio Games Will Include a Team of Refugees
abstract: In an attempt to draw attention to refugees, a small team of them will compete under the Olympic flag at the Summer Games, the president of the I.O.C. said.
lead_paragraph: A small team of international refugee athletes will participate in the Summer Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro this year, Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Video: The Inspiration for Ben & Jerry’s Bernie Sanders Ice Cream
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, the ice cream makers, detailed the inspiration for their new flavor, Bernie’s Yearning, named for the Democratic presidential candidate who represents their home state of Vermont in the Senate.

headline: ‘Affluenza Teen’ Returns From Mexico
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: A judge could decide to give Ethan Couch up to 120 days in prison after he fled the country while on probation for killing four people in a drunken-driving crash.
lead_paragraph: Ethan Couch, the 18-year-old from Texas better known to the tabloids and the 24-hour cable news cycle as the “affluenza teen,” returned Thursday morning from Mexico, where he had fled last month with his mother.

headline: Bernie Sanders Releases Tough Ad on Wall Street Speaking Fees
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s campaign releases a tough new ad that implicitly highlights Hillary Clinton’s acceptance of speaking fees from Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Speaking with reporters on Thursday morning, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was asked if he would satisfy some of his frustrated supporters by making a more direct contrast with Hillary Clinton in the final days before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Huckabee and Santorum to Attend Trump Event During Fox News Debate
abstract: Mike Huckabee, the winner of the 2008 Iowa caucuses who has been struggling to gain traction in this year’s race, will appear with Donald J. Trump and an event for veterans that the billionaire businessman has scheduled as counterprogramming to tonight’s debate on Fox News.
lead_paragraph: Mike Huckabee, the winner of the 2008 Iowa caucuses who has been struggling to gain traction in this year’s race, will appear with Donald J. Trump and an event for veterans that the billionaire businessman has scheduled as counterprogramming to tonight’s debate on Fox News, which he is skipping.

headline: Attack Ad From Ted Cruz Signals Marco Rubio’s Gains in Iowa
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The new ad, criticizing Marco Rubio on immigration, is the first one attacking him to be run by Ted Cruz’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Senator Ted Cruz, who has been harshly criticizing Donald J. Trump all week on the campaign trail and in television commercials here, is now broadening his attacks to include Senator Marco Rubio, an unmistakable acknowledgment that Mr. Rubio is gaining support in the closing days before the Monday caucuses.

headline: In Iowa, Jobs Are Plentiful but Workers Are Not
abstract: Employers across Iowa, whose jobless rate is only 3.4 percent, lament that the state has “run out of people for jobs.”
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Unlike the indoor basketball court, foosball tables or fireside lounge at Workiva’s sprawling campus here, the oversize green prize wheel centered among a hive of work stations is not meant for break times.

headline: Alibaba Searching for New Revenue Sources
abstract: In China, growth in property investment is sagging, and the trend from bricks-and-mortar to online retailing is positive for Alibaba’s top-line growth story.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba is benefiting from China’s shift toward a consumer economy. The e-commerce group’s earnings in the last three months of 2015 offer another insight into China’s economy as well. Both the company and the country need to find new ways to grow.

headline: Syrian Opposition Bloc Still Won’t Commit to Joining Peace Talks
abstract: A spokesman for the main opposition bloc said it wanted an assurance from Secretary General Ban Ki-moon that the Syrian government would lift its sieges of rebel-held towns.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A day before the Syria peace talks were to begin, there was no sign of when the opposition would show up to negotiate, raising the possibility that months of high-level diplomatic efforts to bring the parties to the table could unravel even before the talks started.

headline: Sondra Radvanovsky, Opera Royalty, Takes On Donizetti’s Triple Crown
abstract: Between the present and this coming spring, this soprano will assume the roles of Anne Boleyn; Mary, Queen of Scots; and Queen Elizabeth at the Met.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the largest voices in opera was ricocheting through a small Upper West Side apartment recently, as the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky practiced some fiendishly tricky bel canto passages for her radio broadcast singing the title role of Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena” live from the Metropolitan Opera. Then she had to switch hats, or crowns.

headline: Dr. Herbert L. Abrams, Who Worked Against Nuclear War, Dies at 95
abstract: Dr. Abrams, an expert in cardiovascular radiology, was a founder of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, which won a Nobel Peace Prize for its work.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Herbert L. Abrams, a radiologist at Stanford and Harvard universities and a founder of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, which won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985 for its work in publicizing the health consequences of atomic warfare, died on Jan. 20 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Iowa Caucus Envy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A reader in Brooklyn feels disenfranchised because the presidential candidates rarely venture there.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Two Little-Known Actors Became the Obamas
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies']
abstract: Parker Sawyers and Tika Sumpter play the first couple — on their first date — in the Sundance favorite “Southside With You.”
lead_paragraph: In preparing to film “Southside With You,” which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this week, Parker Sawyers and Tika Sumpter had some impressive shoes to fill. In the film, they play Barack and Michelle Obama (née Robinson) as they were in 1989: he, a Harvard Law summer associate at a prestigious Chicago firm, and she, an ambitious young lawyer and his adviser. Telling the story of their first date, it’s the first major depiction of the Obamas in a feature film, and Sawyers and Sumpter portray the future first couple with such sweetness and magnetism that you’d be forgiven for thinking them an item offscreen. But it didn’t come without baggage. “I was worried that the CIA would come shut us down!” Sumpter says, laughing. “It is the leader of the free world, after all.”

headline: ‘The Ravages of Lead’: Readers on the Water in Flint
abstract: In response to recent editorials and columns, readers condemned the decisions that put thousands of children in Flint at risk.
lead_paragraph: With just a few exceptions, readers condemned what they described as ideologically driven policy decisions that put thousands of children in Flint, Mich., at risk of lead poisoning, in response to recent editorials and columns.

headline: Rural Voters Can Swing the Iowa Caucuses. Meet Five of Them.
abstract: Small-town Iowans have a huge role in picking the next president. Their deep commitment to the process paints a distinct portrait of democracy.
lead_paragraph: Small-town Iowans have a huge role in picking the next president. Their deep commitment to the process paints a distinct portrait of democracy.

headline: Chains Clink, Water Splashes: A Composer’s Beautiful Noise
abstract: The young composer Ashley Fure is burrowing furiously into the very nature of sound.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Ashley Fure, the focus of a Composer Portrait concert on Thursday, Feb. 4, at the Miller Theater, was experimenting with fluid sound. A speaker hung in the corner of a studio in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, that was crammed with equipment hoarded by Levy Lorenzo, the electronics wizard of the International Contemporary Ensemble. Taped to the speaker’s cone was a thin plastic tube, cut off at one end near the woofer’s rim and reaching down to a water pump at the other.

headline: Gina Rodriguez Asks Latino Audiences to Support Latino Actors
abstract: The “Jane the Virgin” star starts #MovementMondays, a social media campaign to support films and shows starring Hispanic performers.
lead_paragraph: The actress Gina Rodriguez has responded to the #OscarsSoWhite controversy with her own call to action for Latino audiences.

headline: At Maison Margiela, an Artisanal Approach to Collage
abstract: Multiple references and an abundance of fabrics came together in each of John Galliano’s spring/summer 2016 couture looks.
lead_paragraph: Multiple references and an abundance of fabrics came together in each of John Galliano’s spring/summer 2016 couture looks.

headline: Officer Shot Man After Brooklyn Robbery, Police Say
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The man, who was fleeing after robbing a cellphone store in the Midwood neighborhood, is in stable condition, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer on Thursday morning shot and wounded an armed man who led the police on an erratic chase through the quiet streets of Midwood, Brooklyn, after robbing a cellphone store, the authorities said.

headline: 130 Years Ago: ‘War and Peace’ Finally Published in English
abstract: Tolstoy’s novel is translated from Russian to French to English, and The New York Times is not impressed.
lead_paragraph: Scully and Mulder weren’t the only TV couple burning up the screen this week. How about Natasha and Andrei, stars of an eight-hour mini-series on the Lifetime, History and A&E channels?

headline: 36 Hours in Porto, Portugal
abstract: From its stunning Beaux-Arts station to its cool bars serving Porto’s signature drink, this charming city combines the best of old and new.
lead_paragraph: From its stunning Beaux-Arts station to its cool bars serving Porto’s signature drink, this charming city combines the best of old and new.

headline: Tight Race for Second Place in New Poll of New Hampshire Republicans
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Donald J. Trump still leads by a large margin in a new poll, with Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida in a close contest for second place.
lead_paragraph: The battle for second place in New Hampshire’s Republican primary has intensified, with Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida all pulling about 11 or 12 percent of the vote, and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida about 10 percent, according to a poll released Thursday.

headline: Puerto Rico Debt Negotiations Resume
abstract: The continuation of talks between Puerto Rico’s power company and its bondholders have revived hopes that a default can be avoided.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations to restructure roughly $9 billion of the debt of Puerto Rico’s power company have resumed after breaking down last week, reviving hopes that a default can be avoided.

headline: Shakespeare in the Park to Offer ‘Taming of the Shrew’ and ‘Troilus and Cressida’
abstract: The annual free Shakespeare in the Park productions will be “The Taming of the Shrew” and “Troilus and Cressida” this summer.
lead_paragraph: Central Park is still coated in snow but the Public Theater is getting ready for warmer weather among the trees.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Healthy, His Doctor Declares
abstract: Mr. Sanders’s campaign released a letter from the congressional physician summarizing his medical history.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has suffered a variety of ailments over his 74 years, including gout, diverticulitis, hernias and a cyst on his vocal cord, but he is in “very good health,” according to a letter from the congressional physician whose office has treated the senator for more than 20 years.

headline: Volkswagen May Buy Back Diesel Cars It Can’t Fix

abstract: A lawyer for the carmaker said the company might have to buy back some tainted cars in the United States because it would take too long to correct emissions problems.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen may buy back some diesel cars in the United States if it cannot make them compliant with air quality rules fast enough, a lawyer for the company says.

headline: Snapchat Offers Original Political Coverage, ‘Good Luck America’
abstract: Snapchat’s first foray into original news programming “aims to provide young voters with an informative and entertaining glimpse into what life on the campaign trail is like,” a spokeswoman says.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Tucked atop the “Discover” tab in Snapchat on Thursday is a new red, white and blue icon that says,“Good Luck America.”

headline: Some Iowans Who Like Carly Fiorina Worry About a Wasted Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: People who could embrace Carly Fiorina, the former Hewlett-Packard chief executive who is struggling in single digits in most Iowa polls, say they might ultimately go for another Republican choice, or even switch parties and vote for a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: ANKENY, Iowa — For nearly four minutes, Carly Fiorina clasped the hand of Brian Thielges and tried to change his mind.

headline: F.B.I. Releases Video Showing Death of Oregon Refuge Occupier
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Federal Lands']
abstract: An agent said that LaVoy Finicum, 54, reached for a weapon after climbing out of his truck Tuesday, and added that four people remained at the refuge.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — The F.B.I. took the extraordinary step of releasing surveillance video on Thursday showing the shooting death of LaVoy Finicum, a member of the armed occupation of a federal wildlife refuge here in eastern Oregon, as the occupation continued by a handful of followers.

headline: A Single Cell Shines New Light on How Cancers Develop
abstract: Researchers set out to solve a puzzle that has baffled cancer investigators: Why do many cells that have cancer genes never turn cancerous?
lead_paragraph: It was just a tiny speck, a single cell that researchers had marked with a fluorescent green dye. But it was the very first cell of what would grow to be a melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer. Never before had researchers captured a cancer so early.

headline: Taxing Google and Other U.S. Giants Is Dividing Europe
abstract: European Union officials in Brussels want uniform rules, but many countries prefer to use tax policies to reward or punish big multinationals.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — For some European nations, big American corporations like Google are seen primarily as employers and technological innovators whose presence can help with their global competitiveness.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Rams’
abstract: Grimur Hakonarson narrates a sequence from “Rams.”
lead_paragraph: Grimur Hakonarson narrates a sequence from “Rams.”

headline: Donald Trump’s Childish Debate Boycott
keywords: ['Boycotts', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Debates (Political)', 'Discrimination', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Television', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s squabble with Fox News has given the world the perfect description of his campaign style.
lead_paragraph: The squabble between Donald Trump and Fox News over the latest Republican presidential “debate” may seem as completely vapid as the debates themselves. But there is a silver lining. Mr. Trump has given the world the perfect three-word description of his campaign style.

headline: Grimur Hakonarson Narrates a Scene From ‘Rams’
abstract: The director discusses a scene from his Icelandic drama “Rams.”
lead_paragraph: The Icelandic drama “Rams” follow two sheep-farmer brothers who haven’t spoken for 40 years, yet live next door to one another. A tragedy that affects their animals further tests their relationship. This scene involves a particularly intense moment between the brothers. In an interview at The Times, the director Grimur Hakonarson talked about his own experiences on a farm and how to cast sheep. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Valentino’s Very Byzantine Couture Collection
abstract: The house showed magical spring/summer 2016 looks, heavily infused with Greco-Roman influences — but no shoes.

headline: Las Vegas Review-Journal Names Publisher
abstract: Craig Moon, a former president and publisher of USA Today, will lead the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Craig Moon, a former president and publisher of USA Today, has been named as the new publisher of The Las Vegas Review-Journal, the newspaper announced on Thursday.

headline: Unraveling the Pop Art Image of Tom Wesselmann
abstract: In a new exhibition, 30 of the artist’s early, less showy collages celebrate intimacy and sexual liberation.
lead_paragraph: Tom Wesselmann, the late Cincinnati-born artist who was a contemporary of Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and Jasper Johns, found fast fame in the 1960s with his supersized and visceral vision of the female form. But in the new David Zwirner gallery show of his portraits and nudes in London, 30 of his early collage works, which date from 1959 to 1964, reveal his softer, more naïve side. There are no gargantuan nipples or smoking mouths here; rather, these pieces have an undone feel that’s at odds with the slickness of his later and better-known works — albeit with familiar flashes of vivid, ad-world color.

headline: Photographing the Effects of Zika
abstract: A Getty Images photographer visited Recife, Brazil, an area affected by the Zika virus, this week.
lead_paragraph: A Getty Images photographer visited Recife, Brazil, an area affected by the Zika virus, this week.

lead_paragraph: A closer view of looks from the spring 2016 haute couture shows.

headline: 7 Hamas Members Are Killed in Tunnel Collapse in Gaza
abstract: The men were repairing an old cross-border tunnel in eastern Gaza used in the war last year when it collapsed, Hamas said. Four workers survived.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — The military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, said Thursday that seven of its members were killed when a tunnel into Israel collapsed as they were working on it.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Not So Simple Math
abstract: Hear the actress Sarah Paulson read the 2010 essay “Open Adoption: Not So Simple Math.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the third episode of Modern Love: The Podcast. This week, you’ll hear the actress Sarah Paulson (“Carol,” “American Horror Story,” “12 Years a Slave”) read a 2010 Modern Love essay by Amy Seek titled “Open Adoption: Not So Simple Math.”

headline: Six of This Season’s Biggest Couture Moments — in Exquisite Detail
abstract: T teamed up with the photographer Iringó Demeter to create a series of videos capturing all the precise, meticulous detail of couture — in slow motion.
lead_paragraph: During spring/summer 2016 haute couture week in Paris, T teamed up with the photographer Iringó Demeter to create a series of six videos that premiered exclusively via Instagram, capturing all the precise, meticulous detail of couture — in slow motion. Now that the shows have wrapped, catch up on all of the videos here, and on T’s Instagram page.

headline: Bernie Sanders Tops His Rivals in Use of Outside Money
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: So far, more super PAC money has been spent directly in support of Senator Sanders than for his Democratic Party rivals.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — As he swung through Iowa this week, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont rarely passed up a chance to bash the rising tide of money in politics, a system he said on Tuesday was “corrupt and undermining American democracy.”

headline: Springsteen’s Early Days, in a Feast of Photographs
abstract: This free viewing at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in SoHo includes images from 1974 to 1984, ranging from stage to studio to the streets of New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen’s “The River” tour is making a stop in SoHo. But don’t expect to hear live renditions of “Hungry Heart” or “The Ties That Bind.” This event, a photography exhibition, is all about the Boss’s iconography.

headline: Has Your Student Experienced Racism in High School?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Is there racial insensitivity in your high school, and how do officials respond?
lead_paragraph: Students at the nation’s oldest public school have taken to social media to protest the way race is approached in their high school, extending the conversation over racial inclusion that erupted on college campuses in the fall, Jess Bidgood writes in The New York Times. The school, Boston Latin, is at the center of a campaign that includes two YouTube videos and a hashtag — #BlackatBLS — which students and alumni are using to detail their experiences with racism or insensitivity at the school.

headline: Advice on Out-Debating Ted Cruz From Someone Who Did
abstract: Jeremy Philips, who beat Ted Cruz in the semifinals of the 1995 World Debating Championships, offered some pointers for Donald J. Trump should he accept Mr. Cruz’s challenge of a “mano a mano” debate.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Donald J. Trump dropped out of the Fox News debate and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas challenged him to a “mano a mano” contest in a forum of his choosing, Mr. Cruz took a break from debate prep in Des Moines to get a bite to eat.

headline: A New Nike Web Series (and Tips) to Inspire Resolution Making — and Keeping
abstract: The brand’s new show, “Margot vs Lily,” begins online Monday. And its on-set trainer shares her New Year fitness formula with T.
lead_paragraph: A far cry from its “Just Do It” commercials featuring serious athletes performing superhuman exercises, Nike’s fun new eight-episode original web series is refreshingly relatable — and aims to inspire real women to accomplish a single, realistic anything. “Margot vs Lily” is part of the brand’s #BetterForIt campaign, which encourages hard work towards specific goals (running your first race, graduating to the heavier set of weights at SoulCycle), and stars two sisters who couldn’t be less alike, save their competitive spirit.

headline: Researchers Weigh Risks of Zika Spreading at Rio Olympics
abstract: Of the visitors expected to pour into Brazil in August, some may get infected by the mosquito-borne virus and then return home at a time of peak mosquito activity.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — With about 500,000 people expected to visit Brazil for the Olympics here this year, researchers are scrambling to figure how much of a risk the Games might pose in spreading the Zika virus around the world.

headline: Shopping for an Expensive Ring? Ask Everything but That
abstract: Plus: a good cook but not a oenophile; a sick friend in a broken friendship; and a neighborhood aglow with lights.
lead_paragraph: Is it appropriate to ask salesmen if they are working on commission? I know we don’t typically go around asking people how they are paid. That would be rude. But I have been shopping for an expensive and significant ring, and I would like to ask the woman at the jewelry store how she gets compensated. That could affect how much I have to pay, correct?

abstract: A statue of Guanyin will go back on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, on Feb. 6.
lead_paragraph: A Buddhist deity sculpture, absent from the galleries at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, for 17 years, will go back on view there next month after undergoing analyses and treatments throughout its gilded surface.

headline: Signs of Modern Astronomy Seen in Ancient Babylon
abstract: Scientists have found a small clay tablet with markings indicating that a sort of precalculus technique was used to track Jupiter’s motion in the night sky.
lead_paragraph: For people living in the ancient city of Babylon, Marduk was their patron god, and thus it is not a surprise that Babylonian astronomers took an interest in tracking the comings and goings of the planet Jupiter, which they regarded as a celestial manifestation of Marduk.

headline: Pepsi Turns Restaurateur, to Serve Up Some Buzz
abstract: Kola House, now being built in New York, is meant to be a testing ground for Pepsi products and, in a subtle way, to stir social media conversation.
lead_paragraph: Behind black doors, what used to be a trendy restaurant in New York had been stripped to its concrete bones. Wires and cables snaked along the floor. Ceiling lights twinkled in the gloom.

abstract: Facebook is shutting down Parse, a toolkit and support system for mobile developers, which it acquired in 2013.

At the time, the social network’s ambitions were high: Parse would be Facebook’s way into one day harnessing developers to become a true cloud business, competing alongside the likes of Amazon, Google and Microsoft.

headline: Review: ‘Burnished by Grief,’ About Living in Close Quarters
abstract: Ellen Maddow’s comedy explores the vicissitudes of cheek-by-jowl urban housing.
lead_paragraph: The vicissitudes of cheek-by-jowl urban housing are the subject of Ellen Maddow’s “Burnished by Grief: A Romantic Comedy,” a mildly morbid but irrepressibly effervescent lark at La MaMa. Despite the presence of lurking neighbors and suggestions of voyeurism, the play evolves into an exuberant celebration of color and quirk, with a tune or two to underscore its sentiments.

abstract: Mr. Johnson, head of the Investor Protection Bureau, was involved in some of the largest settlements with banks over misdeeds in the mortgage market.

headline: ‘Flatlands,’ Where the Familiar Becomes Hypnotically Strange
abstract: This show at the Whitney Museum of American Art presents a dozen works by five young painters that deal cleverly in contradictory illusions.
lead_paragraph: The idea of “deskilling” has incited considerable chatter in the contemporary art sphere in the past decade. In economics the term refers to the technically undemanding labor performed by most modern industrial workers. In art discourse it identifies the deliberate rejection of traditional craft in the service of conceptual provocation and expressive freedom.

headline: Review: In ‘Wagner’s “Ring”: Forging an Epic,’ Valkyries on Their First Flight
abstract: This exhibition gathers artifacts surrounding the creation and first staging of Wagner’s four-part opera cycle in Bayreuth, Germany.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t a typically relaxing summer holiday. In 1876, the conductor Leopold Damrosch traveled from the United States to Bayreuth, Germany, to attend the premiere of Wagner’s epic, epochal four-opera cycle, “Der Ring des Nibelungen.”

headline: Review: Amos Gitai’s ‘Rabin, the Last Day’ Looks Back in Anguish
abstract: Mr. Gitai’s new film delves into the incendiary political culture that led to the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel in 1995.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 4, 1995, after addressing a large peace rally in a Tel Aviv square, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel was assassinated by a law student named Yigal Amir. In March of the following year, an official commission of inquiry, headed by the president of the Israeli Supreme Court, documented lapses in security on the night of the killing and intelligence failures in the months before.

headline: Chinese-Made Cars Arrive in U.S. Showrooms
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: There were snickers in 2007 when the Chinese said they would soon be making cars for the United States. It wasn’t soon, but the vehicles have begun to arrive.
lead_paragraph: A PEEK under the hood of three new cars from Volvo, Buick and Cadillac will not reveal a Made in China label. But those cars are breaking new ground in the auto industry, becoming the first to be manufactured in the People’s Republic and exported to the United States.

headline: A Letterpress Project That Spans a Continent
abstract: The artist Chris Fritton is visiting more than 100 shops across America, creating postcards and prints to send to his backers along the way.
lead_paragraph: In the last half of the 19th century and in the early years of the 20th, back when printing was a trade, there was enough work to carve out a living for anyone with the skills and a union card almost anywhere in the U.S. — and some printers with a taste for travel found their work on the road. The peripatetic lives of these tramp printers, as they were known, are the inspiration for artist Chris Fritton’s crowdfunded Itinerant Printer Project. The campaign will take him to more than 100 letterpress shops across the country, creating postcards and prints to send his backers along the way. (So far he’s visited 67.)

lead_paragraph: The hats and T-shirts for sale at two gift shops inside the Trump Tower may declare “Make America Great Again,” but New York City sent the Trump Organization a different message on Thursday: Make this atrium the same again.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 29-Feb. 4
abstract: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Countdown to Zero’ (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.
lead_paragraph: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Countdown to Zero’ (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? headline: In Cameron Rowland’s ‘91020000,’ Disquieting Sculptures
abstract: Much of the work on view in this Artists Space show has been made by inmates in state prisons.
lead_paragraph: The objects in Cameron Rowland’s remarkable show at Artists Space offer a history lesson and an aesthetic experience, intricately fused. Accompanied by terse explanatory captions, they expose some of the troubling inequities in American society, especially concerning its prisons and their use of compulsory inmate labor. The process of grasping the meaning of this work equally involves looking, reading and feeling but its subject is one of the most urgent of our time.

headline: Review: ‘JeruZalem,’ Through Glasses, Darkly
abstract: A different perspective on a dream vacation to Israel, with all the amenities, including appearances by the undead.
lead_paragraph: “JeruZalem” is an intriguing variation on the found-footage horror genre, showing virtually the entire story through the perspective of a pair of smart glasses. But, as if losing faith in the gimmick, the directors, the brothers Doron and Yoav Paz, ultimately shackle it to a run-from-the-ghouls climax, and intriguing becomes ordinary.

headline: Bernie Sanders Coaxes Young Iowans With 5-Second Videos

lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — It was no accident that Bernie Sanders campaigned in a high school here this morning.

abstract: With seven confirmed cases in the state, including three in the city, health administrators announced plans to prevent the virus from spreading.
lead_paragraph: With a growing number of countries throughout the Americas reporting increased transmission of the Zika virus, New York City heath officials announced plans on Thursday to try to prevent the pathogen from establishing a foothold in the city.

headline: Single Payer Trouble

lead_paragraph: A week ago I worried about the Sanders health plan; it looked as if he was low-balling costs in an effort to obscure how hard making such a plan would be, and how many currently well-insured people would end up being losers. I wrote that his plan

headline: Marco Rubio’s Camp Sees Opening if Donald Trump Wins in Iowa
abstract: According to advisers of the Florida senator, panicked Republicans would flock to Mr. Rubio, while a victory by Senator Ted Cruz would be the worst case.
