headline: Politico Will Lose Its Co-Founder and 4 Others
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Jim VandeHei and Mike Allen will leave the political publication later this year, along with others, shaking up a rapidly expanding organization.
lead_paragraph: The Politico co-founder and chief executive, Jim VandeHei, and one of its best-known journalists, Mike Allen, plan to leave the publication after the November presidential election, its owner Robert Allbritton said in a memo to the staff on Thursday. Three other senior executives also plan to leave.

headline: Review: In ‘Lazer Team,’ Bickering Losers Try to Save the World
abstract: Four small-town idiots accidentally end up in possession of a suit of high-tech armor that is Earth’s best defense against an invasion from outer space.
lead_paragraph: “Lazer Team” ends by setting itself up for a sequel, but that’s mighty wishful thinking. There’s not a big demand for laugh-free comedies.

headline: Family Band Performed at Oregon Refuge
abstract: The Sharp Family Band from Kansas sang at a pavilion in the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge on Saturday, watched by Ryan and Ammon Bundy and other protesters.
lead_paragraph: The Sharp Family Band from Kansas sang at a pavilion in the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge on Saturday, watched by Ryan and Ammon Bundy and other protesters.

headline: Family Gospel Band Provided Soundtrack for Oregon Refuge Standoff
keywords: ['Music', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Gospel Music']
abstract: The Sharp Family Band field trip became a nightmare when the eldest daughter was among those to witness a shooting in confrontation with the police.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — They arrived last weekend to spread Scripture, song and good cheer to the armed group that had taken over the federal wildlife sanctuary here: a single mother from Kansas and eight of her 10 children, members of a family gospel band who brought their instruments in a Partridge Family-style bus bearing the slogan, “Spirit Driven.”

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Jan. 30 Through Feb. 7
abstract: The comedian Alonzo Bodden will perform on Feb. 5 and Feb. 6 at Bananas Comedy Club in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Jan. 30 Through Feb. 7
abstract: The comedian Iliza Shlesinger will perform on Feb. 5 at the Mohegan Sun Uncas Ballroom in Uncasville, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: In ‘Mountain Men,’ Two Brothers Are Forced to Work Things Out
abstract: This Cameron Labine film features mismatched siblings and a road trip gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: There are three good laughs in “Mountain Men” and two modestly dramatic sections. That averages out to a decent moment every 18 minutes. While it may seem unfair to judge a movie using a calculation, it’s appropriate for a script that repeatedly falls back on formulas.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Jan. 30 Through Feb. 7
abstract: “Dreamgirls,” a musical by Henry Krieger and Tom Eyen, will be in Elmont, N.Y., on Feb. 6 through 27.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Noam Chomsky Focuses on Financial Inequality in ‘Requiem for the American Dream’
abstract: In the documentary “Requiem for the American Dream,” Mr. Chomsky conjures a sobering vision of a society in an accelerating decline.
lead_paragraph: “Requiem for the American Dream” is a timely 75-minute teach-in by Noam Chomsky, the M.I.T. linguistics professor who has been a leading leftist political analyst, critic and writer for six decades. Mr. Chomsky, already the subject of several documentaries, focuses here on an election-season theme: financial inequality in America and what he calls its corrosive effect on democracy. Assembling “10 Principles of Concentration of Wealth and Power,” he lays out rules like “Run the Regulators,” “Marginalize the Population” and “Manufacture Consent.”

headline: Seventh Republican Debate: Analysis
abstract: We provided real-time analysis of the last Republican debate before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 29-Feb. 4
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Jan. 30 Through Feb. 7
abstract: An art exhibition called “The New New” is featuring works by Molly McCracken Kumar and other artists through Feb. 13 at Kenise Barnes Fine Art gallery in Larchmont, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Xerox Planning Spinoff, Under Pressure From Carl Icahn
abstract: The company is said to have agreed to spin off its services business to its shareholders by the end of the year, separating it from the legacy hardware side.
lead_paragraph: Another American corporate icon has decided that breaking up is the thing to do.

headline: Acura Taps Van Halen for a Hard-Driving Super Bowl Commercial
abstract: When it comes to Super Bowl ads, the use of well-known songs can be a high-risk, high-reward proposition, an industry expert says.
lead_paragraph: Fleetwood Mac’s “Landslide” served as the perfect soundtrack for Budweiser’s heartwarming 2013 ad where a Clydesdale reunited with its former trainer. The composer John Williams’ “Imperial March” from “Star Wars” added just the right touch to Volkswagen’s humorous 2011 spot about a junior Darth Vader trying to use “the Force.”

headline: Vincent A. Cianci Jr., Celebrated and Scorned Ex-Mayor of Providence, R.I., Dies at 74
abstract: Known as “Buddy,” Mr. Cianci was known for protracted troubles with the law as well as for unfailing devotion to his city.
lead_paragraph: His nickname of “Buddy” hovered in the murky middle between friendly engagement and what’s-it-to-you aggression. Either way, it seemed to capture Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the former mayor of Providence, R.I., known for his finger-snap wit, protracted troubles with the law, and unfailing devotion to his city.

headline: De Blasio’s Wife and Council Members Share Personal Stories at Mental Health Hearing
abstract: Chirlane McCray, the wife of Mayor Bill de Blasio, has prioritized improving mental health care and championed the city’s plan for tackling the issue.
lead_paragraph: Amid the stats and figures, dot-driven maps of New York City and questions about the minutiae of neighborhood issues, a hearing at the City Council on Thursday included more than the usual amount of personal revelation from Council members.

headline: PACs Backing Jeb Bush and Chris Christie Attack John Kasich in New Hampshire
abstract: After largely ignoring him, rivals are now hammering John Kasich in New Hampshire, the state where the Ohio governor has anchored his campaign.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. – First, Gov. John Kasich’s rivals ignored him. Then a few gently criticized him.

headline: Russia Dismisses German Warnings About Exploiting Teen Rape Claim
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Missing Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Russia’s foreign minister said a girl’s disappearance and alleged rape in Berlin was “hushed up.” But German officials have warned against politicizing the case.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, on Thursday dismissed what he called Germany’s accusations that Russia was exploiting the mysterious disappearance of a 13-year-old Russian-German girl, who lives in eastern Berlin, to pursue its political aims.

headline: Review: Bruce Springsteen, Keeping an Eye on the Clock, at Madison Square Garden
abstract: The concert featured a complete performance of “The River,” his 1980 double album.
lead_paragraph: “The subtext to ‘The River’ was time,” Bruce Springsteen said as the E Street Band played a slow, shimmering vamp. “Time slipping away. And once you enter that adult world, the clock starts ticking and you’ve got a limited amount of time to do your work, to raise your family, to try and do something good.”

headline: Review: Bruckner Rises and Stalls in Hands of Two Conductors
abstract: Juanjo Mena, a guest at the New York Philharmonic, and Yannick Nézet-Séguin, of the Philadelphia Orchestra, shared a composer, but little else.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the New York Philharmonic’s hiring of Jaap van Zweden to replace Alan Gilbert as music director in 2018, announced on Wednesday, it is again possible to welcome guest conductors without having to assess their immediate suitability for the permanent post. So the Spanish maestro Juanjo Mena, who is conducting the orchestra’s subscription concerts this week, may escape the closest scrutiny, as he did in his New York Philharmonic debut, late in 2014, when he led a snoozy program of standards more or less lost in the holiday bustle.

headline: With Eye on Growth, Imagine Entertainment Seeks an Investment
abstract: If the deal is completed, Imagine would gain capital and supporters to expand its ability to back film and television productions and make acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Over three decades, Brian Grazer and Ron Howard have built Imagine Entertainment into a top film and television production company, with credits stretching from the movie “Apollo 13” to the television show “Empire.”

headline: Three Films by Richard Lester, a Yank in Britain’s 1960s New Wave
abstract: Kino Lorber releases “The Knack … and How to Get It” (1965), “How I Won the War” (1967) and “The Bed Sitting Room” (1969) on Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: The director Richard Lester, now in his 80s, not only had a career but also a moment. “No filmmaker in this decade appeared more punctually when his hour struck,” the film critic Alexander Walker wrote in his history of 1960s British cinema.

headline: California Votes to Retain System That Pays Solar Users Retail Rate for Excess Power
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Regulators extended a policy that has helped the expansion of rooftop solar power, adding fees for future users but rejecting changes sought by big utilities.
lead_paragraph: Regulators in California, home to more residential solar customers than any other state, agreed on Thursday to retain a system that compensates users of rooftop solar panels for their excess electricity.

headline: Cosby Lawyers and Prosecutors Spar Ahead of Court Hearing
abstract: Bill Cosby legal team says too much time has elapsed to bring charges in a decade-old sexual assault case in Pennsylvania. A district attorney disagrees.
lead_paragraph: The war of words between lawyers for Bill Cosby and Pennsylvania prosecutors who have charged the entertainer with sexual assault continued on Thursday in advance of a hearing scheduled for next week.

headline: Moderates Under Pressure in Iran
abstract: Next month’s elections do not bode well for Iranians eager for more political and social freedoms.
lead_paragraph: Next month’s elections in Iran do not bode well for Iranians eager for more political and social freedoms or for the promising new relationship with the West symbolized by the recent deal limiting Iran’s nuclear program. Even before any ballots are cast, the death-to-America hard-liners who bitterly opposed the deal are stacking the deck against moderates led by President Hassan Rouhani, who signed the agreement and is more open than others in the power structure to further engagement with Western nations as well as expanding rights and freedoms for Iranian citizens.

headline: China to Try Canadian on Spying Charges
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Detainees', 'International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Kevin Garratt, who ran a cafe near China’s border with North Korea, will be tried on charges of spying and stealing state secrets nearly a year and a half after he and his wife were detained.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Canadian man who ran a cafe near China’s border with North Korea will be tried on charges of spying and stealing state secrets, prosecutors announced on Friday, nearly a year and a half after he and his wife were detained by the police.

headline: Many Fertilizer Plants Are Poorly Located and Regulated, Says Report on 2013 Blast
abstract: Nearly 20 fertilizer plants in Texas and others nationwide have the same dangerous proximity to schools, parks and housing as the one that exploded in a Central Texas town, the federal report says.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Nearly 20 fertilizer plants in Texas and others nationwide have the same dangerous proximity to schools, parks, nursing homes and housing as the one that exploded in the Central Texas town of West in 2013, federal officials said in releasing a final report on the blast Thursday.

headline: New Details of Iran Ordeal Emerge From Former Prisoners
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Jason Rezaian of The Washington Post and Matthew Trevithick added to the picture that has been emerging about the prisoner ordeal and the diplomacy that led to their release.
lead_paragraph: Two of the Americans freed by Iran this month in a prisoner deal have provided new detail about their time in captivity, saying they were told by Iranian interrogators that the United States had abandoned them and that they would never leave. One said he had been accused of plotting armed revolution.

headline: Mentally Disturbed Man Killed Teacher at Harlem Shelter, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: The police were searching for Anthony White, 21, after his 62-year-old roommate was found stabbed in the neck.
lead_paragraph: For at least a week, Anthony White, 21, a resident at a shelter in East Harlem, had frightened staff members and fellow residents with threats that he was going to kill someone, residents there said on Thursday.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: The candidates are engaged in the final G.O.P. debate before the Iowa caucuses — without Donald Trump. Here were the highlights.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Following is immediate real-time analysis of the seventh Republican debate. Read additional fact checks here.

headline: Michael J. Kennedy, Lawyer for Underdogs and Pariahs, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Kennedy defended John Gotti Sr., Huey P. Newton and Timothy Leary and won freedom for Jean S. Harris, who killed the Scarsdale Diet doctor.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Kennedy, who as a criminal lawyer championed lost causes and deeply unpopular defendants — including John Gotti Sr., Huey P. Newton and Timothy Leary — and finally won freedom for Jean S. Harris, the convicted killer of Dr. Herman Tarnower, the Scarsdale Diet doctor, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Plotters Talked of Planting Explosives on a Kangaroo in Australia
abstract: A teenager, who pleaded not guilty to terrorism charges on Thursday, is accused of planning a holiday attack on the police in a Melbourne suburb.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — A teenager accused of plotting to behead a police officer as part of a holiday terrorist attack also discussed planting explosives on a kangaroo, painting it with an Islamic State symbol and setting it upon the police, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: More Is Needed to Beat ISIS, Pentagon Officials Conclude
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: To deal a lasting blow to the extremist Sunni militancy, officials believe that additional forces will be needed to work with Iraqi, Kurdish and Syrian opposition fighters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials have concluded that hundreds more trainers, advisers and commandos from the United States and its allies will need to be sent to Iraq and Syria in the coming months as the campaign to isolate the Islamic State intensifies.

headline: Talking Out Their Problems, the Lightning Enter the Playoff Conversation
abstract: A candid meeting helped Tampa Bay break out of a slump and regain the form that vaulted the team to last season’s Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: BRANDON, Fla. — A moment of truth hit the Tampa Bay Lightning deep in western Canada on Jan. 5. A galling, lackluster 3-1 loss to the Calgary Flames — their fourth defeat in six games — symbolized a slide from Stanley Cup contenders to slackers.

headline: Officer’s Response After Shooting Is Scrutinized at Manslaughter Trial
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Prosecutors said that Officer Peter Liang failed in his duties after he shot Akai Gurley in a Brooklyn housing project, while defense lawyers said he was overcome by shock.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police lieutenant who arrived at a housing project in Brooklyn where a man had been shot by a police officer said he had found the officer, Peter Liang, “frozen” on a fourth-floor landing. One level above him lay the man, Akai Gurley, mortally wounded and sprawled on the floor, said the lieutenant, Vitaliy Zelikov, who testified on Thursday at Officer Liang’s trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Jose Calderon Hears Criticism, but Not From Knicks Teammates He Mentors
abstract: Jose Calderon, the eldest member of the Knicks, has been a soft target this season for critics of his defense. But he still manages to influence the game.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Whenever Jose Calderon visits Air Canada Centre, pieces of his past re-emerge. Calderon, a 34-year-old point guard, spent the first seven and a half seasons of his N.B.A. career with the Raptors. He honed his 3-point shot, jettisoning his chicken-wing release. He improved his English. And he quickly became a mentor to teammates who learned to listen.

headline: One Last Debate Before the Caucuses
abstract: The Republican candidates met in Des Moines in the last debate before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Republican candidates met in Des Moines in the last debate before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.

headline: Transcript of the Preliminary G.O.P. Presidential Debate
abstract: Following is a transcript of the Republican “undercard” debate held Thursday in Des Moines, as recorded by the Federal News Service.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the preliminary Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: A Move to End Transparency for New York’s Jails
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The president of the union representing the city’s correction officers says hearings about guards’ disciplinary cases should be closed to the public.
lead_paragraph: Here, courtesy of an obscure New York City agency, is a window into the unseen, a forum for matters of fallibility and trivia and also for outrages that have managed to become the business of the government.

headline: Quest for Olympic Gold in Rio Makes Rugby Sevens a Priority
abstract: Rugby’s return to the Summer Games this year means the focus in the sport will be on the game’s shorter, more dynamic and less complicated version.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — A few years ago, seeing the New Zealand sevens rugby team in seventh place in the World Sevens Series would have been unthinkable.

headline: Thunderous Noises on East Coast Were Sonic Booms, Navy Says
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Nine sonic booms, thought by some residents to be the sounds of an earthquake, occurred during the testing of an F-35C fighter jet.
lead_paragraph: A series of earthshaking noises that left some residents on the East Coast wondering if they had lived through an earthquake on Thursday afternoon were sonic booms caused by the testing of a fighter jet, officials said.

headline: In Spirit of Ryder Cup, a Competition to Honor Rod Laver
abstract: The Laver Cup, named after the Australian champion, will match the best players from Europe against the best from the rest of the world over three days of competition in singles and doubles.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was Novak Djokovic against Roger Federer on Thursday night in Rod Laver Arena in the semifinals of the Australian Open, but if the organizers of a new tennis competition have their way, it will soon be Djokovic and Federer playing on the same European team for a trophy called the Laver Cup.

headline: Review: ‘Sojourners,’ About Nigerians Assimilating to Life in the U.S.
abstract: A Nigerian couple embrace and rebuff life in America in Mfoniso Udofia’s play, directed by Ed Sylvanus Iskandar.
lead_paragraph: In “Sojourners,” an emotionally fervid and dramatically stolid play by Mfoniso Udofia for the Playwrights Realm, a Nigerian couple embrace and rebuff life in America. Ukpong (Hubert Point-Du Jour) and Abasiama (Chinasa Ogbuagu), joined in an ill-conceived arranged marriage, are student newlyweds in Houston in 1978.

headline: Without a Doubt
abstract: David Phillips takes us into our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — If I had asked a Magic 8 Ball last week whether my part of the country was really going to be blanketed by nearly 30 inches of snow, I can only imagine that the answer would have been “IT IS DECIDEDLY SO.” That thought amused me as I was shoveling my way through the blizzard and it will continue to amuse me, at least until it is time for my next dose of Motrin.

headline: California: Another Arrest in Jail Break
abstract: An employee at the Orange County Central Men’s Jail was taken into custody on Thursday for aiding the escape of three inmates from the maximum security facility last week.
lead_paragraph: An employee at the Orange County Central Men’s Jail was taken into custody on Thursday for aiding the escape of three inmates from the maximum security facility last week. The employee, Nooshafarin Ravaghi, had taught English as a second language at the jail since July. At least one of the escapees, Hossein Nayeri, attended her class, and the two developed “some kind of relationship,” said Lt. Jeff Hallock, a spokesman for the Orange County Sheriff’s Department. Ms. Ravaghi, 44, provided Google maps and other help for the escape, Mr. Hallock said, but she has denied providing tools used in the escape. The three men cut through metal bars before rappelling from the jail’s roof using a makeshift rope. Investigators believe the three men may be in a white GMC utility van, which was stolen in Los Angeles on Saturday.

headline: My Take on the Republican Debate, Minus Trump
abstract: The Republican candidates debated without the sulky orange-haired front-runner. Trump was probably wise to skip it.
lead_paragraph: The Republican candidates for president — with one big sulky orange-haired exception — dueled in a Fox News televised debate tonight. And my sense was that Trump was probably wise to skip it: He didn’t pay much of a price for staying away, he avoided tough questions and attacks, and his rivals used the occasion to slash each other. Bush had a better night than usual, and Rubio wrapped himself in the Bible in ways that may be effective in Iowa. Instead of writing a column, I’ve collected some of my tweets about the debate in this blog post. These are raw reflections, on the fly.

headline: New York Council May Vote on Raise and Horse-Carriage Bill on Same Day
abstract: As the Council completed a package of bills on lawmakers’ raises, questions surfaced about possible links to a bill shrinking the horse-cab industry.
lead_paragraph: The City Council completed a package of bills on Thursday to give its members a raise for the first time since 2006, adopting provisions on outside income and financial disclosures called for by good-government groups while lifting their own pay far above the level recommended by a city commission.

headline: Knicks Limp to a Defeat in Toronto
abstract: Carmelo Anthony (knee), Kristaps Porzingis (upper respiratory illness) and Jose Calderon (groin) did not play as the Knicks absorbed their fourth straight loss.
lead_paragraph: A depleted Knicks team tested the Raptors on Thursday before losing, 103-93, at Air Canada Centre.

headline: U.S. Placed Immigrant Children With Traffickers, Report Says
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services put more than a dozen minors in the care of human traffickers after inadequate background checks, a Senate inquiry found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Health and Human Services placed more than a dozen immigrant children in the custody of human traffickers after it failed to conduct background checks of caregivers, according to a Senate report released on Thursday.

headline: Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Clash Harshly, Filling Void on G.O.P. Debate Stage
abstract: The final Republican debate before the Iowa caucuses took a surreal turn as seven candidates found their messages overshadowed by Donald J. Trump’s boycott of the event.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The Republican presidential candidates competed vigorously to fill the vacuum created by Donald J. Trump’s boycott of Thursday night’s debate, with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida trading ferocious attacks on immigration and taking fire from rivals seeking advantage in the Iowa caucuses on Monday.

headline: Paul Kantner, a Founder of Jefferson Airplane, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Kantner wrote or helped write many of the songs that defined the San Francisco psychedelic sound of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Paul Kantner, a founding member of Jefferson Airplane, one of the definitive San Francisco psychedelic groups of the 1960s, and the guiding spirit of its successor, Jefferson Starship, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 74.

headline: Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, Pakistani Diplomat, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Yaqub Khan had a role in facilitating President Richard Nixon’s overture to China in 1972 and helped negotiate the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, a former military leader, foreign minister and diplomat who was Pakistan‘s public face in international affairs for three decades, died late Monday or early Tuesday in Islamabad. He was 95.

headline: 북한 사람들은 정말 정신 나간 사람들일까?
abstract: 북한 정권을 만화책에 나오는 괴짜 악당 취급하는 태도는 이제 버려야 한다.
lead_paragraph: 워싱턴 — 지난 25년간 미국 정부와 싱크탱크 및 학계에서 북한의 핵무기 개발을 저지하는 방법을 연구해 온 전문가로서, 지난 1월 6일 북한의 핵실험과 핵실험 발표 이후 일어난 일련의 사건은 마치 이전에 여러 차례 본 장면처럼 맥이 빠질 정도로 친숙했다. 이 상황을 보면서 영화 “카사블랑카”에서 경찰서장 르노가 릭의 카페를 폐쇄하기 전에 (사실 자신도 이 사실을 알면서 다른 사람들 들으라고) 외쳤던 그 유명한 대사가 생각났다.

headline: 3 Rights Advocates Are Sentenced to Prison in China
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The advocates were sentenced to terms ranging from two and a half to five years after they were convicted of inciting subversion in the southern city of Guangzhou.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Three civil rights advocates were sentenced to prison in southern China on Friday, with the terms ranging from two and a half to five years, after a judge declared them guilty of inciting subversion.

headline: G.O.P. Debate Stars the Ghost of Donald Trump
abstract: During a night of spirited exchanges, there was no getting away from the spirit of the missing Republican front-runner.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Donald Trump’s absence, of course, was the most compelling presence.

headline: Bank of Japan, in a Surprise, Adopts Negative Interest Rate
abstract: The central bank will charge commercial depositors to hold money in its vaults — a move meant to stimulate the economy amid global market turmoil.
lead_paragraph: As Japan’s economic doldrums have lingered, its leaders have tried a number of tricks over the years, from increasing government spending to flooding the financial system with cash.

headline: Obama Moves to Expand Rules Aimed at Closing Gender Pay Gap
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: A new requirement, which follows a 2014 executive order affecting federal contractors, calls for companies with 100 employees or more to report pay by race, gender and ethnicity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday moved to require companies to report to the federal government what they pay employees by race, gender and ethnicity, part of his push to crack down on firms that pay women less for doing the same work as men.

lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — It was supposed to be about the veterans.

headline: Analysis of the Seventh G.O.P. Debate

abstract: Jeremy W. Peters of The New York Times discusses key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Des Moines, as the candidates sparred over immigration and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy W. Peters of The New York Times discusses key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Des Moines, as the candidates sparred over immigration and other issues.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: Elaine May remembers Mike Nichols on “American Masters.” “The Blind Side” recounts the feel-good story of the football player Michael Oher. And “Dateline” takes on the case of Steven Avery.
lead_paragraph: Elaine May remembers her comedy partner Mike Nichols on “American Masters.” “The Blind Side” recounts the feel-good story of the football player Michael Oher, now headed to the Super Bowl with the Carolina Panthers. And “Dateline” takes on the case of Steven Avery.

headline: Who Won the Republican Debate? Critics Call Ted Cruz Flat but Jeb Bush Better
abstract: Commentators across the country assessed the Republicans who attended Thursday’s debate in Des Moines and the one who didn’t: Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump absent from the debate stage, critics had a chance to focus on the rest of the Republican field. While the verdicts varied, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was seen as starting strong but fading late, while Senator Marco Rubio of Florida had his moments but grew testy at times when faced with tough questions. Some thought Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, had one of his most energetic performances, while the retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson barely registered.

headline: Beyond Stereotypes in California and Kentucky
abstract: Working in places like Appalachia and Northern California, William Gendey challenged preconceived notions to find enduring — and unexpected — images.
lead_paragraph: Working in places like Appalachia and Northern California, William Gendey challenged preconceived notions to find enduring — and unexpected — images.

headline: Beyond Stereotypes in California and Kentucky
abstract: William Gedney once said he was not “a social problem photographer.” Working in places like Appalachia and Northern California, he challenged preconceived notions to find enduring — and unexpected — images.
lead_paragraph: Urban California and rural Appalachia were amply documented in the 1960s, even if the usual narratives were often polar opposites: the Bay Area, with its free-loving, psychedelic hippie counterculture or Kentucky with its gritty backwoods scenes of despair and poverty.

headline: The Problem With the Ethanol Mandate That Iowa Loves
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Ethanol', 'Corn', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A misguided federal approach has stifled innovation and hurt efforts to cut auto pollution.
lead_paragraph: IOWA is the nation’s top producer of corn, and nearly half of it ends up as ethanol, thanks to a government mandate that requires ethanol to be mixed into gasoline. The mandate is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to farmers there.

headline: Intolerable Bias in Ireland’s Schools
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Education (K-12)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Discrimination', 'Elections', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Church officials are at odds, with some urging a slow evolution to multidenominational schools. Clearly this won’t do.
lead_paragraph: The people of Ireland have shown a commendable willingness to strike anachronistic bias from the country’s laws, most emphatically in legalizing gay marriage last year in a referendum approved by three out of five voters. With a general election expected next month, a movement is underway in the rapidly changing nation to target another hurtful social condition by which non-Catholic children are legally denied seats at overcrowded state-financed primary schools, 97 percent of which are controlled by Catholic authorities.

headline: Righting a Grave Injustice in Louisiana

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court had people like Taurus Buchanan in mind this week when it reinforced a 2012 decision banning mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juveniles and found that people sentenced before that ruling had a constitutional right to seek parole.

headline: ‘How Stupid Is Iowa?’
abstract: Trump and Cruz have wondered. But a better question for the state might be: After 44 years of caucuses, how come you’re not culling out the crazies?
lead_paragraph: In the 44 years since the two major parties have allowed a small cohort of Midwesterners to decide the nation’s first presidential contest, the good people of Iowa have debated issues ranging from nuclear Armageddon to universal health care.

headline: Plutocrats and Prejudice
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Discrimination', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: An unspoken agenda is behind the ugliness in American politics.
lead_paragraph: Every time you think that our political discourse can’t get any worse, it does. The Republican primary fight has devolved into a race to the bottom, achieving something you might have thought impossible: making George W. Bush look like a beacon of tolerance and statesmanship. But where is all the nastiness coming from?

abstract: For whom does the government work? Presidents decide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHILE presidential candidates from both parties feverishly pitch their legislative agendas, voters should also consider what presidents can do without Congress. Agency rules, executive actions and decisions about how vigorously to enforce certain laws will have an impact on every American, without a single new bill introduced in Congress.

abstract: Such shortages are the new normal in American medicine. But the rationing that results has been largely hidden from patients and the public.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In the operating room at the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Brian Fitzsimons has long relied on a decades-old drug to prevent hemorrhages in patients undergoing open-heart surgery. The drug, aminocaproic acid, is widely used, cheap and safe. “It never hurt,” he said. “It only helps.”

headline: Student Question | What National or International Events That You Lived Through Do You Remember Best?
abstract: How old were you when the event happened? How did you learn about it?
lead_paragraph: When the space shuttle Challenger exploded in 1986, it was among the nation’s worst space disasters ever. This particular launch had especially attracted national interest because it included a high school teacher from New Hampshire, Christa McAuliffe, who won a nationwide competition to broadcast two lessons from space to students. The Challenger disaster was one of those events that American children growing up in the ’80s tend to remember — many of them watched it happen live on TV.

headline: Look! Up Over the Hospital! It’s Super Proxy!
abstract: In a health crisis, we all want superheroes, especially when a not-quite hospital takes its own sweet time treating a friend.
lead_paragraph: We all entertain fantasies of being someone else, and mine lately is Super Proxy — a combination of Superwoman and a legally designated health care proxy, who can make medical decisions faster than a speeding bullet and leap over paperwork in a single bound. I’d especially enjoy using my superhuman strength to dangle the hospital admissions person out a window.

headline: Conquering the Midair Crisis at a Trapeze Class
abstract: Trapeze sessions at Circus Warehouse in Long Island City offer people 45 and older a chance to escape workaday concerns for two hours a week and, of course, a chance to fly.
lead_paragraph: Madeleine Hormann was 7 years old when she decided to run away from home and join the circus. But like the best-laid plans of many second graders, hers went awry. Instead, she grew up, moved to Arizona and found work in engineering. It wasn’t until middle age that Ms. Hormann — fresh from losing a job and recovering from a broken leg — decided to give her childhood aspirations another shot.

headline: On the Way Home
abstract: The unexpected hazards of commuting by bike in a new land.
lead_paragraph: Soon after I arrived in America in May 2010, Jewish Family Services found me a place to live, a room in the home of a retired nurse in Springfield, Mass. They also found me a bicycle, a backpack and a job working the second shift at a bakery in Agawam, a small town on the other side of the Connecticut River.

headline: Drinking With Archibald Motley
abstract: Drawing inspiration at the bar from a great painter of the Harlem Renaissance.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I went to the Whitney Museum of American Art to see the exhibition ‘‘Archibald Motley: Jazz Age Modernist.’’ I found myself spellbound by a nightclub scene: a vivid tableau of dancing couples, so close to the band — a trombone’s slide stretches out between three people — as to appear in a tangle. Another couple can be glimpsed seated at a table, a glass of wine in front of the woman and a cocktail (it looks like a Manhattan) set before her date. I was surprised to see that Motley named the painting ‘‘Blues.’’ The heavy-souled sadness I associate with that music seems at odds with the image — but Motley must have known it was in there, too.

lead_paragraph: Cable news stations were fixated for two days over Donald J. Trump’s decision to pull out of Fox News’s Republican debate, so much so that many anticipated he might provide stiff competition for Fox on Thursday night when he staged his own event in Iowa at the same time. But if Mr. Trump was hoping for uninterrupted live coverage of his event from Fox’s cable news rivals, he did not get it, as both CNN and MSNBC broke away from his appearance about 15 minutes after it started.

headline: Justin Peck Calmly Creates a Kingdom at City Ballet
abstract: “The Most Incredible Thing,” which debuts on Tuesday, is the 10th ballet Mr. Peck has choreographed for the company he joined in 2007.
lead_paragraph: In a 19th-century stone castle in Yonkers, the ballet choreographer Justin Peck tried something he had never tried before: directing a film. He did not look nervous. Nor did he seem intimidated by his surroundings: the ornate, centuries-old furnishings from Europe; the travel trunks left in the attic by the Ballets Russes choreographer Michel Fokine, who lived and taught in the castle in the 1930s. Gently making suggestions or demonstrating what he had in mind, the 28-year-old Mr. Peck appeared self-assured. “If that doesn’t work,” he said at one point, “I have a Plan B.”

headline: 1941: General Metaxas Dies at 69

John Metaxas, to entrust its destiny to a new leader. The man named by King George II to take over the task of leading Greece to victory is fifty-five-year-old Alexander Korizis, former Minister of Public Welfare and president of the National Bank of Greece.

abstract: Ms. Baez’s concert at the Beacon Theater, with guests including Paul Simon, Mavis Staples and Jackson Browne, was taped for PBS’s “Great Performances” series.
lead_paragraph: Joan Baez is still the mother of us all. At the Beacon Theater, where she celebrated her 75th  birthday on Wednesday evening with an all-star concert of duets, she was a quietly magnetic woman in charge. Radiating her characteristic maternal strength and easygoing humor, she projected the welcoming empathy of someone you can turn to in times of trouble. She looked terrific: trim and fit, with short silver hair and a wonderfully goofy smile.

headline: Charlotte Gainsbourg, Jane Birkin and the Possibility of a Serge Gainsbourg Museum

The singer-songwriter, actor and director, who died in 1991, is still a subject of fascination, especially in Paris, where Ms. Gainsbourg, for a time, considered turning his house into a museum. Ultimately, she said no. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation with Ms. Birkin and Ms. Gainsbourg.

headline: London Lost and Found
abstract: Visiting the city I once lived in, I adopt new lines of inquiry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I LEFT London and moved to India in August 2008. Four weeks later, Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, and the global economy went into a tailspin. People who had known the word “derivative” only as an adjective in book reviews were now using it as a noun; “subprime” entered the vocabulary of the uninitiated. The City of London seemed to be at the heart of this disaster whose effects were surging out over the cobbled streets of the Square Mile and into the farthest corners of the world, including my new home in the small southern Indian city Mysore.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Among the exhibitions at the fledgling Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1937 was a show of 150 watercolor copies of prehistoric rock paintings and engravings that, the museum noted, had been selected by its director, Alfred H. Barr Jr.

headline: German Forest Ranger Finds That Trees Have Social Networks, Too
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Forests and Forestry']
abstract: Peter Wohlleben, a career ranger, has topped best-seller lists with “The Hidden Life of Trees,” describing trees as social beings that communicate on the “Wood Wide Web.”
lead_paragraph: HÜMMEL, Germany — IN the deep stillness of a forest in winter, the sound of footsteps on a carpet of leaves died away. Peter Wohlleben had found what he was looking for: a pair of towering beeches. “These trees are friends,” he said, craning his neck to look at the leafless crowns, black against a gray sky. “You see how the thick branches point away from each other? That’s so they don’t block their buddy’s light.”

lead_paragraph: If there is one conclusion to draw from the company earnings reported on Thursday, it is this: Cloud computing is a booming business.

headline: To Grade Presidents on the Economy, Look at Policies, Not Results
abstract: Judging a president by the overall strength of the economy is a common, but flawed, approach.
lead_paragraph: When unemployment falls, inflation is low and the economy grows briskly, we often give the president high marks for handling the economy. But is that really how the economic record of presidents should be judged? As we pick the next president, this question is useful to ponder, for it is central to how we understand our history. Yet most people take the wrong approach to answering it.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jane Mayer’s “Dark Money,” No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has made news partly because it seems Mayer was investigated by the book’s subjects, the Koch brothers.
lead_paragraph: Attack the Messenger: Jane Mayer’s “Dark Money,” about the influence of wealthy families in conservative politics, hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. Mayer’s book has made news partly for its revelation that even as she was investigating the Koch brothers, they seemed to be investigating her: “Dirt, dirt, dirt,” one source told Mayer, describing the mission a team of operatives had to smear her name after The New Yorker published her first long article about the Kochs’ political efforts. (Mayer goes where the facts take her: She had previously written a similar article about George Soros’s influence on liberal causes.) “It’s uncommon for a private detective to be hired to conduct a retaliatory investigation into a reporter’s character,” she writes in the book, adding that although it’s unclear how directly involved they were, “clues leading back to the Kochs were everywhere.”

headline: More Is More, More, More
abstract: According to Guinness World Records, the most prolific author as measured by words published is Charles Harold St. John Hamilton, with 72 to 73 million words to his 25 pen names.
lead_paragraph: January is the month of resolutions, and in her Help Desk column this week, Molly Young tackles new books that promise to show us how to become our most productive selves. Writers — often known in our romantic parlance for being tortured, starving or blocked — can have a love-hate relationship with productivity, fearful that therein lies the road to hackdom. According to Guinness World Records, the most prolific author as measured by words published is the British writer Charles Harold St. John Hamilton (1876-1961), with a whopping 72 to 73 million words to his 25 pen names. But even Hamilton had his limits. In his autobiography, written in the third person (“Like Stendhal,” he declared, he “dislikes the je’s and the moi’s ”), he remembers responding to an “urgent request” by writing an 18,000-word story in one day, an experience he deemed “a tour-de-force that he has never repeated or wanted to repeat.”

headline: 1966: France Returns to Common Market
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France agrees to return to the Common Market in 1966.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — The six Common Market nations ended the crisis that has paralyzed their community for seven months. France agreed to return to the Common Market and drop the boycott it began July 1. The first meeting of the revived community at its Brussels headquarters is expected to take place in the second half of February. In a marathon bargaining session that ended early this morning, the ministers from the six nations patched up their differences by resorting to an artful dodge.

headline: A Bosch Retrospective
abstract: The city of Den Bosch celebrates the 500th anniversary of its native son, Hieronymus Bosch, with a significant exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The small Dutch city of ‘s-Hertogenbosch, known as Den Bosch, is celebrating the virtual return of its native son Hieronymus Bosch, who died 500 years ago. Although the city doesn’t own any of the artist’s paintings, this year it will present the largest retrospective of Bosch’s work ever, with all the works on loan from several leading museums. “Jheronimus Bosch – Visions of Genius,” displaying 20 paintings and 19 drawings, runs from Feb. 13 to May 8 at Het Noordbrabants Museum. Seven other museums in the province of North Brabant will present shows.

headline: Green-Eyed Verbs
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Jealousy and Envy']
abstract: Writing out of a feeling of envy will produce an expression of envy, and envy’s voice is ugly, small.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, when I open a magazine and find yet another intelligently researched piece of journalism or brilliant social analysis in the form of a book review, I think: “What beauty!” And then, almost immediately afterward, I think, “Could I offer the world something so useful and beautiful?”

headline: ‘Not All Bastards Are From Vienna,’ by Andrea Molesini
abstract: An aristocratic Italian clan joins the World War I resistance.
lead_paragraph: “Not All Bastards Are from Vienna,” winner of Italy’s 2011 Campiello Prize, is Andrea Molesini’s first novel for adults — though it still possesses the straightforward narrative line and colorful characters of a story for children. Set during World War I, events are related by 17-year-old Paolo Spada, recently orphaned and now living with a menagerie of relations and servants in the Villa Spada, in a small town north of Venice.

headline: ‘Thomas Murphy,’ by Roger Rosenblatt
abstract: A poet is faced with a wobbly memory and a late-in-life affair.
lead_paragraph: Some novels delight their readers with an intricate and irresistible plot, in which pace and clues and the stumble of events offer an alluring puzzle. Others are wonderful at evoking a time, a place, an emotion. Still others are notable primarily for the way the author creates unforgettable characters — beings so real, so complex, so absorbing that you think about them long after you finish the book, and you cannot quite believe they will no longer be holding your attention, provoking that startled pang of understanding and fellow feeling.

headline: ‘The Castle Cross the Magnet Carter,’ by Kia Corthron
abstract: The parallel lives of two sets of brothers play out amid the nation’s postwar transformations.
lead_paragraph: In February, a film biography of the Olympic runner Jesse Owens is scheduled to arrive in theaters. Whatever its other virtues or lack of same, the movie carries a title of brilliant duality.

headline: ‘Winter,’ by Christopher Nicholson
abstract: A novel pays a call on an aging Thomas Hardy, his young wife and an even younger protégée.
lead_paragraph: The male giants of English literature have often made bad real-life husbands, and the vindication of their suffering wives has taken various forms. Thomas Carlyle, and posterity, might never have realized what a difficult spouse he was without the diary of Jane Carlyle, which the historian read with dismay after her death. Mary Powell, “Wife to Mr. Milton,” had her youthful ordeal imagined by Robert Graves in a witty first-person novel carrying that title. Now, in “Winter,” the English novelist Christopher Nicholson sets out to avenge (up to a point) Florence Hardy, the ­decades-younger second wife of the aged Thomas, as she endures the fall and winter of 1924-25 inside a storm of sickness, jealousy and anger.

headline: Richard A. Posner’s ‘Divergent Paths: The Academy and the Judiciary’
abstract: Posner examines the failings of the federal bench and proposes solutions that law schools might accomplish.
lead_paragraph: If Richard Posner did not exist, who would dare invent him? The most-cited legal scholar of all time, who is arguably America’s greatest living judge; a man who publishes a book a year while writing all his own judicial opinions; an icy ration­alist who once confessed to unrequited love for his cat. . . . It’s all a bit too much to believe. Arthur Conan Doyle’s Sherlock Holmes and Gene Roddenberry’s Mr. Spock are probably the closest anyone has come.

headline: ‘The Poetry of Yehuda Amichai,’ Edited by Robert Alter
abstract: Amichai believed that poems should be useful.
lead_paragraph: I have one selfish quibble with the expansive, magnificent new book “The Poetry of Yehuda Amichai,” edited by Robert Alter. It excludes a personal favorite, “The Eve of Rosh Hashanah.” Every year, on the occasion of its title, I read the poem aloud. In Chana Bloch and Stephen ­Mitchell’s translation, it begins:

lead_paragraph: In a controversial 1999 New Yorker review of Alan Hollinghurst’s novel “The Spell,” John Updike summed up a common prejudice about gay stories: namely, that they have nothing to interest straight readers.

headline: Charity Wine Auctions Are More Than Parties
abstract: A dinner, a brunch and a weekend auction at the Naples Winter Wine Festival will cost a couple $10,000, not counting what they might spend at the auction.
lead_paragraph: DENISE COBB, a former CNN anchor, and her husband, Brian, a media executive, have had some great chefs in their kitchen over the years. Thomas Keller, the owner of the French Laundry in Napa Valley and Per Se in New York, has cooked there three times. Eric Ripert, the chef at Le Bernardin in New York, has been there, too.

headline: La Tour d’Argent, Paris Dining Temple, to Auction Furnishings and More
abstract: The French auction house Artcurial will hold a sale on May 9 of goods from the restaurant.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — La Tour d’Argent, a Parisian shrine to the art of fine dining that traces its roots to the 16th century, is selling off tableware, furnishings and cooking implements as it seeks to reinvent itself for the 21st century.

headline: ‘Margaret Thatcher,’ by Charles Moore
abstract: The second volume of an authorized biography finds the prime minister at the height of her power.
lead_paragraph: In February 1984, during that period when a succession of decrepit Soviet leaders were dropping like flies, the British prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, traveled to Moscow to attend the funeral of Yuri Andropov. There she made an extremely positive impression on her hosts. Not only did she remain outside in frigid temperatures during the entire ceremony, but her personal security man, who shadowed her in his vast overcoat with immense bulging pockets, drew many admiring glances. “Russian security were deeply impressed by this heavily armed man,” one British official recalled. When, however, Thatcher returned to the Kremlin, she removed her own coat and unzipped her fur-lined boots, “whereupon Detective Superintendent Parker produced a pair of high-heeled shoes from his pockets.” A firearm or a stiletto: Both seemed to have potential in the hands of a leader the Soviets had once christened the “Iron Lady.” But the story is indicative of the way the matter of her gender would often surprise and unsettle Thatcher’s contemporaries.

headline: ‘The Lightkeepers,’ by Abby Geni
abstract: This novel’s protagonist, a photographer, spends a year on an island where nature has turned hostile.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has been traumatized by Alfred Hitchcock’s “The Birds” — a high percentage of its viewers, I’d guess — may hesitate to read beyond the early pages of Abby Geni’s first novel, “The Lightkeepers.” The heroine, a photographer named Miranda, is leaving the island where she has spent the previous year, where the sea gulls now seem to be trying to make sure that no one gets out alive. “A gull slams against Miranda’s temple, knocking her off balance. . . . Wings thunder around her shoulders.” But readers who persevere beyond this unnerving beginning will find themselves carried along by a sturdy, rather old-fashioned thriller ramped up by some modern, ecologically themed plot twists.

headline: Michigan Gave State Employees Purified Water as It Denied Crisis, Emails Show
abstract: Months before Gov. Rick Snyder acknowledged a problem with the water in Flint, the state was providing coolers of purified water at its office there.
lead_paragraph: Throughout most of 2015, the administration of Gov. Rick Snyder told the residents of Flint, Mich., that their tap water was safe to drink. But emails released on Thursday suggest the state was concerned about its own employees’ exposure to the city’s water as early as January of last year, even arranging for purified water to be provided at a state office building there.

headline: Super Bowl Referee Is No Stranger to Bizarre Episodes
abstract: The referee, Clete Blakeman, is a well regarded official who may be better known for his role in Deflategate and for recently messing up a coin toss.
lead_paragraph: Referees have made a lot of news this season, not all of it favorable, and the N.F.L. will hope that the Super Bowl is not remembered for another officiating blunder. Perhaps it is odd, then, that the league has chosen Clete Blakeman as the Super Bowl 50 referee. He struggled to flip a coin successfully earlier in the playoffs and also played a small but vital role in the Deflategate contretemps, a misadventure the league probably wants to forget.

abstract: An examination of “Madoff,” the ABC mini-series about the crimes of Bernard L. Madoff, starring Richard Dreyfuss and Blythe Danner.
lead_paragraph: At the McCarran airport in Las Vegas not long ago, I handed my ticket and driver’s license to the T.S.A. agent, a woman who appeared to be in her mid-60s. She examined my return ticket to Newark and then, seemingly out of the blue, looked up and said, “I wish I could move back to New York.”

lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. – Donald J. Trump declared victory in his standoff with Fox News on Friday, telling a packed hotel ballroom in New Hampshire that he had shown the world just how tough he could be when challenged.

headline: #Match4Lara: Mixed-Race Marrow Search That’s Going Viral
abstract: Lara Casalotti’s search for a stem cell donor that matches her Italian, Thai and Chinese ancestry has gone viral, attracting international attention and scores of new potential donors.
lead_paragraph: Lara Casalotti, a 24-year-old global migration master’s student in Britain, had a pain in her lower back. At first it didn’t seem like much, but then when she was in Thailand researching migrant worker conditions, it grew worse and required hospitalization. On Dec. 14, the young human rights activist learned her pain wasn’t from a pulled muscle: She was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, a blood cancer that would require a stem cell transplant by April to save her life.

headline: How Eileen Myles, Poet, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Myles, who published two books in 2015 and won fame through the TV series “Transparent,” meditates, writes and acknowledges doing “secret things.”
lead_paragraph: She’s long been a figure in the counter culture, but recently the writer Eileen Myles has also become something of a household name. In 2015 she published two books: “Chelsea Girls,” a reissue of an autobiographical novel, and “I Must Be Living Twice: New and Selected Poems 1975-2014.” She also made it to television, where the hit series “Transparent” quoted her poetry and featured a character based on her. “I’ve had a lifelong waiting-for-the-other-shoe-to-drop feeling when something good happens,” Ms. Myles said. “But oddly, that’s not happening.” Ms. Myles, 66, splits her time between Marfa, Tex., and Manhattan, where she lives with her golden pit bull, Honey, in the rent-stabilized one-bedroom apartment in the East Village where she has lived since the ’70s.

headline: The Fashion News to Know This Week
abstract: Yeezy Season 3, Balmain for kids and Brooklyn’s side-gig.
lead_paragraph: Keeping up with Kanye

headline: There’s Only Love and Fear: On Cher’s Twitter
abstract: Introducing Social Capital, a column devoted to the social-media presences of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social media presences of celebrities.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bill Bryson on Britain
abstract: This week, Bill Bryson talks about “The Road to Little Dribbling”; Jennifer Schuessler has news from the literary world; Molly Young discusses new books about productivity; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Bill Bryson talks about “The Road to Little Dribbling”; Jennifer Schuessler has news from the literary world; Molly Young discusses new books about productivity; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Four Unfussy — and Totally Unexpected — Things We Saw at Couture Week
abstract: Chanel’s smartphone fanny packs, Schiaparelli’s potato brooches and more surprises from the spring/summer 2016 runways.
lead_paragraph: Haute couture week, fashion’s grandest event, ended on Wednesday in Paris. And while the garments we saw on the spring 2016 runways were as opulent and luxurious as ever, the season also ushered in a lighter, less serious way of dressing. Several houses showed unexpected — and downright unfussy — takes on couture. Here are four.

headline: Pablo Larraín’s ‘The Club’: At Home With the Sins of the Fathers
abstract: This Chilean director admires the film “Spotlight,” which deals with a similar subject. But he takes his tale in a different direction.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Award-nominated film “Spotlight” brings viewers inside The Boston Globe reporting team that broke the story of a widespread cover-up of sexual abuse by Catholic priests. “The Club,” the latest film by the Chilean director Pablo Larraín, takes a different angle. It brings viewers deep inside the home of four priests removed from ministry for a range of sins — or crimes.

headline: Unions Lean Democratic, but Donald Trump Gets Members’ Attention
abstract: Labor leaders fear that Mr. Trump may draw an unusually large number of union voters, possibly improving Republican chances in a November general election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of all the voters who might be expected to resist the charms of Donald J. Trump, the two million members of the Service Employees International Union would most likely be near the top of the list.

headline: Bernie Sanders Trumpets Iowa Paper’s Praise. Unsaid? It Endorsed Hillary Clinton
abstract: An ad citing endorsements of Bernie Sanders could leave the impression that he received the backing of The Des Moines Register’s editorial page. He did not.
lead_paragraph: The Des Moines Register has not endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders, but a new ad from his campaign that started running on Thursday in Iowa may lead viewers to think that it did.

headline: New York-Area Ports Shut Down as Longshoremen Walk Off the Job
abstract: The walkout came as a surprise to many, according to officials, and the reasons behind the move were not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: The East Coast’s busiest port system ground to a halt on Friday as thousands of longshoremen in New York and New Jersey walked off the job, threatening to disrupt the delivery of goods throughout the region.

headline: Creating Originality at Home and at Work
abstract: The primary preoccupation in “Originals: How Non-Conformists Move the World” by Adam Grant is to provide practical tools to “unleash” the hidden creativity in all of us.
lead_paragraph: Adam Grant is a serious social scientist, master storyteller and infectious optimist.

headline: How Scared Should You Be About Zika?
abstract: We already know which pandemics are on the horizon. We just don’t do anything about them.
lead_paragraph: Every time there is a major infectious disease outbreak that scares us — Ebola in West Africa in 2014, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) on the Arabian Peninsula in 2012 and in South Korea in 2015, and now the Zika virus in South and Central America and the Caribbean — government leaders, the public and the news media demand explanations, guidance and predictions, and often express indignation that not enough was done to prevent it. Today everyone is asking about Zika: How did this crisis happen, and what do we need to do to make it go away? We immediately forget about the outbreak that came before it, and don’t plan for the ones we know are on the horizon. Almost no one wants to talk about Ebola or MERS now, or what we have or haven’t done to try to prevent an ugly recurrence.

headline: The Perils of Political Dads
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Candidates’ fathers kept coming up during Thursday’s debate, resulting in some awkward moments.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s debate was about immigration, Obamacare and who could come up with the most unspeakable thing to do to ISIS. But it was also about dads.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Negative Ads Go After Marco Rubio, Rather Than Donald Trump
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: In the final three days before the Iowa caucuses, Ted Cruz is turning his advertising attention in the state toward Senator Marco Rubio, with his strategists letting “super PACs” handle negative spots against the supposed front-runner, Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Senator Ted Cruz, scrambling to put down a growing threat in Iowa from Senator Marco Rubio, is shifting nearly all of his negative advertising from Donald J. Trump to Mr. Rubio for the final three days of the caucuses.

headline: Man Is Charged in Death of His Daughter After Eviction Confrontation
abstract: The police said Donald Meyer Jr. pointed a rifle at a state constable, who fired in return and accidentally killed the man’s 12-year-old daughter.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania man who the authorities say pointed a rifle at a state constable evicting him has been charged in the death of his 12-year-old daughter, who was accidentally shot when the officer fired his weapon in response.

headline: A Renewable Feast
abstract: An energy revolution, suddenly in reach.
lead_paragraph: So you say you want a revolution? Politically, I’m afraid you’ll be disappointed — unless the revolution you have in mind involves putting Donald Trump’s finger on the button. But an environmental/energy revolution? That’s looking remarkably within reach.

headline: Jane Birkin on a Half-Century of Collaboration
abstract: The actress is being honored, along with her daughter, Charlotte Gainsbourg, with the “Jane and Charlotte Forever” series at Film Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Jane Birkin doesn’t watch her own films. “I don’t even know that I saw most of them when they came out,” she says, laughing. “There are a few I have seen and thank goodness never saw again.” But when T sat down with Birkin ahead of “Jane and Charlotte Forever,” a series at the Film Society of Lincoln Center dedicated to the acting work of Birkin and daughter Charlotte Gainsbourg, she was eager to talk about her many collaborations — with former partners Serge Gainsbourg and Jacques Doillon, as well as Agnès Varda — and why’s she now more content doing her own thing.

headline: A David Bowie Biography Coming From Paul Morley
abstract: The rock journalist Paul Morley will write a biography of David Bowie that is expected to be published this year.
lead_paragraph: After the death of David Bowie on Jan. 10 it’s time to start defining his posthumous legacy. The Simon & Schuster imprint Gallery Books has announced a new biography, “The Age of Bowie,” to be written by the rock journalist Paul Morley. Mr. Morley most recently worked as a writer on Grace Jones’s 2015 book, “I’ll Never Write My Memoirs.”

headline: G.O.P. Debate Without Trump Draws 12.5 Million Viewers
abstract: The Thursday debate was Fox News’s second-highest rated program in the network’s 20-year-history.
lead_paragraph: The Fox News Republican debate without Donald Trump on Thursday night drew 12.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen.

headline: Making a Haute Couture Look: Chanel
abstract: Breaking down a garment from the Chanel haute couture runway.
lead_paragraph: On the above image, we take a closer look at the making of one Chanel haute couture look.

headline: Ojen, a New Orleans Favorite, Is Back in the Liquor Cabinet
abstract: The anise-flavored liqueur, which originated in Spain, is now being produced in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Probably more than any city in America, New Orleans loves anise-flavored liqueurs. Yet it’s had a hard time holding on to them.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bill Bryson on Britain
abstract: Bryson talks about “The Road to Little Dribbling” and Molly Young discusses new books about productivity.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

headline: Bloomberg’s Presidential Dreams, and Past Realities
abstract: Beyond the precedent set by the fate of previous independent presidential candidates, Michael R. Bloomberg would face other obvious obstacles on the road to the White House.
lead_paragraph: For the past several months, it has been hard not to imagine Michael R. Bloomberg sitting in his East Side townhouse (or his compound in Bermuda, or his house in London, or his other house in London), throwing a pile of cashmere sweaters the color of citrus fruit at his television in outrage over the ascendancy of Donald J. Trump. If the world were fair, if the citizenry were sane, if cheap showmanship hadn’t long ago triumphed over civic reason, then a different, smarter, better-dressed, more managerially efficient and less volcanically arrogant Manhattan billionaire would be on a course toward the White House.

headline: Exploring Nepal and the Himalayas
abstract: A writer explores his native Nepal, more than 50 years after his parents moved to the country as Peace Corps volunteers.
lead_paragraph: A writer explores his native Nepal, more than 50 years after his parents moved to the country as Peace Corps volunteers.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are in Garden City, N.Y., and Hillsdale, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

abstract: This week’s properties are in Garden City, N.Y., and Hillsdale, N.J.
