headline: Xerox Chief Removed Ego From Decision to Split Company
abstract: The company announced that it would split in two, but Ursula Burns has not yet grabbed any role in the new structure.
lead_paragraph: Chief executives usually have big egos. Ursula Burns, though, is handing bragging rights to the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Seeking Strong Iowa Finish, Marco Rubio Targets Young Suburbanites
abstract: Interviews show that his campaign has put middle-class, college-educated parents ages 30 to 45 who live just outside Des Moines at the center of its caucus effort.
lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Inside Marco Rubio’s presidential campaign, they are known as the “perfect voter”: middle-class, college-educated suburban moms and dads ages 30 to 45 with mortgages and car payments who live just outside Des Moines.

headline: Two Bedrooms on Park Avenue for $18.9 Million
abstract: An apartment at 432 Park Avenue, currently the tallest residential tower in the Western Hemisphere, was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A spacious, light-filled aerie about midway up the recently completed 432 Park Avenue, currently the tallest residential tower in the Western Hemisphere, topping out at 1,396 feet, sold for $18,926,920.09 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Nigeria Plans Inquiry Into Deadly Clashes Between Army and Shiite Sect
abstract: Members of the sect, the Islamic Movement in Nigeria, have said that as many as 800 people were killed during the clashes in December.
lead_paragraph: KADUNA, Nigeria — Government officials in northern Nigeria on Friday announced plans to appoint a judicial commission to investigate clashes in the northern city of Zaria between the Nigerian Army and a Shiite Islamic sect that the sect’s members say ended in a massacre.

headline: Sundance Actors, Ages 10 and 16, Join the ‘Breakthrough’ Ranks
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Markees Christmas, 16, and Royalty Hightower, 10. are among those who could become The Next Big Thing.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Many of the actors referred to as “breakthrough stars” each year at the Sundance Film Festival never go on to do much of anything. But Sundance is supposed to be about discoveries, so entertainment reporters dutifully compile lists of performers who — maybe, possibly, with any luck — could become The Next Big Thing. (It’s not that hard to find candidates; publicists do most of the work.)

headline: After Settlement, Florida State Shows Sympathy for Victim: Itself
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Florida State’s response to the rape accusations against Jameis Winston — first looking the other way, then heaping scorn on his accuser’s lawsuit — sends a worrisome message to women on campus.
lead_paragraph: John Thrasher, the president of Florida State University, is a former politician who once was chairman of the Rules Committee in the Florida Senate and served a stint as chairman of the Republican Party of Florida. He knows how to spin, and how to play hardball. He proved it this week when he issued an astonishingly disingenuous and meanspirited statement after settling a Title IX lawsuit brought by a student who accused Jameis Winston, the former star quarterback of the Seminoles who won the Heisman Trophy in 2013, of raping her in 2012.

headline: Mike Huckabee and Rick Santorum Slammed for Appearing at Donald Trump Event
abstract: From the looks of the polls, they had little to lose, but Mike Huckabee and Rick Santorum might have lost the respect of some conservatives by attending a Trump rally.
lead_paragraph: From the looks of the polls, they had little to lose, but Mike Huckabee and Rick Santorum might have lost something by choosing to attend a Trump campaign rally: respect.

headline: Annuities as an Alternative to Shaky Markets? Not So Fast
abstract: A single-premium immediate annuity or lifetime annuity guarantees a steady income for life, but there are reasons for consumers to be wary.
lead_paragraph: CHECKED your retirement savings plan lately? January’s global stock market plunge is one of those moments that stoke fear among baby boomers that they might run out of money before they run out of years.

headline: The Dear Abby of Death
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Widows and Widowers', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Florence Isaacs, a widow, writes online advice columns about death, which have touched on subjects like funeral etiquette and suicide.
lead_paragraph: “I guess you could say I’m the Dear Abby of Death,” Florence Isaacs, 78, said as she scanned her email queue for new questions about the subject, one recent morning in her West Village apartment.

headline: Peter Stuyvesant and the Fun-House Mirrors
abstract: A story going around the web suggests that the Dutch ruler of what was to become New York was the father of fun-house mirrors. Not so.
lead_paragraph: Q. There’s a story going around the Internet that Peter Stuyvesant, the Dutch colonial ruler of what became New York City, was the father of fun-house mirrors. Is there any truth to it?

headline: Study Finds Growing Reason to Be Wary of Some Reflux Drugs
abstract: Proton pump inhibitor medications are among the most frequently prescribed in the country, but were not intended for long-term use.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you have seen television ads starring the beefy, affable comedian and actor known as Larry the Cable Guy.

headline: Modify Prison Sentences
abstract: A former United States pardon attorney writes that the courts “are institutionally in the best position to handle sentence reductions.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Curtailing Sexual Violence on Farms
abstract: The director of the film “Food Chains” says the solution is for produce buyers to insist on zero-tolerance policies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Biographies of Hillary Clinton for Kids of All Ages
abstract: The presidential candidate’s life story is told in picture books aimed at young children and searching biographies meant for tweens and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: This month brings four new biographies of Hillary Clinton — for kids. The wonder is that whether it’s for preschoolers or for teenagers, each in its own way presents a coherent picture of her. Getting a handle on the Democratic presidential candidate’s swerving, crowded life is a challenge for any biographer, and turning her into a subject for children seems yet more daunting. Even putting aside her husband’s PG-13 affair with an intern, it’s still not clear what the ending of Hillary’s story will be. (As of now, no children’s books about the other candidates are on the horizon.) Yet publishers have done an admirable job packaging just plain Hillary as someone whose life story children may find inspirational, and perhaps even relatable.

headline: Besieged Syria Towns Emerge as Crucial Sticking Point in Talks
abstract: Representatives of the opposition have refused to come to the table until the besieged towns are given a reprieve and bombings of civilians are halted.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — For the third time in four years, world powers have persuaded warring parties in Syria to come to Switzerland, sit around well-appointed rooms and figure out a way to stop the killings.

headline: Syria Talks Are Complicated by Competing Opposition Groups
abstract: The difficult dynamic among competing groups in Syria was apparent even as the opposition refused to participate in the talks Friday.
lead_paragraph: The latest attempt to reach a negotiated end to the conflict in Syria was meant to include participation by armed opposition groups.

headline: Editor of Esquire, David Granger, Steps Down
abstract: Mr. Granger, who has led Esquire since 1997, led the men’s magazine to digital success during a tumultuous period in the industry.
lead_paragraph: David Granger, who has led Esquire since 1997, will leave the men’s magazine on March 31, Hearst Magazines announced on Friday.

headline: Payment Processor to Stop Working With Daily Fantasy Sports Clients
abstract: In perhaps the biggest blow yet to daily fantasy sports, Vantiv Entertainment Solutions said it would no longer handle customer transactions for companies like FanDuel and DraftKings.
lead_paragraph: A payment processing company that handles a significant number of transactions for the two dominant daily fantasy sports companies notified the operators this week that it would no longer handle their payments and in fact was leaving the industry altogether. It is perhaps the biggest blow yet to an industry that has been pummeled by legal challenges in recent months.

headline: No Terror Link Found in Gun Arrest at Disneyland Paris
abstract: The man arrested Thursday with two guns at a hotel in the amusement park has no known links to terrorism but was still being held, the French authorities said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A 28-year-old man who was arrested carrying two guns at a hotel in Disneyland Paris on Thursday has no known links to terrorism but was still being detained by the police, the French authorities said on Friday.

headline: Obama Plans Speech in Springfield, Where He Announced Candidacy
abstract: When the president goes to the Illinois Capitol next month to speak, he will call for a less divisive politics, aides say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will return next month to Springfield, Ill., where he began his campaign to become president, to call for something he has struggled to deliver in Washington: a less divisive politics in America.

headline: Chicory Rocks the Salad Bowl
abstract: Whether crimson or burgundy, pointy or curly fingered, chicory brings a pleasant, bittersweet flavor to a salad.
lead_paragraph: Give me a leafy salad any day. Make it romaine, butter lettuce, watercress, red oak or a mixture of sturdy midsize leaves, and dress it simply with a good vinaigrette or with nuts, fruit and cheese. In cooler weather, compose it with as many kinds of multicolored chicory as possible.

abstract: Readers discuss how a nonprofit organization spends its donors’ money.

headline: The Eight Best Films T Saw at Sundance This Year
abstract: Plus, the $17.5-million one that got away.
lead_paragraph: Each year, there is a moment at Sundance when the murmurs begin and a narrative develops around a single film. Increasingly, this groundswell of admiration happens on Twitter, where one can either participate in the discourse or miss it completely. This year, however, it was hard to miss Sundance’s big story. On Monday, Nate Parker’s “The Birth of a Nation” premiered to rapturous applause — and by Tuesday morning, it had been rewarded with a blockbuster deal. Fox Searchlight bought the film for a reported $17.5 million, besting the previous Sundance record — held by 2006’s “Little Miss Sunshine” — by over $7 million. And by noon that day, after waiting in line for over an hour at a press screening of the film only to be stopped tantalizingly close to the front, I had missed the movie completely.

headline: Couture: In Perspective
abstract: Looking back at the spring 2016 collections in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Picture this: There you are, beside a serene expanse of green grass and oaken pathways, a pleasingly symmetric wood plank house in the distance, soothing music playing in the background. A puppy barks somewhere close by. A handsome gardener in patchwork trousers and a beige jacket appears, and points a garage door opener at the house.

headline: X Games Kick Off Without Shaun White, Their Biggest Star
abstract: White, whose style and dominance of snowboarding over a decade have made him the sport’s biggest star, was not invited — and so far nobody is saying why.
lead_paragraph: The Winter X Games, ESPN’s extravaganza of extreme snow sports, kicked off on Thursday with its crowd-pleasing showcase of some of the world’s best aerial athletes.

headline: Republican Face-Off In Iowa (Silly)
abstract: After a certain age, every man is responsible for his face.
lead_paragraph: Can’t help myself:

headline: Notable Daily News Covers
abstract: A series of attention-grabbing covers that have shifted the conversation around the struggling paper.
lead_paragraph: A series of attention-grabbing covers that have shifted the conversation around the struggling paper.

headline: Drop Dead? Not the Newly Relevant Daily News
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: After an aborted sale and layoffs, the New York tabloid has been reinvigorated with a series of striking front pages and a return to its populist legacy.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Jim Rich, the editor in chief of The Daily News, sat at his computer playing around with front-page headlines, a few well-chosen words that would capture the day’s biggest news: Sarah Palin’s endorsement of Donald Trump in the Republican presidential primary.

headline: The Films of Michael Mann
abstract: Images of the director’s work, which is being shown in a series at BAMcinématek called “Heat & Vice: the Films of Michael Mann.”
lead_paragraph: Images of the director’s work, which is being shown in a series at BAMcinématek called “Heat & Vice: the Films of Michael Mann.”

headline: Sanders Campaign Introduces Text-to-Donate App
abstract: Supporters of Mr. Sanders can now text the word “Give” to a special number and automatically donate $10.
lead_paragraph: It’s a familiar way of donating, mastered by the Red Cross during global catastrophes: Simply text a five-digit number and a donation is made seamlessly through a phone bill.

headline: What Data Can Do to Fight Poverty
abstract: Randomized evaluations of policies are how we learn what actually works.
lead_paragraph: IF social scientists and policy makers have learned anything about how to help the world’s poorest people, it’s not to trust our intuitions or anecdotal evidence about what kinds of antipoverty programs are effective. Rigorous randomized evaluations of policies, however, can show us what works and what doesn’t.

headline: Adam Silver and the Art of Giving Dap
abstract: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver’s daps — a more intricate, intimate handshake — have inspired double takes from players and gleeful Twitter posts from amused spectators.
lead_paragraph: When you are a professional athlete, the commissioner can sometimes seem like your high school principal: He is a lot older than you, he always wears a tie and he can suspend you.

headline: Michael Mann in the Spotlight at BAMcinématek
abstract: This retrospective, “Heat & Vice: the Films of Michael Mann,” focuses on his career as a feature film director.
lead_paragraph: Though Michael Mann has directed only 11 theatrical feature films in 35 years, he has left his mark on a wide range of movie types, including period drama (“The Last of the Mohicans”), sports biography (“Ali”), corporate thriller (“The Insider”) and the ever-popular Nazi paranormal horror flick (“The Keep”).

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Bernie Sanders’s Health Plan Will ‘Never, Ever Come to Pass’
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton also said that Mr. Sanders’s proposal for a single-payer health care system would thrust the nation into “a terrible, terrible national debate.”
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Hillary Clinton said on Friday that Bernie Sanders’s proposal for a single-payer health care system would thrust the nation into “a terrible, terrible national debate” and would “never, ever come to pass.”

headline: Oregon Town Torn Apart by Protest at Wildlife Refuge
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Federal Lands', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The events of the rebellion at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge have left scars and divisions in Burns, Ore., that residents say will not soon heal.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — The courthouse is still blocked by concrete bollards. Tires have been slashed. Family members and old friends have argued and refused to speak again. Fights have broken out in church.

headline: A Day at the Shvitz
abstract: Boris Tuberman and David Shapiro, the two owners of the Russian and Turkish Baths, run the business on alternate weeks and, increasingly, draw different crowds.
lead_paragraph: Boris Tuberman and David Shapiro, the two owners of the Russian and Turkish Baths, run the business on alternate weeks and, increasingly, draw different crowds.

headline: What I Love | Cynthia von Buhler
abstract: The artist, author and playwright lives with her husband, Russell Farhang, on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: The artist, author and playwright lives with her husband, Russell Farhang, on the Upper East Side.

headline: Where Cynthia von Buhler’s Fantasies Have Free Rein
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Art']
abstract: The painter, playwright, performance artist and children’s book author and illustrator lives on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia von Buhler is a painter, playwright, performance artist and children’s book author and illustrator with a reputation for being offbeat. So it’s not a complete surprise to find a miniature pig roaming around her Upper East Side apartment.

headline: Daughter-in-Law of Chile’s President Faces Corruption Charge
abstract: Prosecutors investigating a land deal said Natalia Compagnon, President Michelle Bachelet’s daughter-in-law, was part of a scheme to avoid paying taxes.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Prosecutors on Friday charged President Michelle Bachelet’s daughter-in-law, Natalia Compagnon, and 12 others in a corruption case that touches the presidential family and has damaged Ms. Bachelet’s popularity.

headline: Review: ‘I make me [sic]’ by Will Rawls
abstract: This 50-minute solo work, at MoMA PS1, looks at the relationship between movement and language.
lead_paragraph: The Latin word “sic,” when bracketed inside a quotation, indicates that the material comes straight from the source, mistakes or eccentricities included. (It’s short for “sic erat scriptum,” meaning “thus it was written.”) So how should we read the title of Will Rawls’s new lecture-dance, “I make me [sic]”? Does it suggest that the phrase “I make me” could be questioned, read as erroneous? Is “sic” a play on “sick”? Are these much too literal interpretations?

headline: Review: Jerusalem Quartet Starts a Weeklong Marathon
abstract: The group’s opening leg at the Rose Studio featured three quartets by Bartok, with Beethoven and more Bartok to come.
lead_paragraph: A good string quartet, wisdom has it, is like a single instrument with 16 strings. That sort of unity of sound and purpose is a given in any performance by the extraordinary Jerusalem Quartet, which on Thursday completed the opening leg of a marathon in which it will play all six Bartok quartets and the first six quartets by Beethoven within a single week at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. But during the Andante of Bartok’s Quartet No. 5 on Thursday, the ensemble seemed to morph not so much into a super-instrument as into something organic and animalistic that moved with louche and unpredictable grace.

headline: After 124 Years, the Russian and Turkish Baths Are Still a Hot Spot
abstract: A longstanding bathhouse in the East Village has found ways to attract a new generation of customers — though they tend to come only every other week.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday evening, it was hard to find a bit of bench at the Russian and Turkish Baths in the East Village. It was cold out, and people crowded the saunas — young, slim and in skimpy bathing suits.

headline: Review: ‘American Experience’ Traces President Garfield’s Assassination
keywords: ['Television', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This installment, “Murder of a President,” stars Shuler Hensley and Kathryn Erbe, and is based on a book by Candice Millard.
lead_paragraph: The description of the 1880 Republican convention in Tuesday night’s “American Experience” on PBS sure sounds like a possible future for both major parties as they choose their 2016 presidential candidates.

headline: The Republican Debaters (and a Nondebater)
abstract: Readers discuss Thursday’s Fox News debate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Backing Hillary Clinton Says It Will Raise More Than It Did in ’12
abstract: Priorities USA Action said on Friday that it raised more than $35 million in the last seven months, and with donors committing $42 million more, the group is in a stronger early position than any Democratic ‘super PAC’ before it.
lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” backing Hillary Clinton raised more than $25 million during the last six months of 2015, officials with the group said on Friday, with $10 million more arriving in January.

headline: Greater Diversity Sought for New York City’s Community Boards
abstract: Councilman Ritchie Torres has a bill to collect and publicize information about the panels’ members. He hopes this will prompt the boards to better reflect the neighborhoods they serve.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s ethnic diversity is on full display on and around Main Street in Flushing, Queens, a once predominantly white neighborhood that has become an overwhelmingly Asian enclave, home to another Chinatown.

headline: 22 Clinton Emails Deemed Too Classified to Be Made Public
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: The announcement was the first confirmation of “top secret” material in former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s personal email account.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Friday said for the first time that “top secret” material had been sent through Hillary Clinton’s private computer server, and that it would not make public 22 of her emails because they contained highly classified information.

headline: Evening Hours | Fairy Tale Fashion
abstract: Plus: Celebrating a retirement, art works and antiques.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Celebrating a retirement, art works and antiques.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Kenneth Chang, Jenna Wortham and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 29, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Serbia, India and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Serbia, India and Greece.

headline: Six Wild, Western Projects at L.A.’s Least Stuffy Art Fair
abstract: Several artists participating in Paramount Ranch took inspiration from the event’s setting: the eponymous film set, of “Gunsmoke” fame.
lead_paragraph: Art fairs, typically housed in convention centers and white tents, are rarely wild and woolly affairs. But as the art industry flies southwest this winter for its fair season — anchored in Art Los Angeles Contemporary, held at the Barker Hanger, and Photo LA, at the LA Mart downtown — they will find an exception to this rule at Paramount Ranch. Situated in the Santa Monica Mountains just north of Malibu, the three-year-old event takes place on the eponymous Western film set that served as the backdrop for such horse operas as “Gunfight at the OK Corral” and “Gunsmoke.”

headline: The Complete Guide to New York Men’s Fashion Week
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: From Joseph Abboud to Siki Im, it’s all here: Every designer who will be showing at the second round of men’s wear shows in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: From Joseph Abboud to Siki Im, it’s all here: Every designer who will be showing at the second round of men’s wear shows in Manhattan.

headline: Review: ‘A Dream of Red Pavilions,’ a Love Story Born in the Spirit World
abstract: Jeremy Tiang’s adaptation of Cao Xueqin’s sprawling 18th-century novel about an aristocratic family focuses on a love story.
lead_paragraph: Life could be complicated for Chinese aristocrats in the 1700s. Just ask the members of the Jia family, who populate “A Dream of Red Pavilions,” Pan Asian Repertory’s handsome and solemn new production at the Clurman Theater. They think everything is going to be fine when one of the daughters is chosen to be a royal courtesan. And they never even know that they have two immortal beings living with them, incarnated as family members.

headline: Review: From Trisha Brown, Three Last Dances (Maybe) in Brooklyn
abstract: This choreographer’s company danced “Set and Reset,” “Present Tense” and “Newark (Niweweorce),” works the company says it expects to stop performing.
lead_paragraph: Rigor; wit; experimentalism; sensuousness. The three works by Trisha Brown being performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music — “Set and Reset” (1983), “Present Tense” (2003), “Newark (Niweweorce)” (1987) — blend these virtues so provocatively that they make the best case to date for her greatness as a choreographer.

headline: Sundance Fights Tide With Films Like ‘The Birth of a Nation’
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Minorities']
abstract: At its best, the Sundance Film Festival is still helping to write the next chapters in American cinema.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Art and industry are still slugging it out at the Sundance Film Festival. That’s true even if you no longer hear many anguished discussions about the meaning of independent cinema. These days, chatter about distribution deals, a movie’s commercial potential and even if a title will be in play at the next Academy Awards tends to drown out meaningful discussions of cinema and whether independence can be quantified by vision, spirit, money or some ineluctable combination of these. Then again, given how thoroughly the industry has colonized the festival (as the clusters of agents at screenings suggest), anguishing about it can feel like misplaced nostalgia.

headline: Review: In ‘The Astronaut’s Tale,’ a Farm Boy Dreams of Flying to Mars
abstract: This chamber opera by the composer Charles Fussell is based on Jack Larson’s American update of Stravinsky’s 1917 music theater piece, “The Soldier’s Tale.”
lead_paragraph: Jack Larson, who died in September, was well known for his portrayal of the cub reporter Jimmy Olsen on “The Adventures of Superman.” His less-heralded achievements included several opera librettos, including the one for Virgil Thomson’s “Lord Byron.”

headline: Does Anybody Still Loathe Phil Collins? (Even ‘In the Air Tonight’?)
abstract: After decades spent as the target of jokes and sneers, the singer’s solo career — and the song that built his legacy — are getting fresh looks.
lead_paragraph: For many who were blessed to enter adulthood during the 1980s, it seems as if that decade will hover over us forever, its synth-pop bleats and recycled doomsday sound bites accompanying us into the twilight. Today, that feels truer than ever, as we all welcome back a familiar face: Phil Collins, the amiable sprite of pre-Internet pop. (Both the fairy-tale and computer-graphics definitions of “sprite” apply.) Emerging from semiretirement, Collins is launching a multimonth campaign of remembrance. He’s reissuing eight of his solo albums, including the four blockbusters — “Face Value”; “Hello, I Must Be Going!”; “No Jacket Required”; and “ … But Seriously” — that blanketed the 1980s, selling a combined 24 million copies in the United States alone and generating seven No. 1 singles. He has announced that he’ll record new music and launch a tour. Come October, he’ll publish his autobiography.

headline: A Deal on Concealed Handguns Stirs Virginians
abstract: A compromise to reaffirm concealed-carry reciprocity with 25 states looks like a sellout to gun-control advocates.
lead_paragraph: It seemed a major victory last month for gun safety advocates: Virginia’s attorney general announced that the state would stop recognizing concealed-carry gun permits from states with firearm standards rated inferior and unsafe. But it was overturned this week by a compromise between Gov. Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, and Republican legislative leaders in a surprise deal presented as a public safety advance but denounced as a sellout by angry families of Virginia shooting victims and gun control advocacy groups.

headline: Review: In ‘Tonight/Jungle’ by Philip Ridley, Darkness Rules
abstract: These two plays — “Tonight With Donny Stixx” and “Dark Vanilla Jungle,” playing in repertory at Here — consist of monologues by people who have committed unspeakable crimes.
lead_paragraph: Just how dark do you like it? The British dramatist Philip Ridley, whose excellent “Dark Vanilla Jungle” and “Tonight With Donny Stixx” are in repertory at Here, is notorious for testing the palates of theatergoers who think they prefer their humor black, strong and bitter.

headline: Pinter Estate Shuts Door on ‘The Room’
abstract: The Wooster Group, which opens the play next week in Los Angeles, has run into a serious, and unusual, obstacle.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Wooster Group warily circled Harold Pinter’s first play, “The Room.” The theater troupe — a fixture of the downtown New York experimental theater scene — never had quite the right configuration of actors, never quite the right opening in its schedule.

headline: Apple Sets Its Sights on Virtual Reality
abstract: Apple has acquired an augmented reality start-up called Flyby Media and hired the former director of the Center for Human-Computer Interaction at Virginia Tech.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, Google and Microsoft have all delved into virtual and augmented reality technology. Now Apple is dipping a toe into the space too.

headline: ‘Gilmore Girls’ Set to Return on Netflix
abstract: Netflix is producing a limited-series revival of the fan favorite to be overseen by the series creator, Amy Sherman-Palladino.
lead_paragraph: Friday afternoon is usually a time to release unwelcome news but this annoucement from Netflix will be anything but for “Gilmore Girls” fans: A new limited-series reunion of the show is officially in the works. It will feature the stars Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel and be overseen by the series creator, Amy Sherman-Palladino.

headline: Review: ‘Fifty Shades of Black’ Sells Sex With (Intentional) Laughs
abstract: This satire starring and co-written by Marlon Wayans has fun with the screen adaptation of a certain best-selling book.
lead_paragraph: “Fifty shades of terrible!” says Christian Black (Marlon Wayans), as he reads E. L. James’s erotic best seller “Fifty Shades of Grey.” “Who wrote this, a third grader?” Other trenchant observations pepper “Fifty Shades of Black,” a scattershot satire of the book’s 2015 screen adaptation, but a lot of wading is required to find them.

headline: Facebook Moves to Ban Private Gun Sales on Its Site and Instagram
keywords: ['Firearms', 'Gun Control', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Social Media']
abstract: The ban, which does not apply to posts by licensed gun dealers, will also apply to the company’s photo-sharing service.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is banning private sales of guns on its flagship social network and its Instagram photo-sharing service, a move meant to clamp down on unlicensed gun transactions.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Oregon, Flint
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Australian Open (Tennis)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Jane Got a Gun,’ Clear Skies, Followed by a Hail of Bullets
abstract: Natalie Portman plays a frontier wife who enlists the aid of a former lover, portrayed by Joel Edgerton, to defend her home.
lead_paragraph: “Jane Got a Gun,” a western directed by Gavin O’Connor, is a prime example of what French critics used to call a “film maudit,” or cursed film. The production, started in early 2013, was thrown into disarray when its original director, the visionary Lynne Ramsay, left mere days into shooting. At least two key cast and crew members followed her. In addition, the movie’s original distributor, Relativity Media, lost the rights to the picture in a bankruptcy proceeding. The final film was released by the Weinstein Company, without screenings for reviewers.

headline: Swiss Question Use of Malaysian Sovereign Fund Run by Prime Minister
abstract: The sovereign wealth fund, called 1Malaysia Development Berhad, or 1MDB, has been the focus of investigations around the world involving misappropriated money.
lead_paragraph: Days after the prime minister of Malaysia was cleared of wrongdoing in an investigation into transfers of money into his bank accounts, the Swiss government announced Friday that it had found serious indications that funds had been misappropriated from Malaysian state-owned companies.

headline: NYT Politics on Facebook Messenger
abstract: Our Facebook messenger experiment is over. Thanks to everyone who joined.
lead_paragraph: Our Facebook messenger experiment is over. Thanks to everyone who joined.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Bernie Sanders Rallies Volunteers in Iowa With a Call for Turnout
abstract: The senator told the people who will spend their weekend knocking on doors and begging Iowans to caucus for him that his chances of winning rely on turnout.
lead_paragraph: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont met with campaign volunteers on Friday to energize the people who will spend their weekend knocking on doors and begging residents to caucus for him on Monday.

headline: The Facts About Lead Exposure and Its Irreversible Damage
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention emphasize steps to avoid lead exposure and quickly taking action to mitigate its effects.
lead_paragraph: The crisis in Flint, Mich., over lead in the city’s water supply has many focusing on the long-term effects of lead exposure for children there. Lead exposure in childhood can have lifelong consequences. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention emphasize that preventing exposure is critical, but so are prompt efforts to mitigate lead’s effects. Here are some common questions about lead and lead poisoning.

headline: Ex-Associate of Pharmacists in Al Jazeera Report Assists Doping Inquiry
abstract: Gerry Ramogida, a prominent chiropractor who has treated Olympic athletes, is cooperating with Canadian antidoping officials after an Al Jazeera report said that his former business associates were involved in professional athletes’ doping.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — A prominent sports chiropractor who works for the Seattle Seahawks and has treated Olympic athletes from Canada and Britain is cooperating with Canadian antidoping officials in the wake of an Al Jazeera report that explored a network of people who claimed to have provided performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Madness
abstract: Finding my way in to the new album.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday I attended a small performance by the band Lucius, one of my favorites, and had a wonderful time despite Kylo Ren in the way:

headline: Hillary Clinton and the Huge 3D Printer
abstract: If there is a single symbol summing up Mrs. Clinton on the campaign trail, it is, perhaps, an enormous 3D printer she first encountered at a community college in Waterloo, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: DUBUQUE, Iowa — If there is a single symbol to sum up the standard Hillary Clinton stump speech, it is, perhaps, the enormous 3D printer she first encountered at a technical training center in Waterloo, Iowa.

headline: My Classified Life
abstract: What actually gets classified?
lead_paragraph: Gah. Another Clinton email story, this time involving emails covering material that wasn’t classified when sent but is now deemed top-secret — with the Clinton campaign demanding that they be released, presumably to show how innocuous they really were. Max Fisher at Vox suggests that it’s basically a story about the craziness and excesses of the classification system, and my own experience — although deeply out of date — suggests that he’s probably right.

headline: California: Escapee Turns Himself In
abstract: Bac Duong, one of three men who escaped from an Orange County jail, turned himself in to the police after a week on the run.
lead_paragraph: One of three men who escaped from an Orange County jail turned himself in to the police on Friday after a week on the run. The man, Bac Duong, 43, “contacted a civilian on the streets of Santa Ana and stated he wanted to turn himself in,” said Sandra Hutchens, the Orange County sheriff. Mr. Duong is charged with attempted murder and had been in custody since December. The sheriff did not release any details of his capture. The search continues for the other two men who broke out of the Orange County Central Men’s Jail — Hossein Nayeri, 37, and Jonathan Tieu, 20 — neither of whom has been seen since a 5 a.m. head count on Jan. 22. Sheriff’s department officials previously said they believed the three escapees were together in Southern California and could be receiving assistance from Vietnamese organized crime groups.

headline: Unfamiliar Terrain for Corporate Lawyer in Planned Parenthood Drama
abstract: Derek F. Foran, a commercial litigator in San Francisco, had never worked on an abortion-related lawsuit, and his involvement has turned into a full-time job.
lead_paragraph: Last July, Derek F. Foran, a partner at the large corporate law firm Morrison & Foerster, got an alert that an abortion rights organization was desperately seeking help.

headline: Police Leaders Unveil Principles Intended to Shift Policing Practices Nationwide
abstract: The recommendations include ways to defuse volatile encounters and sidestep violence, document and track the use of force, and, ultimately, restore trust in communities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Police officers should aid anyone they hurt immediately. They should abandon a so-called 21-foot rule, which in some encounters with emotionally volatile people can result in fatal shootings. And they should follow standards higher than those set by the United States Supreme Court for using force.

headline: Henry Worsley and the Undiscovered Earth
abstract: A polar explorer’s death raises a question: What does exploration mean today?
lead_paragraph: THE world of polar exploration is mourning the death of Henry Worsley, whose attempt to make the first unsupported traverse of the Antarctic continent failed only 30 miles short of his goal.

headline: Leaders Deny Strife Caused Departures From Politico
abstract: Politico’s owner and the departing founders dismissed reports that tension among the organization’s leaders had led to the moves.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, the staff at Politico noticed nearly all of its bosses — including the political publication’s founders, Jim VandeHei and John F. Harris — going in and out of meetings at its sleek new offices in Virginia.

headline: France Plans Mideast Peace Effort, and Recognition of Palestine if It Fails
abstract: The announcement was criticized by Israeli officials who said it would encourage the Palestinians not to negotiate seriously.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — France said Friday that it would organize an international conference aimed at resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and that France would recognize Palestine as an independent state if that effort failed.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Announces Plans to Boost Security and Mental Health Staff at New York City Shelters
abstract: The announcement came days after a killing at a shelter in Harlem, where a man with a history of psychiatric issues is suspected of fatally stabbing a former teacher.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration announced steps on Friday to increase security at 27 shelters and add medical staff to help identify people with mental illness among the city’s growing homeless population.

headline: Some in Iowa Surprised by Hillary Clinton’s Ease With Faith
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion and Belief', 'Methodist Church']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, who friends say turns to religion in difficult times, has recently seized opportunities to speak openly about her faith, including how it undergirds her politics.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — There was the rally in Indianola, Iowa, where Hillary Clinton told a crowd that it was the teachings of John Wesley, a founder of the Methodist religion, that had inspired her to seek the presidency, and to “get back up” after setbacks.

headline: Vaccine for Zika Virus May Be Years Away, Disease Experts Warn
abstract: Not only are scientists still learning about Zika, but any vaccine must go through rigorous testing before it’s available to the public.
lead_paragraph: As public health officials warn that the Zika virus is swiftly spreading across the Americas, the search is on to develop a vaccine to halt the disease, which could infect as many as four million people by the end of the year and has been linked to severe birth defects.

headline: Diagnoses of Concussions Increase by Nearly a Third Over Last Season
abstract: After falling during each of the past three seasons, the numbers spiked, leaving the N.F.L.’s medical community to determine the reason.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has taken measures in recent years to detect concussions by placing unaffiliated neuro-trauma consultants on the sideline, adding spotters in the press box and permitting medical personnel to call a timeout if the on-field staff misses a possible head injury. Those advances contributed to the most diagnosed concussions the league has seen in four years, according to data released Friday.

headline: Tears and Bewilderment in Brazilian City Facing Zika Crisis
abstract: The Zika epidemic has spread much faster than science’s understanding of it.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — So many distraught mothers stream into the infant ward clutching babies with abnormally small heads that the receptionist sends them outside, to see if they can find a chair to wait under the mango tree.

headline: Chargers Will Play at Least One More Season in San Diego
abstract: The team will continue to negotiate with local officials on a new facility to replace aging Qualcomm Stadium, but the door remained open for a move to Los Angeles to share a stadium with the Rams.
lead_paragraph: The Chargers will stay in San Diego at least another year.

headline: Puerto Rico Proposes Plan to Delay Its Debt Payments to Free Up Cash
abstract: The terms of the proposal call for the island’s creditors to exchange the debt they now hold for two new classes of bonds that would delay payments of principal and interest.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rican officials, meeting with creditors on Friday, proposed a broad debt exchange program meant to ease the island’s painful cash crisis by slowing down the payments it owes on its $72 billion debt.

headline: Trump’s Sons Are Still Stumping for Dad, Far Off the Trail
abstract: Hunting pheasant in Iowa, Eric and Don Trump try to show there’s an authentic middle-American relatability beneath the father’s plutocratic exterior.
lead_paragraph: OSCEOLA, Iowa — The closest I’d ever come to hunting before was buying steaks from an organic farm in upstate New York. But on Friday, three days before the Iowa caucuses, I pulled on a bright orange vest and went pheasant hunting with Donald J. Trump’s sons.

headline: Yvonne Chouteau, Native American Ballerina, Dies at 86
abstract: Ms. Chouteau, a former principal dancer of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, was one of five celebrated Native American dancers from Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: Yvonne Chouteau, a former principal dancer of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo who emerged as one of a celebrated group of dancers known as the American Indian ballerinas of Oklahoma, died on Sunday at her home in Oklahoma City. She was 86.

headline: 2 Lives Collide in Fatal Night at a Harlem Shelter
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Homeless Persons', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Deven Black and Anthony White ended up in the same room of an East Harlem shelter on Monday. By Wednesday night, Mr. Black was dead, his throat slashed, and Mr. White was on the run.
lead_paragraph: Deven Black was 62, and his life was falling apart. In a few short years, he had gone from respected, award-winning teacher to unemployed felon, losing his marriage and his home, moving into his car for a time and slipping into a depression that went largely untreated. He had nowhere to go.

headline: Las Vegas’s Soft Spot for Hockey
abstract: Despite being a warm-weather city, Las Vegas says it has the strong hockey foundation necessary to support an N.H.L. team.
lead_paragraph: Despite being a warm-weather city, Las Vegas says it has the strong hockey foundation necessary to support an N.H.L. team.

headline: British Woman Is Convicted of Joining ISIS
abstract: The authorities said Tareena Shakil, who went with her young son to Syria to become a “jihadi bride” but returned to Britain, was the first British woman convicted of joining the militants.
lead_paragraph: A British woman who the police said had traveled to Syria to become a “jihadi bride” was convicted Friday of joining the Islamic State, as the authorities continued to push back against a small but steady stream of women who seek to join in jihad by going to the militants’ self-declared caliphate.

headline: New York Council Resists Renaming Effort to Honor Evacuation Day
abstract: In opposing the renaming of a plaza in Lower Manhattan, lawyers pointed to rules that restrict such commemorations to individuals, organizations and cultural works.
lead_paragraph: Evacuation Day was New York’s biggest holiday in the 19th century. Today, the anniversary of the British evacuation of New York in 1783 has been so forgotten that City Council lawyers are resisting efforts to name a street after the historical event the holiday commemorates.

headline: The Corporate Tax Dodge Continues
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: American companies that use porous tax laws to change their nationalities have nothing to lose but their tax obligations — and most lawmakers are fine with that.
lead_paragraph: Johnson Controls, an industrial and auto parts supplier headquartered in Milwaukee, announced this week that is was selling itself to Tyco International, a maker of fire safety products based in Ireland. The deal will let Johnson Controls pass itself off as Irish and, in the process, cut its taxes in the United States by at least $150 million a year.

headline: To Las Vegans, Hockey in the Desert Isn’t So Strange
abstract: Several minor league and youth hockey teams have long called Las Vegas home. With an arena set to open in April, the only question left is whether the N.H.L. wants Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — An N.H.L. team in Las Vegas may seem like a marriage made in one of the city’s notorious wedding chapels, but the city has supported professional hockey before, with several minor league hockey teams having called it home as far back as 1968.

headline: Missing and Presumed Held by China
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Missing Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: It’s alarming that the Chinese government would ignore international borders to pursue its perceived enemies.
lead_paragraph: China has long had one of the world’s worst human rights records because of the way it treats its own citizens. Now, Beijing appears to be reaching beyond its territory and abducting critics from Hong Kong, a semiautonomous city, and from other countries, an alarming expansion of the government’s ruthless determination to crush dissent.

headline: A Misguided Plan for Carriage Horses
abstract: The industry is well-regulated, drivers make a living, and the horses are safe and healthy. So why make expensive changes?
lead_paragraph: Having failed to kill New York City’s carriage-horse industry, Mayor Bill de Blasio has settled for crippling it. He has sent a bill to accomplish this to the City Council, which is expected to vote on it next Friday.

headline: David Bowie’s Will Splits Estate Said to Be Worth $100 Million
abstract: Mr. Bowie left his SoHo apartment in Manhattan to his widow, Iman Abdulmajid Jones, and divided the bulk of his estate among her and his two children.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, David Bowie and Iggy Pop vacationed in Bali. The place made an impression on Mr. Bowie: He directed that his body be cremated and his ashes scattered there, according to his will.

headline: An Iowa To-Do List
abstract: Republicans have a choice of so many good targets to send packing.
lead_paragraph: Iowa Republicans have a lot of choices on Monday, none of whom bear any resemblance to the second coming of Abraham Lincoln.

headline: Cuomo’s Plan for Financing Affordable Housing Worries City Officials
abstract: The governor’s proposal to give New York State more control over funding affordable housing projects, city officials said, would create delays and red tape.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s budget this year calls for more state control over the financing of affordable housing, a move that New York City officials and affordable housing representatives say would slow and undermine efforts to build and maintain such units for low-income New Yorkers.

headline: The War for the West Rages On
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Land Use Policies', 'Federal Lands', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)']
abstract: The difference between the Bundys and the many other ranchers who rage over federal control of land is that they believe God is on their side.
lead_paragraph: Bozeman, Mont. — THE armed siege of a federal wildlife refuge in Oregon, which continued Friday even after one of the occupiers was killed in a confrontation with authorities, is the latest battle in a Nevada family’s war with the federal government.

headline: Parenthetical Figures
abstract: Samuel Donaldson and Brad Wilber return with a terrific Saturday challenge.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Contest Alert! George Barany and Friends is holding a crossword contest called “Eliminating the Competition,” which ends at midnight P.S.T., February 8, 2016. There are multiple prizes, but I can’t talk about them because that would be a spoiler. Click here for more information.

headline: New York City Rejects Federal Findings That Many Elementary Schools Defy Disabilities Law
abstract: The de Blasio administration took issue with a report saying that the majority of city elementary schools are not fully accessible to disabled people.
lead_paragraph: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has rejected federal government findings that the vast majority of New York City’s public elementary schools are not “fully accessible” to children with disabilities, in violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act.

headline: How to Speak of the Dead
keywords: ['Music', 'Death and Dying', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: How much should we kick folks after they die?
lead_paragraph: A MINOR media kerfuffle followed the recent passing of the Eagles guitarist, songwriter and co-founder Glenn Frey.

headline: Prosecutors Recommend Keeping Oregon Protesters in Custody
abstract: Ten of the protesters in Oregon who were arrested this week appeared before a federal magistrate in Portland. The judge ordered the Bundy brothers and three others to remain in custody; two others will be released once the occupation ends; and the judge delayed decisions on three.
lead_paragraph: Ten of the protesters in Oregon who were arrested this week appeared before a federal magistrate in Portland. The judge ordered the Bundy brothers and three others to remain in custody; two others will be released once the occupation ends; and the judge delayed decisions on three.

headline: Ammon Bundy Tells Oregon Court He Wants to ‘Preserve Freedom’
abstract: The leader of the occupation of a wildlife refuge, the first of 10 defendants to appear before a judge in Oregon, was ordered to remain in custody.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Ammon Bundy, the leader of the armed occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon, told a judge here on Friday that his actions were intended to “preserve freedom.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Blizzard City
abstract: Saturday’s snow storm led to the inevitable parade of businessmen in leather shoes jumping over puddles.
lead_paragraph: Saturday’s snow storm led to the inevitable parade of businessmen in leather shoes jumping over puddles.

headline: Knicks Look Spry as They End 4-Game Slide With a Win Over the Suns
abstract: The Knicks’ victory over the Phoenix Suns was just the sort of carefree, feel-good game they needed before they face a stern test at home Sunday night against the Golden State Warriors.
lead_paragraph: Sasha Vujacic was lying on the hardwood floor at Madison Square Garden, his arms and legs spread at midcourt as if he were making a snow angel.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
abstract: The best-selling sports books in December 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in December 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list:

headline: Review: In ‘Buyer & Cellar,’ a Shopkeeper in Barbra Streisand’s Home
abstract: At TheaterWorks in Hartford, Jonathan Tolins’s comedy imagines a job with the singer at her personal shopping mall.

headline: Review: ‘God of Carnage’ Puts Parents in a Metaphoric Bull Ring
abstract: In Yasmina Reza’s comedy, what seems like social banter takes a combative turn as two sets of Brooklyn parents discuss a violent episode involving their sons.
lead_paragraph: The ceramic red bull prancing on a shelf could be considered a symbol for the action that takes place before it, in a chic living room in Brooklyn.

headline: In Putnam County, a Humble Home for Arts on the Lake
abstract: A former firehouse embraces its second life as the base for an active nonprofit organization in Kent.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not it qualifies as a trend, the conversion of former firehouses into arts centers has been going on across the country for years. Some of the repurposed buildings are stylishly hip, like the Wasserman Projects contemporary arts center in Detroit, and some are impressively grand, like the Firehouse Arts Center in Pleasanton, Calif.

headline: Review: Spice Kitchen in Mamaroneck Lives Up to Its Name
abstract: The North Indian restaurant offers dishes that are savory, sweet and piquant, and tries to educate diners who might not be familiar with the cuisine.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things you will see when you enter Spice Kitchen, a North Indian restaurant that opened in Mamaroneck in early September, is a lovely metal carving of Annapurna Devi, the Hindu goddess of nourishment. One evening we were seated beneath a mural of the Buddha at a comfortable banquette, and the ambience had a wonderfully calming effect, which, as it turned out, was very helpful because sometimes the patience of Job was needed when dining there.

headline: Review: Shan Shan Noodles in Parsippany Favors the Foods of Northwestern China
abstract: That region of China claims wheat as a staple crop, not rice, so the the carbohydrates of choice are noodles and pancakes. Even mainstream Chinese dishes have a northwestern spin.
lead_paragraph: Food-obsessed souls like myself are on a perpetual quest to uncover a culinary treasure. The unspoken rule in the search for authenticity: The more unassuming the exterior, the more likely we will find an edible jackpot inside.

headline: Hot Toddies That Will Keep Long Island Winter at Bay
abstract: Hot drinks of various flavors and sweet toppings can warm you up as well as serve as substitutes for dessert.
lead_paragraph: The weather during the holidays was unusually balmy, so Bobby Gulinello strung colored lights around South Shore Dive Pub & Kitchen and used a snow machine to simulate frost on the windows.

headline: Review: At Unionville’s Cure Restaurant and Bar, Bacon Is Basic
abstract: The establishment thoughtfully labels some dishes for vegetarians and diners who avoid gluten, but its six varieties of house-made bacon dominate.
lead_paragraph: Cure Restaurant and Bar, in Unionville, is a hard place to pigeonhole. A lively, boisterous bar area occupies half its footprint, while the nearby dining room is the image of uncluttered refinement, with sufficient space between linen-draped tables to provide a sense of intimacy.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: “The Great Escape” is on TV, or you can opt for “Dateline,” “Cops,” “Sex Sent Me to the E.­R.” or the Wes Anderson film “Rushmore.
lead_paragraph: “The Great Escape” is on TV, rendering all of Saturday’s other programming a pleasant superfluity. If “Dateline,” “Cops” or “Sex Sent Me to the E. R.” don’t grab your attention, go the other direction and stream the Wes Anderson film “Rushmore.”

headline: Fame Is Fleeting. The Wall Is Forever.
abstract: Celebrities like New York's pizza joints, and customers like the celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities like New York's pizza joints, and customers like the celebrities.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If you were going to put something in a population to keep them down for generations to come, it would be lead.”

headline: Corrections: January 30, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: At Some Restaurants in China, a Shortcut to Addictive Food: Poppies
abstract: At least 36 restaurants across China were investigated in the past week for adding poppy capsules and other illegal ingredients to food, the state news media said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It is no secret that fans of Chinese food often find it addictive. They speak longingly of the numbing spice of Sichuan peppercorn or the sour herbs found in Yunnan cooking.

headline: Angelique Kerber Upsets Serena Williams to Win Australian Open
abstract: Kerber, the seventh seed, claimed her first major title and prevented the top-ranked Williams from tying Steffi Graf’s Open-era record of 22 Grand Slam singles championships.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — At the Australian Open on Saturday, all that stood between Serena Williams and Steffi Graf was Angelique Kerber, who took 33 majors to reach her first Grand Slam final. Kerber was trying to become the first German to win a women’s major since Graf won in 1999. Williams was trying to join Graf as a 22-time major winner in singles.

headline: Fake Online Locksmiths May Be Out to Pick Your Pocket, Too
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Locks and Keys', 'Search Engines', 'Online Advertising', 'Maps', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Odds are good that when you search Google for someone to help you get into your home or car, results will include poorly trained subcontractors who will squeeze you for cash.
lead_paragraph: Maybe this has happened to you.

headline: Obama’s Budget Urges a Deeper Commitment to Computer Education
abstract: The president seeks $4 billion to help states expand in an area he views as critical to young people’s success in a changing job market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will call for spending $4 billion to help states pay for computer science education in the schools when he presents his 2017 budget to Congress, administration officials say.

headline: She? Ze? They? What’s In a Gender Pronoun
abstract: Inside the race to be the next great pronoun of our era.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What happens when 334 linguists, lexicographers, grammarians and etymologists gather in a stuffy lecture hall on a Friday night to debate the lexical trends of the year?

headline: At Sundance, Rubbing Shoulders With A-Listers, for a Price
keywords: ['Parties (Social)', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Movies', 'Celebrities']
abstract: Want to party with the movie stars, but not invited? V.I.P. concierges offer well-heeled clients access to screenings, clubs and parties.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Meet and greets with top D.J.s. Easy entry into celebrity-packed parties. Private rides to and from the most popular hotels, bars and restaurants in town, without Uber’s chatty drivers and ubiquitous surge pricing.

headline: Clinton to Attack Sanders in Iowa on Gun Control
abstract: Hillary Clinton will spend her last Saturday before the Iowa caucuses hitting Bernie Sanders, her rival for the Democratic nomination, on an issue that could potentially hurt him the most.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton will spend her last Saturday before the Iowa caucuses hitting Bernie Sanders on the issue that could potentially hurt him the most: guns.

headline: Miners in China Are Rescued After 36 Days Underground
abstract: The four men were among 29 miners caught when a cavernous gypsum mine in Pingyi County, Shandong Province, collapsed on Dec. 25. Thirteen are still missing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Four miners have emerged alive after 36 days trapped 720 feet underground in eastern China, after a huge, intensely reported rescue effort in this country that has been plagued by mine disasters.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: A Signal of Who Might Win the Caucuses
abstract: We sent our reporter Trip Gabriel to live in Iowa. Here’s what he’s watching for as the caucuses near.
lead_paragraph: CLINTON — Good morning from Iowa, where the campaigns have entered the final wind sprint to the finish line. As Donald J. Trump returns to the state, joining nine other Republicans and all three Democrats, campaign operatives and the news media will be anticipating one thing more than any rally: the release at 5:45 p.m. Central time of J. Ann Selzer’s final Iowa Poll.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the midst of the blizzard to the streets of Soho in London.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the midst of the blizzard to the streets of Soho in London.

headline: In India, a Small Band of Women Risk It All for a Chance to Work
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The Indian Constitution guarantees equality under the law. But for women facing a patriarchal social order, strict caste rules and centuries of traditions, that guarantee means little.
lead_paragraph: On a humid, sweaty, honking afternoon last summer, two women were making their way through the court complex in the north Indian city of Meerut, searching for the office of the subdivisional magistrate.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Making Surprising Gains With Less Affluent Whites
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: But there are signs that he’s losing ground with affluent whites, and he’s still struggling with nonwhite voters.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders’s coalition once looked very familiar: He had strong support among well-educated and affluent liberal white voters of the sort who backed Barack Obama, Bill Bradley and Jerry Brown. He struggled among less affluent voters.

headline: ‘We Will Not Apologize’: Chronicling the Defiant Women of India
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Ellen Barry, the South Asia bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses the complex challenge of reporting on a women’s rebellion in an Indian village.
lead_paragraph: Eight months ago, on one of my first visits to the village of Peepli Khera, India, I saw a scene that captivated me, the way a character in a novel can sometimes captivate me.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: How did you do on the “A Little Variety” puzzles?
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Chuck Hagel Encourages Michael Bloomberg on 2016 Race
abstract: Chuck Hagel said he would be likely to back an independent president bid by Michael R. Bloomberg if Republicans nominate a candidate he considers unacceptable.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Hagel, the former Republican senator from Nebraska who served as President Obama’s secretary of defense, says he is likely to back an independent presidential bid by Michael R. Bloomberg if Republicans nominate a candidate he considers unacceptable.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Lessons From Earnings Season
abstract: Analysis on Apple’s iPhone sales, Microsoft’s rebound, Amazon’s profits and Facebook’s success with mobile advertising.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Rules for Clearing Off Snow and Ice
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Smells and Odors', 'Cooperatives', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Sidewalks', 'Roofs']
abstract: This week’s subjects include responsibility for clearing sidewalks of snow; controlling ventilation and odors; and the value of roof decks.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Blizzard City
abstract: Saturday’s snow storm led to the inevitable parade of businessmen in leather shoes jumping over puddles.
lead_paragraph: The legendary Times fashion photographer Bill Cunningham spots and distills the latest trends from the runways of Paris to the colorful streets of New York.

headline: 10 Children Among the Dead as a Migrant Boat Capsizes Off Turkey
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Coast guard officials said at least 33 people had died, and 75 were rescued. But officials suspect more migrants were trapped inside the boat and that the death toll will rise.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — One photo showed a small boy, perhaps 3 years old, dressed for a mild winter — dark blue pants and coat, a sky blue sweater for extra protection. The grown-up who had dressed him for the journey — barely five miles across the Aegean Sea — had cared enough to put on matching socks, with little blue cars. The boy was lying face up on the rocks. A winter hat, sky blue with a white pom-pom, covered his lifeless face.

headline: Hillary Clinton for the Democratic Nomination
abstract: Voters have the chance to choose one of the most broadly and deeply qualified presidential candidates in modern history.
lead_paragraph: For the past painful year, the Republican presidential contenders have been bombarding Americans with empty propaganda slogans and competing, bizarrely, to present themselves as the least experienced person for the most important elected job in the world. Democratic primary voters, on the other hand, after a substantive debate over real issues, have the chance to nominate one of the most broadly and deeply qualified presidential candidates in modern history.

headline: A Chance to Reset the Republican Race
abstract: Gov. John Kasich is the only plausible choice for Republicans tired of the extremist front-runners in the primary contest.
lead_paragraph: The battle to be the Republican choice for president has been nasty, brutish and anything but short. The hope among some Republicans is that the Iowa caucuses on Monday and the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 9 will promote a candidate who can appeal to the half of their electorate that doesn’t support the two current front-runners.

headline: A Little Walmart Gift Card for You, a Big Payout for Lawyers
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Gift Cards and Certificates', 'Coupons', 'Consumer Protection', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: A member of a class-action lawsuit received a Walmart gift card as part of a settlement, but because of a legal ambiguity, the real gift may be for the lawyers.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, we learn a new definition of the word “gift” and plumb the meaning of the word “coupon.” No, you don’t need a dictionary. But a sense of humor might help.

headline: Ve Neill, Oscar-Winning Makeup Artist: Putting a Face on Fantasy
abstract: Ms. Neill, who did the makeup for Michael Keaton in “Beetlejuice” and Johnny Depp in “Pirates of the Caribbean,” has been fascinated with transforming people since she was 5.
lead_paragraph: Ve Neill  is an independent makeup artist for the movie industry in Studio City, Calif.

headline: U.S. Challenges China’s Claim of Islands With Maritime Operation
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: In an exercise intended to challenge excessive territorial claims by China, a United States vessel entered the disputed waters in the Paracel Islands without giving China notice.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China on Saturday accused the United States Navy of violating its laws by sending a warship within the 12-mile territorial zone of an island it claims in the South China Sea after the Pentagon said a Navy vessel had conducted a freedom of navigation operation.

headline: Variety: Spiral
abstract: Will Shortz returns with a Spiral variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I love these Spiral puzzles. On the surface, they seem really easy, but keeping track of the entries going inward and outward can be tricky.

headline: New Weapon to Fight Zika: The Mosquito
abstract: Genetically engineered mosquitoes are among the cutting-edge weapons being tested against diseases, even as some experts say old-fashioned tools like DDT may be worth discussing.
lead_paragraph: Every weekday at 7 a.m., a van drives slowly through the southeastern Brazilian city of Piracicaba carrying a precious cargo — mosquitoes. More than 100,000 of them are dumped from plastic containers out the van’s window, and they fly off to find mates.

headline: Students Say Racial Hostilities Simmered at Historic Boston Latin School
abstract: Two black students, employing YouTube videos and a hashtag, started a campaign to expose what they see as a hostile climate at Boston Latin School, a beacon of high achievement that was founded in 1635.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With court-ordered desegregation of public schools unfolding violently across this city in the mid-1970s, Boston Latin, then about 90 percent white, began admitting more minority students, remaining a place of relative calm in a city engulfed in protest.

headline: Iowa Will Gauge Ardor to Upend Politics as Usual
abstract: Advantages that usually turn candidates like Hillary Clinton and Jeb Bush into inevitable nominees — money, experience and endorsements — will be tested against promises of upheaval.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The presidential race hurtled over the weekend toward a watershed moment: voting that will start to reveal the true depth of Americans’ desire to cast aside traditional politicians and Washington-style compromise and embrace disruptive outsiders appealing to their passions.

headline: Kerber Keeps Cool in Australia, Long a Williams Safe Haven
abstract: Before Saturday, Serena Williams had always won the Australian Open title after reaching the semifinals. But even she knew not to take victory for granted.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — You cannot accuse Serena Williams of not providing fair warning.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Voters Share Anger, but Direct It Differently
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: In interviews, supporters of Mr. Trump expressed concern about terrorists coming across the border, while Mr. Sanders’s backers were anxious about the growing inequality in wealth and income.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — They are angry at a political system they see as rigged. They feel squeezed by immigration, or the power of big banks. They sense that America is heading in the wrong direction, but emphatically believe only their candidate has the strength and vision to change things.

headline: Start-Ups Take Rites From the Funeral Home to the Family Home
abstract: Services are popping up to help relatives looking to bid a more intimate and natural farewell take their end-of-life rituals out of the mortuary.
lead_paragraph: When people call Undertaking LA, they might ask a question like: “My mom just died of cancer in our home. We want to keep her until noon tomorrow. Is that legal? Is that O.K.?”

headline: Leadership Means Learning to Look Behind the Mask
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Careers and Professions', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: Encouraging employees to give you honest, even critical, feedback can help you develop new skills and be a better boss.
lead_paragraph: I waited until it was too late to get the best feedback I ever received in my life.

headline: Meredith Wild, a Self-Publisher Making an Imprint
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Ms. Wild, a successful writer of erotic fiction, is one of a growing number of enterprising authors who are building small publishing houses, revealing just how much self-publishing has matured.
lead_paragraph: One chilly morning this month, Meredith Wild, the best-selling romance novelist, was sitting in her library in Destin, Fla., wrapped in a loose black sweater in front of a crackling fire. Most mornings, Ms. Wild writes her novels in this spot after her children leave for school, but that day she had other business to attend to. She had a call with a reality TV production company that is developing a show about her, and later, a conference call with a team at Waterhouse Press, the small imprint that is publishing her new novel in June.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: It’s Time to End Favoritism Toward College Athletes

headline: Uncomfortable Question for Ted Cruz on Obamacare Silences the Room
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A Hillary Clinton supporter whose brother-in-law, uninsured until the Affordable Care Act, died of cancer, asked Senator Ted Cruz what he would replace the law with if he dismantled it.
lead_paragraph: HUBBARD, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz is often asked about doing away with President Obama’s health care law. He is rarely pressed by voters on what will replace it.

headline: Anna Robbins
abstract: The costume designer for “Downton Abbey” on Russian murder mysteries, watching the river flow, and, of course, beautiful gowns.
lead_paragraph: Anna Robbins is a costume designer best known for her work on “Downton Abbey,” which airs on “Masterpiece” on PBS.

headline: Honing Skills in U.S., a Group of Teenagers Is Fueling China’s Hockey Shift
abstract: Trained in the United States, a group of teenagers are getting ready to display the evolution of Chinese hockey as interest spreads ahead of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, when sporting interests in Beijing gravitated toward the coming 2008 Summer Olympics, a small group of boys began China’s hockey revolution by happenstance.

headline: An Internet Surprise From Louis C.K.: Barroom Drama Flecked With Dark Humor
abstract: With no advance warning, the comedian released a new online show called “Horace and Pete” on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Louis C.K. pulled a Beyoncé on Saturday, releasing a new online show called “Horace and Pete” directly to fans with no prior warning.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Plague of Helicopters Is Ruining New York
abstract: Tourist helicopters disturb the city’s few oases of peace and quiet.
lead_paragraph: IN recent years, New York City has invested over $2 billion in spectacular new waterfront parks. But that investment, and New Yorkers’ enjoyment of their parks and neighborhoods, is being ruined by an invasion of noisy, polluting tourist helicopters.

headline: Welcome to the Age of the Commando
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Our increasing use of Special Operations Forces ensures we never confront the wars fought in our name.
lead_paragraph: A FEW months ago, my wife and I had dinner with a couple we didn’t know very well. It was awkward at first, but there was wine, and conversation soon followed. At one point, the wife asked about my tour in Iraq, where I served four years as a cavalry officer. I began talking about the desert, the tribal politics and the day-to-day travails of counterinsurgency. “That’s all fine,” the husband interrupted. “But tell us about the super-soldiers. The Special-Ops guys. That’s what people care about.”

headline: Here’s the Beauty of Trump
abstract: He knows how to act properly when he needs to, he claims over the phone. But right now he doesn’t need to.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — THE White House has a strange, mind-warping effect on its occupants.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Made in Vermont
abstract: It’s an off-the-grid state, and he is an off-the-grid politician.
lead_paragraph: Rutland, Vt. — BERNIE SANDERS gained his largest margin of victory as a member of the House of Representatives the same year that Vermont experienced its fiercest conservative backlash. In the wake of a bruising fight over civil unions in 2000, Republicans regained the Vermont House and gave the popular Democratic governor, Howard Dean, his severest test.

headline: Calls for More Diversity in Academy Awards
abstract: Several readers argue that the sole standard for a nomination should be the quality of the artistic performance or film, not skin color.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the protests over the all-white nominees in the acting categories.

headline: Trump, Sanders and the Revolt Against Decadence
