keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Recession and Depression', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, in very different ways, are telling us we don’t have to settle for things as they are.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the puzzles of the 2016 campaign, unexpectedly defined by the ascent of a billionaire reality TV star and a septuagenarian Vermont socialist, is why now? Yes, voters are angry, yes, they’re exhausted and disgusted and cynical about everything. But why is everything boiling over in this particular cycle, in this presidential campaign?

headline: Is This the Oldest Image of the Virgin Mary?
abstract: Syrian Christianity, threatened with destruction, still has secrets to reveal.
lead_paragraph: THE Virgin Mary, the mother of Jesus, is the most revered woman in the Christian tradition. In the history of art, she appears almost as frequently as Jesus himself. But for the past 80 years, one of the oldest paintings of her may have been hiding in plain sight.

headline: Her Father Shot Her in the Head, as an ‘Honor Killing’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Women and Girls', 'Honor Killings', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The brave young woman who is the focus of an Oscar-nominated documentary tried to stand up to a culture that allows “honor killings.”
lead_paragraph: WHETHER it wins or not, the Oscar nominee with the greatest impact — saving lives of perhaps thousands of girls — may be one you’ve never heard of.

headline: How to Raise a Creative Child. Step One: Back Off
abstract: Child prodigies rarely become adult geniuses who change the world. Originality is difficult to encourage but easy to thwart.
lead_paragraph: THEY learn to read at age 2, play Bach at 4, breeze through calculus at 6, and speak foreign languages fluently by 8. Their classmates shudder with envy; their parents rejoice at winning the lottery. But to paraphrase T. S. Eliot, their careers tend to end not with a bang, but with a whimper.

headline: Everybody’s a Critic. And That’s How It Should Be.
abstract: To be a critic is to be a defender of the life of art and a champion of the art of living.
lead_paragraph: NEXT month, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will complete its annual ritual of designating the best in two dozen cinematic categories. The Oscars have come under fire this year for the predictable, shameful racial homogeneity of their nominations, but that is not the only reason to complain.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Holy War
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Evangelical Movement']
abstract: I’m less interested in whether a president kneels down than in whether he or she stands up for the right things, including religious pluralism.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — IN the final, furious days of campaigning here, it was sometimes hard to tell whether this state’s Republicans were poised to vote for a president or a preacher, a commander or a crusader.

headline: Fall in Logging Leaves Myanmar’s Elephants Jobless
abstract: Shrinking forests and a ban on raw timber exports have left an uncertain future for Myanmar’s 5,500 or so pachyderms in captivity.
lead_paragraph: Shrinking forests and a ban on raw timber exports have left an uncertain future for Myanmar’s 5,500 or so pachyderms in captivity.

headline: Unemployed, Myanmar’s Elephants Grow Antsy, and Heavier
keywords: ['Elephants', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Unemployment', 'Logging Industry', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Conservation of Resources', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Wood and Wood Products']
abstract: Elephants, which hold a near-mystical place in Myanmar, are out of work because of shrinking forests, and the nation must now figure out how to handle 5,500 pachyderms in captivity.
lead_paragraph: WA KALU PU, Myanmar — Dragging giant tree trunks up and down the steep hillsides of sweltering jungles is a tough job. But there is something worse, say owners of Myanmar’s logging elephants: having no job at all.

headline: De Blasio Arrives in Iowa to Help Hillary Clinton Before Caucuses
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York is visiting the state to drum up support for his former boss, ahead of the caucuses on Monday.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York landed in this Midwestern city last spring as a man on a mission, delivering a fiery speech on the evils of inequality and calling on presidential contenders to adopt his liberal views.

headline: Jamie Murray Wins in Doubles; Andy Murray Has a Long Night, Too
abstract: Just 18 hours before his singles final against Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray watched his older brother and Bruno Soares beat Daniel Nestor and Radek Stepanek.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was after midnight, meaning it was officially Sunday, the day of his Australian Open singles final against Novak Djokovic, and Andy Murray was in the audience at Rod Laver Arena shooting video with his smartphone. On the court, Murray’s older brother, Jamie, paused in mid-interview to scold him. “Andy, you should be in bed,” he said.

headline: Why Sports Fans Risk Life and Limb for a Rolled-Up T-shirt
abstract: From the perspective of the teams, it’s easy to understand the T-shirt-cannon phenomenon. But from the fans’ perspective, the phenomenon mystifies.
lead_paragraph: At Knicks games, it’s the 7th Avenue Squad. The Mets have the Pepsi Party Patrol. The Nets have the inanimate Team Hype. But every team in sports with any semblance of a marketing department has its own version of the Fan Patrol or Fun Police. This unnaturally peppy collective represents a cross between a cheerleading squad and the “motivators” at a bar mitzvah party. Their demeanor and high energy often totally at odds with the tenor of the game, they attempt to energize the crowd by cavorting with the mascot and dancing with kids on the Jumbotron and hosting the fan contest during breaks in the game. But the highlight of their shift comes when they launch T-shirts into the crowd.

headline: Icy Surface Ahead (Please Speed Up)
abstract: About 20,000 spectators flocked to Eagle River, Wis., known as the snowmobile capital of the world, for the annual World Championship Snowmobile Derby in January.
lead_paragraph: About 20,000 spectators flocked to Eagle River, Wis., known as the snowmobile capital of the world, for the annual World Championship Snowmobile Derby in January.

headline: The Iowa Push
abstract: With the caucus on the horizon, the presidential candidates blanketed the state with events.
lead_paragraph: With the caucus on the horizon, the presidential candidates blanketed the state with events.

headline: Remaining California Jail Escapees Are Captured in San Francisco
abstract: Two men who fled a maximum-security jail in Southern California on Jan. 22 were caught a day after a third fugitive turned himself in, officials said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The two remaining fugitives who escaped from a maximum-security jail in Southern California were recaptured in the Bay Area on Saturday, ending an eight-day manhunt, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Tentative Agreement Reached for More Democratic Debates, Aides Say
abstract: Aides to Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders said the campaigns were working on details for holding a debate in New Hampshire next week and three more after that.
lead_paragraph: After days of jostling over whether to meet for more debates, and how many, aides to Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders have reached an agreement, of sorts, they said Saturday: The two will meet next week in New Hampshire and will hold three more debates thereafter.

headline: A Warrior Can Join the Likes of Chamberlain, Bird and Fat Lever
abstract: Draymond Green has always been known for his defense, but he has emerged as the N.B.A.’s most unheralded triple-double threat since Lever, whose prime was short but memorable.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the Golden State Warriors’ championship run last season, Draymond Green became nearly as famous for his offbeat personality as for his lockdown defense.

headline: John Kasich Courts New Hampshire Independents
abstract: “The Republican Party is my vehicle, but it has never been my master,” Mr. Kasich said as he wooed middle-of-the road voters in New Hampshire while his opponents scoured Iowa for last-minute converts.
lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H. – Of all the Republicans campaigning in New Hampshire, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has appealed most explicitly to the state’s population of unpredictable independent voters and moderate Republicans, who play an outsize role in presidential primaries here.

headline: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, a Distinct Sight in Iowa, Rallies the Clinton Troops
abstract: The New York mayor sought to emphasize Hillary Clinton’s foreign policy know-how, a slight shift from his usual focus on social issues, in his remarks at a canvassing event in Des Moines.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The tall man arrived at the house around noon, bending slightly to avoid a ceiling beam, and smiled at the sight of two dozen Hillary Clinton supporters in a sunlit living room.

headline: Donald Trump Offers to Let Children ‘Run Through’ His Plane While He Speaks in Iowa
abstract: At the outset at a rally in Dubuque, Iowa, Mr. Trump offered to keep children happy after waiting more than an hour in a chilly airport hangar by letting them board his plane.
lead_paragraph: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump’s golden-lettered plane is one of the biggest toys in national politics. And he used it as such on Saturday, to keep children happy after waiting more than an hour in a chilly airport hangar for his first of three rallies today.

headline: As Deaths Mount, an Ever Expanding Recall
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The Takata airbag recalls have mushroomed to an estimated 28 million inflaters in more than 24 million cars at 14 automakers.
lead_paragraph: The Takata airbag recalls have mushroomed to an estimated 28 million inflaters in more than 24 million cars at 14 automakers.

headline: Takata’s Faulty Airbags Still Exact Toll as Recalls Lag
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Millions of people are still driving vehicles with Takata airbags that may pose a lethal danger because they have not been repaired or, in some cases, even recalled.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. — The shrapnel from the Ford Ranger airbag punctured Joel Knight’s neck with so much force that investigators initially did not rule out a fatal shooting.

headline: Kenny Sailors, a Pioneer of the Jump Shot, Dies at 95
abstract: A number of players can claim to be the one who created the shot that revolutionized basketball, but many students of the game give the distinction to Sailors.
lead_paragraph: There was just one witness to the moment Kenny Sailors helped revolutionize the game of basketball — his brother, Bud — but by all accounts, no one has ever doubted their story.

headline: Iowa Official Criticizes Cruz Campaign Over Mailer
abstract: Iowa’s secretary of state chastised the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz on Saturday for sending a mailer that he said violated “the spirit of the Iowa caucuses” and misrepresented state election law.
lead_paragraph: HAMLIN, Iowa — Iowa’s secretary of state chastised the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz on Saturday for sending a mailer that he said violated “the spirit of the Iowa caucuses” and misrepresented state election law.

headline: Message to Buyers
abstract: Yaakov Bendavid returns with a message for all of us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We last met up with Yaakov Bendavid nearly two years ago, when he was caught cheating by turning failing F grades to passing Ds. Today, Mr. Bendavid presents us with a list of warnings to buyers that are clued in a punny way. Caveat emptor. Five of the six theme entries make their debuts today, and some work better than others. I liked “Offer of free pillow fill?” for NO MONEY DOWN, “Desert supermarket?” for STORE IN A DRY PLACE and “Sign on the N.S.A.’s entrance” for INTEL INSIDE. For some reason, “Note on a watered-down assault indictment?” for BATTERY NOT INCLUDED made me cringe a bit.

headline: Republicans Attack Hillary Clinton Over Classified Emails
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'E-Mail']
abstract: The candidates got new ammunition with the State Department’s disclosure that “top secret” information passed through her private server as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — With the final hours before the Iowa caucuses ticking away, Republicans are seizing on new and potentially damaging revelations about Hillary Clinton’s handling of sensitive information as evidence that she is unfit to be president.

headline: Liz Cheney to Run for Wyoming’s Only House Seat
abstract: Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, has filed to run for Wyoming’s House seat, which will be open after Representative Cynthia M. Lummis retires at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, has filed with the Federal Election Commission to run for Wyoming’s only House seat, a return to politics after her short-lived but much discussed bid for the Senate two years ago.

headline: Review: Louis C.K.’s ‘Horace and Pete,’ Mournful and Unshakable
abstract: The new series, released without warning on Louis C.K.’s website, may be described as a “Cheers” spec script written by Eugene O’Neill.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you don’t want to go where everybody knows your name. Sometimes it becomes oppressive — the history, the choking familiarity, the endlessly repeated fights. Sometimes you want to go just about anywhere else. But what choice do you have?

headline: Donald Trump Leads Ted Cruz in Top Iowa Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The respected Des Moines Register poll found that Donald J. Trump has widened his lead against Senator Ted Cruz in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Donald J. Trump has widened his edge against Ted Cruz in Iowa, according to a Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics poll on Saturday that shows the billionaire gaining momentum right ahead of Monday’s caucuses.

headline: Why This Is the Iowa Poll That Everyone Was Waiting For
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The final Des Moines Register survey before the Iowa caucuses is a huge event in the world of political polling. Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are the leaders.

headline: One Dead and Several Wounded in Shooting at Colorado Motorcycle Expo

lead_paragraph: Shots rang out when a violent confrontation between biker gangs erupted on Saturday at a motorcycle show in Denver, leaving one person dead and several others injured, the police said.

headline: Greece Resists Its Role as European Union’s Gatekeeper
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Europe has reached a turning point in the migrant crisis, and is starting to coalesce around proposals that would effectively turn Greece into a giant processing center.
lead_paragraph: IDOMENI, Greece — On a recent weekday, 40 buses jammed into the parking lot of a gas station near the Macedonian border, carrying thousands of refugees who had survived a perilous crossing on wintry seas from Turkey.

headline: Now a Survivor, Rod Carew Weeps Without Shame
abstract: The Hall of Famer made his first public appearance since he was nearly killed by a heart attack.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The black vest that Rod Carew wears everywhere these days has pockets on both sides, giving him a choice of where to carry the battery-powered medical device that keeps him alive.

headline: Special Election Is Set for April to Fill Seats Left Vacant in Albany
abstract: An election will be held on April 19 to fill four vacancies in the State Legislature, including those created by the convictions of Sheldon Silver and Dean G. Skelos.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Saturday that April 19 had been set as the date for a special election to fill four vacancies in the State Legislature, including seats left empty when Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly speaker, and Dean G. Skelos, the former Senate majority leader, were convicted on federal corruption charges last year.

headline: Brett Brown and Steve Kerr: Coaches With Much in Common, Aside From Records
abstract: Brown, coach of the Philadelphia 76ers (the worst team in the league), and Kerr, coach of the Golden State Warriors (the best team on the planet), find themselves in disparate roles.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Steve Kerr and Brett Brown began to form their relationship during the 2002-3 season with the San Antonio Spurs. Kerr was in his final season as an N.B.A. player, and Brown was in his first season as the team’s director of player development. They took to each other instantly.

headline: Authorities Arrest Son of Ex-Leader in Sri Lanka
abstract: Yoshitha Rajapaksa, the second son of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, was arrested by financial crimes investigators after being questioned over his involvement in alleged money-laundering.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lankan authorities arrested a son of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa on money-laundering charges on Saturday, the government’s latest attempt to prosecute members of the previous administration, many of whom have been under investigation since Mr. Rajapaksa’s election defeat last year.

headline: Dispatches From the Final Dash of Presidential Candidates in Iowa
abstract: Candidates are crisscrossing the state this weekend in a frantic sprint, cajoling the last undecided voters and energizing supporters before Monday’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: After hundreds of campaign stops and tens of thousands of television ads, candidates are crisscrossing Iowa this weekend on a final, frantic dash, cajoling the last undecided voters and energizing supporters to head to Monday night’s caucuses. Fending off drowsiness with Red Bull and Katy Perry songs, they are racing through a mind-muddying 55 events, from Dubuque in the northeast to Council Bluffs in the southwest, in a blur of speeches and handshakes.

headline: President Xi Jinping of China Is All Business in Middle East Visit
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: President Xi’s arrival after the lifting of sanctions related to Iran’s nuclear program provided a moment for China to set the stage for future deal-making.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When President Xi Jinping of China traveled to the Middle East this month he dropped in on two regional rivals, Saudi Arabia and Iran, a feat few global leaders could pull off.

headline: Ted Cruz Counters Donald Trump With Targeted Approach in Iowa
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Cruz’s operation, using a narrower approach than that of Donald J. Trump’s, is trying to persuade Iowans who are frequent caucus participants to commit to turning out on Monday.
lead_paragraph: URBANDALE, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz’s leading Iowa supporters say his get-out-the-vote operation is the best they have seen for a presidential campaign here. He had better hope they are right.

headline: Myanmar’s Unemployed Elephants
abstract: Myanmar’s newly democratic government has banned the export of raw timber, to help fight deforestation. But that has idled thousands of the elephants that toil in the logging industry.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s newly democratic government has banned the export of raw timber, to help fight deforestation. But that has idled thousands of the elephants that toil in the logging industry.

headline: Turkey Accuses Russia of Again Violating Its Airspace
abstract: Turkey’s Foreign Ministry said a Russian fighter jet entered the country’s airspace after radar units warned it to turn back.
lead_paragraph: Turkey on Friday accused Russia of violating its airspace for the second time in recent months, injecting fresh rancor into a relationship that has been badly strained since Turkish fighters shot down a Russian plane that entered the country from Syria in November.

headline: A Bloomberg Poll Finds Little Support for Michael Bloomberg
abstract: A Bloomberg-sponsored poll delivered some sour news about Michael R. Bloomberg himself: Few Iowa voters like him as he weighs a third party White House run.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – A Bloomberg-sponsored poll, made public in extravagant Bloomberg style amid shrimp and champagne, delivered some sour news about Michael R. Bloomberg himself: Few Iowa voters like him as he weighs a third party White House run.

abstract: A rally and concert at the University of Iowa raises awareness, and the roof.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders held a rally and concert at the University of Iowa tonight with thousands of students, whom he urged to vote for him on Monday and “make the pundits look dumb.”

headline: From Hillary Clinton, a Single Message Told Across the Decades
abstract: A rebuke to those who say that Senator Bernie Sanders is unswerving in his political stands, or that the former first lady adjusts hers to suit the moment.

headline: Tax Scams Are Targeting Uninsured, I.R.S. Warns
keywords: ['Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Income Tax']
abstract: In some cases, the agency said, unscrupulous tax preparers tell clients to pay the penalties for not having health insurance directly to them, and then keep the money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service is warning consumers about tax scams involving the Affordable Care Act and penalties imposed under the law on people who go without health insurance.

headline: Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz, Influential Reform Theologian, Dies at 91
abstract: Rabbi Borowitz argued that a balance must be struck between the modern desire for independently shaping a person’s religious ideas and a more traditional vision of a commanding God.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz, a leading theologian of Reform Judaism who argued that the modern emphasis on reason and self-imposed ethics needed the undergirding of what he called a covenantal relationship with God, died on Jan. 22 at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 91.

headline: Iowa Anomaly: A Town Ignored by Candidates
abstract: In a state where many have taken to grousing about the attention showered on them by candidates, Eagle Grove has a different complaint.
lead_paragraph: EAGLE GROVE, Iowa — There is a high school auditorium here that could fit 200 people, give or take. Some wood-paneled furniture stores, a pharmacy, a three-garage firehouse and a popular deli dot downtown, looking like a postcard from America’s heartland, if not its heart.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz on Healthcare
abstract: Hillary Clinton staked out her position as the lone defender of the Affordable Care Act on Saturday night, warning that her Democratic rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, would scrap it and start over and that Republicans would hand healthcare back to insurers and drug-makers.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Making her final push before the Iowa caucuses, Hillary Clinton staked out her position as the lone defender of the Affordable Care Act on Saturday night, warning that her Democratic rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, would scrap it and start over and that Republicans would hand healthcare back to insurers and drug-makers.

headline: ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Sweeps Top Awards at the Sundance Film Festival
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: You can stream a Shia LaBeouf movie. Elsewhere, Vice reports on the battle against the Islamic State, and “60 Minutes” looks at money laundering.
lead_paragraph: Shia LaBeouf showed all of his movies at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan in November. You can stream one of them. Elsewhere, Vice reports on the battle against the Islamic State, and “60 Minutes” investigates the increasing popularity of the United States as a place for corrupt officials and foreigners to stash money. And the search for Bigfoot trudges onward.

keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Officials were far apart on Sunday over a trans-Atlantic pact that international companies must rely on to move digital data between the regions.
lead_paragraph: American and European officials failed on Sunday to reach an agreement over how digital data — including financial information and social media posts — could be transferred between the two regions.

headline: Terror Threats Thaw Budgets Across Europe
abstract: Europe is greatly increasing military and security spending on the fight against terrorism, a shift from the austerity mantra that has dominated its policies in recent years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A phalanx of soldiers wearing bulletproof vests and wielding machine guns fanned out beneath the Eiffel Tower on a recent afternoon, scanning the crowd for potential terrorist threats. Across the country, nearly 10,000 more armed troops patrolled streets around landmarks, stores and government buildings.

headline: 1891: Ernest Meissonier Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Ernest Meissonier, a celebrated French painter, dies in 1891.
lead_paragraph: Meissonier is dead. The news spread throughout Paris yesterday as only sad tidings can. Most people had heard that this greatest of living painters — as he was until yesterday morning — was in ill-health, and had indeed been forced to resign the presidency of the National Society of Fine Arts in consequence.

headline: In Iowa, Voters on the Edges May Set Tone for Primaries
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Voters on the ideological edges, who dominate both parties in Iowa, have made Senator Bernie Sanders, Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz the standard-bearers of the left and the right.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Iowa, widely derided for being unlike the rest of the United States, was supposed to be irrelevant this year as the presidential race became nationalized — thanks to widely viewed televised debates and the rise of social media.

headline: Why the Iowa Caucuses Loom So Large
abstract: Iowa is overrun by presidential candidates and the media following them. The New York Times reporter Trip Gabriel explains why such a small state has such an outsize significance.
lead_paragraph: Iowa is overrun by presidential candidates and the media following them. The New York Times reporter Trip Gabriel explains why such a small state has such an outsize significance.

headline: Novak Djokovic Wins Sixth Australian Open to Tie Record
abstract: With a straight-sets win over Andy Murray, Djokovic matched Roy Emerson for the most men’s titles in Melbourne and moved into a tie for fifth on the career list for major singles titles with 11.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Grand Slam was there for the taking in September in New York, and although Serena Williams faltered there and then faltered in the final in Melbourne on Saturday, a Grand Slam is still very much on the table.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Quiet Support Will Carry Iowa, Ex-Governor Predicts
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Coming of Age, Whether They Like It or Not
abstract: With a ritual like a bar mitzvah, kids learn to take on something that is extraordinarily hard, something that takes persistence and focus.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before my son’s bar mitzvah last fall, I purchased some Arnold Palmer lemonade/iced tea in what we call “the Man Jug.” It was part of a ritual created by my older son, Charlie, when he came home from his bar mitzvah service, chug-a-lugged the tea straight from the bottle, and proclaimed, “I’m a man, I can drink from the Man Jug.” His little brother, Theo, wasn’t going to miss this opportunity for himself.

headline: 1966: Belgian Miners Killed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Miners on strike are shot by the police in Belgium in 1966.
lead_paragraph: HASSELT, Belgium — Two coal miners were killed and dozens wounded in a violent daylong clash with state police in Waterschei near here today [Jan. 31]. The first was killed by a bullet in the stomach as police stood off attacking miners, police said. The second was killed when police counterattacked.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: Polls Point to Donald Trump, as Do Odd Indicators

Trump and Hillary Clinton with small leads.

headline: For Victims, an Overloaded Court System Brings Pain and Delays

headline: Syria Peace Talks Inch Ahead as Bombings Near Damascus Continue
abstract: Islamic State social media accounts said the group was responsible for the attack, which came as opposing sides of the Syrian conflict were gathered in Geneva for talks.

headline: Far From Home, Djokovic Is a Favorite Son
abstract: Serbian fans once again came out in force to cheer on Novak Djokovic in the Australian Open title, with many arriving four and a half hours before the first point.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Novak Djokovic was trying to explain to the television studio hosts how he had managed to tie two Australian legends with his 6-1, 7-5, 7-6 (3) victory over Andy Murray in the Australian Open final Sunday. But he could not hear himself think.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says Tax Plan Would Not Hurt Democrats’ 2016 Prospects

lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was asked on “Meet the Press” on Sunday whether his health care plan, which would raise taxes to pay for more government benefits, would create a problem for House Democrats running for re-election in 2016.

headline: How Donald Trump Tried to Protect His Name From Others Who Shared It
abstract: Donald J. Trump once sued two real estate developers, Jules and Eddie Trump, claiming their use of the surname was “designed to reap the benefits” of his.
lead_paragraph: “Bygones are bygones,” Jules Trump said, looking back on a legal skirmish that involved nothing more than what’s in a name: his name, or, specifically, the Trump Organization (Donald J. Trump) and the Trump Group (Jules Trump and his brother, Eddie).

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign Says It Raised $20 Million in January
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s campaign will announce that it has raised $20 million in the last month, an enormous haul that backs up the campaign’s assertion that it will have enough money for a long, hard fought nominating fight against Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the Iowa caucuses, Bernie Sanders’s campaign said Sunday is has already raised $20 million this month, an enormous haul that backs up the campaign’s assertion that it will have enough money for a long, hard-fought nominating fight against Hillary Clinton.

headline: Hillary Clinton Campaign Declined Bill de Blasio’s First Offer to Help in Iowa
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s team declined Mayor Bill de Blasio’s initial offer to campaign in Iowa for her candidacy, the New York City mayor said.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Hillary Clinton’s team declined Mayor Bill de Blasio’s initial offer to campaign in Iowa for her candidacy, the mayor said in an interview here on Sunday morning.

headline: Choice to Conduct Independent Tennis Review Has Ties to the Sport
abstract: Adam Lewis, a London-based lawyer selected to scrutinize the sport’s internal integrity unit, has close ties to tennis and has divided experts in sports law, some of whom think he was the wrong pick.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — At the announcement of an independent review into the tennis anticorruption program on Wednesday, Chris Kermode, chairman of the Association of Tennis Professionals, pledged that tennis would do more than a hollow internal inquiry.

headline: Barclays and Credit Suisse to Settle ‘Dark Pool’ Inquiries
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: The two banks will pay a combined $154.3 million to settle allegations that they misrepresented their private stock trading services.
lead_paragraph: Barclays and Credit Suisse will pay a combined $154.3 million to settle allegations that they misrepresented their private stock trading services.  The systems, known as dark pools, are supposed to offer a haven to traditional traders and investors from predatory trading behavior.

headline: Review: ‘Impractical Jokers’ Is Played for Laughs Live at Radio City
abstract: The four comics who star in the “Impractical Jokers” television show on TruTV performed live at Radio City Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: “Impractical Jokers” is just dumb fun, but what do you expect from a prank show in which loud comics accost strangers on the streets?

headline: ‘Kung Fu Panda 3’ is No. 1
abstract: Though the film took in roughly $41 million, that total was a big decline for the series.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood had a bumpy weekend. In its first three days of release, DreamWorks Animation’s high-stakes “Kung Fu Panda 3” may have left money on the table at home in search of riches abroad. “The Finest Hours,” yet another ocean disaster movie, failed to attract an initial audience big enough to justify its cost. And tumbleweeds blew through theaters playing “Jane Got a Gun,” produced by and starring Natalie Portman.

headline: O.J. Simpson Drama Depicts an Old Trial, and Renewed Tensions
abstract: The cable network FX is betting that its 10-episode drama about O.J. Simpson’s trial will resonate with viewers much as the real trial did 21 years ago.
lead_paragraph: For the last two decades, O. J. has been on ice.

headline: Email Issue Dogs Hillary Clinton on Eve of Iowa Caucuses
abstract: On the eve of the Iowa caucuses, Hillary Clinton found herself defending her use of a private email server while serving as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: This is not what Hillary Clinton wanted to discuss the morning before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Donald Trump Field Organizer Accuses Campaign of Sex Discrimination
abstract: Elizabeth Mae Davidson, 26, the Trump campaign’s former field organizer in Davenport, Iowa, said that men in the same job were paid more than women.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Iowa — A former paid organizer for Donald J. Trump who was fired this month has accused his presidential campaign of sex discrimination.

headline: Trying to Separate Bill Cosby From Cliff Huxtable
abstract: For Times reporter Rachel L. Swarns, “The Cosby Show” aired at a pivotal time. She never met Bill Cosby, but she knew a lot of Cliff Huxtables.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby looked haggard and old as he stumbled on his way to the courthouse. And when his mug shot flashed across my screen, I felt a sharp stab of grief.

headline: Palestinian Officer Is Killed After Attacking Three Israeli Soldiers
abstract: A Palestinian policeman shot three Israeli soldiers, seriously wounding two, at a West Bank checkpoint.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian policeman shot three Israeli soldiers, seriously wounding two, at a West Bank checkpoint on Sunday before being killed by soldiers, the Israeli military said.

headline: Battered by War, Iraq Now Faces Calamity From Dropping Oil Prices
abstract: The country depends on oil for 90 percent of its revenue. Now, it faces crippling budget cuts and increasing difficulty paying government workers.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqis seeking to withdraw money from banks are told there is not enough cash. Hospitals in Baghdad are falling back to the deprivation of the 1990s sanctions era, resterilizing, over and over, needles and other medical products meant for one-time use.

headline: Restored Williamsburg Bell to Be Celebrated
abstract: The bell from one of the oldest black churches in America will be celebrated on Monday by Dionne Warwick and Danny Glover.
lead_paragraph: Dionne Warwick, Esperanza Spalding and Danny Glover will be among the performers on hand Monday night at a gala concert honoring the restoration of the bell at the First Baptist Church in Williamsburg, Va., founded in 1776 by slaves and one of the oldest black churches in America.

headline: The Rev. John Romas, Leader of Greek Church at Ground Zero, Dies at 86
abstract: Father Romas was appointed pastor of St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in 1987, and took his small congregation to Brooklyn after the church was destroyed during the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: After St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Lower Manhattan was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001, by the collapse of the World Trade Center nearby, the Rev. John D. Romas held his small congregation together as its worship services moved to Brooklyn and instilled in his parishioners the hope that they would live to see their church rebuilt. He, however, did not.

headline: Israel Approves Prayer Space at Western Wall for Non-Orthodox Jews
abstract: The decision by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s cabinet was seen as a victory for American Jewish leaders and Jewish women who struggled for years for inclusion.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After years of rancor over rituals at the Western Wall, one of the holiest sites in Judaism, the Israeli government on Sunday approved the creation of an upgraded egalitarian prayer space there for non-Orthodox Jews.

headline: More Democratic Debates in the Works
abstract: A debate on Thursday, ahead of the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 9, is expected to be sanctioned and sponsored by MSNBC, and the campaigns have been in talks about holding additional debates in March, April and May.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidates have asked for more debates, and it appears they are going to get their wish.

headline: How Moon Dust Languished in a Downing Street Cupboard
abstract: The moon dust’s fate was revealed by Britain’s National Archives, which released 178 pages of correspondence on the subject going back 30 years.
lead_paragraph: It was a space problem of sorts for the new British prime minister: where to put the minuscule sample of the lunar dust that America’s Apollo 11 astronauts had scooped from the surface of the moon in their giant leap for mankind?

headline: As Family Helped Build Betting System, It Witnessed Horse Racing History
abstract: Pat Mahony, whose father and grandfather helped develop parimutuel wagering in the United States, has retired from his job at Aqueduct.
lead_paragraph: Late Sunday afternoon, when the tote board went dark after the final race of the day at Aqueduct Racetrack, Pat Mahony called it a career, one he has cherished and one that has been part of his family history for more than a century. Like his father and grandfather before him, Mahony is a mutuels man.

headline: In Iran, New Battle Brews Over Contracts With Foreign Oil Giants
abstract: The battle is threatening to complicate government efforts to attract desperately needed foreign investment, two weeks after the lifting of sanctions.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A political battle is taking shape in Iran over any new foreign role in developing the country’s enormous oil wealth, only a few weeks after the Iranian nuclear deal with foreign powers relaxed tough economic sanctions.

headline: Pre-Iowa Notes
abstract: Different kinds of enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know what will happen in the caucuses tomorrow. Actually, I know what will happen on the Republican side: someone horrifying will come in first, and someone horrifying will come in second. The names are less clear.

headline: Twisting Inquiry Into Buenos Aires Bombing Takes New Turn
abstract: Argentina’s new government has vowed to get to the bottom of a 1994 attack on a Jewish center that killed 85 people and led to a lasting rift with Iran.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — For more than two decades, an investigation into the suicide bombing of a Jewish center here in 1994 that killed 85 people has faced setbacks and controversy. It caused an intractable rift between Argentina and Iran. A former president has been put on trial, accused of orchestrating a cover-up. And a prosecutor involved in the case died last year in murky circumstances.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Bush Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Campaign Finance', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Only a year ago, he was a favorite to clinch the Republican nomination. But as Iowa voters prepare for their caucuses, he barely registers in the polls.
lead_paragraph: The biggest stories of this young political year are the surprising surges of the outsider presidential candidates Donald J. Trump and Bernie Sanders, the Democratic senator from Vermont. Close behind is the possible collapse of the once-formidable front-runner, Jeb Bush.

headline: Review: ‘Quicksand,’ Robert Ashley’s Enigmatic Spy-Thriller Opera
abstract: Published in 2011 as a libretto evoking the spy novels Mr. Ashley adored, the work has finally received its world premiere at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Robert Ashley is no longer with us, but his voice — calm, mellow, reassuring, quizzical, amused, earnest — lives on. Surrounded by a shifting, unstable electronic haze, it is the only thing you hear at the Kitchen during “Quicksand,” the opera that he wrote in the final years before his death, at 83, in 2014.

headline: Facebook’s Sensible Ban on Gun Ads
abstract: With Congress refusing to close a background check loophole that allows felons to buy guns, Facebook will stop users from placing ads to sell guns.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s decision last week to prohibit private gun sales on its social networking site and on its photo-sharing app Instagram should make it harder for convicted felons and other dangerous people to acquire deadly weapons. That’s a very good thing, especially considering the unwillingness of lawmakers in Congress to enact sensible gun safety policies.

headline: Jaap van Zweden, Philharmonic’s Maestro-to-Be, Sharpens His Baton
abstract: The Dutch-born conductor, who starts leading the New York Philharmonic in 2018, is known for old-school directness and a relentless drive for quality.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — It was the morning after he had been named the next music director of the New York Philharmonic, and Jaap van Zweden was already back at work here at his current job, rehearsing the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in Mozart’s Symphony No. 39 with the fastidiousness — and relentlessness — for which he has become known.

headline: Boko Haram Burns Villages in Northeastern Nigeria
abstract: At least 50 people, including children, were killed by gunmen and suicide bombers in a series of raids on villages outside the city of Maiduguri, officials said.
lead_paragraph: KADUNA, Nigeria — More than 50 people were killed in a series of raids on villages in northeastern Nigeria that officials say was the work of the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram.

headline: Review: ‘Quicksand,’ Driven by the Rhythm of Words, Light and Bodies
abstract: Steve Paxton is the choreographic force behind this 2011 Robert Ashley mystery story opera, now at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Told from the point of view of a wry, vodka-swilling composer and freelance spy, Robert Ashley’s “Quicksand,” a 2011 opera written as a novel, anticipates action from the start: “I’m sitting on the bathroom floor, leaning back against the sink. I have the gun in my hands.”

headline: Review: ‘The Grand Paradise’ Summons a ’70s Pleasure Palace
abstract: This immersive play conjures a Florida resort built on nostalgia and losing one’s inhibitions.
lead_paragraph: I had barely arrived for my tropical holiday in Brooklyn before I was deflowered. Yes, my lei, which had been hung welcomingly around my neck when I entered the resort called the Grand Paradise, was taken from me (gently) by a vulpine blonde in a pink satin bathing suit and pearls.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 1
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Jordi Savall and Juilliard415 Perform in ‘Shakespeare and Cervantes’
abstract: The Spanish early-music specialist Mr. Savall and the student orchestra performed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Cervantes and Shakespeare died 400 years ago, though not on the same day, as many continue to maintain. For Cervantes, the date on his tombstone — April 23, 1616 — may refer to his burial, and for Shakespeare, the same date was based on the Julian calendar; by the modern Gregorian calendar, it is May 3.

headline: Cartoonist Is Arrested as Egypt Cracks Down on Critics
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Social Media']
abstract: The arrest of the cartoonist Islam Gawish escalated a crackdown by the government on even moderate forms of dissent.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A popular Egyptian cartoonist was arrested Sunday on charges of running a website without a license, the Interior Ministry said, in the latest escalation of a campaign to silence the government’s online critics.

headline: A Word With Spike Lee: ‘They Want to Rewind the Clock’
abstract: The timing of Mr. Lee’s latest film, “Chi-Raq,” has again made him a go-to source on issues like diversity and gun control.
lead_paragraph: In his latest feature, “Chi-Raq,” Spike Lee tells the story of the epidemic of gun violence in Chicago through the eyes of a gangster’s girlfriend, who persuades women to withhold sex until their menfolk disavow firearms. During production last summer, the film made headlines when the city’s mayor, Rahm Emanuel, criticized the title, which borrowed a nickname Chicagoans had coined for their town’s violent turn.

headline: Simile and Metaphor as Critique: Jaap van Zweden Speaks to an Ensemble
abstract: The future conductor of the New York Philharmonic has a knack for analogies when he rehearses with the Dallas Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Jaap van Zweden, who will become the music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2018, is known for his intense, demanding rehearsals. Drilling his current ensemble, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, in a Mozart symphony last week, he used a battery of tools to coax out the sounds he sought: singing out phrases in his pure tenor voice, giving precise technical instructions, and, quite often, venturing into analogies.

headline: Trump or Cruz? Clinton or Sanders? Iowa Hears Last-Minute Pitches
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: With the caucuses fast approaching, the campaigns are activating the final stage of their ground games in hopes of a strong showing.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — They have munched on pork chops in the heat of summer and hunted game in the dead of winter. Spouses and children have been dispatched as surrogates across the plains. But with the caucuses on Monday hours away, the presidential candidates are leaving nothing to chance, furiously crisscrossing Iowa and making direct appeals to voters to stand for them in the election’s first nominating contest.

headline: Review: In ‘No Más Bebés,’ Forced Sterilizations at an American Hospital
abstract: Renee Tajima-Peña’s documentary, now on PBS, focuses on a 1975 lawsuit brought by 10 Hispanic women against Los Angeles County–U.S.C. Medical Center.
lead_paragraph: Outrage may be America’s leading source of energy right now, and it seems endlessly renewable. “No Más Bebés” adds to the supply but in an understated, melancholy way that leaves you more sad than angry.

headline: For the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra, Monday Becomes an All-Week Affair
abstract: The Village Vanguard honors its namesake band, started by Thad Jones and Mel Lewis in 1966, with a weeklong engagement.
lead_paragraph: The Vanguard Jazz Orchestra opened its first set at the Village Vanguard on a recent Monday night with a familiar blend of purring saxophones and punchy brass, carving up “Big Dipper” just as it had in its first performance in the same room almost exactly 50 years ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Maria Stuarda,’ Sondra Radvanovsky Makes a Vivid Impact
abstract: The soprano shines in the second of Donizetti’s three Tudor queens she will portray this season at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: When an announcement is made that a singer is sick but will perform anyway, listener sympathy is sought for any potential flaws. But there was no evidence that Sondra Radvanovsky had a cold, as had been indicated, during her magnificent rendering of the title role of Donizetti’s “Maria Stuarda” on Friday evening, when David McVicar’s production returned to the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Review: ‘Ostend: Stefan Zweig, Joseph Roth, and the Summer Before the Dark’ Revisits Moments in Exile
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: Volker Weidermann’s book recounts how the two writers found themselves in limbo in a Belgian beach town with other intellectuals after fleeing the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, most American readers had never heard of Stefan Zweig, even though he was one of Europe’s most popular authors — every bit as famous as Thomas Mann, certainly — at the sunny peak of his career.

headline: Four-Baggers
abstract: The return of Gary Cee.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of the things I like about Gary Cee’s crosswords is the nod to his profession as a radio D.J. and program director in most of, if not all, of his puzzles. He opens his puzzle today at 1 Across with AM/FM.

headline: Review: In ‘Saala Khadoos,’ a Female Boxer Rises From the Streets in India
abstract: With a rawness that dovetails with the role, the newcomer Ritika Singh stars in this Bollywood film, with her coach played by the seasoned R. Madhavan.
lead_paragraph: You know the story or one like it: Underdog boxer from the mean streets is taken up by a coach, himself in need of redemption. Together, this scruffy pair hope to make it to the big championship.

headline: Man Slashed in Face After Argument on Harlem Subway Platform
abstract: The 27-year-old man was attacked at 110th Street and Lenox Avenue, in an episode that joined a spate of slashings that have put New York City on edge over the past month.
lead_paragraph: A man was slashed in the face as he stood on the subway platform at 110th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem early on Sunday, after getting into an argument with a woman he did not know, the police said.

headline: John Kasich Relishes Attacks From Jeb Bush Backers in Iowa
abstract: Mr. Kasich seemed surprised, if not delighted, at attacks from Right to Rise, the ‘super PAC’ supporting Jeb Bush, saying it was “fantastic” to be viewed as an encroaching rival in Iowa, where neither candidate is faring well in polls.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, N.H. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and his team have complained — and complained — about the attacks the outside group supporting Jeb Bush has lobbed their way.

headline: Condé Nast Adapts to New Forces, Leaving Some Employees Unsettled
keywords: ['Magazines', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Anna Wintour, Condé Nast’s artistic director, and Bob Sauerberg, its new chief executive, are trying to keep the publisher’s many magazines profitable and relevant in the Internet age.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Anna Wintour, David Remnick and Graydon Carter went to see S. I. Newhouse Jr., the man who turned Condé Nast into a gilded publishing empire and who handpicked them to lead its flagship magazines.

headline: Microsoft Plumbs Ocean’s Depths to Test Underwater Data Center
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Data Centers', 'Cloud Computing', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Microsoft sank a data center on the ocean floor, where the sea water acts as a coolant, and plans to use the waves to power it. The results were encouraging enough to try a bigger version.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Taking a page from Jules Verne, researchers at Microsoft believe the future of data centers may be under the sea.

headline: Two Virginia Tech Students Arrested in Girl’s Death
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: David Eisenhauer, a freshman charged with abduction and murder, knew the victim, who had been missing since Wednesday, according to investigators.
lead_paragraph: Two Virginia Tech students were arrested over the weekend in connection with the abduction and death of a 13-year-old girl whose remains were found on Saturday, school and law enforcement officials said.

headline: Theater Flashback: ‘Grease’ on Broadway
abstract: A time-capsule look at how the show as marketed after it first opened on Broadway in 1972.
lead_paragraph: That hair! Their gum! Those songs!

headline: Swedish Police Foiled Planned Attack on Immigrants in Stockholm
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Assaults', 'Gangs', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: When scores of masked men, many of them gang members, descended on the center of Stockholm on Friday to terrorize young migrants, the police were waiting for them.
lead_paragraph: HALMSTAD, Sweden — Scores of masked men dressed in black, some carrying wooden weapons, descended on the center of Stockholm, gathering near the entrance to the city’s main subway station.
